                    MOSFETs Featuring an N-ion Implanted Gate Shielding Layer
authors: Ruoshi Peng, Mingzhe Li, Shaodong Xu, Jun Yuan, Qiangmin Wei, Qichao Ding, Rui Jin, Zheyang Li, Le Yu, Jiahui Wang, Rong Zhang, Guoqing Xin, Zhiqiang Wang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: The $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ field-effect transistor (FET) fully meets the industrial demands for green development and energy efficiency. Among various device architectures, the development of vertical enhancement-mode (E -mode) Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> FETs is considered essential for practical applications. This paper presents novel current aperture vertical metal-oxidesemiconductor FETs (MOSFETs) fabricated using N -ion implantation to form a current blocking layer (CBL) and a gate electric field shielding structure, followed by Si -ion implantation to create a conductive channel. Although the breakdown voltage is currently limited to 150 V and the threshold voltage exceeds 20 V due to suboptimal dimensions of the conductive channel and channel length, this structure eliminates the need for heterogenous p-type materials and maintains a planar architecture.

title: Towards Distributed Resource Coordination in Distribution Networks with SOPs and Topology Reconfiguration
authors: Jie Song, Yi Wu, Chenggang Mu, Tao Ding, Zhuopu Han, Wenhao Jia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: This paper investigates the distributed operational optimization of interconnected distribution networks featuring reconfigurable topologies and soft open points (SOPs). A unified modeling framework is established that integrates the operational characteristics of distributed generation (DG), energy storage systems (ESS), and topology reconfiguration constraints, while capturing inter-area coupling via SOPs. To ensure network connectivity and radiality, a virtual power flow (VPF)-based modeling method is adopted. Furthermore, a distributed optimization algorithm based on the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) is proposed to support distributed coordination among multiple areas, ensuring data privacy and computational scalability. Simulation studies on interconnected IEEE 33-bus systems demonstrate the proposed model's effectiveness in reducing operation costs, enhancing voltage regulation, and enabling inter-regional energy sharing. The results validate the synergy between SOP-based interaction and topology flexibility in future smart distribution networks.

title: Enhanced Pneumonia Diagnosis using Mask R-CNN and ResNet50-Based Deep Learning on Chest X-Rays
authors: Girija Rani G, M. Usha Rani
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This study proposes a robust and efficient two-stage deep learning framework aimed at the accurate classification of Chest X-ray images into NORMAL and PNEUMONIA categories. The methodology integrates Mask R-CNN for precise segmentation of lung regions, followed by a fine-tuned RestNet50 model for binary classification. B y e ffectively is olating lung areas, Mask R-CNN enhances the relevance of extracted features, thereby improving diagnostic performance. On the original imbalanced dataset, the framework achieved a classification accuracy of 90.71%. Upon the incorporation of data augmentation techniques to address class imbalance, the performance significantly improved, reaching an accuracy of 95.26%. These results underscore the critical role of data balancing in enhanced model generalization and reliability. This research highlights the synergistic benefit of combining of instance segmentation with deep classification networks for superior pneumonia detection in chest radiographs. The integration of segmentation enables the model to focus on diagnostically relevant regions, thus boosting the efficacy of fe ature ex traction an d classification. Future research will investigate the inclusion of clinical metadata (e.g.: age, symptoms, comorbidities) to further personalize and refine diagnostics accuracy. This advancement holds potential for facilitating the deployment of AI-assisted diagnostic tools in the real world clinical settings, ultimately contributing to timely and reliable medical decision making.

title: Optimization of Thermal Field for Large Scale SiC Growth with Resistance Heating Method
authors: Peng Liu, Wancheng Yu, Ning Zhang, Xiying Zhang, Wenhao Han, Xiufang Chen, Lihuan Wang, Xiaobo Hu, Xiangang Xu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) is critical for next-generation power and radio frequency devices due to its superior electro-thermal properties, yet thermal management complexities escalate exponentially as boule diameters scale toward 8-12 inches. Resistance heating emerges as a promising solution for largediameter crystal growth owing to its precise thermal field control. This study employs multi-physics finite element analysis to optimize thermal configurations in resistive heating systems. By introducing a graphite baffle between dual heaters, we demonstrate that extending baffle length can enhance axial thermal gradients by 2 times while radial temperature variation reduce to $90 \%$. These controlled gradients enhance the crystal growth rate and reduce thermal stress. The modified thermal design establishes a costefficient approach for mass production of high-quality largescale SiC single crystals.

title: Modern Llvm-Based Compiler Autotuning for Wcet Optimization
authors: Gabriele Magnani, Davide Baroffio, Federico Reghenzani, Giovanni Agosta, William Fornaciari
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: The problem of compiler optimization selection and ordering, known in the literature as compiler autotuning, has been tackled many times for average-case execution time reduction. Optimizing the WCET is becoming a prominent problem for modern hard real-time systems, where the difficulties in accurate WCET estimation hinder the full exploitation of computing platform capabilities. In this article, we propose a novel methodology and a tool based on LLVM for iterative WCET-driven compiler autotuning, which is the first strategy to operate at function-level granularity and to consider not only the selection of optimization passes, but also their ordering. Our findings show that standard optimization levels <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{O} 0, \mathrm{O} 1, \mathrm{O} 2$</tex>, and O 3 are suboptimal when targeting the WCET, and that a per-function selection and ordering of the transformations is necessary. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms the standard optimizations and opens up new directions for future research.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Smart Health Monitoring with Anomaly Detection and Severity Analysis
authors: Hemaprabha. G, Priya. V. S, Ajeyprasaath K B, Prabu S, Krishna Kumba, G Manikandaraja
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Smart health monitoring systems have transformed healthcare, but fall detection and severity assessment inaccuracies accompany most available models. This paper enhances accuracy and credibility by introducing a Smart Health Monitoring System with Machine Learning-based Fall Detection and Severity Assessment using multiple sensors and a hybrid machine learning model. The system employs GPS, GSM modules, accelerometers, heart rate, and Spo2 sensors for real-time health monitoring. The approach enables prioritisation of critical conditions by separating falls from regular activity and evaluating severity based on physiological changes by monitoring multi-sensor data. Live location tracking also enables real-time sending of emergency alerts, which reduces response times and enhances patient safety. Early intervention of the likely health issue is enabled by combining the system with anomaly detection and past health trends. The system allows for a 91.9 % rate of anomaly detection accuracy, reducing false alarms by 30 % compared to available thresholdbased approaches. The emergency response time is also reduced by 40 %, making it an extremely cost-effective and reliable approach for real-time health monitoring.

title: Economic Feasibility of Power Generation by Integrating Floating Photovoltaics on Sea and Small Wind Turbines at Samui Island in Southern Thailand
authors: Kittisak Chaisuwan, Arkom Palamanit, Sakda Somkun
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This study aims to evaluate the economic feasibility of power generation by integrating floating photovoltaics (FPV) on the sea with small wind turbines in Koh Samui, Surat Thani Province, a well-known tourist destination in southern Thailand. The island typically experiences high electricity demand, with a peak of approximately 104 MW and a monthly energy consumption of about 60.5 GWh. Currently, this energy is supplied from the mainland via an underwater transmission system. Given that Koh Samui is surrounded by the sea, it presents an opportunity to install FPV systems and wind turbines. Based on local weather data, the potential area for FPV installation is approximately 900 square kilometers, with an estimated annual energy output of 142.02 MWh. This system could reduce <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions by about 49.7 tons per year. Economic evaluation using internal rate of return (IRR) equal to 6.98 % and levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) equal to 2.32 THB/kWh indicates that the investment is financially viable. Future studies should also assess the social and environmental impacts, considering the island's importance as a major tourist destination in Thailand.

title: Named Entity Recognition Approaches for Multihop Reasoning based Clinical Question Answering Systems
authors: Pranav Salunkhe, Aditya Prakash, Sowmya Kamath S.
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Managing clinical data in EHR systems is challenging due to scattered and fragmented information, requiring significant manual effort to compile and extract meaningful insights. In a Question Answering System, complex clinical queries often necessitate multihop reasoning across multiple data tables and contexts to retrieve accurate answers. To enable effective multihop reasoning, the first step is to identify and extract relevant tables that contribute to generating a precise response to a given user query. However, existing approaches lack a dedicated framework for MIMIC-specific table name extraction. Traditional models do not inherently support identifying relevant table names such as "DIABETES" and "PRESCRIPTION" based on a query, nor do they establish appropriate links between extracted entities and corresponding database tables. To overcome these limitations, we propose three entity extraction workflows leveraging semantic similarity calculations, LLM-boosted mapping, and table-based matching techniques, ensuring improved accuracy in retrieving structured clinical information. Experiments were conducted using the MIMIC-III dataset to evaluate the performance of these workflows. The semantic similarity approach achieved a high recall of 0.93, indicating its effectiveness in retrieving relevant tables, while the LLM-boosted mapping showed a precision of 0.64, demonstrating its accuracy in identifying correct tables. These results highlight the potential of the proposed techniques to enhance clinical question answering systems.

title: Cyberattack Detection in Multi-Agent System
authors: Rawaa Dkhil, Boumedyen Boussaid, Ahmed Zouinkhi, Mohamed Djemai
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the secure consensus problem for multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) linear multi-agent systems (MASs) under false data injection (FDI) attacks, where an adversary corrupts the output measurements exchanged among agents. To mitigate the effect of such attacks, we design an unknown input observer (UIO) that relies only on relative output information and reconstructs the consensus error while filtering out the injected malicious signals. On the basis of the proposed observer, we design a robust consensus control law. By employing a common Lyapunov function (CLF) together with linear matrix inequality (LMI) techniques, we establish sufficient stability conditions ensuring that consensus among agents is preserved even when false data injection (FDI) attacks occur, provided certain observability and robustness conditions are met.

title: Forecasting Temperature Patterns using LSTM for Enhanced Agricultural Decision-Making
authors: Geetha G, Swaminathan J N, Jagadeesh A
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Agriculture that makes use of modern innovations to optimize farming operations with the goal of increasing crop yields and maximizing resource efficiency h as become k nown as precision agriculture. A precision farming model is presented in this work, with the primary focus being on the forecasting of temperature trends to assist in agricultural decision-making. The model obtains a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 1.9393 and a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 1.5011, which indicates that it has a good level of predicting accuracy. This model assists farmers in making intelligent choices concerning agricultural operations and resource allocation by giving accurate temperature forecasts. Temperature forecasts are provided by this model.

title: Contextual Text Analytics for Knowledge Extraction in Biomedical Device Design Education
authors: Muslima Temirova, Barnokhon Shamsiyeva, Bahodirjon Nosirov, Nilufarkhon Murkhanova, Khusniddin Milinorov, Dildor Eshmuratova, Zafar Adilov
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Contextual Text Analytics for Knowledge Extraction in Biomedical Device Design Education addresses the growing need to efficiently process vast amounts of unstructured textual data generated during education and research. Traditional manual methods struggle to extract meaningful information from complex biomedical design documents, student feedback, and literature, causing delays in curriculum improvement and innovation. To tackle this, the paper proposes a novel framework termed Contextual Biomedical Text Analytics (CBTA) that integrates natural language processing (NLP) techniques with domain-specific ontologies to enhance contextawareness in text processing. CBTA leverages semantic embedding, named entity recognition, and topic modeling to extract relevant knowledge, trends, and competency indicators from diverse textual datasets. Experimental validation on biomedical device design course materials demonstrates CBTA's enhanced ability to identify key concepts, design challenges, and learning gaps, outperforming baseline text mining techniques by 18% in precision and 15% in recall. The results indicate that CBTA facilitates actionable insights for educators, enabling targeted curriculum updates and personalized learning paths. In conclusion, CBTA presents an intelligent, scalable solution for advancing biomedical device design education through data-driven knowledge extraction, supporting both academic excellence and industry readiness.

title: Design and Implementation of Auto - Chagre in Electric Vehicle
authors: Gokulraj K G, Tharani B, Sundar G, Sountharya D, Theepasri S, Karthikeyan R
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This paper presents the operational workflow of an electric vehicle system designed for efficient and sustainable mobility. The process begins with charging the lithium-ion battery through an external charger. The stored voltage is directed to a controller, which regulates power flow based on vehicle speed. The speed is managed via a throttle, and corresponding voltage is supplied to the hub motor to drive the vehicle. An innovative feature includes dual battery packs: while one powers the motor, the second is charged during travel using regenerative input from other motors. If the primary battery depletes, the system automatically switches to the backup, ensuring uninterrupted operation. This dual-battery design enhances reliability, efficiency, and range, making electric vehicle a practical solution for urban transportation.

title: Intelligent Battery Sensor Fault Detection for Enhanced Electric Vehicle Safety
authors: Mohana Devi. S, V. Bagyaveereswaran
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Battery Management Systems (BMS) are critical to the safe and efficient operation of Lithium-Ion Batteries (LIBs) in electric vehicles (EVs). They rely on precise sensor data—particularly voltage, current, and temperature measurements—to conduct critical tasks including state estimation, defect diagnostics, and cell balancing. However, in complex and dynamic environments, sensor faults or signal anomalies can occur, potentially compromising system safety and performance. The proposed work focused on sensor fault diagnosis methods, including data-driven, model-based, and signal processing approaches. While these techniques have shown effectiveness, limitations such as sensitivity to model errors and reduced adaptability remain challenges. This paper highlights these gaps and introduces improved strategies aimed at enhancing diagnostic accuracy and robustness. By addressing sensor faults more effectively, these advancements contribute to safer battery operation and reduced risk of fire in EV applications.

title: Electrical Fault Analysis and Fault Location Prediction in Power Systems Using Generative Adversarial Networks and Deep Learning
authors: Yogesh Ramesh Patni, Nilesh Pandurang Dabe, Sunil S. Kadlag, Ashish Dandotia, Mukesh Kumar Gupta, Amit Tiwari
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Accurate fault detection and localization are critical for ensuring the stability and reliability of modern power systems. This research presents a novel approach integrating Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with deep learning models to enhance fault classification and location prediction in electrical transmission networks. The proposed framework is evaluated on an IEEE 9-bus system, where various fault scenarios-such as single line-to-ground (LG), line-to-line (LL), double line-to-ground (LLG), and three-phase to ground (LLLG) faults are simulated using MATLAB. The dataset was self-generated by introducing various symmetrical and unsymmetrical faults at different buses. It includes Voltage and current waveforms during fault and normal conditions, and corresponding labels for fault type and fault location (in kilometers), and Synthetic data generated by GANs is used to augment the training dataset, resulting in improved generalization and robustness of the classifier. Comparative analysis shows that the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model augmented with GAN-generated data achieves an accuracy of 94.5%, outperforming Artificial Neural Network (ANN) and CNN models trained on real data alone. Additionally, the location prediction module demonstrates high precision, with errors typically under 1.2 km. The results confirm the effectiveness of generative AI in addressing data scarcity and enhancing the accuracy of both fault type identification and fault location prediction, making it a promising solution for intelligent fault management in smart grids.

title: Network Monitoring for Wireless Sensor Network Using Vertex-Cover Models
authors: Yomna A. Abdou, Mohamed Abdelraheem, Amr Abdelhafez, Abdel-Rahman Hedar
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Minimum Vertex Coverage (MVC) algorithms are frequently used to identify changes and facilitate autonomous decision making in network management due to the fast growth of networks. Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) can benefit from the MVC problem in a number of ways, such as increased security, bandwidth conservation, energy conservation, grid networks, and extended network lifetime. Additionally, by scheduling various MVC sets on a regular basis, MVC algorithms improve the base station's dependability. This study suggests a new algorithm to effectively solve the MVC problem. To solve the issue in the context of WSNs, we use operations based on differential evolution. Furthermore, search enhancement techniques are used to increase search intensification and diversification. The efficacy of the proposed approach for manufacturing enhanced MVC solutions for the evaluated networks is evidenced by the outcomes of extensive simulations performed on diverse network situations.

title: Automatic Numerical Focusing Algorithm Based on Two-Dimensional Fourier Transform Spectral Analysis
authors: Ying Li, Guoqing Song, Wenlong Shao, Wanfei Ren
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: This paper proposes an automatic numerical focusing algorithm based on frequency-domain high-frequency component analysis. It addresses imaging issues caused by system limitations and defocus in digital holographic microscopy. By combining two-dimensional Fourier transform spectra with a global search strategy, the algorithm effectively overcomes twin-image interference and local extrema problems in phase object reconstruction. Experimental results show that, compared to the Roberts gradient function and the variance evaluation function, the proposed method offers superior focusing stability and accuracy across different propagation distances. It also demonstrates significant advantages in capturing high-frequency information. This research provides an effective automatic focusing solution for the reliable application of digital holographic microscopy in precision measurement and biomedical detection.

title: Meme Classification using a Multimodal Approach
authors: Namya Chandel, Shikha Mundra, Ankit Mundra
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: With the rapid growth of meme culture across social media sites, the role of memes in shaping mental health and sentiment interpretation has become a relevant research field. Nevertheless, precise categorization of the sentiment of memes has proven difficult to achieve owing to the intricate interactions between text and images. This paper delivers a comparative discussion of unimodal and multimodal methods of meme classification. The multimodal model combines ResNet101 and VGG16 for image features and BERT for textual data processing, while the unimodal models are: An image model implemented using ResNet101 and VGG16 to classify images standalone. A text model that uses BERT for text-only classification. The results from the individual models are concatenated, where the predictions from the two modalities are merged to maximize classification performance. Our findings show how the multimodal model, using ResNet101 and VGG16 for image features and BERT for text data, performs much better compared to the unimodal methods. The highest Macro F1 Score of 0.87 is achieved by the multimodal approach, an indicator of a much better performance compared to the unimodal methods. Our work demonstrates the strength of multimodal fusion for meme classification tasks and improving the performance of classification by an appreciable margin.

title: Effect of Valve Stiction on Multivariable Processes: Application to Two-Input Two-Output (TITO) Systems
authors: E Govinda Kumar, M Elenchezhiyan
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: In this paper, the authors have analyzed the effect of valve stiction on multivariable TITO process. Valve stiction is a major nonlinearity in process industries, often causing oscillations and poor control performance. The majority of research focuses on stiction detection in single-input single-output (SISO) systems, although loop interactions present extra difficulties for multivariable processes. In this work, valve stiction in a closedloop, two-input, two-output (TITO) process is examined. Three scenarios are studied: stiction in Loop 1 while Loop 2 remains linear, stiction in Loop 2 while Loop 1 remains linear, and stiction in both loops. For each scenario, the controller output (CO), manipulated variable (MV), and process variable (PV) are recorded for both loops to examine the propagation of nonlinear effects. Performance is evaluated through correlations between COs and MVs. The results show that stiction in one loop not only affects its own performance but also causes oscillations and performance degradation in the interacting loop, emphasizing the need for MIMO aware stiction diagnosis and compensation.

title: Concurrency-Aware Self-Duration and Hierarchical RCA for Deep Microservice Call Chains
authors: Tiantian Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Distributed microservice systems face challenges in root cause localization because both endogenous anomalies and propagated anomalies can appear. Under deep invocation paths, error accumulation and concurrency make misdiagnosis more likely. Existing methods often cannot separate overlapping durations, control false positive rates, or adapt to changing workloads, which reduces their use in real-time systems. This paper proposes HERALD, a hierarchical error recognition and localization framework that separates anomaly sources and keeps accuracy under complex call structures. The framework uses concurrency-aware duration estimation, cascading anomaly isolation, adaptive statistical boundaries, multi-resolution profiling, enhanced trace tree normalization, and robust impact-aware ranking. With these methods, HERALD goes beyond earlier work in separating endogenous and propagated anomalies and supports scalability and real-time performance in microservices.

title: Research on thermal management of power battery based on robust optimization and multi-objective genetic algorith
authors: Fengbin Wang, Yumeng Wang, Junyu Yi, Yongren Zhang, Dehui Ma, Hao Zhang, Meixia Lin, Yu Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: In the large-scale application of new energy vehicle industry, the performance bottleneck of battery thermal management is becoming more and more prominent - excessive temperature difference will lead to uneven distribution of thermal stress within the battery pack, accelerating structural fatigue and performance degradation, directly affecting the range and service life of the whole vehicle; and excessive pressure drop of the cooling system will significantly increase the energy consumption of the pumping and reduce the overall energy efficiency of the system, and even cause local overheating due to insufficient cooling, threatening the safety of the battery. If the cooling system pressure drop is too high, it will significantly increase the pumping energy consumption and reduce the overall energy efficiency of the system. Therefore, the simultaneous optimization of temperature difference and pressure drop is not only the key to improve the utilization of battery energy density and shorten the fast charging time, but also the core demand to ensure the reliability and economy of the battery system throughout its life cycle. Aiming at the parameter uncertainty problem commonly faced in multivariate multi-objective optimization in the engineering field, this paper focuses on the core requirements of battery thermal management system (BTMS), and innovatively proposes a multi-objective genetic algorithm for the robust optimization of internal and external cycles, which focuses on solving the synergistic balance between the temperature difference control and pressure drop optimization in BTMS. By constructing a Kriging agent model to capture the complex nonlinear relationship between the independent variables and the response, and combining the framework of internal and external double-loop robust optimization: the internal loop is based on random sampling to quantify the influence of parameter fluctuations on temperature difference and pressure drop, and the external loop adopts genetic algorithm to search for the optimal solution globally, ultimately, it achieves the balance optimization with multi-objective under uncertain environment, and provides an efficient and reliable solution for the optimization of multi-response parameters in the engineering practice. efficient and reliable solution for multi-response parameter optimization in engineering practice.

title: Power System Transient Stability Assessment Based on Semi-Supervised Graph Convolution Network
authors: Yao Wang, Zihao Li, Qingsheng Zhao, Xueting Cheng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The approach of power system transient stability assessment relying on machine learning mainly uses supervised learning. However, in practical applications, it is common to encounter difficulties in obtaining the labeled samples required by supervised learning methods, or the cost of labeling is high. In this paper, a method for power system transient stability assessment (TSA) relying on a semi-supervised graph convolutional network is proposed. First, the power system data is obtained through timedomain simulation and transformed into graph-structured data. Then, by incorporating the idea of the temporal ensembling algorithm, a semi-supervised graph convolutional network (SGCN) framework is constructed to extract features from the power system data, and the mapping relationship between the graph convolutional network (GCN) and power system transient stability is established. Finally, through the analysis and verification of the IEEE 39-bus system, the outcomes demonstrate that the devised method demonstrates good overall performance when dealing with a small number of labeled samples.

title: Bridging the Plausibility-Validity Gap by Fine-Tuning a Reasoning-Enhanced LLM for Chemical Synthesis and Discovery
authors: Malikussaid, Hilal Hudan Nuha, Isman Kurniawan
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Large Language Models frequently generate outputs that appear scientifically reasonable yet violate fundamental principles—a phenomenon we characterize as the “plausibility-validity gap.” This challenge proves especially acute in chemistry, where superficial correctness masks deeper errors in molecular structure, reaction mechanisms, and synthetic pathways. We present a systematic approach combining a reasoning-centric model architecture (Magistral Small) with Low-Rank Adaptation fine-tuning on a dual-domain dataset covering molecular properties and chemical transformations. Evaluation reveals substantial improvements: the fine-tuned system achieves 96.3 % format adherence, 97.4 % chemical validity, and 74.4 % synthesis feasibility. Comparative analysis shows our approach outperforms specialized translation models like MolT5 (97.4 % vs 77.2 % validity) while achieving performance comparable to complex tool-augmented systems like ChemCrow (9.0/10 vs 9.24/10 expert rating) through a more transparent, efficient methodology. Results demonstrate a learning hierarchy where syntactic correctness develops before chemical understanding, which precedes synthetic planning capability. This work establishes a reproducible framework for transforming generalist language models into dependable scientific tools while identifying critical areas including stereochemical precision, knowledge currency, and computational accessibility as key challenges for future advancement.

title: A Novel Method to Suppress Inter-Axis Crosstalk in Multiplexing Fiber Optic Gyroscopes for Miniaturized Inertial Navigation Systems
authors: Jiliang He, Chenyang Jiao, Chenran Wang, Haonan Ren, Xianmu Li, Bing Liu, Sicong Niu
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: This paper investigates inter-axis crosstalk in multiplexing fiber optic gyroscopes (MFOGs), focusing on residual intensity crosstalk (RIC) and spike-induced crosstalk (SIC). Through theoretical modeling and experimental test, we demonstrate that RIC originates from imperfect ± π phase modulation in idle axes, while SIC emerges from distortion of transition spikes in analog circuits. A pyramidal modulation method is proposed to suppress both effects by strategically allocating crosstalk spectra to f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>/3 (RIC) and 2f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>/3 (SIC), achieving attenuation through frequency-domain isolation. Experimental results show the method reduces drift by 1.04 °/h and improves instability by 0.017 °/h.

title: Low-Voltage 203dB High-Accuracy CMOS Exponential Function Generator
authors: Cosmin Radu Popa
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: The paper will present an original approach of an exponential function generator, developed for obtaining an extremely large output dynamic range. The new proposed method uses an original mathematical form of the approximation function, based on a combined Padé-polynomial approximation method and on an original variable changing. The utilization of CMOS current-mode computational structures for implementing the high-accuracy exponential function generator strongly increases the overall accuracy of the proposed circuit, allowing a practical independence of its operation on temperature and also on technological caused errors. The resulted output dynamic range of the new exponential function generator is approximately 203 dB, for an approximation error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1 ~\text{dB}$</tex>. The exponential function generator is designed for a low-voltage low-power operation, having a supply voltage equal with 1 V and a maximal power consumption equal with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>. The silicon occupied area is approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \mu ~\mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>. The circuit is developed for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> TSMC CMOS process, SPICE simulations confirming the theoretical estimated results.

title: Variance Extrapolated Class-Imbalance-Aware Domain Adaptive Myocardial Segmentation in Multi-Sequence Cardiac MRI
authors: Fangxu Xing, Xiaofeng Liu, Iman Aganj, Georges El Fakhri, Panki Kim, Byoung Wook Choi, Jonghye Woo
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Fully automated myocardial segmentation from cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is vital for efficient diagnosis and treatment planning. Although numerous automated methods have been proposed, they typically focus on single MRI sequences and therefore have difficulties in generalizing across vendors and across cardiac MRI protocols. Simultaneous analysis of complementary cardiac MRI sequences, such as cine, T1 mapping, and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE) MRI, remains challenging due to their distinct image characteristics and scanner-specific variations. To address these issues, we propose an unsupervised domain adaptation approach that allows robust myocardial segmentation across multi-vendor cine, T1, and LGE MRI data. In particular, we introduce a class- imbalance self-training framework to transfer information learned from a source domain with labels to any unlabeled target domain, while maintaining consistent performance across different MRI sequences. Our framework iteratively refines segmentation accuracy by generating pseudo-labels for target data using a hardness-aware strategy, thus effectively addressing the problem of class imbalance in cardiac MRI segmentation. To mitigate data scarcity following pseudo-label selection, we employ a variance-guided vicinal feature extrapolation, which expands data points in the feature space into a probabilistic distribution. This, in turn, facilitates joint source–target training by generating a larger intersection in the feature space. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework outperforms existing methods when assessed using the Dice coefficient and Hausdorff distance. Our framework enables cardiac evaluation across MRI protocols without sequence-specific manual annotations.

title: Node-Set Synchronization and Calculation of General Boolean Networks Combining STP and Q -Learning
authors: Zhipeng Zhang, Leihao Du, Haitao Li, Yang Liu, Zengqiang Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: The calculation of the synchronization problem is a very important topic in the research of Boolean networks (BNs). This article focuses on the study of state-flipped control on the node-set synchronization problem of general BNs and incorporates reinforcement learning algorithms to enhance the calculation efficiency of the synchronization problem. First, the synchronized nodes are algebraically represented by the semi-tensor product (STP) of matrices, and the analysis of the BN for node-set synchronization under state-flipped control is given. Second, the sufficient and necessary conditions that can enable general BNs to realize node-set synchronization are derived. Meanwhile, an algorithm for finding the flip sequence is designed. In addition, this article develops a comprehensive calculation scheme connecting the recursive algorithm to the Q-learning for finding all the optimal paths. Finally, some cases are provided to verify the effectiveness of state-flipped control and the superiority of reinforcement learning in the calculation of synchronization problems. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed reinforcement learning-based algorithm achieves up to 100% success rate in finding the optimal flip sequence, outperforming the traditional method (23.4% success rate), reducing the average flip action by 15%, and improving the scalability of large-scale networks.

title: Blockchain-Based MIMO UAV-Aided Mobile Edge Computing
authors: Xuewen Dong, Xiaojie Guo, Shuangrui Zhao, Xindi Ma, Jiandong Wang, Qiang Qu, Yulong Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-aided mobile edge computing (MEC) with a blockchain consensus algorithm is a promising solution for addressing mobile offloading of computation-intensive or latency-sensitive tasks with extensive service range, while ensuring the authenticity of the offloading. Existing UAV-aided MEC studies focus on task offloading or trajectory planning of single-antenna UAVs, missing multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) UAV systems. In addition, most blockchain-based UAV-aided edge computing studies adopt energy-consuming proof-of-work-based consensus mechanisms, which are unsuitable for energy-limited UAV scenarios. To address the above issues, in this paper, we develop a joint deadline-aware task offloading and UAV trajectory planning scheme, utilizing the effects simulated through an energy-efficient consensus protocol. In order to prevent the exhaustion of UAVs' energy and ensure the authenticity of decision-making, we propose an energy-based Raft (E-Raft) consensus algorithm, enabling dynamic leader selection through a series of decreasing energy thresholds. Subsequently, we present a computational profit maximization problem to jointly optimize deadline-aware task offloading and the UAV swarm's trajectory planning. To address this NP-hard problem, we develop an online priority-based task offloading and trajectory selection algorithm, which is performed by the selected leader of the E-Raft consensus in each round. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed scheme achieves up to 40% performance improvement over other approaches.

title: Mmscribe: Streaming End-to-End Aerial Handwriting Text Translation Via Mmwave Radar
authors: Qin Chen, Yu Tian, Yaoxi Chen, Zongyong Cui, Zongjie Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: This paper presents a novel mmWave-based aerial text input method that allows users to write freely through hand movements in the air, effectively recognizing English words. Unlike existing radar character recognition methods that require pauses between adjacent letters for segmentation, the proposed mmScribe system supports continuous handwriting and streaming recognition. Our approach first utilizes Frequency-Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) mmWave radar to extract micro-Doppler time series features characterizing gesture movements. Then, a hybrid CTC/attention architecture baseline method is proposed to achieve end-to-end (E2E) text output without explicit letter segmentation. By introducing a dynamic block training strategy, the model can process contextual data of arbitrary length. During inference, the connectionist temporal classification (CTC) decoder generates n-best hypotheses at the character level in a streaming manner, while the attention decoder subsequently re-scores these hypotheses to update the final result at the text level. We have constructed the first word-level handwriting dataset for mmWave radar, and also conducted a comprehensive evaluation of the proposed method on this dataset. The results demonstrate that the method exhibits excellent performance. Furthermore, when deployed on mobile devices, mmScribe maintains its outstanding performance with minimal latency. Our code and dataset are available at: https://github.com/Tkwer/mmScribe.

title: UAB-Sync: An Efficient Time Synchronization Protocol for Underwater Acoustic Backscatter Devices in IoUT
authors: Tong Zhang, Jun Liu, Shenghua Gong, Zhenxiang Zhao, Tingting Yang, Yuanguo Bi, Guangjie Han
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Underwater acoustic backscatter communication technology brings a new perspective on addressing the energy dilemmas of Internet of Underwater Things (IoUT). However, time asynchronism in underwater acoustic backscatter devices (UABDs) can significantly degrade the performance of the UABD-based IoUT system. Existing time synchronization algorithms lose practicability leading to high energy consumption in scenarios where charging delays vary. To address these challenges, we propose UAB-Sync, a time synchronization algorithm specifically designed for the system. UAB-Sync introduces a novel three-stage architecture that uses dual constraints of time and energy to dynamically optimize the duration of energy signal, achieving adaptive approximation of optimal results. Besides, a closed-form solution for clock parameter estimation that incorporates Doppler factor estimation and accounts for multi-source measurement errors is developed, ensuring effective synchronous correction. Simulation results demonstrate that UAB-Sync significantly outperforms existing synchronization schemes in terms of both accuracy and energy efficiency for the UABD-based IoUT system.

title: A Unified Framework for DFRC Systems Based on WFRFT-OTFS
authors: Zhenduo Wang, Fanrong Dong, Menghai Zeng, Rongchen Sun
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Multi-device cooperative integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) serves as a key paradigm for enhancing wireless network sensing capabilities and provides new design dimensions for ISAC systems. Dual-Functional Radar-Communication (DFRC) is a key 6G enabler for ISAC, which ensures efficient hardware and spectrum utilization. In this paper, we propose a unified framework to tackle the challenges of performance trade-off between radar and communication in DFRC systems. Firstly, we introduce the Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) waveform into DFRC systems, and then establish a unified performance trade-off framework through developing an Integrated Sensing and Communication Trade-off (ISCT) algorithm, where Pareto optimal waveforms can be obtained through balancing beampattern and multi-user interference (MUI) under varying trade-off coefficients. Furthermore, we use the Weighted Fractional Fourier Transform (WFRFT) to extend the OTFS waveform in proposed unified DFRC framework, where an additional degree of freedom with more waveform choices can be achieved in WFRFT-OTFS, and thus more flexible trade-off optimization can be considered for diverse scenarios. Finally, we propose a Peak-to-Average Power Ratio (PAPR) suppression algorithm under the WFRFT-OTFS based DFRC framework, where flexible PAPR performance can be obtained according to jointly optimizing the trade-off coefficient and WFRFT order. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed unified framework based on WFRFT-OTFS achieves flexible performance adjustments and trade-offs. In addition, PAPR performance can be controlled according to the dual parameter characteristic as well as the proposed PAPR reduction algorithm, which greatly enhances the practicality and scalability of the unified framework for DFRC systems.

title: Non-Invasive Estimation for Core Temperature and Power Loss in Electrolytic Capacitors Using a Single-Sensor Inverse Algorithm
authors: Jinxiao Wei, Peng Chen, Yi Zhang, Peng Qin, Xianbin Qi, Shuang Zhao, Helong Li, Lijian Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: This letter proposes a single-sensor, non-invasive method for simultaneous estimation of core temperature and power loss in electrolytic capacitors, eliminating the need for equivalent series resistance (ESR) and capacitance measurements in conventional methods. An inverse numerical algorithm is developed by reversing the conventional forward calculation (e.g., finite-element), enabling accurate reconstruction of heat generation and core temperature from one single shell-mounted measurements. One important novelty involves using cooling curve to determine the equivalent convection heat transfer coefficient h, do not rely on the simulations or engineering assumptions for field applications. This method has potential applications in lifetime prediction, efficiency evaluation, thermal management, and the design of protective measures for capacitors.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Improving User Review Classification for Usability and Security& Privacy
authors: Kiranbir Kaur, Kuljit Kaur Chahal
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The wide spread of mobile applications forced people to perform their daily activities online. Mobile application developers heavily depend on user feedback in the form of reviews, as it helps them identify problems with their apps and ensures they currently meet user expectations. User reviews are inherently informal, disorganized, and unstructured. It is challenging to extract and classify the information on relevant issues due to the vast number of reviews. To expedite the classification of reviews, many researchers implemented machine-learning approaches. This work proposes a deep learning-based framework, MAUSPC, which utilizes RNN-LSTM to classify user reviews of mobile learning applications (apps), assessing usability, security& privacy. This approach leverages deep learning’s ability to extract useful information and automatically create classifications. The proposed framework builds on the latest developments of the GPT-3 Transformer by utilizing a text embedding approach. This method offers a high-quality depiction that can enhance the efficacy of detection. Furthermore, we employed the hybrid approach, which combined RNN-LSTM models into a single model that performed noticeably better than the sum of its components. The dataset of mobile learning applications was divided into two categories—usability and security & privacy—was used to conduct the model’s experimental assessment. With an accuracy of 98.59%, the results demonstrated performance that surpassed all other approaches.

title: MSCK-Net: Multiscale Chinese Knot Convolutional Network for Dim and Small Infrared Ship Detection
authors: Yuhao Lin, Dongliang Peng, Liang Wang, Lingjie Jiang, Haewoon Nam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing infrared ship detection is crucial for maritime safety and traffic management in civil-military integrated applications. However, the detection accuracy and robustness of current methods are still limited by dataset constraints, including small scale, narrow target size distribution, sparse targets, and high scenario specificity. To address these problems, we integrate publicly available datasets to construct IRShip—a relatively large-scale infrared ship detection dataset comprising 27,138 images, significantly improving data scale and diversity. We further design a copy-poisson blend (CP-PB) offline data augmentation approach and introduce a dense one-to-one (Dense-O2O) online augmentation strategy, which improve adaptability to complex backgrounds and scale variations, mitigate problems from sparse targets, and improve dataset utility and model robustness. We propose MSCK-Net, a multiscale chinese knot convolutional network tailored for detecting dim and small infrared ship targets (DSIRST). Specifically, we propose a novel Chinese Knot Convolution (CKConv) that better aligns with both the local features of small targets and the morphological characteristics of ship targets, thereby significantly enhancing low-level feature representation. Built with CKConv, the multiscale knot block (MSK-Block) and Stem-ck modules enhance deep feature transmission efficiency and global modeling of DSIRST, leading to notable gains in detection performance. Extensive experiments on IRShip, NUDT-SIRST-Sea, ISDD, IRSDSS, and Maritime-sirst demonstrate that MSCK-Net-M achieves state-of-the-art performance, with AP<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">50</sub>, AP<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">75</sub>, and AP of 82.5%, 53.1%, and 50.9% on IRShip, significantly outperforming the existing 20 general object detectors and 6 infrared target detectors. Generalization experiments on four sub-datasets further verify the effectiveness and robustness of our proposed method. The code and dataset are available at: https://github.com/sjxxrh/MSCK-Net.

title: 3D High-quality Power Doppler Using Coherence-based Null Subtraction Imaging_supp3-3649288.mp4
authors: Jianwen Luo
publish: N/A
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) power Doppler (PD) imaging enables visualization of volumetric microvasculature networks. However, 3D ultrafast PD imaging with matrix arrays suffers from limited resolution due to the restricted aperture size and the use of unfocused plane waves, while delay-and-sum (DAS) exhibits high sidelobe levels and broad main lobes, hindering high-quality PD imaging. In this study, we aim to improve the 3D null subtraction imaging (NSI) and propose coherence-based NSI beamformers including NSI based on coherence factor (NSI-CF) and NSI based on spatial and angular coherence factor (NSI-SACF). Specifically, NSI-SACF integrates the high-resolution capability of NSI and the high-contrast performance of spatial and angular coherence factor (SACF). The proposed beamformers are validated through simulations, phantom experiments, and in vivo experiments. Qualitative and quantitative evaluations confirm the superiority of NSI-SACF. In the simulations, NSI-SACF achieves a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 0.059 mm compared with 0.391 mm for DAS and 0.225 mm for SACF. NSI-SACF also reduces the sidelobe level by 75.5 dB and 33.6 dB compared with DAS and SACF respectively, while effectively suppressing grating lobes. In the in vivo experiments, NSI-SACF improves the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) of blood flow by 20.03 dB and 8.65 dB over DAS and SACF, respectively. Furthermore, the FWHM of the vessel is reduced to 0.098 mm with NSI-SACF, compared with 0.326 mm for DAS and 0.159 mm for SACF. In summary, the proposed NSI-SACF beamformer effectively enhances the PD imaging by simultaneously improving spatial resolution and contrast, demonstrating the potential for clinical applications.

title: Trajectory Planning and Tracking Control for Human-Machine Co-Driving Intelligent Vehicles on Curved Roads
authors: Qingya Zhou, Liang Liu, Zhaoping Xu, Xianhui Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Human-machine co-driving (HMcD) is a crucial technical architecture in the transitional stage of automobile intelligence development. However, a potential conflict due to inconsistent intentions between human drivers and autonomous driving (AD) systems enormously hinders the progress of intelligent vehicles, especially on curved roads. Even though there have been certain studies on human-like trajectory planning methods, few of them address from the perspective of driving behavior characteristics learning. This paper proposed a collaborative trajectory planning and tracking control scheme for HMcD in curve scenarios. Firstly, the data of skilled human drivers were collected under various curved conditions on a designed driver-in-loop (DiL) real-time simulation platform, and the steering behaviors and trajectory characteristics of human drivers were analyzed in terms of lane, roadside constraint and road curvature. Based on these characteristics, a sliding online human-like trajectory planning (SOHTP) model was proposed, path information, vehicle state, and driving outcome were identified as model input. In addition, a HMcD shared controller was designed on account of Nash equilibrium and optimal control theory. The dynamic disturbance, i.e., future time-varying curvature, was incorporated into the closed loop of human-vehicle-road planning and control. Finally, the performance comparisons and verification tests were designed and carried out. The results show that the constructed HMcD collaborative control system efficiently alleviates human-machine conflict, reduces driving burden, and improves driving satisfaction compared to completely manual driving.

title: Comparative Analysis of Visual Function Variations Under Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) and Direct Current (DC) Dimming in Mobile Display
authors: Yanlong Sun, Shanshan Zen, Hu Fang, Ya Guo, Shupeng Li, Jianqi Cai, Yi Chen
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Under low-to-moderate ambient lighting, screen flicker from display devices can lead to considerable visual discomfort. The industry typically addresses this issue through the implementation of Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) and Direct Current (DC) dimming technologies. Current assessments of flicker risks primarily focus on the quantitative analysis of hardware physical parameters. These measurements indirectly characterize flicker intensity based on the fluctuation properties of light sources. However, this methodology does not take into account the physiological variations in human visual responses and overlooks the persistent deviations from optimal optical conditions during standard device usage. As a result, existing methods are insufficient for adequately evaluating the visual function abnormalities that may arise. Research indicates that screen flicker influences brain function by modulating oscillations in the visual cortex. These neurological effects are expected to result in measurable changes in visual performance. However, existing studies predominantly concentrate on detecting brain function, with a notable absence of direct physiological evidence that establishes a link between flicker and visual impairment.To address these limitations, we conducted human-factor experiments assessing PWM and DC dimming effects on ocular function through three physiological markers: Accommodation Microfluctuations (ACC), Higher-Order Aberrations (HOAs), and Modulation Transfer Function (MTF). Participants engaged in 45-minute visual tasks on PWM and DC-dimmed displays, with ocular measurements taken before and after each session.At a brightness level of 45-55 nits, PWM dimming exhibited a significantly greater impact on ocular imaging quality compared to DC dimming during continuous visual tasks.However, $\triangle \mathrm{ACC}$ testing indicated no statistically significant difference in visual fatigue indices between the two technologies. While PWM’s high-frequency brightness oscillations increased wavefront aberrations (spherical and coma aberrations), both technologies demonstrated comparable cumulative effects on retinal neural adaptation fatigue. This study provides empirical guidance for optimizing dimming technology selection in display devices.

title: GaN-Based High-Efficiency Two-Stage Converter with Buck and LLC for Aerospace Application
authors: Qi Cao, Xinran Chen, Dejun Ba, Yuxin Niu, Yihe Wang, Xiaofeng Lyu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: To meet the requirements for high reliability and power density in spacecraft power systems, this paper proposes a radiation-hardened, aerospace-qualified GaN-based two-stage isolated DC/DC converter with a Buck-LLC topology. The front-stage Buck circuit accommodates a wide input voltage ranging from 80 to 120 V, while the rear-stage LLC resonant tank employs secondary-side synchronous rectification and soft-switching techniques to achieve low-loss power conversion. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed converter exhibits excellent performance with high peak efficiency of 94.3% and power density of $4.82 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$, and robust single-event tolerance for extraterrestrial environments.

title: Edge-Based TinyML for Fault Detection Using Sound Vibration Analysis
authors: A.R. Danila Shirly, S. Prathiba, L. Ramya Hyacinth, Lokeshwar K, Jennifer Ruth Pauline G
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: In this work, we propose a new edge computing framework for fault detection of industrial machines based on sound vibration analysis. A low footprint TinyML model has been used and deployed on the Arduino Nano RP2040 microcontroller via TensorFlow Lite. The machines' acoustic signals are evaluated for unusual patterns indicative of damage or wear. Features are extracted by the MelFrequency Energy (MFE), which is introduced to effectively represent spectral properties of the audio signal related to the machine condition monitoring. Conventional fault detection systems are generally based on cloud services, which inevitably rely on continuous data to be transmitted from the edge devices to the remote servers for the purpose of processing and inferencing. This solution comes with the added latency, power usage and network dependency and security risks. In contrast, the proposed edge computing approach enhances extensive work on scene graph generation and detection. online inference on the embedded device. This provides immediate fault finding, low latency, higher data security, and removes the requirement of always-on cloud connection. Local processing of data reduces Operative Costs due to less bandwidth consumption and less dependence on Cloud services. It may save energy, thus making it suitable for use in the industrial area which is far away from the city or lack of energy sources. By reducing the response time any potential for delays, which can often manifest as system failures or downtime, is kept at a minimal. The paper also provides empirical evaluation and comparative studies to show that the edge-based model is more effective than the conventional cloud approach. In summary, this work showcases the promise of TinyML and edge computing for smart, cost-effective, and energy-efficient fault detection in industrial applications.

title: Precision Clock: A Multi-Frequency Generator for Soc Application
authors: Dharaneesh R N, Swamynathan S, Kavitha K R, S. Vijayalakshmi, B. Murali Babu
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Modern digital systems need precise clock generation for proper operation. This design creates multiple stable clock frequencies using efficient counter-based division techniques to produce 5 different signals from a 50 MHz input dual clock. The system has differential clock inputs to improve signal quality and reduce noise in high-speed, interference-sensitive areas. Both synchronous reset mechanisms and a flexible design ensure smooth operation and the ability to meet various application needs. Precise clock generation is crucial for error-free operation in modern digital systems. Many applications need a precision clock divider to create multiple synchronized timing domains from one input clock source. This solution focuses on low power use and high efficiency, making it perfect for re-source-limited applications like FPGAs and ASICs. The system clocks maintain temporal synchronization and provide accurate timing signals, ensuring compatibility with systems that have strict timing requirements. This solution is valuable for digital signal processing, communication protocols, data acquisition systems, and embedded control applications.

title: Intelligent Traffic Management System for Ambulances and Pedestrians Using YOLOv8 and Multi-Modal Fusion
authors: Bavithra Karunanidhi, Angulakshmi R, Chitrupa S, Kamaleshvar KK
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: In developing nations, traffic congestion delays emergency vehicles like ambulances, causing precious time and life-threatening delays. Pedestrian safety is also a principal issue in urban areas with rising population and vehicular concentrations. This paper proposes an intelligent traffic management system integrating vision-based YOLOv8 object detection and audio-based siren detection for real-time ambulance identification and pedestrian crowd density assessment. The system employsYOLOv8neuralnetworksforambulanceandpedestrian detection, complemented by Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCC) and CNN-based audio processing. A novel adaptive decision fusion framework dynamically integrates multi-modal data based on environmental context. Experimental validation demonstrates 92.3% precision for ambulance detection and 95.1% for pedstr riandetection, with 35% false positive reduction compared to single-modality approaches. Real-world deployment shows 28.3% improvement in emergency response times with 99.2% system availability.

title: AI-Driven Personalization in Tourism: A Survey
authors: Evaggelos Spyrou, Dimitrios Koutrintzes, Stavros Karkanis
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Tourism is shifting from generic offerings to semantically rich, agent-based, and value-aware personalization. This survey synthesizes advances in user modeling (traits, culture, affect, and implicit behavioral signals), knowledge-aware and sequence-aware recommenders (knowledge graphs, deep learning, reinforcement learning), and intelligent software agents for service discovery, negotiation, and real-time re-planning. We introduce an indicative reference pipeline that links user inputs, data analysis, agent planning, and service orchestration; propose a compact taxonomy of personalization tasks and techniques; and contrast recommendation paradigms by their strengths, limitations, and integration costs. We further map core value dimensions (sustainability, fairness, inclusivity, privacy) to actionable system levers and review explainability mechanisms and participatory controls that align personalization with user and societal goals and present a research agenda on transparency, cross-cultural generalization, privacy-preserving learning, interoperability across providers, and robust operation under real-time constraints, aiming to guide the design of adaptive, accountable, and user-centered personalization in tourism.

title: Analytical Study of Fuel Cell Stack Behavior Under Variable High-Frequency Ripple using Adaptive Converter Control
authors: PM Preethiraj, Belwin Edward J, Narendra Kumar Aridas, R. Sarjila
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This work provides a thorough examination of how high-frequency current ripple impacts a proton exchange membrane's functionality (PEM) fuel cell stack, integrating both experimental data and predictive modeling through an advanced equivalent resistance framework. This study innovatively combines adaptive converter management with ripple-frequency-dependent energy modeling to assess power loss and fuel inefficiency, building on known methodologies. The converter functions over an extensive frequency range (10-60 kHz) and ripple amplitude spectrum (0-25%), facilitating a more profound understanding of ripple-frequency dynamics. Experimental findings indicate a significant fluctuation in stack voltage and efficiency contingent upon ripple parameters, with efficiency losses reaching 22 % at elevated ripple and low frequency. The proposed model precisely forecasts performance under ripple conditions and facilitates the design of ripple-tolerant converter systems for fuel cell applications.

title: BrainDx: Tumor Detection and Segmentation with Efficient Neural Networks
authors: Sujatha Canavoy Narahari, Abhishek Gudipalli, Nemmaniwar Sohan, V. S. S. Sankeerth, M. Harish Goud
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Manual detection of brain tumors in MRI scans is time-consuming and even irregular in some clinics lacking trained personnel or special equipment. To make this a faster process, we created a web-based platform that delivers cuttingedge deep learning to clinicians' fingertips. Once you upload an MRI image, users are navigated through an interface powered by Flask: a very well-optimized MobileNetV2 model scans first for any sign of a tumor, and a U-Net segmentation network then sharply defines its edges. In development, we tested various architectures, such as DenseNet-121 and a custom MobileNet-ViT hybrid, and ended up with MobileNetV2 due to its optimal balance between speed and precision. The platform returns tumor detection and segmentation outcomes in seconds, with precise, actionable information to enable confident medical decisions. By encapsulating powerful neural networks within an easy-to-use interface, our solution provides reliable brain tumor diagnosis more affordably and helps enhance patient care.

title: TRCP-SSG: A Tamper-Resilient Cryptographic Protocol for Secure Smart Grids
authors: Nabeil Eltayieb, Majdi Abdellatief, Samah Mohamed Osman, Rahsad Elhabob
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Smart grids integrate advanced communication and computing technologies to improve the efficiency and reliability of power systems. However, their growing complexity and makes them vulnerable to sophisticated threats such as algorithm substitution attacks (ASAs) and cryptographic subversion. Traditional cryptographic methods are often inadequate in detecting or mitigating such attacks. This paper proposes a tamper-resilient cryptographic framework that combines Certificateless Proxy Re-encryption (CL-PRE) with the concept of a Cryptographic Reverse Firewall (CRF). The TRCP-SSG scheme securely distributes encrypted data from smart meters to users via smart grids and resists data exfiltration and ciphertext forgery, even under system compromise. The analysis shows that the proposed approach is lightweight, scalable, and effective in securing smart grid communications against adversarial models such as CPA and ASA.

title: Adaptive Physics-Informed Neural Network for Large-Scale Multi-Magnitude Electric Field Prediction in Power Systems
authors: Lanling Wang, Ziyang Ye, Jiefu Zhang, Yanjun Xu, Yihui Ding, Junyi Cai
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: Electromagnetic field prediction is critical for ensuring the safety and reliability of modern power systems. However, conventional numerical solvers are computationally prohibitive, and standard Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) often suffer from training instability in large-scale scenarios. To ad- dress these challenges, we propose an Adaptive Physics-Informed Neural Network (APINN) with a decoupled architecture that separates feature representation from physical constraint enforcement through a soft domain decomposition strategy. This design mitigates gradient conflicts while preserving strict physical consistency. Furthermore, adaptive sampling and dynamic weight scheduling are incorporated to enhance stability and efficiency. In validation across six typical power system scenarios, APINN achieves a 93.8% reduction in mean absolute error (MAE) and converges 36% faster than conventional PINNs. In addition, APINN delivers an inference time of only 42 milliseconds, fully demonstrating its capability for real-time electromagnetic field simulation. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of APINN as a fast and reliable framework for real-time electromagnetic field simulation.

title: Review of AI Methods for Intelligent Photovoltaic Systems in Smart Grids: Forecasting, Sizing, MPPT, and Fault Diagnosis
authors: Oumayma Lanaya, Hajar El Karch, Youssef Natij, Meriem Elatik, Abdelmounaim Belaarbi, Abdelkader Mezouari
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The growing integration of photovoltaic (PV) energy into smart electrical grids presents significant challenges related to intermittency, fault detection, system sizing, and real-time control. This review provides a comprehensive analysis of recent advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI), particularly Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL), for optimizing the operation and management of PV systems within smart grids. The study categorizes and compares AI-based methodologies in energy forecasting, fault detection and diagnosis, intelligent PV system sizing, and optimization of Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) techniques. Through a critical evaluation of recent literature (2020-2025), the review highlights the complementary roles of classical ML models and advanced DL architectures, including Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) networks, Transformer models, and hybrid approaches combining physics-based knowledge with datadriven learning. Moreover, heuristic optimization algorithms such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) are discussed for their contribution to enhancing convergence speed and accuracy in MPPT and diagnostic applications. This review not only synthesizes state-of-the-art AI strategies but also identifies key technical gaps related to data availability, computational complexity, and model interpretability. Emerging solutions such as federated learning, edge computing, and Explainable AI (XAI) are discussed as promising pathways toward scalable, trustworthy, and autonomous PV energy systems. The study aims to support researchers and practitioners in designing robust, real-time AI-based frameworks for next-generation renewable energy integration.

title: Lyapunov-Based Stability and Delay Bounds for IEEE 802.1Qbv in Imperfectly Synchronized TSN
authors: Zhuangye Luo, Feng Zeng, Xi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: IEEE 802.1Qbv Time-Aware Shaper (TAS) is a cornerstone of Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN), offering bounded latency and near-zero jitter for critical traffic (CT). However, prior scheduling algorithms either rely on ideal clock synchronization or resource reservation, sacrificing bandwidth efficiency. In this paper, we present a unified framework for the analysis of stability for queueing process and delay bounds in TAS, in which clock drift, gate-switching jitter, and sync-message loss are modeled as a stochastic service-loss process in TAS scheduling. Then, a Lyapunov-drift analysis is used to derive both deterministic worst-case delay bounds under maximal service loss and probabilistic stability conditions when the average service rate exceeds the arrival rate. Finally, based on the theoretical analysis, the guard-band sizing and slot-provisioning guidelines are proposed for practical TSN deployment under non-ideal synchronization. Extensive simulations have been conducted to validate the tightness of our delay bounds, and the simulation results demonstrate that the proposed configuration rules can guarantee bounded latency and queue stability.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Smart Tourism: Key Benefits and Systemic Comparison with Centralized Models
authors: Abdelaziz Boukhalfa, Meryem Lasaad, Lamya Benaddi, Abdeslam Jakimi, Moulay Youssef Hadi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Recently, smart tourism marks a significant evolution in the tourism industry, driven by the adoption of cutting-edge digital technologies. Yet, it continues to grapple with persistent issues such as centralized data control, reliance on intermediaries, and challenges to digital sovereignty. Blockchain technology has several core characteristics that make it uniquely capable of handling the in-built challenges of smart cities -specifically smart tourism-. This paper examines the potential of blockchain technology to address these issues through its decentralized, secure, and transparent infrastructure. By analyzing both the foundations and limitations of the current smart tourism model, the study outlines how blockchain can contribute to a more robust, disintermediated, and user-centric tourism ecosystem. It also explores the technical, legal, and organizational barriers to blockchain implementation, and proposes directions for its sustainable and responsible integration into the sector.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Edge Computing and Fog Computing in Decentralized Networks: Performance and Scalability
authors: Adnan A. Hnaif
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The rapid expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) and the growing need for real-time data processing have accelerated the development of decentralized computing paradigms. This paper presents a detailed comparative analysis of edge computing and fog computing architectures, exploring their distinct roles in modern decentralized networks. By evaluating architectural differences and performance metrics, we assess the advantages and limitations of each approach. The proposed methodology combines theoretical analysis with comparative frameworks. Our findings indicate that edge computing excels in ultra-low-latency applications with minimal infrastructure, while fog computing offers greater scalability and efficient resource management for complex distributed systems. We conclude that the choice between edge and fog computing depends on application-specific requirements, with hybrid models emerging as a promising solution for future decentralized networks. This study enhances the understanding of decentralized computing architectures and provides actionable insights for system designers and network architects.

title: Classification of celestial objects using a Multi-level wavelet based Convolutional Neural Network on a high-performance computing architecture
authors: Varun Srivastava, Anil Kumar Mahto, Aastha Maheshwari, Tarun Agrawal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The paper aims to classify astronomical images into two categories: stars and galaxies using a Convolution neural network (CNN) accelerated with CUDA programming. The dataset comprised of images of stars and galaxies from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), which are first preprocessed and then fed into a CNN model. The algorithm first enhances the images and then apply a multilevel wavelet transform to highlight the area having stars or galaxy. The dataset is then fed into a CNN model for classification between stars and galaxies. The results are compared on a normal computational device and a GPU accelerated super computer with NVIDIA A100 GPUs. An accuracy of 88.12% is obtained for the proposed model. Also, a speed up of 9.8% is obtained when the same algorithm is run on a GPU cluster.

title: Aquaguard: A Modular AI System for Detecting Drowning, Rip Currents, and Sharks Using Drone Surveillance
authors: Hanine Aymen El Sayed, Rahma Shabaan Esmail, Esraa Ahmed Ibrahim, Mohamed Emad Mohamed, Mostafa Saad Sobeih, Mohamed Essam, Ahmed Salah El Din
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Coastal hazards such as drowning, rip currents, and shark encounters pose persistent threats to public safety. Traditional monitoring methods-lifeguards, signage, and patrols-struggle with scale and response time. This paper introduces Aquaguard, a drone-based surveillance system that uses deep learning to detect aquatic dangers autonomously. Aquaguard integrates three AI modules: (1) a drowning detection pipeline combining YOLO, DeepSORT, and a transformer-based sequence classifier; (2) a shark detection model using YOLOv11; and (3) a rip current detection system evaluated through scene classification. The drowning module achieved a classification accuracy of 85.0% using a transformer-based model. The YOLOv11-m for shark detection reached over 91% mAP on validation data and showed generalization on unseen test frames. The rip current classifier achieved an accuracy of 77% on an unseen test set. Aquaguard demonstrates how modular AI pipelines can deliver scalable coastal hazard detection.
