Its edge-deployable design and mobile alert system enable rapid, informed response-helping reduce risks and save lives.

title: Self-supervised Distillation Method for Lightweight Convolutional Networks
authors: Zhiliang Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: In deep learning visual tasks, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have demonstrated excellent performance in various image classification scenarios. However, their large number of parameters and dependence on large-scale annotated data severely restrict the application of the model in small samples and resource-limited environments. To address this issue, we present a lightweight image classification framework that couples self-supervised teacher pre-training with knowledge distillation to a compact student. The teacher (ResNet-18) is pre-trained with SimCLR and, under the same unlabeled budget, with MoCo v2 and BYOL; the student (LiteNet-DSC) uses depthwise-separable convolutions with batch normalization. Beyond final-logit distillation, we add a lightweight feature-level transfer aligning two intermediate stages, and incorporate consistency regularization with semi-supervised pseudo-labels. On MNIST and CIFAR-10 under a low-label regime (CIFAR-10: 10k labeled / 35k unlabeled), the student reaches up to 93.1% top-1 with ~0.5M parameters and 0.50 ms single-image latency, about 5× faster than the teacher. Ablations show consistent gains from alternative SSL (BYOL ≥ MoCo v2 > SimCLR) and from feature-level transfer. The approach achieves a high-accuracy, low-overhead balance suitable for mobile and embedded deployment.

title: 4H-SiC Homoepitaxy via Single-Source MTS Under Controlled Growth Temperatures
authors: Hanyu Zhao, Yuyang Wang, Yicheng Pei, Moyu Wei, Yunkai Li, Jingyi Jiao, Han Kong, Chenlin Ai, Qing Katherine Mu, Guoguo Yan, Yingxi Niu, Xingfang Liu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) was employed to systematically investigate the influence of growth temperature on the crystal structure and surface morphology of $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ homoepitaxial layers under a single-source precursor, methyltrichlorosilane (MTS). The results reveal that the epitaxial layer grown at $1550^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is predominantly composed of $3 \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{SiC}$ with a rough surface, whereas increasing the temperature to $1600^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1650^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ leads to the formation of $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$. Energydispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis indicates that the $\mathrm{Si} / \mathrm{C}$ ratio at $1600^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is close to the stoichiometric value, while significant carbon enrichment occurs at $1650^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Comparative analysis demonstrates that the epitaxial layer grown at $1600^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ exhibits lower surface roughness and uniform step-flow morphology, making it the optimal temperature for achieving high-quality $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ homoepitaxy. In contrast, excessive temperature at $1650^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ induces black defect spots on the surface, deteriorating the uniformity and crystalline quality of the epitaxial layer. This study effectively promotes the optimization of $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ epitaxial growth and the industrialization of high-performance power devices by validating the distinct advantages of MTS, such as simplified reaction pathways, a stable $\mathrm{Si} / \mathrm{C}$ ratio, and improved layer uniformity.

title: Research on Distribution Network Fault Restoration Considering Mobile Resource Optimization Scheduling
authors: Xin Chen, Xiaoqing Han, Tingjun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: In recent years, large-scale power outages in distribution grids caused by natural disasters, human-made accidents, and other factors have occurred frequently, with the damage they inflict on distribution grids growing increasingly severe. Mobile energy storage devices (MESS), however, possess capabilities such as flexible deployment, dynamic regulation, and rapid response, enabling them to play a significant role in restoring power supply to distribution grids. Against this backdrop, this paper establishes a mobile energy storage optimization scheduling model for post-disaster fault recovery based on a power-transportation integrated system, taking into account the response of distribution grids to major disasters. The model uses load reduction as the objective function and implements post-disaster recovery scheduling under the scenario of distributed power source islanding. Finally, the proposed method is applied to improve the N-5 fault under the IEEE 33-node system. The case study demonstrates that the proposed model can obtain the optimal MESS dispatch path, thereby achieving faster and more effective restoration of interrupted loads.

title: Solar-Powered Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring System Using Arduino
authors: Chamakura Krishna Reddy, Rampelli Manojkumar, Prasanta Kumar Jena, Balusu Srinivasa Rao, Chakali Gowthami, Yerrabachala Roshini
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a cost-effective, solar-powered, real-time air quality monitoring and hazard alert system utilizing an Arduino microcontroller integrated with gas and particulate matter sensors. The research addresses the growing need for accessible and sustainable indoor air quality monitoring solutions in residential, commercial, and industrial environments to safeguard human health. The system incorporates MQ-series sensors-MQ-2 for smoke, MQ-3 for alcohol, and MQ-135 for toxic gases including ammonia, nitrogen oxides, benzene, and carbon dioxide-along with the PMS7003 sensor to measure concentrations of PM1.0, PM2.5, and PM10. Sensor data are collected and processed by the Arduino to evaluate pollutant levels. Based on predefined thresholds, the system categorizes air quality into three levels: normal, moderate, and high-risk. In the event of hazardous conditions, an audible alert is triggered via a buzzer, and the pollutant readings are displayed in real time through the serial monitor for data logging and immediate analysis. The entire system is powered by a solar energy setup, enhancing its environmental sustainability and enabling deployment in areas with limited electrical infrastructure. The design is modular and scalable, allowing future integration with wireless communication modules for remote monitoring and control. The results demonstrate that the system reliably detects and differentiates multiple air contaminants, making it a practical and eco-friendly tool for early warning and continuous environmental assessment.

title: A Multi-modal Power Operation and Maintenance Meta-Reinforcement Learning Approach Based on Liquid Neural Network Reward Models
authors: Hongquan Xu, Qi Jin, Yi Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Power automation operations and maintenance involve complexity and high risk. Existing reinforcement learning methods commonly suffer from insufficient generalization capabilities and limited timeliness in agent decision-making, making them ill-suited for multimodal information environments. Power operation scenarios involve massive amounts of temporal data, textual logs, and monitoring images, placing higher demands on the learning efficiency and decision accuracy of agents. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a multi-modal power operation meta-reinforcement learning method based on a Liquid Neural Network (LNN) reward model. This approach combines the dynamic adaptability of LNNs in temporal modeling with the rapid transfer learning capability of meta-reinforcement learning to achieve efficient optimization in complex operation scenarios. Through multimodal fusion training, the agent rapidly identifies potential failure patterns and delivers precise auxiliary decisions in novel fault scenarios, thereby enhancing the intelligence and automation of power grid operations. Experiments demonstrate that this approach not only effectively reduces human labor but also provides higher-level support for optimizing maintenance strategies and preventing failures in complex environments, showcasing promising application prospects.

title: Charging Load Forecasting of Electric Vehicle Based on Graph Neural Network
authors: Zixuan Liu, Yushan Li, Qi Tian, Yeqing Zhang, WenLi Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The fluctuation and uncertainty of electric vehicle charging station load bring great challenges to power grid planning. This paper proposes an electric vehicle charging load forecasting model based on graph neural network. Through this model, the charging load of electric vehicle cluster can be predicted more accurately and the accuracy of load forecasting can be improved. By encoding the charge correlation and distance correlation into the graph structure, and using the hippo optimization algorithm (HO) to optimize the model hyper parameters, the prediction accuracy is improved. The experimental results show that the proposed model is superior to the existing models in terms of mean square error (MSE), mean absolute error (MAE) and symmetric mean absolute percentage error (SMAPE). It can better adapt to the fluctuation and randomness of charging load, which is of great significance to the load planning of power grid.

title: Investigation of angle effect on single-event leakage current degradation in Cascode GaN HEMTs
authors: Zhinian Jin, Peipei Hu, Shiwei Zhao, Xiaoyu Yan, Danmei Lin, Pengfei Zhai, Yu Dong, Yuzhu Liu, Lijun Xu, Li Cai, Xuefeng Zheng, Jie Liu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In this work, we conducted a systematic single-event effect (SEE) study on commercial 900 V Cascode GaN HEMTs devices with different types of heavy ions. Sustained Single-event leakage current (SELC) was observed during irradiation, where the drain-source leakage current $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{ds}}$ increased with both drain bias and LETs. Singleevent burnout (SEB) occurred at a bias of 75 V when the LET reached $75.3 \mathrm{MeV} /\left(\mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}\right)$. Post-irradiation scanning electron microscope (SEM) analysis revealed the SEB site to be at the source electrode, showing a complete material void. Experiments with different ion incident angles showed that the SELC rate decreased with increasing angle. Technology computer-aided design (TCAD) simulations were employed to investigate the influence of irradiation angle on the electrical characteristics, and the simulation results are consistent with the experimental data. This results from the oblique ion track angle, which both reduces charge collection efficiency due to misalignment with the dominant electric field and enhances carrier trapping/recombination in the buffer layer.

title: Federated Learning for DDoS Attack Detection in SDN: A Privacy-Preserving Approach
authors: Hind Amrani, Jamal Elhachmi, Abdellatif Kobbane
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The main objective of this contribution is to provide an in-depth analysis of the vulnerabilities present in the various layers of the SDN environment as well as to propose a novel solution to detect distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, as they pose serious threat to the stability and availability of softwaredefined networks. In addition, a federated learning framework is introduced to identify DDoS attacks in SDN environments, which simultaneously protects privacy while maintaining high detection accuracy. Our proposed solution reduces the risk of data breaches and protects the confidentiality of sensitive data by training models locally. We have used FL to train three classifiers: Deep neural networks (DNN), convolutional neural networks (CNN) and (LSTM) Long Short-term memory to classify two categories of DDoS attacks, namely: UDP Flood, TCP SYN. Achieving 99.99% accuracy and a 99.99% F1-score on TCP SYN floods, alongside 99.94% and 99.97% on UDP floods, our federated CNN not only exceeds the most robust centralized benchmarks but also outperforms our own federated DNN and LSTM models, establishing a new benchmark for SDN DDoS detection while ensuring complete privacy of raw traffic within each domain.

title: Machine Learning Classifiers for Disease Diagnosis Using Wrist Pulse Signal
authors: Aathithya S V, Achanta Sai Krishna, Kuralanbu S, Vimal Dharshan N, R Shanmughasundaram, S. Veera Alagiri
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Ayurveda, an ancient Indian medical tradition, uses a diagnostic method Nadi Pariksha evaluates the pulse to determine imbalances in doshas and constitution, providing information about a patient's state of health. Even though Nadi Pariksha has a centuries-old heritage, combining it with contemporary technologies brings new opportunities to reduce the time taken for the identification of disease and also with better accuracy. The dataset is collected from Git. This dataset serves as a critical component in training a machine learning model designed to discern patterns between pulse characteristics and various health conditions. Machine Learning techniques like Decision Tree, SVM, Logistic Regression, XGBoost and KNN are used. The XG Boost algorithm emerging as the preferred choice due to its superior accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(96 \%)$</tex> when compared to other models, such as Decision Tree, SVM and Logistic Regression. Alongside with the help expert and hardware support like Arduino UNO, Photoplethysmography (PPG) sensor wrist pulse signals are manually collected by placing three fingers alongside on the radial artery, and the three points placed on the hand are known as doshas, i.e., vaatha, pittha and kapha and the abnormality in doshas is identified for that particular person. The results from the Machine Learning model and the Arduino UNO micro controller is compared and checked whether the results are matched.

title: An Adaptive Strong Tracking Extended Kalman Filtering Approach for State Estimation in Sensorless Control of PMSM
authors: Yazhi Chen, Jinliang Zhang, Yanlin Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This paper presents a position sensorless control algorithm for permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) based on an Adaptive Strong Tracking Extended Kalman Filter (ASTEKF). The proposed algorithm addresses the limitation of conventional EKF in tracking abrupt state changes by introducing a fading matrix to adaptively adjust the Kalman gain, thereby enhancing the rapid tracking capability. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms the conventional EKF in terms of estimation accuracy, dynamic tracking performance, and noise suppression.

title: Deep Learning-Based COVID-19 Forecasting in Egypt Using Behavioral and Epidemiological Features Across Multiple Time Horizons
authors: Aya Mahmoud Ahmed, Khaled Tawfik Wassif, Hanaa Bayomi Mobarz
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Forecasting covid-19 trends plays a crucial role in enabling timely public health interventions. This work proposes a deep learning model incorporating cumulative infections, deaths, vaccination data, and mobility to forecast COVID-19 cases in Egypt. Several models have been trained and compared, and their performance is analyzed through Bidirectional GRU with Attention, BiLSTM model with attention and CNN model. The BiGRU-Attention model performed the best across all the forecast horizons 3 days, one week, two weeks, and 4-weeks achieved an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 6. 7 0 \%}$</tex> for 3-day forecast and 77.40 % for 4 -weeks predictions. The results demonstrate consistent improvements in forecasting accuracy with the use of attention mechanisms and vaccination data while forecasting over larger time horizons. The study demonstrates the use and potency of attention-based architectures and multi-feature integration in capturing pandemic patterns. The proposed framework presents a fast and reliable method to support epidemic monitoring and health policy planning in resource-limited settings.

title: Boosting IoT Intrusion Detection with Hybrid Federated Learning
authors: Salah El Hajla, El Mahfoud Ennaji, Yassine Maleh, Soufyane Mounir
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: IoT network security faces dual challenges: effectively detecting intrusions while safeguarding user privacy. This paper introduces HFEL (Hybrid Federated Ensemble Learning), an innovative approach integrating tree-based algorithms with neural networks in a privacy-preserving federated architecture. By combining Random Forest and XGBoost with a Federated Multi-Layer Perceptron, our framework maintains data locality while enhancing detection capabilities through ensemble techniques. HFEL uniquely addresses the performance initialization issues common in federated learning systems through its hybrid design. Experimental validation on BoT-IoT and Edge-IIoT datasets demonstrates HFEL's exceptional performance, achieving detection accuracies of 99.94 % and 97.53 % respectively. Comparative analysis reveals substantial improvements over both traditional federated approaches and current state-of-the-art methods. This research advances the field by demonstrating how ensemble strategies can overcome key limitations in federated intrusion detection without compromising privacy constraints.

title: Transformer Architectures for Predictive Maintenance Content Generation in Smart Grid Education
authors: Maktuba Murtazakhojayeva, Gennadiy Bogdanovich, Qonaqbay Turdibaev, Nodira Yangibayeva, Nurillo Abdullayev, Navruza Salokhitdinova
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The integration of transformer architectures in smart grid education offers a promising avenue for predictive maintenance and adaptive content generation. By leveraging advanced deep learning models, educational systems can provide real-time, scenario-based training for grid operators, enhancing understanding of complex energy systems. However, existing approaches often rely on conventional machine learning or standard transformer models that primarily focus on historical sensor data, lacking the ability to incorporate domainspecific knowledge. These methods struggle with contextual understanding of interdependent components and fail to generate explainable educational content. To address these limitations, this study proposes a Knowledge-Enhanced Transformer for Contextual Predictive Maintenance (KE-T-PPM). The framework combines time-series sensor data with a smart grid knowledge graph, capturing both temporal dependencies and component relationships. This hybrid approach enables accurate prediction of equipment failures while producing explainable insights linked to operational knowledge. The KE-T-PPM framework is applied to generate adaptive educational content for smart grid operators, including interactive simulations, case studies, and preventive maintenance guidelines. By contextualizing predictive alerts within real-world scenarios, the system enhances operator comprehension and decision-making skills. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed method improves prediction accuracy, reliability, and clarity of training content compared to traditional models, highlighting its potential for smarter, knowledge-driven educational platforms in power systems.

title: Syntax Tree Parsing for Automation Control System Optimization in Robotics Learning Platform
authors: Nadira Khalkhmurzayeva, Lolakhon Saidova, Muhammadbobur Turg'unboyev, Zilola Sattorov, Dadaxon Abdullayev, Gulistan Kanaatova, Bobur Ismoilov
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The increasing integration of robotics in digital era has created a demand for intuitive programming environments that balance simplicity with computational efficiency. Automation Control Language (ACL), often employed in robotics training platforms, provides students with a structured method for coding robot tasks but suffers from complexity in optimization and error-prone manual interpretation, which hinders learning outcomes. The problem lies in the lack of automated tools that can analyze and refine ACL scripts while ensuring pedagogical clarity and maintaining execution efficiency. To address this gap, the paper propose a Syntax Tree Parsing for Automation Control Language Optimization (STP-ACLO) framework, which employs abstract syntax tree (AST) techniques to systematically parse ACL instructions, identify redundancies, and restructure code for optimized performance. STP-ACLO enhances the readability of student programs, provides automated feedback, and reduces execution overhead by minimizing redundant loops and control flow inefficiencies. Experimental evaluation conducted on robotics digital era simulators demonstrated that STP-ACLO achieved up to 28% reduction in code execution time and improved program comprehension scores among students by 35 %, compared to traditional ACL-based programming approaches. The findings suggest that syntax tree parsing not only improves code efficiency but also strengthens digital eraal outcomes by fostering better conceptual understanding of control structures. In conclusion, the STP-ACLO framework offers a robust and scalable method for optimizing ACL in robotics digital era, bridging the gap between performance and pedagogy while laying the groundwork for future AI-assisted code generation tools in STEM learning environments.

title: Linearity Analysis of Multi-loop Regulation Voltage Reference Based on GaN MIS-HEMTs
authors: Ruiqi Gong, Hengzhi Qiu, Yunsong Xu, Jiangmin Gu, Ang Li, Wen Liu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Wide-bandgap gallium nitride devices offer a high critical field, good thermal conductivity, and fast switching, enabling high-voltage, high-temperature applications. This work introduces a generic multi-loop regulated voltage reference topology on a monolithic AlGaN/GaN MIS-HEMT consisting of a D-mode and multiple E-modes. A 4-Transistor implementation produces a stable $2.33 \mathrm{~V} \mathrm{~V}_{\text {ref }}$ across a $2.8 \sim 50 \mathrm{V} V_{D D}$ supply while achieving an extremely low line sensitivity of $1.27 \times 10^{-10} \% / \mathrm{V}$. Closed-form analytical expressions for reference voltage, line regulation, and start-up voltage are derived to reveal parameter dependencies. These analytical results provide systematic guidance and practical design insights for GaN-based voltage references in highvoltage sensor biasing, power-integration modules, and nextgeneration intelligent power converters.

title: CRFAN Reimagined: Enhancing Cross-Resolution Attention for Super-Resolution Tasks
authors: Serena Gogoi, Nagaratna B. Chittaragi, Shashidhar G. Koolagudi
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: This paper presents a study of Cross-Resolution Feature Attention Networks (CRFAN) and related single-image super-resolution (SISR) frameworks. We review recent advances in multi-level feature integration, context-aware attention mechanisms, and architectural innovations, while also proposing refinements to the core CRFAN architecture. Our enhancements include adaptive spatial attention units, iterative reconstruction feedback loops, and improved optimization techniques, yielding measurable gains in image fidelity (e.g. PSNR). Rigorous testing on facial imagery datasets such as CelebA contrasts baseline and enhanced CRFAN variants, highlighting the impact of architectural tweaks and training adjustments. By combining theoretical insights with hands-on experimentation, this work strengthens the connection between algorithmic concepts and practical deployment, maps emerging methodologies, and identifies open challenges in cross-resolution enhancement systems.

title: Optimal Test Case Selection for On-Target Embedded Testing
authors: Varsha Peringothara Suresh, Farsana Shajahan, Sabitha S
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: On-target testing is unavoidable in the validation and verification process of embedded software. The presence of false positives or redundant test case data can lead to increased testing time and effort, and thus to an increase in the overall cost of testing. This paper addresses the challenge of generating optimal test case data for embedded software by proposing a table-based technique to select promising test data based on target branch coverage. The approach is implemented and integrated with the software testing and debugging tool, KLEE. The implementation is evaluated for its performance on a small set of benchmarks from the literature and it is observed that the approach demonstrates a reduction of test cases for selected benchmarks without loss of target branch coverage. The methodology substantially improves the testing efficiency for embedded systems.

title: Classification and Prediction of Soil NPK in Tobacco Fields Using Multi-Channel Reflectance Spectroscopy and Electrical Parameters
authors: Yingxiong Nong, Kangbai Peng, Jianqin Luo, Ying Lu, Cong Huang, Yanbing Liu, Huaguang He
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Rational management of nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K) is critical for tobacco production, while excessive fertilization wastes resources and harms the environment. Traditional chemical analyses are unsuitable for rapid field monitoring. This study presents a multimodal real-time soil monitoring system combining an AS7265 visible and near-infrared spectrometer (410-940nm, 18 channels) with sensors for soil temperature, moisture, and electrical conductivity. Data collected over four months were used to train and test an LSTM model for nutrient classification. Results showed classification accuracies of about 90% for nitrogen, 88% for phosphorus, and 65% for potassium. The findings demonstrate that integrating spectral and electrical data with machine learning enhances soil nutrient estimation, offering practical support for precision fertilization in tobacco fields.

title: Spiking Neural Network for Visual Attention in Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Mostafa Ahmed, Shady A. Nagy, Mohammed A.-M. Salem
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) with visual attention mechanisms offer a biologically-inspired approach for medical image analysis and segmentation, aiming to address the high computational cost and power consumption of traditional deep learning models. This work proposes a SNN architecture that mimics the brain's efficient processing for tumor segmentation in brain MRI images. We explore spike-based attention mechanisms and compare them to conventional models, highlighting the potential for energyefficient, interpretable, and deployable solutions in medical imaging. Our contributions include the design of a spiking visual attention network, a comprehensive evaluation against standard architecture, and insights into the role of attention in spike-based segmentation. This advances the development of energy-efficient, biologically plausible neural networks for medical imaging applications.

title: Global-Local Normalization based Model Pool for Online Anomaly Detection in IIoT
authors: Yuanzhe Liu, Yang Liu, Cunyu Zhang, Yaotian Dong, Shuxin Ma, Longfei Zhang, Yang Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Accurate online anomaly detection of multivariate time-series data collected from multiple sensors is crucial for Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) systems. A big challenge of online anomaly detection is how to deal with concept drift, the temporal evolution of intrinsic statistical properties of the data, which induces significant distribution discrepancies between training and testing data. Existing methods failed to adapt to such distribution shifts, leading to low detection accuracy. To address this problem, this paper propose a Global-Local Normalization based Model Pool (GLNMP) framework for accurate online anomaly detection in IIoT. First, a global-local normalization module is designed to simultaneously capture both short-term local anomalies and long-term global pattern changes. Second, we propose an adaptive model pool update module to address both the problem of model adaptation to concept drift and the overfitting problem. Finally, experiments on 10 real-world datasets demonstrate that GLNMP outperforms state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Study on Carrier Concentration and Signal Enhancement of SiC MOSFET Based on SCM
authors: Qin Hu, Fang Su, Di Wu, Qizhi Li, Yidan Chen, Jiamin Tian, Jun Du, Hongyan Liu, Kuang-Tse Ho
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: As a promising wide-bandgap semiconductor material, silicon carbide (SiC) is widely used in the industry for fabricating planar metal-oxide-semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFET). For these devices, carrier concentration and doping range exert a decisive influence on device switching characteristics and breakdown voltage. Traditional carrier characterization methods lack sufficient spatial resolution for analyzing micro-regional carrier distribution in SiC MOSFETs, whereas Scanning Capacitance Microscopy (SCM) offers distinct advantages in such microscale characterization, yet several issues compromise the accuracy of carrier concentration analysis-including surface roughness, stray capacitance, and low signal contrast induced by system parameters. As a predominantly qualitative technique, growing efforts are directed at establishing SCM as a method for quantitative characterization with nanoscale resolution. Herein, we investigate the optimal SCM test conditions for enhancing SCM signals of SiC MOSFET, focusing on optimizing sample preparation processes and debugging key test parameter. The mechanism, by which direct current (DC) voltage affects the SCM phase, is briefly discussed with considering the inversion effect of capacitance. Finally, a semi-quantitative method for analyzing carrier concentration in doped regions of SiC MOSFET is established by comparing the profile of PN junction with Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS) techniques. The proposed SCM signal enhancement and analysis methods provide a technical reference for SCM characterization of wide-bandgap semiconductor devices, and fills the gap in nanoscale quantitative characterization of SiC MOSFET. Additionally, this work offers support for failure analysis of SiC MOSFET, rational design of device structures, and improvement of device performance reliability.

title: Partitioning Kernel With Capability Controlled Temporal and Spatial Partitioning
authors: Henrik Karlsson, Roberto Guanciale
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Partitioning kernels often face challenges such as static resource allocation and insufficient temporal protection, limiting their applicability in dynamic and mixed-criticality systems where resource needs and security boundaries evolve over time. To address these limitations, we present S3K, a capability-based multicore partitioning kernel for embedded RISC-V systems. S3K provides robust spatial and temporal isolation, time protection, and dynamic resource reconfiguration, enabling flexible adaptation to changing operational requirements while maintaining strong safety and security guarantees. Its capability-based model ensures secure and efficient resource management, while in-kernel data partitioning prevents information leakage and mitigates side-channel attacks. Additionally, S3K's scheduler guarantees deterministic process dispatch, free from microarchitectural interference. Evaluation results demonstrate S3K's effectiveness, showing the absence of scheduling jitter, resistance to intra-core side-channels, and efficient interprocess communication. These results highlight S3K's suitability for safety-critical and security-critical applications in dynamic, resource-constrained environments.

title: Statistical Machine Translation for Multilingual Access to Medical AI Education Content
authors: Nilufar Khodjayeva, Bibijon Kurbanova, Makhbubakhon Yakubova, Muxammad Yusuf Po'latov, Kholida Matyakubova, Firuza Khayitova
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Statistical Machine Translation (SMT), as part of an overall human-centered machine translation process, provides a significant opportunity for multilingual access to digital content, such as specialized educational content in medical artificial intelligence. As medical knowledge is a continually evolving field of study and is critical for timely and accurate access by global learners and health professionals, providing accurate and accessible learning materials across many languages makes sense. The traditional translation solutions including online machine translation utilize outdated methods of translation that do not account for specific or context-relevant solutions, and domain-specific languages, terminologies, and linguistic affordances or preferences. Rule-based machine and general-purpose machine translation solutions will be limited in reflecting medical terminology and will ultimately adversely affect the translation quality and educational access provided. Therefore, here suggested a new framework called MED-SMT (Medical Educational Domain Statistical Machine Translation) to deal with these problems. MED-SMT is a domain adapted statistical translation model, with an established medical terminology database and a set of contextually grounded alignment processes that will translate medical common language. MED-SMT supports the translation of various medical specific language patterns and provides accurate multi-linguistic rendition of the original medical course content. The MED-SMT framework aims to allow the worldwide access to medical Artificial Intelligence (AI) education through the automatic translation of course materials (e.g. lecture notes, research papers, interactive tutorials) into a variety of languages at a minimal cost in human operator time. This will make it easier for medical students, professionals, and researchers who do not speak English to understand advanced AI content. Experimental results show that MED-SMT provides a notable improvement in translation quality and terminology consistency over the advanced methods achieving better understanding and knowledge transfer of medical concepts in medical AI education.

title: A Hybrid Cnn-Lstm Model for Short-Term Wind Power Forecasting with Meteorological Feature Integration
authors: Gaoqian Xue, Lina Yang, Shibai Jiang, Kai Zhou, Lulu Liu, Zhewen Niu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: Accurate wind power forecasting is essential for maintaining power system stability. This paper proposes a parallel hybrid Convolutional Neural Network-Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-LSTM) model to enhance short-term prediction accuracy. Core input features are selected using Grey Relational Analysis combined with Mutual Information Rate (GRA-MIR), which effectively reduces redundancy. The model adopts a dualbranch architecture: a 1D-CNN captures local spatial patterns, while a Bidirectional LSTM (Bi-LSTM) extracts long-term temporal dependencies. The outputs are fused through a fully connected layer to enable joint spatial-temporal representation learning. An enhanced Sparrow Search Algorithm (SSA) is introduced to optimize hyperparameters based on the validation Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that the proposed model significantly outperforms individual CNN and LSTM models, particularly in winter scenarios, achieving lower error metrics. These results indicate the model's effectiveness in improving forecasting reliability and supporting stable grid operation amid growing wind power integration.

title: Performance Analysis of Multiplier Architecture and Their Application in Convolution Operations on FPGA
authors: Reshma S, Subhitha GS, Jayasanthi M
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Convolution is a fundamental operation in digital signal processing and machine learning, and its efficiency strongly depends on the underlying multiplier architecture. This works conducts a detailed evaluation of Braun, Booth and Wallace tree multipliers on FPGA platforms, focusing on their role within convolution operations. The 32×32-bit designs were developed in Verilog HDL and synthesized using Xilinx Vivado, with performance measured in terms of delay, logic resources, and power efficiency. The Booth design exhibited the lowest power consumption (61.418 W) and smallest area (1026 LUTs), but introduced a longer delay (33.969 ns). The Braun structure provided a moderate balance with 21.428 ns delay, 81.587 W power, and 1073 LUTs. In contrast, the Wallace tree was the fastest (21.488 ns), though it consumed the most resources (115.416 W, 1479 LUTs). Within a 3-tap FIR convolution module, the dedicated DSP multiplier proved the most efficient (37.828 W, 15.594 ns, 68 LUTs). Substituting it with a Booth multiplier raised both power (62.979 W) and delay (18.903 ns), while leaving the area nearly unchanged (69 LUTs). Overall, DSP slices remain the most efficient choice for FPGA convolution, though Booth multipliers offer a compact alternative, Braun designs provide modularity, and Wallace trees trade power and area for speed.

title: Work-in-Progress: Optimizing IDK Cascades Skip Decisions Utilizing Random Forest Predictions
authors: Ronit Katikaneni, Albert M. K. Cheng, Thomas Carroll
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: IDK Cascades are a framework used to improve time usage within classification tasks. A cascade is comprised of a series of classification models with increasing levels of complexity. A prediction occurs when a single model's computed confidence is above a certain threshold; otherwise, an IDK classification is made, which leads to the next model in the series considering the input. A recent improvement to this scheme is the idea of skipping a model in the case where the prior model's confidence was extremely low. However, this method has inherent issues when predicting whether to skip. This paper improves on the method of skipping certain models by using a Random Forest model trained on multiple parameters, resulting in smart skipping. Unlike the previous threshold skipping approach, the Random Forest's is able to more accurately predict when a skip should occur, leading to larger time savings. Ultimately, we are able to obtain an IDK Cascade utilizing Random Forest skipping that is more computationally efficient than threshold skipping across three datasets.

title: Knowledge Distillation or Efficient Attention? A Systematic Benchmark of Compact Transformers for ESG Text Classification
authors: Yasser Elouargui, Abdellatif Sassioui, Meriyem Chergui, Rachid Benouini, El Mehdi Benyoussef, Mohamed El Kamili, Mohamed Ouzzif
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Automated assessment of textual disclosures along the Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) pillars demands language models that are at once lightweight and transparent. We deliver the first systematic comparison of two compact transformer families—knowledge-distilled models (Tiny Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers and Distilled BERT) and efficient-attention models (Fourier Network and Longformer)-on three balanced datasets of 2000 documents each, separately targeting the Environmental, Social, and Governance dimensions. All models are fine-tuned on a single 8 gigabyte Graphics Processing Unit and judged on predictive accuracy, inference latency, token-level interpretability obtained with SHapley Additive exPlanations, and concise resource indicators such as per-epoch training time and peak memory consumption. Distilled transformers achieve the best classification performance while offering significant speed-ups and memory savings relative to a BERT-base reference, whereas efficient-attention models become appealing only when inputs exceed four thousand tokens. Attribution analysis reveals that distillation focuses explanatory mass on domain-specific terms such as “diversity” and “emissions”, whereas efficient-attention diffuses importance across generic words. These findings position knowledge distillation as the most practical route for productionready ESG text classification under tight compute and audit constraints, and establish baselines to steer future adaptations of efficient-attention architectures to this domain.

title: Design and Optimization of a Wind–Solar Hybrid Micro-Generator for Electric Vehicle Battery Support
authors: T. Boopathi, I. Jacob Raglend
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The increasing demand for energy-efficient electric vehicles (EVs) is driving interest in integrated renewable energy harvesting systems that can adapt to diverse vehicle conditions. This paper introduces a hybrid micro-generator system that combines front-mounted wind and rooftop solar energy to support EV battery performance in real time. The system features a horizontal-axis micro wind turbine integrated into the vehicle's front to capture kinetic wind energy while moving. Photovoltaic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{PV})$</tex> panels on the roof generate power from solar radiation, particularly when the vehicle is idle or parked. Both energy sources are optimized using Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) techniques and regulated by DC-DC converters to supply power directly to the EV battery or auxiliary systems. An energy management control logic dynamically prioritizes input sources based on vehicle speed and solar irradiance. Simulation results from MATLAB/Simulink indicate that this system can supplement battery charge, decrease reliance on external charging, and slightly extend vehicle range, all with minimal impact on aerodynamics and weight. This study confirms the viability and advantages of a compact, dualsource micro-generator for sustainable EV applications.

title: Electromagnetic-Thermal-Fluid Coupled Simulation of the Leakage Flux Transformer with Magnetron Load
authors: Liang Zhang, Yaxiang Wu, Ziwen Zhang, Peng Si, Jin Liu, Junke Wu, Hao Qiu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The leakage flux transformer is a core component in the internal power supply circuit of microwave ovens. It not only has the basic function of voltage stepping up and down like ordinary transformers but also possesses unique voltage stabilization characteristics. The performance parameters and manufacturing cost of the leakage flux transformer directly determine the heating efficiency and market competitiveness of microwave ovens. At present, many scholars have conducted systematic research on leakage flux transformers, including their working principles, the establishment of equivalent circuits and simulation models. However, there are few reports on the systematic simulation modeling of the electromagnetic-thermalfluid fields of leakage flux transformers. This paper first introduces the working principle of the leakage flux transformer, then obtains the core loss and winding loss of the leakage flux transformer through open-circuit and short-circuit experiments, and finally carries out the simulation modeling of the electromagnetic-thermal-fluid fields for the leakage flux transformer, putting forward effective measures to reduce the temperature rise of the leakage flux transformer.

title: Hybrid IDS for IoT Approach Combining Deep Extraction and Robust Classification
authors: Nouhaila Sennouni, Jamal Elhachmi, Abdellatif Kobbane, Khaoula Oulidi Omali
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The rapid adoption of the Internet of Things (IoT) has significantly increased security risks, exposing networks to advanced cyber threats. In this paper, a structured analysis of the IoT architecture has been provided to identify vulnerabilities and attack vectors for each layer. To address these challenges, we developed a deep learning-based intrusion detection system, evaluated on the ToNIoT dataset. The experimental results confirm its effectiveness in detecting intrusions with high precision, demonstrating its potential to improve IoT security. This work highlights the potential of deep learning to improve IoT network security and resilience, providing a robust framework for future research and practical applications.

title: IoT-based Support System for Cognitive Fatigue and Posture Detection using CNN and Machine Learning
authors: Aadharsh B, Poongothai M, Dharunprakash J
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: In today's digital work environment, maintaining good posture and staying mentally alert during long hours at a desk can be challenging. This project presents an intelligent support system designed to promote ergonomic awareness and cognitive well-being for desk-bound users. At its core is an ESP32based sensor module that captures real-time pressure data to assess sitting posture, using a Random Forest model trained on four distinct sensor inputs. Simultaneously, a USB webcam captures facial features, and lip distance is calculated using Dlib to detect yawning-an indicator of fatigue. A CNN-based classifier, with an accuracy of 92.5 %, identifies yawning events. The system also tracks active applications and system resource usage via the psutil library. All data is sent to a Flask backend and visualized in real-time through Grafana or HTML-JavaScript dashboards. This integrated solution supports healthier work habits and boosts overall productivity.

title: Development and Implementation of a No-Code Portfolio Creation Platform using AWS Services
authors: S. Angalaeswari, Aditya Aryan, Souhard Aditya Sahu, Rohan Kumar, Aishwaraya Pandey, Aniket Baravkar, O. V. Gnana Swathika
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Cre8AI is a project built on Amazon Web Services (AWS) designed to enable users to create personalized portfolios without any coding knowledge. The platform, ideal for students, professionals, and individuals working under tight deadlines, offers 32 unique themes, project visit tracking, and instant desktop and mobile previews. Key AWS services used in this project include Amazon S3 for secure image storage, AWS Amplify for streamlined front-end development and deployment, and Amazon RDS for robust database management. This report outlines the development process and evaluates the effectiveness of AWS in creating a scalable, secure, and user-friendly application.

title: Design and Simulation of a High-Sensitivity Thermal Mass Flow Sensor Based on a Glass-Based Diaphragm Structure
authors: Rui Zhao, Qingyuan Liu, Rui You, Xiangyang Wei
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: To address the demand for high-sensitivity flow sensing in micro-flow scenarios, we presented a glass-based diaphragm-type thermal mass flow sensor. By employing a low thermal conductivity glass substrate in combination with a diaphragm structure, conductive heat loss was effectively suppressed and convective heat transfer was significantly enhanced, resulting in improved sensitivity. Using a multi-physics simulation tool, the effects of key structural parameters—such as diaphragm structure and electrode spacing—on sensor performance were systematically analyzed, leading to an optimized design for maximum sensitivity. Simulation results indicated that within a flow range of 0–5 sccm, the sensor achieved a high normalized sensitivity of 17.52 mV/(m/s)/mW with a low power consumption of only 6.61 mW. This structural design provides technical support for the development and further application of thermal mass flow sensors in high-sensitivity micro-flow detection.

title: Low-Light Polarized Image Enhancement via Multi-Scale Feature Fusion Network
authors: Zhixin Dong, Hao Wu, Xiangyue Zhang, Chengdong Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Polarization imaging provides additional physical information beyond conventional RGB images, making it valuable in various vision tasks. However, the quality of polarized images is often degraded due to inconsistent light intensities across different angles and the challenges posed by low-light environments. In this paper, we design a multi-scale feature fusion-based network for enhancing low-light polarized images (MPLENet), which progressively enhances low-light polarized image features through three specialized sub-networks: illumination restoration, perceptual enhancement, and polarization information refinement. Specifically, we introduce a lightweight multi-scale residual block and an intensity-polarization attention fusion mechanism. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on both the PLIE and LLCP datasets.

title: Dissecting Pain: A Study on Multiple Modalities Using Advanced CNN and Transformer Models
authors: Shubham Solanki, Tejas Jadhav, Prakhar Gupta, Sunil Ghane
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Assessment of pain intensity remains a significant challenge in healthcare. In recent years, significant advancements have been achieved in the field of automated pain detection. Modalities such as facial expression analysis [1], vocalisation patterns [2], and textual sentiment [3], each offer a unique insight into pain-related behaviour. This research presents a comparative investigation of three modalities - facial expressions, voice, and text - to perform pain detection and classification using state-of-the-art deep learning techniques. By identifying the most important landmarks, our proposed CNN-LSTM-Attention-based model achieved an impressive pain intensity classification score of 87.15%. In the audio domain, non-speech vocalisations (e.g., groans, cries) from the ASPVD dataset are converted into mel-spectograms and then fine-tuned using Audio Spectrogram Transformer (AST) to classify pain-related vocal patterns. This model achieved 80% accuracy in identifying non-speech vocalisation associated with pain. For textual data, pain-related sentiment was analysed using the EmoLit data set. By fine-tuning the RoBERTa transformer model, a sentiment analysis of emotions associated with pain allowed for a more accurate detection with a score of 95%. This comparative analysis highlights the unique strengths of each modality in pain intensity recognition. It also provides valuable information for multimodal fusion systems. The findings of this research aim to contribute to a greater understanding of developing more robust, clinically relevant and accurate pain recognition tools.

title: A 2.5D Hybrid Packaging Structure for Enhanced Dynamic Current Balancing in Multi-Chip SiC Power Module
authors: Baolin Liu, Zihao Chen, Lejia Sun, Hao Yuan
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Parallel operation of multi-chip SiC MOSFETs is an effective solution to increase the current rating of power modules in high-power applications. However, dynamic current imbalance leads to uneven thermomechanical stress distribution among parallel chips, which may further induce thermal runaway. To address this issue, this paper proposes a 2.5 D hybrid packaging structure that combines a printed circuit board (PCB) and a direct bonded copper (DBC) substrate. By exploiting the mutual inductance cancellation effect between the upper and lower current paths, the proposed structure effectively reduces parasitic inductance imbalance among parallel branches, thereby enhancing dynamic current balance. Simulations show that the proposed structure reduces the parasitic inductance imbalance from $36.4 \%$ to $5.95 \%$, while exhibiting excellent thermal performance. Furthermore, a double-pulse test circuit is implemented in LTspice to obtain branch current waveforms consistent with actual operating conditions. The results indicate that the dynamic current imbalance ratio is reduced from $37.26 \%$ to $3.55 \%$. Experimental validation confirms that the proposed 2.5 D hybrid packaging structure effectively improves the consistency of dynamic current distribution among parallel branches.

title: Does Interactive AI-Enhanced Learning Increase Study Time: A Large-Scale Longitudinal Survey of Japanese Junior and Senior High School Students
authors: Shiroh Ohno
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: This study investigates whether interactive AI- enhanced learning increases study time among Japanese junior and senior high school students, using two-wave longitudinal panel data from the Survey on Children's Lives and Learning. Fixed-effects models controlling for individual heterogeneity were applied to 1,705 junior high students (3,328 observations) and 1,095 senior high students (2,134 observations) who participated in both 2023 and 2024 survey waves. Results demonstrate that AI use is significantly associated with increased study time among junior high students (β = 0.077, SE = 0.020, adjusted p = 0.00028), while no significant effect was observed for senior high students (β = 0.027, SE = 0.025, adjusted p = 0.389). Furthermore, a problematic attitude that "AI Makes Study Unnecessary" is significantly related to decreased study time among senior high students (β = -0.101, SE = 0.030, adjusted p = 0.0018), but shows minimal effect among junior high students (β = -0.052, SE = 0.024, adjusted p = 0.041). Smartphone use is negatively associated with study time in senior high students but shows no effect for junior high students. These findings suggest that interactive generative AI can be beneficial for learning engagement in early adolescence, while excessive reliance or misconceptions about AI may reduce academic effort, particularly among older students.

title: Power and Performance Evaluation of Spidergon and Mesh Topology in Network-on-Chip
authors: Sai Kumar Reddy, Mushtaq Ahmed, Agam Kumar Singh, Bhavna Ambudkar
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Network on Chip (NoC) design is crucial in modern multi-core systems, where interconnect topology and routing algorithms significantly affect power consumption, latency, and throughput performance. This paper outlines a comparative study on power and performance efficiency of the Mesh and Spidergon topologies within the NoC framework. It also emphasizes the Spidergon architecture, which is often compared with the more widely used Mesh topology, owing to its circular arrangement of nodes with direct links to nodes that are diametrically opposed. Python has been used as an implementation platform, and various routing algorithms, including well-known XY routing, North-Last routing(NL) and Parameterized Randomized Oblivious Minimal routing(PROM) have been implemented and analyzed for different node configurations. The findings of the study illustrate that the Spidergon topology dominates the efficiency metrics of power consumption and performance when compared to the Mesh topology. Even in the least favorable scenario (XY routing), Spidergon achieved a notable 25.82 % more effecient than Mesh, with the maximum efficiency being 67.91 % over Mesh. This paper puts forward the Spidergon topology as a suitable alternative to other topologies in NoC.A major new feature of this work is using the DSENT(Design Space Exploration for Network Technologies) simulation framework to closely evaluate power and performance. Unlike previous methods that rely on analysis, DSENT allows for precise modeling of both dynamic and static power consumption using real-world factors like buffer size, link traversal, voltage levels, and switching activity. This provides a detailed, hardware-like comparison between Spidergon and Mesh network structures.

title: A Fast Single-Ended Protection Scheme for Renewable-Energy Dc Transmission Systems with Modular Multilevel Dc-Dc Converter
authors: Yu Guan, Yayu Yang, Jianjun Ma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The uneven geographic distribution of renewable energy and load centers necessitates long distance, high-capacity power transmission. In this context, DC collection and transmission system with modular multilevel DC-DC converters (DC-MMCs) have emerged as a promising solution. However, DC faults in such systems propagate rapidly, demanding fast and reliable fault detection. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a single-ended protection scheme based on the transient voltage across the current-limiting reactor. First, the fault equivalent model of the DC-MMC is analyzed. Then, fault characteristics under three scenarios are investigated: internal faults, forward external faults, and reverse external faults. Results reveal that the initial fault voltage across the current-limiting reactor exhibits a large positive value for internal faults, a smaller positive value for forward external faults, and a large negative value for reverse external faults. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed scheme can accurately distinguish internal and external faults within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 ~ m s}$</tex> across various fault types, locations, and resistances.

title: LIXO:A Smart Waste Management System Using Machine Learning and Location-Based Services
authors: EGovinda Kumar, K S Lena Shrinivas, V Dharun, M S Ananthakumar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Effective waste disposal is a critical challenge for nations worldwide. India alone generates approximately 65 million tons of waste annually, presenting significant difficulties for traditional waste management systems. This study proposes LIXO, an innovative waste management platform that integrates location-based public reporting, machine learning-based waste classification, and optimized collection routing. Through a user-friendly web interface, residents can submit geo-tagged images to report the status of waste bins. These images are processed using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to classify waste types and estimate bin fill levels. While CNNs are powerful for image classification, their performance can be affected by factors such as varying illumination, occlusions, and cluttered backgrounds, as well as challenges in detecting small or detailed features. LIXO addresses these limitations with advanced filtering techniques that prioritize bins requiring urgent collection. Optimized routing algorithms then schedule waste collection efficiently, reducing operational costs and environmental impact. The backend system provides centralized oversight and data management, aligning with smart city objectives for transparent and sustainable waste systems. Pilot studies demonstrate that LIXO improves collection efficiency, fosters community participation, and offers a cost-effective, practical, and low-intervention solution to urban waste management challenges

title: An end-to-end non-contact heart rate estimation method based on facial videos via continuous tracking model
authors: Xiwen Zhang, Zhanbin Zhang, Yunqi Wang, Meilin Wang, Bingo Wing-Kuen Ling
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: In recent years, non-contact heart rate (HR) estimation methods based on remote photoplethysmogram (rPPG) have attracted much attention. This approach estimates heart rate by detecting subtle changes in skin light absorption caused by blood volume pulsations. In this paper, we propose a novel end-to-end HR monitoring system based on the Segment Anything Model 2 (SAM 2) for remote measurement using low-cost cameras. SAM 2 adaptively tracks the region of interest (ROI) on the face, effectively extracts facial features under varying motion and lighting conditions, and outputs corresponding RGB video streams. The rPPG signal is then derived via the CHROM algorithm, and heart rate is calculated based on inter-beat intervals (IBI). Experimental comparisons with various ROI detection methods and state-of-the-art end-to-end remote HR algorithms demonstrate superior performance. Moreover, a key advantage is that it requires no scenario-specific training, greatly expanding its practical applicability.

title: Methodical Detection of Silent Data Errors from Foundry to Fleet
authors: Manu Shamsa, David Lerner, Arani Sinha, Thiago Macieira, Yogesh Varma
publish: IEEE Micro
abstract: Silent Data Errors (SDE) represent a significant challenge for at-scale computing infrastructure because of their potential to cause data loss or data corruption. Identifying and removing the defective devices prone to SDE before they affect customer workloads is crucial. However, detecting these events is challenging due to their subtle nature and the specific conditions required for them to occur. In this work we investigate the underlying defect mechanisms responsible for SDE and formulate an end-to-end framework for efficient detection, estimation of quality metrics, and use of fault models to capture marginal defects that may cause SDE. Silicon defect characterization, enhancements to manufacturing test and system level test, use of SDE estimation metrics, and use of reinforcement learning are discussed, along with in-field testing for detection of latent defects and wear-out that may manifest as SDE.

title: Fuzzy Direct Torque Control for a Nine-Phase Open-End Winding PMSM With a Modified Torque Regulator
authors: Chunliang Zhang, Haifeng Wang, Conghui Huang, Hongyuan Shen, Xibo Yuan, Xinzhen Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Direct torque control (DTC) has the advantages of rapid dynamic response and strong robustness, but its torque ripple is obvious. In traditional DTC systems, according to the equation of torque variation, the torque variation rate is closely related to the load and speed, resulting in the actual torque deviating from the reference torque in some cases, which degrades torque tracking performance. Moreover, in multiphase permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs), voltage vector (VV) selection in DTC is more complex. To address these challenges, this article proposes an improved DTC strategy for a nine-phase open-end winding (OW) PMSM. The primary contribution is the design of a torque hysteresis regulator that prioritizes virtual VVs that enhance torque, reducing the torque’s steady-state error. Additionally, a fuzzy controller dynamically adjusts the torque hysteresis band based on torque and speed variations, further improving torque tracking and robustness. Experimental results show that compared to optimized DTC, the proposed fuzzy DTC algorithm significantly improves torque tracking performance. Compared to fuzzy MPTC, it retains the advantages of traditional DTC, including fast dynamic response and a simple control structure.

title: MTRT: Multi-Task Reconstruction Transformer for Sleep Stage Classification Based on Internet of Things Enabled Wearable Devices
authors: Haitao Meng, Peng Liu, Xing Shao, Yongping Zhang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Sleep stage classification is an effective approach for diagnosing sleep disorders and holds significant importance in sleep research and biomedical studies. In recent years, sleep stage classification models based on machine learning and deep learning have achieved remarkable progress. However, several challenges remain. First, conventional deep learning-based sleep stage classification models struggle to effectively handle noise and artifacts, leading to inaccurate feature extraction. Second, the scarcity of minority class data, such as deep sleep and REM stages, prevents models from learning crucial features of these stages. Additionally, computational resource limitations hinder the deployment of previous models on wearable devices. To address these issues, we propose a Multi-Task Reconstruction Transformer (MTRT) for sleep stage classification based on internet of things and wearable devices. MTRT integrates multiple advanced techniques, including masked autoencoders, Transformer networks, Focal Loss, and model pruning, to enhance classification performance and applicability. By introducing a masked autoencoder within a multi-task learning framework, the model effectively removes noise and artifacts from EEG signals, enabling the extraction of high-quality signal representations, thereby improving classification robustness and accuracy. The combination of signal reconstruction and sleep stage classification tasks facilitates feature sharing between the encoder and decoder, enhancing the model’s ability to learn from minority class samples and improving generalization. Moreover, model pruning reduces complexity, minimizing computational and memory requirements, making MTRT more suitable for real-time applications on wearable devices. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed MTRT model.

title: From Strategy to Structure: Guiding Code Quality with GPST in Game-Based Programming Environments
authors: Chien-Wei Hu, Yi-Hsuan Liao, Hewijin Christine Jiau
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Enhancing programming skills is essential for developers to keep pace with technological advancements and to maintain effective participation in software development practices. Game-based programming platforms have been widely adopted to promote learner engagement and skill acquisition. However, without structured guidance, programmers may adopt ineffective strategies, leading to stagnation and wasted effort. This paper investigates the programming skills developed through ELOP, a competitive game-based training platform that has accumulated longitudinal programming data from hundreds of users. A mixed-methods analysis reveals that while ELOP fosters iterative strategy refinement, key skills such as writing well-documented code and refactoring maintainable programs remain difficult for many learners to master. To address these challenges, we present GPST (Game-based Programming Skill Trainer), an extended platform that augments ELOP with instructional features including automated code smell detection, comment quality guidance, and targeted training materials. GPST aims to support learners in developing clean, readable, and maintainable code while preserving the motivational benefits of game-based learning. Preliminary evaluation results from a small-scale pilot study (n=5) demonstrate the feasibility of GPST and suggest positive learning outcomes, while indicating directions for larger future deployments.

title:

authors: Aiwen Wang, Xinglin Piao, Xinze Zhang, Yujia Guo, Yong Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Big Data
abstract: The effectiveness of Transformer-based methods in tabular data processing has been extensively validated. However, most existing models primarily adopt Transformer-based encoder architectures, which overly emphasize feature correlations while neglecting the unique explicit information representation characteristics of tabular data. The significantly higher information density of tabular data compared to textual data introduces noise that degrades performance. Consequently, directly applying language models to tabular data often yields suboptimal results. To address this limitation, we propose the Residual Attention Transformer (RAT), a Transformer-based mechanism specifically designed for tabular data. In subsequent sections, the Residual Attention Transformer will be referred to as RAT. RAT introduces residual connections into the self-attention mechanism, effectively preserving raw information while capturing dependencies with higher-order features, thus enhancing the richness of information representation. Additionally, we design a simplified Transformer output head, termed Light-Transformer, which consists of a lightweight Transformer block specifically dedicated to the output stage. This design not only significantly reduces the model's parameter count, but also greatly improves training and inference efficiency. Extensive experiments were conducted on six public datasets to evaluate our model. The results show that the RAT model consistently outperforms other models in various tasks, confirming its effectiveness and superiority.

title: Biofeedback speeds adaptation to exoskeleton gait assistance
authors: Ava Lakmazaheri, Steven H. Collins
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Exoskeletons may enhance mobility, but users require extensive training to receive their full benefit. While augmented feedback can accelerate motor learning, it remains difficult to apply for exoskeleton gait assistance given that desired changes depend on complex multi-joint coordination and user actions are coupled to device control dynamics. We developed a visual biofeedback system to guide novice users of an ankle exoskeleton to modify their ankle joint kinematics and foot placement toward patterns associated with improved energy economy. Biofeedback-based training doubled the energy savings from exoskeleton use. Individuals who trained with biofeedback (N = 13) achieved a 23.5% ± 12.6% (p = 2e-5) reduction in metabolic cost of walking with assistance, compared to a 11.8% ± 20.9% (p = 0.06) reduction for a control group (N = 13). Biofeedback enabled new exoskeleton users to achieve benefits comparable to fully adapted users in one-quarter of the time. Participants had not fully adapted after the hour-long training session with biofeedback, underscoring the task’s difficulty and suggesting that greater benefit from exoskeletons might be unlocked with continued use of this approach. Energy savings were associated with increased exploration and progression toward lower-cost gait parameters in task-relevant dimensions. Our findings demonstrate that biofeedback can accelerate motor adaptation to exoskeletons, potentially enhancing their effectiveness and promoting broader device adoption.
