title: A Linearly Polarized Fed All-Metal Dual Circularly Polarized Planar Reflectarray Antenna With Independent Control of Beams
authors: Lu Guo, Jiaoqian Wang, Nan Qin, Rodica Ramer
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, a linearly polarized (LP) fed all-metal dual circularly polarized (CP) planar reflectarray antenna (RA) with independent control of beams is proposed. Since a linearly polarized wave can be decomposed into a right hand circularly polarized (RHCP) wave and a left hand circularly polarized (LHCP) wave, the designed all-metal element can simultaneously adjust its dynamic phase and geometric phase to compensate the phases of RHCP and LHCP waves independently, so as to separate them in the intended directions respectively. For proof of concept, an X-band reflectarray prototype in a circular aperture with a diameter of 380 mm and illuminated by a LP horn is designed, manufactured, and tested. Testing results indicate that with the LHCP wave pointing at -15°, the 3-dB gain bandwidth and 3-dB axial ratio (AR) bandwidth are 17% (9-10.7 GHz) and 27% (8.7-11.4 GHz), respectively; with the RHCP wave pointing at 15°, the 3-dB gain bandwidth and 3-dB AR bandwidth are 17% (9-10.7 GHz) and 29% (8.7-11.6 GHz), respectively. In addition, a total maximum aperture efficiency of 52.7% is also realized. Compared with other similar dual-CP RAs that employ CP feeds and dielectric substrates, the proposed design adopts a simple and less expensive LP feed and also an all-metal configuration, therefore demonstrating its advantageous features such as low-cost and stable behavior.

title: Integrating EDF-PI Scheduling with TDMA-CAN for Reliable Fault-Tolerant Real-Time Embedded Systems
authors: Wael Badawy
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Safety-critical embedded systems deployed in modern industries require architectures that are capable of guaranteeing both functional correctness and strict temporal reliability under unpredictable workloads. These systems must also sustain availability and fault tolerance despite the presence of transient and permanent failures that arise in real-world operating conditions. In particular, embedded platforms in automotive electronic control units, unmanned aerial vehicles, and medical devices depend on maintaining deterministic timing constraints and resilient communication even under stress. This paper introduces a hybrid framework that integrates Earliest Deadline First scheduling enhanced with Priority Inheritance (EDF-PI) together with Time Division Multiple Access overlays applied to Controller Area Network (TDMA-CAN). The integration addresses two of the most critical weaknesses in conventional architectures: uncontrolled priority inversion at the task scheduling level and nondeterministic arbitration delays at the communication level. The design was implemented on STM32 microcontrollers running FreeRTOS and validated with both hardware experiments and large-scale simulations under aggressive fault injection. The experimental evaluation demonstrated that the proposed EDFPI scheduler reduced deadline misses by up to 42% compared to plain EDF, while the TDMA layer reduced latency variance by 73% compared with arbitration-based CAN. Availability remained above 98.6% across extended fault scenarios. The results demonstrate the feasibility of unifying dynamic task scheduling, priority inversion protection, deterministic communication, and fault recovery into a single coherent framework for distributed embedded systems.

title: Next-Generation MCDM: How AI is Revolutionizing the Decision Support Process
authors: Mai Hesham Ahmed, Magdy Aboul-Ela, Randa Elwakil, Basem M. Ibrahim
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM) has long been essential for addressing complex decision problems involving numerous, often conflicting, criteria. However, conventional MCDM still faces limitations related to subjective bias, data uncertainty, and methodological rigidity. This paper explores how cutting-edge Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies can fundamentally transform the MCDM process. Building on a novel “divide-and-inject” framework, the study systematically decomposes decision problems into modular subproblems and injects tailored AI solutions at each step. This approach enables dynamic formation of criteria, objective weighting, automated alternative generation, and intelligent method selection, while ensuring transparency and scalability through step-local explainability and governance. Case studies from diverse domains such as healthcare, public policy, and education demonstrate the framework's adaptability and practical impact. The findings highlight AI not only as an auxiliary tool, but as an integral, orchestrated agent for building robust, adaptable, and interpretable MCDM systems. The paper concludes with recommendations for future research, including hybrid symbolicdeep learning models, cross-domain validation, and real-time feedback integration to foster a new generation of intelligent, explainable decision support systems.

title: Advancements in Leaf Recognition Technologies: a Comprehensive Review
authors: Khaled Suwais, Sally Almanasra
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: An important area of research in the scientific community is plant leaf recognition, which involves identifying leaves through image processing techniques. To achieve the highest accuracy, several different strategies using various algorithms have been developed. This study aims to offer an analytical evaluation of the numerous methods employed in image processing for plant recognition based on their leaves. These methods facilitate the extraction of valuable information for botanists to use in comprehending the medicinal properties of these leaves, as well as for other environmental and agricultural applications. Additionally, we provide insights and a thorough evaluation of the different methods researchers use to analyze various attributes and classifiers. To enhance the accuracy of classification systems, specific attributes and classifiers are being studied for their capabilities. Notably, Convolutional Neural Networks and support vector machines emerge as prominent contenders for their superior accuracy, as corroborated by our research findings.

title: Joint SIB19 and GNSS Data Fusion for Enhanced UE Acquisition in LEO NTN
authors: Harshit Gupta, Nidhi Srivastava
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTNs) pose special challenges for User Equipment (UE) acquisition with high mobility, high handover frequency, and dynamic link conditions. This paper introduces a new method that combines System Information Block 19 (SIB19) information with Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) measurements to improve initial UE acquisition and tracking in LEO NTNs. The suggested fusion framework employs real-time satellite ephemeris and Doppler data for proactive neighbor cell configuration and accurate time-frequency synchronization. Simulation results show better acquisition time, lower signaling overhead, and improved reliability under realistic satellite dynamics.

title: Control of a Nonlinear Liquid Level Processusing Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient Algorithm
authors: S. Praveen Kanna, B. Jaganatha Pandian
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents the development and training of a Reinforcement Learning (RL) controller using the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm for a nonlinear Multi-Input Multi-Output (MIMO) process, specifically the Interacting Twin Conical Tank System. A first-principles-based model in MATLAB Simulink captures the dynamic interaction between the two tanks. The objective is to manage varying reference inputs by adjusting the water levels in each tank. Observations such as tank heights, tracking errors, and integral deviations are incorporated into the mathematical representation of the system, forming the basis of the RL environment used in this study. In order to promote performance within system limitations, reward shaping is carried out using a negative gain and an absolute error metric. By directing neural networks toward the best possible behavior, reward shaping is essential to the training of reinforcement learning agents. By rewarding behaviors that result in desired outcomes, it increases learning efficiency. E rror-based <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r$</tex> eward s ignals in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$t$</tex> he <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$t$</tex> winc onical tank system enable the agent to quickly adapt, guaranteeing consistent control performance even in the face of operating condition variations and system nonlinearities. Through iterative learning, the trained RL agent effectively controls interacting conical tanks, progressively improving its control strategy. It ensures stability by applying higher flow rates at first and adjusting close to setpoints. Alternative RL techniques and real-time validation can improve deployment and cut down on training time even more.

title: Reconfigurable Ring-Enhanced Circular Patch Antenna for 5G and Dual-Band WiFi Applications
authors: Nouhayla EL Anzoul, Younes Karfa Bekali, Khalid Minaoui
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The development of new wireless technologies has increased the demand for innovative patch antenna designs capable of operating across multiple frequency bands. In this work, we propose a compact and reconfigurable ring-enhanced circular patch antenna optimized for sub-6 GHz 5G mobile communication and WiFi standards, including WiFi 2.4 GHz and WiFi 6E. The proposed antenna adopts a compact circular patch geometry, facilitating its integration into wireless systems and components. Frequency reconfigurability is ensured through the use of a PIN diode that acts as a switching element. The antenna structure is designed and analyzed using CST Studio Suite and Ansys HFSS, and is implemented on an FR4 epoxy substrate with a relative permittivity of 4.4 and a thickness of 1.6 mm.

title: A Multi-Layered Architecture for AI-Enhanced Learning in the Edu-Metaverse
authors: Chaimae Illi, Azeddine Elhassouny
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The Edu-Metaverse presents a transformative approach to digital learning, integrating immersive environments, artificial intelligence, blockchain, and learning management systems to create dynamic, interactive, and personalized educational experiences. This paper presents a multi-layered architecture for implementing the Edu-Metaverse, addressing the critical components needed for an effective digital learning ecosystem. The proposed architecture is divided into User, Application, and Data Layers, integrating Virtual Learning Environments (VLEs), AI-driven tutors, Learning Management Systems (LMS), and blockchain-secured credentialing. A potential small-scale prototype is discussed to validate the feasibility of this approach. Additionally, we propose and evaluate a policy synchronization mechanism inspired by federated learning that allows AI tutors across different virtual classrooms to share knowledge without compromising user data. This system is tested using Unity-based simulations and shows promising results in generalization and policy adaptation. Finally, we analyze adoption challenges and future directions.

title: A Deep Learning Approach to Early Warning Systems for Glacial Lake Outburst Floods (GLOFs)
authors: Sireesha Chittepu, Sanath Macha, Akshitha Reddy Sudugu, Shreya Burra, Amruta Kajuluri
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Climate change-induced GLOFs threaten mountainous communities and ecosystems with increasingly frequent events. This paper introduces a machine learning-based EWS that integrates IoT sensors and real-time data analysis to monitor key indicators such as water levels and temperature. The real-time data analysis was able to identify high-risk conditions with accuracy for instant alerts for timely response to disasters. This scalable system enhances preparedness in GLOF-prone areas, addresses the gaps of existing monitoring methods, and improves resilience in the face of climate-related hazards.

title: Position Control of Servo Motor Using Intelligent P Controller
authors: Kaumudi Sharma, Devakikrishnan H, V. Bagyaveereswaran
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Proportional-Integral (PI) and Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controllers have long been foundational in industrial control due to their simplicity and ease of implementation. However, their effectiveness diminishes in systems with significant nonlinearities or parameter uncertainties, often requiring complex tuning and lacking robustness. This research explores the application of the intelligent Proportional (iP) controller, a model-free control (MFC) strategy that eliminates the need for a detailed system model. The iP controller is implemented on a flexible, real-time position control task using a DC servo motor through MATLAB/Simulink with hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) integration. Comparative analysis against a conventional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P}$</tex> controller highlights the advantages of the iP controller in terms of steady-state accuracy, noise rejection, and ease of tuning. Results affirm that the iP controller performs competitively, even in dynamic and uncertain conditions, and suggests potential for broader application in power systems and robotics.

title: AI-Driven Real-Time Adaptive Camouflage System
authors: Sajad Ghatrehsamani, Dylan Moore, Shuvashis Saha, Lawrence Ong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: We developed an algorithm that replicates the cuttlefish’s ability to dynamically adapt its coloration and patterning in response to environmental stimuli. Our model is based on a classification machine learning approach to detect the biome in which the soldier is positioned, combined with ORB (Oriented FAST and Rotated BRIEF) detection to recognize, select and scale camouflage patterns. Our approach enables real-time adaptive camouflage by continuously responding to environmental changes. We also fabricated a small-scale prototype implementing the algorithm, demonstrating promising results and potential real-world tactical advantages.

title: UAV-Assisted Surface Hole Detection and Volume Estimation for Construction Site Monitoring
authors: Sabella Millicent Sefho, Sajid Mubashir Sheikh, Ali Akbar Firoozi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Construction site monitoring in rapidly urbanizing regions is hindered by the limitations of traditional ground-based inspections, which are often slow, labor-intensive, and lack coverage in hazardous areas. While UAV-integrated systems offer improved aerial perspectives, many existing solutions fall short in real-time volumetric estimation and rely on lightweight CNNs that sacrifice accuracy. To address this, we propose a UAV-based, multisensor hole detection and measurement system powered by a custom deep convolutional neural network called HoleDimNet. Unlike lightweight models, HoleDimNet is optimized for high-precision volumetric regression. Experimental evaluation involved handcrafted test holes measured at three UAV altitudes across four terrain types. HoleDimNet delivered more accurate area and volume predictions than its lightweight counterpart, achieving lower Mean Absolute Error and showing resilience to variable geometry and elevation at lower heights. This approach offers a modular and scalable solution for real-world construction environments. The HoleDimNet model, thus presents a tool for enhancing excavation planning, safety compliance and autonomous site auditing.

title: AgriTwin-Sim: An Interactive Digital Twin Framework for AI-Driven Smart Farming
authors: Yassine Ben-Aboud, Abdellatif Kobbane
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Modern agriculture faces unprecedented challenges requiring innovative solutions for enhanced productivity and sustainability. Digital Twins (DTs), coupled with Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT), offer a transformative paradigm for creating dynamic virtual replicas of agricultural systems. This paper introduces an advanced interactive web-based Digital Twin framework designed to bridge the gap between virtual sensor data and intelligent, actionable insights for smart farming. The framework integrates a high-fidelity simulation core, encompassing sophisticated mathematical models for environmental dynamics and plant biophysiology, with a robust AI engine capable of complex analysis, prediction, and decision support. Simulated data from a virtual sensor network feeds the DT, enabling the AI to perform real-time assessments, identify anomalies, predict future states, and recommend optimized management actions. The entire system is exposed through an intuitive and visually rich web interface that facilitates interactive exploration, scenario analysis, and direct visualization of the DT's evolution and the AI's reasoning. We demonstrate the framework's architecture, the formal underpinnings of its key components, and its utility as a powerful tool for research, development, and operational management in next-generation agriculture, showcasing a seamless pathway from data acquisition to intelligent intervention.

title: Adaptive RIS-Assisted User Management for NOMA in 6G Networks
authors: J Gurunadhan, Budhaditya Bhattacharyya
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) and Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) are rapidly emerging as vital technologies for sixth-generation (6G) networks, offering solutions to meet demanding criteria such as high spectral efficiency, minimal latency, and extensive user connectivity. RIS enhances the signal quality by adaptively managing wireless propagation without active transmission, whereas NOMA boosts spectrum utilization by concurrently serving multiple users on shared resources. Hybrid RIS-NOMA systems demonstrate superior performance compared to standalone configurations, particularly in terms of energy efficiency, fairness, and throughput. However, traditional clustering methods and static RIS deployments are inadequate in dynamic and densely populated settings because of their scalability and adaptability limitations. Moreover, reliance on simulations, excessive computational overhead, and overfitting in machine learning-based designs restrict their practical implementation. This study examines recent advancements in RIS-NOMA, focusing on clustering-driven allocation (CDA) and coordinated optimization algorithms (COA), and evaluates their strengths over baseline methods such as K-means. It also highlights the ongoing challenges, including hardware prototyping, complexity-aware algorithm design, and scalability, offering actionable insights to guide the development of adaptive, efficient, and user-oriented RIS-NOMA frameworks for future 6G applications.

title: Real-time detection of hotspot defects in photovoltaic panels based on machine vision and edge computing
authors: Defa Han, Yingge Li, Wenxing Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: When employing drones to inspect hotspot defects in photovoltaic panels, small-target hotspot defects often suffer from information loss during detection, leading to false or missed detections. Additionally, the computational resources of edge computing devices are limited. To address the aforementioned issues, this study proposes PVHSD2Net, a YOLO11-based network for detecting hotspot defects in photovoltaic panels. StarNet is incorporated, and improvements are made to the backbone network of the YOLO11 algorithm to reduce the model's parameters and enhance its real-time detection capability; The XSmall detection head is added to the head of the YOLO11 algorithm and the designed C3k2_SCConv module is introduced in the neck to improve the model's detection ability for hotspot defects of small targets. The PVHSD2Net model is verified on the PV-HSD-2025 dataset. The experimental results indicate that, in comparison to the original YOLO11n model, the new model achieves increases of 5.98% in precision, 4.15% in recall, and 5.59% in mAP50, while reducing the number of parameters by 24.14%.

title: The Impact of AI on Worker Productivity: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Moses Laksono Singgih, Akhmad Saladin Noufridhan Arzhanie, Faridah Rahma Yasnita, Faris Budianto
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has become a significant force in transforming the world of work, especially in increasing workforce productivity. This literature review aims to examine the impact of AI technologies, including machine learning, neural networks, and intelligent systems, on worker performance across various sectors. We conducted an in-depth analysis of 25 open-access articles from the Scopus database using a systematic literature review (SLR) approach based on the PRISMA framework. The study's results indicate that AI can enhance productivity by automating technical processes, enabling predictive monitoring, and facilitating datadriven decision-making. However, implementation challenges persist, including resistance to change, limited digital literacy, and ethical concerns. This study offers a comprehensive understanding of the drivers, barriers, and future trends of AI implementation in enhancing worker productivity, providing a strategic foundation for organizations and stakeholders to design an adaptive and sustainable work ecosystem.

title: A Multi-View Signal Fusion Network for Rotating Machinery Fault Diagnosis Using 1D-CNN, Transformer, and LSTM
authors: Tiantian Lu, Weichao Xu, Yanzhou Zhou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Intelligent fault diagnosis is essential for rotating machinery safety and reliability. While deep learning has advanced this field, most existing methods face three constraints: reliance on single-sensor data, single-domain analysis, and isolated model architectures. These limitations hinder the effective use of complementary information in complex vibration signals. To address these issues, this paper proposes a multi-view signal fusion network (MVSFN) for rotating machinery Fault Diagnosis that simultaneously fuses multi-view data and time-frequency domain information. The model integrates raw time-domain signals from multiple sensors with frequency-domain representations via FFT, forming a multi-view, multi-domain input. It employs a hybrid architecture combining a 1D CNN for local features, a Transformer for global dependencies, and an LSTM for temporal dynamics. Broad Learning mechanisms are incorporated to create lateral connections across stages, enabling both progressive "local-global-temporal" learning and cross-level feature propagation. Experiments on our datasets confirm that the method outperforms existing approaches, demonstrating strong potential for industrial applications.

title: Enhancing Housing Development under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana through Advanced Machine Learning and Predictive Analytics
authors: Ashwarya Negi, Lovish Tripathi, Sneh Prabha, Sudhir Dawra
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY) is a crucial initiative aimed at ensuring affordable housing for all in India. Despite its ambitious goals, inefficiencies in fund utilization, project execution delays, and resource misallocation persist, limiting the scheme's effectiveness. This study utilizes machine learning techniques, including advanced regression models, time series forecasting, clustering to analyze PMAY data, predict housing demand, optimize fund allocation, and assess policy impact. By leveraging data-driven methodologies, this research provides actionable insights for policymakers to enhance decision-making, improve housing completion rates, and develop a sustainable framework for future housing projects. The findings reveal key patterns in resource distribution and provide a roadmap for refining government housing policies.

title: An Efficient Deep Learning Framework for Retinal Diseases Diagnosis and Treatment Guidance Based on Explainable AI
authors: Yasmine Mohammed, Eman Amin, Rasha Ismail
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Retinal disease is a primary contributor to preventable blindness globally. Effective therapy depends on an accurate and timely diagnosis, but conventional diagnostic in places with limited resources, approaches are frequently unavailable, inconsistent, and time-consuming. This paper introduces a deep learning algorithm that utilizes fundus images for automated diagnosis of 13 retinal illnesses. It incorporates explainable artificial intelligence (AI) and a clinically guided treatment recommendation module. Utilizing a pre-trained ResNet-18 model and Grad-CAM for interpretability, the system achieves high diagnostic performance and offers heatmap-based visual explanations for each classification. The framework also integrates clinical treatment protocols, enhancing its practical utility for ophthalmologists. Evaluation on a combined dataset of 24,557 images demonstrates the model's accuracy and scalability. This approach reduces diagnostic errors, lowers costs, and improves accessibility to retinal care.

title: Corona Discharge Pulse Shape Analysis for Sphere Plane Configurations
authors: Pradeep Kumar Gupta, Maninder Choudhary, Pau Bas-Calopa, Jordi-Roger Riba Ruiz, Kaur Tuttelberg, Jako Kilter
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This paper aims to study the experimental corona discharge pulse shape analysis (PSA) for different sizes of sphere-plane electrode configurations at different voltage levels for AC and DC sources. To achieve this goal, experimental corona discharge signals measured via oscilloscope in the form of time-resolved partial discharge pattern (TRPD) were used to assess the peak pulse amplitude <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(i_{p})$</tex>, rise time <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(t_{r})$</tex>, fall time <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(t_{f})$</tex> and pulse width <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(t_{p w})$</tex>. The study is carried out on a sphere-plane configuration test object using the proposed pulse detection tool to detect discharge pulses and extract pulse shape characteristics of pulses acquired during a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2 0}-\text{m s}$</tex> time period. PSA patterns are based on the sequence of discharge occurrences. This approach might be very useful when corona discharges are examined and assessed, and can be utilized to comprehend the behavior of corona discharge at various voltage levels for different high-voltage sources.

title: Research on Adaptive Dual Fuzzy Logic Driving Style Trajectory Control Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yue Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Precise trajectory tracking is crucial for ensuring the safety and comfort of autonomous vehicles. Traditional PID controllers often exhibit limited adaptability under complex driving conditions involving diverse road surfaces and driving styles, while single fuzzy PID control methods face challenges in balancing precision and robustness. To address these limitations, this paper designs a deep learning adaptive dual fuzzy logic controller that integrates fuzzy PID, adaptive cruise control (ACC), and neural networks. The performance of the proposed method is compared against traditional PID controllers and single fuzzy PID controllers.This study employs a two-degree-of-freedom vehicle dynamics model and presents visual comparisons of actual trajectories against target trajectories under four control strategies: conventional PID, conservative fuzzy PID, radical fuzzy PID, and the combined fuzzy PID approach at the core of the dual-fuzzy strategy. Additionally, trajectory deviation trends are analyzed under two critical scenarios: first, varying speeds (80/30 km/h, corresponding to high-speed/low-speed driving) on homogeneous surfaces; second, different road surface friction coefficients (0.5/0.9, corresponding to wet/dry surfaces) at constant speed. Results demonstrate that the combined fuzzy PID strategy achieves significantly lower tracking deviation than other methods under all test conditions. This study confirms the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in enhancing tracking performance in complex scenarios, providing a valuable framework for optimizing autonomous vehicle control systems.

title: Randomizers in Video Games: Algorithms and Complexity Analysis
authors: Alexandre-Quentin Berger
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Many video games include randomizers natively or can be augmented with external randomizers. The goal of these randomizers is to change some parts of the game randomly, while keeping it playable and ensuring that the game can still be finished. In this paper, we investigate the problem of randomizing a game. We start by formalizing this problem as a labeling problem in directed graphs. Unfortunately, we show that a general randomizer (i.e., one that can possibly generate any finishable game) involves solving NP-hard problems as a subroutine. Motivated by this limitation, we define of a restricted family of randomizers that produce finishable games by construction. We present two polynomial time randomizers in this family. The first one is simple. The second one improves it with custom probability parameters that make the generated game more natural. Finally, some properties of these algorithms are analyzed theoretically.

title: Toward Energy-Aware AI: Optimization Strategies and Practitioner Guidelines
authors: Razan Bayoumi, Hanan Hindy, Taymoor Nazmy, Abdel-Badeeh M. Salem
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Energy-efficient model design is becoming a critical approach in modern AI development, aimed at optimizing computational resources while minimizing environmental impact. As deep learning models grow increasingly large and complex, their energy consumption-especially during training and inference can become significant, leading to higher operational costs and increased carbon emissions. This concern has led researchers to start prioritizing techniques that reduce power demand while preserving model accuracy. However, this shift is not yet universal. Many AI development pipelines still prioritize performance metrics such as accuracy and throughput, often overlooking energy efficiency during early design stages. To truly align with Green AI principles, energy efficiency must be embedded from the outset, guiding model selection, training strategies, and deployment decisions alike. This paper explores the essential stages involved in designing energy-efficient AI models, highlighting the strategies and methodologies that contribute to optimizing computational efficiency and reducing environmental impact while maintaining model performance. It focuses on two key perspectives: model architectural optimization, which includes pruning, quantization, and model compression techniques, and efficient training strategies, which transfer insights from larger models to smaller ones and optimize training efficiency to minimize AI's environmental footprint. This paper builds towards building the AI research community awareness in this domain, resulting in developing environment-friendly AI models.

title: Impact of Mg Doping Concentration on Hole Distribution and Transport in p-GaN/AlGaN/GaN Heterostructure for Complementary Logic Integration
authors: Yutao Geng, Yat Hon Ng, Tao Chen, Yan Cheng, Kevin J. Chen
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This work investigates the impact of Mg doping concentration on hole distribution and transport in the p $\mathrm{GaN} / \mathrm{AlGaN} / \mathrm{GaN}$ heterostructure. Hall measurements from 80 K to 600 K were conducted on three epilayers with different Mg doping concentrations in $p-\mathrm{GaN}\left(3 \times 10^{19} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}\right.$, $1 \times 10^{19} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$, and $5 \times 10^{18} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$). It is revealed that the higher Mg doping concentration leads to higher 2DHG density due to more out-diffused Mg dopants in the AlGaN barrier that can be ionized by the polarization field to form 2DHG. However, the hole mobility decreases with the increase of Mg doping concentration. As a result, a medium Mg doping concentration ($1 \times 10^{19} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$) yields the optimal balance, achieving the lowest sheet resistance ($32 \mathrm{k} \Omega / \square$) at 300 K, with a hole mobility of $12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} / \mathrm{V} \cdot \mathrm{s}$ and a 2DHG density of $1.1 \times 10^{13} \mathrm{~cm}^{-2}$. These findings provide key insights for designing high-performance p-channel GaN devices and complementary logic circuits.

title: Coala Enabling Platform: Advancing Low-Impact Agriculture in Australia with Irrigation Management Solutions
authors: Francesco Vuolo, Aleksandrova Jekaterina, Guido D'Urso, Oscar Rosario Belfiore, Carlo De Michele
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The COALA platform provides an automated data processing chain integrating Copernicus Sentinel-2 data, weather models, and robust algorithms for atmospheric correction, crop biophysical indicators, and evapotranspiration ET) estimation. This system delivers high-quality, scalable Earth Observation (EO) products, including irrigation mapping, crop water requirements, water stress monitoring, and fertilization support. Its Application Programming Interface (API) supports customizable outputs, seamless integration, and machine-to-machine communication standards. COALA's development was completed in 2023, with a three-year legacy phase planned to exploit results and generate new research and business opportunities. This paper highlights applications developed during the project in Australia, exploring their potential for deployment in new regions and use cases. The validation of the COALA satellite-derived products against district-level water irrigation volumes and TERN CMRSET actual evapotranspiration (AET) data showed strong agreement. For example, the comparison of monthly averages of ET showed a RMSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.63 \text{mm} /\text{day}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> of 0.91. Most divergences relate to standing water from flooding irrigation events that are picked up by the TERN CMRSET dataset and not by the COALA dataset. Technical and operational differences and their implications will be discussed and opportunities for further collaborations explored.

title: Enhancing Intangible Cultural Heritage Preservation: A VR-Based Learning Platform for Jiangmen’s Fish Lantern Craftsmanship
authors: Qingqing Yuan, Ratanachote Thienmongkol, Ruethai Nimnoi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Communication and Information Systems (ICCIS)
abstract: The transmission of intangible cultural heritage (ICH) crafts like Jiangmen’s fish lantern is hindered by the tacit nature of procedural knowledge and the decline of master-apprentice models. We present a virtual reality (VR) learning platform that digitizes both the embodied skills and cultural narratives of the craft. A mixed-methods study with vocational students ($\mathrm{N}=24$) and experts ($\mathrm{N}=6$) demonstrated that the VR group achieved significantly higher procedural fidelity, as measured by Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) ($\mathrm{p}\lt 0.01, \mathrm{~d}=1.58$), and produced structurally superior products ($\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{0. 0 2}$) compared to a traditional learning group. The platform enabled self-paced, multi-perspective practice and deep contextual learning, offering a scalable model for ICH preservation in vocational and museum settings.

title: Blue Ocean: A Digital Hub for Empowering India's Fishermen
authors: Vibin Sri R, Sherin Mithushiya P, Shanker Shalini
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Over the last few years, fishermen have experienced greater difficulties in maintaining safety while on expeditions and obtaining low-cost resources. The new platform offers a web-based solution in the form of an e- commerce marketplace coupled with a real-time maritime boundary warning system. The marketplace enables fishermen to purchase and sell fishing gear directly within the community, supporting economic development, less reliance on middlemen, and fair pricing. For safety, the platform has a real-time boundary alert system that sends timely alerts as fishermen enter restricted maritime areas, preventing violations and ensuring safer fishing. It also encourages community participation by providing a platform for knowledge sharing and encouraging sustainable fishing. The proposed system seeks to enhance fishermen's livelihoods, increase productivity, and spur sustainable growth by combining safety with economic opportunities.

title: Leveraging MinIO and FileCloud for On-Premise Storage-as-a-Service in Educational Institutions
authors: Atharva Salvi, Bhumesh Masram, Varad Deokar, Pranav Kolte, Shreyash Dhas
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Cloud storage has emerged as a cornerstone of modern computing infrastructure, vital for both academic institutions and enterprise organizations. As data volumes grow and applications become increasingly data-intensive, the need for scalable, secure, and cost-effective storage systems continues to intensify. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of private cloud storage technologies, focusing specifically on object-based and file-based storage systems. We evaluate three primary storage paradigms—filesystem-based, block-based, and object-based storage—highlighting their respective advantages, limitations, and suitable use cases. Particular attention is given to object storage due to its scalability, rich metadata model, and compatibility with modern APIs such as Amazon S3, making it well-suited for AI/ML workloads, big data analytics, and cloud-native architectures.As a practical case study, this paper presents a Storage-as-a-Service (STaaS) platform deployed for the Computer Engineering Department. The solution integrates MinIO, a high-performance, S3-compatible object storage server, with FileCloud, a secure file sharing and management system. This implementation provides centralized, reliable, and user-friendly access to data for students and faculty, supporting secure backups and collaborative workflows.

title: Explainable AI for identifying biomarkers for breast cancer survivability prediction
authors: Megha Rathi, Himani Agrawal, Bhupendrajeet Singh, Shobhit Bansal, Swastik Dixit
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Globally, breast cancer continues to be one of the major causes of death for women. This study suggests a machine learning architecture that has been augmented with Explainable AI (XAI) in order to find important biomarkers and improve diagnosis. After five classifiers were tested, Random Forest's accuracy of 94.68% was later increased to 95.21% by the use of Bayesian hyperparameter tuning. Force plots, beeswarm, and LIME explanations were utilized to highlight important features in both global and local feature interpretation using SHAP and LIME approaches. Interaction analysis and feature engineering using PCA improved model performance even more. Based on SHAP and LIME rankings, the top 10 features were chosen to produce the best results, which made the model accurate, comprehensible, and trustworthy for classifying breast cancer.

title: Remote Glucose Monitoring and Decision Support for Diabetes Management Using IoT and Deep Learning
authors: Vaishnavi S, Suprajaa D, Kiranmayi C K
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a chronic metabolic disorder affecting millions worldwide, requiring continuous monitoring to prevent severe complications such as hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia. Traditional glucose monitoring techniques, like finger-prick testing, are often invasive, discontinuous, and inconvenient for patients, especially in remote or resourcelimited areas. This study focuses on addressing these limitations by developing a real-time, cloud-integrated remote glucose monitoring system. The proposed solution involves an ESP32 microcontroller that simulates blood glucose values and transmits them to the cloud platform. A mobile application, developed using ReactJS, retrieves this data and classifies glucose levels as hypo-glycemia, normoglycemia, or hyperglycemia. Firebase integration ensures secure authentication, data storage, and real-time access, while additional healthcare features-such as doctor appointment booking and medical report downloads-enhance usability. Two machine learning models, trained for pre- and post- meal scenarios, enable precise classification of glucose states. The models achieved classification accuracies of 91.3% (pre- meal) and 89.7% (postmeal), with end-to-end latency under 2 seconds. This system enhances diabetes management by enabling secure, real-time monitoring and has potential for clinical sensor integration and predictive analytics in future applications.

title:
4H-SiC trench MOSFET with an ultra-low specific on-resistance of 1.87mΩ·c
                    <sup>2</sup>
authors: Yue Zhang, Song Bai, Shiyan Li, Runhua Huang, Yong Yang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Owing to its high operating temperature, high switching frequency and superior blocking voltage, silicon carbide (SiC) metal oxide semiconductor field-effect transistor (MOSFET) has attracted considerable research attention. However, SiC planar MOSFET has several drawbacks, including low channel mobility and large cell size. The other popular device architecture is SiC trench MOSFET (TMOS), which is regarded as an effective solution to lower specific on-resistance ($R_{\text {on, sp }}$) due to higher channel mobility and the elimination of the JFET effect. In this paper, we have fabricated the $1200 \mathrm{~V} / 10 \mathrm{~m} \Omega$ SiC TMOS with deep P-well region (DP-TMOS). Numerical simulations have been completed to study the proposed device. The maximum electric field in gate oxide of the DP-TMOS is suppressed to below $3 \mathrm{MV} / \mathrm{cm}$, while the $R_{\text {on, sp }}$ of the DP-TMOS is tremendously decreased compared with that of conventional SiC planar MOSFET. The fabricated DP-TMOS demonstrates outstanding characteristics, including a breakdown voltage of 1450 V, a threshold voltage of 3.7 V and a specific onresistance of $1.87 \mathrm{~m} \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$, which are comparable to those of state-of-the-art commercial trench SiC MOSFET devices. The fabricated DP-TMOS also demonstrates excellent avalanche reliability, which make the proposed device a competitive candidate for commercial production.

title: From Structure to Strength: A Deep Learning Approach to Edge Weighting in Graph-Based Community Detection
authors: El Ouatiq Meriem, Ait Abdelouahad Abdelkaher, Dahmouni Abdellatif
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Complex networks analysis requires a full comprehension of the interconnection between the nodes and how these interconnections give rise to community structures. This is done by finding clusters of nodes that are well connected within the cluster but relatively poorly connected with the rest of the network. Out of the many methods conceived to make this task easier, edge weighting has become an indispensable tool, allowing one to quantify the strength of connection in terms of the importance or level of interaction between the nodes. In this work, we propose a new mechanism of edge weighting based on representation learning using autoencoders. The model is trained using the network's adjacency matrix to learn latent structural aspects of the nodes in the network, which are then used as a basis of calculating pairwise similarities using an amplified Gaussian similarity function. As a methodology, this allows us to capture some of the more subtle structural patterns that cannot be identified through traditional local heuristics. Due to the experimental results, we show that our method can give the same performance in a community detection task to popular similarity-based weighting strategies such as Jaccard, cosine similarity, and the Adamic-Adar index, thus proving that learned representations may find success in these kinds of collaborations.

title: Importance of Doses and Dose-Response Modeling in Light Therapies: A Mini Review
authors: Zhuowei Zhang, Jianfei Dong
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: As a physical factor therapeutic modality, the effect of a light therapy strongly depends on the dose, i.e. the light fluence $\left(\mathrm{J} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}\right)$, delivered to the target tissue. Especially, it is well known that there exists a biphasic dose response in light therapies, where neither too low nor too high doses can lead to effective and safe treatment. Moreover, in the existing research literatures, the reported effective doses may vary in a large range even in treating a same type of disease. This, on the one hand, may be attributed to the lack of precise control and measurement methods of the therapeutic light sources. On the other hand, despite the large number of studies on light therapies and the underlying photobiomodulation (PBM) mechanisms, the research on modeling the dose response in light therapies is still very rare, because of the tremendous challenge in identifying and quantifying the related chromophores and signaling pathways. In comparison, in the other physical factor therapies, e.g., photodynamic therapy, heavy ion therapy and proton therapy, mathematical dosimetric modeling has already become a much richer research literature. This mini review paper aims at surveying the recent research reports about the doses and dose-response models in light therapies, and thereby attempts to draw more attention to these important issues.

title: G-Band Pre-Matched GaN HEMTs with 2.6 dB Single-Stage Gain
authors: C. Mi, B. Yi, Z. Hu, J. He, X. Wu, S. Xie, Z. Cheng, M. Lian, Q. Xie, Y. Zhang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In this study, we performed parameter extraction for the small-signal model (SSM) of Gallium Nitride High Electron Mobility Transistors (GaN HEMTs) using a semi-analytical approach. During the iterative process of this method, peripheral parasitic parameters are treated as optimization variables for parameter optimization, followed by direct calculation of internal intrinsic parameters based on microwave circuit network theory. Meanwhile, an error function is constructed to compute the discrepancy between measured and simulated results. This algorithm not only preserves the physical rationality of the theoretical model but also ensures the fitting accuracy of actual measurement data. Ultimately, within the frequency range of 1 GHz to 67 GHz, the simulated S-parameter results of the obtained small-signal model are nearly completely consistent with the measured results. Based on this small-signal model, we further designed, fabricated, and finally tested a G-band pre-matched device, whose pre-matching structure is designed based on Coplanar Waveguide (CPW) transmission lines. The device underlying this small-signal model exhibits excellent direct current (DC) and radio frequency (RF) performance, with an on-resistance of less than $0.9 \Omega / \mathrm{mm}$, a maximum current cutoff frequency $\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{T}}$ of 191 GHz, and a maximum oscillation frequency $\mathrm{f}_{\text {max }}$ of 331 gigahertz (GHz). Benefiting from the outstanding DC and RF performance of the device, the pre-matched device achieves a peak gain of 2.6 dB in the G-band. Furthermore, the measured results in the frequency range of 140 GHz to 190 GHz are highly consistent with the simulated results, validating the reliability of the proposed modeling method. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the first time that a GaN HEMT matching structure capable of achieving G-band amplified gain has been realized on sapphire substrates.

title: Super Twisting Sliding Mode Controlled Interleaved Boost Converter for Ev Charging Application
authors: Mohamed Imran A, Radhika P, Vengadachalam N
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The growing demand of electric vehicles (EVs) necessitates sophisticated charging systems that emphasize efficiency, reliability, and adaptability. Modern EV chargers typically has a two-stage power conversion architecture, consisting of an AC-DC rectification stage followed by a DCDC conversion. These systems often utilize buck, boost or buck-boost converter configurations. While conventional boost converters remain common, their effectiveness in highpower EV charging scenarios is affected by excessive current ripples and declining efficiency. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an interleaved boost converter (IBC) topology integrated with a Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control (ST-SMC), designed to minimize current ripple and hence improve performance in EV charging applications. The IBC's multi-phase current distribution mechanism substantially reduces input current oscillations, reduces inductor losses and enhances power capacity. The MATLAB simulation results shows a peak efficiency of 89% and decrease in current ripple as compared to conventional converter designs. Additionally, the IBC's modular architecture enables scalable power output for demanding applications and compatibility with renewable energy integration. These advantages position the converter as a robust solution for high-speed charging networks, delivering benefits such as lower electromagnetic interference, enhanced component longevity, and improved grid stability.

title: Instructor Effectiveness Evaluation for Industry Training Using Rough Set Theory
authors: Vinodha R, Saravanan R, Mahmudov Kahramon Shuhratjonugli, Xabiba Yusupova, Rajesh Sehgal
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Instructor effectiveness plays a vital role in the success of industry training, directly influencing employee skill development and organizational performance. Accurate evaluation of instructors ensures better learning outcomes and a more effective return on investment in training. However, existing evaluation methods often rely on subjective feedback, statistical averages, or weighted scoring models, which struggle with redundancy, vagueness, and uncertainty in data. To address these limitations, this study proposes a Rough Set-Based Decision Rule Extraction (RSBDRE) framework for evaluating instructor effectiveness. The framework identifies the most influential attributes, eliminates redundancies, and generates interpretable IF-THEN rules for decision-making. This approach is applied to industry training scenarios, enabling managers to classify instructor effectiveness with higher accuracy and transparency. Findings indicate that communication clarity, engagement, and post-training performance are strong predictors of effectiveness, offering actionable insights for instructor development and training quality improvement.

title: A Novel Framework for Autonomous Electric Vehicle Systems: 5G/6G Network Integration with Machine Learning and Multi-Access Edge Computing
authors: Ramya G R, Pranav S V, Goppinath Saravanan, Aswin Raksha S, Shrickar Nagendra Kumar, Leroy Samuel P
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: We propose a unified framework that integrates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> and emerging 6 G networks with machine learning (ML) and multi-access edge computing (MEC) for autonomous electric vehicle (AEV) systems. Designed to meet ultra-reliable lowlatency communication (URLLC) demands, the architecture comprises four distinct layers Vehicle, Communication, Edge Computing, and Application to support intelligent and scalable V2X communication in IoT-based vehicular environments. The system deploys advanced ML models, including LSTM, CNN, Deep Q-Networks, Support Vector Regression, and Gradient Boosting, on GPU-enabled MEC nodes to enable real-time decision-making, anomaly detection, and energy-aware Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) operations. We evaluate the framework using a co-simulation environment based on NS-3 and SUMO, simulating 200 AEVs within a dynamic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \text{km} \times 5 \text{km}$</tex> urban grid. Results demonstrate up to 22.5 % energy savings, latency under 5 ms, a packet delivery ratio of 98.3 %, and anomaly detection accuracy of 97.2 %, significantly o utperforming c loud-based a nd localonly baselines. The proposed architecture lays the foundation for secure, efficient, a nd s calable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> ext-generation intelligent transportation systems.

title: A Comparative Study based GRU and CNN2 Modulation Recognition
authors: Xin Chang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Automatic Modulation Recognition (AMR) plays a vital role in wireless communication. Traditional AMR methods exhibit limited robustness, while systematic quantitative comparisons have been lacking regarding performance differences between Convolutional Neural Networks 2 (CNN2) and Gate Recurrent Units (GRU) in deep learning approaches across varying Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNR) ranges. This study focuses on the AMR task, systematically comparing the performance of CNN2 and GRU across continuous SNR ranges from 0 to 30 dB, clarifying their respective application scenarios. Using the RadioML2018.01A dataset, with consistent hyperparameters and training strategies, the models were evaluated based on recognition accuracy and confusion matrices. Results indicate CNN2 achieves 50%-70% accuracy with strong noise resistance at low SNR (0-6 dB), while GRU demonstrates 80%-94% accuracy in medium-to-high SNR (6-20 dB) conditions, excelling in capturing temporal features. Beyond 30 dB, both models show slight performance fluctuations, with each demonstrating distinct advantages in specific application scenarios.

title: Mask Regional Graph Neural Network Based DeepLearning Techniques for Fish Identifcation and Tracking in the Underwater Environments
authors: Dhamodharan K, Thanapal P
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: An increasing number of underwater investigators have used video-based submerged tracking to observe ecosystem modifications over the years. The growth of the aquaculture sector has been hampered by the production of fish, and recording techniques are problems that arises during the hatching phase. Prior studies were unable to produce accurate results because they primarily relied on counting techniques that were not based on graph neural network (GNN). In this study computer vision techniques were used for visual object tracking of fish in their unaltered natural habitat. This study focuses on a duallevel GNN (DL-GNN) approach to model object appearance using Mask Regional Convolutional Neural Network (MR-CNN) activations. According to the evaluation results, the DL-GNN tracking techniques under investigation have significantly higher tracking accuracy than existing methods for fish tracking. Thus the modified Mask R-CNN model can achieve an accuracy rate of up to 98.62

title: Portable Microplastics Electrochemical Sensor: Combining Experiment and Density Functional Theory
authors: Jinhui Liu, Wanqing Wu, Jiaqi Niu, Ye Ning, Ziyang Zhang, Jing Cheng
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: The challenge of rapidly monitoring in-situ of microplastic pollution in environmental necessitates moving beyond conventional detection methods. In this study, a novel portable electrochemical sensing approach, guided by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, was developed. The platform integrates a three-electrode system with a portable electrochemical workstation, enabling on-site analysis of water samples from the environmental via a smartphone-controlled interface for data acquisition and processing. DFT computations were employed to gain a deep insight into the interaction mechanisms between microplastics and the sensor interface, elucidating the electron transfer processes and key interactive forces. The experimental results demonstrated a significant and sensitive electrochemical response of the portable sensor against microplastics. This work successfully bridges theoretical modeling with experimental validation and provide a novel paradigm for the development of high-performance detection technologies for on-site microplastic analysis.

title: Characterization and analysis of 4H-SiC hydrophilic bonding based on plasma activation
authors: Shuang Niu, Xiufei Hu, Dongyue Wu, Yong Yang, Muqing Zhang, Xiufang Chen, Rongkun Wang, Xuejian Xie, Huaying Ren, Guanglei Zhong, Xiangang Xu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ is emerging as an ideal material for highreliability MEMS sensors in extreme environments, owing to its excellent mechanical, thermal, and chemical stability. However, its traditional high-temperature and high-pressure bonding process introduces residual stress and limits device performance. To address this problem, plasma activated bonding (PAB), a low-temperature technology, enables highstrength bonding through surface activation and lowtemperature annealing, thereby representing a key breakthrough in the manufacturing of SiC-based MEMS sensors. In this paper, an optimized process combining plasma activation, SC1 cleaning, hot pressing bonding, and annealing in a protective atmosphere is proposed. The effects of O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> plasmas on the surface morphology, chemical state, and wettability of $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ were systematically evaluated for activation times ranging from 30 to 210 s. The results indicate that under optimized parameters, both plasmas induce no significant changes in surface roughness, thus achieving lowdamage activation. Through the synergistic treatment of ‘plasma activation + SC1 cleaning’, the surface contact angle was reduced to less than 2°, thereby achieving a superhydrophilic state. XPS analysis revealed that O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> plasma efficiently introduces oxygen-containing functional groups through directional oxidation, whereas N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> plasma also triggers concomitant oxidation under certain conditions. SC1 treatment forms a dense hydrophilic layer through surface reconstruction, thereby significantly improving wettability. Finally, high-area-ratio bonding was achieved under $350^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $450^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ annealing conditions. This not only verified the feasibility and effectiveness of the PAB process for lowtemperature, high-strength bonding of $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ but also provided both process and theoretical support for its application in the manufacturing of high-performance SiC devices.

title: Comparative Evaluation of ChatGPT, Gemini, and DeepSeek in Educational Problem Solving
authors: Daniel M. Muepu, Yutaka Watanobe, Amin Md Faizul Ibn, Mia Md. Shahajada
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: This study compares the performance of three large language models; ChatGPT, Gemini, and DeepSeek, on a set of programming-related educational problems from the Aizu Online Judge (AOJ) platform. The evaluation focuses on problem-solving accuracy and code characteristics, with additional comparisons to human Java submissions to contextualize model performance. Metrics include CPU time, memory usage, and code size, enabling a detailed analysis of solution quality and efficiency. Results indicate that ChatGPT consistently achieves the most efficient solutions while maintaining high accuracy, often matching the fastest human submissions. Gemini and DeepSeek also demonstrate strong accuracy but tend to produce less optimized code in computationally demanding cases. These findings contribute to understanding how current LLMs can address structured problem-solving tasks within educational environments.

title: Smart Child Monitoring System with Real-Time Danger Detection Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Rowane Ahmed, Clara Kamel, Marie Osama, Mehrati Sameh, Merna Tarek, Kareem Ali, Radwa Reda Hossieny, Doaa Ezzat
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Ensuring child safety within indoor environments has become a critical concern, as children are highly vulnerable to a wide range of household hazards such as sharp objects, electrical outlets, and fire sources. Despite continuous parental supervision, accidents can occur unexpectedly due to momentary distractions, fatigue, or the limitations of constant human oversight. These risks underscore the urgent need for automated safety systems that support caregivers in detecting and responding to dangerous situations before harm occurs. In this work, the proposed system presents an intelligent surveillance solution that employs computer vision and deep learning techniques to detect and mitigate potential threats to children in real time. The system processes live video feeds to identify children and surrounding hazardous objects using the YOLOv8 object detection model. The experimental evaluation demonstrated the system's robustness, achieving an object recognition accuracy of 98.3% and a child recognition accuracy of 96.5%. These results confirm the model's effectiveness in identifying hazardous situations promptly and reliably. Ultimately, the system offers a proactive and practical solution to enhance child safety in domestic environments. By providing timely alerts through a user-friendly interface.

title: Flexibility-Aware Network Resource Partitioning for Multi-State Real-Time Mission-Critical Applications
authors: Tianyu Zhang, Kefan Wu, Jiachen Wang, Chuanyu Xue, Xiaobo Sharon Hu, Song Han
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: A growing trend in large-scale industrial system design is the integration of multiple real-time, mission-critical applications over shared network infrastructures to reduce hardware costs and improve scalability. Recent advances in network resource partitioning techniques provide practical mechanisms for managing these applications hierarchically while maintaining operational isolation. However, as system complexity increases, applications often exhibit multi-state behaviors that challenge the system's ability to meet stringent timing requirements - especially under static resource partitions. While dynamic resource reconfiguration can restore feasibility, it is typically costly and disruptive in industrial environments. To address this challenge, we propose a flexibility-aware network resource partitioning framework that introduces a novel metric - partition flexibility - to quantify how effectively a resource partition supports an application's state transitions. Using this metric, we develop efficient strategies for both static partition allocation and dynamic partition adjustment, with the goal of minimizing reconfiguration overhead. We validate our framework design through a real-world case study involving a NASA extra-terrestrial habitat system deployed on a time-sensitive networking (TSN) testbed. Extensive simulations further demonstrate that the proposed partitioning framework reduces <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 6. 4 \%}$</tex> reconfigurations compared to the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Profiling Data Movement in SNN Memory Hierarchies
authors: Isaac Chee, Subrahmanian Hari, Kaustubh Harnoor, Colleen Josephson, Jason K. Eshraghian
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) process information via sparse, event-driven spikes. In hardware, this sparsity can dramatically reduce the volume of data moved between memory hierarchies, which often dominates both energy and latency. This paper presents a profiler that estimates the three principal stages of data movement-between register and cache, between cache and memory, and between memory and storage-and quantifies how increasing sparsity linearly lowers dynamic traffic while leaving static weight movement unchanged. This can act as a robust surrogate for energy consumption, helping deep learning engineers evaluate the viability of SNNs in resource-constrained deployment scenarios. Furthermore, it can potentially inform of optimal hardware architectures, for example, by evaluating dataflow efficiency or the impact of GPU-style DRAM interactions.

title: Adaptive Finite-Time Attitude Tracking Control for Quadrotor UAVs with Prescribed Performance
authors: Liang Zheng, Wenzhe Wang, Yunpeng Ju, Qiaoyan Sun
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: In response to the contradictory issue between convergence speed and overshoot in attitude tracking control for quadrotor drones, this paper proposes an adaptive prescribed performance control method. First, the Euler-angle attitude dynamics model of the drone, incorporating gyroscopic effects, is established. Next, a prescribed performance function is designed to ensure that the tracking error remains constrained within predefined transient and steady-state boundaries, effectively avoiding overshoot and insufficient steady-state accuracy. Furthermore, by designing a time-varying performance function to constrain the dynamic response of the tracking error, a nonlinear error transformation is introduced to convert the original constrained system into an unconstrained one. Combining backstepping sliding mode control with an adaptive law, the method addresses parameter uncertainties, achieves online compensation for rotational inertia uncertainty, and ensures finite-time convergence of the system states. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can rapidly converge to the target attitude while guaranteeing both transient and steady-state performance.

title: MindSync:An Enhanced Depression Detection Deep Learning Using Multimodal Data Fusion
authors: Alphonsa Sini P J, Sherky K K
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This study proposes MindSync, a novel multimodal deep learning framework for enhanced depression detection that integrates audio, video, and EEG data. In the preprocessing stage, modalityspecific techniques are applied: Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) are used for noise reduction and feature extraction from audio signals; MobileNet V2, MobileViT, and OpenFace are employed for facial feature extraction from video data; and ShallowConvNet, Power Spectral Density (PSD), and Fractal Dimensions are utilized to extract neurological features from EEG signals. A Light-Weight Self-Refinement Attention (LSRA) mechanism is introduced to refine and fuse the extracted features, selecting the most relevant indicators for depression classification. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves superior performance, with an accuracy of 99.11 %, a balanced F1score of 98.49 %, precision of 97.89 %, and sensitivity of 98.20 %. Furthermore, the model demonstrates rapid training efficiency, completing training within 10.28 seconds, and maintains low false positive (1.00 %) and false negative (0.92 %) rates. Extensive validation confirms the robustness and effectiveness of MindSync, highlighting its potential as a reliable tool for objective mental health evaluation.

title: UAV Batch Authentication Protocol with Trust Management Mechanism
authors: Nitish Bhardwaj, Kunwar Pal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles equipped with onboard units(OBUs) have ushered in a new era for the traffic management systems. With their aerial view and high mobility capabilities, UAVs have fast-forwarded advancements in the field. UAVs have become central to contemporary digital innovation, making every related field intrigued to look into them. With our increasing reliance on UAVs, it is equally important not to overlook the security concerns associated. UAVs communicate over wireless channels, making them vulnerable to cyberattacks. The resource-constrained nature of the UAVs limits the use of complex cryptographic standards. In this paper, we have presented a lightweight elliptic curve-based batch authentication protocol with a trust management mechanism. The trust-evaluated authentication aims to lower the number of invalid rendered authentication failure batches. The security of the protocol is proved using the widely accepted AVISPA tool. Informal security analysis using conventional cryptanalysis highlights the resilience of the protocol against various known attacks, such as modification attack, impersonation attack, man-in-the-middle attack, and replay attack. The protocol surpasses the computation and communication cost of various state-of-the-art protocols.

title: Improvement of the Traffic Light System and Railway Gate at Wonokromo Station Surabaya Using PLC
authors: Eka Rachma Aprilidanti, Wilda Prihasty, M. Firza Aji Zulfani, Sisca Dina Nur Nahdliyah, Aldi Yudha Pratama
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The Industrial Era 4.0 has driven the development of advanced automation systems in transportation management, particularly at traffic intersections and railway stations. This research aims to address traffic congestion and optimize the traffic system in the Wonokromo area of Surabaya by implementing an intelligent control system based on a Programmable Logic Controller (PLC). The research method adopts an experimental approach utilizing push buttons as inputs for the railway gate, an Omron PLC, and ladder diagram logic to coordinate the interaction between traffic lights and the railway crossing gate. The system is designed to detect the arrival of trains and automatically adjust traffic signals, thereby reducing congestion and enhancing safety. The results show the effectiveness of the ladder program in solving traffic issues at the study location, using three red lights and push buttons as inputs for the railway barrier. This study contributes to the development of responsive and efficient intelligent transportation systems.

title: Soil Moisture Retrieval on Sloped Terrains Using Airborne SAR Data for the Nisar Mission
authors: Seungbum Kim, Tien-Hao Liao, Mehmet Kurum, Andreas Colliander
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: We preset time-series soil moisture retrievals using airborne SAR data at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6}-\mathbf{m}$</tex> resolution on slopping terrains, to assess the capability of the retrieval algorithm. The goal is to support landslide and forest research, as well as the upcoming NISAR (NASA ISRO SAR) mission. The first test case is on a seasonally active landslide region on grassland with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex> slope in the northern California Coast Ranges, USA. The second case is the hilly forest in the US Northeast. A physically-based radar scattering model is used to retrieve the near-surface (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5-\text{cm}$</tex> depth) soil moisture. Over the grassland, the soil moisture retrieval using HH&VV shows unbiased RMSE (ub-rmse) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.058 ~\mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$</tex>. Polarimetric decomposition shows that the surface and double-bounce scattering dominate, which contributed to the successful retrieval of soil moisture despite the slope effect. Over the forest, the same airborne SAR observed a forest target over slopes with two different incidence angles, which allows the investigation on whether soil moisture retrieval algorithm can compensate for the slope effects rigorously. There are indications that the retrieval algorithm has successfully corrected for the slope effects but require future thorough studies.

title: AI-Driven Approaches for Geriatric Neurodegenerative Diseases Prediction and Detection: A Comprehensive Study
authors: Maram Hatem, Shaimaa Haridy, Naglaa Fathy, Walaa Gad
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Geriatric neurodegenerative diseases—including dementia, Alzheimer's disease (AD), and Parkinson's disease (PD)—represent a growing global health challenge due to aging populations and the progressive nature of these diseases. For efficient patient care and better quality of life, an early and precise diagnosis is essential. Complex, multimodal biological and behavioral data gathered from neuroimaging, blood biomarkers, cognitive tests, speech, handwriting, and motor function may now be analyzed with greater ease because to developments in computing techniques, especially machine learning and deep learning. Promising outcomes have been shown in the classification of disease stages, prediction of progression, and differentiation among related disorders using methods like convolutional neural networks, random forests, support vector machines, and ensemble classifiers. Personalized diagnosis across a range of patient populations is supported and model interpretability is improved through the integration of demographic, clinical, and multisource biological data. However, there are still issues with managing data variability, addressing disease heterogeneity, guaranteeing model generalizability, and promoting clinical translation. This review highlights methodological advancements, existing limitations, and future research directions towards scalable, dependable, and clinically impactful diagnostic systems. It also summarizes the most recent AI-driven approaches for the early detection and classification of geriatric neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Input-Output Data Driven Intelligent $H_{\infty}$ Fault-Tolerant Tracking Control for Industrial Process in Industry 5.0
authors: Limin Wang, Linzhu Jia, Ridong Zhang
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Dear Editor, This letter investigates a data-driven <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$H_{\infty}$</tex> feedback fault-tolerant tracking control problem using off-policy Q-learning, focusing on challenges such as unobservable system states, external disturbances, and actuator faults in industrial processes. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulations on an injection molding process.
