title: Beamforming Design and Satellite Selection for Realizing the Integrated Communication and Navigation in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Jiajing Li, Binghong Liu, Yaohua Sun, Mugen Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Relying on the powerful communication capabilities and rapidly changing geometric configurations, Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites have become strong candidates for offering the integrated communication and navigation (ICAN) services in future sixth generation (6G) networks. Considering the distinct performance and resource requirements, how to strike a balance between communication and navigation is one of the key design issues in LEO-ICAN systems. Against this backdrop, we take the transmission rate and geometric dilution of precision (GDOP) as evaluation metrics of communication and navigation performance, respectively, and formulate a weighted rate and GDOP maximization problem by jointly optimizing the beamforming design and satellite selection. To deal with the optimization problem, we split the original problem into the beamforming design and satellite selection subproblems, and propose a two-layer resource allocation algorithm to solve these subproblems iteratively until convergence. Specifically, in the inner layer, the beamforming design is modeled as a difference-of-convex (DC) problem, and the DC programming method is applied to maximize the communication rate. In the outer layer, the satellite selection is modeled as an overlapping coalition formation (OCF) game, and the OCF-based satellite selection algorithm is proposed to simultaneously reconcile the navigation GDOP. Extensive simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithms and reveal the trade-off between communication and navigation performance.

title: Respiratory Sensors Based on Force-sensitive Resistor and Piezoelectric Disk for Continuous Respiration Monitoring
authors: Bahram Rashidi
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In this paper, we present two respiratory sensors for monitoring and evaluating inhalation and exhalation. The proposed sensors and circuits detect normal and abnormal respiratory activity. These structures are based on a force-sensitive resistor sensor and a piezoelectric disk, offering a low-cost solution. The first design relies on changes in the resistance of a pressure sensor, while the second operates based on voltage variations generated by a piezoelectric disk. Since the forces of abdominal and chest breathing are relatively low, the sensors are designed to be highly sensitive to these variations. Additionally, we developed two circuits with LED displays to show inhalation and exhalation power, and one with an LCD to measure and display the respiratory rate. Breathing intensity can be visually identified by turning the LEDs on and off. The materials used and the performance of these sensors make the device a cost-effective, portable, user-friendly, and reliable alternative to current wearable smart health devices. The sensors have been tested, and the results are satisfactory. We successfully monitored various breathing patterns, including normal breathing, deep breathing, rapid breathing, weak breathing, and apnea, which are applicable for breath monitoring and data recording. Based on the results, the proposed structures demonstrate acceptable performance in respiration monitoring systems.

authors: Imed Hadj-Kacem
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: The mathematical function ln(1 + x) is used in various research fields and has great importance in multiple applications. Within the context of cellular networks, it is utilized to compute the achievable data rate for a given user. This paper explores the approximations of the function ln(1+x) to propose bounds for the average data rate. Initially, we adapt some approximations of the function ln(1+x) found in existing literature for the computation of the mean data rate. Then, we introduce several approximations of the function ln(1+x) that enable the derivation of simplified and accurate expressions for lower and upper bounds of the average data rate. These new bounds reduce the time and memory complexity of implementation compared to the exact expression of the average data rate, making them easily integrated into planning and optimization tools.

title: Quantum Multi-View Feature Selection With Configurable Kernel Circuits and Adaptive Fusion
authors: Jiaye Li, Hang Xu, Gang Chen, Shichao Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Quantum feature selection offers a powerful route to extracting informative features from high-dimensional data by exploiting quantum parallelism and superposition. However, most existing methods focus on single-view data and fail to address the challenges of multi-view scenarios, where heterogeneous views must be integrated while maintaining the fidelity of each view. In such scenarios, achieving both inter-view complementarity and intra-view consistency is difficult due to complex dependencies and latent structures within each view. To address this problem, we propose Quantum Multi-View Feature Selection (QMVFS), a unified framework that combines configurable quantum kernel circuits with adaptive multi-kernel fusion. For each view, configurable quantum kernel circuits with distinct architectures and parameterizations embed data into a Hilbert space, producing diverse kernel representations. An integrated optimization objective jointly learns view weights, fuses multiple kernels, and enforces sparsity, enabling QMVFS to capture inter-view synergy while preserving intra-view structures. Experiments on six public multi-view datasets show that QMVFS outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by an average of 4.44% in classification accuracy, demonstrating its effectiveness and adaptability for quantum-enhanced multi-view learning. Source code is available at: https://github.com/xhchangsha/Quantum-Multi-View-Feature-Selection.

title: DMRAD: Dynamic Decomposition and Memory-Aware Reconstruction for Noise-Resilient Multivariate Time Series Anomaly Detection
authors: Zhenchang Xia, Jun Ma, Bolong Zheng, Liangliang Wang, Yanan Chang, Jianqun Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Unsupervised anomaly detection in multivariate time series can prevent large-scale system failures and is crucial for various applications. Most existing methods only consider a single temporal pattern and insufficiently model the normal pattern, causing the model to learn incorrect temporal patterns from anomalous or noisy data. This poses a significant challenge for accurate anomaly detection. To overcome these challenges, we introduce a new dynamic decomposition and reconstruction anomaly detection algorithm, DMRAD. DMRAD captures various regular patterns of multivariate time series by designing a dynamic decomposition module that learns trend and seasonal features. By integrating improved channel and temporal attention mechanisms, DMRAD effectively learns the correlations within the sequence and dependencies across different sequences, thereby enhancing the model's capacity to distinguish between features and extract relevant information. DMRAD incorporates a latent anomaly-noise detection algorithm to identify and suppress the influence of noise and latent anomalies, elevating the overall accuracy of anomaly detection. Extensive experimental comparisons demonstrate that DMRAD achieves state-of-the-art performance on a variety of datasets for real-world application scenarios.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Hyper-Heuristic for Time-Dependent Green Logistics With Crowdsourcing
authors: Chu Tang, Qu Wei, Jingbin He, Guido Perboli, Hu Qin, Kang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The rapid growth of e-commerce has increased the complexity of supply chain management, particularly in urban logistics where efficiency and sustainability are critical concerns. In response, this study proposes a selection hyper-heuristic framework for time-dependent green logistics, incorporating key factors such as economic costs, carbon emissions, rider types, real-time traffic conditions, and time-window constraints. To address the complexities introduced by these real-world factors, we design a two-layer distribution model with crowdsourced delivery that covers the flow from city distribution centers to regional hubs and ultimately to end customers. The first layer involves location selection and the delivery process, while the second layer focuses on order allocation and last-mile delivery. For the location selection and order allocation problems, exact optimization models are developed to obtain high-quality solutions. In the delivery process, we integrate Deep Reinforcement Learning to replace the traditional adaptive layer of the Adaptive Large Neighborhood Search algorithm, enabling dynamic and intelligent adjustments during the search. Comparative analyses against existing and traditional methods across various benchmark instances demonstrate the superior efficiency and solution quality of the proposed framework. Simulation experiments based on a real-world road network in China validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework. In addition, the well-trained model can be directly applied to various scenarios, highlighting its strong generalization capability.

title: Optimizing Management of Persistent Data Structures in High-Performance Analytics
authors: Karim Youssef, Keita Iwabuchi, Maya Gokhale, Wu-chun Feng, Roger Pearce
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Large-scale data analytics workflows ingest massive input data into various data structures, including graphs and key-value datastores. These data structures undergo multiple transformations and computations and are typically reused in incremental and iterative analytics workflows. Persisting in-memory views of these data structures enables reusing them beyond the scope of a single program run while avoiding repetitive raw data ingestion overheads. Memory-mapped I/O enables persisting in-memory data structures without data serialization and deserialization overheads. However, memory-mapped I/O lacks the key feature of persisting consistent snapshots of these data structures for incremental ingestion and processing. The obstacles to efficient virtual memory snapshots using memory-mapped I/O include background writebacks outside the application's control, and the significantly high storage footprint of such snapshots. To address these limitations, we present Privateer, a memory and storage management tool that enables storage-efficient virtual memory snapshotting while also optimizing snapshot I/O performance. We integrated Privateer into Metall, a state-of-the-art persistent memory allocator for C++, and the Lightning Memory-Mapped Database (LMDB), a widely-used key-value datastore in data analytics and machine learning. Privateer optimized application performance by 1.22× when storing data structure snapshots to node-local storage, and up to 16.7× when storing snapshots to a parallel file system. Privateer also optimizes storage efficiency of incremental data structure snapshots by up to 11× using data deduplication and compression.

title: An Ultra-Low-Harmonic Composite Control Strategy for Single-Phase PWM Rectifiers
authors: Qingqing He, Zhaoyang Tang, Zhong Wang, Li Zhu, Keliang Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: In this paper, a tailor-made ultra-low-harmonic composite control strategy is proposed for single-phase PWM rectifiers with LCL filter to completely eliminate grid current harmonic distortions in the presence of various system disturbances, such as DC bus voltage ripples, grid voltage distortions, grid frequency variations, and so on. This strategy adopts a double-loop control structure. In the outer voltage loop, a moving average filter (MAF) is added to the PI controller. The MAF could completely suppress harmonic interference induced by DC bus voltage fluctuations, and then enables the generation of a clean reference current. In the inner current loop, a weighted average inductive current (WAIC) controller was developed, which significantly simplifies the control design. Moreover, a frequency adaptive repetition controller (FARC) is added to eliminate the harmonic distortion of grid current caused by grid voltage distortion in the presence of grid frequency variation. Experimental results of a 1kVA single-phase PWM rectifier with LCL filter demonstrate that, compared with conventional control schemes, the proposed control strategy could enable PWM rectifiers to produce ultra-low-harmonic grid current with the total harmonic distortion (THD) below 1% while maintaining fast and robust voltage and current responses in the presence of significant system disturbances.

title: A Clinically Validated Multi-Model Fusion Framework Integrating Machine Learning and LSTM Networks for Real Time Geriatric Frailty Assessment
authors: Mukul Kumar, Si-Huei Lee, Yi-An Chien, Eric Hsiao-Kuang Wu, Chun-Chuan Chen, Shih-Ching Yeh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Detecting frailty early and objectively is crucial for preventing falls and maintaining independence in older adults, yet traditional assessments remain subjective and resource intensive. We developed a portable, real time frailty assessment system using a consumer grade depth camera (RealSense D435) with Nuitrack for skeletal tracking. From 3D gait data, temporal and kinematic features were extracted and evaluated using five classical machine learning models and an Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network. To address limitations of prior work such as reliance on single model classifiers, wearable sensor constraints, and depth camera studies limited to Parkinson’s or fall-risk tasks we introduce a hierarchical multi-model fusion framework that integrates LSTM derived temporal representations with lower limb skeletal features. This architecture enhances robustness to noise, improves generalization on small clinical datasets, and enables real time non-wearable frailty assessment using only a monocular depth sensor. In a clinical study involving 120 gait samples across three sites, CatBoost and ensemble models achieved 97% accuracy. With multi-model fusion, performance improved to an F1-score of 0.98 and reached 100% accuracy across four frailty levels. This clinically validated framework provides a fast, objective, and scalable solution for geriatric frailty assessment in hospitals, homes, and tele-health settings.

title: Probing In-Orbit Radiation Environment with Sentinel-1 A & B Single Event Effects on Payload Mass Memories
authors: V. Pietrosanti, R. Mancini, G. Ferrari, A. Leo, R. Marec, S. Francola
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: In-orbit Single Event Effects (SEEs) data collected from the payload mass memory units of the Sentinel-1A and Sentinel-1B satellites are analyzed and compared with simulation-based predictions. In-orbit telemetry data on Single Event Functional Interrupts (SEFIs) and on Single Event Upsets (SEUs) corrections performed by on-board error correction codes are retrieved and employed for the radiation analysis. The simulations are derived from ground-based irradiation test data, information on the space radiation environment, and detailed three-dimensional CAD representations of the satellite architecture and on-board electronic components. The analysis focuses on radiation-sensitive SDRAM devices integrated within the mass memory units, which serve as effective in-orbit radiation monitors. The in-orbit SEFI rate data are compared with simulated rates performed using industry-standard tools based on space environmental models. The availability of precise geometrical information from the satellite down to the component level supports a correlation analysis between SEU rate and the shielding thickness provided by the satellite structure. Finally, the correlation between solar activity and in-orbit SEFI rate trend is analyzed over the short-, medium- and long-term periods and across different phases of the solar cycle.

title: The Loss Separation and Global Hotspot Optimization of High-Speed Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Systems
authors: Boyu Chen, Jiwei Cao, Sen Yan, Yanbo Wang, Liyi Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: At present, the motors of propulsion systems in the aviation field are developing towards higher speed and lighter weight. However, the significant increase in electromagnetic loss under high-frequency operating conditions and thermal management issues have severely restricted the progress in this field. To this end, this paper proposes a system loss analysis and global magneto-thermal collaborative optimization method for quantifying the air-gap flux density. This method, based on the surface current method, constructs a two-dimensional magnetic field analytical model of an arbitrary shape permanent magnet array and establishes a magnetic circuit model considering the nonlinearity of the core. By quantifying the contribution mechanism of the air-gap flux density to the core loss and the eddy current loss of permanent magnets, the main parameters such as the permanent magnet array were extracted to optimize the electromagnetic loss. Then, an electromagnetic-thermal coupling node model was developed to investigate the temperature rise at the hot spot of the motor, and the temperature field optimization was carried out for the situation where the temperature rise at the hot spot was too high. Finally, an experimental platform was built, and load temperature rise tests were conducted on 60kW, 60,000 rpm high-speed permanent magnet synchronous motors under different cooling conditions. Theoretical analysis and experimental results provide important guiding suggestions for the global optimization of high-speed motors.

title: A Graph-Enhanced DeepONet Approach for Real-Time Estimating Hydrogen-Enriched Natural Gas Flow Under Variable Operations
authors: Sicheng Liu, Hongchang Huang, Bo Yang, Mingxuan Cai, Xu Yang, Xinping Guan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: Blending green hydrogen into natural gas presents a promising approach for renewable energy integration and fuel decarbonization. Accurate estimation of hydrogen concentration in hydrogen-enriched natural gas (HENG) pipeline networks is crucial for operational safety and efficiency, yet it remains challenging due to complex dynamics. While existing data-driven approaches adopt end-to-end architectures for HENG flow state estimation, their limited adaptability to varying operational conditions hinders practical applications. To this end, this study proposes a real-time estimator for HENG hydrogen concentration in the pipeline network under variable operations. The estimator is realized by a customized graph-enhanced DeepONet structure, where a dual-network architecture integrates operational information and target spatiotemporal location, and outputs the estimated hydrogen concentration. Moreover, cross-attention layers and graph attention layers are adopted, aiming to handle the missing boundary hydrogen concentrations and achieve high-performance aggregation about pipeline operational features. Case studies demonstrate that the customized structure achieves superior estimation accuracy for HENG concentration under varying operational conditions.

title: Battery Discharge Capacity Estimation Using Pearson Correlation Retrieval-Based Deep Learning with Initial Cycle Data
authors: Yunseo Jang, Kyoung-Tak Kim, Chun-Gu Lee, Joung-Hu Park
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: We present a selective-retrieval framework for battery life prediction that, when only a few initial cycles of a new cell are available, trains on a small subset of historically similar cells rather than the full database. Similarity is scored primarily by Pearson correlation (cosine as a fair baseline under identical backbones). On a randomized-policy 18650 set (54 cells) and an external 5 Ah pouch-cell set (12 cells), Pearson-based selection matches or improves accuracy while sharply reducing the amount of training data. On the 54-cell set, Pearson improves both RMSE and MAE over training with all data in 46/54 (85.2%) for MLP, 52/54 (96.3%) for RNN, 53/54 (98.1%) for GRU, and 53/54 (98.1%) for Transformer; on the 12-cell validation set, the corresponding fractions are 12/12 (100%), 9/12 (75.0%), 7/12 (58.3%), and 11/12 (91.7%). In the rare instances where Pearson is worse than “All,” the increases are small—about 10⁻² Ah in RMSE and 10⁻³ Ah in MAE. Using Top-k retrieval also reduces the training set size by ∼94% (k=3), ∼91% (k=5), or ∼87% (k=7) relative to using all 53 source cells, yielding commensurate training-time savings. Overall, the method offers a practical, data-efficient update path that preserves (and often enhances) accuracy at substantially lower computational cost.
