title: Feasibility Analysis of an Off-Grid Solar PV / Diesel-Generator / Battery System for an Independent Residential Household in a Village of Andhra Pradesh
authors: Soumya P, Jayabarathi T
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: To cater to households' growing energy demands, the government is promoting the use of renewable energy sources (RES) while lowering the usage of fossil fuels. The reduction of natural resources over time has caused the need for dependence on non-conventional or RES as much as possible. In areas where grid connectivity is complex/ infeasible, diesel generators, battery energy storage systems, and various renewable energy sources, such as solar, wind, and bioenergies, can provide an uninterrupted power supply. The integrated or hybrid system minimizes greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) and harnesses local resources to meet the daily energy demand of the system. The proposed microgrid system integrates solar PV, a diesel generator, and a battery energy storage system. The independent household is located in Buchireddypalem, a village in Andhra Pradesh, India, with coordinates of latitude <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$14^{\circ} 31.97^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{N}$</tex> and longitude <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$79^{\circ} 52.51^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{E}$</tex>. The daily average load is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$39.45 \text{kWh} /$</tex> day, at peak load 3.52 kW, and load factor 0.47. The optimal net present cost (NPC) is $92,297, operation and maintenance (O&M) is $<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5,648 / y r$</tex>, and the levelized cost of Energy (LCOE) is $ 0.496 / kWh, respectively. The simulation results from HOMER Pro software emphasize that a renewable fraction of 39.4%, a total fuel consumption of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3,214 \mathrm{L} / \text{Yr}$</tex>, and an internal rate of return of 14 % make the system cost-effective and sustainable in comparison with other configurations.

title: Secure and Intelligent Roaming Settlements Using Blockchain and AI
authors: Dinesh Kumar, Chandra Jaiswal, Ahmad Saeed, Ravi Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Blockchain technology introduces a new paradigm for multiparty distributed data storage by offering built-in consensus mechanisms and data immutability. Concurrently, telecom infrastructure has evolved from 2G, 3G, and 4G to 5G, introducing new complexities in roaming use cases. In response, the GSMA developed the Billing and Charging Evolution (BCE) standard to support the dynamic nature of future wholesale roaming settlements. BCE provides a flexible, simplified settlement model through standardized formats such as Usage Data Reports (UDRs) and Billing Statement Reports (BSRs), enhancing revenue assurance and enabling support for diverse charging models, including access-based billing. This is particularly important for Internet of Things (IoT) scenarios where traditional TAP (Transferred Account Procedure) designed primarily for voice and SMS is no longer sufficient. Unlike TAP, BCE supports dynamic, real-time roaming across 5G use cases, including IoT, satellite networks, AI-driven services, and autonomous systems. Its ability to streamline inter-operator billing, settlement, and invoicing processes is essential for managing the scale and complexity of 5G environments. This paper presents a production-ready architectural framework that integrates BCE with permissioned blockchain, AI-based anomaly detection, and predictive analytics. The proposed framework is secure, extensible, and optimized to support a wide range of next-generation roaming settlement use cases.

title: Gain Improvement of a Monopole Antenna for Wimax /Wlan 5G/6G Applications Using Amc Technique
authors: EL-Arrouch Tarik, El Amrani El Idrissi Najiba, Chaibi Mohamed, Sudipta Das, Errajraji Karim
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: In this work, a compact broadband patch antenna integrated with an Artificial Magnetic Conductor (AMC) structure is proposed for WiMAX <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(3.6 / 4.8 \text{GHz})$</tex> and WLAN (5.1/5.825 GHz) 5G applications. The antenna, fed by a 50Ω microstrip line, consists of a partial ground <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.035 ~\text{mm})$</tex>, an FR4 substrate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\varepsilon_{r}=4.4\right.$</tex>, thickness <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=1.6 ~\text{mm}$</tex>, loss tangent = 0.025), and a rectangular patch with parasitic elements and an elliptical slot. It achieves a wide impedance bandwidth of 3.03 GHz within a compact size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26.5 \times 29 \times 1.6 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex>. A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4 \text{AMC}$</tex> array is placed on the back to suppress back radiation lobes and enhance gain. The overall antenna size is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \times 40 \times 10.4 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex>. Simulated and measured results confirm a bandwidth from 3.62 to 6.65 GHz, with a peak gain of 10 dB at 6 GHz and 8.5 dB at 5.8 GHz, making it a promising candidate for WiMAX and WLAN <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> systems.

title: GenAI-based Mental Health Chatbots: Efficacy, Personalization and Ethical Considerations
authors: Kaushal Surana, Aditya Sharma, Vatsal Tibrewal, Riti Kushwaha
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: This paper investigates the creation, execution, and evaluation of mental health chatbots powered by generative AI (GenAI) which provide users with tailored coping mechanisms. The progress in GenAI has allowed for high levels of personalization to be integrated through advanced content delivery systems, psychological profiling, and mood tracking. Primary research shows slight to moderate improvement in depression and anxiety symptoms. Nonetheless, this research tends to be overly simplistic in reporting sample sizes, description of participants, and research methods, and so comparability across different populations is limited. In combining various forms of technologies, instruments, such as PHQ-9, GAD-7, and mood self-report diaries, have been meticulously integrated. No authoritative comparative studies have been conducted that quantify or directly measure the scalability, user engagement, safety, or clinical efficacy of GenAI powered chatbots in relation to traditional interventions; the data available is primarily qualitative or bare minimum. This paper also looks to the challenges of privacy ethics and clinical oversight troubling data security, consent, bias, and transparency. Clinical oversight with reporting outcomes has been done in an inconsistent manner, indicating a significant absence of data and the necessity for systematic assessment frameworks alongside clear below assess grayaz add reporting. There is a consensus that GenAI chatbots have made strides in widening the scope of mental health attention. There’s a critical need to uphold privacy regulations, ethical standards, and meticulous clinical supervision to safe-guard the expansion of these scalable, cost-effective solutions.

title: Urban Noise Canceller
authors: Kavin K, Mohiit Muthiah S, Kavitha K R, S Vijayalakshmi, B Murali Babu
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Urban noise pollution is a growing environmental concern, particularly in sensitive areas such as hospitals, schools and residential neighbourhoods. Extended exposure to background noise can lead to stress, sleep problems, cognitive issues, and heart-related conditions. To address this issue, a smart, real-time Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) system, known as the Urban Noise Canceller, has been developed using MATLAB for simulation, signal control, and performance evaluation. The system focuses on low-frequency urban noise between 50 Hz and 800 Hz by generating anti-phase sound waves that cancel out incoming noise. Unlike traditional passive noise control methods that depend on heavy acoustic insulation, this approach is lightweight, flexible, and energy-efficient. It uses the Filtered-x Least Mean Squares (FxLMS) algorithm, which is an adaptive filtering method that adjusts to changing noise patterns in real time. Microphones capture ambient noise, and MATLAB processes this data to create inverse waveforms that effectively reduce noise. Simulation results show good noise reduction in controlled settings. It is scalable and adaptable. The system is well suited for smart buildings, transport hubs and IoT based monitoring. This innovation supports Sustainable Development Goal 11 by promoting healthier and quieter urban spaces.

title: On the use of pharmacies to establish a defibrillator network
authors: Manolis Wallace, Christos Champilomatis, Panagiota Ventirozou, Georgios Pappas, Vasssilis Poulopoulos, Costas Vassilakis
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Sudden cardiac arrest (SAC) is a leading cause of mortality. In recent years, though, many lives have been saved through the use of defibrillators by random bystanders. As a result, defibrillators have been popping up in various locations. In this work we propose a state mandate demanding the presence of a defibrillator at every pharmacy store and argue that it could greatly enhance and augment the impact of the defibrillator network. We support our claim via detailed calculations of the immediate (a defibrillator readily available) and partial (a defibrillator available at a reasonable distance) population coverage achievable by the implementation of our proposal, taking the Argolis area in Peloponnese Greece as a case study. Our findings indicate that, in addition to other benefits, the use of pharmacies to establish a defibrillator network could bring an eight-fold increase in the immediate population coverage of defibrillators and would provide immediate/partial access to a defibrillator to 18/24 incidents of SCA per year that would otherwise lead to death, potentially leading to the saving of numerous lives. Alternative scenaria are also discussed.

title: Optimizing Sowing Dates and Crop Yield with Predictive Models
authors: Graceline Jasmine S, Gabriel Joshua R, Lourdeena J S, Lila Iznita Izhar, Benin R
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Effective crop management is crucial for meeting global food demand, yet traditional methods often lead to inefficiencies. This study utilizes data-driven models to enhance sowing date optimization and crop yield prediction (CYP) by integrating real-time sensor data-such as NPK levels and soil temperature-with weather forecasts generated using a linear regression model. Comprehensive data preprocessing ensured high-quality datasets by addressing missing values, scaling data, and selecting regions with at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0}$</tex> years of historical records. To determine optimal sowing dates, a Random Forest model was employed to analyze historical trends and forecasted conditions, achieving an impressive accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 4 \%}$</tex>. Meanwhile, an Extra Trees model captured complex feature interactions to improve crop yield predictions, attaining an accuracy of 92%. Both models underwent hyperparameter tuning to maximize performance. Results highlight the effectiveness of Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven precision agriculture in optimizing resource utilization and boosting food production. By leveraging Machine learning (ML) for predictive insights, this research demonstrates how AI can transform traditional farming into a more sustainable and efficient practice. Ultimately, the integration of real-time monitoring, historical analysis, and advanced forecasting techniques enhances decision-making, improving food security and promoting agricultural sustainability.

title: System and Method for Accelerating Multilinear Tensor Transformations Using an Isomorphic Architecture and Efficient Sparse Processing
authors: Stanislav Sedukhin, Yoichi Tomioka, Kazuya Matsumoto, Yuichi Okuyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Multilinear transformations are fundamental in high-performance computing (HPC) and artificial intelligence (AI), but their computational and memory demands grow rapidly with dimensionality. Conventional scaling-adding more processing units-quickly drives up energy costs, especially for sparse data that dominate modern workloads. This paper introduces TriADA (Trilinear Algorithm and isomorphic Device Architecture), a co-designed algorithm and architecture that addresses these challenges. TriADA combines a massively parallel low-rank algorithm for trilinear discrete orthogonal transforms (3D-DXTs), a novel outer-product-based GEMM kernel with decoupled streaming memory, and a fully distributed 3D cross-wire network of compute cells that operate in a data-driven, coordinate-free manner. In addition, it incorporates the Elastic Sparse Outer-Product (ESOP) method, which dynamically eliminates redundant computation and communication with zero operands, improving both energy efficiency and numerical accuracy. By executing diverse trilinear tensor transforms with hypercubical complexity in only a linear number of steps, TriADA achieves simplicity, scalability, and high data reuse. Moreover, it supports both dense transforms, corresponding to lossless compression, and sparse transforms, which implement lossy compression by pruning high-frequency basis functions-enabling flexible trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency.

title: MEMSCOPE: Open-Source Kernel-Level Framework for Heterogeneous Memory Characterization
authors: Golsana Ghaemi, Gabriel Franco, Kazem Taram, Renato Mancuso
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: This paper presents an open-source kernel-level heterogeneous memory characterization framework (MemScope) for embedded systems. MemScope enables precise characterization of the temporal behavior of available memory modules under configurable contention stress scenarios. MemScope leverages kernel-level control over physical memory allocation, cache maintenance, CPU state, interrupts, and I/O device activity to accurately benchmark heterogeneous memory subsystems. This gives us the privilege to directly map pieces of contiguous physical memory and instantiate allocators, allowing us to finely control cores to create and eliminate interference. Additionally, we can minimize noise and interruptions, guaranteeing more consistent and precise results compared to equivalent user-space solutions. Running our Framework on a Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+ ZCU102 CPU-FPGA platform demonstrates its capability to precisely benchmark bandwidth and latency across various memory types, including PL-side DRAM and BRAM, in a multi-core system.

title: Toward Predictable Deflection Routing in Routerless NoCs for Real-Time Systems
authors: M Norazizi Sham Mohd Sayuti, Leandro Soares Indrusiak
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Contention between packets on shared resources, such as ejection links, causes high latency on routerless Networks-On-Chip. Missing packet timing guarantees due to high latency render a real-time application unschedulable. Deflection routing is a mechanism that addresses contention when multiple packets try to access the same links simultaneously. Despite its benefits, packets may be deflected more than what their timing guarantees allow in the worst-case scenario. To achieve an upper bound of deflections in conjunction with mapping, we proposed two methods: first, a method that increases the deflections of all communication flows, and second, a method that increases the deflections based on selective communication flows. Our findings, based on running both methods in an evolutionary optimisation, show that the latter outperformed the former, with a statistically significant improvement in the maximum deflection.

title:
Experimental Study on Dynamic Resistance Characteristics of Ga
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Schottky Barrier Diodes
authors: Zijie Zhou, Jiangbin Wan, Hengyu Wang, Kuang Sheng
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This study investigates the on-resistance characteristics of gallium oxide $\left(\mathrm{~Ga}_{2} \mathrm{~O}_{3}\right)$ Schottky barrier diodes (SBDs) during their transition from the blocking state to various forwardcurrent conditions. A pulse test circuit incorporating an active clamping circuit was developed to enable high-fidelity dynamic resistance characterization. The core of this setup is a SiC Schottky barrier diode connected in parallel, which facilitates precise voltage sampling during the rapid switching of the device under test (DUT) from reverse blocking to forward conduction. This approach allows accurate measurement of the on-state voltage immediately after switching. Using this platform, the dynamic on-resistance of $\mathrm{~Ga}_{2} \mathrm{~O}_{3}$ SBDs was systematically characterized under blocking voltages from 50 V to 400 V and load currents from 2 A to 5 A. Experimental results reveal the absence of significant dynamic on-resistance ($R_{\text {on }}$) degradation in the $\mathrm{~Ga}_{2} \mathrm{~O}_{3}$ SBDs. The study provides key experimental data for in-depth understanding of $\mathrm{~Ga}_{2} \mathrm{~O}_{3}$ SBDs characteristics.

title: Review of Global Inertia Procurement Practices: Lessons for South Africa
authors: Josh A. Dippenaar, Bernard Bekker
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: As power systems transition toward high shares of inverter-based renewable energy, declining levels of synchronous inertia present growing challenges for managing frequency stability. Globally, system operators are developing mechanisms to value and procure inertia as a dedicated service. This paper evaluates international approaches to defining minimum inertia requirements and procuring inertia services, drawing on experience from Great Britain and Australia. These insights are contextualised within South Africa's regulatory and market framework. Regulatory gaps related to the procurement of inertia in South Africa's Grid and Market Codes are identified, and amendments are proposed to support technology-neutral approaches through a combination of long-term contracts and spot market mechanisms. The analysis highlights the need for regulatory reform, and for further research to ensure secure and cost-effective inertia provision in a future low-inertia power system.

title: A Modified Kornai-Liptak Decomposition Method for Equitable Photovoltaic Operating Envelopes Allocation in Distribution Systems
authors: Wenjun Tang, Zhenzi Wang, Shan He, Yuming Zhao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the accelerating global energy transition, the rapid integration of photovoltaic (PV) systems into distribution systems has introduced significant operational challenges. Traditional direct control methods have proven inadequate for managing the flexible regulation requirements of large-scale PV penetration. The operating envelope (OE), as an indirect control approach, defines the feasible power operation region for secure operation at each node, providing an effective method for distribution systems with high renewable energy penetration. By preserving the autonomous regulation capability of distributed generation while ensuring grid security, OEs have emerged as a critical research focus in modern power systems. Unlike the traditional Kornai-Liptak (KL) decomposition method that allocates the right-side coefficients based on contribution degrees, this paper proposes an improved KL decomposition method based on proportional equitable conditions. Firstly, the linear DistFlow model and the photovoltaic (PV) unit model are established, and all constraints were integrated into a compact convex polyhedron form. Subsequently, the KL decomposition decomposes the coupling constraints into specific allocations for multiple subsystems and introduces the equitable condition to reconstruct the OE of each PV. This method not only retains the computational efficiency advantage of KL decomposition, but also ensures that the OE of each PV are strictly matched with their proportional factors. The simulation results show that the proposed method achieves the equitable OE for PV units while ensuring the security operation of the power grid.

title: Power System Risk Assessment and Premium Determination Considering on Wind Turbine Faults
authors: Jiakai Feng, Dingkang Liang, Zewen Ma, Yinglong Li, Ronghao Zhang, Ningtao Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: This paper develops a wind farm output model considering wake effects and turbine failures, and uses Monte Carlo simulation to assess power system risk and economic loss. Based on the Esscher premium principle, an insurance pricing model is proposed to transfer wind power uncertainty risk. Case studies show that the proposed insurance mechanism effectively reduces the impact of high-loss, low-probability events and improves system reliability and economy.

title: A Stereo Vision-Based Method for Measuring Cathode Bar Consumption in Electrolytic Cells
authors: Hongtao Liu, Feifei Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Addressing the cumbersome and time-consuming process of measuring iron content in rare earth ferroalloy products, this study proposes a binocular vision-based method for quantifying cathode iron rod consumption. Leveraging the characteristic that all iron in the alloy originates from cathode iron rods during production, the method indirectly calculates the iron content in the alloy by measuring rod consumption. The method first calibrates a stereo camera system. After image preprocessing, it employs an SGBM-enhanced algorithm based on adaptive GrabCut for stereo matching to generate a disparity map. Three-dimensional point cloud reconstruction and volume calculation then determine the consumption volume. Experimental results demonstrate that the average relative error of consumption volume obtained through this measurement method is less than 5.5%, providing a reference for rapid measurement of rare earth electrolytic cathode iron rod consumption.

title: Affective State Recognition in Online Learning: A Deep Learning Approach with Data Augmentation
authors: Ashwitha Devasya, Andrew Abel, Yuchen Wang, Laibing Jia
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Academic affective states are crucial indicators of student engagement and participation. With the rise of digital education, understanding students’ emotional and interest levels has become more challenging. In this study, we utilise the DAiSEE video dataset and present a streamlined spatiotemporal framework that combines a customised CNN-BiLSTM architecture with time-distributed processing, and experiment with facial cropping, data augmentation, and alternative architectures. Despite our model’s simplicity, when paired with carefully chosen data augmentation techniques such as horizontal flipping and adaptive gamma brightness correction, the model outperforms larger architectures while achieving significantly lower inference latency. We show that body posture and contextual cues offer vital information beyond facial expressions through ablation studies comparing full-frame versus face-only inputs. With the right data augmentation strategy, even simple models can achieve state-of-the-art performance in educational environments.

title: Study on Surface Damage of 12-Inch Silicon Carbide Wafers During Diamond Wire Cutting
authors: Qingyu Li, Yong Yang, Wancheng Yu, Xiufang Chen, Xianglong Yang, Xuejian Xie, Rongkun Wang, Guanglei Zhong, Xiangang Xu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Wire sawing serves as an essential initial step in the manufacturing of silicon carbide ingots into wafers. Compared with traditional slurry-based sawing, diamond wire sawing enables superior cutting efficiency and operational speed, but introduces significant surface and subsurface damage that degrades the mechanical integrity and performance of wafers in subsequent semiconductor fabrication processes. In this study, a comprehensive optimization of processing parameters based on wire diamond sawing was bulit to mitigate cutting-induced surface damage. The experimental procedure utilized a wire diamond saw for precision cutting of silicon carbide ingots under rigorously controlled conditions. The descent speed of the worktable was dynamically modulated through a multi-stage profile, starting with an initial gradual deceleration followed by progressive acceleration, with the descent speed controlled within the range of $220-530 \mu \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{min}$. A diamond wire with a nominal diameter of $162 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ was operated under precisely maintained parameters: a wire speed of $2600-2800 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{min}$, a tension force of $25-28 \mathrm{~N}$, and an oscillatory motion of $\pm 3-5$ degrees at a speed of $5.5-6.0 \mathrm{deg} / \mathrm{s}$. Post-cutting evaluation of surface characteristics was conducted using white-light interferometry to quantitatively assess topological features and roughness parameters. Experimental results demonstrated consistent trends in both horizontal and vertical surface roughness evolution during the cutting process. Scratch depth analysis revealed progressive variation patterns corresponding to different cutting stages. Furthermore, substantial differences in surface quality were observed between crystalline orientations, as the carbon-terminated (C) face exhibited significantly higher surface roughness and deeper scratches than the silicon-terminated (Si) face, attributing to the fundamental difference in interfacial fracture toughness between these planes. Through systematic parameter optimization, the modified cutting process achieved a notable reduction in surface damage. These findings provide valuable insights for predicting material removal requirements in subsequent thinning operations and offer practical strategies for enhancing material utilization efficiency while improving overall wafer production yield. The optimized processing parameters demonstrate significant potential for implementation in industrial-scale semiconductor manufacturing environments.

title: Design and Simulation of the 19 kV N-Channel SiC IGBT: Buffer Stack Engineering for High Blocking Capability and Low Forward Voltage Drop
authors: Yanjun Li, Hongyi Xu, Lingxu Kong, Xingyu Yan, Yuanying Li, Yefeng Wang, Ji Cheng, Liming Wei, Na Ren
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This work presents the design and TCAD simulation of the 19 kV N-channel SiC IGBT based on a P-type substrate. Key device elements-drift layer, N-type fieldstop buffer layer, stepped-doping injection-assist layer, and active cell structure-are systematically optimized to achieve robust blocking performance while minimizing forward voltage drop. On the basis of a $\mathbf{1 1 0} \boldsymbol{-} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}$ drift layer with a doping concentration of $2 \times 10^{14} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$, an N-type field-stop (FS) buffer layer was introduced, enabling a simulated breakdown voltage of 19 kV. Moreover, a bilayer buffer stack, which incorporating a low-doped minority carrier injection enhancement (MCIE) layer ($\sim \mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{1 5}} \mathbf{~ c m}^{-\mathbf{3}}$), increases conduction current density by $\mathbf{4. 5}$ times and yields a forward voltage drop of 4 V at 100 $A / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$. In the cell structure, high-energy ion implantation was employed to optimize the current spreading layer (CSL), alleviating P-type straggling effect in the low-doped drift region and thereby enlarging the JFET width, reducing its depth, and enhancing device conduction performance. The presented design provides a practical solution for the development of high-voltage SiC bipolar devices with high-current capability.

title:
High-Efficiency Al
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    /AlN/GaN MIS-HEMTs for Low-Voltage RF Power Amplifiers
authors: Shiyang Li, JieJie Zhu, Lingjie Qin, Bowen Zhang, Qing Zhu, Xiaohua Ma
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In this work, we report high-efficiency AIN/GaN metal-insulator-semiconductor high electron mobility transistors (MIS-HEMTs) fabricated on a Si substrate with Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> and ICP-SiN as the gate dielectric, respectively. The introduction of the gate dielectric results in a significant suppression of the gate leakage current and an enhanced breakdown voltage. A regrown ohmic contact structure was adopted for both gate-dielectric devices, achieving a contact resistance of $0.1 \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~mm}$ and an enhanced peak transconductance. The device with the Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> gate dielectric demonstrated superior DC and radio-frequency (RF) performance. It exhibited a maximum drain current density ($I_{\text {dmax }}$) of $1453 \mathrm{~mA} / \mathrm{mm}$ and a peak transconductance ($G_{\mathrm{m}, \max }$) of $656 \mathrm{mS} / \mathrm{mm}$, which are significantly higher than the $1312 \mathrm{~mA} / \mathrm{mm}$ and $562 \mathrm{mS} / \mathrm{mm}$ obtained from the device with the ICP-SiN gate dielectric. Similarly, the cut-off frequency and maximum oscillation frequency ($f_{\mathrm{T}} / f_{\text {max }}$) for the Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-gated device were measured at $86 / 148 \mathrm{GHz}$, outperforming the $68 / 116 \mathrm{GHz}$ of the ICP-SiN-gated device. This performance advantage was also confirmed by load-pull measurements at 3.6 GHz and 6 V, where the Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> device achieved an output power ($\mathrm{P}_{\text {out }}$) of 19.63 dBm and a power-added efficiency (PAE) of 72.71%, compared to 17.59 dBm and 64.01% for its ICP-SiN counterpart. In addition, the current collapse was evaluated under a bias condition of $V_{\mathrm{GS}}=-8 \mathrm{~V}$ and $V_{\mathrm{DS}}=40 \mathrm{~V}$. The Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> gate dielectric shows a superior performance with a current collapse of only 7.9%, whereas the ICP-SiN device suffers from a larger collapse of 14.2%.

title: Integrating Machine Learning Approaches for Consumer Behavior Analysis in Retail Transactions
authors: Andreas Kanavos, Gerasimos Vonitsanos, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Retail analytics has become essential for supermarkets, which generate vast volumes of transactional data on a daily basis. Harnessing this data to model consumer behavior enables informed decision-making in marketing, inventory management, and customer engagement. This paper proposes an integrated methodology that combines association rule mining, k-means clustering, and Random Forest classification to extract and exploit insights from retail transactions. Association rules revealed frequent co-purchasing patterns with lift values consistently above 1.2, underscoring non-random associations of staple products. Clustering identified three distinct consumer groups—high-value, medium-level, and low-frequency shoppers—demonstrating the heterogeneity of purchasing behaviors. Random Forest achieved the strongest predictive performance, with segment-level models improving F1-scores up to 0.74 compared to a global baseline of 0.66. Experiments on publicly available supermarket datasets confirm that integrating segmentation and prediction enhances both accuracy and interpretability. By combining descriptive, unsupervised, and supervised learning, the methodology provides actionable insights and reliable forecasts, offering a comprehensive decision-support tool for modern retail environments.

title: FreeRTOS based Smart Waste Management System
authors: V G Aasish, Mari Shankar C, Shanmugasundaram M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a FreeRTOS-based smart waste management system for urban and municipal applications using the dual-core ESP32 microcontroller. The system aims to enable real-time monitoring of waste bin conditions-specifically fill level, temperature, and humidity-while optimizing collection efficiency and resource utilization. Leveraging FreeRTOS multitasking capabilities, the architecture assigns Core 1 to sensor acquisition and actuator control, while Core 2 handles cloud communication and data synchronization. Ultrasonic sensors are used to detect bin fill levels, DHT11/DHT22 sensors monitor environmental conditions, and RFID modules enable unique bin identification. The system utilizes FreeRTOS features such as queues, semaphores, and mutexes to ensure efficient inter-task communication and synchronization. Sensor data is transmitted securely via WiFi to a remote cloud server, allowing for real-time alerts, bin status visualization, and dynamic collection scheduling. An optional LCD/OLED module provides localized feedback. The proposed system is energy-efficient, modular, and scalable, making it well-suited for integration into smart city frameworks. By minimizing manual waste inspection and enabling data-driven route planning, the system contributes to cleaner cities and more sustainable waste management practices.

title: Custom Image-To-Graph Transformation Strategies for Object Detection with GATs on the KITTI Dataset
authors: Rabab BENFOUINA, Ahmed Drissi el Maliani
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Object detection in autonomous driving scenarios represents a critical challenge in computer vision, traditionally dominated by Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). This paper presents a comprehensive investigation of Graph Attention Networks (GATs) as an alternative approach for object detection, focusing on three distinct image-to-graph transformation methods. We evaluate: (1) PCA-based patch flattening, (2) PCA with positional enrichment, and (3) advanced textural descriptors including Local Binary Patterns, GLCM, and entropy measures. Our study utilizes the KITTI dataset with 7,841 annotated images, segmented into <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32 \times 32$</tex> pixel patches treated as graph nodes. To address the significant class imbalance (81% Background and Car classes), we examine three dataset variants: original distribution, GraphSMOTE balancing, and hybrid image augmentation with graph balancing. Results demonstrate that Method 2 (PCA with positional enrichment) achieves superior performance with a weighted F1-score of 0.5924 and 25.75% exact match accuracy on the original dataset, highlighting the critical importance of preserving spatial information during graph transformation. While GAT-based approaches show inferior performance compared to established CNN methods, the progressive improvement observed across transformation strategies and the exceptional enhancement in minority class detection (Cyclist: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.013 \rightarrow 0.406$</tex>, Person sitting: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.005 \rightarrow 0.980$</tex>) reveal promising optimization directions for graph-based object detection systems in autonomous driving applications.

title: Grape: Efficient Spatiotemporal Prediction Services with Stale Sensing Streams
authors: Liekang Zeng, Yunchao Liu, Shengyuan Ye, Mu Yuan, Di Duan, Xu Chen, Guoliang Xing
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Emerging cyber-physical systems have embraced a large number of IoT devices spanning geo-distributed, which generate and consume massive volumes of data continuously. Accurate and timely spatiotemporal predictions (STP) over these streaming sensor data are critical and, in growing demand, ubiquitous across various edge scenarios such as traffic flow forecasting. Towards that, recent advanced systems have developed sophisticated optimizations among STP pipelines, aiming at optimal prediction performance. However, based on our empirical studies in real-world settings, we identify a previously overlooked bottleneck of end-to-end STP performance: data staleness. To mitigate this issue, in this work, we investigate a new task, namely stream interception, which deliberately terminates the acceptance of incoming sensor data and anticipates model execution with imputed missing features. We propose a novel dynamic interception strategy to determine the time slot to exit waiting and present Grape, an STP system that implements it with practical system designs. Extensive evaluations on real-world traces show that Grape can strike a superior tradeoff between prediction accuracy and serving latency, achieving 1.69-1.90× speedup against traditional all-waiting baselines across various STP services with high prediction accuracy on par with offline optimal cases.

title: A Tubular IPMC Sensor for Two-Dimensional Dynamic Flow Sensing
authors: Yeda Tan, Hezheng Lan, Kejie Zhao, Hong Lei
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: As a key type of electroactive polymer (EAP), ionic polymer-metal composites (IPMCs) possess intrinsic underwater sensing and actuation capabilities. This makes them well-suited for use as artificial lateral line sensors to capture flow information. Existing single IPMC flow sensors generally exhibit only one-dimensional sensing capability. Therefore, IPMC sensors with two-dimensional flow field perception can provide artificial lateral line systems with enhanced spatial awareness and more comprehensive flow information. This paper proposes a two-dimensional flow field sensor based on a tubular IPMC structure. It presents theoretical methods for decoupling and dimensionality reduction of the sensor’s physical model. An experimental scheme-based on the dipole model and potential flow theory-is designed to characterize the sensor’s two-dimensional perception performance. These studies lay a theoretical foundation for the subsequent modeling, calibration, and application of tubular IPMC sensors in sensing underwater oscillatory flow fields.

title: Efficient Machine Unlearning using Mislabel Unlearning
authors: Aashutosh Chahal, Yatin Sharma, Shikha Mehta, Anuradha Surolia
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Modern machine learning frameworks inadvertently keep facing issues related to data privacy, adversarial data poisoning attacks, and lack of dynamism. The solution often demands the removal of a set of data points from a trained model. Machine unlearning aims to remove the influence of specific data points on the outcome of a pre-trained model. Retraining a model from scratch after removing influential training points is an effective approach to achieve the desirable results, but it is often computationally inefficient and impractical.Mislabel unlearning is a sub-domain of machine unlearning that focuses on removing the influence of a specific data point on the outcome of a trained model without retraining from scratch while maintaining efficient computational expenses and retaining accuracy. This paper proposes a mathematically robust and adaptable mislabel unlearning framework that enables the removal of influence of a specific set of training points from a pre-trained model, making the model behave as if it has never seen the training point. By tracking how individual data points impact the model and simulating label inaccuracies during unlearning, our approach ensures stable performance with markedly lower computational demands.Our approach involves assigning a random label to a selected training point accompanied by mathematical calculations estimating its influence on the model’s output. The effect of the influence function is coupled with the corrupted labeling, effectively pushing the model boundaries away from the influence of the original point. The framework was evaluated against a baseline model retrained from scratch, and our results show a twofold reduction in computational time while preserving key performance metrics.

title: A Study on the Performance and Usability of Managed Memory and Unified Memory for Accelerating Numerical Calculation Program
authors: Satoshi Ohshima, Akihiro Ida, Masatoshi Kawai, Takeshi Fukaya, Rio Yokota
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of NVIDIA Managed Memory and Unified Memory for GPU-accelerated numerical computing using CUDA Fortran. We focus on Block Low-Rank QR factorization implemented with CUDA Fortran, evaluating two approaches: memory control via compiler option and manual specification using variable qualifiers. Experiments on GH200 and H100 systems reveal that manual memory placement reduces runtime by up to 68 % compared to compiler-option-based control. Unified Memory consistently outperforms Managed Memory on GH200, highlighting its suitability for integrated CPU/GPU architectures. Our contributions are: (1) a systematic evaluation of memory strategies for CUDA Fortran applications, (2) insights into productivity-performance trade-offs, and (3) practical guidelines for auto-tuning memory placement in HPC environments.

title: Performance Optimization of Machine Inference Applications on Edge Devices with a RISC-V Custom Instruction
authors: Daichi Higashi, Hitoshi Oi
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: In this paper, we present a case study of optimizing the executions of machine learning applications on edge devices. Workload profiling of two typical applications, Micro Speech and Person Detection, has revealed that more than 70% of the clock cycles are spent in convolution operations which are actually multiply-and-accumulate operations of two arrays. We have added a custom instruction, which is a packed-SIMD multiply-and-accumulation into the basic RISC-V ISA. The results of cycle-accurate simulations show that the relative speed of the Person Detection is accelerated to 240% of the execution without the custom instruction. On the other hand, the performance of the Micro Speech is degraded by 13%. Analysis of this performance degradation needs further investigation but one possibility is the pipeline flushes caused by array boundary check and the overhead of additional instructions for packing the operands into registers for the custom instruction. Compared to a sample RISC-V implementation, PicoRV32, the hardware overhead of the function unit for the custom instruction is 3%.

title: Ultralow Radio Frequency Loss for GaN on Sapphire
authors: Kun Yin, Qing Zhu, Bowen Zhang, Jiejie Zhu, Xiaohua Ma
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In this paper, the radio-frequency loss mechanism of sapphire-based GaN was investigated, and for the first time, the variation of loss with epitaxial layer thickness on sapphire substrate was elucidated. A coplanar waveguide fabricated on the sapphire-based GaN epitaxial wafer without any additional processing achieved an ultra-low loss of 0.4 $\mathrm{dB} / \mathrm{mm}$ at 40 GHz. Furthermore, through simulation, optimization directions for both dielectric loss and conductor loss were proposed: etching the intermediate region of the transmission line and increasing the conductor thickness can further reduce the RF loss. This study demonstrates the potential of sapphire-based GaN in MMIC applications, thereby paving the way for cost-effective GaN MMICs with low radio-frequency loss.

title: Mitigation of Complex Transients and Electrical Noise in Distribution Grids using a Series Compensation Framework
authors: J.Jansi Priya, I.Jacob Raglend, Muhammad Syahril Mubarok
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The utilization of semiconductor devices is causing a gradual decline in the quality of power over time. The absence of power quality leads to disruptions in the system. The quality of power is mostly determined by the voltage's quality. The key factors affecting voltage quality are sag, swell, transient, noise and harmonics. This work focuses on enhancing the voltage quality of delicate loads by employing a dynamic voltage restorer (DVR). It is a specialised power device that is mounted directly after the distribution transformer. Its purpose is to safeguard the loads from any fluctuations or deviations in the supply voltage. This work mitigates voltage transients and Noise. The effectiveness of the proposed control mechanisms for the DVR is assessed by simulations conducted using MATLAB/Simulink.

title: Impact Analysis of Single-Phase and Three-Phase Electric Vehicle Charging Stations on Power System Operation and Quality
authors: Supakan Janthong, Pornchai Phukpattaranont
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of various EV charging strategies, including single-phase and three-phase, home, workplace, and fast-charging stations on a typical 22 kV/0.4 kV radial distribution feeder using a detailed MATLAB/Simulink model. The system comprises a 250 kVA Dyn11 transformer, a 1 km RL feeder, and five load buses with diverse load profiles. EV chargers are modeled as controlled current sources with stochastic time-varying profiles. The simulation runs over a 24-hour period with 1-second resolution, incorporating harmonic analysis and voltage monitoring. Key performance metrics such as voltage deviation, total harmonic distortion (THD), voltage unbalance factor (VUF), transformer loading and losses, power factor (PF), and reactive power (Q) flow are evaluated. The results reveal that high EV penetration, especially with fast-charging stations, leads to increased voltage fluctuations, harmonic distortion, and transformer stress. These findings underscore the need for grid modernization, including harmonic mitigation and smart charging strategies, to ensure stable and reliable power system operation under increasing EV demand.

title: Coronary Artery Disease Detection using Machine Learning
authors: Aditi Sandeep, Vorugallu Sneha, Vijayalaxmi, Harish S. V., Sandhyalaxmi G. Navada
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Cardiovascular Diseases (CVD) remain the leading cause of death worldwide, posing a significant challenge to global health systems. Early identification ofi ndividuals a tr isk is crucial for effective prevention and management, especially as sedentary lifestyles and metabolic disorders become increasingly prevalent. In this context, there is a growing need for accessible, reliable, and interpretable tools that can empower individuals and clinicians to assess cardiovascular risk proactively. The objective of this paper is to develop HeartWise Score, a web-based system that leverages machine learning to provide personalized cardiovascular risk predictions using routinely available health and lifestyle information. The methodology for this paper centers on the comparative analysis and deployment of multiple machine learning models-including Artificial N eural Network (ANN), Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Logistic Regression-using a large-scale CVD dataset sourced from Kaggle, comprising <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> records. After extensive evaluation, Logistic Regression was selected as the final predictive model due to its superior accuracy and interpretability. The dataset was carefully preprocessed, with clinical and engineered features such as BMI, pulse pressure, and mean arterial pressure calculated to enhance predictive performance. The frontend of the application was developed using React and TypeScript, styled with Tailwind CSS to ensure a modern and responsive user experience. The backend was implemented with Flask, which serves predictions from the trained and serialized Logistic Regression model. Key health metrics are computed client-side, and user data is securely transmitted to the backend for real-time cardiovascular risk assessment. The results are presented in an interpretable format, clearly highlighting individual risk factors and providing actionable insights. This work demonstrates the effective integration of machine learning and web technologies to deliver a practical, accessible, and privacy-conscious tool for preventive cardiovascular healthcare.

title: A Ridge Recognition Method Based on the Statistical Law of Digital Image Pixel Values
authors: Qiaoyan Sun, Jiayi Wang, Zixiang Gao, Dejun Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: In order to realize precise navigation of agricultural robots by using machine vision technology in complex arable land environment, this paper proposes a method paddy ridge recognition based on the statistical law of digital image pixel values. Firstly, the R-dimensional grayscale image of the RGB color image is selected, and n image strips are extracted from bottom to top according to the pixel size of the picture, where n is 6 in this paper. Then, the sum of the image pixels is summarized according the column of the image narrow strip, and the curve of the image pixel and is smoothed by using the mean filtering for many times. The number of peaks of the pixel and the is judged by the statistical pixel and the curve. According to the characteristics that the pixel points of the same path are farther from the pixel points of other paddy ridges, the points of the paddy ridges are discriminated to the belonging path, and finally the recognized points are used to fit the straight line by LSM to find the path of paddy ridge, and the coordinates of the recognition points which exceed the error range are adjusted continuously until they meet the set range. After verification with the collected images, this paper shows the algorithm used in this paper can identify the position of the paddy ridge better, and provide effective directional information for the navigation of agricultural machinery.

title: FP-FBEMS: FPGA-Based Optimization of Forward/Backward EMS Decoding for CV-QKD
authors: Kaijie Wei, Devanshu Garg, Ryutaro Nagai, Takao Tomono, Hideharu Amano
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) offers unconditional security for symmetric key exchange by leveraging fundamental quantum principles such as the no-cloning theorem and measurement disturbance. In recent years, continuous-variable QKD (CV-QKD) protocols have gained prominence because of their compatibility with standard optical components, higher key rates over short distances, lower cost, and potential for photonic integration. However, their performance deteriorates over long distances due to increased sensitivity to channel loss and noise. To mitigate this, non-binary Low-Density Parity Check (NB-LDPC) codes have emerged as an effective error correction strategy during the reconciliation phase. The Extended Min-Sum (EMS) algorithm is a well-suited decoding technique for NB-LDPC codes over Galois Fields (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GF}(q)$</tex>). However, its high computational complexity poses significant challenges for real-time deployment. Forward/backward EMS (FB-EMS), a scheduling-optimized variant of EMS, substantially reduces complexity and improves the feasibility of hardware implementation. This paper presents a flexible High-level Synthesis (HLS)-based implementation of FBEMS, accompanied by a comprehensive design space exploration on the Zynq Ultrascale+ RFSoC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 2$</tex> platform. The proposed architecture, FP-FBEMS, achieves a balance between on-chip resource usage and throughput, providing more than 2.48 Mbps over GF(64) with high scalability. Furthermore, our design achieves up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 2. 0 3} \boldsymbol{\times}$</tex> higher throughput than a software implementation on the Ryzen Threadripper 3960X. Extensive designspace exploration confirms the system's flexibility, robustness, and state-of-the-art performance.

title: Wide Band Gap Semiconductor Devices in Power Converter Design for Electric Vehicle Applications
authors: Indragandhi V, Poornesh M, Walid Issa, Subramaniyaswamy V
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The rapid growth in electric vehicle (EV) adoption has generated an imperative demand for power electronic converters that exhibit high efficiency, compactness, and reliability. Conventional silicon (Si)-based semiconductors are reaching their theoretical limits and hence open the door for exploring wide band gap (WBG) and ultrawide band gap (UWBG) materials. This article provides an extensive review of the recent advancements in WBG semiconductor devices and their application to EV power converters. We assess the material properties, fabrication issues, and device performance of wellestablished WBG materials such as silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (GaN) and emerging UWBG materials such as diamond and gallium oxide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex>). Special focus is given to performance parameters important to EV systems, including on-state resistance, switching losses, thermal management, and operation at harsh conditions, e.g., cryogenic temperatures. Based on a comparative evaluation, we explore the applicability of each material to various EV power converter topologies, such as traction inverters, on-board chargers (OBCs), and DC-DC converters. The paper concludes by combining the technology readiness levels, establishing the current research gaps, and forecasting future trends in WBG device deployment to facilitate the development of electric mobility.

title: Implementation of Field Oriented Control for Induction Motor Drive for Electric Vehicle Application
authors: Vishwa Kumar V K, Afiya S, Theja Thanuj S R, Ponnambalam P
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Electric vehicles (EVs) demand efficient, high-performance motor drives to ensure precise torque control and fast dynamic response. Three-phase induction motors (IMs) are widely used in EVs for their robustness and cost-effectiveness, but their nonlinear characteristics make control challenging under varying loads. This paper presents the implementation of Field Oriented Control (FOC) for an induction motor drive tailored to EV propulsion. FOC enables decoupled control of torque and flux by transforming three-phase stator currents into a rotating reference frame using Clarke and Park transformations. The system uses cascaded PI controllers for speed and current control, and Space Vector PWM (SVPWM) for inverter switching, optimizing DC bus utilization and minimizing harmonics. MATLAB/Simulink simulations show improved torque accuracy, dynamic performance, and energy efficiency. The results confirm that FOC is a suitable control strategy for meeting the demanding requirements of modern EV applications.

title: Socioeconomic Impact Assessment of Renewable Energy Access Using DBSCAN Clustering Methods
authors: Gayrat Bekbergenov, S. Lokeshwari, Shailesh Singh Thakur, Manoj Govindaraj, Abdullayeva Shakhnoza Anvarovna
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Renewable energy advocates worldwide emphasize the importance of environmental protection and the simultaneous advancement of social and economic benefits. Access to renewable energy sources, particularly in rural and underdeveloped regions, may increase incomes, employment, and prevent energy poverty. Legislators and stakeholders worry about accessibility and benefit inequality. Understanding geographical trends and socioeconomic grouping is essential for informed planning and targeted action. This paper seeks to identify regions where renewable energy sources have a significant social and economic impact by focusing on clusters and patterns that standard methods of inquiry may overlook. Current assessment approaches struggle to capture regional diversity and multiple socioeconomic characteristics, making policy recommendations difficult. A novel solution to these issues is to divide the globe by the social and economic benefits of renewable energy. To overcome these challenges, this paper proposes a novel methodology using Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) to classify geographic regions based on the intensity of socioeconomic benefits derived from renewable energy access. DBSCAN identifies high-impact clusters without requiring a fixed number of clusters, making it suitable for diverse datasets. It examined multivariate socioeconomic parameters, including income, employment, education, and energy affordability, across regions. Renewable energy improves socioeconomic conditions in evident geographical groupings, whether you're seeking success stories or ignored locations. Policy implications include prioritizing investments and aid in low-impact zones for equitable development. An effective socioeconomic impact assessment technique, DBSCAN clustering facilitates datadriven decision-making and strategic planning for renewable energy development.

title: Control Strategy for High-Inertia Energy Storagebased Synchronous Condenser During Power Grid Short-Circuit Faults
authors: Lanxiang Lou, Chuan Qin, Hao Liang, Guangtao Zhang, Jing Hao, Ken Tao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: As renewable energy penetration grows, voltage and frequency instability induced by grid disturbances have become more severe. To address this issue, this paper presents a highinertia energy storage-based synchronous condenser (HIESC) integrating a high-inertia flywheel and a doubly-fed electric machine, equipped with a dedicated control strategy to support the grid voltage and frequency during faults. First, the mathematical modeling of the HIESC is established, and control strategies for the grid-side and machine-side converters are proposed. Second, based on a simplified circuit model during voltage dips, the impact of active and reactive power on grid voltage and frequency during faults is analyzed, along with the optimal active and reactive power ratio. Then, a simultaneous active and reactive power distribution method is introduced. Compared to traditional control strategies that only provide reactive power, the proposed strategy shows significant advantages in optimizing frequency and enhancing voltage stability. Finally, the effectiveness of the control strategy is verified through simulations.

title: Data augmentation and parameter prediction method based on CTABGAN and GBDT for chemical oxidation process
authors: Yehong Li, Yaqi Wang, Shijie Zhu, Sha Chen, Shuai Li, Jiaqi Mai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: As a core technology in surface treatment of aviation parts, chemical oxidation is widely applied in enhancing corrosion resistance, strengthening coating adhesion and improving surface performance. Accurate parameter prediction of chemical oxidation is crucial for improving process stability and surface performance. However, due to experimental constraints, detection costs, and operating complexity, its experimental data often faces small sample and uneven distribution issues, namely insufficient samples under key conditions and deviated overall distribution, which prevents traditional models from learning inter-variable correlations and thus limits prediction accuracy. To address these problems, this study proposes a data augmentation and parameter prediction method based on conditional table generative adversarial networks (CTABGAN) and gradient boosting decision tree (GBDT) for chemical oxidation process. Firstly, considering the hybrid imbalance continuous and classified parameters in chemical oxidation small sample data, CTABGAN is utilized for data augmentation for generating high fidelity synthetic samples based on the statistical characteristics and variable dependencies, while maintaining the correlation between key variables to alleviate data imbalance. Then, considering the complex time-varying and coupling characteristics of multiple parameters in chemical oxidation process, parameter prediction model is built by GBDT integrating the original and enhanced data to achieve precise parameter prediction of chemical oxidation. The feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed method were validated on a practical chemical oxidation process of aviation parts.

title: Research on Functional Safety Development and Testing Methods of PCU System for HEV
authors: Yue Fu, Hang Sun, Bowen Yin, Bo Li, Hanbing Wu, Bin Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The power control unit (PCU) is the most important electrical and/or electronic (E/E) system of Hybrid Electrical Vehicle (HEV), the functional safety technology level of PCU system directly affects the vehicle safety. Based on the methodology of ISO 26262, this paper describes the item definition, hazard analysis and risk assessment, safety goal, functional safety requirement, technical safety requirement and gives an example of verification method by fault injection test. This paper provides reference for functional safety development of PCU system.

title: Simulating Quantum Threats to Web3 Cryptographic Primitives using Qiskit
authors: Vimal Kumar, Rakesh Sharma, Ishan Aggarwal, Debjani Ghosh
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Web3 technologies are fundamentally secured by classical cryptographic algorithms like the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA), Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), and Secure Hash Algorithms (SHA). The advent of fault-tolerant quantum computers, however, poses a significant threat to these systems. Shor’s algorithm can break the asymmetric schemes that underpin user wallets and asset ownership, while Grover’s algorithm quadratically weakens the security of symmetric ciphers and hash functions. This paper presents an integrated simulation framework, built using Python and Qiskit, to demonstrate these quantum threats in a unified context. We implement simulated attacks against simplified, small-scale instances of RSA, ECDSA, AES, and SHA to model the structural feasibility of these quantum attacks. For Shor’s algorithm, we utilize a classical simulation of the quantum oracles for modular exponentiation and elliptic curve point addition, focusing on the viability of the overall quantum-classical workflow. For Grover’s algorithm, we use standard Qiskit circuit library implementations with simplified oracles. Our findings confirm the theoretical vulnerabilities—successfully factoring RSA-15, solving the ECDLP on a toy curve, and finding keys/preimages in 8-bit search spaces. More importantly, this work highlights the practical simulation challenges and immense resource requirements for breaking production-scale keys, reinforcing the critical need for the Web3 ecosystem to transition towards post-quantum cryptography.

title: Smart Meter Implementation for Advanced Home Energy Optimization
authors: S. Kumaravel, Dharun Prasanth G, Raaj A V Giri, Helson Boby J, V. S. Sri Raja Balaguru
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents a Smart Meter-based advanced home energy optimization system designed to enhance residential energy efficiency through real-time monitoring, intelligent control, and automated Demand-Side Management (DSM). The proposed system employs customdesigned smart adapters to extend HEMS functionality beyond aggregated household control, enabling precise appliance-level energy intelligence, proactive maintenance, and seamless smart grid interaction. Data from these adapters is wirelessly transmitted to the smart meter, where a Python-based optimization algorithm analyzes load patterns and generates an optimized load curve to facilitate DSM strategies such as load shifting, peak clipping, and valley filling. These strategies are aligned with Time-of-Use (ToU) pricing, promoting costeffective energy consumption while improving grid stability. Beyond energy optimization, the system incorporates automated billing with tariff calculation and a lockout mechanism to enforce payment compliance. The major contribution in this work is the incorporation of smart adapters capable of monitoring individual appliances in real time, controlling their operation, and diagnosing inefficiencies or faults. By integrating load optimization, financial accountability, and predictive maintenance, this solution offers a comprehensive, sustainable approach to modern smart home energy management, delivering benefits such as reduced energy costs, enhanced grid reliability, and lower carbon footprints.

title: ASIC Implementation of 5-Stage Pipelined RISC-Vprocessor with 4-Stage Pipelined Multiply Unit using Openlane
authors: Pankaj Nair V. M., P. Jayakrishnan
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The paper presents the ASIC implementation of a 32-bit, in-order, 5-stage pipelined RISC-V processor compliant with the RV32IM Instruction Set Architecture (ISA). The processor adopts a hybrid control logic scheme combining onehot and binary encoding to optimize control complexity and area efficiency. A notable enhancement is the introduction of arithmetic pipelining within the multiply unit, which improves the throughput of multiplication operations. The design was described in Verilog HDL and functionally verified using ModelSim to ensure correctness prior to synthesis. Physical implementation was carried out using the OpenLane open-source EDA toolchain, targeting the SkyWater 130nm process design kit (SKY130 PDK). The ASIC flow included synthesis, floorplanning, placement, clock tree synthesis, and routing. Post-layout analysis reports a maximum operating frequency of 100 MHz, a total power consumption of 36.1 mW, and a core area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$272,563 \mu^{2}$</tex>, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 5 \%}$</tex> utilization. The work demonstrates an efficient, lightweight RISC-V processor implementation and highlights a complete open-source ASIC design flow from RTL to GDSII.

title: Predictive Current Control of Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor Based on Improved MRAS Parameter Identification
authors: Xulong Wang, Tao Su
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: Incremental Deadbeat Predictive Current Control (IDPCC) does not require flux observation and has good application prospects. However, it is prone to performance degradation or even instability when inductance mismatch occurs. In this paper, an improved Model Reference Adaptive System (MRAS) parameter identification method is proposed to realize the online identification of inductance without flux linkage. This method improves the accuracy of inductance identification while ensuring the flux-free characteristics of IDPCC, and effectively solves the instability problem of the system under inductance mismatch.

title: BiCrossNet: Bridging Image and Landmark-Guided Features with Bidirectional Cross-Attention for Head Pose Estimation
authors: Jijun Wang, Zhou Tan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Head pose estimation plays a vital role in applications like human-computer interaction and driver monitoring. However, some existing methods often exhibit degraded performance under challenging conditions, particularly extreme head angles, partial occlusions, and varying illumination conditions, which limits their estimation accuracy. To address these challenges, we propose BiCrossNet, a two-branch convolutional neural network model that extracts landmark-guided features and image features through independent branches, and then fuses these two features to realize head pose estimation. We observe that naively concatenating and adding these features cannot fully utilize their complementarity, significantly reducing the accuracy of pose estimation. Therefore, we introduce the BiCrossGate module, employing a bidirectional cross-attention mechanism to model feature interactions and a dynamic gating mechanism to adaptively fuse features. Experiments demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms most existing approaches and achieves competitive, state-of-the-art performance on AFLW2000 and BIWI.
