title: MSIA: A Multi-Scale Interactive Attention Network Assisted by Self-Supervised Contrastive Learning for Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Gu Gong, Jiahua Zhang, Xiaopeng Wang, Xiaodi Shang, Zhicheng Pan, Jingyuan Wang, Xianwei Huo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Hyperspectral image classification is a crucial research area in hyperspectral remote sensing, aiming to identify the land cover type of each pixel in remote sensing images using computer analysis. This task faces two major challenges: (1) patch-based models typically operate at a fixed scale, limiting their ability to capture cross-scale interactions and often blurring the contribution of the central pixel due to interference from neighboring pixels; and (2) labeled samples in hyperspectral datasets are extremely limited, making supervised training prone to overfitting. To address these issues, we propose a Multi-Scale Interactive Attention Network (MSIA) that explicitly divides each patch into three concentric regions—Center, Near, and Relevant—to overcome the single-scale limitation. The Center Region is processed through multiple Transformer Encoders to enhance target-pixel perception, while the Near and Relevant Regions interact via a Central Attention Block, enabling effective local–global feature exchange. To mitigate the challenge of label scarcity, we further introduce a self-supervised contrastive pretraining strategy, which leverages abundant unlabeled samples and fine-tunes the network with only a small set of labeled data. Experiments on five benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art classification performance under limited supervision.

title: Granularity-Inconsistent Transformer for Unsupervised Hyperspectral Anomaly Detection
authors: Cong Wang, Yunfeng Wang, Yu Wang, Mingming Xu, Leiquan Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In hyperspectral anomaly detection (HAD), anomalous pixels typically exhibit a sparsely distributed spatial pattern. Existing deep models often generate backgrounds by reconstructing spectral vectors, yet fail to capture the inherent spatial characteristics of the image. To overcome the semantic and structural information loss caused by neglecting spatial features, we propose the granularity-inconsistent transformer (GIFormer) for unsupervised HAD. Specifically, the interaction between the spatial and spectral dimensions is leveraged to enhance the spatial-spectral feature representation of hyperspectral images, highlighting the differences between background and anomaly features. The GIFormer performs multilevel background reconstruction to detect anomalies. In the encoder, patch-level anomaly elimination masks are applied to reconstruct background features, where spatial correlations of anomalies are utilized to suppress anomalous patterns spanning multiple pixels. The decoder operates at the pixel level, using fine-grained receptive fields for global attention modeling, which enables the model to refine local details that may have been aggregated by the encoder in larger patches, ensuring the final reconstruction retains the intricate structure of the original hyperspectral data. Furthermore, adaptive weight loss is incorporated to guide network training. Extensive experimental results confirm the superior performance of GIFormer.

title: Exploring the Role of Randomization on Belief Rigidity in Online Social Networks
authors: Adiba Mahbub Proma, Neeley Pate, Raiyan Abdul Baten, Sifeng Chen, James N. Druckman, Gourab Ghoshal, Ehsan Hoque
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: People often stick to their existing beliefs, ignoring contradicting evidence or only interacting with those who reinforce their views. This tendency, referred to as being rigid in one's beliefs, is often driven by one's emotional connection to their beliefs and worsened by social media platforms which promote highly personalized content to maximize user engagement. As increased belief rigidity can negatively impact decisions, it is crucial to study and design interventions to reduce belief rigidity in online social networks. We design an experimental framework to passively infer belief rigidity and empirically quantify the effects of introducing randomness into the network structure as an intervention strategy. We recruit 163 participants into two conditions: one emulating traditional online platforms and the other more random. Our results suggest that individuals' beliefs are influenced by peer opinions, regardless of whether those opinions are similar to or differ from their own. Moreover, people are more likely to incorporate peers with (slightly) differing opinions into their networks when the recommendations are more randomized. Our findings highlight the need for future exploration into how design interventions can shape people's psycho-social functionalities in online social platforms.

title: An Adaptive Multi-scale Graph and Seasonal Decomposition LSTM Framework for Accurate Wastewater Effluent Forecasting
authors: Yifan Wu, Mengjia Shuo, Yongze Liu, Xiaoyu Zhang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Predicting effluent indicators is crucial for enabling a wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) to actively adjust treatment processes. However, research on long-term sequence forecasting under sudden water-quality fluctuations remains scarce. In this study, we propose a novel framework called multi-scale graph convolutional seasonal decomposition LSTM (MGCSD-LSTM) to enhance effluent prediction. It integrates temporal decomposition and multiple attention mechanisms with LSTM to capture both spatiotemporal dependencies and dynamic variations in water-quality data. Experiments on real WWTP datasets show that MGCSD-LSTM achieves high predictive accuracy across key effluent indicators, with R2 values of 0.9221, 0.8419, and 0.9151 for PRA, TN, and TP, respectively. The model consistently outperforms the four baseline models used for comparison. For example, when compared with conventional LSTM and Transformer architectures, the average R2 improves by approximately 20.1% and 7.0%, highlighting the superior modeling capability of the proposed approach. Moreover, the model exhibits notably narrower 95% confidence intervals across repeated runs, demonstrating enhanced prediction stability under different initialization conditions. Overall, MGCSD-LSTM provides accurate, robust, and computationally efficient effluent forecasting even in dynamic and disturbance-prone environments.

title: ELG-YOLO: Multi-Scale Feature Fusion and Attention Mechanisms for Enhanced Steel Surface Defect Detection
authors: Zihui Chen, Weijun Fan, Bin Guo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Surface defect detection is essential for industrial product quality assurance. To address challenges including large-scale variations, diverse defect morphologies, high inter-class similarity, and strong background interference in steel surface defects, an improved ELG-YOLO model based on YOLOv11n is proposed. The design integrates Gated Bottleneck Convolution (GBC) to enhance the C3K2 module, constructing the C3K2_GBC structure that reduces parameters while improving the extraction of steel defect detail features. Local-global feature representation is synergistically strengthened through the incorporated LRSA-EVCBlock attention module, boosting the discrimination of defects with high inter-class similarity. A Quadruple Adaptive Spatial Fusion Head (QASFFHead) is adopted to resolve insufficient small-object detection performance, suppress feature redundancy, and mitigate conflicts arising from multi-scale feature fusion. Additionally, the Focaler-IoU is selected as the bounding box regression loss function to optimize localization accuracy by focusing on samples of varying difficulty. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that ELG-YOLO surpasses both baseline and state-of-the-art YOLO models. It achieves a 6.91% higher mAP@0.6 than the baseline, with improvements of 4.72% for crazings, 10.29% for inclusions, 26.76% for rolled-in scales, and 8.40% for scratches. These results validate ELG-YOLO’s accuracy and robustness, providing an efficient and reliable solution for steel surface defect detection in real industrial scenarios.

title: MSMD-YOLO: Enhanced Printed Circuit Board Defect Detection with a Multi-Scale Merging and Attention Network
authors: Chan Deng, Ribhan Zafira Abdul Rahman, Asnor Juraiza Ishak, Raja Kamil Raja Ahmad
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The growing demand for flawless printed circuit boards (PCBs) necessitates highly precise and reliable defect detection technologies. However, the tiny size of defects, complex textures, and irregular geometries present major challenges to existing vision-based approaches. To overcome these limitations, this study introduces MSMD-YOLO, an enhanced detection framework developed as a next-generation extension of YOLOv11 [1] for PCB inspection. The proposed Multi-Scale Feature Merging (MSFM) module enables comprehensive fusion of structural information across multiple scales, enriching fine-grained feature representation and detail extraction. In parallel, the MDA-Attention module integrates channel-wise and spatial attention mechanisms with dilated convolutions [2], significantly improving semantic discrimination and spatial sensitivity while maintaining low computational complexity. Additionally, the Weighted IoU(WIoU) [3] loss introduces adaptive attention that prioritizes medium-quality anchors and enhances localization of small or low-quality defects. Experimental evaluation on a challenging PCB defect dataset demonstrates that MSMD-YOLO achieves a mean average precision (mAP) [4] of 92.9%, outperforming YOLOv11 by 5.0 percentage points. The model effectively minimizes false detections and missed defects, confirming its robustness and reliability as a practical solution for high-accuracy industrial inspection and automated quality control in advanced PCB manufacturing environments.

title: Machine Learning Approaches for Handling Missing Data in Antimicrobial Resistance Databases
authors: C. Condorelli, V. Carchiolo, M. Frasca, L. V. Gambuzza
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a growing global health threat, and data-driven approaches play a critical role in monitoring, understanding, and predicting resistance patterns. However, AMR datasets often suffer from missing values, which can significantly compromise the performance and reliability of statistical analyses and machine learning models. In this study, we investigate the effectiveness of various machine learning-based imputation techniques to handle missing data in AMR datasets. Specifically, we address two types of missing data, missing completely at random and missing not at random, and evaluate their impact in both binary datasets, where entries indicate the presence or absence of resistance genes, and continuous datasets, where values represent the relative abundance of antimicrobial resistance genes. For binary datasets, we assess the robustness of each imputation method using standard classification metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve. For continuous datasets, we assess imputation performance using regression metrics, including normalized mean absolute error and normalized mean root squared error. Our results demonstrate that advanced imputation techniques substantially improve data completeness and model performance across both data types. These findings highlight the importance of tailored imputation strategies in enhancing the quality and reliability of AMR surveillance and predictive systems.

title: Handling Dual Skewness in Citywide Crime Prediction Using Personalized Graph Federated Learning
authors: Bhumika, Philippe Lalanda, German Vega, Debasis Das
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: The widespread deployment of sensors and recent advances in machine learning have enabled the development of predictive services in smart cities, particularly in the domain of public safety through predictive policing across different regions. Recently, training on these distributed regions is facilitated by federated learning (FL) without exposing sensitive data. However, crime data exhibit inherently complex spatiotemporal dynamics and suffer from dual skewness, as both the quantity and category distribution of crimes vary significantly across regions. Most existing federated methods struggle to effectively handle such skewed distributions, while also being limited to capture spatial dependencies. To overcome these challenges, we propose an approach called graph structured personalized federated learning (GSpfl), which jointly models spatial and temporal patterns in crime data. Specifically, GSpfl incorporates graph based aggregation at the server to model spatial dynamics, where similarity based adjacency matrix enable convolution among related clients to mitigate quantity skewness. On the client side, temporal dynamics are learned locally with regularization terms to balance global knowledge sharing and local model adaptation, while Focal Tversky loss is employed to address category imbalance. Experiments on real-world crime datasets from Los Angeles (LA) and Chicago (CHI) demonstrate the superior performance of our approach compared to ten baseline and state-of-the-art FL methods.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Transformer Network-Based Probabilistic Multi-Energy Flow Calculation in Integrated Energy System
authors: Huayi Wu, Zhao Xu, Shengwei Wang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Probabilistic energy flow (PEF) is a fundamental task for the operation of conventional model-based integrated energy systems (IES), electricity–gas–heating coupled systems, while challenged by heavy computational burdens and uncertainties introduced by renewable energy sources (RES). To overcome this bottleneck, a novel data-driven hybrid quantum-transformer network (HQTN) is proposed for fast PEF calculation. Specifically, the classical Transformer network captures the dynamic spatial uncertainty features via a novel graph attention mechanism to model the uncertain fluctuating RES features. Additionally, a quantum neural network is proposed to extract the high-dimensional, complex relationships of IES operational data, thereby improving calculational accuracy. Case studies are conducted on both IEEE 33-node electric/20-node gas/17-node heating and 118-node electric/48-node gas/14-node heating systems. Experimental evaluation results verify that the proposed approach achieves high accuracy and maintains strong computational performance in PEF calculation.

title: Prototype Development and Testing of a Superconducting Synchronous Condenser With REBCO Rotor Magnets
authors: Qihong Wu, Peng Song, Zhengjun Shi, Zhirong Yang, Liangjun Shao, Timing Qu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: The advancing commercialization of high-temperature superconducting (HTS) materials has positioned HTS synchronous condensers (SCs) as a promising solution for dynamic reactive power compensation in modern power grids. To advance this technology, the China Southern Power Grid Corporation launched a project to develop a 10 Mvar-class HTS SC, with an initial 100-kVA-class prototype designed to validate core technologies. The prototype, featuring Rare Earth Barium Copper Oxide (REBCO) magnets and a helium gas circulation cooling system, underwent thermal and electrical performance tests. The thermal test showed that, under a stable 150 A excitation for over 1 hour, the rotor magnet's temperature rose by a mere  1 K. Furthermore, in the electrical performance tests, the stator withstood a short-circuit current exceeding 500 A, and the prototype delivered nearly 100 kW of active power output in generator mode. The prototype also successfully passed multiple rapid excitation regulation tests without any damage. These results validate the technical feasibility of the REBCO-based HTS SC design, marking a significant step toward its practical application for enhancing grid security and stability.

title: Attitude–Orbit Integrated Modeling and Control for Flexible Spacecraft Based on Twistors and Fully Actuated System Approach
authors: Dongyan Jin, Jianbin Qiu, Wenqiang Ji, Tong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: The complex coupling relationship among attitude, orbit, and vibration challenges the control of flexible spacecraft. This article investigates the integrated attitude–orbit dynamical modeling and control of flexible spacecraft, which accurately describes the above complex coupling relationship to improve control performance. First, a twistor-based attitude–orbit integrated model of flexible spacecraft is established, avoiding the unitary constraint of the dual-quaternion-based model. Then, the attitude–orbit integrated control strategy based on the fully actuated system (FAS) approach is proposed for flexible spacecraft, which yields an arbitrary designable linear closed-loop system. Finally, the correctness of the dynamical model and the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed control strategy are demonstrated by two sets of simulations.

title: Development of a Microwave SQUID Multiplexer for Magnetic Microbolometers
authors: N. Müller, J. Bonilla-Neira, J. Geria, M. García Redondo, L. Ferreyro, M. Hampel, M. Wegner, A. Almela, S. Kempf
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The search for primordial B-modes in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) requires highly sensitive and scalable detector systems. The magnetic microbolometer (MMB) is an emerging detector concept that exploits the magnetic properties of paramagnetic materials at sub-kelvin temperatures, offering bolometers with a high dynamic range and low intrinsic noise. In recent years, the microwave SQUID multiplexer (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>MUX) has become a key technology to efficiently read large low-temperature detector arrays, enabling the readout of hundreds to thousands of detectors over a single transmission line with low noise and minimal power dissipation while reducing the cryogenic setup complexity. In this work, we report the design, fabrication and characterization of a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>MUX optimized for MMB detectors and share our latest experimental results from a bolometer prototype. These findings provide valuable insight of the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>MUX in advancing next-generation CMB instrumentation and also demonstrate its suitability for novel detector technologies such as the MMB.

title: Multivehicles Cooperation: USV and AUV Cooperative Data Collection for Underwater Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Zheng Hu, Qichao Xu, Zhou Su, Minghui Dai, Ruidong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: To advance the development of maritime intelligent transportation systems (MITS), underwater wireless sensor networks (UWSNs), composed of numerous sensor nodes, have been widely deployed for underwater information perception. However, UWSNs face critical challenges in achieving cost-effective and timely data collection due to their large-scale deployment and stringent data timeliness requirements. To address this challenge, this paper proposes an efficient data collection scheme for UWSNs through the collaboration between uncrewed surface vehicles (USVs) and autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). Specifically, we first introduce a cooperative framework where AUVs select appropriate USVs to form USV-AUV clusters. Within each cluster, AUVs are responsible for sensing data collection, while USVs act as relay nodes, moving toward the destination (e.g., data center). We then devise an evolutionary game-theoretic cluster forming mechanism, deriving evolutionarily stable strategies (ESS) through replicator dynamics analysis, which guarantees a provable Nash equilibrium. Next, we present a hierarchical optimization method that models the interaction between UWSNs and the cluster as a two-agent Markov decision process, where a dual-agent Q-learning algorithm is designed to jointly optimize the decisions of both entities. Finally, extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed scheme outperforms conventional methods in improving the efficiency of sensing data collection for UWSNs.

title: A Novel Approach to Identifying Oscillation-Vulnerable Buses Through Reflection Coefficient Analysis
authors: Taewan Choi, Min-kuk Kim, Seongmin Pyo, Haechul Choi, Dongho Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: In modern power systems, the proliferation of renewable energy resources and power-electronic devices has increased the risk of oscillations, necessitating stability assessment that extends beyond rotor-angle, frequency, and voltage stability to explicitly include oscillation stability. This study proposes a method to proactively identify oscillation-vulnerable buses under steady-state conditions. Conventional approaches rely on modal analysis of time-series data collected after system disturbances or over long operating periods, which limits proactive intervention. We analyze the magnitude and phase of the reflection coefficient derived from the grid impedance seen from a given bus and the bus impedance, and across variations of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{P}, \mathrm{Q}, \mathrm{V}$</tex> operating point extract the reflection-coefficient shape characteristics to construct a probabilistic bus-wise oscillation-vulnerability index. Using the power-system simulator PSS/E, we compute reflection coefficients across multiple test systems and verify the association between reflection-coefficient features and oscillation-prone locations.

title: Performance-Driven MAC Unit Designs in Convolution Engines: A Hardware-Centric Review
authors: E. Margaret Belsia, M. Thiruveni
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Convolution operations are extensively used for deep learning tasks and especially in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for image processing, computer vision, and other machine learning applications. Having a memory order infrastructure is not a sufficient condition for correctness of programs such as these, because these operations are computationally intensive and need high parallelism and memory bandwidth to execute on a traditional general purpose processor. To overcome this issue, Graphics Processing Units (GPUs), Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs), and Application Specific Integrated Circuits (ASICs) have been implemented as a special hardware accelerator for accelerating the convolution operation. This research paper has reviewed architectures and performance efficiency of various hardware accelerators for convolution engines. Systolic arrays, SIMD/SIMT based MAC acceleration, as well as dataflow architectures, are examined in the paper for proposing key architectures to optimize Multiply Accumulate (MAC) operations, critical to convolution tasks. Also, the techniques of reducing latency and increasing data throughput like on-chip buffering, tiling, in-memory computing are discussed in view how to optimize the memory. Finally, the paper also compares the pros and cons of GPUs, FPGA, ASIC, and neuromorphic computing platforms that are emerging, and where they can be used for particular convolution. Finally, the challenges of the design complexity, scalability, and energy consumption are discussed and future research trends of hardware based convolution acceleration are discussed as well.

title: Drone Based Precision Agriculture Technique to Increase Crop Yield Using Machine Learning
authors: V. C. Mahavishnu, S. Kalyan Kumar, Surya Sai Ganga Dhaaran Pithani, U. Cheran
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The increasing global population, combined with climate variability and finite natural resources, poses significant challenges to modern agriculture. Conventional farming practices are often labor-intensive, inefficient, and lack real-time monitoring of crop health and soil conditions. Precision agriculture has emerged as a solution by integrating advanced technologies such as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), Internet of Things (IoT) sensors, and artificial intelligence (AI). In this work, we propose a drone-based precision agriculture framework that utilizes highre-solution aerial images and cloud-based deep learning pipelines to automate key farm management operations. The system focuses on four main objectives: (i) detecting water scarcity to enable responsive irrigation, (ii) mapping and identifying weeds, (iii) recognizing plant diseases and suggesting appropriate treatments, and (iv) monitoring crop growth to provide accurate yield predictions. The proposed framework aims to improve efficiency, reduce resource wastage, and support data-driven decision-making in agriculture. The proposed system employs a DJI mavic 2 pro UAV equipped with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 K}, 60 \text{fps}$</tex> camera to capture high-resolution imagery during scheduled flights. Captured images are transmitted to the cloud, where advanced machine learning algorithms process them to generate actionable insights. Experimental results demonstrate strong performance, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 4. 3 2 \%}$</tex> accuracy in growth estimation, 97.84% accuracy in weed detection, and 93.87% accuracy in disease identification with recommended treatments. The findings indicate that the framework effectively reduces manual labor, optimizes resource usage, and enhances crop productivity. By delivering real-time insights to farmers through mobile applications, this approach supports data-driven decision-making, promotes sustainable agricultural practices, and contributes to addressing global challenges of food security and resource management.

title: A Soft-Real-Time Optimal Scheduler for DAG Tasks with Node-Level Self Dependencies
authors: Shareef Ahmed, James H. Anderson
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Modern real-time workloads are often expressed as processing graphs that have complex dataflow dependencies. No scheduling algorithm with a holistic analysis of graph-based tasks is known that can provide bounded response times without utilization loss, thus ensuring soft-real-time optimality, when a node instance depends on some of its prior instances and multiple invocations of the same graph can be active simultaneously. This paper presents a scheduling policy for such a graph-based task and provides a response-time analysis that guarantees bounded response times without utilization loss. Experimental evaluations show that our scheduler yields significantly tighter response-time bounds than existing soft-real-time optimal schedulers.

title: Semantic Embedding Models for Technical Documentation Analysis in Battery Management Systems Education
authors: Gulbaxor Mamurjonova, Kamoldin Karimov, Azizbek Kenjayeva, Ozoda Nazarova, Marifatkhon Anarbaeva, Baxtiyor Zikirov
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The increasing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) has highlighted the critical role of battery management systems (BMS) in ensuring safety, efficiency, and longevity of energy storage components, emphasizing the need for effective educational tools to train future engineers and technicians. Traditional BMS training relies heavily on static manuals, unstructured technical documents, and lecture-based instruction, which limits learners' ability to quickly extract, relate, and apply complex technical information. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a Semantic Embedding Model for Technical Documentation Analysis in Battery Management Systems Education (SEM-BMS), which leverages advanced natural language processing (NLP) techniques, including domain-specific embeddings and semantic similarity analysis, to automatically extract key concepts, relationships, and procedures from diverse BMS documentation. SEM-BMS organizes the extracted knowledge into structured, interactive knowledge maps, enabling adaptive learning, efficient information retrieval, and enhanced comprehension of intricate battery operation concepts. Experimental evaluation on a curated dataset of BMS manuals, technical reports, and instructional notes demonstrated that SEM-BMS achieved a 92 % accuracy in concept extraction, improved knowledge retrieval efficiency by 36 %, and increased student learning outcomes by 29 % compared to conventional keyword-based and lecture-driven methods. These results confirm that semantic embedding-based analysis significantly enhances both accessibility and quality of BMS education. In conclusion, SEMBMS provides a scalable, intelligent, and interactive framework for structuring unstructured technical content, bridging the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical understanding, and fostering a more effective learning environment for battery management systems education.

title: Mixed Supervision for 6-DoF Grasp Pose Estimation with Few-shot Annotation
authors: Yi Zhong, Tianshi Xu, Zhijie Zhong, Lianfang Tian, Yuheng Huang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Grasp pose estimation is a fundamental capability in service robotics and industrial automation, essential for precise manipulation in complex scenes. The point cloud-based 6 degrees of freedom (6-DoF) grasp pose estimation methods play a crucial role in this field but require expensive fine-grained annotations. To address this challenge, we propose a mixed supervision learning framework that integrates a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data for the 6-DoF grasp pose estimation task. Our method both take point cloud and image modalities as inputs, with supervision from 6-DoF and rectangle grasp annotations, respectively. Furthermore, for the abundant unlabeled data, we adopt a pseudo-labeling strategy, where estimations from the image-based model are used to guide the training of the point cloud-based branch. By jointly training on labeled and unlabeled data, our approach reduces the reliance on costly 6-DoF grasp pose annotations. We evaluate our method on the GraspNet-1Billion benchmark under the few-shot setting, demonstrating that our mixed supervision strategy significantly improves 6-DoF grasping performance even with limited labeled data.

title: Electric Vehicle Charging Station with Solar PV and Grid Power
authors: Yashraj Singh, Antra Nakhasi, S Meikandasivam, Abhigna Raptad, Vasadi Gowtham Raj, D Vijayakumar
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The unreliability of the grid in India with frequent load shedding and high dependence on fossil fuels as an energy source, has created a need for sustainable and green energy source that can facilitate a robust and well-connected charging infrastructure. A hybrid charging system connected with the PV system and the grid provides reliable and sustainable energy supply. When the power output of the PV system is high, it is the sole supplier of the charging station and the backup battery. The boost converter along with perturb and observe (P&O) MPPT algorithm ensures maximum power output. When the solar energy is unable to take the load of the charging station, the grid and backup battery supplies energy to the charging station. The V2V charging is also implemented to better manage and optimize the energy flow. To manage the power flow amongst these components, a bidirectional buck boost converter along with an optimized PI controller are used to control the charging and the discharging process of the batteries connected. The complete work is implemented in MATLAB/Simulink environment.

title: A Multimodal Biometric Authentication Framework using Hybrid CNN-LSTM and Aquavian Optimization for Robust Face, Hand, and Iris Recognition
authors: Brajula W, Menaka D
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The framework proposed in this study is a Multimodal Biometric Authentication Framework which provides extremely accurate and reliable identification by combining face, hand, and iris traits from the Multimodal Biometric Dataset (MULB). It operates sequentially in five stages, namely, Data Collection, Preprocessing, Feature Extraction, Feature Selection, and Classification, to enhance accuracy and robustness under varying acquisition conditions. During the preprocessing step, MTCNN detects and aligns the faces, CLAHE is used for contrast enhancement, and Gaussian filtering is done along with z-score normalization to remove noise and balance pixel values. Data augmentation methods such as horizontal flipping of images, small-angle rotation, and synthetic noise are applied to make the system robust under pose and illumination variations. Feature extraction is done on face images with MobileNetV3, which possesses the ability to describe discriminative spatial representations, whereas optical flow maps carry temporal information necessary for dynamic patterns. Multimodal feature fusion across all biometric traits then happens by means of simple feature concatenation that represents more complete information. The AOA is a hybridization of the WOA and POA; it chooses the most salient features by balancing the need for global exploration/local exploitation, thereby improving dimensionality reduction and classification accuracy. The final classification is carried out by a hybrid CNN-LSTM model that concurrently considers CNNbased spatial feature learning and LSTM-based temporal modeling, with a softmax layer atop for identity verification. Experimental evaluation shows that the proposed framework has secured accuracy of 99.36 %, which well above the baseline framework in terms of standalone CNN loss of 96.10 % and MobileNetV2 loss of 95.24 %, while also maintaining low false positive and false negative rates of 0.92 % and 0.78 %, respectively. Due to the lightweight nature of this system, it can be run on edge devices in real-time, based on which adaptive decisions can be taken in security-critical environments. In the future, work can be done to make it more robust about extreme lighting conditions and cross-cultural variations, thus extending the framework further for global biometric authentication systems.

title: Modified RIME Algorithm with Deep Reinforcement Learning Assisted Operator Selection for Robotic Assembly Line Balancing Problem
authors: Hao Guo, Zhiwei Luo, Jinxiong Zhang, Zhigang Zhao, Jing Zhu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Aiming the cost optimization problem in Robotic Assembly Line Balancing (RALB) by proposing a modified RIME algorithm that integrates Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL-RIME). Innovatively, a DRL framework is embedded within the RIME algorithm: using population convergence, diversity, and feasibility as the state space, and evolutionary operations as the action space, a weighted reward function is designed to drive the Q-network for dynamic operator selection. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly out-performs traditional methods in benchmark cases, providing a novel solution for improving both the production efficiency and energy-saving performance of assembly lines.

title: Android UI Based Portable PCB Components Identification System Using Template Matching Image Processing Strategy
authors: Priyanka Roy, R. Raja Singh, J. Dheeba, Sitharthan R, Ketaka Singh
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Modern-day printed circuit boards (PCBs) given their complexity, are bound to have defects, and to have a faster and accurate testing method, machine vision is a promising technology. This paper uses the OpenCV template matching to discuss an Android user interface-based system for testing PCBs for missing components. Adding new and distinct PCBs to the system, which could be inspected for missing components, is a breeze in the proposed system; simply populate the database with additional templates. This contrasts with the need for an ML. Including an entirely novel PCB for algorithm testing necessitates the recurrence of the laborious process of amassing hundreds of datasets and training the algorithm. Objectively, the project sought to create a straightforward yet precise method for locating absent PCB components. The developed algorithm is trained and tested using the MOSFET circuit driver PCB. The system was evaluated by performing two tests, and the maximum accuracy was noted to be 94 percent with good speed of detection.

title: Research on Cat’s Eye Target Detection Algorithm Based on Multi-Kernel Perception
authors: Tao Jiang, Yulian Xiao, Xinan Lian
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: To address the detection bottlenecks of small cat’s eye targets in complex environments—specifically low pixel ratio and insufficient feature extraction—this study proposes an improved YOLOv8 algorithm based on multi-kernel perception. First, the C2f-MKP module is designed to enable parallel extraction of multi-scale features and alleviate gradient vanishing; second, the Decoder module of RT-DETR is integrated to enhance localization and decoding performance. Together, these components construct an end-to-end detection framework. Experiments confirm the effectiveness of the proposed modules, and the improved algorithm achieves a lower false alarm rate, providing a practical solution for cat’s eye target detection.

title: A Simple Proof of Consensus for Second-order Integrator Agents with Switching Topology and Time-varying Delays
authors: Changjiang Li, Shuxia Ye, Keli Li, Xueying Sun, Qi Fu, Jiahui Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: In this paper, the consensus problem for discrete-time second-order integrator agent network is revisited. For the commonly used consensus protocol of this agent network, under conditions of periodically asymmetric topology switching and time-varying delays, a simple and rigorous proof for consensus achieving is obtained by a seminorm-convolution integrated method. Numerical examples illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: CH2AI: Dynamic Checkpoint Scheduling of Anytime Neural Networks on Heterogeneous Units
authors: Matthias Stammler, Georgios Sotiropoulos, Julian Hoefer, Tanja Harbaum, Krishnendu Guha, Amlan Chakrabarti, Jürgen Becker
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: The execution of diverse machine learning (ML) functionality on centralized automotive systems has dynamic execution characteristics. This includes uniform release characteristics as well as spikes in utilization of the deployed accelerators, during which functional constraints still need to be met, albeit at a reduced confidence in the result. Existing methods address this problem with dynamic rescaling or scheduling of anytime neural networks. Dynamic rescaling is not available for most pretrained neural networks, and existing work either do not support heterogeneous execution units or incur a high timing overhead. We introduce our open-source tool CH2AI to solve this challenge. CH2AI extends existing work by the support for heterogeneous execution units and a streamlined execution. CH2AI supports the generation of anytime neural networks from existing neural networks without the need to retrain the original network and the scheduling of these anytime neural networks onto heterogeneous execution units. Our evaluation includes an analysis of timing overheads, a timeliness analyses, as well as a tradeoff analysis between accuracy and (over) utilization. We observed a timing overhead between 2.1% and 7.2% for our tested ML models. For an (over) utilization of 250%, we observed timeliness of up to 99% for uniform task releases and between 70% and 85% for random task releases, depending on the used model. We preserved the accuracy in a 15% range for utilization spikes of up to 250%.

title: Towards Proactive Cybersecurity in Smart Grids: Behavioral Advanced Persistent Threat Detection via Adversarial and Autoencoder Architectures
authors: Lahcen Hassine, Yassine Loukili, Hasna Chaibi, Younes Ledmaoui, Rachid Saadane, Abdellah Chehri
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Smart grids are confronted with growing cybersecurity threats by Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) targeting vulnerabilities of cyber-physical systems with stealthy, multi-stage attacks. Conventional signature-based rule-driven detection mechanisms cannot detect these advanced threats. This paper presents an active behavior detection system using Generative Adversarial Networks and Autoencoders for benign network behavior modeling and anomaly detection characteristic of APTs. Tested on actual smart grid data, our hybrid solution is 96.5 % accurate and has an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{F 1}$</tex>-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{96.59 \%}$</tex>, surpassing baseline MLPs and state-of-the-art techniques. The main innovations are adversarial training for generating attack patterns and Autoencoder reconstruction for anomaly detection. Experiments show the framework's robustness to stealthy APTs with few false positives. This research propels adaptive defense technologies for critical infrastructure, bridging the gaps in scalability and dynamic threat modeling.

title: Identification method of gas-solid flow regime based on electrostatic sensor and TSResNet
authors: YiNan Jiang, XueZhen Cheng
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: To address the limitations in the accuracy of gas–solid two-phase flow regime identification, this paper proposes a deep learning approach that integrates electrostatic sensor signals with a two-stream residual network (TSResNet). A ring-shaped electrostatic sensor was employed to acquire signals corresponding to stratified flow, dispersed flow, annular flow, and the transitional regime between laminar and dune flow (laminar-dune flow) in a horizontal pneumatic conveying pipeline. The signals were then transformed into two-dimensional images using Gramian Angular Fields (GAF) and Markov Transition Fields (MTF), which were subsequently fed into the TSResNet. By integrating static and dynamic features through dual parallel branches, the proposed GAF–MTF–TSResNet model enables effective recognition of various flow regimes. Experimental results show that the model achieves an accuracy of 96.31%, and demonstrates superior robustness and recognition stability compared with other deep learning architectures, including ResNet50, ResNeXt, and the two-stream convolutional neural network (TSCNN).

title: HybridFaceNet: AI-ML Framework for Digital Attendance Systems with GPS and Multi-Modal Biometrics
authors: Bhumesh Masram, Shailesh More, Satya Prakash Patel
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Traditional attendance systems face significant challenges, including inefficiency, reliance on contact-based methods, and vulnerability to proxy attendance. HybridFaceNet is a comprehensive framework that integrates YOLOv7-based face recognition, GPS location verification, and liveness detection. The proposed system achieves 96.8% accuracy by combining (1) a lightweight variant of FaceNet optimized for edge devices, (2) encrypted GPS geofencing to prevent location spoofing, and (3) MediaPipe-based liveness detection to thwart fraudulent attempts. It is assessed on a dataset that includes more than 500 students in different lighting situations. Compared to current systems, HybridFaceNet reduces false positive rates by 40% and guarantees GDPR compliance using blockchain-secured log files. The modular Django-TensorFlow architecture makes this system scalable to large institutions with real-time processing at 30 frames per second. We also suggest a privacy-preserving Federated Learning extension to handle ethical issues related to biometric data processing. Index Terms - Face Detection, Face Recognition, YOLOv7, Computing, Federated Learning, GPS Geofencing, Blockchain, Attendance System

title: AI-Driven Stylistic Analysis of PLC Programming Content for Industrial Automation Education
authors: Bekpashsha Ahmedova, Dilrabo Quvvatova, Dadaxon Abdullayev, Muhayyo Azimova, Shavkatjon Mirzayev, Muhabbat Qodirova, Khalima Akhmedova
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly being deployed in industrial automation education to enhance the comprehension and delivery of programming content for programmable logic controllers (PLCs), which remain foundational to modern factory systems. However, the rapid growth of PLC-based instructional materials often varies widely in style, complexity, and pedagogy, creating inconsistencies that hinder student engagement, knowledge retention, and adaptability across diverse learning environments. Traditional curriculum designs rarely account for stylistic alignment between instructional text and learner needs, limiting the effectiveness of teaching PLC logic and programming structures. To address this problem, the paper propose an AI-Driven Stylistic Profiling and Adaptation Model (AISPAM), which combines natural language processing (NLP), transformer-based text representation, and unsupervised clustering to analyze and adapt PLC programming content according to stylistic markers such as technical density, instructional clarity, cognitive load, and domain-specific readability. AISPAM classifies content into pedagogical clusters, aligning instructional material style with targeted learner categories ranging from novice technicians to advanced engineering students. Experimental validation on a curated dataset of PLC programming manuals, learning modules, and industrial training documents demonstrated that AISPAM achieved over 87 % accuracy in stylistic clustering, while adaptive transformation improved student comprehension scores by 22 % in test scenarios. These findings confirm that AI-based stylistic analysis can effectively bridge the gap between technical rigor and adaptive pedagogy, providing a robust framework for developing dynamic, learner-centered curricula in automation education. The work highlights future potential for integrating stylistic adaptability into smart industrial training platforms and intelligent tutoring systems for lifelong learning.

title: Real-Time Smart Headlight Switching for Enhanced Road Safety
authors: Dhanapriya D, Dikssha M M, Harini V K, Arthi V N
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This Project is aimed at creating an Arduino-based (smart vehicle headlight auto switching) to improve driving safety during night and overall visibility. The system employs an Arduino Uno board as the central controller, as well as an LDR (Light Dependent Resistor) sensor to measure light levels around the environment. When the sensor senses high light conditions usually during Night, the headlight tilt from up to down to provide unbroken visibility to the driver and to offer improved road illumination. Also, a servo motor is incorporated to change the headlight's vertical position. This embedded system controls vertical positioning of headlights alone and not with the vehicle wheels or the steering mechanism. It is distinct from IoT-based solutions, as it works in complete autonomy independent of an internet connection, resulting in cost efficiency, reliability, and simplicity to install. Adjusting the position of the headlamp automatically based on the condition in the surrounding environment, the system provides enhanced road safety, lesser glare to the approaching cars, and comfort to drive on various lighting environments.

title: Watt Watcher: An RTOS-Powered Energy Meter
authors: Surya K, K Samhith, Monish Kumar H S, Shanmugasundaram M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a real-time energy monitoring system built around the ESP32 microcontroller and the FreeRTOS real-time operating system. With growing demands for accurate, responsive, and networked energy metering in smart homes and microgrids, the need for deterministic and modular embedded solutions has become critical. The proposed system employs the ZMPT101B voltage sensor and SCT-013 current transformer to acquire analog signals, which are digitized through the ADS1115 16-bit ADC for high-resolution sampling. FreeRTOS plays a pivotal role in orchestrating multiple parallel tasks-voltage and current acquisition, RMS computation, OLED visualization, and Blynk-based IoT communication-by leveraging features such as task prioritization, core pinning, queues, semaphores, and software timers. Through structured multitasking and resource isolation, FreeRTOS ensures minimal jitter, reliable data integrity, and real-time responsiveness across all processes. High-priority tasks like ADC sampling are protected from delays caused by Wi-Fi communication or display rendering, which are offloaded to lower-priority threads. This design enables the system to perform continuous real-time monitoring without blocking or data loss, even under fluctuating workloads. Experimental results validate the accuracy, efficiency, and robustness of the RTOS-powered system, demonstrating consistent energy tracking over time and seamless cloud synchronization via Blynk. Furthermore, the RTOS-centric approach provides a scalable foundation for future extensions such as TinyML-based edge analytics, blockchain integration, and energy-aware task scheduling for self-powered IoT applications. The outcomes highlight the indispensable role of RTOS in advancing next-generation, intelligent, and decentralized energy monitoring solutions.

title: Real-Time Roadside Animal Detection for Traffic Safety Using Yolov8 and Faster RCNN
authors: Jayapriya M, Priyanka R, Renuga Devi G, Jenipa R, Mathumitha T, Deepa Lakshmi A
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Roadside animal detection systems are advancing road safety by integrating real-time animal detection into traffic monitoring and in-vehicle applications. This scalable, softwareonly solution can be deployed on personal computers or servers, offering an efficient way to prevent vehicle-animal collisions. Using deep learning, this system leverages advanced object detection models like YOLO (You Only Look Once) and Faster R-CNN, achieving accurate animal detection from live video feeds captured by roadside or in-vehicle cameras. The system is built entirely in Python and uses frameworks such as TensorFlow or PyTorch for developing detection models, while OpenCV facilitates real-time video processing. By identifying and classifying animals, the system displays bounding boxes with confidence scores around detected animals, providing clear visual cues to drivers. Its primary goal is to deliver timely alerts, helping to minimize vehicle collisions with wildlife, especially in areas with frequent wildlife crossings. Designed to be robust, the system operates effectively under a range of environmental conditions, ensuring reliable detection during both day and night. This project ultimately aims to enhance road safety and reduce the environmental impact of vehicle-wildlife collisions, addressing a pressing need for sustainable and intelligent traffic solutions.

title: Work-in-Progress: A Timing-Anomaly Free Dynamic Scheduling on Heterogeneous Systems
authors: Yixuan Zhu, Yinkang Gao, Binze Jiang, Xiaohang Gong, Lei Gong, Chao Wang, Xi Li, Xuehai Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Heterogeneous systems commonly adopt dynamic scheduling algorithms to improve resource utilization and enhance scheduling flexibility. However, it may introduce timing anomalies, wherein locally reduced tasks' actual execution times can lead to an increase in the overall system execution time. This phenomenon significantly complicates the analysis of WorstCase Response Time (WCRT), rendering conventional analysis either overly pessimistic or unsafe, and often necessitating exhaustive state-space exploration to ensure correctness. To address this challenge, this paper presents the first timing-anomalyfree dynamic scheduling algorithm for heterogeneous systems, referred to as Deterministic Dynamic Execution. The core idea is to apply deterministic execution constraints, which partially restrict the resource allocation and execution order of tasks at runtime. It achieves a safe and tight WCRT through a single offline simulation execution. In this paper, we provide preliminary experimental validation of the timing-anomaly-free property of our algorithm and outline the basic idea of a formal proof.

title: An LLM-Enabled Multi-Agent System for Evidence-Grounded Fact Checking
authors: Hong N. Dao, Yasuhiro Hashimoto, Truong Cong Thang
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Fact-checking is essential to mitigate the spread of rumors and misinformation on social media. While large language models (LLMs) have enabled progress in automated factchecking, current approaches remain limited as they largely focus on producing more convincing rationales without systematically assessing how evidence quality affects verdict accuracy. In this paper, we propose a multi-agent fact-checking system. The proposed system is based on multiple independent agents with a retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline. Evaluation is carried out with metrics of accuracy, Hungarian METEOR, and AVeriTeC scores. The experimental results show that the proposed system yields higher-quality evidence and more accurate verdicts across four categories.

title: A Monolithically Integrated GaN MIS-HEMT DFF Circuit for High Temperature and High Frequency Applications
authors: Yihao Xu, Zhengxuan Li, Jie Jiao, Qiyuan Cui, Pingyu Cao, Kepeng Zhao, Yinchao Zhao, Miao Cui
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This paper presents a monolithically integrated D-type flip-flop (DFF) based on GaN MIS-HEMT technology, designed for high-temperature and high-frequency operation. The circuit, employing both depletion- and enhancement-mode MIS-HEMTs, was evaluated up to $200^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 500 kHz. Key metrics including propagation delay and signal integrity were characterized. The DFF maintains stable DC margins across $25-200{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1-500 \mathrm{kHz}$. Rise time increases with frequency from $0.32 \mu \mathrm{~s}$ at 10 kHz to $0.59 \mu \mathrm{~s}$ at 200 kHz with little temperature dependence, while fall time show a small variation from 0.13-0.35 $\mu \mathrm{s}$. These results demonstrate the feasibility of GaN MIS-HEMT sequential logic under thermal and switching test conditions.

title: Cross-Modality Cooperative Perception for Multiple Vehicles under V2X
authors: Tianci Fu, Fengxiang Long, Mengzhen Li, Xiaobo Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Environmental perception, as a core module of the autonomous driving system, plays a crucial role in ensuring the rationality and safety of driving behavior. In recent years, Vehicle-To-Vehicle cooperative perception has significantly enhanced the accuracy of environmental perception for intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs). Among them, cross-modality cooperation enables the integration of complementary information between heterogeneous data structures, leading to further improvements in perception accuracy. However, in practical applications, it still faces problems such as limited communication bandwidth, high redundancy in data transmission, and lack of collaborative scheduling. To address these challenges, in this paper, we propose a method of cross-modality cooperative perception for multiple vehicles under V2X (Vehicle-To-Everything), which leverages the communication and computing resources deployed at roadside infrastructure to enable coordination and centralized processing of perception information. In this method, first, each ICV projects the raw perceptual data of both 3D point clouds and 2D images onto a unified bird’s-eye view plane during feature extraction to reduce spatial differences between modalities. Next, the vehicles apply a feature selection algorithm based on Region of Interest to filter intermediate features and upload data with high value for perception tasks to roadside infrastructure. Then, the roadside infrastructure centrally fuses the heterogeneous data from multiple vehicles, performs object detection, and returns the final results to each vehicle. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method significantly reduces communication bandwidth overhead while maintaining perception performance, and enhances the robustness of system perception.

title: Federated-Aware Intelligent Mode Selection with Low-Latency Scheduling in Computing Power Networks
authors: Yanmin Zhang, Xin Liu, Fengbiao Zan, Tianyi Xu, Tie Qiu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Computing Power Networks (CPN) integrate distributed resources, aiming to achieve full-domain coverage and dynamic allocation of computing resources. However, its task scheduling mechanisms still face significant challenges. Existing approaches either restrict themselves to single-node allocation while overlooking collaboration possibilities, or adopt static federated collaboration strategies that lack flexibility. This paper proposes the Federation-aware Proximal Policy Optimization (FPPO) algorithm, which achieves intelligent execution mode selection for the first time. FPPO leverages federation-aware state representation to capture system task conditions, adopts a hierarchical action space to decouple mode selection from resource allocation, and introduces a hybrid decision mechanism to balance learning capability with decision reliability. Experimental results demonstrate that FPPO significantly reduces average response time compared to a baseline algorithm, while maintaining a high success rate.

title: Physical Motion Classification in Assistive Industrial Robotics Using Support Vector Data Description
authors: Janna Nazarova, Rajeshkumar M, Gaurav Tamrakar, Zaid Alsalami, Bekmirzayev Mirjalol Xusanboyugli
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Today's industrial assistive robots improve worker safety, productivity, and cooperation. Robots can't understand, predict, or respond to human behavior without good body movement classification. Traditional classification methods struggle with real-time adaptability, uneven data, and noise. This paper addresses faulty classification approaches that cannot handle limited-sample or one-class learning in assistive robots. Standard machine learning methods fail in industrial settings due to the lack of large, balanced datasets. This restriction makes it challenging to design intelligent robotic systems that assist humans in adapting to changing situations. Physical Motion classification using Support Vector Data Description (PM-SVDD) is our novel solution to these issues. PM-SVDD models usual motion patterns and identifies outliers that may indicate undesirable or aberrant motions using SVDD's one-class classification feature. Kernel-based mapping and temporal feature extraction boost discriminative performance in many industrial situations. A custom assistive robotics dataset and conventional motion datasets were employed for experimental validation. With an average classification accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 4. 7 \%}$</tex>, PM-SVDD outperforms SVM and k-NN in scenarios with limited negative data. Due to its low computational delay, the approach is ideal for real-time robotics. Finally, the PM-SVDD technique for physical motion classification in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A I}$</tex> is strong and effective, enabling more intelligent and safer human-robot interaction.

title: A Decentralized Identity System Based on Unbound Implicit Certificates for Intelligent Eco Networking
authors: Mengze Chen, Shengli Zhang, Ziwei Yan, Guohui Yuan, Peng Xiangli, Jingjing Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Aiming at the high technical complexity, insufficient versatility and security vulnerabilities in the traditional data confirmation and transfer scheme, a lightweight data element confirmation and transfer scheme based on blockchain is proposed. Through the design of alliance chain architecture and smart contract, the whole process trust system of ' right confirmation-circulation-cooperation ' is constructed. A multi-level security mechanism is designed: in the right confirmation stage, the hash summary and the chain ownership record are used to realize the unique identification and non-tamperable traceability of data rights; in the circulation stage, the transaction legitimacy is verified by intelligent contract automation, and the secure transfer of data ownership and the synchronization of offline rights are realized by combining asymmetric encryption and event trigger mechanism. Through the system model, attack threat modeling and algorithm optimization, the scheme realizes the balance of security, efficiency and universality, and provides a technical path of ' right confirmation and traceability, circulation control and risk prevention ' for the construction of data factor market, which has practical reference value for promoting the market-oriented allocation reform of data factors.

title: AI-Driven QoS Optimization and Buffer Management in Software Defined Networks
authors: Ansu Raj, Astitva Sharma, Dhruv Sharma, Deepika Rani Sona
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: In modern Software Defined Networks (SDNs), Quality of Service (QoS) is challenged by dynamic traffic, node failures, and malicious attacks. This paper presents an AI-driven SDN framework that integrates CNN-LSTM models for congestion forecasting, Q-learning for dynamic buffer control and rerouting, LSTM Autoencoders for node failure prediction, and Isolation Forests for DDoS detection. Real-time telemetry enables closed loop optimization across the control plane. Experiments in a simulated SDN environment demonstrate a 43.7% reduction in packet loss and a 40% decrease in latency compared to baseline methods. The proposed system showcases scalable, proactive QoS optimization and resilience, positioning it as a viable solution for 5G and next-generation networks.

title: A Hybrid Approach for Predicting Maternal Health Risks: An Ablation Study Analysis
authors: Shweta, Madhushi Verma, Gitika Sharma
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Maternal health risks (MHR) pose a significant threat to the well-being of pregnant women, often leading to adverse outcomes during gestation and delivery. Addressing these risks is essential for improving global maternal health and reducing pregnancy-related complications. We suggest a hybrid model to improve early risk prediction and intervention. This research investigates maternal health risk prediction using a deep learning hybrid model, supplemented by an ablation study to assess the contribution of each feature to model performance. Maternal health is a significant area of concern because there is a high incidence of pregnancy, perinatal, childbirth, and postpartum complications, which have significant impacts on maternal and neonatal health. This ablation study rigorously analyses the contribution of each feature and hence detects key predictors like Body Mass Index (BMI) and pre-existing diabetes. In addition, our suggested hybrid model has a better classification performance, 99% accuracy, and high ROC-AUC scores compared to current benchmarks. This implies enhanced discriminatory ability at different levels of risk. Therefore, our contributions extend beyond predictive enhancement to providing clinical interpretability and robustness through deliberate architectural design and feature-level validation.

title: Similarity-Based Trajectory Prediction in Location-Based Social Network
authors: Eman M. Bahgat, Alshaimaa Abo-alian, Sherine Rady, Tarek F. Gharib
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: In recent years, significant research has focused on location-based social networks (LBSNs). However, real-world LBSN datasets present several challenges, including sparsity, limited size, privacy issues, and a lack of reliable ground truth data. This paper addresses the location prediction problem in LSBNs, emphasizing a notable research gap, which is the underestimation of users' tendency to withhold information about specific visited locations and activities. In order to bridge this gap, this research proposes an Associative Hidden Location Trajectory Prediction model based on similarity measures (AHLTP-SM) that analyses user trajectories to predict unchecked, privately visited locations. The model examines the relationship between trajectory similarity and distance measure using cosine similarity and Jaccard coefficient. The proposed model is evaluated using several machine-learning techniques, including deep learning, gradient-boosted trees, and K-Nearest neighbors. Experiments conducted on the Foursquare dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, classified with gradient-boosted trees and deep learning, achieving the highest accuracy at 99%, followed by K-Nearest neighbor with 89% accuracy. A Comparative analysis on the same real-world dataset demonstrates our model's superior accuracy compared to our previous work.

title: Hybrid Embedding-Based Approaches for Fake Profile Detection
authors: Carol Hanney Ishak, Aya Salama Abdelhady
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The significance of online social networks in modern lives cannot be denied, with billions of users relying on these platforms for communication and social interactions. However, like anything else that rises in popularity, so do the threats they face. Often, humans or bots create fake accounts to engage in malicious or illegal activities. To control this problem, we propose a hybrid embedding-based approach that uses a combination of static word embeddings and transformer-based embeddings. This method relies on embeddings, a fundamental and powerful technique in modern machine learning, specifically combining multiple embedding types which are not commonly explored in fake profile detection. Transformer-based embeddings provide powerful context awareness to handle ambiguous or misleading language, which is often common in fake profiles, while static embeddings capture word-to-word relationships efficiently. By combining the two types of embeddings, the model uses the strengths of each to accurately distinguish fake profiles from real ones. The model was tested using a publicly available dataset that contained 3,600 LinkedIn profiles. Three machine learning classifiers (SVM, Random Forest, and XGBoost) were tested across binary and multi-class classification tasks. The experimental results show that this approach achieves a high detection rate of 98.96% using a hybrid embedding combination.

title: Mind Ease: An Empathetic AI Companion for Women's Mental Wellness
authors: Monica Subashini M, Sumant Shyam, Jahnavi Gayatri D, Sarjila R, Prastika Krisma Jiwanti, Jacob Raglend I
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The rising prevalence of mental health challenges, particularly among women, underscores the urgent need for accessible, empathetic, and gendersensitive support tools. This paper presents the development of a mental health support chatbot designed with a focus on the unique needs, preferences, and communication styles of women. Through interdisciplinary collaboration involving mental health professionals, AI developers, and gender studies experts, the chatbot was crafted to provide a safe, nonjudgmental, and culturally sensitive conversational experience. The system integrates natural language processing, sentiment analysis, and contextual understanding to deliver personalized support, self-care guidance, and resource referrals. User feedback and iterative testing with a diverse group of women informed the bot's tone, response patterns, and functionality. Preliminary evaluations indicate increased user satisfaction, trust, and willingness to engage compared to generic mental health bots. This paper discusses the design methodology, ethical considerations, and future directions for deploying gender-informed AI in mental health care.

title: A Low-Complexity Time-Domain Equalization Method for Cross-Domain Iterative Reception in OTFS-SCMA
authors: Maosen Liu, Zhenghuan Wang, Yaning Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Cross-domain iterative detection exploits both time-domain and delay-Doppler (DD) domain characteristics to achieve high-performance signal detection in Orthogonal Time Frequency Space-Sparse Code Multiple Access (OTFS-SCMA) systems. To alleviate the high complexity of time domain equalization in existing algorithms, this paper introduces the concept of delay-Doppler decoupling and proposes a low-complexity equalization scheme that leverages the banded Hermitian property of the channel matrix. By decoupling the channel matrix along the delay and Doppler dimensions, the large-scale matrix is partitioned into several low-dimensional sub-matrices. It is theoretically proved that each sub-matrix is banded, positive-definite, and Hermitian. Based on this property, a Cholesky factorization is employed to further reduce computational complexity. Simulation results show that the proposed approach reduces both time (by 55%) and memory complexities (by 75%) without sacrificing detection performance, thereby offering a feasible receiver design for highly dynamic communication systems.

title: Two-tier Planning and Design of Capacity Allocation for Polar Integrated Energy Systems based on Improved Keplerian Algorithm
authors: Deran Kang, Runquan Meng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: In the Antarctic region, there is a huge demand for wind and solar power generation, but because of the instability of wind and solar resources, the effective utilization of these resources is an extremely important issue for polar countries, so energy storage technology is of great significance in the Antarctic region. Considering the impact of low temperature on wind turbines and other equipment, and fully reflecting the economy and reliability of power supply to the capacity of each device for two-tier planning and configuration, the upper optimization to minimize the total annualized investment cost as the goal, the introduction of the LTSM prediction mechanism and improve the Keplerian algorithm to determine the optimal solution for the capacity configuration, and the lower optimization to minimize the penalties of wind and light abandonment and cut-load penalties, the use of the CPLEX solver to calculate the system optimal The CPLEX solver is used to calculate the optimal operation scheme of the system. The simulation results show that the independent microgrid power supply system can maximize the efficiency and reliability indexes and reduce the energy waste.
