title: Gold Nanoparticle Coating Reduces Acoustic Pressure Threshold for Perfluorohexane Nanodroplet Vaporization: Potential Mechanisms and Therapy Implications
authors: Nishita Mistry, Ruchika Dhawan, K. S. Manu, Himanshu Shekhar, Karla P. Mercado-Shekhar
publish: IEEE Transactions on NanoBioscience
abstract: Ultrasound-induced vaporization of perfluorocarbon (PFC) nanodroplets can be used for triggered drug delivery. Nanodroplets of perfluorobutane (PFB) and perfluoropentane (PFP) can vaporize spontaneously at physiological temperature, which can cause off-target effects. Using high-boiling-point PFCs, such as perfluorohexane (PFH), can overcome this limitation. However, PFH requires higher peak negative pressures for vaporization, making its in vivo use challenging. We investigated the feasibility of reducing the vaporization pressure threshold by gold-coating lipid-encapsulated PFH nanodroplets (Au-PFH-ND). We synthesized PFH nanodroplets, and the gold-coating was confirmed by UV-visible spectra. The mass of gold per nanodroplet was 5.12×10-4 pg. The size distribution peaked at 200 nm and had a mean concentration of 2×1010 droplets/ml. Au-PFH-ND demonstrated excellent stability over 8 weeks. Ultrasound imaging in vitro was used to determine the pressure threshold for nanodroplet vaporization upon exposure to 2 MHz ultrasound. The vaporization threshold for Au-PFH-ND (3.29 ± 0.93 MPa) was significantly lower than uncoated PFH nanodroplets (PFH-ND, 6.19 ± 1.25 MPa). Au-PFH-ND had a similar pressure threshold to uncoated PFP nanodroplets (PFP-ND, 2.81 ± 1.08 MPa). These findings show that the Au-PFH-ND can be vaporized at a similar ultrasound pressure as PFP-ND. Increasing pulse duration from 2 to 60 cycles enhanced vaporization of Au-PFH-ND, demonstrating the dominant role of a thermal mechanism. Even when accounting for the total ultrasound on-time and effective peak negative pressure, longer bursts (i.e., more cycles per burst) were more effective in inducing vaporization, consistent with the role of localized heating around the gold coating rather than a purely probabilistic effect. Additionally, inertial and stable cavitation emissions were quantified. Au-PFH-ND exhibited a marginally lower inertial cavitation threshold and similar second harmonic emissions than PFH-ND, suggesting that cavitation could also have played a role in reducing the pressure threshold. These findings are a step towards employing gold-coated PFC nanodroplets for multimodal drug delivery.

title: Gproxy: Communication-Efficient Federated Graph Learning With Efficient Adaptive Proxying
authors: Junyang Wang, Lan Zhang, Mu Yuan, Yihang Cheng, Yunhao Yao, Junhao Wang, Zhonghao Hu, Qian Xu, Bo Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Federated graph learning (FGL) enables multiple participants with distributed but connected graph data to collaboratively train a model in a privacy-preserving way. However, the high communication cost hinders the adoption of FGL in many resource-limited or delay-sensitive applications. In this work, we focus on reducing the communication cost incurred by the transmission of neighborhood information in FGL. We propose to search for local proxies that can play a substitute role as the external neighbors and develop a novel federated graph learning framework named <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Gproxy</small>. <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Gproxy</small> utilizes representation similarity and class correlation to select local proxies for external neighbors. Additionally, we propose to dynamically adjust the proxy strategy according to the changing representation of nodes during the iterative training process. We also design a proxy cache to accelerate the search process by reusing proxy search outcomes for similar external neighbors. Furthermore, we provide a theoretical analysis and show that using a proxy node has a similar influence on training when it is sufficiently similar to the external one. Extensive evaluations show that <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Gproxy</small> significantly reduces communication cost while maintaining model performance compared to strong baselines.

title: Multimodal Contrastive Prototype Learning for Resilient Brain Tumor Segmentation With Missing Modalities
authors: Heran Xi, Yu Ye, Jinghua Zhu, Jinbao Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Multimodal fusion is an effective solution for holistic brain tumor diagnosis; however, it faces challenges under missing modalities. Traditional multi-encoder architectures can easily capture modality-specific features, while single-encoder architectures readily obtain modality-shared features. The reverse, however, is challenging. In this paper, we propose a two-stage dual-view prototype learning framework to extract the modality-specific feature and the class-specific feature simultaneously. In the first stage, we utilize the Transformer decoder to learn the modality-prototypes that are used to optimize the modality reconstruction task. A masked autoencoder is introduced to generate shared features of incomplete modalities. The learned modality-prototypes that contain modality-specific features are blended with the modality-share features for the reconstruction process. In the second stage, we learn the class-prototypes through the Transformer decoder to generate a segmentation mask through voxel-to-prototype comparison. A masked modality strategy is introduced to handle random modality absence during training. Furthermore, modality-view and class-view contrastive learning strategies are developed to enhance prototype learning. We conduct experiments on BraTS2020 and BraTS2018; the experimental results demonstrate the superior performance of our model under various missing modality scenarios. On BraTS2020, our model achieves DSC improvements of 5.9% for ET, 0.5% for TC, and 0.2% for WT compared to state-of-the-art methods. Notably, in the challenging T1C modality missing scenario, our model achieved clinically significant gains of 9.5% for ET and 1.8% for TC. The code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Xiheran/MCPL</uri>.

title: A Multi-level Probabilistic Deep Learning Network Augmented with Normalizing Flow for Ambiguous Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Satirtha Paul Shyam, Shaikh Anowarul Fattah, Mohammad Saquib
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Medical image segmentation often involves inherent uncertainty due to inter observer variability. In this case, a single deterministic mask obtained by conventional segmentation networks, such as U-Net, cannot capture the distribution of plausible expert annotations, risking missed clinically relevant variants. In order to enable uncertainty quantification and reflect inter expert variability, probabilistic models like Probabilistic U-Net are used, which perform aleatoric or ambiguous segmentation where a latent space is sampled to generate multiple segmentation masks. However, the common use of a conditioned unimodal posterior in these models fails to represent true multimodality, leading to mode bias and limited diversity. To address these limitations, a multi-level Probabilistic U-Net augmented with normalizing flows is proposed to enhance the expressiveness of the latent distribution. The multi-level design induces multiple latent distributions in separate levels of U-Net, enabling more diverse sampling, while the flow module transforms the posterior to add data required modes and expand representational capacity, thereby enriching the expressiveness of the distributions. The proposed flow incorporated multi-level network enables a more flexible and powerful distribution, thereby enhancing the model’s ability to generate high fidelity segmentation masks. Extensive experiments on some publicly available datasets with multiple expert annotations per image demonstrate that the proposed model reduces generalized energy distance (GED), preserves clinically meaningful diversity and sharpens boundary fidelity, with latent grid analyses indicating fuller mode coverage and fewer artifacts. Collectively, these results indicate that the proposed framework advances accuracy, robustness, and clinical reliability for aleatoric, uncertainty aware medical image segmentation.

title: Integral-type terminal sliding mode MPPT controller for a standalone PV system with a DC-DC boost converter under real time varying weather conditions
authors: Jawhar Aiboudi, Habiba Rizki, Redouane Chaibi, Nawfal Jebbor, El-Mahjoub Boufounas, Ahmed El Hajjaji
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Robust nonlinear controllers, in particular sliding mode control (SMC), have been a convenient solution for maximum power point tracking (MPPT) of photovoltaic (PV) systems, as they deal with the nonlinearity of the system and can catch the MPP in various weather conditions; however, chattering and infinite time of convergence have been related to conventional sliding mode control. In this article, we propose an integral-type terminal sliding mode MPPT (ITTSMC) controller for a PV system powering a DC load, based on the tracking error of the inductor’s current of the DC-DC boost converter, which is connected to the PV array’s output, to follow the MPP. The paper provides a theoretical study of the controller in question, demonstrating its stability and its finite-time convergence. The controller is tested under four environmental conditions, firstly, standard test conditions with a constant load, then with a variable load, secondly, a step changes in temperature and irradiance, thirdly, under real weather conditions relying on the data of temperature and irradiance of a weather station in the Faculty of Sciences and Technologies of Errachidia in the eastern south of Morocco, finally, the controller will be evaluated under realistic partial shading conditions. To assess its performance, the ITTSMC is compared to the basic terminal SMC and the classical SMC. The ITTSMC achieves an 85% reduction in reaching time, a reduction of up to 88% in chattering magnitude, and a 66% decrease in voltage RMSE compared to SMC. Moreover, it exhibits strong robustness under real environmental conditions and partial shading while ensuring high-precision MPP tracking. Overall, the ITTSMC reaches a power extraction efficiency of 99.92%, outperforming TSMC (99.81%) and classical SMC (99.64%). These quantitative improvements clearly demonstrate the superior tracking accuracy, faster transient response, and reduced chattering of the proposed control strategy.

title: Visually Meaningful Encryption via Image-to-Image Reversible Transformation
authors: Jianfeng Yang, Zhili Zhou, Yuhuan Liu, Daizhi Liao, Yifeng Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Image encryption techniques generally encrypt a secret image into a meaningless noise-like format, which could easily attract attention from attackers who then may try to crack it. On the other hand, image steganography typically embeds secret image data within a cover image, but it inevitably incurs a lot of distortion to the cover image. This makes the secret image data vulnerable to attacks by steganalysis tools. In light of the above, in this paper, we propose a Visually Meaningful Image Encryption (VMIE) scheme via image-to-image reversible transformation based on the Glow model. In this scheme, a secret image is encoded and compressed as a latent vector by the deep compression autoencoder. Then, the latent vector is scrambled and inputted into the Glow model to generate a visually meaningful encrypted image. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed VMIE scheme not only provides desirable security against attacks, but also enables the reconstruction of the original images with negligible quality loss. Codes are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/AIMS-Group-ZhiliZhou/VMEI</uri>.

title: Variable-Carrier-Based PWM Control of Hybrid Energy Storage System for More Electric Aircraft
authors: Ming Huang, Renhao Chang, Yang Qi, Weilin Li, Zhen Kang, Jianlong Zou, Xikui Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The hybrid energy storage systems (HESSs), often configured with battery and supercapacitor (SC) combinations, can effectively regulate power imbalances between generation and loads within more electric aircraft (MEA) dc microgrids. However, traditional control exhibits limitation in precisely tracking high-frequency components within SC current loop. To address this deficiency, this article proposes a novel current control strategy enhancing SC current tracking capability in HESS. Departing from conventional approaches, the proposed strategy eliminates the proportional-integral (PI) controller from the SC current loop, instead integrating SC current regulation with pulse-width modulation (PWM) to form a modified PWM unit. Consequently, the input signal of this modified PWM unit derives from given function of the SC current, while the amplitude of the PWM carrier signal is reformulated to vary instantaneously with the SC current. The variable-carrier-based PWM method accelerates the realization of SC current synthesis. Furthermore, a small-signal model is also explored to deeply investigate the stability of the HESS. Subsequent simulations are conducted to verify the performance across multiple scenarios. Experimental validation conducted on a 25 kW HESS power stage demonstrates the theoretical feasibility of the proposed control methodology.

authors: Yuntao Wu

abstract: Neutron detection materials play a vital role in the field of nuclear security, radioactive waste management, non-destructive testing, and fundamental physics research. Due to the shortage of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>He gas, the alternative neutron detection materials with high light yield, good energy resolution, and efficient n/γ discrimination capabilities are in high demand. In this work, high quality <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>Li-containing single crystals of Cs<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>Cu<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sub>:Tl,Li, Cs<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>LiYCl<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sub>:Ce, and NaI:Tl,Li as neutron and gamma detection materials were grown by the Bridgman method. title: Blockchain-Based Decentralized Production Progress Early Warning in Social Manufacturing Paradigm
authors: Kangqian Zheng, Shaowei Zhi, Kai Ding, Qingdi Liu, Fuqiang Zhang, Jizhuang Hui, Felix T. S. Chan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Social manufacturing (SM) is a task-oriented production paradigm that enables coordinated scheduling across distributed manufacturing resources. However, its operational efficiency is often limited by reliance on centralized management systems. In this context, blockchain technology shows strong potential for decentralized management in SM. However; the corresponding models for early warnings of production progress, especially for task fulfillment and delay risks, remain largely unexplored. To address the limitations, this article first proposes a blockchain-based decentralized production progress early warning system in SM. Furthermore, a corresponding early warning workflow is developed to define the overall interaction logic among participants. Then, a hybrid state machine is implemented within the smart contract to construct a task fulfillment status early warning model. Afterward, a Bayesian network-based model is designed to assess the evolving delay risks of interdependent tasks. Finally, a case study on air-conditioner production is conducted to validate the proposed models. Results show that the prototype system maintains scalable performance, achieving up to 17.56 transactions/s under write-intensive workloads and 52.45 transactions/s under read-intensive workloads, demonstrating more stable scalability than traditional centralized and directed acyclic graph (DAG)-based systems.

title: The Role of Cyber-Physical Security Mechanisms to Secure the Operation of Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Reynaldo Nuqui, Martin Naedele
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Cyber-physical systems are systems that integrate digital control systems with plants in the real world, such as industrial installations, smart homes/smart cities, transportation systems, or utility grids for power, water, or gas. Such cyber-physical systems have existed for decades, but with the rise of internet-connected control systems and Internet-of Things (IoT) systems in the past decade, they have become prominent and with that the challenge of securing these systems against cyberattacks, that is, remote and computer-based attempts to operate these installations in unauthorized ways, has become more urgent. In recent years a lot of research has been initiated on specific cyber-physical security mechanisms to secure cyber-physical systems. In this paper we compare such cyber-physical security mechanisms with conventional cyber security mechanisms and explain what cyber-physical security mechanisms can and cannot achieve. We propose a template for summarizing the applicability of cyber-physical security schemes. We conclude that cyber-physical security schemes come at a cost of reducing optimality of normal operation and that they can and should only serve as n-th level of defense mechanisms behind a comprehensive conventional security architecture.

title: CMOS-Compatible Low-Temperature Au-Free Ohmic Contact Process for GaN
authors: Jiajie Pan, Hanxiang Jia, Junlei He, Jie Ruan, Zongchao Liu, Panpan Wang, Bo Zhao, Sichao Li, Baohua Tan, Shuangzan Lu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Silicon-based GaN HEMT devices offer advantages such as high breakdown voltage and low on-resistance, demonstrating broad application prospects in fields like newenergy vehicles and high-power electronics. The rapid advancement of large-scale Si-based GaN epitaxial growth technology has spurred industry exploration into fabricating GaN devices on established CMOS process lines. However, traditional high-temperature Au-based ohmic contact schemes render HEMT devices incompatible with Si-CMOS processes. Furthermore, Au acts as a deep-level impurity that will contaminate process lines. This work addresses the finelinewidth requirements for p -GaN gate enhancement-mode HEMT devices while ensuring compatibility with existing SiCMOS production lines. We developed a CMOS-compatible, low-temperature $\left(500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$, Au-free ohmic contact process based on Ti/Al/TiN metallization scheme. Through systematic optimization of key process parameters-including lowdamage etching, pre-cleaning, alloy deposition, and post-annealing-which critically influence ohmic contact characteristics, the optimized contact resistivity ($R_{\mathrm{c}}$) was reduced to $0.5 \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~mm}$. This achievement lays the foundation for realizing 650 V GaN HEMT devices with low onresistance ($R_{\mathrm{DS}(\mathrm{on})}=220 \mathrm{~m} \Omega$).

title: HLS to FPGAs: Extending Software Regions Via Transformations and Offloading Functions to the CPU
authors: Tiago Santos, João Bispo, João M. P. Cardoso, James C. Hoe
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: On a CPU-FPGA system, C/C++ applications are typically accelerated by offloading specific code regions onto the FPGA using High-level Synthesis (HLS). Although modern FPGAs can implement increasingly large and complex designs, the size and variety of potential offloading code regions remain constrained by the limitations of HLS tools (e.g., no support for dynamic memory allocation and system calls). This paper proposes automated C/C++ source-to-source transformations that tackle these limitations in two steps. Firstly, transformations reduce the entropy of an input C/C++ application by converting it into a subset of C, e.g., by flattening arrays and structs. Secondly, additional transformations make a selected code region synthesizable, e.g., by moving dynamic memory allocations out of the region, converting them to static memory, and offloading non-synthesizable C standard library calls, such as printf(), to the CPU. We evaluate the impact of these transformations showing results obtained through Vitis HLS for four real-world examples: the disparity and texture-synthesis benchmarks from CortexSuite, which contain dynamic memory allocations and indirect pointers in their hotspots; llama2, a Large Language Model that calls printf() every time it predicts a new word; and the spam-filter benchmark from Rosetta, as a debugging showcase.

title: Workers Target Detection in Workshop Based on Improved YOLOv5
authors: Qihao Chen, Gaocai Fu, Yifei Fan, Minhui Ni
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: To improve the accuracy of detecting safety helmets in complex workshop environments, where small targets and occlusions are common, this paper proposes an enhanced YOLOv5 algorithm. The model is optimized using a specialized workshop dataset by introducing the NWD (Normalized Wasserstein Distance) loss function for better small target detection and the Mish activation function for improved feature learning. Experiments show the method achieves a high mAP of 87.73% and real-time performance, significantly outperforming the original YOLOv5 and other models.

title: Multi-physical simulation study on optimizing the temperature gradient in SiC single crystal PVT growth by regulating emissivity via roughness gradient on the outer wall of graphite crucible
authors: Ming Zhou, Xunxi Zhang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This study proposes an innovative and cost-effective approach to optimize the thermal field in SiC single crystal physical vapor transport (PVT) growth by regulating emissivity through a strategically designed roughness gradient on the outer wall of the graphite crucible. Rooted in the Stefan-Boltzmann law, the gradient, ranging from a roughness (Ra) of $1 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ at the bottom to $10 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ at the top, facilitates an increase in emissivity from 0.7 to 0.9, thereby enhancing the axial temperature gradient critical for efficient sublimation and deposition processes. The simulation leverages SL720 and SL920 graphite materials sourced from SIAMC, employing a 2D axisymmetric finite element model on the COMSOL Multiphysics platform. This model integrates heat conduction and radiation modules, with convergence ensured through Newton-Raphson iteration and the preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) solver, maintaining a tolerance of $10^{-7}$ to ensure computational accuracy. The simulation results reveal that the roughness gradient elevates the axial temperature gradient to a range of $14-16 \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{cm}$, effectively reduces radial temperature variation to less than 25 K, and achieves a significant growth rate gain of up to $18.3 \%$ (with an average of 10.5-10.7%). Additionally, the Von Mises stress is meticulously controlled within $7-8.5 \mathrm{MPa}$, remaining well below the flexural strength of the materials $(45-46 \mathrm{MPa})$, ensuring structural integrity during the growth process. This method offers a low-cost, scalable thermal field optimization strategy specifically tailored for 8 -inch SiC crystals, addressing key industrial challenges such as thermal uniformity and defect reduction. The potential for further refinement through multi-segment gradient experiments is highlighted, promising to advance the industrialization of large-diameter SiC crystals by enhancing growth efficiency and crystal quality in high-throughput production environments.

title: Instruction-Directed MAC for Efficient Classical Communication in Scalable Multi-Chip Quantum Systems
authors: Maurizio Palesi, Enrico Russo, Hamaad Rafique, Giuseppe Ascia, Davide Patti, Abhijit Das, Sergi Abadal
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Scalable quantum computing requires modular multi-chip architectures integrating multiple quantum cores interconnected through quantum-coherent and classical links. The classical communication subsystem is critical for coordinating distributed control operations and supporting quantum protocols such as teleportation. In this work, we consider a realization based on a wireless network-on-chip for implementing classical communication within cryogenic environments. Traditional token-based medium access control (MAC) protocols, however, incur latency penalties due to inefficient token circulation among inactive nodes. We propose the instruction-directed token MAC (ID-MAC), a protocol that leverages the deterministic nature of quantum circuit execution to predefine transmission schedules at compile time. By embedding instruction-level information into the MAC layer, ID-MAC restricts token circulation to active transmitters, thereby improving channel utilization and reducing communication latency. Simulations show that ID-MAC reduces classical communication time by up to 70% and total execution time by up to 30-70%, while also extending effective system coherence. These results highlight ID-MAC as a scalable and efficient MAC solution for future multichip quantum architectures.

title: Machine Learning Models for Predicting Deformation in RC Slabs Shielded by Auxetic Sandwich Panels Under Impact
authors: Aya Elhozayen, Zahy Y. Elgendy, Bahy Y. Elgendy
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into structural engineering is accelerating, with machine learning (ML) techniques showing strong potential for predictive modelling tasks. This study introduces a data-driven framework that systematically predicts the deformation response of a protective system made up of an auxetic sandwich panel resting on a reinforced concrete (RC) slab impacted vertically. Traditional finite element (FE) analysis of such impact scenarios is computationally intensive and may involve manual processes prone to human error. To overcome these limitations, this study combines FE simulations with machine learning (ML) to be able to efficiently predict the structural deformation under varying impact conditions. A series of simulations were conducted in ANSYS, systematically varying the impactor parameters in order to generate a training dataset. The main objective is to develop a predictive model for the deformation of both the auxetic core and the underlying RC slab. Various machine learning regression models—involving ensemble tree-based models (Extra Trees, Random Forest), kernel-based models (Kernel Ridge), and linear models (Linear Regression, Ridge, Lasso)—were trained and evaluated. The performance of the model was measured using the coefficient of determination (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex>), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). The Extra Trees model yielded the greatest accuracy predicting core deformation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2} = 0.98$</tex>), while the Kernel Ridge model was the best for predicting slab deformation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2} = 0.94$</tex>). Overall, these results confirm the promising aptitude of machine learning for the rapid prediction of structural response for applications in impact protection design, while providing an actionable framework for realizing optimal materials and geometry for layered protective systems.

title: A Data-Driven Framework for Female School Dropout Analysis and Targeted Recommendations
authors: Avantika Singh, Prerna Sharma, Parmeet Kaur
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Female dropout rates in Indian schools continue to be a significant barrier to achieving educational equity and national development. This study presents a two-phase data-driven solution to analyze and address this issue. In the first phase, historical data (years 2001-2010) sourced from data.gov.in was used to visualize patterns in dropout rates across Indian states demographics and school levels. Key insights were derived using Power Bi dashboards and clustering states on the basis of higher decline in dropout rates ratio. In the second phase, states were clustered based on dropout rate decline percentages, forming five prominent clusters with similar socio-educational trends. This clustering enabled the development of a recommendation system which can provide cluster-specific solutions. The suggested solutions include development of mentorship programs, providing financial support and targeted resource allocation. The data-driven approach illustrated the existing disparities between different states and regions and highlighted the need for localized interventions.

title: YOLOv8 Driven Pothole Detection with Manual Geolocation Tagging for Intelligent Road Networks
authors: K L Shreyan Reddy, Amogh S Guthur, Syed Thouheed Ahmed, Bhavana N, Punarva Bettadamane Channabasappa
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: On Indian highways, potholes are a leading cause of vehicle damage and fatal collisions because of excessive speeding, careless driving, and a failure to promptly repair roads. Traditional methods of detection, like manual inspection and sensor-based systems, are costly, unreliable, and not scalable. We propose a real-time pothole detection system based on the YOLOv8 object identification framework and the Ultralytics package. Using 645 annotated images (70 percent training, 20 percent validation, and 10 percent testing), our model was improved over 70 epochs with 97.8 % detection accuracy, 1.00 precision, 0.91 recall, and mAP@0.5 of 0.98. The model uses an RTX 2060 Super GPU to process 45 frames per second video streams, enabling real-time pothole detection. The GPS coordinates of potholes are extracted to enable prompt infrastructure repair. Road safety is increased, smart city initiatives are supported, and road condition monitoring is made easier by this inexpensive, automated technology.

title: Autonomous Indoor Customization: The Future of Human Comfort and Productivity
authors: Adeyinka Akintola, Jun Ma, Naser Hossein Motlagh, Georgios Bouloukakis, Huber Flores
publish: Computer
abstract: In this article, we present a research vision for autonomous customization of indoor spaces using autonomous technologies. By examining the current maturity of these technologies and existing enablers, we outline our vision and highlight how they can drive innovative scenarios.

title: PHMN-Gap: An Enhanced Algorithm for Mining Periodic High-Utility Itemsets with Temporal Gap Constraints
authors: Pushp S. Mathur, Satish Chand
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: High-Utility Itemset Mining (HUIM) identifies item combinations in transactional datasets that yield high utility, such as profit or importance. Existing approaches to periodic high-utility mining (PHM) fail to consider two practical limitations: the inability to handle items with negative utilities, and the lack of mechanisms to suppress overly frequent, low-value patterns. This paper introduces PHMN-Gap, an enhanced framework that incorporates negative utility handling and a user-defined minimum temporal gap constraint between itemset occurrences. The algorithm extends utility-list based mining by modifying the candidate generation and join process to enforce temporal separation. This ensures that only itemsets recurring after a meaningful interval are considered, thereby filtering trivial or noisy repetitions. Extensive experiments conducted on standard utility mining datasets demonstrate that PHMN-Gap achieves better performance in terms of runtime and memory usage, while generating a more concise and interpretable set of patterns. As the minimum gap constraint increases, the number of discovered patterns decreases significantly, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed pruning strategy. PHMN-Gap achieves this with linear-time joins in candidate generation and lower memory overheads, making it scalable and suitable for large-scale applications. The resulting itemsets are more relevant for real-world applications where both profitability and temporal behavior must be jointly analyzed.

title: AP Energy-based Handoff in High Speed 802.11ac WLAN
authors: Biplab K. Mandal, Babul P. Tewari, Nirupama Mandal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Limited coverage regions and multiple service overlaps raise the issue of increased handoffs and larger delays in Wi-Fi networks. Additionally, energy-concerned communication is highly desirable in future wireless networks. The current manuscript presents an energy-conscious handoff strategy that addresses the handoff delay simultaneously. The proposed algorithm limits the number of channels to be probed by considering a minimal set of target APs under scanning. This selection is based on the consumed energy of the target AP. This results in a reduction in handoff delay, keeping the dissipated energy as minimal as possible. Appropriate simulations have been conducted based on performance parameters such as throughput, consumed energy, and delay during handoff. The comparative study with the existing work also demonstrates the judicious target network selection.

title: Scientific Data Management Beyond Traditional Computing Boundaries
authors: Patrick Widener, Laura Biven, Ian Foster, Beth Plale, Sarp Oral, Rafael Ferreira da Silva
publish: Computer
abstract: Scientific data management is undergoing a fundamental transformation driven by the convergence of artificial intelligence (AI)/machine learning workflows, distributed computing and storage environments, and exponential data growth. We analyze how these developments address current limitations while enabling new capabilities for cross-facility collaboration and AI-driven research.

title: Real-Time GUI-Based Facial Emotion Recognition Using the IEMOCAP Dataset
authors: Syed Shakil Mahmud, Khandaker Jannatul Ritu, Ohidujjaman, Mahmudul Hasan
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Emotion detection by observing faces is an important but challenging aspect of human-computer interaction due to its dynamic, context-specific, a nd s ubtle <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> ature. Proposed research establishes a graphical user interface (GUI) that allows real-time prediction of emotions from live webcam videos and static images, thereby demonstrating its practical use in real-world scenarios. The system uses the Interactive Emotional Dyadic Motion Capture (IEMOCAP) corpus, specifically designed to tackle difficulties i nd yadic i nteractions, w here two individuals can have different emotional states simultaneously. The pipeline involves accurate frame selection based on annotated timestamps, followed by systematic pre-processing through face alignment and normalization. The proposed convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture is trained on a speaker-independent data split to avoid temporal data leakage. The proposed CNN architecture achieved an accuracy of 83.72 % and demonstrated a balanced performance across six emotions: anger, happiness, sadness, frustration, neutral, and excitement. In addition, we also implemented and evaluated the IEMOCAP dataset using YOLOv11 and YOLOv12 for static image-based facial emotion recognition. The real-time GUI system had an average of 25 ms per frame on the commodity hardware, demonstrating practical deployability. Applications include mental health checks in telemedicine, emotion-aware adaptive tutoring systems, and emotion-based user feedback analyses for customer care.

title: Analysis of Regression and Bayesian Regularisation Models for Enhancing Load Forecasting Towards Affordable and Clean Energy
authors: K.Shanmukha Sundar, G. Radhaswamy, P.Kasi Viswanathan, Rashmi C Pattan, Rajath G R, Renukaprasad G
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Accurate forecasting is essential in areas such as energy systems, demand management, and load prediction; even slight differences between the real-time and predicted values can influence planning and decision-making. Traditional regression models are often used for forecasting because of their simplicity, but they face challenges when the data becomes complex or non-linear. These limitations can lead to less reliable predictions, especially when the models are prone to overfitting. In this study, we compare the performance of a standard regression model with a Bayesian Regularisation (BR) model for forecasting. Using the real and forecasted datasets, the analysis was carried out, and the accuracy of both methods was evaluated with performance measures such as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and the coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>). The results show that although both approaches produce forecasts close to the actual data, the Bayesian Regularisation model performs more consistently and with greater accuracy. Its capability to balance between complexity and generalisation makes it a reliable and good choice for forecasting under uncertainty. The results emphasise the strength of BR and its potential for extensive application in forecasting jobs across energy and data-driven domains.

title: Investigation on the Influence of Interface Traps Type, Energy Level and Location on I-V and C-V Characteristics in SiC MOSFET
authors: Zhichao Cheng, Ling Sang, Feng He, Yawei He, Zheyang Li, Rui Jin
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: High interface-trap density at $\mathrm{SiC} / \mathrm{SiO}_{2}$ persists as a key bottleneck for SiC MOSFET electrical performance. In this work, we conduct TCAD simulations to determine the role of interface traps in governing the I-V and C-V characteristics of SiC MOSFET. A SiC MOSFET TCAD model is first constructed, followed by a systematic analysis of how variations in interface traps type, energy level, and location affect the device’s I-V and C-V characteristics. The results indicate that acceptor traps near the valence band (Ev) and donor traps near the conduction band ($\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{C}}$) located at the $\mathrm{SiC} / \mathrm{SiO}_{2}$ interface within the channel region cause significant shifts in the $\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{D}}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{G}}$ curve, while interface traps in the JFET region have negligible impact. For the C-V characteristic, however, both acceptor traps close to $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{V}}$ and donor traps close to $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{C}}$ - whether located in the channel or JFET region induce notable shifts in the $\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{G}}-\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{G}}$ curve, whereas other traps show minimal influence. These analyses provide a deeper insight into how interface traps affect the I-V and C-V characteristics of SiC MOSFET.

title: A Study on Differences in Visual Function Between Black and East Asian Populations
authors: Shupeng Li, Shanshan Zeng, Fang Hu, Jun Rong, Linhao Lu, Ya Guo, Jianqi Cai
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Human visual function serves as a critical physiological foundation for visual perception and daily activities, with its variations directly impacting visual quality and ocular safety. Current research in visual function primarily concentrates on characteristic analyses within single ethnic groups, whereas systematic investigations into differences across diverse ethnicities remain scarce. This study targeted individuals of Black and East Asian descent, employing standardized visual function assessments to conduct a comparative analysis of both static ocular parameters, which reflect the eye‘s inherent structural features, and dynamic visual function metrics, which characterize its responsive properties. The results revealed statistically significant differences between East Asian and Black ethnicities in static parameters-including axial length (AL), corneal curvature (KM), and anterior chamber depth (ACD)-as well as in dynamic indicators such as ciliary muscle accommodative ability (ACC), modulation transfer function (MTF), and higher-order aberrations (HOAs). This study systematically elucidates inherent disparities in core visual function indicators between these two ethnic groups, thereby providing a scientific basis and theoretical support for the precise diagnosis and treatment of ophthalmic diseases, the design of personalized optical products, and the ethnic-specific optimization of light health models.

title: Low Cost AIN/GaN HEMTs on Sapphire for Low Voltage Terminal Application
authors: Kun Yin, Qing Zhu, Jiejie Zhu, Xiaohua Ma
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Recent years have witnessed the expansion of GaN applications from high-voltage to low-voltage terminal fields, where GaN-on-sapphire devices demonstrate distinctive advantages in both comprehensive performance and costeffectiveness for terminal low-voltage applications. This work fabricated HEMTs on sapphire-based in-situ SiN/AlN/GaN heterostructures, preserving partial in-situ silicon nitride during ohmic etching, which reduced the ohmic contact resistance from $0.65 \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~mm}$ to $0.29 \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~mm}$ compared to structures without in-situ silicon nitride. The fabricated Dmode devices achieved a maximum output current of 1330 $\mathrm{mA} / \mathrm{mm}$ and peak transconductance of $424 \mathrm{mS} / \mathrm{mm}$. An Emode device was successfully realized through plasma oxidation treatment converting the gate-recess AlN into AlON, exhibiting a threshold voltage of 0.57 V and transconductance of $623 \mathrm{mS} / \mathrm{mm}$. The D-mode devices demonstrated fT/fmax $=43 / 71 \mathrm{GHz}$, while the E-mode devices showed fT/fmax $=30 / 63 \mathrm{GHz}$. Under 7.2 GHz operation with 12 V bias, the D -mode devices exhibited a gain of 13.58 dB and output power density of $2.5 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{mm}$, compared to 14.19 dB gain and $0.99 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{mm}$ output power density for E-mode devices. Although the enhancement-mode devices showed noticeable performance degradation, this cannot be attributed to the sapphire substrate, thereby demonstrating the potential of low-cost sapphire-based AIN/GaN technology for terminal low-voltage applications.

title: ESP32-Based IoT Aquatic Cleaning Robot with YOLO Edge AI for Plastic Waste Removal
authors: RajaRaja R, Madhu Bharathi D M, Akshitaa G, Janani S, Mahendran Y, Ashok Kumar P
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Plastic pollution in aquatic ecosystems has emerged as a critical environmental challenge while the conventional methods offer a labor intensive and inefficient solution. To address this issue, we propose an ESP32-based autonomous water-cleaning robot that integrates Internet of Things (IoT) connectivity, edge-deployed YOLO object detection, and a conveyor-based mechanical collection mechanism. This robot navigates over water surfaces, capture floating debris, and classify objects in real time. The system employs DroidCam as a live video source, processed using a Python-based pipeline with TensorFlow and a YOLO-trained deep learning model to classify floating objects as plastic or non-plastic. Upon classification, decision signals are transmitted to an ESP32 microcontroller, which governs the conveyor belt and servo mechanisms to either collect or release objects. The ESP32 also handles wireless connectivity through the Blynk IoT platform, enabling remote monitoring, manual override, and operational data logging. Experimental evaluation demonstrates reliable detection accuracy and efficient debris handling under constrained hardware resources. The proposed design represents a scalable cyberphysical IoT system that leverages edge-assisted AI, embedded actuation, and mobile IoT integration to address sustainable plastic waste management in aquatic environments.

title: Routing in Multi-Chip Platforms with Hybrid Interconnects
authors: Joy Halder, Nayeem Ahmed, Viktor Razilov, Emil Matus, Gerhard Fettweis
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: To scale the performance of multi-processor systems, hierarchical architectures with hybrid interconnects are commonly employed. However, accurately predicting performance and energy consumption in such systems is challenging due to the vast design space resulting from numerous task mapping and routing strategies. This letter presents an overview of a three-dimensional architecture for a multi-chip platform with hybrid connections. It highlights various types of inter-core communication within the architecture and the associated routing techniques. To assess its performance in terms of energy consumption and the utilization of different interconnects, we employ a nearestneighbor (NN)-based online task mapping policy for allocating various applications. Overall, this platform could also be applied to other multiprocessor system-on-chip (MPSoC) architectures that utilize hybrid connections.

title: Developing Smart City Applications Employing the Vertex Fixed Vertex-to-Edge Geodetic Number of Graphs
authors: T. Sheeba Helen, J. John, A. Arul Asha
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: To develop “smart cities,” a lot of contemporary cities work to incorporate information technology into every facet of urban life. Smart cities use a variety of technology and application sectors to enable complex interactions between citizens, external parties, and city organizations. The study explains why different smart city applications have little effect on their own and offers suggestions for increasing their efficacy. A network with three or more connected vertices is said to have an XVTE (x-vertex-to-edge) geodetic number, according to this study. Look at a few general characteristics that this idea satisfies. For several kinds of graphs, the geodetic numbers from x-vertex to edge are found. The system's goal is to have fewer cars on the road in order to lessen traffic congestion, pollution, and energy use. The proposed vertex fixing vertex-to-edge the geodetic number of Graph solutions will result in hundreds of thousands fewer cars on the road, significantly lowering energy consumption, eliminating traffic congestion, and promoting a more active lifestyle for residents of smart cities.

title: Design, Performance Evaluation, and Hydrogen Recovery Potential of a Mobile Solar E-Waste Incinerator Using Scheffler Dish Concentrator
authors: Balamurali Duraivel, Natarajan Muthuswamy, Shaik Saboor, Satheesh Anbalagan, Thirumal Pattabi
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The improper disposal of electronic waste (e-waste) presents significant environmental and public health challenges. To address this issue, we developed a mobile solar incinerator integrated with a Scheffler Dish Concentrator (SDC) for decentralized and sustainable e-waste management, particularly suited for residential and small-scale industrial use. The system demonstrated effective combustion of e-waste, accompanied by simultaneous steam generation within the incinerator chamber. Performance evaluation yielded thermal and exergy efficiencies of 27.90 % and 2.80 %, respectively. Flue gas generated during incineration was analyzed using accessible instrumentation, revealing key constituents including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}, \text{CO}, \text{CH}_{4}$</tex>, and trace levels of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex>, consistent with standard pyrolysis profiles. Based on this composition, hydrogen production through a catalytic Water-Gas Shift Reaction (WGSR) was identified as a viable recovery pathway. The proposed setup, using in-system steam and moderate flue gas temperatures, can produce up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 9 g}$</tex> of hydrogen per day when scaled to a 50 kg e-waste capacity. Additionally, the recovered thermal energy from the flue gas can be repurposed for drying, absorption cooling, or other thermal applications. This integrated solution advances beyond waste disposal, offering a multifunctional platform for sustainable energy recovery and decentralized hydrogen generation

title:
Recent Advances in Ohmic Contact with β-Ga
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    : A Review
authors: Man Luo, Xin Qi, Yi Shen, Yang-Chao Liu, Qing-Chun Zhang, Hong-Ping Ma
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: $\beta$-Gallium Oxide (Cr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) is considered a potential material for next-generation high-power electronics and optoelectronic devices due to its ultra-wide bandgap ($\sim 4.8 \mathrm{eV}$) and high breakdown voltage ($8 \mathrm{MV} / \mathrm{cm}$). It exhibits great promise for high-voltage, high-power, and low-loss power electronics devices. However, the performance of Cr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> based devices remains far from expectations, with a considerable gap existing before large-scale industrialization can be achieved. One of the key challenges hindering the development of $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ materials and devices is the formation of metal $/ \beta$ - Cr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> contacts. Compared to other semiconductors, the extremely wide bandgap of $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ makes it more challenging to achieve ohmic contacts. Therefore, an in-depth investigation into the physical mechanism underlying the metal $/ \beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ contact interface is crucial for enhancing device performance and facilitating its practical application. One of the key criteria for the successful preparation of $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ power devices is the formation of ohmic contacts with low specific contact resistivity and high reliability. In this work, recent advances in ohmic contact with $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ have been reviewed. Initially, we provided a concise overview of prior research advancements concerning the ohmic contact formation of $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$. This includes the utilization of conventional $\mathrm{Ti} / \mathrm{Au}$ electrodes as well as the application of processes such as rapid thermal annealing (RTA) and reactive ion etching (RIE) to achieve ohmic contacts in $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$. Subsequently, we present a detailed discussion of recent developments in ohmic contact with $\beta$ Cr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, focusing on $\beta$ - Cr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> ohmic contact preparation from four perspectives: annealing technique, surface treatment method, multilayer electrode, and ion implantation strategy. This paper not only offers novel insights into the selection of ohmic contact electrode materials and fabrication processes for $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, but also elucidates the reaction mechanisms at the metal $/ \beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ interface and the underlying physical principles involved in the formation of ohmic contacts. Furthermore, it contributes to a deeper understanding of the developmental trends in $\beta-\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ ohmic contact strategies.

title: SiC Film Growth on Sapphire via Pyrolysis of Polycarbosilane
authors: Hanyu Zhao, Yuyang Wang, Yicheng Pei, Moyu Wei, Yunkai Li, Jingyi Jiao, Han Kong, Chenlin Ai, Qing Katherine Mu, Guoguo Yan, Yingxi Niu, Xingfang Liu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) thin films were grown on sapphire (Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>) substrates via the pyrolytic conversion of polycarbosilane (PCS) precursor. The experiments were carried out under argon protection, systematically investigating the effect of growth temperature $\left(800^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right.$, $900^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$) on SiC film growth, with a fixed growth time of 1 h. The films were characterized by using optical microscope, scanning electron microscope (SEM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) and atomic force microscope (AFM). The results show that growth temperature at $1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ the SiC films exhibit smooth surfaces morphology, good interface quality, and uniform thickness, with a root-mean-square (RMS) roughness as low as 1.92 nm, thereby achieving the best crystalline quality. With the temperature rising to $1100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the 3 C SiC phase is maintained, however, thermal stress leads to the formation of cracks on the surface and the RMS roughness increases to 2.22 nm. This study demonstrates the feasibility of 3C-SiC films growth within temperature range of $800-1100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ using the PCS precursor method, providing a new approach for the growth of SiC films on sapphire substrates.

title: Medical Device Failure Prediction Framework
authors: Bitada Dubois Emmanuel, P Chandru, R Ragul, A Mohanarathinam
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The increasing reliance on medical devices in critical healthcare environments demands robust mechanisms to ensure their reliability and prevent unexpected failures. MedDevice-Guard is an AI-driven system designed to predict potential failures in medical devices before they occur, thereby enhancing patient safety and operational efficiency. The system collects real-time device telemetry, analyzes historical failure patterns, and applies machine learning algorithms to detect early signs of malfunction. This predictive maintenance approach aims to reduce downtime, optimize healthcare workflows, and support proactive intervention strategies in hospitals and clinical settings.

title: Deep Integrated Denoising and Super Resolution Framework for Panchromatic and Multispectral Image Fusion
authors: Sujatha Canavoy Narahari, Krishna Pracheth K, Pavan Venkata Sai B, Abhishek Gudipalli
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Image Super Resolution (SR) enriches the spatial resolution of low-resolution images, while image denoising removes noise to improve visual quality. We propose a novel hybrid model architecture integrating multi-image super resolution and denoising techniques. Our method addresses two objectives i.e., denoising multispectral low-resolution ima7ges, which are then input into the super resolution model, and improving spatial and spectral resolution by combining panchromatic and multispectral images. The denoising module employs convolutional layers with rectified linear units and sigmoid activations to suppress noise and normalize outputs. The processed multispectral image and the corresponding panchromatic image are inputs to the super resolution module, which utilizes convolution layers and resid- ual skip connections for enhanced reconstruction. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed hybrid architecture sur- passes Cutting-edge super resolution models, achieving superior spatial and spectral enhancement performance. This work offers significant advancements for applications in remote sensing and image processing.

title: Loop Planning for UAV Monitoring the Cultivated Land
authors: Jiaxuan Zhuo, Nan Huang, Xinyu Sun, Chenglin Han, Yuanyuan Liang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: This paper studies the path planning problem of full coverage unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in a 3-D terrain environment. Aiming at the realistic constraints such as terrain fluctuation, occlusions, and no-fly zones, a method of UAV coverage path generation and optimization is developed, employing a random experiment strategy and simulated annealing (SA) optimization. The approach begins with grid-based discretization of the UAV flight space and the 3-D terrain, followed by the establishment of a camera field-of-view model that accounts for terrain shading. Combined with the simple sweep-based approach and A* algorithm, an initial loop satisfying the coverage requirement is generated. On this basis, the SA algorithm is designed to optimize the initial path with the coverage rate and path length as the optimization objectives. The adaptive acceptance mechanism strikes a balance between solution quality and search efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively address terrain occlusion and no-fly zone constraints, and significantly shorten the monitoring path while ensuring high coverage. The method outperforms the comparison algorithms, demonstrating excellent practicality and stability.

title: Systematic Review of Swin Transformer Architectures for Medical Image Classification
authors: Mahmoud Adel Nour, Ahmed F. Elnokrashy, Mai S. Mabrouk
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The growing complexity and volume of medical imaging data have driven the need for advanced automated classification systems that combine precision with computational efficiency. Swin Transformers have emerged as a transformative architecture in this domain, leveraging hierarchical feature extraction and shifted window attention to address the unique challenges of medical image analysis. Unlike conventional approaches, Swin Transformers excel at capturing both fine-grained details and broader contextual information, making them particularly suited for tasks requiring multi-scale analysis. This systematic review explores the role of Swin Transformers in medical image classification, examining their architectural advantages, clinical applicability, and current limitations. Future research should focus on optimizing Swin Transformers for real-world healthcare settings, including the development of lightweight variants and robust benchmarking protocols. The review also identifies gaps in current applications, particularly in understudied modalities like ultrasound, and calls for more comprehensive datasets to enhance model generalizability. By addressing these challenges, Swin Transformers have the potential to advance medical image classification significantly, bridging the gap between cuttingedge AI research and practical clinical implementation. This work provides a foundation for further innovation in the field, emphasizing the need for interdisciplinary collaboration to realize the technology's promise in healthcare.

title: Performance and Security in AI-Driven mHealth: A Comparative Evaluation of PostgreSQL, MongoDB, and Firebase for Endometriosis Management
authors: Manal Ed-Daoudi, Karima Moumane, Zineb Mouman, Ibtissam AIT Lakhal, Farha Oudaoud
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Mobile health (mHealth) applications transform healthcare for chronic conditions like endometriosis. This paper compares Firebase Firestore, MongoDB, and PostgreSQL for “PainCare”, an mHealth application developed for endometriosis symptom tracking and AI-driven predictive analysis. We evaluated these systems on backend performance (using ApacheJMeter with up to 100 users), application security (MobSF static, Burp Suite dynamic), and Random Forest AI model integration (trained on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex>-instance Kaggle dataset) for endometriosis likelihood prediction. Our findings show PostgreSQL exhibited superior performance and stability under load <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(28-32 ~\text{ms}$</tex> avg. response, 0 % error). Firebase enabled rapid development but faced Firestore performance testing limitations due to SSL errors, alongside a critical vulnerability from an exposed API key. All implementations received “Medium Risk” MobSF security scores (Firebase: 50/100, MongoDB: 44/100, PostgreSQL: 48/100), highlighting common weaknesses like debug configurations. MongoDB offered flexibility for the AI integration, where the Random Forest model achieved approximately 63.27 % accuracy. With 63 % accuracy, the AI model cannot be used for clinical diagnosis, but can serve as an awareness or preliminary triage tool, helping direct patients to medical consultation. Future improvements are needed to strengthen its reliability and applicability. This study provides empirical evidence and practical considerations for DBMS selection in AI-enabled mHealth, highlighting the essential relationship between performance, security, AI feasibility, and robust application-level security practices while supporting global smart connectivity for decentralized healthcare systems.

title: Watwaos: A Framework for Worst-Case-Aware Tailoring and Whole-System Analysis of Energy-Constrained Real-Time Systems
authors: Tobias Häberlein, Eva Dengler, Phillip Raffeck, Peter Wägemann
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Emerging embedded systems have to increasingly meet energy constraints besides their timing requirements. While frequency-scaling techniques are well explored, existing operating systems for embedded real-time systems have shortcomings in comprehensively exploiting energy-saving features present in modern system-on-chip (SoC) platforms. Existing systems lack operating-system abstractions to exploit the tradeoff between computing performance and energy efficiency. Consequently, whole-system analysis techniques are not applicable to yield optimal configurations tailored to the applications' requirements. Finally, the complexity of modern energy-saving hardware features creates huge search spaces for optimal configurations. In this paper, we present WATWAOS, a framework for worst-case-aware tailoring and whole-system analysis of energyconstrained real-time systems. WatwaOS acts as both an analysis/tailoring framework and a (generated) real-time operating system. The approach exploits knowledge acquired during wholesystem analysis and applies worst-case-aware tailoring of the system for its runtime. WatwaOS has an awareness of the application's requirements (i.e., deadlines, peripheral devices) and the underlying SoC's energy-saving features. To achieve the tailoring, WATWAOS introduces a concept of hierarchical abstractions, which offer fine-grained power-management decisions. These abstractions are designed to enable merging of their states without loss of accuracy. Static analysis based on these abstractions yields worst-case-optimal (i.e., provably energy minimal) solutions with regard to given deadlines. To tackle the enormous search space of our bilevel problem, WatwaOS employs several concepts to exploit advanced features of mathematical optimizing tools. The evaluations of WATWAOS validate our claim of finding worst-case-optimal solutions within acceptable analysis times.

title: A Large Language Model-Based Framework for Generating Simulation Models of Power Systems
authors: Duange Guo, Shanyu Li, Yushi Liu, Xingyu Shi, Shan Jiang, Ye Zhu, Georgios Konstantinou, Mengxuan Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This paper proposes a dual-agent framework based on a large language model (LLM) to automatically generate power system dynamic simulations. The progress is divided into two Agent parts: Agent I is responsible for creating a plan and transferring the reasoning output into a specific, recognized procedure with functions; Agent II is responsible for generating code, utilizing a database if functions exist, or creating new functions and then storing them in the database. Meanwhile, two feedback loops are used for code generation and the planner to ensure the automation of the entire process. Electromagnetic transient models of the IEEE 9-bus benchmark model are generated in MATLAB/Simulink platform as an example to illustrate that the general commercial LLMs have the potential to be used in the power system domain to perform insightful tasks based on the simulation feedback, and generate the data source during training progress to achieve a self-evolving LLM.

title: A Synergistic Approach to PID Control in Buck Converters with Red Panda and Lyrebird Optimization Algorithms
authors: Saravanan G, Pazhanimuthu C, Sathish Kumar D, Yamuna R, Subramaniam G
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The DC-DC buck converter is used in wide applications demanding efficient voltage step-down, particularly in electronic gadgets, electric vehicles, industrial automation, and renewable energy systems. The stable DC voltage enhances the efficiency of the system and protects the components. This work regulates the output voltage of the DCDC converter with the aid of a PID controller. The metaheuristic approaches are utilized to identify the gain of the controller in the recent years. The Red Panda Optimization Algorithm (RPOA) and the Lyrebird Optimization Algorithm (LOA) are proposed and achieve better performance under the uncertainty scenario of electronic components. By analyzing the quick response, overshoot, and bandwidth, the LOA has superior performance compared to RPOA and also compared with existing algorithms. The system is tested at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 20 \%$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 25 \%$</tex> of tolerance of electronic components, and the LPOA has reached stable output quickly without overshoot, and also it has a large bandwidth. This significant improvement indicates that LPOA has better efficacy for real-time systems.

title: Optimized Real-Time Control for Soldering Station
authors: Kunal Sanjay Gugale, Yash Rakesh Mistry, Sharon Jose B L, Shanmugasundaram M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a Real-Time Operating System (RTOS)based soldering station using FreeRTOS on the Raspberry Pi Pico RP2040 microcontroller. The system provides precise temperature control and intuitive user interaction for a reliable and efficient soldering process. Core functionalities include real-time temperature monitoring, control signal generation for the heating element, and dynamic user input handling. Tasks are structured as single state machines and coordinated through shared global variables, including setpoint, actual temperature, setpoint edit, and control signal. The system employs an OLED display for feedback, three button user input for navigation and configuration, and a buzzer for alerts. This modular design demonstrates the advantages of FreeRTOS in embedded control systems, showcasing efficient task scheduling, inter-task communication, and deterministic performance for real-time applications.

title: EHKEA: A Lightweight and Secure Authentication Protocol for Healthcare Iot Systems in 5G Networks with Enhanced Resistance to Emerging Threats
authors: Younes-Amine Loutfi, Marc Frappier, Brahim EL Bhiri, Pierre Martin Tardif, Mohammed Raiss El Fenni
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Secure authentication remains a critical challenge in healthcare IoT (H-IoT) systems, where constrained devices must ensure data integrity, privacy, and resilience despite limited resources. This paper proposes EHKEA, a lightweight mutual authentication and key establishment protocol designed specifically for H-IoT environments. EHKEA relies solely on symmetric cryptographic primitives and ephemeral randomness to provide mutual authentication, forward secrecy and resistance to common attacks such as replay, impersonation, and man-in-the-middle intrusions. We formally verify EHKEA in the Tamarin prover under the Dolev-Yao adversary model, proving key security properties including injective agreement and session key secrecy. A detailed informal analysis further confirms its robustness against desynchronization, insider threats, and key compromise impersonation. Comparative analysis with recent H-IoT protocols demonstrates that EHKEA achieves superior efficiency while offering stronger security guarantees, making it well-suited for deployment in real-time healthcare monitoring applications.

title: Energy Management Optimization in Residential Microgrids Using Blood Sucking Leech Optimizer
authors: Thirumoorthy Ramasamy, Thiruvenkadam Srinivasan, In-Ho Ra
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Residential Microgrids (MGs) utilize Renewable Energy Sources (RESs), Hybrid Energy Storage System (HESS), and Electric Vehicles (EVs) to supply local power and improve energy reliability. However, RES output fluctuations can increase the reliance on backup systems, higher running costs and reducing MG efficiency, while poor coordination between EVs, batteries, and RESs can raise emissions and underutilize clean energy. To overcome these limitations, this article proposes a Blood Sucking Leech Optimizer (BSLO) algorithm to optimize Energy Management (EM) in residential MG with RESs, HESS, and EVs. The main objective of the proposed BSLO algorithm is to minimize operating expenses, emissions, maximize the efficiency of the MG, and utilize RESs by optimizing the energy allocation and ensure efficient utilization of resources. The suggested method is implemented in MATLAB and compared with various existing approaches like Particle Swarm Optimization, Coati Optimization Algorithm, and Gannet Optimization Algorithm. The suggested technique achieves an operational efficiency of 98.9%, reduces emissions to 68.4 ppm, and minimizes energy cost to 1502 cents, effectively enhancing energy allocation accuracy and improving system reliability in MG systems integrated with RESs, HESS, and EVs.

title: Optimizing Agricultural Decision-Making: Leveraging SMOTE and Machine Learning for Balanced Data Insight
authors: Dhinakaran Sakthipriya, Thangavel Chandrakumar, S. Srimathy, R. Rajkumar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The agricultural zone is increasingly more integrating records-driven technology to beautify selectionmaking, productivity, and aid control. A number one assignment in using system mastering for agricultural predictions is the imbalance in datasets, where uncommon events like crop failures or pest infestations are underrepresented. This can lead to biased observations and erroneous forecasts, prohibiting their true effectiveness. This addresses the unbalanced observed record in the use of the Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique (SMOTE), which is synthetic models for minority groups, balances the data set and improves model development efficiency. Machine learning of models, such as Random Forest, Extensive evaluation of imbalance and SMOTE-balanced records is carried out with Support Vector Regression (SVR), Decision Trees, and ok-Nearest Neighbors(KNN), and highest quality model tuning is done using GridSearchCV. Results: The results show that SMOTE improves the predictive accuracy of models greatly, especially for minority classes, making models much more reliable for the agricultural packages like crop health monitoring and yield prediction.

title: IoT-Based Wearable Device for Fetal Health Monitoring
authors: Ramya. S, Sabariviswanathan. S, Balamuralidharan. C, Kanisk. K, Vengatesh. R
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Fetal movement plays an important role in women's pregnancy period. Existing technologies used in clinical application are not effective in the long term, and they are accessed easily. We present a wearable system using an accelerometer sensor for continuous monitoring. The main concept of this project is based on Personalized home care. Terminal monitoring unit connects to the control centre with the help of Internet of Things (IOT). Internet of Things (IoT) is applied to the system to connect the terminal monitoring units to the Control Centre. This system mainly consists of two parts: the local control unit and the remote health evaluation unit. The local control unit includes a garment integrating accelerometers for data and an embedded system for signal processing, an Android-based local control platform used for visualization of fetal health status based on the information received from the garment via Wi-Fi, and it is also used to alarm the pregnant woman if any changes in fetal movement occur. The Mobile Health Check Unit offers remote access to patient's medical data for monitoring purposes through cloud-based infrastructure. It has a highly advanced diagnostic system and will be able to initiate responses in case of emergency. The Mobile Health Check Unit is also designed to aggregate individual patient health information for scientific inquiry. Together with the local components for the system's control, the Mobile Health Check Unit is an example of a functional Internet of Things (IoT) in home healthcare and well-being.

title: Behavior-Preserving Top-Down Construction of Cross-Organization Emergency Response Processes
authors: Cong Liu, Huiling Li, Qingtian Zeng, Qi Mo, MengChu Zhou, Long Cheng, Shangce Gao
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: When an emergency happens, one of the most important tasks is to perform effective emergency disposal. To this end, emergency organizations need to collaborate to accomplish missions that exceed the capacity of any single organization. Typically, an emergency disposal is structured as a set of collaborative processes, referred to as cross-organization emergency response processes (CERPs). To deliver better emergency services, the initial step is to construct a high-quality CERP model. This paper introduces a top-down CERP model construction approach to tackle one of the most challenging issues in this area: How to construct a CERP model such that each organization can design, change, and modify their own processes without disturbing the overall collaboration and correctness of CERP. The proposed top-down CERP model construction approach involves the following stages: 1) Cross-organization public process model construction; 2) Intra-organization public process model generation; 3) Behavior-preserving intra-organization private process model construction; and 4) Organization-specific CERP model construction. A case study on cross-organization fire emergency response is conducted to demonstrate the applicability and effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Wellness Monitoring of Industrial Operators Using Sparse Autoencoder Analysis of Wearable Data
authors: Ugiljon Qushnazarova, Subha R, Rajesh Sehgal, Nodira Khodjaeva, Nurullaeva Ugulkhon
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: New possibilities for real-time operator health and safety monitoring have emerged with the incorporation of wearable technologies into industrial settings. Industries that deal with high levels of stress, physiological instability, and weariness must implement continuous wellness assessments to ensure the safety and efficiency of their workers.
