When it comes to multimodal wearable data, however, traditional monitoring methods that rely on threshold-based metrics or human supervision often miss subtle, nonlinear trends. With these restrictions, it is more difficult to identify signs of wellness decline early, which delays care and increases dangers in the workplace. The new framework, Sparse Autoencoder-based Wellness Monitoring of Industrial Operators using Multi-modal Data (SAWIM), is designed to fill this need. Wearable data such as skin temperature, heart rate variability, and accelerometer readings are compressed and learned by SAWIM using sparse autoencoder neural networks. Anomalies are detected with high sensitivity and a low number of false alarms by SAWIM through the modeling of individual baseline health profiles. Through experimental assessment on a simulated industrial dataset, SAWIM outperforms traditional PCA and thresholding approaches in anomaly identification, while also enhancing recall and accuracy in recognizing signs of stress and fatigue. Finally, SAWIM offers a data-driven, efficient method for proactively monitoring operators' well-being, enabling more robust and secure industrial operations.

title: Graphics-Based Data Center Information Room Scenario Simulation System
authors: Qian Dang, Wenbo Shang, Jianrong Fu, Pengdong Lu, Mingkang Guo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: As societal electricity demand continues to climb, the scale and complexity of power grid data centers keep increasing. Traditional manual-dependent equipment room inspections have revealed significant shortcomings in efficiency, objectivity, and real-time responsiveness, struggling to meet higher demands for operational stability and reliability. Addressing this challenge, this paper proposes and implements a graphics-based simulation and joint debugging system for power grid data center information rooms. This system aims to provide a reproducible, scalable virtual inspection verification platform. Utilizing Unity as the execution engine, it constructs realistic 3D room environments and equipment models. Built-in NavMesh/Agent technology handles path optimization and obstacle avoidance, while a UI panel enables visual display of equipment status and historical path playback. Python serves as the control terminal for task scheduling and data processing. Both components establish bidirectional communication via TCP Socket, forming a closed-loop process: "command issuance → navigation execution → status collection → result display → data export." Communication and execution performance were evaluated in a loopback network environment: end-to-end transmission latency remained stable below 20 ms (minimum 0.69 ms), while internal response time from command issuance to execution in Unity was controlled within 1 s. Results demonstrate the system’s engineering characteristics of low cost, scalability, and robust real-time performance, providing effective support for intelligent server room inspection research and implementation.

title: Study of Brain Image Segmentation Techniques: Bridging Classical Methods and Quantum Innovations
authors: Salma Mostafa A. Helmy, Salsabil A. El-Regaily, Abeer M. Mahmoud, El-Sayed M. El-Horbaty
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The intricate architecture of the Central Nervous System (CNS) underscores its pivotal role in sensory and motor function, with the brain's diverse regions—cerebellum, brainstem, and cerebrum—each contributing uniquely to cognitive and physiological processes. This comparative study delves into the critical challenges of brain tumor and ischemic stroke segmentation, emphasizing the necessity for precise imaging techniques, particularly MRI, in diagnosing and treating these conditions. We explore the evolution of segmentation methodologies, from traditional active contour models to cutting-edge quantum machine learning (QML) approaches, highlighting their respective strengths and limitations. Our analysis reveals significant advancements in segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency, particularly through hybrid quantum-classical frameworks that leverage the power of Quantum Convolutional Neural Networks (QCNNs) and advanced deep learning techniques. By synthesizing findings from recent literature, we demonstrate how these innovative algorithms not only enhance diagnostic precision but also pave the way for personalized treatment strategies. This study ultimately advocates for the integration of quantum computing in medical imaging, positing that such advancements could revolutionize brain tumor management and improve patient outcomes. Future research directions are proposed to optimize these models for broader clinical applicability, ensuring robust performance across diverse imaging datasets and real-world scenarios.

title: Toward Dynamic Risk Assessment: Machine Learning and LLMs in Software Vulnerability Prioritization
authors: Mohammed Moustaid, Soufiane Hamida, Abdelaziz Daaif, Bouchaib Cherradi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The rapid growth of software vulnerabilities demands advanced prioritization beyond static scoring systems. Recent works (2020-2025) have applied machine learning (ML) and large language models (LLMs) to predict and rank the risk of vulnerabilities based on features such as CVSS metrics, exploit presence, context and natural language descriptions. This review surveys supervised, unsupervised, and hybrid ML approaches-including neural networks, ensemble classifiers, graph-based models-and LLM-based NLP methods. We examine various model types (e.g. Random Forest, XGBoost, CNN, DistilBERT), data sources (NVD/CVE descriptions, exploit databases, OSINT, telemetry), evaluation metrics (accuracy, F1-score, MSE), and quantitative results. Performance trends indicate ML can improve on CVSS baselines (e.g. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{8 3 \%}$</tex> accuracy), whereas LLMs require domain adaptation to perform well. Finally, we discuss gaps in research, such as limited real-world validation and the need for dynamic, context-aware models.

title: A Framework for Generation Expansion Planning Under Transmission Constraints: A Case Study of the Western Cape
authors: Grace Ruzive, Chantelle Y. van Staden, Karen S. Garner
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: South Africa's energy crisis persists despite significant renewable energy integration, with grid constraints emerging as a critical bottleneck. This study addresses the challenge by proposing a deterministic framework for generation capacity expansion planning under transmission constraints for networks with limited grid upgrades. This is achieved through the application of deterministic hosting capacity analysis to generation expansion planning. The transmission constraints considered for the study are transmission line thermal limits and transformer thermal limits. The framework calculates the generation capacity margin at each bus and iteratively adds a fixed percentage of generation capacity until the transmission constraints are exceeded or violated. This framework is applied to a case study of the Western Cape transmission network and implemented using a linear load flow analysis in PyPSA. Results indicate that a 20% increase in maximum generation capacity at each bus in the network results in line overloading. The proposed framework offers a computationally efficient and scalable approach to generation expansion planning enabling planners to assess congestion and overloading thresholds without relying on computationally intensive generation expansion planning methods.

title: Failure Analysis of SiC Gate Turn-off Thyristor Under Repetitive Discharge Conditions
authors: Xiaohong Li, Lishuai Han, Jiesen Li, Xia Luo, Xinghuan Chen, Shengzong He, Yijun Shi, Liang He, Yuan Chen
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: abstract- This work investigates the repetitive discharge capability of SiC GTO devices and analyzes the underlying failure mechanisms. The devices exhibit an electrical signature of short-circuit failure after repetitive discharge. Firstly, no discernible morphological anomalies and significant voids in the devices are observed by non-destructive X-ray and scanning acoustic microscope (SAM) analysis, respectively. It indicates that repetitive discharge does not induce damage at the package level and failure originates primarily at the chip level. The devices are then mechanically decapsulated and chemically stripped of the silicone-gel encapsulant, after which lock-in infrared thermography is used to rapidly pinpoint internal failure sites. Subsequent scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is employed to precisely locate the failure region. Results show that, the burn-out site is situated far from the gate pad. It originates at the edge of the anode-cell termination, with damage extending between the gate and anode. The primary cause is likely excessive gate current within the die or a defective dielectric layer between the anode and gate. This study provides valuable insights for further optimization of SiC GTO design, enhancing discharge capability and system reliability.

title: Neural Network-Based Mapping of Deep Neural Networks Onto Network-on-Chip Architectures
authors: Md Farhadur Reza, Dominik Cloud
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Network-on-Chips (NoCs) are the standard communication fabrics for interconnecting cores and uncores in multi/many-core systems. Deep learning relies on deep neural networks (DNNs), which run efficiently on NoCs due to their scalability, parallelism and power efficiency. However, DNNs mix global (fully-connected) and local (convolutional) communication patterns. Therefore, computations for different DNN layers must be mapped to mitigate communication bottlenecks within the NoC. Traditional heuristic-based approaches often struggle with scalability and adaptability. This paper presents a neural network (NN)-based framework that learns to map DNN neurons onto NoC cores by optimizing load distribution and communication efficiency. We also adapted and implemented three mapping heuristics, simulated annealing (SA), genetic algorithm (GA), and dragonfly algorithm (DA), and compared their performance to that of our NN-based mapper. Simulations of mapping DNNs trained on CIFAR-10 and Fashion-MNIST show that our NN-based mapper balances per-core load (by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.5 \times$</tex>) and minimizes communication cost, yielding up to 17.1 % higher overall performance, 9.7 % lower latency, 16.8 % greater throughput, and 5.2 % energy savings compared to SA, GA, and DA, while providing fast mapping solutions (up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13,000 \times$</tex> faster).

title: Work-in-Progress: A First Practical Look at Arm's MPAM for Real-Time Systems
authors: Ashutosh Pradhan, Daniele Ottaviano, Alexander Zuepke, Andrea Bastoni, Marco Caccamo
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Arm's Memory Partitioning and Monitoring (MPAM) extension introduces standardized mechanisms for partitioning cache and memory bandwidth. From a real-time systems perspective, this can aid in improving predictability in heterogeneous MPSoCs. In this paper, we present the first practical evaluation of MPAM on a COTS platform—the Radxa Orion O6 with the CIX CD8180 SoC. We characterize the SoC's MPAM capabilities and experimentally assess cache portion partitioning and proportional stride memory bandwidth partitioning under controlled interference. Our results show that enabling MPAM features can reduce interference, but their behavior often diverges from expectations based on the specification, with anomalous effects observed across workloads and cores. These findings highlight both the promise of predictability from MPAM for real-time systems and the current challenges arising from optionality, heterogeneity, and limited documentation. We conclude that broader evaluation across future MPAM-enabled SoCs, aided by detailed performance counter analysis, is essential to establish MPAM's practical value for real-time practitioners.

title: Optimization of 254 nm Deep Ultraviolet Light-Emitting Diodes with Convex-Shaped Electron Blocking Layer
authors: Aoxiang Zhang, Jiayi Yao, Fang Wang, Juin J. Liu, Yuhuai Liu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: AlGaN-based deep ultraviolet light-emitting diodes (DUV-LEDs) suffer from significant electron leakage, which reduces hole injection. To reduce electron leakage, a convex-shaped (CS) electron blocking layer (EBL) is proposed and investigated. The DUV-LED reported by Khan et al., with an emission wavelength of 254 nm, serves as the reference device. The performance of DUV LEDs employing rectangular EBL and CS EBL was simulated by APSYS software. The results show that the CS EBL effectively suppresses electron leakage in the p-type region and enhances carrier injection efficiency. At an injection current of 75 mA, the IQE and output power are increased to 16.9% and 4.0 mW, respectively. The proposed CS EBL serves as a theoretical basis for alleviating electron leakage in 254 nm DUV-LEDs.

title: Photovoltaic Fault Detection with Deep Learning: Trends, Challenges, and Gaps
authors: Amira Fekry, Yasmine M. Afify, Nivin A. Helal, Walaa Gad
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) modules are prone to various defects that can significantly reduce energy yield and operational lifespan. Imaging-based inspection techniques, particularly Electroluminescence (EL) and Infrared (IR) thermography, have emerged as effective non-destructive tools for detecting and classifying such faults. This paper reviews recent advances (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2019-2025$</tex>) in deep learning and computer vision approaches applied to EL and IR images for PV fault detection. Public datasets, including ELPV, PVEL-AD, ELDDS1400C5, and the Infrared Solar Modules Dataset, are discussed alongside their characteristics and challenges. The surveyed methods range from lightweight convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to transformer-based architectures and hybrid deep learning-machine learning models, incorporating data augmentation, attention mechanisms, and generative adversarial networks to improve robustness. Comparative analysis highlights that EL-based methods generally achieve higher classification accuracy due to controlled imaging, while IR-based methods excel in large-scale field inspections. Performance trends, research gaps, and potential directions—such as real-time deployment, multi-modal fusion, and explainability—are identified to guide future development.

title: Real- Time Gas Leak Prediction using LSTM on MQ-6 Sensor with ESP32
authors: Adhavan B, Jeyashree A, Velmurugan K, Sriram K, Umabharathi S, Dharunika T B
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Detecting gas leaks is essential to ensure safety in residential, industrial, and commercial environments. This paper introduces an intelligent gas monitoring system using the MQ-6 semiconductor sensor with an ESP32 microcontroller, integrated with a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-based deep learning model. Time-series sensor data is continuously collected and preprocessed using normalization and sliding-window segmentation methods. The trained LSTM model captures temporal variations in the data to provide early and precise predictions of potential leaks. Once a leak is identified, automated safety measures such as solenoid valve closure, power disconnection, and audible alarms are triggered to minimize risks. Furthermore, sensor readings and prediction results are uploaded in real time to a Firebase cloud platform, ensuring remote supervision, data storage, and instant notifications. Experimental evaluations show that the proposed system outperforms conventional threshold-based methods, offering higher sensitivity and reliability. The integration of artificial intelligence with Internet of Things (IoT) technology highlights a scalable and proactive solution for advanced gas safety management.

title: Mitigating Mismatch and Wiring Losses Through Static PV Array Reconfiguration
authors: Prathima H. V., R. Shivarudraswamy, Praveen Kumar Bonthagorla, M. Ramesh, Keerthana C. P., Lekhana. G. B.
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Partial shading in photovoltaic (PV) arrays results in considerable mismatch losses, diminished power output, and the potential for hotspot development. To alleviate these adverse effects, various static physical reconfiguration techniques are employed to improve energy yield and facilitate shade dispersion. In this study, the conventional Total-Cross-Tied (TCT) configuration, along with two static reconfiguration strategies namely Column-Based Reconfiguration and Array-Level Reconfiguration are examined under a range of shading scenarios, including L-shape, Long-wide, Random, and Right Top Corner (RTC) patterns. The proposed methods are modelled and analyzed within the MATLAB/Simulink framework, integrating realistic wiring specifications and accounting for resistive losses. For performance assessment, irradiance levels of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1000 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> (unshaded), <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$700 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, 500 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}, 200 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> (shaded) were employed to simulate various shading conditions. Simulation results reveal that both static reconfiguration approaches enhance shade dispersion and improve current uniformity compared to the conventional TCT arrangement, with Method 2 (Array-Level Reconfiguration) demonstrating superior shading tolerance at the expense of higher wiring resistance. The study highlights the trade-off between wiring complexity and mismatch reduction, offering insights into the practical implementation of shade-resilient PV array configurations.

title: Fuzzy Constraint Dominance Strategy for Constrainted Multiobjective Optimization Problems with Multiple Constraints
authors: Weixiong Huang, Rui Wang, Tao Zhang, Sheng Qi, Ling Wang
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Solving constrained multiobjective optimization problems (CMOPs) is a highly challenging work. Numerous complex nonlinear constraints significantly add to the complexity of CMOPs, resulting in an exceptionally intricate feasible region. Makes it difficult for the algorithm to search for the complete constraint PF. In addition, under the influence of multiple complex nonlinear constraints, the conventional calculation method of overall constraint violation is inefficient for assessing the quality of infeasible solutions, potentially misguiding the evolutionary direction of the population. In response to these challenges, this paper proposes the fuzzy constraint dominance strategy (FCDS). This novel approach facilitates nuanced comparisons of solutions to strike a better balance between objectives and constraints. The fuzzy constraint violation introduced in FCDS mitigates the misleading impact of complex nonlinear constraints. Moreover, FCDS divides the solution process of complex CMOP into multiple stages from easy to difficult, and uses adaptive methods to increase the difficulty level of the problem. Systematic experiments on four test suites and three real-world applications have conclusively demonstrated the superior competitiveness of FCDS against leading algorithms.

title: Analytical Modeling of Task Allocation for Distributed Anthropomorphic Robots in Mission-Critical Environments
authors: Zhishang Wang, Yassine Khedher, Khanh N. Dang, Michael Cohen, Abderazek Ben Abdallah
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Efficient task allocation among mobile agents is critical in high-stakes scenarios such as disaster response, battlefield coordination, and emergency healthcare. This paper introduces a framework for task allocation across distributed anthropomorphic robots (androids) operating in dynamic, resource-constrained environments. The system leverages decentralized decision-making, context-aware prioritization, and adaptive communication protocols to maintain robust performance under intermittent connectivity, limited energy availability, and unpredictable task demands. We present an analytical model that formalizes the interplay between agent autonomy, resource limitations, and task urgency, enabling adaptive behavior in volatile conditions. Preliminary evaluation indicates the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed approach, with notable gains in task distribution efficiency, reduced latency, and improved fault tolerance compared to centralized alternatives. In particular, the proposed leader-based allocation method that incorporates force, energy, and timing constraints achieves a success rate about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.0 \times$</tex> higher than existing approaches with 30 tasks and 100 androids and more than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 \times$</tex> higher with 50 tasks and 300 androids. These results lay the foundation for resilient, scalable coordination mechanisms in mission-critical mobile networks.

title: Non-Communicative Decentralized Cooperative Navigation: Reinforcement Learning From Point Clouds
authors: Yu Zhai, Zhe Liu, Yanzi Miao, Hesheng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Last-mile transport is costly and operationally fragile due to frequent layout changes, mixed traffic with pedestrians and other robots, and unreliable connectivity that makes precise maps hard to maintain. Classical multi-agent planners rely on globally consistent maps or communication. Local BEV pipelines depend on tightly registered perception stacks. End-to-end vision models can be brittle across scene changes. While 3D LiDAR offers geometry that transfers well, its high dimensionality and occlusions complicate real-time, multi-agent control without messaging. We propose an end-to-end mapless, communication-free navigator that consumes a single onboard 3D LiDAR scan and outputs discrete actions for decentralized execution. The approach introduces a dual-channel LiDAR projection that preserves near-field free space while aligning goal guidance. A graph-attention interaction head infers neighbors’ motion tendencies from local observations only, which guides different coordination strategies for pedestrians and vehicles. A structure-aware dense reward stabilizes learning around occlusion-prone layouts (e.g., long walls, U-shaped bays). Our simulations demonstrate strong generalizability and scalability across layouts and sizes. The module trained only in random scenes with 10 agents transfers to crowd and warehouse styles, which to clusters with over <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10^{3}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> agents. Real-world trials validate sim-to-real transfer without retraining. We deploy the model on transport vehicles and small robots under changing environments. The results indicate robust, scalable, and deployment-friendly navigation for last-mile operations.

title: MLSTP: A Mamba-Based Long-Short Term Fusion Network for Improved Trajectory Prediction in Autonomous Driving
authors: Jiaxing Ren, Bochao Zou, Juntao Lyu, Huimin Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Traffic trajectory prediction plays a crucial role in ensuring the safety and efficiency of autonomous driving systems. With increasing traffic complexity, accurate and real-time prediction of surrounding vehicle trajectories has become a major challenge. Existing methods often define trajectory prediction as a static task, predicting future trajectories at once based solely on historical states. However, this approach leads to significant long-term prediction errors and struggles to capture potential hazards in complex, dynamic traffic conditions. In this paper, we propose a lightweight end-to-end trajectory prediction model integrating a long-term guidance module and a short-term feedback mechanism. The long-term guidance module predicts the final driving goal that remains unchanged over time, guiding the vehicle’s eventual position. The short-term feedback mechanism captures the dynamic driving environment, continuously updating the model with immediate changes in vehicle interactions and road conditions to avoid unexpected dangers. At each time step, our approach leverages accumulated historical information and incorporates both short-term and long-term future information to iteratively predict multi-modal trajectories, effectively reducing long-term prediction errors. Additionally, our method introduces the Mamba module, which enhances real-time prediction performance and reduces historical information loss during long-term prediction. Experiments on the Argoverse 1 and Argoverse 2 datasets show that our method, with fewer parameters and higher inference speed, achieves results comparable to or surpassing previous state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient and Fault Tolerant Data Stream Processing With Uncertain Data Rates in Serverless Edge Computing_supp1-3647054.pdf
authors: Wenzheng Xu
publish: N/A
abstract: Data stream processing is a functionality of various AI applications to obtain continuous insights from data streams. Serverless edge computing (SEC) is a key solution for implementing data stream processing requests by deploying serverless functions into cloudlets. However, existing data stream processing methods focus more on processing delay, ignoring fault tolerance and complex dependencies among functions, resulting in critical events being missed in the event of any fault and processing inefficiency. Besides, due to the uncertainty of data streams, existing function deployment methods may not be suitable for their newly changed data rates, causing resource waste or shortages. To address these problems, we first propose an optimization framework to enable efficient and fault tolerant function deployment, such that the delay of data stream processing is minimized while meeting its fault tolerant requirements and resource capacity constraints of cloudlets in an SEC network. We then design an online learning algorithm that predicts data rate changes through a multi-timescale machine learning method and proactively adjusts instance locations and numbers to absorb data rate uncertainty. Experimental results in a real test-bed show that our proposed algorithms outperform their counterparts by 13.5% on the average delay and 26.3% on the average fault tolerance.

title: Limited-on-Site-Data-Driven Fast and Accurate Online Parameter Identification for UWPT Systems
authors: Zhixin Chen, Fei Xu, Qingxin Yang, Xian Zhang, Pengcheng Zhang, Xiquan Deng, Yize Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Online parameter identification is essential for underwater wireless power transfer (UWPT) systems to ensure charging stability and high efficiency. However, strong conductivity, harmonic interference, and parameter deviations pose huge challenges for traditional parameter identification methods that rely entirely on circuit models. Data-driven methods are an effective method to solve this problem, while a large amount of on-site data and long computation time are necessary for high-accuracy, which limits its versatility. To overcome this limitation, this letter proposes a transfer learning (TL)-driven online joint parameter identification method with a small amount of experimental data and fast computation speed for UWPT systems. Firstly, a source domain model (SDM) is pre-trained on augmented air-domain data. Then, a target domain model (TDM) is obtained by fine-tuning with limited seawater samples, enabling joint identification of mutual inductance and load resistance while reducing underwater testing effort. A 1 kW UWPT prototype was built to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The results show that the proposed framework provides fast, accurate, and practical parameter identification under seawater conditions. The framework achieves 0.12 ms estimation latency and errors below 5% with 109 samples.

title: DeTrAck: UAV Detection and Tracking using Neural Networks Ensemble on Surveillance Systems
authors: Trandafir-Liviu Serghei, Dan Popescu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly deployed in critical environments (e.g., borders, airports), where real-time detection and tracking remain challenging due to small target size, complex backgrounds, long ranges, and resource constraints. We present DeTrAck, a non-invasive UAV monitoring system designed for embedded platforms that couples a YOLO11-based detector with an in-loop validation convolutional neural network (VaL_CNN) and DeepSORT tracking, while issuing pan-tilt-zoom (PTZ) commands via ONVIF to maintain target on-sight. We curated a custom dataset comprising both visible spectrum and infrared imagery. Across recorded sequences, the proposed ensemble reduces false positives, enables lower detection thresholds, and sustains continuous tracking. In a 3,647-frame sequence, it preserved target identity without loss, achieving competitive detection performance (≈ mAP@50 78%) at near real-time throughput (≈10% FPS reduction versus baseline). An ablation study across YOLO11 variants shows that the YOLO11s + VaL_CNN configuration provides the best precision–speed trade-off, resulting in an over 4% increase in true positives and a 2.6 times inference processing reduction in false positives compared to the baseline detector even for very small targets 1:2500. DeTrAck supports multi-target and multi-camera operation via RTSP/ONVIF integration, making it suitable for practical surveillance deployments on portable ground-air observation points.

title: Integrated Optical Camera Communication and Scene Sensing Based on Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Wenping Liu, Qian Deng, Zheng Yang, Fu Xiao, Bingpeng Zhou, Xuewen Geng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: This paper studies the problem of integrated optical camera communication and scene sensing. Due to the tight coupling between background images and stripe information in low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) encoded images, existing methods cannot simultaneously achieve high-quality optical signal decoding for LED-to-camera communication and background image reconstruction for scene sensing. To address this challenge, this paper analyzes the adversarial characteristics between stripe information and background images, and proposes GANOCCAS, a generative adversarial learning framework tailored for integrated optical camera communication and scene sensing that effectively resolves mutual interference between stripes and background content. First, we design a generator using a CondConv-based 4-layer U-NET architecture with SimAM modules on the last three residual layers and CondConv+PixelShuffle combinations as upsampling layers. Second, we develop a discriminator that combines multi-scale convolutional networks, pooling layers, and residual networks to output stripe sequences for optical signal decoding. Third, by leveraging pixel loss, multi-scale structural similarity loss, and adversarial loss, we ensure that the generator outputs clean background images suitable for scene sensing while the discriminator decodes optical signals for communication in complex environments. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate that GANOCCAS effectively reduces communication interference from background images and accurately reconstructs stripe-free background images across various SNR scenarios, outperforming current state-of-the-art methods in both reflected OCC and scene sensing tasks.

title: Effects of edge geometry and interface characteristics on delamination strength of REBCO tapes under transverse tension using anvil method
authors: Richard Pascua, Michael de Leon, Sang Heon Lee, Hyung-Seop Shin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Multilayer REBCO-coated conductor (CC) tapes undergo various stresses and strains when utilized in superconducting devices such as high-field magnets and coils. The stresses encountered by REBCO tapes include radial transverse tensile stresses from Lorenz forces and thermal stresses arising from differences in the thermal expansion coefficients of the constituent layers during quenching. These stresses can cause delamination at multiple interfaces within the REBCO CC tape's multilayer architecture, compromising its integrity and leading to catastrophic failure of the superconducting device. Meanwhile, the Cu stabilizer surrounding the CC tape plays a key role in preventing delamination failure by binding multiple constituent layers with different mechanical properties and maintaining structural stability against transverse external forces. However, the effect of slit edges created during the CC tape manufacturing process on delamination resistance under transverse loading is still unclear. To address this critical research gap, we conducted comprehensive delamination tests using the anvil method. We compared the effects of the slit edge geometry and the Cu layer at the edges on the mechanical delamination strength of REBCO CC tapes. By conducting a comprehensive analysis, we aimed to examine the roles of edge geometry and interfacial properties in the delamination behavior of REBCO CC tapes. This will offer valuable insights for optimizing the design and fabrication of these high-field coils, contributing to the development of more robust and reliable superconducting devices.

title: A Novel Diagonal-Laminated Fe-Based Nanocrystalline Ribbon Shielding Structure in Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: De'an Wang, Zhi Bie, Shumei Cui, Jiantao Zhang, Chunbo Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electromagnetic Compatibility
abstract: In recent years, the application of nanocrystalline materials in wireless power transfer systems has been continuously investigated. However, due to their significantly higher conductivity characteristics than ferrite, they can trigger additional eddy current losses and attenuate the transmission efficiency of the system. This article presents a novel diagonal-laminated Fe-based nanocrystalline magnetic structure, which significantly reduces the additional eddy current loss of typical flat-laminated nanocrystalline structures and possesses excellent shielding effects. The modeling and analytical calculations of magnetic shielding energy efficiency and eddy current losses are performed and discussed in conjunction with magnetic reluctance modeling and finite element simulations. The superiority of the proposed core structure is verified by comparative experiments with five different magnetic pads prototypes of wireless power transfer couplers. Results show that the shielding effect is almost comparable to that of the ferrite pads when transmitting 3 kW power. The system efficiency is higher than 93.4%. Specifically, compared with the ferrite pads, the proposed structure reduces the core weight and volume by about 15.1% and 31.9%, respectively, realizing the lightweight design and efficient operation of the system.

title: Comparative Study of Electromagnetic Forces in External Rotor SPMSMs With Different Slot/Pole Combinations Considering Force Modulation Effect
authors: Wenting Wang, Yuqi Wang, Lijian Wu, Hua Li, Tianjie Zou, David Gerada, Chris Gerada
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This study comprehensively investigates and compares the electromagnetic force characteristics in external-rotor surface-mounted permanent magnet machines, considering the modulation effect. Four representative slot/pole number combinations, i.e., 10p9s, 8p9s, 10p12s, and 14p12s, are studied. The discrete radial force couple model, commonly used for stator analysis, is extended into a continuous formulation to capture the relationship between tangential force and its resultant radial vibration. Furthermore, the study highlights how phase relationships, both between radial and tangential forces and between low- and high-order harmonics, can lead to either amplification or suppression of vibrations. Additionally, the influence of geometric parameters, including pole arc ratio and stator tooth-tip arc ratio, on force amplitude and phase is thoroughly explored. The results reveal that, with a fixed slot number, a higher pole count tends to induce stronger vibration due to the reinforcement between the radial force modulated from radial force harmonics and the equivalent radial force from tangential force harmonics. Moreover, a contrasting pattern is observed that high-order forces intensify low-order components in 9-slot machines but suppress them in 12-slot machines.

title: Multimodal Hypergraph Representation Learning for Drug Synergy Prediction_supp1-3648991.docx
authors: Xian-gan Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Drug combination therapy for complex diseases is currently widely utilized in clinical treatment. An increasing number of computational methods are being adopted to discover new drug combinations. However, most existing methods mainly focus on phenotypes, while ignoring the deep level interactions between drug pairs and cell lines. In this paper, we introduce a multimodal hypergraph representation learning approach named MHGSynergy, aimed at predicting drug synergies. MHGSynergy models the synergistic relationship as a hypergraph by considering the structure, targets, and physicochemical features of drugs. The nodes represent drugs and cell lines, and hyperedges capture synergistic triplets of drug pairs and cell lines. Different drug features are used as attributes of drug nodes in the hypergraph to construct three hypergraphs. Hypergraph neural networks are employed to update embedding features of drugs and cell lines, then input these embedding features into the channel attention comprehensive fusion module to obtain a representation. Finally, these representations are used to build predictive models. In both classification and regression tasks, MHGSynergy performs well on two benchmark datasets, and outperforming those baseline methods, and MHGSynergy has unique advantages when facing unknown drug pairs or cell lines. We believe that MHGSynergy is a valuable tool for discovering synergistic drug combinations. The implementation of this method is available at https://github.com/ZhangZ33/MHGSynergy.

title: Automated Detection of Nonhelmeted Motor Cyclists and License Plate Recognition - YOLOv8 With Paddle OCR
authors: Saravanaprabhu D, Naresh Prasad V, Gowtham Kumar P, Rajaveeramuthu T, Vijay J T
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Motorcycle accidents remain a major public safety concern, with the absence of helmets being one of the primary causes of serious injuries and fatalities. Traditional methods of enforcing helmet laws often rely on manual observation or reviewing CCTV footage, which is both time-consuming and prone to human error. This work introduces an automated system that detects motorcyclists not wearing helmets and identifies their license plate numbers using advanced computer vision and text recognition techniques. The solution employs the YOLOv8 deep learning model to detect helmet usage and locate motorcycle license plates from uploaded images. When a helmet violation is detected, the corresponding license plate is cropped and processed using Paddle OCR, which extracts the alphanumeric details after applying preprocessing steps such as noise reduction, grayscale conversion, and contrast enhancement. The system is implemented in Python with a Stream-lit based interface for ease of use and clear result visualization. It can handle multiple riders in a single image with high accuracy, reducing the need for manual surveillance. This approach can be integrated into existing traffic monitoring infrastructure for real-time or offline analysis, ultimatelyassisting authorities in improvinghelmet law compliance and enhancing road safety.

title: IoT Based Multi-Parameter Environmental Monitoring System using ESP32 for Real-Time Safety and Air Quality Assessment
authors: Delshi Howsalya Devi. R, R. Divya, S. Radjarejesri, S. Sanchita, K. Saranya, S. Gowdhamkumar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The ESP32 microcontroller platform [11] is used in this study's creation and deployment of an inventive Internet of Things-based environmental monitoring system for thorough real-time safety and air quality evaluation with integrated machine learning capabilities. When compared to traditional systems, the system's innovative adaptive threshold algorithms, sensor fusion methods, and predictive analytics capabilities greatly increase detection accuracy and lower false alarm rates. In addition to a DHT11 sensor [13][15] for monitoring ambient temperature and humidity, the system incorporates several specialized sensors, such as MQ-5, MQ-9, and MQ-135 gas sensors [10][18] for detecting dangerous gases like liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), carbon monoxide (CO), methane, ammonia, benzene, and smoke particles [9]. The use of a dynamic calibration algorithm, which improves measurement accuracy by 23% over static calibration techniques by compensating for environmental changes and sensor drift in real-time, is a significant advance. The major processing unit is the ESP32 microcontroller [11], which uses its dual-core architecture and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4 0 M H z}$</tex> operating speed together with builtin Wi-Fi and Bluetooth to provide smooth data processing, collection, and the creation of predictive alerts. With response times averaging 18 seconds (65% faster than commercial alternatives), detection accuracy of 95.2%, and false alarm rates decreased to 2.1% from 8.3% in traditional systems across a variety of operating environments, comprehensive performance evaluation shows superior system effectiveness [14]. This system is affordable for residential, commercial, and industrial applications because it uses easily accessible components and reduces costs by 78% when compared to comparable commercial solutions while keeping better performance metrics [8][23].

title: Improved A* algorithm for amphibious robot based on energy consumption and path length
authors: Jiwei Wang, Zhanfeng Ying, Hao Ge
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: To meet the requirement of collaborative optimization of mission endurance and path efficiency of amphibious robots in complex environments, a cross-domain path planning method integrating energy consumption and distance is proposed. Secondly, based on the improved A* algorithm, the heuristic function constructed by the energy consumption estimation model and the distance estimation model is used to determine the path cost of the proposed algorithm, and the weight coefficient is introduced to balance the contradictory objectives of the two, so as to realize the multi-objective optimization of energy consumption and path length. The simulation results show that the proposed algorithm can balance path length and energy consumption effectively compared with the single distance optimization path planning method. Under the premise of ensuring reasonable and feasible path planning, the total energy consumption can be reduced by 54.27%, which verifies the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in power constrained tasks.

title: Evaluation of Peak Shaving Demand Charge and Greenhouse Gas Reduction with Photovoltaic Systems in Medium General Service
authors: Natchapol Ruangsap
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This paper presents an evaluation of peak shaving demand charge and greenhouse gas reduction with photovoltaic system in medium general service. The objective is to evaluate peak shaving, demand charge reduction and greenhouse gas reduction with photovoltaic system. The capacity of photovoltaic systems are 20 kW and 30 kW, respectively. The total load is 360 kW per day. Calculation electricity cost uses type 3 medium general service by Metropolitan Electricity Authority. The calculation uses Electricity Generation from Renewable Energy (T-VER-S-METH-01-01) from Thailand Voluntary Emission Reduction Program (T-VER). The result found that photovoltaic systems can reduce demand charge, change peak load and greenhouse gas reduction.

title: Design of a Solar-Powered Automated Dip Spray System for Small Stock Farmers in Remote Areas in Developing Countries
authors: Kelebaone Tsamaase, Sajid Mubashir Sheikh, Theo Motlhatlhedi, Thabang Seeketso, Karabo L. Sithole
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: This study describes the design and implementation of a mobile, solar-powered automated dip spray system designed for small livestock, like sheep and goats. The main goal is to address the ongoing difficulties that farmers in isolated and off-grid areas of Botswana face, especially with regard to ticks and other ectoparasite control. The conventional methods of treating livestock, such as applying tick grease and manually spraying, are frequently labor-intensive, inconsistent, and inefficient at guaranteeing full-body coverage. An Arduino Nano microcontroller was used to create a prototype that automated the spraying mechanism in order to address these issues. The system incorporates a solar-powered pump for the dispersion of an antiparasitic solution, servo motors for gate control, a capacitive sensor for dip level monitoring, and ultrasonic sensors for animal detection. This paper presents the system's technical development and performance analysis, as well as a comprehensive future roadmap that includes integrating animal weight sensors for customized treatment, upgrading to an ESP32 microcontroller for wireless connectivity, and enabling real-time cloud data logging and mobile application interfacing. The system will become an allinclusive smart livestock management solution that is appropriate for smallholder farmers in sub-Saharan Africa with these future enhancements.

title: TEB Pretreatment for Mg doped p-type h-BN
authors: Dengrui Zhao, Li Zhang, Zhongming Zeng, Baoshun Zhang, Xiaodong Zhang, Xianqi Dai
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Achieving stable and efficient p-type conductivity is a key challenge for advancing the application of wide-bandgap hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) in electronic and optoelectronic devices. However, the high B-N bond energy and oxygen diffusion from the substrate generally limit the incorporation and activation efficiency of Mg, thereby restricting the attainable hole concentration and hindering device development. In this work, we propose a triethylboron (TEB) pretreatment strategy based on metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD). By introducing TEB pre-paving on sapphire substrates, in-situ Mg doping is realized during the epitaxial growth of h-BN. This approach not only effectively suppresses oxygen diffusion from the sapphire substrate but also enhances Mg incorporation and activation efficiency in h-BN. Experimental results demonstrate that the h-BN films subjected to TEB pre-treatment exhibit significantly improved conductivity, with Hall effect measurements confirming p-type conduction. Moreover, the hole concentration is increased by an order of magnitude compared with untreated samples. Importantly, this method achieves remarkable enhancement in p-type conductivity without introducing additional complexity to the epitaxial process. These results indicate that the TEB pre-treatment strategy provides an effective pathway to overcoming the doping bottleneck in h-BN and enables its integration into next-generation wide-bandgap semiconductor devices.

title: Multi-Class Building Change Detection in Urban Areas Using High-Resolution Aerial Images with Class Imbalance Mitigation and VSSM-Based Model
authors: Young-Woong Yoon, Hwi-Young Kim, Impyeong Lee
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Multi-class building change detection in urban areas is critical for urban monitoring, disaster management, and planning. This study focuses on improving multi-class change detection performance in high-resolution aerial imagery by addressing the challenges of data imbalance and leveraging a Visual State Space Model (VSSM)-based architecture. To mitigate class imbalance, we introduced object-based random cropping and dynamic class weighting, which enhanced the representation of underrepresented classes during training. These strategies, combined with the robust spatio-temporal modeling capabilities of VSSMs, enabled accurate classification of changes such as new construction, demolition, renovation, color change, and no change. The proposed approach achieved balanced performance across all categories, with a mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) of 0.575 and Cohen's Kappa Coefficient (Kappa) of 0.691, demonstrating its effectiveness in multi-class building change detection tasks in complex urban environments.

title: JIIT Campus Navigator
authors: Vibhu Chaudhary, Anjali Chaturvedi, Suma Dawn
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Getting around a big, complicated campus can be confusing and stressful for students, staff, and visitors. This paper introduces an easy-to-use campus navigation system built with open-source mapping tools and modern web technology. Many campuses struggle with outdated maps, unclear signs, and poor accessibility, making it hard for people to find their way. Using the existing technology, navigation within a campus having multiplex buildings is not accurate. With the usage of OpenStreetMap data, the proposed methodology will help deliver a more accurate location, having current maps, allowing for advanced search, and better multiple route planning features. The system prioritizes accessibility so anyone, even with disabilities, can navigate the refurbished campus system smoothly. The proposed system will also work seamlessly on any device, making it convenient for all users. The goal is to make campus life easier, reduce unnecessary travel, and create a more welcoming, efficient environment for everyone.

title: Research on Power Purchase and Sale Strategy of Electricity Retailers Based on Renewable Portfolio Standard
authors: Haoyang Yu, Xinhui Du, Jia Su, Gan Liang, Shuaishuai Qian, Xuan Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: This paper investigates the evaluation of renewable portfolio standards (RPS) for electricity retailers and proposes a procurement and sales strategy model for electricity retailers that takes RPS into account, aiming to better address the challenges posed by the renewable energy consumption responsibility system. The model is a two-layer optimization model. The upper-layer model optimizes the procurement portfolio of electricity retailers across multiple markets to achieve the lowest procurement costs. The lower-layer model establishes appropriate sales strategies to maximize profits and minimize risks. This paper also analyzes the impact of RPS and electricity retailers' risk aversion on electricity purchase and sales decisions, providing theoretical guidance for electricity retailers' participation in multi-market trading decisions under the RPS framework.

title: Thermally Stable Quantum Dots Converted High-Power Light-Emitting Diodes
authors: Shilong He, Zhongsheng Nie, Chong. Geng, Qing Li, Jay Guoxu Liu, Shu Xu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Quantum dot (QDs) converted light-emitting diodes (QcLEDs) have shown significant promise for advanced lighting and display applications due to their high efficiency, spectral tunability, narrow emission linewidths, and compatibility with micro/nano fabrication techniques. However, ensuring their long-term stability under combined conditions of air exposure, high temperature, and high light intensity remains a critical challenge. This study investigates the impact of heat and light on the performance and degradation of Qc-LEDs, aiming to guide the development of thermal- and photo-stable QDs for high-power Qc-LED applications. Steady-state and hightemperature transient photoluminescence measurements were utilized to examine the exciton dynamics and the surface reaction mechanisms of QDs under harsh conditions, focusing on how exciton dynamics influence the degradation mechanism and kinetics. Light-induced photodegradation accelerates when excitons migrate to the surface, a process that is primarily governed by the heterostructure of the QDs and the surface energy states. A well-designed QD structure, with enhanced heat dissipation and higher surface energy levels, can better withstand high light power densities. To address these challenges, we developed a series of CdSe and perovskite-based green and red emitting core-shell QDs with multiple surface modifications and protective encapsulation layers. These modifications significantly enhance the longterm stability of the QDs under both high-temperature and high-light density conditions. The thermally stable QDs, incorporating proper surface anion passivation, demonstrated superior resistance to both heat and light-induced degradation, retaining over 90% of their initial luminance after 500 hours of operation at $150^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. This study provides valuable insights into the design of robust Qc-LEDs for commercial lighting, display technologies, and other optoelectronic applications where thermal and optical stability is crucial.

title: Revisiting Community Detection and Centrality: Integrating Label Propagation, and the LACM-Score for Enhanced Network Insights
authors: Shivam Singh, Vaidik Parashar, Avni Aggarwal, Alka Singhal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Community detection and influential node identification are fundamental tasks in social network analysis. While communities reveal densely connected subgraphs, influential nodes are those that impact connectivity, flow, or structure the most. This paper bridges both concepts through a unified framework.Node-Influence and community identification approaches capture complementary aspects of network structure: the latter ranks nodes according to their structural relevance, while the former reveals coherent subgraphs. We study effective community-detection techniques, Label Propagation, with three traditional influence metrics: MDS (Minimum Dominating Set), Articulation-Point Centrality, K-Core Number, and Local Clustering Coefficient. To overcome their unique biases and build on their strengths, we provide the LACM-Score (Local Articulation-Core-Mds Score), a geometric-mean composite centrality that strikes a compromise between core embeddedness, global connectivity criticality, and local cohesiveness. We illustrate each method’s behaviour by extensive dry runs on several toy graphs, and we show that LACM-Score reliably finds truly influential nodes across a variety of topologies, beating any one metric alone.

title: Multiplier-Free In-Memory Vector-Matrix Multiplication Using Distributed Arithmetic
authors: Felix Zeller, John Reuben, Dietmar Fey
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Vector-Matrix Multiplication (VMM) is the fundamental and frequently required computation in inference of Neural Networks (NN). Due to the large data movement required during inference, VMM can benefit greatly from in-memory computing. However, ADC/DACs required for in-memory VMM consume significant power and area. ‘Distributed Arithmetic (DA)’, a technique in computer architecture prevalent in 1980s was used to achieve inner product or dot product of two vectors without using a hard-wired multiplier when one of the vectors is a constant. In this work, we extend the DA technique to multiply an input vector with a constant matrix. By storing the sum of the weights in memory, DA achieves VMM using shift-and-add circuits in the periphery of ReRAM memory. We verify functional and also estimate non-functional properties (latency, energy, area) by performing transistor-level simulations. Using energy-efficient sensing and fine grained pipelining, our approach achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.5 \times$</tex> less latency and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 \times$</tex> less energy than VMM performed in memory conventionally by bit slicing. Furthermore, DA completely eliminated the need for power-hungry ADCs which are the main source of area and energy consumption in the current VMM implementations in memory.

title: Depth-Assisted Intelligent Automatic Landing Site Estimation for UAVs
authors: Kevin P, Naveen Raj R
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The application of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) spans diverse domains, including agriculture, surveillance, and search-and-rescue operations, thereby underlining the pressing need for autonomous and safe landing mechanisms. In this work, a cost-effective and real-time approach is proposed, leveraging Monocular Depth Estimation (MDE) and image segmentation techniques to identify safe landing zones for UAVs. The MiDaS model is utilised to generate depth maps from single camera images, eliminating the requirement for expensive stereo or LiDAR setups. Depth gradients are processed using Sobel filters to a nalyse s urface fl atness to fil ter out une ven regions. An unsupervised clustering is carried out with algorithms like DBSCAN and k-means to detect homogeneous flat surfaces. The proposed method demonstrates robustness across varying environments, computational efficiency, and suitability for real-time deployment. Experimental results on aerial imagery indicate accurate detection of safe landing zones, offering a scalable solution for autonomous UAV navigation.

title: Permanent Magnet DC Motor Parameters Estimation Using Artificial Bee Colony Algorithm
authors: V. Sankardoss
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper discusses the permanent magnet dc (PMDC) motor parameter estimation with artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm. The electromechanical, mechanical, and electrical parameters are estimated based on the ABC algorithm and are utilized for modelling the permanent magnet dc motor in MATLAB/Simulink. The evaluation results indicate that an ABC algorithm attained motor parameter estimates with greater accuracy and is low likely to become trapped in local minima. This method is mainly preferred for estimating PMDC motor parameters in applications like wheelchairs due to its faster convergence and less error rates. Specifically, the ABC algorithm demonstrates angular speed and armature current errors that are smaller than those produced by conventional experimental techniques, with values of 5.5607 and 1.03485, respectively.

title: A Computational Framework for Early Dysgraphia Screening via Handwriting Analysis
authors: Vilasini V, Keerthi V, Sriram S
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Dysgraphia, a specific learning disability that impairs handwriting and fine motor skills, often remains undetected due to its subtle presentation and lack of standardized screening methods. This paper proposes a computational framework for the early detection of dysgraphia in children, leveraging handwriting analysis as the sole diagnostic input. The dataset comprises handwriting samples of students aged 6-10 years. Feature extraction techniques were applied to quantify aspects such as stroke formation, letter spacing, alignment, pressure patterns, and writing speed. These features were then used to train machine learning classifiers to distinguish between typical and dysgraphic handwriting profiles. The proposed method aims to provide a scalable, costeffective, and non-invasive alternative to conventional diagnostic practices, with potential applications in educational and clinical settings for early intervention and support.

title: Research on Automatic Connection Technology for Substation Grounding Wires Based on Intelligent Sensors
authors: Hao Cai, Shiyi Wang, Shuai An, Hao Wu, Xiongjian Huang, Jun Chai
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of low efficiency and poor safety of manual operation in substation grounding wire connection, this study proposes an automatic connection technology scheme based on intelligent sensors. By integrating visual perception, deep learning, and multi-sensor information processing methods, a target recognition and positioning system is constructed, achieving high-precision identification of connection points and 3D spatial coordinate calculation. The system design adopts a modular structure, integrating functions such as voltage verification, discharge, and connection, combined with a hybrid force-position control strategy to enhance operational reliability. This study conducted extensive testing across various substation settings (outdoor, indoor), collecting data on electromagnetic interference and illumination variations to optimize model robustness. It introduced both hardware synchronization (PTP protocol) and software synchronization (Kalman filter) algorithms to improve the spatiotemporal alignment accuracy of multi-sensor data. Experimental results show that the system exhibits good environmental adaptability in complex electromagnetic environments, with a target recognition accuracy exceeding 98%, a positioning error below 5mm, and a full-process operation success rate of 99.5%. This study provides a new approach for the intelligentization of substation operation and maintenance.

title: Zero-Knowledge Proofs for Privacy-Preserving Agricultural Yield Verification: A Blockchain-Based Incentive System for Sustainable Farming Methods
authors: Pooja Singhal, Nisheeth Joshi
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: This paper presents a novel blockchain-based incentive system that protects farmers' privacy while promoting sustainable farming methods by using zero-knowledge proofs, or ZKPs. With this method, farmers can show that they've met their yield goals without giving away private production information. We implement the system as an Ethereum smart contract that uses cryptographic assurances to ensure correct reporting and distributes incentives based on verified crop yields. Our method addresses important problems in agricultural sustainability projects, like protecting privacy, the cost of verification, and making sure that rewards are shared fairly. The suggested answer affects sustainable agriculture policy, privacy-focused data exchange in supply lines, and the use of cryptographic methods in environmental governance.
