Based on these findings, we propose rational recommendations and optimization strategies for the future evolution of China Telecom’s IP backbone network. These strategies include accelerating network architecture optimization and the introduction of emerging technologies, actively upgrading intelligent operation systems, and adjusting market strategies in a timely manner.

title: Weakly Supervised Food Image Segmentation using Vision Transformers and Segment Anything Model
authors: Ioannis Sarafis, Alexandros Papadopoulos, Anastasios Delopoulos
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a weakly supervised semantic segmentation approach for food images which takes advantage of the zero-shot capabilities and promptability of the Segment Anything Model (SAM) along with the attention mechanisms of Vision Transformers (ViTs). Specifically, we use class activation maps (CAMs) from ViTs to generate prompts for SAM, resulting in masks suitable for food image segmentation. The ViT model, a Swin Transformer, is trained exclusively using image-level annotations, eliminating the need for pixel-level annotations during training. Additionally, to enhance the quality of the SAM-generated masks, we examine the use of image preprocessing techniques in combination with single-mask and multi-mask SAM generation strategies. The methodology is evaluated on the FoodSeg103 dataset, generating an average of 2.4 masks per image (excluding background), and achieving an mIoU of 0.54 for the multi-mask scenario. We envision the proposed approach as a tool to accelerate food image annotation tasks or as an integrated component in food and nutrition tracking applications.

title: Model-Based and Model-Free Control for Active Suspension System
authors: Sagneek Sengupta, Pratik Kumar Singh, Adya Bhalla, M. Manimozhi, Praveen Kumar Medarametla
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The primary task of a suspension system is to ensure driver comfort and safety. It successfully separates the car body from road disturbances. In the case of the active suspension, an external energy source modifies the damping coefficient. This paper aims to compare different Active Mass Suspension (AMS) controllers designed. The main objective is to evaluate and improve the suspension system's performance in terms of ride quality, handling characteristics on a surface roadway, and dynamic stability. The findings of this research will prove essential for automotive engineers and researchers who design controllers, as they aim to optimize performance in terms of passenger comfort and safety.

title:
Design and Implementation of a Platform for Managing Stress and Anxiety in Higher Education Based on Wearable Devices
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Ilias Maglogiannis, Parisis Gallos, Stamatios Orfanos, Christos Panagopoulos, Andreas Menychtas
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: In the academic environment, students, researchers, professors, and professionals occasionally experience high stress levels due to increasing coursework demands, deadlines, and personal factors, which can lead to burnout and decrease in their academic performance. To address this challenge, we propose a platform based on a Digital Twin (DT) model for student stress management, integrating physiological, self-reported, and contextual data to enable stress monitoring and prediction. The proposed solution includes wearable devices to collect heart rate, heart rate variability, activity, and sleep quality, while a mobile application gathers pre- and post-activity stress levels, workload evaluations, and academic performance metrics. Additionally, contextual data, including academic schedules and deadlines, will be examined as stress related factors. The proposed DT use machine learning algorithms to predict individual stress and to optimize personalized interventions. The system aims to adjust study plans and suggest behavioral changes, in order to prevent high stress levels of the individuals. Initial results reveal that integrating biosignals with academic data, enhances stress prediction accuracy, offering an adaptive tool for improving students’ well-being and academic performance.

title: Adaptive Voting Ensemble-Based Machine Learning Algorithm for Breast Cancer Diagnosis
authors: Meenal Jain, Priya Porwal, Manjusha Gundale, Varsha Shukla
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: To develop predictive models and manage data effectively, researchers have widely adopted machine learning and data mining techniques across various domains, including marketing, computer science, education, aviation, finance, and most notably, medicine. These approaches serve as powerful analytical and diagnostic tools that aid in making informed decisions. This study investigates the effectiveness of various machine learning algorithms—both individual and ensemble—in the diagnosis and prediction of breast cancer. Key evaluation metrics, including accuracy, specificity, sensitivity, and precision, are employed to assess model performance and efficiency. The analysis involves the application of several individual classifiers, such as Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Naive Bayes (NB), Decision Tree (C4.5), and Simple Logistic, alongside ensemble methods including Majority Voting and Random Forest. All models were evaluated using a breast cancer dataset obtained from the UCI Machine Learning Repository, with 10-fold cross-validation employed to ensure reliable and unbiased performance estimation. Experimental results demonstrate that the Majority Voting ensemble—comprising SVM, KNN, and Simple Logistic—consistently outperforms individual models, achieving a classification accuracy of 98.1% and an error rate of only 0.01%. These findings suggest that the proposed ensemble approach offers a highly accurate and robust solution for breast cancer diagnosis.

title: Adaptive Reliability Optimisation of New Energy Vehicle Gear Transmission Systems Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Congkai Lin, Jinyu Liu, Junhui Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: The reliability of new energy vehicle gear transmission systems is a critical factor affecting overall vehicle performance and service life. This paper establishes an adaptive reliability optimisation framework for transmission systems based on reinforcement learning. A dual reward mechanism guides the agent to learn optimal control strategies under multi-objective constraints. This approach achieves precise identification and adaptive optimisation across diverse operating conditions and fault modes, overcoming limitations of conventional control methods in complex dynamic environments. The research offers novel insights for intelligent optimisation of new energy vehicle transmission systems, demonstrating significant application value in reducing failure rates, extending service life, and enhancing system adaptability.

title: Intelligent Cyber Threat Analytics and Prediction Model for Secure Cloud Communication Systems
authors: Charu Shukla, Deepika Saxena
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Cloud-Based communication systems face increasing cybersecurity threats due to their dynamic and high-dimensional data environments. Existing detection methods often struggle to achieve both scalability and high accuracy in cyber threat identification while maintaining computational efficiency. To address these challenges, this paper presents an Intelligent Cyber Threat Analytics and Prediction (ICT-AP) model that integrates Random Forest for feature selection, Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) for supervised dimensionality reduction, and the Isolation Forest algorithm for efficient cyber threat detection within a three-tier architecture. The ICT-AP model is validated using the Canadian Institute for Cybersecurity Intrusion Detection System 2017 (CICIDS 2017) dataset. Experimental results show that the model achieves high precision (greater than 0.93), recall (greater than 0.89), and a stable Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUC-ROC) of approximately 0.90, even with limited training data. The proposed method outperforms existing approaches while maintaining low computational overhead, making it suitable for real-world virtualized environments.

title: System-Based Protection Testing with IBRs and Negative-Sequence Injection
authors: Veronica A. Rosero-Morillo, F. Gonzalez-Longatt, André Silva-Melo, Ana García, Joao Márcio Jorge, Eduardo Orduña
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This work investigates how inverter control modelling influences protection in distribution networks with Inverter-Based Distributed Generation (IIDG). This paper analyse two representative fault-response schemes—(i) conventional, positive-sequence only, and (ii) advanced, with coordinated positive- and negative-sequence injection—both configured to satisfy Fault Ride-Through (FRT) requirements and to provide dynamic voltage support during disturbances. As international standards (e.g., IEEE 1547-2018; IEEE 2800-2021) continue to evolve, incorporating such models into protection assessments is increasingly essential. Our objective is to validate MATLAB/Simulink fault-response models and benchmark them against implementations available in OMICRON RelaySimTest software, quantifying their impact on relay-measured currents in medium-voltage feeders. The results validate the model across multiple fault types and elucidate the direct implications of inverter control choices on the behaviour of protection devices in distribution networks.

title: Real-Time Cognitive Emotion Mapping for Human- Avatar Interaction in VR
authors: Seif Ehab El Sheikh, Hossam Sanad, Nada Hamed Sharaf, Mohammed A.-M. Salem
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: With the shift toward online platforms for education, coaching, and therapy especially accelerated by the COVID19 pandemic-the need for emotionally expressive digital tools has grown significantly. Traditional virtual education solutions often lack the emotional interactivity required for effective communication, particularly for children with communication disorders such as autism. Furthermore, most avatar-based systems are built around English-speaking contexts, leaving a cultural and linguistic gap for widely spoken dialects such as Egyptian Arabic. This paper presents the development and evaluation of an Egyptian emotional avatar designed to express six primary emotions: Anger, Sadness, Fear, Surprise, Happiness, and Neutrality at varying intensity levels. The avatar was adapted from a Unity Asset Store model (Awaii Studio), enhanced by adding ten custom blendshapes using Blender to support additional facial expressions. Emotion targets were modeled based on average facial expressions of an Egyptian actor, derived from a curated dataset. Synchronization of lip movement was achieved using an Egyptian Arabic Text-to-Speech model developed by Omar Samir, alongside a blinking system to enhance realism. A user study was conducted with 40 participants (22 female, 18 male), comparing avatar videos with and without emotional expressions. Participants were divided to mitigate order bias and assessed the avatar based on naturalness, understanding, and reasonableness. Filler and attention-check questions were included to ensure reliability of responses. Results showed that 95% of participants preferred the emotionally expressive avatar, and found its expressions believable and contextually appropriate. This research contributes a culturally-tailored, emotionally rich avatar system for Arabic-speaking learners. Future work will explore dynamic emotional transitions, integration of body language, and enhancements to the TTS system for improved Egyptian Arabic fluency and realism.

title: Analysis of Mechanical Properties of High-Voltage Transmission Towers Under Wind Load
authors: Ruhai Liu, Peng He, Huikun Pei, Xi Chen, Zujian Cai, Shuang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: As the core component of the power system, the high-voltage transmission tower may be damaged in extreme weather conditions such as strong winds, which seriously affects the safety of power grid operation. Aiming at the problem of structural instability and failure caused by wind load during the service of transmission towers, firstly, an accurate three-dimensional mechanical finite element analysis model is established for an ultra-high voltage tower as the research object. Secondly, considering the change of wind speed with the height of the tower, the magnitude and distribution of wind load at different tower heights under the action of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$34 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> extreme wind speed are calculated, and the mechanical properties of the tower under the combination of the extreme wind speed and three wind direction angles are studied, and the equivalent stress and deformation law of the tower under different working conditions are calculated. The results show that the combination of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 5}^{\circ}$</tex> wind direction and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$34 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> wind speed is the most unfavorable working condition, under which the top displacement of the tower reaches 97.94 mm, and the maximum stress of the wire cross-bearer is 161.2 MPa, which has reached 46.7 % of the yield strength of Q345 tower steel.

title: Scalable and Robust AI Forecasting of University KPIs Using LSTM and Random Forest within the Lamar Data Lakehouse
authors: Ronish Shrestha, MD Masud Rana, Frank Sun, Bo Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Forecasting in higher education is needed for enrollment planning, staffing, budgeting, and research investment. This paper examines multivariate forecasting of university key performance indicators (KPIs) using annual data from the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS) and the NSF HERD survey covering 2010–2023. Four KPIs are modeled: enrollment, employees, graduates, and R&D expenditure. Two approaches are applied: Random Forest regression on lagged targets with covariates, and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks trained on multivariate sequences. Models are evaluated with an 80/20 chronological split using MAE, RMSE, MAPE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Results across three universities of different scales show that Random Forest produces lower errors and more stable forecasts. At the same time, LSTM is sensitive to recent fluctuations but less reliable with short annual series. The study demonstrates that Random Forest is a dependable baseline for long-term institutional planning, while LSTM offers value for scenario testing when longer or higher-frequency data are available.

title: OASIS: Optimized Active Sampling for Intrusion Detection in IoT Systems
authors: Aymin Javed, Nadeem Javaid, Zeeshan Ali, Nidal Nasser
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Intrusion detection in Internet of Things (IoT) environments is a critical yet challenging task due to the heterogeneous nature of devices and the complex attack landscape. Traditional machine and deep learning models often suffer from limitations such as poor class balance, irrelevant or redundant features, suboptimal classification accuracy, ineffective hyperparameter tuning, and scarcity of labeled data. To address these challenges, we propose an enhanced intrusion detection system model. Variance threshold is applied to select informative features, while the proximity weighted random affine shadow sampling technique is used to balance the dataset effectively. Capsule Network (CapsNet) is employed for robust classification due to its ability to capture spatial hierarchies in data. To further optimize CapsNet, we implement the Reptile Search Algorithm (RSA), resulting in the Reptile-Optimized Capsule Network (ROC-Net). ROC-Net is further enhanced using Margin-Based Active Learning (MBAL), forming Marginal Active-learning with Reptile-optimized Capsule Network (MARCO-Net), which efficiently annotates the most uncertain samples from the unlabeled pool. Experimental results show that the proposed ROC-Net and MARCO-Net significantly outperform traditional models, achieving improvements of 8.75 % and 12.5 % in accuracy, 13.75 % and 11.25 % in precision, 1.19 % and 9.52 % in recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7. 4 1 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1. 1 1 \%}$</tex> in F1-score, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 1. 9 4 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0. 9 0 \%}$</tex> in Matthews Correlation Coefficient, and 13.64 % and 22.73 % in Cohen's Kappa. Additionally, there is a reduction of 36.84 % and 52.63 % in hamming loss, and 75.86 % and 82.70 % in log loss, respectively. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system for accurate and efficient intrusion detection in IoT environments.

title: Integrating Environmental Toxins into Biomedical Knowledge Graphs for Disease Prediction Using Graph Neural Networks
authors: Rofida Gamal Agmy, Tayseer Hassan A. Soliman, Aliaa Gamal Agmy, Heba Atia Yassa, Marwa Hussein Abdelreheim
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Environmental toxins interact with disease determinants in complex ways, requiring computational structures able to capture biological heterogeneity. Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) represent a promising conceptual framework to describe such complicated interplays. In our current research, we build a heterogeneous biomedical knowledge graph (KG) based on the Toxin and Toxin Target Database (T3DB) 1, containing 49,501 nodes and 89,988 edges which are toxins, symptoms, protein/gene targets, routes of exposure, and environmental factors. Our prediction task can be defined as a two-step procedure: we first apply node prediction to toxins using embeddings and then apply link-prediction methods in order to identify toxin-disease associations. This type of layered architecture makes it easier to extract shared nodes among the predicted links, thus enhancing both interpretability and biological relevance. Experimental assessments were done on an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80 / 20$</tex> training test split, using a variety of random seeds to ensure robustness. Accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score were used as a measure of model evaluation. Findings highlight that Graph Attention Networks (GAT) have the best trade-off between accuracy and generalization, reaching an F1-score of 0.975; compared to RGCN and Enhanced GCN which is stable when faced with smaller or noisier graphs. The work has three main contributions: (1) incorporation of environmental exposure pathways into a toxin-disease KG, thus transcending the scope of a pure molecular toxicity prediction; (2) a systematic benchmark of a variety of GNNs within a systematic evaluation pipeline; and (3) the insights of interpretability, elucidating a variety of biologically meaningful substructures. Our proposed work highlights the critical nature of KG embeddings in combination with GNNs for predictive toxicology and environmental health analytics.

title: Steady-State Low-Frequency Automatic Precision Non-Essential Load Reduction Control System Based on Stable Control Technology
authors: Haifeng Xia, Mengqiu Zheng, Yening Lai, Mingying Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: Under the dual carbon goals, the rising proportion of new energy sources-to-load ratio brings greater challenges to power supply-demand balance due to its inherent uncertainties. In the current and foreseeable future, the “supply-demand imbalance” in electricity has become the new normal, with heightened risks of exceeding steady-state frequency limits. Therefore, in the critical frequency window between exhausted generator frequency regulation capacity and pre-low-frequency load shedding activation, it is imperative to establish an additional frequency control defense layer that automatically disconnects partial loads, serving as an effective supplement to dispatch-based load curtailment measures. This paper analyzes the inadequacies of existing load control measures in modern power grids. Aligned with the functional positioning of steady-state low-frequency active control defenses, it investigates two major control schemes (centralized and decentralized). It proposes four engineering implementation plans: Utilization of batch load control functionalities, Upgrades to precision load-shedding security and stability control systems, Retrofit of existing low-frequency load shedding devices at substations, Deployment of compact automation devices for interruptible load disconnection. The paper provides a detailed analysis of the advantages and disadvantages of each plan, offering engineering implementation solutions and equipment support for frequency active prevention and control functions in emergency supply scenarios under high-proportion renewable energy power systems.

title: A Comprehensive Review on Machine Learning Approaches for Detecting Knee Osteoporosis
authors: Nadeen Tarek Moussa, Eman Amin, Walaa Gad
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Knee osteoporosis is a degenerative bone condition characterized by reduced bone density, leading to increased fracture risk and impaired mobility. For prompt treatment to be possible and long-term complications to be avoided, early and accurate diagnosis is essential. Despite their effectiveness, traditional diagnostic methods like quantitative ultrasound (QUS) and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) are still constrained by subjectivity, cost, and accessibility. Deep learning (DL) and machine learning (ML) approaches have recently demonstrated great promise for automatically detecting osteoporosis in the knee from radiographic pictures. This paper provides a thorough analysis of machine learning (ML)-based methods used to detect osteoporosis in the knee from medical imaging modalities, with an emphasis on datasets, feature extraction methods, classification models, and assessment metrics. With the use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transfer learning, several studies have shown encouraging results, reaching up to 91% accuracy. However, there are several issues with current research, including limited explainability, inconsistent labeling standards, small dataset sizes, and a lack of external validation. Finally, we discuss new developments, challenges, and future directions to enable ML-driven osteoporosis detection systems that are trustworthy, comprehensible, and clinically useful

title: Development of an IoT-Enabled Environmental Monitoring System for Integrated Air and Soil Quality Analysis
authors: Srinivasan S, Saravanakumar Raju, Pankaj Sharma, Nithin T, Vinoth Babu. G, Chenduran A
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Monitoring our environment is more important than ever as they face growing challenges from pollution and climate change. This paper introduces an IoT-based system designed to keep a close eye on air and soil quality in real time. Using a network of affordable sensors, the system tracks key environmental factors such as air temperature, humidity, particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10), CO, NO, soil moisture, pH, and essential nutrients. These sensors send data wirelessly to a cloud platform that can be easily viewed and analyzed using a user-friendly web dashboard or mobile app. Alerts are generated when environmental conditions cross safe limits, helping users respond quickly. The system is designed to be scalable and adaptable, making it suitable for cities, farms, and industrial areas alike. Testing has shown that the system works reliably and accurately, offering a practical tool for better environmental awareness and smarter decision making. Ultimately, this approach supports healthier ecosystems and contributes to sustainable living. In general, their work provides a versatile and easy-to-use framework to monitor air and soil quality side by side. The system enables users from farmers to city planners to take action on real-time environmental insights by combining affordable technology with dependable data pipelines and reasonable interactive visualizations. This not only supports smarter agricultural practices and more resilient urban planning, but also contributes to healthier ecosystems and communities. The proposed system architecture, using the sensor calibration techniques, the data processing workflows, and the outcomes of field case studies that demonstrate the platform's usefulness and potential are covered in the parts that follow.

title: Hybrid Deep Reinforcement Learning for Joint Resource Allocation in Multi-Active RIS-Aided Uplink Communications
authors: Mohamed M. H. Shalma, Engy Aly Maher, Ahmed El-Mahdy
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Active Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS)s are a promising technology for 6G wireless networks. This paper investigates a novel hybrid deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for resource allocation in a multi-user uplink system assisted by multiple active RISs. The objective is to maximize the minimum user rate by jointly optimizing user transmit powers, active RIS configurations, and base station (BS) beamforming. We derive a closed-form solution for optimal beamforming and employ DRL algorithms—soft actor-critic (SAC), deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG), and twin delayed DDPG (TD3)–to solve this high-dimensional, non-convex optimization problem. Simulation results demonstrate that SAC achieves superior performance with a high learning rate leading to faster convergence and lower computational cost compared to DDPG and TD3. Furthermore, the closed-form of optimal beamforming enhances the minimum rate effectively.

title: Work-in-Progress: Real-Time Deep Neural Inference on Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
authors: Md Tasnim Farhan Fatin, Monowar Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are now central to perception and control in time-critical cyber-physical systems, yet many mid- and low-tier edge platforms (e.g., single-board computers without GPUs and most microcontrollers) cannot host full models or meet real-time constraints. Cooperative inference by offloading workload across nearby devices improves feasibility, but most existing schemes do not analyze end-to-end timing and are thus not suitable for real-time applications. This Work-in-Progress paper studies deadline-aware distributed DNN inference with an asynchronous execution semantics: a device proceeds as soon as its required partial outputs are available, without global synchronization. We develop a time-aware optimization model that minimizes response time subject to deadline constraints. We also outline our ongoing research efforts and future extensions of the proposed work.

title: Driver Behavior Monitoring and Analysis in Intelligent Cockpits
authors: Yidan Zhang, Kaixin Li, Wenzao Shi, Min Xiong, Zhibo Song, Yaxuan Lin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This study focuses on the intelligent cockpit driver behavior monitoring system based on YOLOv7 algorithm and Huawei Cloud ModerArts platform, and systematically discusses its key technologies and application value in improving driving safety. Traditional driver behavior monitoring methods have limitations such as low accuracy and poor real-time performance. However, this study realizes real-time recognition and analysis of driver fatigue state, distraction behavior and other multi-dimensional features by integrating YOLOv7's efficient target detection ability and ModerArts platform's powerful image processing function. The system captures real-time images of drivers by calling on-board cameras, preprocesses images, extracts features and recognizes behaviors through ModerArts platform, and finally prompts drivers to pay attention to safety through early warning mechanism. Experimental results show that the system performs well in accuracy, real-time and stability, especially in fatigue driving detection, which significantly improves recognition accuracy and response speed.

title: Stability-Guaranteed Scheduling for Mesh Networked Control Systems with Fine-Grained Timing
authors: Ruijie Fu, Yehan Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: As industrial control applications scale up, mesh networked control systems (MNCSs) are gaining popularity, where multiple control loops share a multi-hop mesh network. However, these loops often suffer from long-span, time-varying delays caused by the multi-hop transmissions of multiple flows, which significantly degrade control performance, particularly stability. Existing studies on delay-aware stability conditions are usually independent with network scheduling, leading to a pessimistic stability analysis. Meanwhile, existing stability-aware scheduling approaches rely on coarse-grained designs, further worsening stability guarantees and limiting network capacity. In this work, we propose a stability-guaranteed scheduling mechanism for MNCSs with fine-grained timing. We first establish a stability condition that accounts for time-varying delays over an extended horizon spanning multiple superframes, which reduces the pessimism in stability analysis and enables more refined scheduling strategies. Based on this condition, We design a Long time-horizon and Fine-grained network scheduling mechanism with Stability Guarantee (LFSG), which deterministically maps the stability condition into the fine-grained network scheduling, considering fluctuating delays over the extended horizon. Furthermore, we provide a stability-capacity-aware LFSG (SCA-LFSG), which aims to maximize the number of stabilizable control loops and demonstrates its effectiveness through various application paradigms. Extensive studies demonstrate the advantages of stability analyses, LFSG, and SCA-LFSG over state-of-the-art approaches in terms of both control and timing performance.

title: Cyber Wolf: A Hybrid Optimization Framework Leveraging Heterogeneous Graphs and Multimodal Surrogate Simulators for Fast Analog Sizing
authors: Nathan Chanez, Pascal Urard, Severin Trochut, Roberto Guizzetti, Kai Wang, Luc Moulin, Marwan Khader, Douglas Mateus Machado
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: In recent years, Artificial Intelligence (AI) has demonstrated its ability to accelerate various tasks by leveraging data to fit equations in neural networks. In the semiconductor industry, circuit design still relies on complex tools that deliver accurate results for simulating and optimizing circuits at the cost of high runtimes. Regarding the analog device sizing problem, researchers have proposed replacing traditional circuit simulators with trained neural networks to accelerate simulations. However, these approaches face limitations in generalizing circuit representations and using such surrogate models. This preliminary work proposes an enhancement in circuit representation compatible with any circuit topology and, through an example, presents a complete methodology for generating databases, representing circuits, and finally including the neural network model into an optimization framework to reduce the optimization time of the sizing of an analog circuit.

title: Power System Emergency Control Strategy Based on Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Constrained Graph Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhifang Dang, Xiaoqing Han, Zhewen Niu, Chaohui Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: To address the challenges of complex spatiotemporal coupling and strict physical constraints in emergency control of power systems with high penetration of renewable energy, this paper proposes a Dynamic Spatio-Temporal Constrained Reinforcement Learning framework (DSTC-RL). The method aims to balance model accuracy, computational efficiency, and action feasibility, thereby overcoming the adaptability bottlenecks faced by traditional approaches under strong uncertainty. Specifically, a dynamic spatio-temporal graph modeling module is developed to capture the evolving transient characteristics of the power grid using an adaptive adjacency matrix and gated spatio-temporal convolution units. By leveraging reinforcement learning, the DSTC-RL framework enables the system to autonomously learn optimal emergency control strategies through trial-and-error interactions with the environment, rather than relying on handcrafted rules or offlineoptimized schedules. This learning paradigm facilitates real-time decision-making under uncertainty, while incorporating spatiotemporal dynamics and operational constraints into the policy learning process. Experimental results on the IEEE 39-bus system demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms conventional DQN and DDQN-based approaches. Moreover, under node short-circuit faults, the proposed strategy enables rapid voltage recovery and stabilization, offering a highly reliable solution for the secure and stable operation of nextgeneration power systems.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Hemodialysis Management: Framework, Simulation, and Evaluation
authors: Akkaoui Achraf, Dachry Wafaa, Zahidi Yassine, El Moufid Mohamed, Medromi Hicham, Gziri Hassan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The treatment of hemodialysis remains complicated and operator-dependent due to the need to adjust machine settings continuously. This need comes to respond to changing patient situations and avoid complications like intradialytic hypotension. Existing systems do not have adaptive control and are not dynamically customized so that treatment can change on-the-fly. The purpose of this study is to provide a RL framework that facilitates patient-specific hemodialysis treatment management. This article suggests a simulation environment designed for clinical purposes that recreates both machine mechanics and patient physiology. Therefore, it encompasses machine-level state that can reach up to a 20-dimensional vector and another continuous action space that regulates critical machine dynamics. The agent is encouraged to learn stable and effective treatments through a hierarchical reward function that adheres to medical safety guidelines. The performance of the three RL algorithms, including Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), Soft Actor-Critic (SAC), and Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG), were compared in terms of cumulative reward, alarm frequency, and physiological stability. The results indicate that DDPG demonstrates better performance in terms of smoother controlled policies and alleviated number of safety violations. This study shows the promise of using Reinforcement Learning as a potential tool for modeling and optimizing dialysis treatment in a dynamic yet safe way. The discussion also covers limitations that exist when it comes to clinical integration, simulation of fidelity, safety guarantee, and interpretability. It appears that the methodology presented is a promising scheme for future intelligent dialysis systems that can provide personalized care while minimizing clinician workload.

title: A Nonvolatile IoT Sensor Node Based on Input-Data Driven Power-Gating Scheme and its Emulation Using FPGA and Temperature Sensor
authors: Daisuke Suzuki, Takahiro Hanyu
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Standby power consumption is one of critical issues in conventional CMOS-based IoT sensor node due to continuous power supply to retain internal data. In this paper, a nonvolatile IoT sensor node where nonvolatile (NV) memory is used for the storage element of the micro-controller unit (MCU). The use of NV memory makes it possible to perform instant power-gating behavior without losing internal data which results in great standby power reduction. Moreover, the use of sensorinput driven power-gating scheme, where the power supply of the NV-MCU is turned on only when a valid sensor input is obtained, makes it possible to extend standby time and skip wasted MCU operation which results in further power saving. For the functional verification, the proposed IoT sensor node is virtually implemented on an FPGA board (Digilent Basys 3) with a temperature sensor device (Digilent Pmod TMP2). It is estimated that the proposed IoT sensor node saves 35% of power consumption compared to conventional CMOS-based IoT sensor node under 1-second data sampling rate.

title: Wish a Pic: An AI-Powered Platform for Automated Visual Content Generation
authors: Omar Ayman Abdallah, Moataz Mohamed Abdelmonem, Nouran Tarek Abdelazim, Mohamed Ayman Mohamed, Hager Ahmed Hassan Alfakharany, Abdallah Mohamed Shaban, Engy Abdallah Mohamed, Mona A. Azim
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: In recent years, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into creative workflows has redefined how individuals and organizations approach visual design. Despite their strengths, traditional design tools demand specialized expertise, considerable time, and repeated iteration, creating barriers for non-experts and slowing professionals' productivity. This paper introduces Wish a Pic a unified AI-powered design platform that streamlines the creative process by transforming natural language prompts into high-quality visual. By combining multiple advanced AI models into a single, user-friendly interface, Wish a Pic empowers users-from seasoned designers to small business owners and students-to generate compelling visual content quickly, accurately, and without the need for prior design experience. The platform achieved a 0.4149 average CLIPScore after prompt enhancement, improving alignment with user prompts in 87.7% of test cases. Additionally, 89.38% of surveyed users preferred the enhanced outputs, confirming the efficiency of the developed system.

title: Ros ${ }^{\text {RT }}$: Enabling Flexible Scheduling in Ros 2*
authors: Sizhe Liu, Rohan Wagle, Shareef Ahmed, Zelin Tong, James H. Anderson
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: The Robot Operating System 2 (ROS) is heavily used in autonomous systems due to its large ecosystem and modular design. However, ROS remains problematic for real-time applications despite prior efforts to improve its real-time capabilities. Many of these problems are rooted in the implementation of the ROS executor, which does not support preemption or userspecified priorities. These properties are fundamental to real-time scheduling and desirable for general systems to reduce latency. ROS variants in prior work have separately supported the preemption and prioritization of callbacks but place restrictions on the application, preventing their adoption in a real-world workload. This paper addresses these deficiencies with a novel executor framework, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{ROS}^{\text{RT}}$</tex>, which is compatible with any type of ROS application while supporting preemptive, priority-driven scheduling. Additionally, to support flexible EDF scheduling in ROS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{\text {RT }}$</tex>, a custom EDF scheduler implementation is proposed using the new Linux scheduling class SCHED_EXT. ROS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{\text {RT }}$</tex> s flexibility and real-time compatibility do not come at the cost of overheads: it achieves a significant decrease in publisher-tosubscriber overhead from the native ROS executor. Finally, this paper concludes with a case study performed on the Autoware Reference System, which simulates the execution of the LiDAR module in an autonomous driving application, demonstrating the ability of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{ROS}^{\text{RT}}$</tex> at real-time scheduling in real-world scenarios.

title: Optimizing Falcon-Based Post-Quantum Blockchain Performance Through Compression Integration
authors: Dahhak Hajar, Afifi Nadia, Hilal Imane
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Falcon and other post-quantum cryptographic algorithms were introduced to counter the critical threats posed by quantum computing to conventional security systems. At the same time, blockchain infrastructures continue to face challenges in maintaining performance and efficiency when adopting these heavier cryptographic primitives. This work investigates how data compression can be integrated into postquantum blockchains to alleviate computational stress and improve scalability, particularly in fluctuating load environments. Our results indicate that, while compression introduces a slight overhead during data encoding, it significantly reduces memory consumption and improves latency stability under pressure. For example, our experiments reveal that compression reduces average transaction latency under normal conditions and lowers memory usage during peak CPU loads. These findings contribute to the growing research on enhancing the efficiency of postquantum blockchain systems, offering a lightweight and practical optimization technique.

title: Control Synthesis of Cyber-Physical Systems for Real-Time Specifications Through Causation-Guided Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xiaochen Tang, Zhenya Zhang, Miaomiao Zhang, Jie An
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: In real-time and safety-critical cyber-physical systems (CPSs), control synthesis must guarantee that generated policies meet stringent timing and correctness requirements under uncertain and dynamic conditions. Signal temporal logic (STL) has emerged as a powerful formalism of expressing realtime constraints, with its semantics enabling quantitative assessment of system behavior. Meanwhile, reinforcement learning (RL) has become an important method for solving control synthesis problems in unknown environments. Recent studies incorporate STL-based reward functions into RL to automatically synthesize control policies. However, the automatically inferred rewards obtained by these methods represent the global assessment of a whole or partial path but do not accumulate the rewards of local changes accurately, so the sparse global rewards may lead to non-convergence and unstable training performances. In this paper, we propose an online reward generation method guided by the online causation monitoring of STL. Our approach continuously monitors system behavior against an STL specification at each control step, computing the quantitative distance toward satisfaction or violation and thereby producing rewards that reflect instantaneous state dynamics. Additionally, we provide a smooth approximation of the causation semantics to overcome the discontinuity of the causation semantics and make it differentiable for using deep-RL methods. We have implemented a prototype tool and evaluated it in the Gym environment on a variety of continuously controlled benchmarks. Experimental results show that our proposed STL-guided RL method with online causation semantics outperforms existing relevant STLguided RL methods, providing a more robust and efficient reward generation framework for deep-RL.

title: Evaluating Multimodal Large Language Models for Clinical Diagnosis of Oral Lesions: A Biomedical Informatics Perspective
authors: Fatma E.A. Hassanein, Jylan El-Guindy, Yousra Ahmed, Asmaa Abou-Bakr
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Accurate diagnosis of oral lesions remains challenging due to overlapping clinical features and the high risk of missing malignancies. Multimodal large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT-4 and Google's Gemini Pro 2.5, can assist clinicians by integrating textual and visual data. This study compared these models with human experts in diagnosing oral lesions and quantified the added value of clinical images (photographs radiographs) on diagnostic accuracy. A total of 160 case vignettes with intraoral images were evaluated using ChatGPT-4 and Gemini Pro 2.5, with Top-1, Top-3, and Top-5 accuracy metrics benchmarked against two oral medicine specialists. Each model was tested with and without images, and analyses included Cochran's Q, McNemar tests with Bonferroni correction, Cohen's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$h$</tex>, and logistic regression. With images, ChatGPT-4 achieved 63.7 % Top-1 accuracy versus Gemini's 71.2 % and experts' 87.5 %. ChatGPT-4 improved significantly with image input (+13.8 points, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p=0.017$</tex>), while Gemini's gain was smaller and non-significant. Both reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 95 \%$</tex> Top-3 accuracy, closing the gap with experts. Visual input was most beneficial in high-difficulty and morphologically complex cases, while radiographs offered limited additional value. These findings underscore the promise of multimodal LLMs as assistive tools in oral diagnostics and the need for cautious, evidence-based clinical integration.

title: Research on Replacing Fluorescent Tube with UV LED Light Source Based on Total Reflection Little Angle UV Packaging Technology
authors: Wei Wei, Zou Jun, Song Jinde, Xiong Jingkang, Zhang Guoyi
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: A new type of high-efficiency small angle ultraviolet packaging device is designed in this paper to address the issue that the efficiency of medium pressure mercury lamp ultraviolet fluorescent lamp is higher than that of ultraviolet LED. By designing the light emitted by the ultraviolet LED at a small angle, directional beam shaping is achieved, greatly improving the actual light utilization efficiency of ultraviolet light. Compared with the reflective secondary optical design of traditional fluorescent lamps, it is found that this technology can achieve higher electro-optical conversion efficiency. In some segmented ultraviolet application fields, its efficiency is more than twice that of existing ultraviolet fluorescent tubes. In the future, with the further reduction of light source versions, it is expected that the penetration rate of these segmented fields will increase rapidly. This technology is worth promoting.

title: Scalable Discrete Cosine Transform Engines on a Many-Core Platform
authors: Michael Wang, Bevan M. Baas
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: The discrete cosine transform (DCT) and inverse discrete cosine transform (IDCT) are crucial components in many digital signal processing applications. In particular, they are often an important step in image processing and multimedia applications such as lossy compression algorithms due to their ability to isolate key signal information. Real-time signal processing is used in all manner of devices, where high throughput, energyefficient, and area-efficient implementations of the discrete cosine transform are a necessity. This work presents scalable software C++ discrete cosine transform designs developed for a fine-grain many-core platform, demonstrated using the programmable 32 nm KiloCore chip. These designs are compared with the Nvidia Tesla T4 (GPU), Nvidia GT-720M (GPU), and Intel i5-4200M (general purpose). Results for all devices are scaled to 32 nm CMOS for fair comparison. The KiloCore designs achieve <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$140 \times, 740 \times$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1670 \times$</tex> higher throughput per chip area compared to the commercial devices. KiloCore also achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$74 \times, 79 \times$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5470 \times$</tex> lower energy dissipation per transform than the others. Combining both energy and throughput metrics, KiloCore achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0 9 0} \times, \mathbf{1 5, 1 0 0} \times$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2, 5 4 0, 0 0 0} \times$</tex> lower energy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times$</tex> delay product normalized to chip area than the three commercial chips.

title: Enhancing Doping Concentration Uniformity and Batch Repeatability in 4H-SiC Homoepitaxy via Ammonia Doping
authors: Xie Tianle, Liu Zhu, Wan Shengqiang, Deng Jiale, Yang Yu, Li Ping, Li Kun, Hu Fan, Gong Xiaoliang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In the homoepitaxial growth of $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$, nitrogen gas $\left(\mathrm{N}_{2}\right)$, commonly used as an n-type dopant source, presents significant limitations. Residual nitrogen from a previous epitaxial growth run can lead to an uncontrolled increase in the average doping concentration of subsequent epitaxial wafers, adversely affecting the doping concentration stability during run-to-run growth. Furthermore, the disparity in doping concentration increase between the edge and center of the epitaxial wafer hinders the regulation of doping uniformity during growth, resulting in poor within-wafer doping concentration uniformity. To maintain yield during mass production of continuous multi-batch epitaxial wafers, frequent fine-tuning of the dopant flow rate based on data from prior runs becomes necessary, significantly reducing equipment productivity and automation levels. To address these challenges, this study systematically investigates the doping mechanisms of nitrogen and ammonia by analyzing the structural configuration of the epitaxial growth reactor and the distinct doping characteristics of the two sources. A 0.4 vol. $\% \mathrm{NH}_{3} / \mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas mixture is proposed as an alternative dopant to replace N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. Meanwhile, the gas delivery system for ammonia-based doping is further optimized, which significantly improves the within-wafer doping concentration uniformity of SiC epitaxial wafers from over 2.5% to below 1.5%, and optimizes the wafer-to-wafer stability across 15 consecutive runs from 5% to within 1.5%.

title: Optimization of Green Certificate-Carbon Trading Integrated Energy System Considering Multidimensional Time Granularity Differences
authors: Rui Zhao, Xiaoqing Han, Tingjun Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: To achieve the strategic goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, China has established a multi-energy market system centered on electricity, carbon, and green certificate markets. However, significant temporal scale differences exist among the three markets: the electricity market operates primarily on hourly trading, the carbon market adopts monthly settlements, and the green certificate market implements annual compliance, creating severe challenges for coordinated optimization decisions of power generation enterprises due to temporal granularity mismatches. A multi-temporal-scale market optimization model for integrated energy systems incorporating P2G and CCS technologies is developed in this paper. First, a three-tier nested architecture covering annual-monthly-daily periods is established, through which coupled analysis of electricity-carbon-green certificate markets is achieved via a two-stage generator decision-making process. Second, an information transfer mechanism across temporal scales is designed, effectively solving the temporal granularity mismatch problem among different markets. Finally, a rolling correction optimization framework is constructed, realizing coordination between long-term planning and short-term scheduling. Based on the annual-monthly nested optimization architecture, coupled analysis of the three markets across medium-to-long-term and short-term temporal dimensions is achieved, effectively enhancing both economic efficiency and environmental performance of system operations. Optimization results demonstrate that, compared with single temporal scale optimization, the multi-temporal-scale optimization increases renewable energy generation proportion by 21.1 %, reduces annual total costs by 12.1 %, and decreases carbon emissions by 7.2 %, validating the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Low-Barrier Dataset Collection With Real Human Body for Interactive Per-Garment Virtual Try-On
authors: Zaiqiang Wu, Yechen Li, Jingyuan Liu, Yuki Shibata, Takayuki Hori, I-Chao Shen, Takeo Igarashi
publish: IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications
abstract: Existing image-based virtual try-on methods are limited to frontal views and lack real-time performance. While per-garment virtual try-on methods have tackled these issues by adopting per-garment training, they still encounter practical limitations: (1) the robotic mannequin used for per-garment datasets collection is prohibitively expensive; (2) the synthesized garments often misalign with the human body. To address these challenges, we propose a low-barrier approach to collect per-garment datasets using real human bodies, eliminating the need for an expensive robotic mannequin and reducing data collection time from 2 hours to 2 minutes. Additionally, we introduce a hybrid person representation that ensures precise human-garment alignment. We conducted qualitative and quantitative comparisons with state-of-the-art image-based virtual try-on methods to demonstrate the superiority of our method regarding image quality and temporal consistency. Furthermore, most participants in our user study found the system effective in supporting garment purchasing decisions.

title: Estimating Workload for Supervisory Human–Robot Teams: An Initial Analysis of Meta-Learning
authors: Joshua Bhagat Smith, Julie A. Adams
publish: IEEE Transactions on Human-Machine Systems
abstract: A robust understanding of a human's internal state can greatly improve human–robot teaming, as estimating the human teammates' workload can inform more dynamic robot adaptations. Existing workload estimation methods use standard machine learning techniques to model the relationships between physiological metrics and workload. However, such methods are not sufficient for adaptive systems, as standard machine learning techniques struggle to make accurate workload estimates when the human–robot team performs unknown tasks. A meta-learning-based workload estimation algorithm is introduced and an initial analysis is conducted to show how adapting a machine learning model's parameters using task-specific information can improve result in more accurate workload estimates for unknown tasks.

title: Human-LLM Collaboration Framework for Translating Health Instruments_supp1-3649657.docx
authors: Hind Bitar
publish: N/A
abstract: Large language models have revolutionized various sectors, including education and healthcare, by demonstrating significant advancements in producing human-like text and enhancing translation accuracy. Despite these advancements, the conventional process of cross-cultural instrument translation remains labor-intensive, expensive, and heavily dependent on the expertise of human professionals, including translators and healthcare specialists. The objective of this study is to address the translation challenges in health-related instruments. This study introduces a Human and Large Language Models Collaboration Framework, called H-LLMCF, designed to automate the key steps of instrument translation while maintaining linguistic precision and cultural appropriateness. The proposed framework integrates human expertise and LLM capabilities across two phases: AI-guided translation and human-guided evaluation and refinement. When applied to the translation of two validated instruments in the health sector from English to Arabic, the framework demonstrated promising outcomes. The proposed framework achieved BLEU scores of ~0.54 and ~66 for the two instruments. SBERT-based cosine similarity exceeded 0.85 for 80% of items, with a mean of ~0.92 and ~0.96, indicating strong semantic alignment with human translations. Human evaluation of the 35-item HPV Knowledge Assessment instrument yielded an average I-CVI of 1.00, with 91.42% of items rated as fully acceptable by both reviewers. For the KIDMED instrument, out of 16 items, 15 (93.75%) received a rating of 3 from both reviewers, resulting in an I-CVI of 1.00 for those items. Most discrepancies were linked to translation and fluency adaptation. This highlights the potential of LLMs to enhance cross-cultural translation processes while maintaining translation quality.

title: Real-time Operation of Electric Autonomous Mobility-on-Demand System Considering Power System Regulation
authors: Lyuzhu Pan, Hongcai Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid
abstract: Electric autonomous mobility-on-demand (EAMoD) systems are emerging all over the world. However, their potential swarm charging in depots may deteriorate operation of the power system, further in turn affecting EAMoD system’s optimal operation. To prevent this latent risk, we develop a real-time coordination framework for the EAMoD system and the power system. First, the temporal-spatial characteristics of EAMoD fleets are fully described based on a Markov decision process model, including serving trips, repositioning, and charging. Second, charger accessibility of EAMoD depot charging is well modeled as real-world configuration, wherein fast and slow charge piles are both included. Third, the power system regulation model provides real-time charging regulation constraints for EAMoD systems to prevent potential overload and undervoltage. To address the poor solution quality attributed to the complex decision space of the EAMoD system, this paper proposes a piecewise linear-based approximate dynamic programming algorithm combined with model predictive control. Numerical experiments in the Manhattan and a 14-node power distribution network validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm and underscore the necessity of system coordination.

title: 3D High-quality Power Doppler Using Coherence-based Null Subtraction Imaging_supp2-3649288.mp4
authors: Jianwen Luo
publish: N/A
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) power Doppler (PD) imaging enables visualization of volumetric microvasculature networks. However, 3D ultrafast PD imaging with matrix arrays suffers from limited resolution due to the restricted aperture size and the use of unfocused plane waves, while delay-and-sum (DAS) exhibits high sidelobe levels and broad main lobes, hindering high-quality PD imaging. In this study, we aim to improve the 3D null subtraction imaging (NSI) and propose coherence-based NSI beamformers including NSI based on coherence factor (NSI-CF) and NSI based on spatial and angular coherence factor (NSI-SACF). Specifically, NSI-SACF integrates the high-resolution capability of NSI and the high-contrast performance of spatial and angular coherence factor (SACF). The proposed beamformers are validated through simulations, phantom experiments, and in vivo experiments. Qualitative and quantitative evaluations confirm the superiority of NSI-SACF. In the simulations, NSI-SACF achieves a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 0.059 mm compared with 0.391 mm for DAS and 0.225 mm for SACF. NSI-SACF also reduces the sidelobe level by 75.5 dB and 33.6 dB compared with DAS and SACF respectively, while effectively suppressing grating lobes. In the in vivo experiments, NSI-SACF improves the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) of blood flow by 20.03 dB and 8.65 dB over DAS and SACF, respectively. Furthermore, the FWHM of the vessel is reduced to 0.098 mm with NSI-SACF, compared with 0.326 mm for DAS and 0.159 mm for SACF. In summary, the proposed NSI-SACF beamformer effectively enhances the PD imaging by simultaneously improving spatial resolution and contrast, demonstrating the potential for clinical applications.

title: Evaluating Safety Benefits of Ramp Metering by Leveraging Connected Vehicle Data: Case Study of Indiana Roadways
authors: Jairaj Desai, Christopher Gartner, Rahul Suryakant Sakhare, Edward D. Cox, Darcy M. Bullock
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Traditionally, crash data, crash risk models, video recordings and user surveys have been utilized by agencies to measure the safety benefits of ramp metering technology. Connected vehicle data can now provide an agile evaluation alternative for quantifying impact of ramp meter deployments. Furthermore, in contrast to crash data, connected vehicle near miss events occur much more frequently, so the before-after evaluation can be conducted over a much shorter time period consisting of a few months, or perhaps even a few weeks. Indiana deployed ramp meters on the southeast section of I-465 around Indianapolis, on or around May 14, 2024, which were then active primarily during the morning and evening peak hours. Hard-braking events, a surrogate safety performance measure, were estimated from high-frequency connected vehicle data available at 3-second fidelity for vehicles passing through the metered ramps and the adjacent mainline interstate. A before-after analysis for the 4-5 PM peak hour showed approximately a 61% reduction in hard-braking events on mainline merge areas adjoining the metered ramps on the inner loop of I-465. Spatial analysis also showed a 70%, 41% and 33% median reduction in mild, moderate and severe hard-braking events per 0.1-mile segment in the entire 7.5-mile mainline corridor adjacent to metered ramps. The methodologies and performance measures provided in this paper demonstrate how connected vehicle data scales well to systematically assess and document the performance of new ramp metering deployments.

title: Performance Bound for Online Scalable Video Coding and Scalable Semantic Coding
authors: Weijia Han, Xiaoyu Zhang, Bizheng Luo, Wei Teng, Xiao Ma, Chuan Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Recently, scalable video coding (SVC) and scalable semantic coding (SSC) have emerged as effective solutions for supporting online video streaming in applications such as remote cockpits and telemedicine. Although the significance of SVC and SSC is well established, the underlying principles related to their performance bounds have not been thoroughly investigated. To address this issue, we study the performance bounds for online SVC/SSC in this paper. Initially, to evaluate coding performance, we propose a new metric referred to as effective coding gain (ECG), which jointly considers the entropy of the source data and the mutual information between the source and the encoded video data. Next, from the perspective of information theory, we derive a closed-form expression for the ECG bound while accounting for the impacts of diverse SVC/SSC coding structures. Our results not only ensure that the performance bounds can be efficiently evaluated but also provide valuable insights for resource allocation, cost optimization, performance evaluation and comparison, as well as for understanding the optimization space of existing systems.

title: BIELM: Integrating Incremental Extreme Learning Machine and Blockchain for Secure Data Gathering in IoT-based WSNs
authors: P V Pravija Raj, Pranav M. Pawar, Raja Muthalagu, Ashish Gupta
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is advancing at a rapid pace with Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) and is becoming integral for real-time monitoring and data-driven decision-making in different sectors. Emerging real-world applications are greatly reliant on IoT-based WSNs to improve productivity and operational efficiency. However, WSNs encounter significant challenges in handling substantial data amounts and maintaining robust security requirements. These networks are prone to many security risks that may compromise network operation and data integrity. This paper proposes a novel technique by integrating Blockchain and Incremental Extreme Learning Machine (abbreviated as BIELM) to effectively detect such malicious nodes in WSNs and ensure secure data collection. BIELM utilizes an interplanetary file system for efficient data storage and blockchain to record hashes and provide secure data access. This work also introduces an effective feature selection method by modifying the Sparrow search optimization and the edited nearest neighbor for data balancing with a combination of a standard oversampling technique (SMOTE). The experimental results reveal an accuracy of 99.38%, demonstrating the superior performance of BIELM in detecting malicious nodes, with an average cost saving of approximately 22.72% in blockchain transaction costs across key operations compared to conventional blockchain-based methods, revealing its overall efficiency over existing methods.

title: Secrecy Performance of Energy Harvesting Cooperative Network With Power Control
authors: Amit Patel, Shankar Prakriya
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: In this paper, we analyze the secrecy performance of a two-hop cooperative network consisting solely of energy-harvesting (EH) self-sustaining nodes drawing energy from a multi-antenna power beacon (PB). The performance of such networks is quite different from that of powered nodes. For improved performance, we consider the optimal combining of the direct and relayed signals at the multi-antenna destination as well as the multi-antenna eavesdropper. Due to massive deployment of machine-type communication nodes, the availability of channel state information at the source is impractical in such networks, we assume fixed-rate signaling. To implement incremental signaling, we utilize feedback bits from the destination. Assuming practical nonlinear EH, approximate expressions are derived for the secrecy outage probability of the selective decode-and-forward (SDF) and the incremental decode-and-forward (IDF) relaying schemes. It is demonstrated that IDF has much better secrecy performance than SDF, just as with powered nodes. However, unlike with powered nodes, the secrecy performance is a convex function of the transmit power of PB. We propose a novel power back-off scheme to improve secrecy under different network operating conditions. The security-reliability trade-off is analyzed to highlight the trade-off between outage and secrecy performance with the power back-off scheme. Simulation results validate the analytical expressions.

title: Contactless Fault Diagnosis Technique by Magnetic Field Image Recognition for Lithium Battery
authors: Wenchao Miao, Qiqi Chen, Keyu Duan, Xuecheng Sun, Yunpeng Zhang, King Hang Lam, Philip W.T. Pong
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Model-based, signal analysis-based, and data-driven methods are commonly employed for fault detection in lithium-ion batteries. However, these approaches are often limited by their reliance on accurate parameter identification, threshold-setting issues, and the need for large-scale, high-quality data. In recent years, there has been increasing interest in active measurement techniques utilizing sensors for the fault diagnosis of lithium-ion batteries. Among these, magnetic-field sensing presents a contactless solution for fault diagnosis. This paper proposes an innovative intelligent magnetic-field sensing technique based on Tunnel Magnetoresistive (TMR) sensors and magnetic-field image recognition for the effective and low-cost fault diagnosis of lithium-ion batteries. First, the electrochemical and magnetic characteristics of lithium-ion batteries are investigated to establish the underlying principles of magnetic field variation and to model the battery. A TMR sensor is employed to measure the magnetic field of lithium-ion batteries under various conditions, and magnetic field distribution patterns and image features are subsequently identified. A contactless fault diagnosis system is then developed using the convolutional neural network algorithm and a Raspberry Pi 5. The proposed system is demonstrated to reliably diagnose the healthy, aging, anomalies, and swelling of batteries, offering a promising solution for production quality inspection and recycling of lithium batteries.

title: Development of Portable TMS-MEP Device for Emergency Medicine
authors: Zhaohuan Ding, Jinbei Tang, Tao Liu, Heng Gu, Gaoxiang Ouyang, He Chen, Xiaoli Li
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This study presents the development of a portable Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation-Motor Evoked Potential (TMS-MEP) system for emergency medicine, addressing the bulkiness and mains power dependency of conventional devices. The system integrates a battery-powered TMS module with a wearable MEP detector, with a total weight of <3.5 kg. The TMS module utilizes a push-pull converter topology to generate a 720 V DC source from a 12 V lithium battery, coupled with a resonant circuit that produces transient currents exceeding 2000 A in a figure-8 coil. The MEP module employs a 361.7 Hz low-pass filter and a 24-bit analog front-end to suppress electromagnetic artifacts and maintains a resolution of 0.08 μV/bit. Experimental results demonstrated a linear magnetic field output (0.38-0.77 T) at ≥ 50% intensity with <1% residual error. MEP recordings from the first dorsal interosseous muscle in five healthy subjects showed amplitudes surpassing the 50 μV threshold (range: 75.2-283.3 μV). While the system's magnetic field intensity limits high-intensity paradigms, its portability enables deployment in emergency settings. Future integration of high-energy-density capacitors may reduce the performance gap with conventional systems.
