title: A Two-Stage Framework for Power System Resilience Assessment: Process Design and a Case Study in Kinmen
authors: Y. H. Wu, Y. F. Wang, C. H. Cho, H. H. Hsieh, C. J. Liao, H. H. Tseng, T. L. Yang, Y. J. Hsieh
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This study presents a two-stage framework to assess the resilience of power systems along practical decarbonization pathways against high-impact, low-frequency (HILF) events. The first stage employs integrated resource planning and simulations to design cost-optimal decarbonization pathways. The second stage then conducts a detailed resilience analysis, considering factors like equipment damage probability and system-wide impacts, which are quantified using generalized metrics. A case study on the Kinmen region, targeting a 2030 carbon intensity of 0.4 kg CO2e/kWh, examines system resilience against tsunamis. Results indicate that achieving the target requires substantial deployment of solar PV and energy storage to increase renewable energy (RE) penetration and reduce reliance on thermal generation. Findings reveal that decentralized BESS with grid-forming capabilities are critical for system resilience. Moreover, the proposed generalized metrics uniquely capture bidirectional frequency deviations, offering a more effective assessment tool and actionable insights for planners.

title: Early-Exit Neural Architecture Search for Energy-Harvesting Edge Computing
authors: Pierre-Louis Sixdenier, Mark Deutel, Jürgen Teich
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Energy harvesting (EH) is increasingly used in wireless sensor nodes to extend the lifetime of battery-powered devices in remote locations. On such devices, the use of deep neural networks (DNNs) is limited not only by the memory and computational constraints of the system, but also by the often large amount of energy required to perform DNN inference. As a result, continuous DNN inference cannot be guaranteed on such systems, especially under severe power constraints resulting from small battery capacities and solar panel sizes. A promising approach to dynamically adjust the power consumption of DNN inference are early-exit neural networks (EE-NNs), that allow a DNN to exit early at different points during its inference. In this paper, we propose a simulation-aided neural architecture search framework to explore EE-DNN architectures (EENAS) and an online energy manager (EM) that dynamically decides which early exit to take based on the available energy and the EE-NN's confidence in its predictions while ensuring energyneutral operation (ENO). We evaluate our approach on four vision datasets and show not only that our EENAS approach can find EE-NNs with low energy consumption that maintain a high accuracy, but also that our proposed EM can execute the explored EE-NNs with an up to 36 % improved accuracy compared to the state-of-the-art while satisfying the ENO constraints.

title: Twitter recommendations across dialects: Seeing the big board through Faiss
authors: John Sigurd Hammer, Konstantinos Theodoropoulos, Georgios Drakopoulos, Georgios Bardis, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Twitter account recommendations rely on a broad spectrum of factors including language, which influences all spheres of social life. Most notably, virtually every action of informal human communication online is almost exclusively actualized by language. As it largely remains the main stage upon which such communicative acts unfold freely, language is subject to a myriad of minor changes eventually accumulating to discernible patterns indicating lexical, syntactic, or semantic changes giving rise to dialects. Since often they are readable by speakers of the original language, it is statutory to ask whether recommendations can be made based across dialects and, if so, whether it can be deployed on a scalable back end infrastructure. Two use cases using Faiss for storage and Go as the implementation language yield encouraging results.

title: MambaGuard: A Hybrid Framework for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in IIoT Networks
authors: Feng Xiong, Aniket Mahanti, Ni Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) systems face cybersecurity threats that require anomaly detection mechanisms capable of processing long-range temporal dependencies in multivariate time series data. Existing deep learning approaches are lack of efficiency, generative modeling, and adversarial training for industrial environments. While recent advances have introduced state space models like Mamba for various applications, their integration with generative adversarial training for IIoT security remains unexplored. To address these challenges, we propose MambaGuard, a hybrid architecture that combines Mamba state space models, variational autoencoders (VAEs) and generative adversarial networks (GANs) for unsupervised anomaly detection in IIoT environments. Our method uses Mamba’s selective state space mechanism for long-sequence modeling, VAE’s probabilistic framework for latent representations, and GAN’s adversarial training for improved discrimination. The key contribution is the feature-space reconstruction approach that allows all components to work together effectively. We also introduce automated hyperparameter optimization using Bayesian optimization with hyperBand (BOHB) to eliminate manual tuning requirements. Experimental results on four datasets (UNSW-NB15, ToN-IoT, Bot-IoT, and CICIDS2018) demonstrate improvements over existing methods, showing good performance across different network environments and anomaly rates while maintaining efficiency for real-time deployment.

title: Reviving Fine Details in Historical Photographs Using A-ESRGAN: An AI Framework for Digital Heritage
authors: Yvonne C. Jegede, Temitope D. Jegede, Atef Mohamed Shalan
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Restoring degraded historical photographs poses challenges, including loss of fine-grained detail, limited model transparency, and inadequate evaluation frameworks. This study presents an enhanced deep learning pipeline, Attention-Enhanced Super-Resolution Generative Adversarial Networks (A-ESRGAN), to address these gaps. By integrating attention mechanisms into the RRDBNet generator within the Real-ESRGAN framework, the model focuses on semantically meaningful regions, such as facial features, inscriptions, and textures, thereby improving perceptual and structural fidelity. We synthetically degraded the curated public-domain dataset with Gaussian blur and JPEG compression to mimic real-world conditions. We evaluated the model on paired low- and high-resolution images using PSNR and frequency-spectrum analysis. Results show that A-ESRGAN enhances PSNR and restores high-frequency details critical for visual clarity and historical interpretation. This research offers a scalable, interpretable framework for ethical and transparent AI-driven digital heritage restoration.

title: Cost-Sensitive Learning for HER2-Positive Breast Cancer Diagnosis Using Clinical Data: A Resourceconscious Framework for Low-Resource Settings
authors: Hoda Waguih
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Breast cancer remains the most prevalent cancer type among women globally, contributing to high mortality and substantial economic and social costs. HER2-positive (HER2+), accounting for 15-20% of cases, represents an aggressive subtype that worsens prognosis without timely treatment. Although HER2-targeted therapies like trastuzumab have improved survival, early diagnosis remains challenging in developing countries due to limited diagnostic infrastructure and high testing costs. This study investigates a cost-sensitive learning (CSL) framework leveraging routinely collected clinical features from the METABRIC dataset to support HER2+ classification in resourceconstrained settings. After data preprocessing and SMOTEbased class balancing, three CSL models-Decision Tree, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and XGBoost-were trained and evaluated. Despite these adaptations, all models struggled to achieve clinically meaningful performance. SVM attained perfect recall (1.00) but extremely low precision (0.12), misclassifying nearly all HER2- cases. XGBoost offered better precision (0.30) but low recall (0.09), while Decision Tree showed modest balance across metrics. These results underscore the difficulty of detecting minority class instances using routine clinical features alone, even with advanced imbalance-handling strategies. CSL, while valuable, cannot fully compensate for limited feature separability. Enhancing diagnostic reliability may require integration of more discriminative yet cost-conscious and interpretable data sources, such as histopathological or molecular inputs. Nonetheless, this study provides empirical insight into the limitations and opportunities of deploying interpretable, resource-aware diagnostic frameworks in constrained healthcare environments.

title: Global Offshore Active Oil and Gas Platform Extraction Based on High Spatial Resolution Nighttime Light Remote Sensing Data from SDGSAT-1 GLI
authors: Lin Yan, Zhongzhong Chen, Yujia Qiu, Xiao-Ming Li, Changyong Dou, Longhai Xiong
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper presents an automated algorithm for extracting global offshore active oil and gas platforms, leveraging the characteristics of these platforms, namely their fixed positions and continuous illumination, in conjunction with high spatial resolution nighttime light remote sensing data from the SDGSAT1/GLI. A total of 1,582 offshore active oil and gas platforms were identified, with 341, 182, 765, 233, and 61 platforms located in the Northern Gulf of Mexico, the North Sea, the Persian Gulf, the Gulf of Guinea, and the Gulf of Thailand, respectively. Multiple datasets, including industry investigation datasets (Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE), the Oslo and Paris Commissions (OSPAR)), remote sensing data (Landsat 8 OLI (manual check) and the Sentinel 2 MSI), and remote sensing data products (VIIRS Night-Fire), were adopted to validate the extracted offshore active oil and gas platforms using SDGSAT1/GLI with an overall precision rate of 93.48 %. The results demonstrate the high-resolution SDGSAT-1/GLI's capability to detect offshore active oil and gas platforms effectively. Utilizing high-resolution SDGSAT-1/GLI nighttime light remote sensing data for the extraction of active oil and gas platforms can provide more comprehensive and accurate data support for monitoring marine carbon emissions.

title: Dynamic Fuzzing-Based Whole-System Timing Analysis
authors: Alwin Berger, Simon Schuster, Peter Wägemann, Peter Ulbrich
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Worst-case timing analysis traditionally begins with estimating the worst-case execution time (WCET) of individual tasks using either static analysis or measurement-based techniques. To derive worst-case response times (WCRTs), engineers typically compose these WCETs with bounds on preemption and operating system overheads. However, WCRTs depend on complex system-level interactions, including task communication, OS behavior, and asynchronous events. Compositional analysis often overestimates, assuming that worst-case conditions across components coincide, admitting infeasible global control-flow paths. whole-system Static techniques refine this by modeling the system holistically but require platform-specific tailoring or extensive annotations. A dynamic equivalent has been missing. We present Fret, the first dynamic whole-system approach for estimating WCRTs. Fret employs feedback-guided fuzzing to uncover timing-critical dependencies, including inter-task communication, task/OS interactions, and interrupt effects, without requiring prior knowledge of inputs or states. Implemented using LibAFL and evaluated on FreeRTOS with realistic benchmarks, FRET consistently outperforms state-of-the-art fuzzing strategies in estimating accurate response times. Although not sound, Fret delivers more than timing estimates: it produces actionable artifacts-worst-case inputs, interrupt schedules, and intertask program-flow information-that complement static analyses and support system validation, runtime monitoring, and robust mixed-criticality scheduling.

title: Tank Level Control Using Lora and PLC
authors: Suji Prasad.S.J, C.M. Iniyan, E.M. Barath, GM. Thangatamilan, R. Gayathri, M. Apoorva
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Effective water level monitoring is vital in agriculture, utilities, and industry, where conventional methods are often labor-intensive and costly, especially in remote areas. This project introduces an automated water tank management system integrating a Differential Pressure Transmitter (DPT), LoRa communication, Siemens IoT 2040 gateway, PLC, SCADA, and cloud connectivity. The DPT ensures precise level measurement, while LoRa enables reliable long-range data transfer to the Ubidots platform for real-time monitoring. PLC-based pump control prevents overflow and dry-run conditions, with SCADA providing centralized supervision, historical logging, and improved decision-making. A mobile application supports remote monitoring, alerts, and manual operation. The system is scalable, energy-efficient, cost-effective, and reduces manual effort, promoting sustainable water management.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Heart Pulse Detection Sensors Using Statistical Analysis and Bland-Altman Method
authors: Amy Fedora F, Santhoshi S, Manimozhi M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This study presents an analysis of three sensors KY-039, Murata 7BB- 15-6LO and an MAX30102 for detecting the pulse rate. Performance evaluation was carried out using Bland-Altman and linear regression methods are used to determine the accuracy and correlation. Data was collected from 60 individuals aged between 18 and 25, with each sensor's output being validated by the readings from pulse oximeter. This gives us the variations in measurement consistency and signal quality across the sensors. This analysis provides information for selecting appropriate sensors in health monitoring applications. Additionally, this study addresses a key limitation in the existing literature by presenting a comparative analysis of three distinct types of pulse detection sensors MAX30102, KY-039, and Murata 7BB-15-6LO under uniform experimental conditions, benchmarked against a clinically validated pulse oximeter. While prior studies have independently evaluated the MAX30102 and KY-039, or compared them in limited scenarios, few have incorporated a mechanical-mode piezoelectric sensor such as Murata's 7BB-15- 6LO into a direct comparison with optical sensors. The novelty of this work lies in its multimodal approach, where optical and pressure-based sensing modalities are evaluated together using standardized testing. Additionally, this study enhances methodological rigor by employing both Bland- Altman plots and a suite of statistical performance metrics, including MSE, RMSE, MAE, coefficient of determination <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}\right)$</tex>, and correlation coefficient. These comprehensive metrics allow for a detailed performance characterization, surpassing many earlier comparative works that relied only on correlation or visual agreement. The result is a holistic framework that informs sensor selection in both research and real-world biomedical applications, especially in lowcost or embedded monitoring systems.

title: Optimization and Non-Destructive Examination of High-Speed Computational Technique for Talent Identification in Sports
authors: Maithili Kamalakannan, Pingili Venkataramana, Vudula Shalini, Saniya Firdous, Nagarjuna Reddy, Ilansezhiyan Iyyanar
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Talent identification in sports is a critical yet often subjective process, traditionally relying on fragmented tools such as Wyscout, Hudl, and Opta, which separately handle video footage, performance metrics, or physiological data. This paper proposes an AI-driven, high-speed computational framework that unifies video analysis, biomechanical evaluation, and predictive analytics into a single holistic platform. The system integrates YOLO for player and object detection, 3D-CNNs for spatio-temporal action recognition, RNNs for sequence modeling, and XGBoost for structured performance prediction. Data flows seamlessly from raw match/training footage and wearable sensors through a multi-stage processing pipeline, producing real-time player rankings and visual analytics for scouts and coaches. Hypothetical validation on a mixed dataset of cricket players indicates classification accuracy of 94%, action recognition F1-score of 0.91, and prediction latency under 0.8 seconds. This unified approach overcomes fragmentation in current platforms, providing objective, scalable, and instantaneous talent evaluation across multiple sports.

title: A Zone-Based LoRa Deployment for Agriculture Area Monitoring
authors: El Hadji Malick Ndoye, Ousmane Diallo, Malaw Ndiaye, Mohamed El Kamili
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Recent technological advances have opened up new possibilities in the field of wireless sensor networks. One such advancement is LoRa (Long Range) technology, which enables long-range transmission of data with reduced power consumption. The deployment of LoRa devices is a very important issue in the case of large-scale networks. Indeed, the various Spreading Factors (SF) can be sources of interference that significantly impact the performances of a LoRa network. One of the most well-known deployment techniques in LoRa networks is circular deployment around the gateway. LoRa nodes are deployed in circular bands and are assigned spreading factors based on their distance from the gateway. This type of deployment, while interesting, has its limitations when the network scales up. Indeed, in this case, Co -SF interference can severely impact network performance. The main objective of this paper is to find an efficient and optimal deployment of LoRa nodes in a large multi-agricultural area. It follows the same principle of SF allocation as in the case of circular deployment. The major innovation is the division of the area into vertical zones corresponding to crops. Thus, depending on the monitoring requirements of each crop area, LoRa nodes can be activated periodically and independently..

title: Web Automation Testing in Industry: Lifecycle, Framework Challenges, and the Future with AI
authors: Kuldeep Singh, Shweta Rani, Sandeep Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: In rapid development cycles driven by Agile, web testing has become more and more important in guaranteeing software dependability and user satisfaction. A popular open-source automation tool for facilitating user interface testing in business settings is Selenium WebDriver. However, creating and maintaining reliable WebDriver test scripts often presents substantial organizational, process, and technical difficulties. The life cycle of creating WebDriver UI test scripts is thoroughly examined in this paper, along with the related frameworks, tools, and integration techniques in enterprise CI/CD pipelines. This paper also explores how scalability and stability concerns affect the efficacy of UI testing in enterprise Agile environments. This work presents empirical results from a financial case study and identifies persistent issues with the scalability and stability of test scripts. We also assess how Artificial Intelligence (AI) can be beneficial in creating and maintaining test scripts and other future scopes of AI in software testing. We emphasize the importance of organized frameworks, committed quality control procedures, and intelligent automation.

title: Enhancing Predictive Maintenance via Multi-Model Integration for Industrial Fault Detection
authors: Yinuo Cao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This investigation addresses the critical challenges associated with equipment fault detection within industrial production processes. The primary objective is to enhance the Recall and efficiency of fault detection models by employing techniques involving multi-model integration and feature engineering. Initially, the study examines the performance of various machine learning models, including Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), particularly in managing high-dimensional data and capturing nonlinear relationships. Subsequent research efforts focus on improving the overall efficacy of fault detection through feature enhancement of multi-class prediction probabilities and the implementation of multi-model integration strategies. The results indicate that employing a Stacking model significantly enhances Precision by 22.29% and Recall by 3.03% when utilizing a newly devised training dataset inclusive of multi-class prediction probabilities from XGBoost, thereby demonstrating a substantial improvement in predictive performance. This approach illustrates economic viability in reducing prediction costs, especially in practical applications where the advantage is more pronounced as the false negative-to-false positive ratio escalates. The contribution of this research is the integration of multi-class prediction probabilities with model integration strategies, offering a novel and cost-effective solution for fault detection and providing innovative perspectives for future research endeavors.

title: Energy Management Strategy for Common Spaces in High Rise Buildings Considering Optimized Solar PV Output
authors: Jia Yun Lian, Nurulafiqah Nadzirah Binti Mansor, Aiman Muqri Bin Mohamad Sukri, Rizki Mendung Ariefianto, Hazlie Bin Mokhlis, Mohammad Sameer Ahmad
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This study presents the design, simulation, and optimization of a hybrid grid-connected solar photovoltaic (PV) system integrated with battery energy storage to provide reliable and sustainable energy for common spaces in high-rise residential buildings. The solar PV system was modelled using Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) with optimized tilt and azimuth angles to maximize the PV power output under varying irradiance and temperature conditions. The battery energy storage system was evaluated for charging and discharging performance within a safe state-of-charge (SOC) range of 20% to 80%. Grid integration was achieved through droop control to enable decentralized power sharing. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) was employed to optimize energy flow management, prioritizing renewable energy utilization, and leveraging time-of-use tariffs to minimize the grid's imported power and costs. Results demonstrate enhanced energy efficiency, reduced grid dependency, and a cost-effective, reliable power delivery solution tailored to urban residential energy demands.

title: Research on Adaptive Dynamic Window Algorithm for Path Planning of Medical Delivery Robots
authors: Yuqian Meng, Menglong Cao, Ming Cao, Qiaoyan Sun
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: To address the issues of poor real-time path planning and insufficient obstacle avoidance capability in medical delivery robots in complex hospital environments, an adaptive DWA algorithm is proposed. By introducing a dynamic speed adjustment model, the robot can adjust its motion speed based on environmental changes, improving the responsiveness of path planning. By considering obstacle size and adding dynamic obstacle prediction functionality, the robot can adjust its path in real-time to cope with moving obstacles. An adaptive weight adjustment strategy based on obstacle distance is adopted to increase the flexibility of path planning in different environments. Simulation results show that the improved algorithm significantly enhances path planning efficiency, obstacle avoidance success rate, and other aspects, demonstrating strong practicality.

title: A Fault Location Method for Distribution Networks Based on Compressed Sensing Technology
authors: Yipeng Xie, Xiaoxi Yang, Qian Zhao, Yan Shen, Yaoxu Bai, Jing Bian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: To address the challenge of fault location in complex distribution networks, this paper proposes a fault location method based on compressive sensing technology. The node voltage of the distribution network is selected as the characteristic quantity for fault localization. Leveraging the advantages of compressive sensing, sparse sampling of nodal fault voltages is performed in multi-branch distribution networks. A node voltage equation is established at the measurement points, and the fault location is determined by reconstructing the nodal fault current. A 33-node complex distribution network model is built in PSCAD to validate the accuracy of the proposed method.

title: Detecting Earth-Hazardous Asteroids Using Graph Sample and Aggregate Algorithm
authors: Venkata Naga Ganesh Jujhavarapu, Allu Pranav Srihas, Subramaniyaswamy Vairavasundaram, K Ragavan
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The asteroid classification is crucial because they may threaten living organisms on Earth. This research helps in identifying near-Earth asteroids (NEAs) as hazardous or non-hazardous. So, by taking advantage of current modern technology, Advanced Artificial Intelligence (AI) models have been explored and compared such as Self-Attention and Intersample Attention Transformer (SAINT), Graph Sample and Aggregate (GraphSAGE), Tabular Neural Networks (TabNet), Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs), Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT), and Simple Contrastive Learning Representation (SIMCLR), are utilized. The dataset was taken from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) and contains more than 4000 samples. The features include magnitude and perihelion distances. Finally, the GraphSAGE architecture achieved the highest accuracy, and the key findings were beneficial for the early detection of Earth-hazardous asteroids, which aids in a better understanding of the attributes. Furthermore, astronomers will gain a better understanding of asteroids and greatly contribute to society.

title: IoT- Based Rural Animal Monitoring and Theft Prevention System
authors: Sowmiya P, Sujitra R, Srinidhi M R, Bhuvana B P, Yokesh V
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The proposed project addresses the issue of smart livestock management and anti-theft system to be implemented in rural farming communities, where farmers cannot usually constantly supervise animals because of large grazing lands, insufficient workforce, and anti-theft. This system is a combination of motion detection, GPS tracking and timely communication to achieve instant alerts when suspicious acts happen. An Arduino microcontroller is used as the central device, and controls a Passive Infrared (PIR) sensor to identify abnormal motion, GPS module to get accurate location of the animal and GSM module to relay SMS alerts to farmers. The coordinates through the GPS are instantly transmitted through GSM when motion is detected; this allows a prompt action to be taken even whenever one is in another place. It has an LCD display for on-site indications of motion status, location information and system diagnostics to ensure monitoring in low mobile network circumstances. The system is built to suit the rural environment and is economically, electrically and environmentally sustainable in terms of cost, energy usage and the potential to work off-grid by using either batteries or solar power. It can be extended in the future by addition of temperature or health monitoring sensors as well due to its modular design. This solution will minimize the need to manually monitor hazards, get alerts quicker once an attack has been detected, and decrease the risk to the livestock, hence guaranteeing farmers more security and freedom of mind and maximum protection of their valuable animals.

title: Real-Time Posture Monitoring using Flexi Sensor
authors: Rachit Madhegaria, Vasu Jain, Ruban Nersisson
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Daily human activities such as prolonged sitting, standing, or walking can significantly influence physical health and body posture. Poor posture habits formed during these repetitive actions often lead to serious health concerns like chronic back pain, joint strain, and long-term musculoskeletal disorders. Addressing these challenges necessitates effective, accessible monitoring tools that raise awareness of body positioning and promote corrective actions. This paper presents the development of a low-cost, real-time posture monitoring system that is simple in design, easy to use, and built around a flexible (bend) sensor embedded within a wearable kneecap connected to an Arduino Nano microcontroller. The sensor continuously tracks knee joint movement and generates analog voltage values corresponding to the bending angle, which the Arduino processes to classify the user's activity-sitting, standing, or walking-based on predefined threshold ranges. This proposed system provides a standalone, fully offline solution, displaying posture data instantly on a serial monitor for immediate feedback. Its compactness, low power consumption, and affordability make it suitable for various use cases, including physiotherapy for tracking patient recovery, office settings for posture correction, and personal wellness applications to promote awareness of movement habits.

title: Arduino Enabled Smart Irrigation System: A Sustainable Approach for Efficient Water Management in Agriculture
authors: Sarvesh M R, Harsh Shukla, Purab Jain, Deepa T, Aravind C K, Krishna Kumba
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The Smart Irrigation System (SIS) automates watering using an Arduino Uno, moisture sensors, relays, solenoid valves, and an LED display to optimize water use. Soil moisture sensors trigger irrigation when levels drop below a set threshold, activating solenoid valves to release water until the desired moisture is reached. The system employs drip irrigation for efficient water delivery, minimizing evaporation and runoff. Real-time monitoring via an LED display enhances usability. Designed for agriculture and home gardening, this IoT-based solution conserves water, reduces manual effort, and is ideal for regions facing water scarcity, showcasing automation's role in sustainable agriculture.

title: Ground Fault Location of Hydro Generator Based on Recursive Least Squares Parameter Identification with Forgetting Factor
authors: Shuhua Wang, Leiming Hu, Ming Chen, Qianxin Xu, Wenchao Wang, Ping Jin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the continuous development of the power system, the safe and stable operation of hydroelectric generators is of vital importance for ensuring the power supply. Grounding fault is one of the common faults of hydroelectric generators. Accurately and quickly locating the position of the grounding fault is of great significance for timely fault repair and reducing power outage losses. This paper proposes a method based on the identification of the least recursive squares parameter of the forgetting factor for the location of grounding faults in hydroelectric generators. By establishing the mathematical model of the hydroelectric generator and using the least recursive squares algorithm with the forgetting factor to update and identify the model parameters in real time, the accurate estimation of the grounding fault location can be achieved. The experimental results show that this method has high positioning accuracy and fast convergence speed, and can effectively improve the efficiency and reliability of ground fault location for hydroelectric generators.

title: Optimized Operation of Regional Electricity Market Based on Electricity-Carbon-Green Certificate Interactive Trading
authors: QiMing Wu, Ning Zhang, SiJia Wen, LingXiao Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: In the course of China's promotion of green and low-carbon energy transformation and the realization of the “dual-carbon” goal, various types of market trading mechanisms have been gradually introduced to optimize the existing trading structure in order to promote the development of the electricity market in a low-carbon direction. Among them, the carbon quota trading mechanism can inhibit the excess emission behavior of traditional energy generators from the source, and reduce the overall carbon emissions by clarifying the supply-side carbon emission rights and responsibilities; the green certificate trading mechanism can effectively stimulate the enthusiasm of renewable energy generators. Therefore, the interactive trading of electricity, carbon quotas and green certificates will play an important role in promoting the optimal operation of the regional electricity market, and thus facilitating the transformation of the energy structure from traditional energy-led to renewable energyled.

title: Textual Medical History Summarization for Diagnosis
authors: Deepika R, Pradeep Kumar T S
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: In the fast-paced world of healthcare, doctors and medical professionals deal with enormous quantities of patient data every day. It is not uncommon for medical records to be long-winded and laborious to read manually. This work is a Medical Summarization and Explainable AI (XAI) Framework that automates the task of summarizing complex medical text in an explainable manner. It demonstrates the potential of combining XAI techniques like LIME and token gradients in conjunction with BioBERT to summarize and respond to medical queries with higher levels of explainability. It aids in speedy diagnosis and increases the overall efficiency of the diagnosis.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Driver Drowsiness System Based on Eye Aspect Ratio
authors: Divya R, Vasanth Raj P, Naveen Bharath V
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Considering driver fatigue is a major contributing factor to traffic accidents, trustworthy real-time monitoring solutions are required. In this study, a vision-based Driver Drowsiness Detection System that combines integrated hardware and image processing is presented. The system computes the Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR) to identify indicators of exhaustion and uses Python modules such as Dlib and OpenCV to detect face landmarks. An Arduino-controlled buzzer, LED, and LCD display are used to sound an alert when drowsiness is detected. When tested in both simulated and real-world scenarios, the system showed excellent responsiveness and dependability in recognising patterns of eye closure. An effective and affordable way to improve driver safety and lower occurrences linked to fatigue is provided by this comprehensive solution.

title: Power Factor Correction with Totem Pole Boost Converter Using Matlab
authors: Malar E, Subashree R, Abi P, Arnesh S
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative simulationbased analysis of three boost converter topologies for Power Factor Correction (PFC) using MATLAB Simulink. The study investigates the performance of a conventional totem-pole boost converter, a dual boost converter, and an advanced totem-pole configuration under identical input and load conditions. The primary objective is to evaluate each topology's effectiveness in improving the power factor, reducing total harmonic distortion (THD), and enhancing overall efficiency in ACDC conversion systems. MATLAB Simulink is used to model each converter topology and simulate their behavior in continuous conduction mode (CCM) with PFC control strategies. Key performance parameters, including input current waveform quality, output voltage regulation, and dynamic response to load variations, are analyzed. Special attention is given to the effectiveness of each topology in achieving near-unity power factor and maintaining low input current distortion. The results provide valuable insights into the trade-offs between control complexity and power quality improvement.

title: Interactive Cyber Risk Analysis: A Gamified Approach for IT and IOT Security Environments
authors: Anusha Nerella, Pratik Badri, Siva Teja Reddy Kandula, Pradeep Kumar Muthukamatchi, Vinodkumar Reddy Surasani, Arpit Jain
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: This research focuses on tackling risk or on-the-job training for cyber-physical systems, but the increasing incidents of cyber-attack (and updated methods of attack) on both OT and IT make it imperative that new ways of doing risk analysis, training and planning defenses be developed. We introduce the PenQuest, a gamified cybersecurity platform that simulates adversarial dynamics with a standard-aligned metamodel made based on various frameworks of MITRE ATT&CK, CAPEC, D3FEND, NIST SP 800-53. As an interactive 2-grouparch strategy game, PenQuest models realistic attack-defense processes of reconnaissance, intrusion, mitigation and recovery on interdependent assets. In a role-playing context, participants experience cybersecurity as attacker and defender forces, each with a distinct set of tools and tactics. Scenario based learning, cascading failures modeling and quantitative risk analysis was comprised by the platform. An experimental investigation with students and practitioners has shown that Pen Quest improves cybersecurity knowledge, decision-making, and strategic thinking. Additionally, the model’s consistency and generality can enable its application in penetration testing planning and AI-based adversarial simulation. In this paper, we describe the underlying metamodel, gameplay mechanics, educational evaluation, and observed limitations while also taking stock of ongoing improvements that we plan on integrating such as reinforcement learning and domain-specific expansions. PenQuest combines gamification and cyber security best practice to innovatively engage risk online and educate across a variety of digital environments.

title: Eat'osure: an AI-Powered Food Allergen and Diet Planner Web Application
authors: Sri Janani P, Prateeksha J, Sri Sai Divya R, Sugantha Priyadharshini P
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Eat'osure is a simple web-based application designed to aid individuals with food allergies or diet restrictions by recommending personalized meals. The application utilizes a Random Forest machine learning algorithm to accurately detect allergens in restaurant foods. Most importantly, the application is designed to ensure user safety and restaurant confidentiality while withholding full recipes. Notable features include custom diet filters, such as Nut-Free and Vegan, along with live menu updates. This article describes the system architecture, Artificial Intelligence strategy, and measures of performance, with specific examples where Eat'osure can provide food safety along with dining convenience.

title: Ways of Seeing, and Selling, AI Art
authors: Imke van Heerden
publish: Computer
abstract: Christie’s first artificial intelligence (AI) art auction opened amid controversy, serving as a microcosm of AI’s contested position in the creative economy. By foregrounding responsible framing, this article adds nuance to the polarized debate on generative models and human values.

title: Deep Learning with Ensemble Learning Model for Short-Term Wind Speed Prediction
authors: Sathyaraj J, Sankardoss V
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Wind is one of the most important renewable energy sources, contributing to a cleaner and more secure environment. The accurate forecast of wind speed is vital to ensure optimal power production in wind energy systems, particularly in the wind turbine sector. The volatile nature of wind patterns poses a significant challenge to wind power generation. To overcome this, several techniques of wind speed prediction are applied to improve electricity yield. This research mainly aims to develop deep learning models that incorporate ensemble learning methods, including recurrent neural networks, long short-term memory networks, gated recurrent units, and ensemble models. The performance evaluation metrics of these models are based on the four primary measures: mean squared error, root mean squared error, mean absolute error, and the coefficient of determination. The performance evaluation results indicate that the ensemble learning model outperforms other models significantly in terms of prediction accuracy. In particular, the ensemble learning model obtains a short-term wind speed forecasting accuracy of 0.5252 MSE, 0.7247 RMSE, 0.5302 MAE, and 0.9686 R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Deep Hybrid Models for Accurate Skin Disease Diagnosis Using Medical Imaging
authors: Vijayalakshmi K, G Geetha, V. Kavitha
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The successful management of dermatological conditions relies on prompt identification; y et, d ermatologists are not readily accessible. This paper proposes a conversational AI chatbot that categorizes images using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and diagnoses symptoms using natural language processing (NLP). Users may input symptoms or upload images to the algorithm, which delivers initial diagnoses and recommendations. Photographs of skin diseases are precisely categorized with a fine-tuned <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R$</tex> esNet-18 m odel, whereas verbal descriptions are processed by an NLP-driven decision tree model. The chatbot, utilizing Google Dialogflow e nable real-time engagement, is implemented through a Flask-based API. Experimental data validate the system's efficacy as an assistance in dermatological examinations, demonstrating a classification accuracy of 94.1

title: CARTEL: Consensus Adapting Real-Time and Efficient Logging
authors: Seunghoon Lee, Wonyeong Lee, Seungyeon Cho, Seongtae Lee, Jinkyu Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Consensus algorithms are widely adopted in clustered systems to distribute data efficiently, with Raft being a prominent failover algorithm due to its effectiveness and fault tolerance. However, Raft and other consensus algorithms do not provide timing guarantees, limiting their application to time-critical systems such as industrial control systems, drone swarms, and autonomous vehicle networks, where it is critical to distribute state machines in time and prevent multiple timing misses of data. In this paper, we propose CARTEL (Consensus Adapting Real-Time and Efficient Logging), a novel consensus algorithm that integrates time-predictability into the Raft framework. To achieve this aim, we examine Raft's mechanisms and identify the characteristics that impact the timing of data propagation within a distributed system. Based on these insights, we design CARTEL by developing two mechanisms that address the primary limitations of Raft: (i) CARTEL voting to solve the uncertainty of leader election timing, and (ii) CARTEL node buffer to limit the number of indeterminately deferred data during leader failure. Moreover, we propose how to utilize the mechanisms of CARTEL to ensure time-predictability in leader elections and mitigate the indeterminate nature of data logging during leader transitions, without harming the integrity of Raft. We validate the effectiveness of CARTEL through real-world implementation. The experiments confirm that CARTEL not only reduces the uncertainty of system recovery inherent in the election process (by 65.7% compared to Raft) but also enhances the integrity of the distributed system by guaranteeing timely data logging.

title: Seizure Detection Using Reduced Temporal EEG Channels: A Performance-Driven Approach
authors: Mohsin Khalil, Raheel Asif, Muhammad Amir Tahir, Muhammad Nasar Jamal
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is integral to diagnosing brain disorders, particularly epilepsy. As research advances, there is a significant shift towards mobile and ambulatory EEG systems, necessitating the simplification of traditional setups that typically involve numerous electrodes, thereby increasing cost and complexity. This study harnesses time domain features within EEG recordings, proposing the exclusive use of temporal channels to enhance device practicability. Utilizing the CHB-MIT dataset, we investigate three experimental setups: one employing all available channels, another using six temporal channels (three from each hemisphere), and a third deploying ten channels (five from each temporal region). Our analysis reveals that while the full-channel configuration achieved a True Positive Rate (TPR) of 95 % and a False Positive Rate (FP/hr) of 0.16, the reduced-channel configurations yielded promising results, with only minor decreases in performance metrics. Notably, the ten-channel configuration demonstrated precise seizure focus localization, occasionally surpassing the full setup's performance. This paper substantiates that reducing EEG channels to ten temporal channels can maintain robust detection capabilities, thus supporting the development of more efficient and cost-effective EEG systems.

title: A Novel Whittle Index-Based Scheduling for Age of Information Minimization in IoT Networks
authors: Arian Morteza, Dongyu Qiu, Yousef R. Shayan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: The Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) protocol has become a widely adopted standard in IoT systems due to its lightweight and energy-efficient publish/subscribe architecture. However, ensuring timely data delivery remains a challenge, especially for applications requiring fresh information. In this paper, we address this issue by integrating the Age of Information (AoI) metric into the MQTT framework. We formulate the MQTT-AoI optimization problem as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) and propose a novel Whittle index-based scheduling policy. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach effectively minimizes AoI while satisfying resource constraints. Furthermore, we show that the dual variable converge, ensuring the algorithm reaches a feasible solution under the hard constraints. This work provides a practical solution for managing information freshness in MQTT-based IoT networks.

title: Triangular Array-Based Miniaturized Capsule Antenna for in-Body Biotelemetry Applications
authors: Madurakavi Karthikeyan, Shanmugam Kumaravel, Nagarajan Vasugi
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: A novel conformal capsule-based implantable antenna for endoscopy biomedical applications have been presented in this paper. The proposed antenna features a compact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> triangular-shaped array configurations integrated within a cylindrical capsule of dimensions <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7.2} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{21.5} \times 0.25 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex>, significantly smaller than many existing designs. The homogenous spiral phantom has been used in simulations with a diameter of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{100 ~ mm}$</tex> to mimic realistic in-body conditions. According to simulation results, the antenna has a 2.4 GHz resonance frequency, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{15.8\%}$</tex> operational bandwidth between 2.2 GHz and 2.58 GHz, and a return loss (S11) of -28.5 dB, which indicates excellent impedance matching. The antenna achieves a maximum gain of -21.6 dBi despite the lossy tissue environment. This gain is acceptable for short range in-body to on-body communication. The array's low-profile, conformal design guarantees structural flexibility and biocompatibility while also improving integration into tiny implanted capsules.

title: Coordinated Control of Grid-Connected DFIG-Based Wind Energy System with STATCOM and Supercapacitor Energy Storage
authors: Maloth Hussen, Thirumalaivasan R, Janaki M, Lilik Jamilatul Awalin
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel coordinated control strategy for a grid-connected Doubly Fed Induction Generator (DFIG)-based wind energy system integrated with a Static Synchronous Compensator (STATCOM) and Supercapacitor Energy Storage System (SCES). The approach enhances voltage stability, reactive power support, and transient performance under varying wind conditions by leveraging the inherent reactive power capabilities of DFIG combined with fast active power buffering from SCES. A detailed MATLAB/Simulink model validates the proposed framework, demonstrating a 150 ms voltage recovery during faults, a 62% reduction in power fluctuations, and a 52% decrease in converter losses compared to conventional systems. These results highlight the effectiveness of the coordinated control in improving grid code compliance and system reliability.

title: CFU Proving Ground: a Hardware/Software Co-Design Framework for Leveraging a Custom Function Unit and RISC-V Custom Instructions
authors: Aoba Fujino, Kenji Kise
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: The mismatches between hardware and software often prolong the development time of application-specific instruction-set processors (ASIPs). While hardware/software codesign approaches have improved development environments, challenges remain regarding usability and flexibility. This research proposes CFU Proving Ground, a hardware/software codesign framework targeting FPGAs that improves performance by leveraging a custom function unit (CFU) as an accelerator. This framework supports agile ASIP development through the design flow of register transfer level and a resource-efficient CFU that supports RISC-V custom instructions. It enhances usability and flexibility by providing lightweight libraries, explicit file dependencies, and flexible memory mapping. We discuss the effectiveness of our framework based on evaluation results using a low-cost FPGA board.

title: Pervasive Physical AI
authors: Jyotika Athavale, Dejan Milojicic, Nita Patel
publish: Computer
abstract: The year 2025 saw an accelerated artificial intelligence (AI) adoption in every foreseeable and unforeseeable facet of human life and profession. The next year will see increased pervasive adoption of physical AI.

title: Decentralized Path Planning for Multi-Robot Systems Using GNNs on HBE-Robocar
authors: Mohamed Ali, Randa M. Abdelmoneem
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: This paper explores decentralized multi-robot path planning using deep learning. Inspired by recent advancements in distributed deep learning, we designed a framework in which each robot communicates solely with its local neighbors to collaboratively compute collision-free paths. Throughout our approach, each robot encodes its local observations, extracts valuable features using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), aggregates the extracted features using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and structured graphbased message passing. Finally, efficient and informed decision-making is performed using multilayer perception (MLP) to predict conflict-free actions for each robot based on shared contextual information. The proposed approach enhances system scalability, robustness, and reduces communication overhead without centralized coordination. It achieves 97.6% Accuracy, and 98.9% success rate. A Hardware prototype is implemented and tested showing that the proposed system holds promise for real-world applications such as autonomous warehouse management and coordinated robotic exploration, contributing to the advancement of intelligent and cooperative multi-agent systems.

title: A Mixture of Experts Approach for Morgan -Keenan Spectral Classification of Gaia DR2 Stars
authors: Subhayan Mukherjee, Poulomi Mukherjee, Babul P. Tewari
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The classification of stars, galaxies, and quasars is essential for constructing a coherent picture of galactic structure and evolution, and further distinction of stars into spectral type and luminosity classes are essential to enabling targeted analysis of stellar populations, cosmological parameters, and unusual astrophysical events. In this paper, we introduce a Mixture of Experts (MoE) model to classify astronomical objects from Gaia DR2 catalog data. The model is able to leverage the strengths of various expert networks to achieve a high classification accuracy of 93.8%, which is better than various traditional and deep learning-based approaches presented in the literature. Moreover, the model exhibits robustness to outliers and rare object classes, such as carbon-enhanced stars or heavily reddened quasars, thereby offering both improved performance and interpretability relative to monolithic neural networks or static template-matching methods. In addition, by adding uncertainty estimation or Bayesian MoE versions, we can increase the stability of the model in real applications where data quality can be significantly heterogeneous. These projects can assist in pushing the grand goal of enabling rapid and accurate cataloging of stars in the realm of big data astronomy.

title: Optimal Photovoltaic–Battery Storage Sharing for Affordable Net-Zero Urban High-Rises
authors: Raghuraman Ramakrishnan, Vijayakumar Krishnasamy, B Chitti Babu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Designing net-zero energy buildings in the context of urban high-rises with solar photovoltaic source alone is challenging due to affordability concerns and limited rooftop space availability. This work deals with an optimal photovoltaic-battery energy storage system (PV-BESS) sizing framework for two urban high-rises. The proposed architecture utilizes a shared BESS that buffers the complementary load profiles of the buildings considered in this study. Inter-building energy exchange is facilitated through a common DC bus. Three objectives have been formulated to capture energy reliability, affordability, and grid stress. A multi-objective grey wolf optimization algorithm is applied to these conflicting objectives in order to achieve a balanced, cost-effective, and grid-supportive net-zero energy operation. A comparative study between individual and shared BESS configurations has been performed. The shared BESS with the proposed energy transfer significantly enhances overall grid friendliness by 42%, and lowers deficit energy by 68% with a moderate, justifiable increase in initial investment in the considered buildings. The results confirm that shared BESS-based optimal sizing improves operational efficiency and affordability, thereby promoting net-zero energy attainment in urban settings.

title: A Step Towards Improvement in PCOS Detection Using Explainable AI
authors: Prateek Kumar, Kavita Pandey, Vedant Singh Chauhan, Shivam Singh
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome is one of the most common endocrine disorders, affecting 8–13% of women globally who are of reproductive age. Early detection is essential to mitigate the risks of long-term complications such as infertility, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases. However, PCOS diagnosis remains a challenge because of its heterogeneity and reliance on subjective clinical evaluation. This article tackles these challenges by integrating Explainable AI for the detection of PCOS. A fine-tuned MobileNet model is employed for the classification of ovarian ultrasound images, while Grad-CAM is utilized to enhance interpretability by highlighting critical regions influencing the model's predictions. The proposed approach achieves high classification accuracy and provides visual explanations, thereby improving trust and clarity in clinical decision-making. This work contributes a robust and interpretable AI solution for PCOS diagnosis, underscoring deep learning’s capability in fostering confidence in medical image analysis.

title: A Two-Stage YOLO-CNN Framework for Automated Lithium-ion Battery Defect Inspection
authors: Puncharus Phongphithongchai, Achara Pichetjamroen, Ekkachan Rattanalerdnusorn, Tsuyoshi Isshiki, Natthawuth Somakettarin
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are widely used in electric vehicles and energy storage systems, but their inspection remains a challenge. Manual visual inspection is labor-intensive, inconsistent, and unsuitable for high-throughput production lines. This study presents an automated inspection framework based on a two-stage computer vision pipeline. In the first stage, YOLO-based detectors (YOLOv8n, YOLOv8s, and YOLOv11n) were used to localize battery cells from raw images. In the second stage, cropped regions of interest were classified into four categories: normal prismatic cell, damaged prismatic cell, normal pouch cell, damaged pouch cell using lightweight CNN architectures (ResNet18 and EfficientNet-B0). A custom dataset of 1,120 images, expanded to 5,000 through augmentation, was collected using a dual-camera setup with top and side views. Experimental evaluation on a held-out test set demonstrated that the best configuration, YOLOv11n combined with EfficientNetB0, achieved 95.83% accuracy with precision, recall, and F1scores above 0.96. These results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid pipeline and its strong potential for real-time industrial applications in battery production and recycling.

title: A Physics-Informed APSO-BiLSTM Model for Photovoltaic Power Forecasting
authors: Yujie Xun, Bing Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This study proposes a physics-informed APSO-BiLSTM model to improve the accuracy and interpretability of photovoltaic power forecasting. The model enhances input features with theoretical power derived from physical principles and optimizes BiLSTM hyperparameters using an Adaptive Particle Swarm Optimization (APSO) algorithm. Experiments on historical PV plant data show that the proposed model achieves an MSE of 4.35 and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.97, significantly outperforming standard BiLSTM, GWO-BiLSTM, and BO-BiLSTM. It also converges faster and balances prediction accuracy with computational cost more effectively. The work demonstrates a successful integration of physical insight with data-driven modeling for reliable PV forecasting.

title: Research on Economic Dispatch of Distribution Network with Electrochemical-Pumped Storage Based on Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Shitong Luo, Jun Wu, Liang Wang, Shiting Cui, Shuo Wang, Bowen Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the continuous increase in the proportion of new energy sources connected to the power grid, the operational uncertainty of distribution networks has significantly increased. Reasonably configuring and dispatching energy storage systems has become a key approach to enhancing the flexibility, stability, and economic efficiency of the system. This paper takes a typical distribution network as the research object and constructs a joint economic dispatch model that includes battery energy storage and pumped - storage systems. It comprehensively considers factors such as the charging and discharging behaviors of the two types of energy storage, energy state updates, water level changes, and capacity investment, and establishes a joint objective function that includes operating costs and construction costs. To solve this model, an improved multi - particle swarm optimization algorithm is adopted, and simulation verification is carried out in the IEEE 33 - bus distribution network to optimize the dispatch scheme of the system under the typical daily load curve. The results show that the introduction of pumped storage significantly improves the utilization rate of wind power and the economic efficiency of the system. Reasonable configuration of hybrid energy storage can effectively improve the ability of the distribution network to absorb wind and solar energy and its operational stability.

title: An Improved Deep Learning Based RGB-D Saliency Detection Model
authors: Mudar Sarem, Yunping Zheng, KeJun Wang, Laya Albshlawy
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: RGB-D Saliency Object Detection (SOD) is a specialized research area in computer vision that focuses on identifying the most prominent or attention-grabbing objects within a scene using both RGB (color) images and depth information (D). It is used for various applications like image segmentation, video analysis, and object recognition, where highlighting key objects quickly and accurately is essential. The RGB-D SOD methods typically involve deep learning techniques. Lately, many deep learning methods based on encoder-decoder architectures have been introduced. The RD3D model and its improved version (RD3D+) addressed the RGB-D SOD through 3-D convolutional neural networks. In this paper inspired by the RD3D+ deep learning-based model, we propose an improved RD3D+ model, which aims to enhance the performance of salient target detection. Our innovations are reflected in the following: Firstly, based on the RD3D+ model, a deep supervision strategy is introduced for this model, where an auxiliary supervision branch is added for each decoder. Secondly, the Intersection and Union ratio (IoU) loss and the pixel-level Binary Cross Entropy (BCE) loss are combined to be optimized together, which facilitates the rapid convergence of the model and improves the detection capability. The experimental validations show that our improved model has an excellent performance on five benchmark datasets compared with seven state-of-the-art RGB-D SOD approaches in terms of four key evaluation metrics.

title: A Hybrid Semi-Supervised Learning Approach Based Dimensionality Reduction for Emerging IoT Cyber Attack Analysis
authors: Youssra Baja, Khalid Chougdali
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: With internet connectivity's dynamic development and network communication escalating, an upward trend in advanced threats and cyber attack crimes is being witnessed, targeting sensitive data and critical systems. As the number of connected devices continues to increase, more opportunities are provided for malicious actors to exploit these vulnerabilities. Therefore, the attack surface expanded, particularly within the Internet of Things (IoT), reinforcing the necessity to design a suitable and adaptable security model for protecting data and minimizing the damage caused by network system intrusions and attacks. Machine learning is a swift and flexible way to develop a cybersecurity model. Clustering and other unsupervised learning techniques are frequently used to find hidden patterns or anomalies without needing labeled data. Still, they are limited in accurately distinguishing between normal and malicious behaviors, particularly when dealing with emerging attacks (such as zero-day attacks). This paper provides a hybrid semi-supervised classification-based clustering approach model to distinguish malicious emerging cyber-attacks. Initially, unsupervised clustering methods were implemented to group related data points and find underlying patterns to the reduced data dimensionality under Principal Component Analysis (PCA). Then, the pseudo-labels generated by clustering were used in supervised tasks with a Support Vector Machine (SVM) for classification. The experiments have been carried out on two IoT datasets, namely MQTTset and IoTID20, and the results confirm that the hybrid strategy is a viable and effective approach to dealing with IoT security issues in complicated and real-world situations.

title: Chatbot with Voice Assistant Integrated in a Website using Amazon Lex, S3, Cloud Formation and Cloudfront
authors: Aayushi Yogesh Malode, Anna John, Alyssa Dominica Sequeira, Prajot Prakash Borkar, O.V.Gnana Swathika
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents the design, development, and deployment of a fully cloud-native, voice-enabled chatbot system integrated into a web-based cab booking platform, utilizing only Amazon Web Services (AWS). Unlike conventional chatbot implementations that rely on hybrid or third-party integrations, the proposed system is entirely built using AWS services, ensuring seamless scalability, security, and performance. The chatbot employs Amazon Lex for speech recognition and natural language understanding, enabling both voice and text interactions which is novel integration that supports hands-free engagement directly within a web environment, without external plugins or APIs. The system architecture incorporates AWS CloudFormation for automated infrastructure provisioning, Amazon S3 for scalable static content hosting, and Amazon CloudFront for low-latency global content delivery. The paper details the step-by-step development process, architecture design, deployment strategies, and challenges encountered, offering practical insights into building robust, scalable, AI-driven web applications using cloud-native technologies.

title: A Probabilistic Load Modeling Approach for Electric Vehicle Charging Stations Considering Uncertainties in Travel Behavior
authors: Juan Xu, Wenjun Tang, Shan He, Jiaming Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the growing penetration of electric vehicles, the coupling between urban transportation and power distribution networks has intensified, introducing charging load uncertainties that challenge system operation. To address these uncertainties and spatial correlations among loads, this paper proposes a probabilistic EV charging load modeling approach. A probabilistic traffic assignment-based simulation model captures realistic charging load distributions using optimal path generation. Multiple linear regression further characterizes spatial correlations among charging stations, enhancing model accuracy. Case studies confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method in reflecting realistic urban charging load characteristics, thus supporting infrastructure planning and coupled transportationdistribution network analysis.

title: Chargetime Predictor: A Data-Driven Approach for Estimating Smartphone Charging Session Duration
authors: Yusuf Awad, Islam Hegazy, El-Sayed M. El-Horbaty
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Overcharging smartphone batteries is one of fundamental causes of battery degradation. As it can significantly impact their lifespan by the increased battery temperature it causes. Predicting the target time for unplugging the smartphone from the charger has become a hot topic in both academia and industry. In this paper, we propose a new machine learning approach using XGBoost to predict the target unplugging time, the event upon which the user will unplug the phone from the charger, based on the user's charging routine. We integrate our proposed approach into a commercial product that charges the battery at intervals based on the predicted unplugging time. This technique can almost double the average battery lifespan cycle from two to four and a half years in realworld testing. Our proposed technique can help users extend their battery life by avoiding overcharging by predicting the end time of the charging session. Our end-to-end system is introduced in this work, emphasising the prediction machine learning model. To train our model, we used a real-world dataset with different charging routines, achieving an accuracy of 0.94 and an F1-score of 0.91 in real-world testing, not limited to simulation testing. Additionally, our solution provides a reasonably accurate prediction for any charging session, unlike previous work, which focused solely on predicting the longest session.

title: A single-stage step-down LED driver Combined with visible light communication modulation strategy
authors: Lin Songhui, Lin Weiming, Chen Jiahui, Li Fulong, Wang Yapeng
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: A single-stage step-down Cuk/TI Buck LED driver and a power control strategy combined with Visible Light Communication (VLC) modulation is proposed in this paper. The proposed circuit is integrated by the AC-DC step-down Cuk circuit and the DC-DC improved step-down TIBuck circuit unit. The proposed LED driver can be output the specific AC signal waveform in LED output current by adjusting the parameters such as amplitude, phase, and frequency, for the data modulation required for VLC communication. The operating principle, operating process and steady-state characteristics of the proposed driver are analyzed in this paper, circuit variable relationships is derived, and the circuit parameters are designed. Finally, a computer simulation analysis was conducted, and a prototype with $185-265 \mathrm{~V}_{\mathrm{rms}} / 50 \mathrm{~Hz}$ AC input, $1 \mathrm{~A} / 50 \mathrm{~W}$ full-load output, and $30 \%-100 \%$ dimming capability was fully tested. A data transmission rate of $10 \sim 15 \mathrm{kbps}$ and a dimming output range of $30 \%-100 \%$, with a power factor of over 0.97 can be achieved in the prototype. The simulation and experimental results have been obtained to verify the proposed LED driver and the proposed modulation strategy.

title: Machine Learning-Based Predictive Gas Leak Detection Using Pressure Pattern Recognition on ESP32
authors: Hari Ragavan B, Logeshwaran J, Deepa M, Thiru Murugan A, Thanwanth V G
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Gas leaks pose significant safety and economic risks, and therefore, early detection is an imperative need in industrial as well as residential settings. Conventional gas sensors give reactive signals only after a significant leak occurs, which restricts them from preventing accidents. This work presents a machine learning predictive gas leak detection system deployed on an ESP32 microcontroller based on pressure pattern recognition. Pressure sensor readings are continuously being monitored and analyzed by a trained ML model that detects minor fluctuations and anomalies that signal the development of a leak. A hybrid of LSTM and XGBoost models is employed to detect both gradual and sudden leaks with improved accuracy. In contrast to threshold-based measures, the proposed system utilizes time-series pressure trends to predict possible severe declines before they reach critical points, thus offering an early warning system. Experimental results show that the system provides stable detection accuracy under a resource limited IoT platform. The proposed solution is scalable, low-cost, and holds great promise in improving safety in gas distribution networks, storage facilities, and domestic applications.
