title: A Dual-Perspective Analysis of IGBT Open-Circuit Faults in Hybrid Modular Multilevel Converters: Unified Characteristics and Diagnoses
authors: Hong Wu, Yue Wang, Yi Liu, Yufei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: The hybrid modular multilevel converter (HMMC) comprising both full-bridge submodules (SMs) and half-bridge SMs has drawn extensive attention for its cost-effective DC fault ride-through capability. However, IGBT OCF diagnosis-a prerequisite for fault isolation and fault reconfiguration, is critical to the reliability of HMMCs, while relevant research remains scarce. Furthermore, varied OCF scenarios within HMMC further complicate fault diagnosis. To fill this gap, this article first conducts a dual-perspective analysis of IGBT OCFs in HMMCs, covering single and multiple OCF scenarios in an SM. Two unified characteristics are yielded: 1) Unified Characteristic I, derived from the mode-type perspective and reveals that IGBT OCFs cause specific mode-type conversions of the faulty SM; 2) Unified Characteristic II, derived from the switching-function perspective, indicates that the faulty SM maintains a specific switching function. Therefore, a unified characteristics-driven strategy is proposed, including a detection stage and a localization stage. In the detection stage, the suspected faulty SM is selected via Unified Characteristic II and its status is then ascertained using Unified Characteristic I. Upon the identification of a fault, other suspected faulty SMs are screened, with their statuses determined in the ensuing localization stage. Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: A Near-Field Beam-Tracking Technique for Extremely Large Uniform Planar Array Systems with Overlapped Subarray Configuration
authors: Youngmin Kim, Yeong Jun Kim
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: Extremely large antenna arrays, operating at mmWave or sub-THz frequency bands, are essential to meet the ambitious performance targets envisioned for sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks, but they face near-field challenges due to spherical wavefronts. This study proposes a novel beam-tracking method for extremely large uniform planar arrays (ELUPAs) using an overlapped subarray configuration. The method tracks the beam by estimating the spatial response parameters, which include both angle and range, using the first-order differential product between signals from closely spaced and overlapped subarrays. A single-antenna-element displacement between overlapped subarrays introduces phase symmetry, enabling robust and efficient parameter estimation for near-field beam tracking.

title: An Analytical Investigation on Selection of I-APF and R-APF to Mitigate Harmonic Resonance in HVDC Terminal Under Capacity Constraints
authors: Yang Wang, Jiadong Yang, Zhiquan Ma, Qunwei Xu, Jinshuai Zhao, Xianyong Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: With the rapid advancement of power electronics, active power filters (APFs) have emerged as a preferred solution for mitigating harmonic resonance in high-voltage direct current (HVDC) systems. APFs can be broadly categorized into current compensation APFs (I-APFs) and resistive APFs (R-APFs), depending on their control strategies. Although both types have demonstrated effectiveness in practical applications, previous studies have not comprehensively compared their resonance mitigation performance, particularly under capacity-limited conditions. To address this gap, this paper establishes an equivalent harmonic model for LCC-HVDC systems with APFs connected and proposes a novel metric, capacity utilization efficiency (CUE), to compare the resonance suppression effectiveness of APFs. The variation characteristics of CUE are systematically analyzed considering factors such as resonance frequency, system damping, and APF capacity. The findings provide a practical guideline to assist utilities in selecting the optimal APF control, accounting for factors such as varying network impedances and background harmonic distortions. Finally, the developed harmonic model and the APF-selection guideline are validated using a real-life LCC-HVDC system experiencing resonance issues and a modified IEEE 39-bus system.

title: On the Benefits of Quantum Entanglement and Compton Kinematics for Scatter Discrimination in PET Imaging
authors: M. Moulin, G. Montémont, S. Stanchina, J. M. Létang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: This paper compares methods for rejecting in-patient scattered photons in PET instruments, which can degrade image quality by introducing bias and noise. The focus is on events where both annihilation photons interact several times in the detection medium. Compton scattering physics and annihilation photon polarization entanglement are utilized. Events are classified by the number of hits in the detector to assess information quality, and the spatial response from lines of response or Compton cones is analysed. A comparison between methods is made through a simulation of an ideal cylindrical detector with a radius of 15 cm and a thickness of 1 cm, using Geant4. Results from the simulations are used to create histograms for the different observables. Metrics, such as receiver-operating-characteristic (ROC) curves and noise equivalent count (NEC), are used to quantify the efficiency of each method and the influence of hit multiplicity. Alongside this simulation-based investigation, an experiment using a pair of CdZnTe Compton cameras has been set up to validate the entanglement model and its integration simulation. We demonstrate that entanglement information may be considered less valuable, achieving an area under the ROC curve of 52% compared to energy deposition and Compton kinematics, which have an area of 97%. Finally, the obtained detective quantum efficiency (DQE) demonstrates the superiority of Compton cones for low resolution, up to around 0.05 cm-1, followed by the line of response, which achieves a spatial bandwidth of 1.6 cm-1, thus showing the complementarity between the two types of information. This study highlights the importance of Compton kinematics and the limited value of entanglement for rejecting scattered events.

title: A Smart Dual Thermistor-Based Nasal Mask for Respiratory Health Monitoring
authors: Thomaskutty Mathew, Chapala Anjaneyulu, Joel Mohapatra, Brithik Biju R, Anoop C. S.
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: In this letter, we propose a low-cost, portable, and wearable smart nasal thermistor mask with associated electronics for continuous respiration monitoring. A commercially available mask incorporating a thermistor realizes the smart mask. The above-mentioned thermistor, along with another thermistor for ambient temperature monitoring, together realize a dual thermistor bridge. The output voltage of the bridge topology interfacing the above dual-thermistor is amplified using an instrumentation amplifier stage. The above signal was signal-conditioned, and the respiration rate of the subject was inferred. The accuracy in measurement was tested using twenty healthy volunteers of various age groups. The resulting error was less than 1 breaths per minute. The developed prototype was tested with different states of the subject, likewise during exercise and during a short nap. A comprehensive sensitivity study of the acquired bio-signal was performed for different positions of sensor placement. The potential applications of the smart mask include integration with telemedicine, advanced driver assistance systems, and in space applications.

title: A Ka-Band Variable-Gain Phase Shifter Using a Merged Phase-Shifted and Attenuated Unit
authors: Shiwei Wu, Dongfang Pan, Hongliang Zhao, Lin Cheng
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This article presents a compact variable-gain phase shifter (VGPS) that incorporates both a merged phase-shifted attenuator (ATT) and a merged attenuated phase shifter (PS) unit. The merged phase-shifted ATT achieves an additional phase-shifting capability using a modified switched <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pi $</tex-math> </inline-formula>-type ATT structure, while the merged attenuated PS provides an additional attenuation function based on revised high-pass/low-pass or high-pass/direct-pass PS topologies. The proposed VGPS achieves a bidirectional 20.5-dB gain control range and a 360° phase control range with a 0.5-dB gain step and 5.625° phase step in standard 65 nm CMOS technology. Measurement results demonstrate a maximum root mean squares (rms) phase error of 3.3° and a maximum rms amplitude error of 0.37 dB across the 33–37GHz. The fully passive circuit exhibits high linearity, featuring a minimum input 1-dB compression point (IP1dB) of 11.1 dBm. The core size is 0.27 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> excluding pads.

title: SolPhishHunter: Towards Detecting and Understanding Phishing on Solana
authors: Ziwei Li, Zigui Jiang, Ming Fang, Jiaxin Chen, Zhiying Wu, Jiajing Wu, Lun Zhang, Zibin Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Solana is a rapidly evolving blockchain platform that has attracted an increasing number of users. However, this growth has also drawn the attention of malicious actors, with some phishers extending their reach into the Solana ecosystem. Unlike platforms such as Ethereum, Solana has distinct designs of accounts and transactions, leading to the emergence of new types of phishing transactions that we term SolPhish. We define three types of SolPhish and develop a detection tool called SolPhishHunter. Utilizing SolPhishHunter, we detect a total of 8,058 instances of SolPhish and conduct an empirical analysis of these detected cases. Our analysis explores the distribution and impact of SolPhish, the characteristics of the phishers, and the relationships among phishing gangs. Particularly, the detected SolPhish transactions have resulted in nearly $1.1 million in losses for victims. We report our detection results to the community and construct SolPhishDataset, the first Solana phishing-related dataset in academia.

title: Evaluating the Performance of China's Transmission Grid: A Provincial Case Study through Dynamic Factor Analysis
authors: Xiaoyu Wang, Lin Wang, Yi Mi, Hongjiang Li, Junfeng Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: This study employs dynamic factor analysis to establish a performance evaluation system for transmission grids, encompassing three dimensions: low-carbon performance, social performance and operational performance, with nine tertiary indicators. We analyzed the operational performance of transmission grids across 31 Chinese provinces from 2015 to 2023, revealing performance disparities among the provinces. Based on the experimental findings, we propose targeted strategic recommendations for each province.

title: Reliability Study of Au-Sn Bumps Based on Thermal Gradient Bonding for Micro-LED
authors: Yanbin Zhu, Haojie Zhou, Boyan Zhao, Luqiao Yin, Jianhua Zhang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Micro-LED possess advantages such as high brightness, high definition, high contrast, fast response speed, and long lifespan. They have a wide range of applications and are regarded as the next-generation display technology. This study utilized COMSOL software and the finite element method to simulate the thermodynamic behavior of a $3 \times 3$ Micro-LED array. The stress and thermal expansion of the bumps after thermal gradient bonding and isothermal bonding were analyzed. The results indicated that thermal gradient bonding would generate a certain temperature gradient on both sides of the solder bumps, driving Au atoms to diffuse into Sn and form intermetallic compounds. This temperature gradient can alleviate local thermal expansion, significantly reducing the stress and displacement of the bumps compared to isothermal bonding, thereby enhancing the reliability of the device. In addition, thermal gradient bonding can form IMCs in a shorter time, avoiding excessive growth of IMCs due to prolonged isothermal processes.

title: Multivendor E-Commerce Market Place with Real Time Bidding System and AI Integration
authors: D. Arulmozhi, S. Gowdhamkumar, Deepika. M, J. Suji Priya, A. Nithyasri, Avinash P
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The evolution of intelligent systems in e-commerce has led to the creation of dynamic platforms that drive user engagement and deliver tailored shopping experiences. This paper presents the design and implementation of a multi-vendor e-commerce marketplace that integrates a real-time bidding (RTB) mechanism enhanced by artificial intelligence (AI). The system aims to provide a competitive yet user-centric environment, allowing vendors to manage product listings and inventories while enabling customers to participate in live bidding sessions for selected products. AI integration enables several advanced functionalities, including predictive analytics for inventory forecasting, fraud detection for transactional integrity, AI-driven customer support via chatbots, and personalized product recommendations. Experimental evaluation confirms the system's effectiveness, showing improved operational efficiency, optimized pricing dynamics, and elevated user interaction metrics. The architecture supports secure data transactions, role-based access control, and real-time updates through WebSocket communication. This study demonstrates the feasibility and impact of combining real-time bidding with AI technologies in a multi-vendor marketplace, laying a strong foundation for the development of intelligent, scalable, and adaptive e-commerce ecosystems.

title: Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HCAI): An Ethical Approach
authors: Sai Nikhil S, Shanthosh Babu R, N Priya, P Aruna
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HCAI) in virtual assistants enhances user interactions by fostering seamless communication between humans and machines. By integrating advanced AI algorithms and emotional intelligence, virtual assistants can understand user emotions, preferences, and behavior, ensuring more personalized and meaningful interactions. This approach prioritizes user needs, ethical AI principles, and transparency, allowing AI systems to respond effectively while maintaining human oversight. Ethical considerations in HCAI emphasize fairness, accountability, and data privacy, ensuring that AI-driven decisions are unbiased, explainable, and respectful of user autonomy. Through continuous training and adaptive learning, HCAI-driven virtual assistants aim to achieve the highest level of user satisfaction by providing context-aware, emotionally intelligent, and privacy-preserving responses while adhering to responsible AI development practices. This study compares Google Assistant and Siri using realworld queries and integrates OpenAI's Whisper for multilingual speech recognition. The setup evaluates accuracy and contextual understanding across English, Tamil, and Malayalam, highlighting the need for ethical, emotionallyaware AI systems.

title: Speech Recognition Using Deep Learning Techniques: A Comparative Study
authors: Hasini E, K Lokesh, Anilkumar P, Alluri Venkataramana, Madhanapalli Mahesh Kumar, D Prabhu Kumar
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems have undergone tremendous advancement over the last few years but remain challenged with errors in transcription and readability, particularly in spontaneous speech. In this paper, a hybrid ASR system that employs the T5 transformer model in postediting is introduced for improving transcription quality and coherence. Our methodology focuses on utilizing a conventional ASR pipeline to obtain preliminary transcripts followed by a fine-tuned version of the T5 model, which refines errors and makes the transcript readable. We experiment with the system on several corpora, producing significant gains in word error rate (WER) and linguistic clarity. Experimental metrics indicate that the hybrid method not only surpasses baseline ASR models in precision but also achieves greater readability, rendering it especially appropriate for realistic applications like subtitles, meeting records, and virtual assistants. Further, we also investigate the versatility of the model to accommodate variability in speaking behavior and domain terms. The system we suggest points towards the capabilities of transformer-based post-processing in transforming ASR output to make it more human-like and contextually correct. Our research also discusses the computational efficiency of the process, which ensures its practicality for real-time deployment. We also test the robustness of the model over various conditions of noise and speech accent and prove its generalizability.

title: A Comparative Study of Extractive Summarization Techniques
authors: Ashwathi Nair, Himanshu Agarwal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Due to time being a limited resource today, effective text summarisation is critical to quickly extract and present essential information from mass volumes of texts. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative study of five classical extractive summarization techniques—TextRank, LexRank, Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA), KL-Sum, and the Luhn algorithm. The study evaluates these methods on multiple dimensions, including content quality (measured by ROUGE and BERTScore), linguistic readability, processing<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> efficiency, and compression ratio. The results indicate that while graph-based methods (TextRank and LexRank) excel in semantic fidelity and content retention, frequency-based approaches such as Luhn and KL-Sum provide superior computational efficiency and are easier to read for users. These findings indicate that the choice of summarization technique should be driven by the specific constraints of the scenario in hand.

title: Monitoring of Urban Expansion Pressure on Peri-Urban Ecosystems in Taipei City, Taiwan
authors: Stephan van Gasselt
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: The metropolitan area of Taipei-Keelung-Taoyuan is home to 10 million people turning the region into one of the new global megacities. Despite dwindling birth rates and a super-aging society, urban expansion is increasing in both vertical and horizontal direction. The consequence of this expansion is an increased pressure on ecosystems in the city as well as on urban fringes and a decrease of ecosystem service provisions. This work presents a multitemporal estimation of built-up area dynamics and its impact on ecosystems along with its service provision for the Taipei City. The area was chosen as it forms and administrative island within the municpality of New Taipei City area which limits expansion. The mutlitemporal assessment is based on pixel classification of Landsat 5 Thematic Mapper and Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager data as well as on secondary data derivatives and indices with yearly time slices classified using a U-Net Deep Learning architecture combined with a ResNet50 backbone. The model training accuracy reaches 84 % over all training classes on average and provides consistent results for different time slices, presenting a granular picture complementing the Urban Centre Database grid assessment of human settlements. Results show a gradual increase in built-up area of 4.3 % over the last 25 years and a reduction of regulating ecosystems by approximately 8.8 % mainly in the periurban space.

title: Enhancing Wi-Fi Localization Through GAM-LDPL Modeling and Machine Learning for Scalable IoT Applications
authors: G Umamaheswari, A K Kowsalyadevi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Accurate Wi-Fi-based localization remains a challenge in dynamic IoT environments, where multipath propagation, non-line-of-sight (NLoS) conditions, and environmental variations degrade performance. To address these challenges, this study introduces a generalized additive model-log distance path loss (GAM-LDPL) formulation integrated with advanced machine learning (ML) models, including Random Forest (RF), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and hybrid CNNLSTM architectures. Data were collected using ESP32 devices for Wi-Fi measurements and DHT22 sensors for environmental monitoring, ensuring the inclusion of temperature and humidity. Experimental results demonstrate that the GAMLDPL model reduces localization errors by 30%, achieving a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 10.05 dB and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.93. Among ML approaches, RF provided the best trade-off between accuracy and efficiency, while K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN)-based fingerprinting achieved an average error of 4.09 m. The findings confirm that integrating environmental parameters with ML significantly enhances the accuracy, robustness, and scalability, thereby enabling reliable real-time localization for IoT applications.

title: Bridging Cryptographic Robustness and Hardware Efficiency: A Comprehensive Analysis of S-Box Design Methodologies for SoC Integration
authors: Maitri Iyer, Jai Gopal Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Symmetric-key cryptosystems depend on substitution boxes (S-boxes) for their main source of nonlinearity to enhance security against cryptanalysis. However, the design of S-boxes presents a fundamental challenge of balancing cryptographic properties with resource-efficient hardware implementation. The proposed article provides a comprehensive analysis of the design methodologies of contemporary S-boxes. It categorizes mathematically constructed, heuristic approaches to combinational logic and lookup table-based implementations. These methodologies are evaluated considering both classic security metrics such as nonlinearity and differential uniformity and crucial hardware efficiency metrics including area (gate count), circuit depth, and multiplicative complexity. Furthermore, the paper synthesizes the major open challenges in the field, such as the escalating complexity of achieving resistance against sidechannel attacks and the demanding constraints of lightweight cryptography. Finally, we outline promising future research directions, emphasizing the growing role of automation, machine learning, and application-specific co-design in advancing the development of secure and efficient S-boxes for next-generation computing systems.

title: An AHBF LED Driver With Improved Hybrid Control Strategy
authors: Wang Yapeng, Lin Weiming, Chen Hongxing, Chen Jiahui, Lin Songhui
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: The asymmetric half-bridge flyback (AHBF) converter is widely used in applications such as switch-mode power supplies (SMPS) and low-power chargers etc. However, excitation circulating current is easily induced in light-load conditions under conventional PWM control in the AHBF converter, which will lead to a reduction in efficiency. Owing to the advantages of SiC power devices-including smaller output capacitance ($C_{\text {oss }}$), no reverse recovery in the body diode, and high-frequency switching capability-this paper proposes a hybrid control strategy for the AHBF LED driver by further leveraging the unique characteristics of SiC devices (specifically stable resonant frequency and low voltage spike amplitude), wherein the switching frequency is reduced during light-load operation. Both upper and lower switches are controlled by a hybrid PWM/PFM scheme to initiate a free-resonance stage. Subsequently, zero-voltage switching (ZVS) turn-on of the main switch can be enabled by a short pulse applied to the clamp switch at the half-bridge voltage valley point to improve the light-load efficiency. The operating principles and operating process of the AHBF driver with the proposed control strategy are analyzed in detail. Key circuit and control parameters are thoroughly designed. Computer simulations were performed, a $160-\mathrm{W}$ prototype (40 -V/4-A output) was developed, and experimental results have been obtained to verify the feasibility of the AHBF LED driver with the proposed control strategy.

title: Comparative Assessment of Emerging Subsea Renewable Energy Technologies: A Data-Driven Systems Analysis
authors: C. V. Pavithra, AmalanJoseph J, Enbharajan M, Nantha Kumar S, Savitha S
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The global energy transition necessitates the integration of offshore and hybrid renewable energy systems to address challenges of sustainability, cost, and resource availability. This study develops a synthetic yet empirically anchored dataset for seven emerging offshore technologies—Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion (OTEC), offshore solar, tidal, wave, floating wind, piezoelectric harvesters, and subsea compressed air storage—across ten geographically diverse marine regions. Real-world anchors were obtained from the International Energy Agency (IEA), National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), and other authoritative databases to construct realistic techno-economic parameters such as Levelized Cost Of Energy (LCOE), Capital And Operational Expenditures (CAPEX/OPEX), Technology Readiness Levels (TRL), and sustainability indices. The analysis reveals that offshore solar and OTEC exhibit relatively stable long-term LCOE trajectories, while floating wind and subsea compressed air storage demonstrate the steepest cost-reduction slopes. Regionally, the Gulf of Mexico and Arabian Sea achieve the lowest average LCOEs, whereas the North Sea and South China Sea remain comparatively higher due to harsher installation and maintenance conditions. Correlation analysis further indicates weak but notable relationships between resource potential and LCOE, suggesting that resource abundance alone is insufficient to guarantee economic viability without supporting policies and technology maturation. The findings highlight the potential of hybridized offshore systems to balance sustainability and affordability, while also providing a reproducible framework for scenario analysis of emerging marine renewables between 2025 and 2050.

title: Real-Time IoT Intrusion Detection using Deep Learning with Uncertainty and Optimization Mechanism
authors: Hira Khan, Nadeem Javaid, Asmaa Ali, Nidal Nasser, AbdulAziz Al-Helali
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The increasing complexity and interconnectivity of Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystems have heightened the need for robust and intelligent intrusion detection mechanisms. However, the development of effective detection models is impeded by challenges such as imbalanced data distributions, limited availability of labeled samples, and the difficulty of tuning deep learning architectures to accommodate diverse threat patterns. In response to these challenges, this paper introduces two novel DenseNet-based frameworks, DN-UBS and DN-GBO, for advanced IoT intrusion detection. The proposed approach begins by applying a variance threshold technique on RT-IoT2022 dataset, to eliminate low-variance features, followed by synthetic minority oversampling technique to alleviate class imbalance and enhance minority class representation. DN-UBS integrates an uncertainty-based sampling strategy to iteratively select the most ambiguous instances for annotation, reducing labeling effort while improving model discriminability. In contrast, DN-GBO incorporates a gradient-based hyperparameter optimization using the hyperband strategy, allowing for automatic adjustment of network depth, learning rate, and regularization parameters. The DN-GBO achieved superior detection performance with an improvement of 7% in accuracy, 4% in F1-score, 12.8% in precision, 6 % in recall, 3 % in Receiver Operating CharacteristicArea Under the Curve (ROC-AUC), and 17.6 % in Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC). Similarly, DN-UBS also delivered high efficacy with an improvement of 5.3 % in accuracy, 3 % in F1-score, 3% in precision, 4.6% in recall, 4% in ROC-AUC, and 10.1 % in MCC, while minimizing reliance on labeled data. These findings highlight the effectiveness of the proposed models in delivering scalable, adaptive, and data-efficient solutions for securing IoT infrastructures against intrusive threats.

title: DMS4096+: Enhancing Cryptographic Strength and Efficiency through Advanced Key Generation
authors: Devansh Singh, Shlok Avatade, Minakshi Sonawane
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: In this paper, we present an upgraded version of Devansh, Minakshi, Shlok (DMS4096), which is DMS4096+, a significant enhancement of the previously proposed DMS4096 encryption algorithm. DMS4096+ addresses several limitations inherent in DMS4096 by introducing improvements in key generation, encryption speed, memory usage, and brute-force resistance. The new version maintains the robust 4096-bit key size but incorporates optimized techniques for faster encryption, key management, and improved computational efficiency. To evaluate the performance and security of DMS4096+, we conduct comprehensive experiments comparing it against AES-256, a widely recognized industry standard. Key performance metrics such as encryption time, brute-force resistance, memory usage, and storage size are analyzed. In particular, DMS4096+ demonstrates superior brute-force resistance, with a significantly higher time-to-crack than both AES-256 and the previous DMS4096 algorithm. Additionally, we compare DMS4096+’s key generation time, memory footprint, and encryption efficiency to show its practical viability in real-world applications. The results indicate that DMS4096+ offers not only a substantial increase in security but also notable performance enhancements, making it a strong candidate for use in systems requiring high levels of encryption. This paper discusses the design decisions behind DMS4096+, presents its cryptographic analysis, and highlights its improvements over DMS4096.

title: Device- and Location-Aware Client Clustering for Heterogeneous Federated Learning
authors: Maryam Ben Driss, Essaid Sabir
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The exponential increase in decentralized data generated by heterogeneous devices presents critical challenges for federated learning (FL), particularly in handling nonindependent and identically distributed (non-IID) data, limited client resources, and the preservation of privacy. Traditional FL approaches often suffer from prolonged training times, reduced accuracy, and high energy consumption due to uncoordinated client participation and data diversity. In this paper, we propose an advanced FL framework that strategically clusters clients based on multiple attributes, including data distribution patterns, device types, and geographic locations, to address these challenges. By leveraging this multi-dimensional clustering, our framework optimizes client selection processes, resulting in faster convergence, improved model accuracy, and enhanced energy efficiency. We benchmark our approach against random, roundrobin, and accuracy-based client selection strategies through extensive experiments. The results demonstrate notable improvements, including up to a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 0 9 \%}$</tex> decrease in model loss, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 8 \%}$</tex> boost in accuracy, a 20.6 % reduction in training duration, a 30.8 % cut in communication overhead, and a 25.5 % increase in energy efficiency compared to baseline methods. Our findings highlight the critical role of incorporating device heterogeneity and geographic context into client clustering for scalable, efficient, and privacy-preserving FL deployments.

title: FALCON: FPGA Accelerated Real-Time Intelligent Controller for Autonomous Systems
authors: Siwei Ye, Jintao Chen, Yehan Ma, An Zou
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: The growing complexity and stringent real-time demands of autonomous systems, such as self-driving cars and drones, have driven the adoption of intelligent control methods based on deep neural networks (DNNs). While these methods offer improved control performance over traditional modelbased approaches, they also pose significant computational challenges, particularly for resource-constrained platforms. FieldProgrammable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) offer an attractive solution due to their energy efficiency and customizable architecture. In this work, we propose FALCON, an innovative approach for designing real-time intelligent controllers for autonomous systems using FPGA accelerators. Our approach begins with designing DNN-based intelligent controllers with varying levels of complexity and accuracy on the FPGA platform. Then, a performance function is proposed to capture the interplay among controller complexity, computational behavior, physical system characteristics, and overall control performance. Based on this performance function, we develop an algorithm-hardware codesign framework to determine the optimal control complexity, hardware configuration, and resource allocation. Finally, a case study on the co-design of intelligent controllers and FPGAbased overlay processors, together with a hardware-in-the-loop simulator, is conducted to demonstrate the advantages of the proposed methods. Compared to benchmarking controllers on other platforms, FALCON's optimized intelligent controller using FPGA accelerators shows competitive control performance with superior real-time capability and power efficiency. FALCON's optimization reduces the worst-case response time (WCRT) by up to 46.52%, improves the control performance by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.93 \times$</tex> compared to the default setup. For performance per power efficiency, FALCON achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.67 \times$</tex> improvement compared to the DNN intelligent controller on TX2 and a remarkable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30.78 \times$</tex> improvement compared to traditional MPC on CPU.

title: AI-Enhanced Speech Processing Communication in Wind Energy Feedback Systems
authors: Mukhayyo Abdurakhmonova, Mukhlisa Sharakhmetova, Aziza Mirzanazarova, Ma'rufkhoja Nadjimkhodjaev, Mohira Yusupova, Otabek Safarbaev
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The rapid expansion of wind energy technologies has increased the demand for practical, lab-based training that prepares students and professionals with technical and communication skills essential for safe and efficient operations. In wind energy Feedback system labs, effective instructor–trainee communication is critical, particularly when dealing with complex procedures such as turbine maintenance, performance monitoring, and safety protocols. However, conventional communication methods are often hindered by noisy lab environments, technical jargon misunderstandings, and limited real-time feedback, resulting in reduced clarity and learning efficiency. To address this issue, the paper propose the AI-Enhanced Speech Processing for Wind Energy Feedback system (AISP-WEE) framework, which integrates speech recognition, noise reduction, domain-specific language modeling, and real-time feedback mechanisms to improve clarity and interaction. AISP-WEE employs advanced natural language processing and acoustic modeling to filter ambient noise, transcribe domain-specific instructions, and provide adaptive feedback through bilingual captions, alerts, and interactive prompts. Experimental evaluation in simulated wind lab environments demonstrated that AISP-WEE improved speech recognition accuracy by 28%, reduced communication errors by 33%, and enhanced trainee task performance by 24% compared to traditional verbal instruction methods. These results highlight the potential of AI-driven speech processing systems in improving both the effectiveness and accessibility of wind energy Feedback system. In conclusion, AISP-WEE offers a scalable, intelligent solution that enhances instructor–trainee communication, ensures safety, and fosters more effective experiential learning in renewable energy training environments.

title: Classification of Non-Line-of-Sight Scenarios Based on Dual-Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Shuo Cheng, Guangliang Cheng, Xianwei Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: Positioning technology has extensive applications in daily life, but signals can be obstructed by various indoor structures, thereby affecting accuracy. In this study, a novel neural network-based approach was proposed to classify line-of-sight (LOS) and non-line-of-sight (NLOS) scenarios using channel impulse response (CIR) amplitude signals from UWB devices. Data were collected from four sources, including personal measurements and three publicly available datasets, encompassing various indoor environments and obstacles. proposed method employs a dual-convolutional-block neural network architecture, consisting of a large convolution block to extract peak features and a small convolution block to capture inter-channel fluctuation. Additionally, a channel attention mechanism is incorporated to enhance feature learning and improve classification accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model consistently outperforms traditional machine learning algorithms (k-means, LS, SVM, RF, LSTM, MLP) and baseline CNN model across all datasets. The dual-convolutional-block network with channel attention achieved the highest classification accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-scores, with ROC-AUC values approaching or reaching 1.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning and Feature Fusion Framework for Robust Potato Leaf Disease Detection in Real-World Conditions
authors: Asmita Yadav, Hammad Javed, Akshat Kaw, Aditya Choudhary
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Plant diseases pose a significant threat to global food security, with potato crops being highly susceptible to fungal infections like Early Blight and Late Blight. While numerous studies have utilized convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to classify these diseases using image data, most models are trained on clean, ideal datasets and fail under real-world conditions. This paper proposes a robust hybrid model that integrates deep CNN features with handcrafted descriptors such as GLCM, HOG, and PCA for improved disease classification. A custom 4-class dataset is constructed, including a Non-Potato class to simulate practical field deployment scenarios. Experimental evaluations on both 3-class (standard) and 4-class (realistic) datasets show that the proposed hybrid architecture, combined with SMOTE and fine-tuned MLP classifiers, achieves superior performance in terms of accuracy and macro F1-score. The model achieved up to 98.0% accuracy on the 3-class dataset and 85.8% on the challenging 4-class dataset. Extensive ablation studies and feature importance analysis further validate the robustness and generalizability of the framework. This research contributes a scalable, interpretable, and real-world-ready AI solution for precision agriculture.

title: Observer-Based Practical Prescribed-Time Consensus Tracking Control for Multiagent Systems with Unknown Virtual Control Coefficients
authors: Jianhui Wang, Jiarui Liu, C. L. Philip Chen, Zhi Liu, Kairui Chen
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: This paper proposes an observer-based prescribed-time consensus tracking control method for nonlinear multiagent systems with unknown virtual control coefficients. Existing prescribed-time distributed observers require information about leader input dynamics, which is unavailable in many practical applications. To address the above issue, this paper proposes an improved prescribed-time strategy as a foundation. Then, an auxiliary system is constructed, which removes restrictions on leader input information. With the assistance of such a system, a distributed observer is synthesized, which enables a prescribed-time observation of leader state signals. Meanwhile, by decomposing the virtual control coefficient, a prescribed-time compensation law is investigated to handle nonlinear dynamics and unknown virtual control coefficients. In addition, a prescribed-time control protocol is formulated, which drives the stabilization of the multi-agent systems and the boundedness of all signals for any initial condition. Finally, the efficacy of the proposed control method is evaluated through simulation under three distinct conditions.

title: PADIIoT: On the Design of a PUF-based Authentication Scheme for Digital Twin Environments in Industrial IoT
authors: Siddhi Purohit, Neha Verma, Bhawna Narwal, Shivangi Batra
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Nuclear power plants are one of the most pregnable infrastructures of the country. Digital Twin (DT) technology has accrued burgeoning recognition for creating virtual models of physical systems like nuclear power plants. Within Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) setting, DT finds its applications in product design, predictive maintenance, and performance optimization. Our research exploits the dominant attributes of Physical Unclonable Function (PUF), fuzzy extractor (FE), and blockchain technology to propose a PUF-based Authentication Scheme (AS) for DT Environment in IIoT (PADIIoT). PADIIoT mutually authenticates the communicating entities involved in a nuclear power plant. Moreover, the security analysis indicates the effectiveness of PADIIoT against sundry attacks. Furthermore, the evaluation highlights the superior performance of PADIIoT in terms of computation and communication costs.

title: Application of Extended Anomaly Analysis in Renewable Energy Extreme Characterization
authors: Xin Zhao, Aobin Zhang, Naixin Duan, Jiliang Jin, Suoping Wang, Yuxing Tong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: In power systems with high renewable energy penetration, the extreme characterization of multiple consecutive low output days can critically undermine the long-term supplydemand balance of new power systems. In this paper, we define extreme energy scenarios of successive low output days using an extended anomaly metric, and we propose a recognition method that integrates extended anomaly analysis with run analysis, employing merging rules to consolidate interdependent extreme events. Finally, taking the daily utilization hours of photovoltaic generation in a region of China as a case study, we perform the extended anomaly analysis and successfully identify that region's extreme energy scenarios.

title: Edge Powered System for Latency-Sensitive Remote Health Informatics
authors: Ragaa Shehab
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Edge computing boosts telemedicine systems by moving away from reactive treatment to more preventive care. It improves the quality and continuity of healthcare while protecting the patient's privacy. This research presents an edge-powered system that detects the condition of cardiovascular disease patients and provides real-time diagnosis and treatment managed by consulting caregivers. We demonstrate how edge computing is a key enabling technology for latency sensitive remote health informatics applications, which aids in achieving highly regulated telemedicine applications. We propose a comprehensive control framework for remote patient monitoring. Furthermore, we examine the impact of distributing cardiovascular disease application modules across multiple edge layers. IFogSim was used to simulate the system under two modes of operation: pulse rate mode and ECG mode. In comparison to cloud-only systems, the results show a reduction of up to 80% in application loop delay, 90% in network usage, and 83% in energy consumption. Our simulation results also elucidate the importance of monitoring edge device utilization to avoid system underutilization or performance degradation of the critical health applications under fluctuated workloads.

title: A Random Forest Approach for Intelligent Vehicle Anomaly Detection and Safety Assurance
authors: Chandani S. Bartakke, Patil Sarang Maruti, Mukesh Kumar Gupta, Amit Tiwari, Himanshu Vasnani, Neny Pandel
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Ensuring safety and reliability in vehicles becomes challenging because traditional diagnostic systems often fail to detect real-time exceptions, leading to delayed responses or serious accidents in the era of intelligent vehicle systems. In this paper, we address this issue with a novel approach based on the Random Forest (RF) method for an interpretable and lightweight anomaly detection framework. The model utilizes four key input features—vehicle speed, engine temperature, brake pressure, and steering angle and predicts abnormal vehicle behavior in real-time. With an accuracy of 94% and an OOB error of 0.22, the model demonstrates good generalization and low variance. According to Gini feature importance, engine temperature is the most significant predictor (importance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx$</tex> 0.75), followed by speed (importance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.15$</tex>) and brake pressure (importance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx \mathbf{0. 1}$</tex>), which contribute to a lesser extent. Our approach performs competitively with recent advanced models, including CNN, LSTM, and XGBoost, offering advantages of interpretability and lower computational costs. The originality of this work lies in its usefulness for real-time construction processes by being reliable and providing explanatory insights through visualizations such as feature importance plots, prediction confidence curves, and convergence graphs. Due to its ability to both classify and explain anomalous predictions, our model can be easily deployed for smart vehicles, autonomous systems, or preventive maintenance applications, significantly enhancing road safety and vehicle health.

title: The Role of Literature in Teaching English as a Foreign Language with the Help of Digital Educational Games
authors: Evangelia-Anastasia Tsilakou, Yorghos Voutos, Anna Sotiropoulou, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: The use of literature in foreign language learning has been largely disputed over the last decades as not being necessary or even as being a hindrance for the learners since it makes no contribution to the purpose of learning a language for practical use. However, lately there has been a turn towards using authentic material in the classrooms and literature provides such a resource. But young children and teenagers seem to have lost interest in reading books since they prefer digital media. So, how can a teacher use literary texts without discouraging their students from studying them? Technology has come to help. Multimodal texts and digital educational games have received increasing attention in recent years as research shows that they affect students’ learning and motivation. They stimulate the students’ imagination and promote skills such as problem solving and collaboration. They help students develop multiliteracies such as visual literacy, cultural literacy, information literacy and critical literacy. In this paper we shall focus on the main steps to consider in this process.

title: Hybrid Framework for Hinglish to English Machine Translation using Multi-lingual Transformers for Social Media Discourse
authors: Sanjeev Rao, Arshjeet Singh
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: In India, over 19,500 dialects with 121 major languages are spoken, making accurate communication challenging, thus highlighting the need for effective translation solutions. The existing machine translation systems are often inaccurate and face challenges due to limited or insufficient linguistic data and research for low-resource and code-mixed languages, such as Hinglish. To improve the translation of Hinglish low-resource language, to standard English, we propose a neural machine translation framework comprising four major steps: dataset acquisition, text normalization and pre-processing, translation using multi-lingual transformers, and performance evaluation. The experimentation is performed on two varying-size datasets representing social media discourse: Hinglish-TOP (10896 instances) and PHINC (13738 instances). The datasets are normalized, preprocessed, and passed to the proposed translation system. The translation system comprises Google Cloud Translation API (GAPI), mBART, and MarianMT multi-lingual transformers. The GAPI leverages Google’s pre-trained or translation-focused large language models (LLMs) to offer the scalability, ease of use, and cost-effectiveness of Google Cloud’s infrastructure. The quality of the translation is evaluated using recent evaluation metrics such as BLEU, METEOR, and WER scores. The proposed GAPI+mBART approach obtains better results than existing machine translation techniques/approaches, i.e., an average BLEU score of 0.342, an average METEOR score of 0.512, and 0.692 WER on the PHINC dataset. Also, the proposed GAPI+mBART approach performed better than the proposed GAPI+MarianMT approach on Hinglish-TOP datasets

title: Random Forest-Based Approximation for Quantized CNNs on Edge FPGAs
authors: Yasuyuki Suzuki, Hiroshi Saito, Shogo Semba, Yoichi Tomioka, Takahiro Hanyu
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: One promising approach to accelerating AI processing on edge devices is the use of Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs). However, edge devices often face constraints such as low power consumption and restricted physical space, making AI model compression essential. To address this, we propose an approximate search method for Quantized Convolutional Neural Networks (QCNNs) using Random Forests (RF). The proposed method identifies layers that can be approximated within given accuracy requirements, while taking into account the number of operations relevant to FPGA implementation. In our experiments, the proposed method was applied to five QCNN models, and the resulting approximated QCNN models were implemented on an FPGA. We demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method through evaluations of circuit area, execution time, dynamic power consumption, and energy consumption.

title: GCNIM: A Booth-6T-SRAM Based Graph-Convolutional-Networks-in-Memory Computing Macro
authors: Yan Yan, Zhaoyang Zhang, Shaochen Li, Defa Wu, Jun Yang, Xin Si
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Computing-in-memory (CIM) architectures have demonstrated great potential in accelerating convolutional neural networks (CNNs) because of its breakthrough in the traditional von-Neumann architecture. However, deploying Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) on CIM architectures faces several challenges. In this paper, we presents a Booth 6T-SRAM based GCN-in-memory (GCNIM) computing macro using: 1) a cell bank with aggregation storage arrays (ASAs) and local booth computing arrays (LBCAs) to improve energy and area efficiency under weight bit sparsity condition; 2) feature input encoding drivers (FIEDs) to encode the input according to Booth algorithm requirements; 3) Subgraph dividing and adjacency matrix stationary to mitigate the input sparsity and irregularity; 4) reconfigurable data bit-width mechanism that adapts to the complexity. A split-word line structured Booth-6T-SRAM was used at the hardware level to achieve an energy efficiency of 45.54 TOPS/W. GCNIM achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times$</tex> better speed and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.24 \times$</tex> better energy efficiency compared with previous work.

title: Adaptive DQN: An Enhanced Approach for Robot Path Planning in Dynamic Environments
authors: Wenxing Wang, Yingge Li, Defa Han
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: Deep Q-Networks (DQN) have achieved remarkable success in solving complex control tasks but their performance is sensitive to the stability of the target network and learning efficiency. This paper proposes an enhanced algorithm that combines the Dueling DQN architecture with an adaptive target network update mechanism. The mechanism dynamically adjusts the update frequency of the target network based on the Bellman error and Q-value stability, thereby improving the stability and performance of the training process. Experimental results in the CartPole-v1 environment show that the Adaptive DQN outperforms both Fixed DQN and Dueling DQN in terms of average reward and stability. Specifically, the Adaptive DQN achieves average rewards that are 88.11% and 36.58% higher than Fixed DQN and Dueling DQN, respectively. Moreover, the average Bellman error of Adaptive DQN is reduced by 84.25% compared to Fixed DQN and by 82.91% compared to Dueling DQN. In path planning tasks within the FrozenLake-v1 environment, Adaptive DQN also demonstrates superior success rates and stability. It achieves a success rate of 0.015, which is significantly higher than the 0.008 for Fixed DQN and 0.008 for Dueling DQN. Additionally, the path length planned by Adaptive DQN is notably shorter at 25 steps, compared to 33 steps for Fixed DQN and 81 steps for Dueling DQN. In the continuous maze environment, Adaptive DQN effectively mitigates ineffective exploration behaviors in robotic path planning, enhancing the efficiency of reaching the target point. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the Adaptive DQN in enhancing the efficiency and stability of path planning.

title: A Stackelberg Game of Demand Response from the Aggregator's Perspective
authors: Seangleng Khe, Parin Chaipunya, Athikom Bangviwat
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate on the modeling of demand response activities between a single aggregator and multiple participating consumers. The model incorporates the Stackelberg game structure that naturally occurs in the information structure and decision sequence, where the aggregator assumes the role of a leader and the participating consumers play the role of followers. The aggregator aims to reduce the most electricity consumption during on-peak hours so that it can obtain most commission and similarly, the consumers aim to save some electricity bills and get more rewards. The proposed model is demonstrated to be effective in load control, helping the aggregator to meet the target reduction while the consumers pay a cheaper electricity bill. We also discuss a way to incorporate fairness into all consumers with a tradeoff for the profit and the performance.

title: Raspberry PI-Based IoT System for Real-Time Patient Monitoring and Early Health Detection
authors: Chenduran A, R Saravanakumar, Pankaj Sharma
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Remote health monitoring systems are increasingly being adopted in India and other countries to monitor patients health indicators using the Internet of Things (IoT). The proposed system facilitates continuous monitoring of vital signs, including body temperature and blood pressure, in both residential and clinical environments. By employing Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, it ensures seamless connectivity and real-time health data acquisition. The Raspberry Pi is a compact tool that records and displays data from the monitoring process, which can be shared with patients and their families via IoT networks. This integration bridges the physical and digital worlds, providing convenience and peace of mind for patients and their families.

title: Unsharp-Inspired Adversarial Point Cloud Perturbation Via Low-Rank Approximation
authors: Kyo Seok Lee, Han-nyoung Lee, Hak Gu Kim
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) for 3D point cloud recognition have achieved remarkable performance, but remain highly vulnerable to adversarial perturbations. Existing adversarial methods often suffer from a trade-off between imperceptibility and attack strength, either producing noticeable outliers or requiring excessive point displacements. In this paper, we propose a novel unsharp-inspired adversarial perturbation that leverages low-rank approximation to balance global structure preservation and fine-detail manipulation. Specifically, the point cloud is decomposed via eigenvalue decomposition (EVD) into global and residual components, where the low-rank reconstruction captures the overall shape and the residual highlights salient details. Perturbations are then selectively applied to these fine-detail regions and smoothed according to local magnitude and orientation, ensuring geometric consistency. Extensive experiments on ModelNet40 and ShapeNet-Part using PointNet and DGCNN demonstrate that our method achieves 100% attack success rate while significantly reducing geometric distortion compared to state-of-the-art methods. These results highlight the effectiveness of spectral-domain low-rank modeling for generating adversarial point clouds that are both strong and imperceptible.

title: SAR-UMSDN: The Unsupervised Multimodal Ship Detection Network Based on SAR Images
authors: Junpeng Ai, Liang Luo, Shijie Wang, Liandong Hao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In response to the problems faced by synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images in detecting ships in complex near-shore scenarios, such as low signal-to-noise ratio of small targets and limited feature representation capacity of a single SAR mode, and also due to the fact that real optical images in near-shore areas are often affected by conditions like clouds and day/night, and thus difficult to be real-time registered with SAR images. We propose an unsupervised multimodal SAR image ship detection network (SAR-UMSDN) with its performance enhanced by deriving multimodal inputs from SAR data. SAR-UMSDN consists of a self-supervised SAR image enhancement network (URSIEN), SAR colorization module based on generative adversarial networks (cGAN4ColSAR), and multimodal detection model. URSIEN performs unlabeled illumination–reflection decoupling and detail restoration to enhance the original SAR image, while cGAN4ColSAR maps the single-channel SAR image onto a pseudo-color image with rich optical textures. We use images of these two modalities as inputs to the multimodal SAR-UMSDN for ablation tests, model comparisons, and other evaluations. URSIEN achieves a peak signal-to-noise ratio of 28.63 dB and inference speed of 0.0017 s for a model size of 0.4 million parameters, improving most indicators compared with other image enhancement models. After applying URSIEN, the mean average precision at 0.5 (mAP@0.5) of SAR-UMSDN is 0.4% higher than that of the baseline model, and after using cGAN4ColSAR, mAP@0.5 is 1.9% higher than that of the baseline model. The combined effect of the two components improves the SAR-UMSDN mAP@0.5 to 93.5%. SAR-UMSDN outperforms 10 baseline models and 7 state-of-the-art models, with its mAP@0.5–0.95 (67.4%) being superior to that of traditional single-modal and mainstream baseline models, showing improvements of 1.4–2.7%. The generalization experiments conducted on six public ship datasets have shown that SAR-UMSDN has a significant advantage in ship detection within SAR images. The relevant data and code are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/MARCH442529/SAR-UMSDN</uri>.

title:

                    -Guard: An Adaptive Decision Fusion Framework for Cloud-Native Threat Detection
authors: Zihao Lin, Weiyong Zhang, Hao Liu, Hui Lu, Zhihong Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing
abstract: Traditional threat detection systems fail in dynamic cloud-native environments, primarily due to their inability to resolve the inherent trade-off between high-precision detection of known attacks and high-recall discovery of unknown threats. We propose D3-Guard, a novel framework whose core innovation lies in a dynamic decision fusion engine grounded in Bayesian decision-theoretic principles. The engine computes a similarity score from incoming requests to serve as a real-time contextual signal for the Bayesian framework. It then uses this signal directly as a dynamic weight to adaptively integrate the outputs of two complementary expert models: a high-precision LSTM-Attention for known patterns and a high-recall Isolation Forest for unknown threats. This synergy, reinforced by an adaptive update layer to mitigate concept drift, achieves F1-scores of 99.39% and 96.97% on the CSIC 2010 and ATRDF 2023 datasets, respectively. Performance tests in a production-like environment further validate its practical viability, demonstrating that this high accuracy is achieved with a justifiable overhead. An ablation study highlights the pivotal role of our fusion engine: disabling it results in a sharp decline in F1-score on the ATRDF 2023 dataset, from 96.97% to 11.47%, demonstrating its critical contribution to robust, dual-model collaboration.

title: Triple Collocation-Based Error Evaluation of FY-3G MWRI-RM and FY-3F MWRI-II Brightness Temperatures_supp1-3649405.docx
authors: Ji Zhou
publish: N/A
abstract: The recent launch of the Chinese FengYun-3G/3F (FY-3G/3F) satellites provides new opportunities for Earth observation enabled by their unique combination of non-sun-synchronous and sun-synchronous orbits. This study provides the first comprehensive evaluation of the Level-1 brightness temperature (BT) products from both the FY-3G MWRI-RM and FY-3F MWRI-II microwave imagers. Using a globally collocated dataset with the GPM Microwave Imager (GMI) as the reference, we assess the radiometric consistency through direct comparison and quantify the random errors of using the Triple Collocation (TC) method. Results show that both two sensors have high consistency and low systematic bias, with Mean Bias Deviations (MBD) generally below 1.0 K and Root Mean Square Deviations (RMSD) of lower than 3.0 K for most channels. Nevertheless, the TC results uncover a significant performance divergence in their random errors, particularly over land. Specifically, MWRI-II exhibits a high level of performance, with an overall Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) over barren land of 0.72 K, compared to 0.82 K for GMI. In contrast, while the MWRI-RM performs well over oceans, its TC-derived errors are substantially larger over vegetated land, reaching a peak RMSE of 4.67 K. The findings from this study suggest that the FY-3F MWRI-II BT has good potential in a wide range of scientific applications, while the FY-3G MWRI-RM BT, though valuable for oceanic studies, requires substantial refinement of its land surface processing to realize its full potential.

title: Secure Distributed Threshold Decryption Scheme for Electronic Personal Health Records Sharing System
authors: Isaac Amankona Obiri, Qi Xia, Jianbin Gao, Hu Xia, Yangyang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: The growing adoption of electronic personal health records (ePHRs) demands cryptographic solutions that ensure secure and efficient data access. Threshold cryptography provides a framework for controlled multi-party access, yet existing schemes face practical limitations. Many require trusted key dealers, creating single points of failure and key escrow vulnerabilities, while others rely on pairing-based constructions that scale poorly. Furthermore, batch-oriented processing in previous schemes fails to support individual on-demand access patterns typical in healthcare applications. We propose a Distributed Identity-Based Threshold Decryption (DIBTD) scheme that addresses these limitations. First, our protocol removes all trusted setup assumptions through a fully distributed key generation mechanism based on verifiable secret sharing. Second, it achieves constant-time encryption and decryption operations, independent of committee size, by using efficient elliptic curve operations on secp256k1 rather than computationally heavy pairings, yielding up to 56× faster encryption than prior work. Third, DIBTD integrates the detection of malicious actors via zero-knowledge proofs, allowing the dynamic exclusion of compromised participants during system initialization. We provide formal security proofs showing the security of IND-CCA2 in the random oracle model under the discrete logarithm of the elliptic curve (ECDLP) and computational Diffie-Hellman (CDH) assumptions. The scheme remains secure against adaptive adversaries that control up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$t-1$</tex-math></inline-formula> participants. Experimental evaluation demonstrates practical efficiency: ciphertexts of only 86 bytes, constant 33-byte public keys, and sub-millisecond encryption latency. A pure Rust implementation on commodity hardware achieves 0.065ms per patient record while maintaining 128-bit security.

title: ISAR Imaging of Maneuvering Targets Via GRFT-MNPSO Algorithm
authors: Jin Wei, Yicheng Jiang, Bin Liu, Zitao Liu, Siming Li
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: In ISAR imaging of maneuvering targets, time-varying Doppler frequency and range cell migration pose challenges for obtaining focused ISAR images. To address these issues, an imaging algorithm called General Radon Fourier Transform-Modified Niching Particle Swarm Optimization (GRFT-MNPSO) with low computational complexity is proposed. First, this algorithm employs NPSO to distribute particles around the potential peaks of the received signal in the GRFT domain for preliminary search. Then, a hierarchical clustering algorithm is used to cluster these particles around each peak to form subpopulations. Subsequently, GRFT-PSO is applied to each subpopulation to refine the peak locations in the GRFT domain. Based on the estimated peak locations, high-quality ISAR images can be constructed. The proposed algorithm has low computational complexity while maintaining diversity, convergence and estimation accuracy, and performs well even in low SNR conditions. Experiments on both simulated and real data demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed algorithm.

title: Quantum Error Correction for 2nd Generation Quantum Repeaters
authors: Dawei Jiao, Mahdi Bayanifar, Alexei Ashikhmin, Olav Tirkkonen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Quantum Engineering
abstract: We consider 2nd generation (2G) Quantum Repeaters (QR) for creating long-distance entanglement in quantum networks. Combining a distance-dependent depolarizing error model with the non-local Bell-state purification procedure required by 2G QRs leads to an error model consisting of correlated and biased errors. To correct correlated errors, non-symmetric CSS codes with joint decoding between stations can be used. The dominating errors are biased, such that different repeater stations suffer from different types of errors. To mitigate this, different quantum codes can be used at the stations, optimized for the specific error model of the station. To comply with the 2G QR procedure, the codes used in neighboring stations must allow for the transversal implementation of non-local logical CNOT gates across the two stations, or alternatively, non-local CZ gates combined with logical Hadamards. We provide a complete characterization of pairs of Calderbank-Steane-Shor (CSS) codes that allow CNOT- or CZ-transversality, and examine an explicit family of mirrored CSS codes allowing CZ-transversality. We verify the Hadamard gate transversality using our framework and show the importance of the mapping matrix. Also, we conclude that using different QECCs can not achieve transversal universal computation with Clifford + <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$T$</tex-math></inline-formula>-gate set. Finally, we study the entanglement generation rate (EGR) in 2G QRs with limited quantum memory, minimizing the number of intermediate stations for a given fidelity and EGR. By simulation we observe that non-symmetric and mirrored structure QECCs outperform the conventional approach of using symmetric CSS codes at the repeater stations.

title: STISA: A 0.16-GOPS/W/PE Single-Shot Inference FPGA-Based SNN Accelerator With Algorithm and Hardware Co-Design
authors: Kainan Wang, Chengyi Yang, Lei Liu, Chengting Yu, Yee Sin Ang, Bo Wang, Aili Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) offer great potential for low-power intelligent computing owing to their event-driven nature, yet their deployment is limited by high inference latency and inefficient hardware utilization caused by temporal dependencies. Existing accelerators struggle to balance timesteps, accuracy, and energy efficiency, while hardware-oriented timestep compression remains underexplored. To address these challenges, this work presents STISA, a unified algorithm-hardware co-design framework featuring: 1) a Temporal Splitter Compression (TSC) technique with a Temporal Split Structure (TSS) to reduce temporal redundancy while preserving network dynamics; 2)a hardware-efficient spatiotemporal parallelism scheme, which co-optimizes dataflow and architecture through a Temporal-Prioritized Output-Stationary (TPOS) mapping and a flexible Block-Mux Streaming (BMS) architecture; and 3) a joint TSC-TPOS-BMS co-optimization framework featuring a bandwidth-aware resource allocation strategy to achieve balanced accuracy, latency, and energy efficiency across diverse network architectures. On the algorithmic side, TSC reduces synaptic operations by 24.44%-51.71% while achieving competitive accuracies of 96.38%, 81.10%, 68.51%, and 82.40% on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, ImageNet, and DVS-CIFAR10, respectively. On the hardware side, FPGA prototypes deliver up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$7.99\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> speedup, 30.4% power reduction, and 30.1% LUT reduction. Compared with state-of-the-art SNN accelerators, STISA achieves 0.16 GOPS/W/PE, demonstrating its scalability and superior energy efficiency for real-time SNN inference under constrained hardware resources.

title: A Delay-Free Adaptive Stepsize for the Incremental Aggregated Gradient Method
authors: Zhicheng Deng, Xuyang Wu, Jie Lu
publish: IEEE Control Systems Letters
abstract: In most existing asynchronous methods, the stepsize depends on an upper bound on the delays and decreases as this bound increases. However, since the upper bound is usually unknown and large, the resulting stepsizes are not only difficult to determine in practice but also overly conservative, which leads to slow convergence. To solve this issue, we propose an adaptive stepsize strategy for a typical asynchronous optimization method—the Incremental Aggregated Gradient (IAG) method. Unlike existing methods in the literature, our stepsize does not rely on any delay information and is less conservative, which leads to easier stepsize determination and faster convergence. Under standard assumptions, we provide the convergence rate of IAG with the proposed stepsize. Numerical experiments demonstrate the superior performance of our stepsize over alternative stepsize strategies.

title: Transient Stability Analysis for DC-link Voltage Synchronization Grid-Forming Converter Considering Frequency-Related Varying Inertia and Internal Voltage
authors: Zhen Tian, Pan Feng, Meng Huang, Junyang Liang, Yangjian Ling, Xilin Li, Xiaoming Zha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: As the penetration of inverter-based resources (IBRs) increases rapidly, the power system's transient stability is facing severe challenges. Grid-forming converters (GFMC) with voltage-frequency support capability are in urgent need of investigation. Conventional power-synchronization based GFMCs need a constant DC-link voltage (DV), which is not always available. DV synchronization control (DVSC) that can spontaneously maintain constant DV has better adaptability in practice. However, the transient stability of DVSC-based GFMC is relatively complicated and has been rarely studied due to its frequency-related varying inertia and internal voltage. In this paper, the kinetic and potential energy of DVSC-based GFMC is analytically deduced, which captures the impact of frequency-related varying inertia and internal voltage. Based on equal area criterion (EAC), the transient stable boundary of DVSC-based GFMC is accurately quantified through an iterative method. Further, the influence of different control parameters on transient stability is revealed. Experimental results verify the effectiveness of the transient stability analysis results.

title: Beyond IoT: AGI as a Transformative Solution for the Internet of Everything and Relationship Explosion
authors: Wenwei Mao, Yujia Lin, Jiabo Xu, Lingfeng Mao, Jianguo Ding, Huansheng Ning, Mahmoud Daneshmand
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: This review explores the evolution from IoT to the Internet of Everything (IoX) within the cyber-physical-social-thinking (CPST) hyperspace, centering on the emerging challenge of ”relationship explosion.” As interconnected systems grow in scale and complexity, the exponential proliferation of internal (e.g., device coordination, data aggregation) and cross-space (e.g., streaming, translating, adapting) relationships leading to scalability, security, and real-time processing challenges. Through a systematic literature review guided by five research questions, we analyze how this relational explosion intensifies across IoX domains—spanning IoT, IoP, and IoTk—and undermines the efficacy of Artificial Narrow Intelligence (ANI) in managing dynamic, heterogeneous environments. This review proposes that Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) offers a transformative solution, enabling adaptive reasoning, cognitive firewalls, and unified decision-making to navigate complex relationship networks. AGI-driven methodologies enhance system resilience, security, and efficiency in aggregating, moderating, and evolving relationships across CPST spaces. The paper outlines a classification of relationship types, evaluates AGI’s advantages over ANI, and proposes a future research roadmap emphasizing ethical governance, human-AGI collaboration, and sustainable architectures. By framing IoX development around the management of relationship explosion, we provide a roadmap for future research, emphasizing interdisciplinary efforts, ethical governance, and sustainable frameworks to foster intelligent, socially aware IoX ecosystems.
