title: A Gate Driver Generating Line-by-Line Sweep Signal for μ -LED Displays With Oxide Thin-Film Transistors
authors: Seungmin Woo, Jaein Noh, Seungho Lee, Seongcheol Moon, Solbee Lee, Jin Jang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This article proposes an oxide gate driver circuit capable of simultaneously generating line-by-line sweep signal. The proposed circuit supports the scan generation (SC) and sweep generation (SW) parts. A linearly decreasing sweep signal is generated with the thin-film transistors (TFTs) with various threshold voltages (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\textit{V}_{\text {TH}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> by introducing <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\textit{V}_{\text {TH}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> compensation. The proposed gate driver circuit can operate with the oxide TFTs showing depletion mode. We measured the pixel current driven by the sweep signal generated in the proposed circuit. The measured data on pulsewidth and falling time of the pixel currents match the simulation results. The results confirm that the proposed circuit can generate a sweep signal for micro-light-emitting diode (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-LED) display.

title: Enhancing Cost Efficiency in Serverless Computing via AI-Based Optimization Techniques
authors: Santhosh Kumar Somarapu, Munish Kumar
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Serverless computing has become a convenient and economic way to deliver contemporary applications. Nevertheless, it is still confronted by several bottlenecks, including underutilization of resources, high latency, and cold start. In this paper, we present an innovative AI-powered optimization framework that aims to improve the cost-effectiveness and performance for serverless systems. The framework leverages dynamic workload prediction, function scheduling, and resource provisioning machine learning algorithms to... Intelligently orchestrate serverless queries. Experiment results show that the proposed approach significantly outperforms traditional static provisioning and heuristic scheduling schemes in terms of cost (less than 30% reduction), latency (both for warm and cold start), cold start frequency, throughput and resource utilization. These findings suggest AI-driven approaches to fill the gaps found in existing serverless infrastructures to promote effective and reactive cloud-native applications.

title: Differential Impacts of Large-Scale Electric Vehicle Charging and Battery Swapping Modes on Grid Load Dispatchability Potential
authors: Xiaoyu Zhao, Wenping Qin, Wenbo Zhang, Jie Wang, Anting Zhao, Boyang Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The rapid development of large-scale electric vehicle (EV) deployment poses new challenges for grid load dispatch, where the distinct characteristics of charging and battery-swapping modes directly influence the system's dispatchable potential. This study conducts a quantitative analysis of their differential impacts on distribution networks through comparative assessment of load profiles. The methodology comprises: (1) constructing a trip chain-based EV operation forecasting model to characterize vehicle travel distances and energy consumption; (2) developing separate models-a charging station load prediction model and a battery-swap station scheduling model-to simulate the dynamic load characteristics of each mode; (3) performing simulation analysis on the IEEE 33node test system under three scenarios (pure charging, pure swapping, and hybrid configuration) to comparatively evaluate nodal load and voltage fluctuation patterns. The research elucidates the differential mechanisms through which charging/swapping modes affect grid dispatchability, providing theoretical support for distribution network planning with highpenetration EV integration.

title: A Wind Power Prediction Model Based on GRU_LSTM Model Optimized by HPO Algorithm
authors: Selamawit Mesfin Bogale, Xu Minghai, Fan Wenli, Ding Mengxiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the rapid development and increasing adoption of wind power, its growing contribution to energy supply introduces significant challenges due to output uncertainty, which may lead to cascading turbine disconnections from the grid. To address this critical issue, we propose an enhanced K-means_HPO_GRU_LSTM prediction model that combines K-means clustering analysis with Hunter-Prey Optimization (HPO) and GRU_LSTM networks. The model first performs high-dimensional clustering of input data using K-means to identify optimal data subsets, then employs HPO to automatically optimize the parameters of the GRU_LSTM prediction model. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that this integrated approach achieves substantially higher prediction accuracy compared to conventional wind power forecasting methods.

title: Adaptive AI-Based Skill Development Platform for EV Maintenance and Diagnostics Training
authors: Grandhi Sai Guptha, Yashasvi Tumuluri, G Vasanti, Sarika R Sagar, Komal Shyamrao Gagare, Pankaj B Devre
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The demands of the emerging, continuous maintenance and diagnostic requirements of electric vehicle (EV) technicians require advanced training programs to be effective. The nature of EV systems is complex, data-intensive, and it is no longer effective to employ traditional training methods. Traditional methods are based on static manuals, ineffective lab training opportunities, and similarly constructed learning opportunities for training implementation beyond the requirements of the speed of technological change. These situational and contextual issues create knowledge gaps and contribute to ineffective skill acquisition. The ASDIDT (Adaptive Skill Development and Intelligent Diagnostics Training) framework is suggested as a method for resolving these challenges. This framework utilizes AI, adaptive learning algorithms, and simulations to provide a tailored and constantly changing training environment. Furthermore, ASDIDT draws upon real-time diagnostic data from EVs and concurrently alters its training modules according to performance. Technicians can develop their skills with an AI-enabled simulation, a customized learning path, and diagnostic tools in the proposed platform. This ensures that the development of the EV workforce can be flexible and ramped up. The findings indicate that ASDIDT helps to establish a skill, highly-trained, future-ready EV workforce through enhanced learning retention, reduced training time, and improved precision of EV diagnosis and maintenance capabilities.

title: NoSQL Databases: Models, Architectures, and Trends for Scalable Data Management
authors: Elias Dritsas, Maria Trigka, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: The increasing heterogeneity, volume, and velocity of modern data have exposed fundamental limitations in traditional relational database management systems (RDBMS), fueling the widespread adoption of Not Only Structured Query Language (NoSQL) databases. This survey provides a comprehensive examination of NoSQL systems and offers a structured analysis of their design motivations, classification schemes, architectural models, and performance characteristics. We explored how different storage engines, consistency models, and replication strategies shape system behavior under diverse workloads. A comparative study of benchmark results across representative NoSQL platforms is presented, complemented by a domain-driven mapping of use cases to database categories, which bridges architectural insights with deployment-centric perspectives. Additionally, we highlight the ongoing research challenges related to interoperability, security, and intelligent query processing. This study aims to serve as a reference and decision-support tool for researchers and practitioners navigating the evolving NoSQL landscape.

title: Investigation Of Avalanche Robustness On Different JFET Region Designs Of SiC MOSFET
authors: Jianhua Shen, Yibo Zhang, Xiaoyan Tang, Qingwen Song, Hao Yuan, Chenyu Wang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) planar-gate MOSFETs can achieve relatively higher robustness as the gate oxide is shielded from the high electric field by the underneath p -well regions in blocking state. The design of JFET region influences both the device’s characteristic and reliability.The electric fieldshielding effect is greatly enhanced when the distance between the two adjacent p -well regions ($\mathrm{W}_{\text {JFet }}$) is reduced. However, this can aggravate the conduction performance of SiC planar-gate MOSFETs as the narrow JFET region contributes a large proportion of device resistance in conduction mode. SiC MOSFETs are used as power switches in circuits without clamp protection, which results in the device operating in avalanche mode. In this work, the effects of JFET region width on the avalanche reliability of 1200 V planar gate SiC MOSFET devices with narrow JFET region designs were investigated. The avalanche capability of the devices with the different JFET region widths was compared through the unclamped inductive switching (UIS) tests. The results show that the device of $\mathrm{W}_{\text {JFET }}=1.6 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ has the weakest avalanche robustness. TCAD simulation demonstrate that the primary failure mechanism of the devices is the source metal melting. When the $\mathrm{W}_{\text {JFet }}$ less than $1.6 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, the proportion of P+ region decreases, leading the avalanche current density increases. The enhanced electrical stress causes the weaken avalanche robustness. The current path during the avalanche process shifts from the bottom of the P+ region to the corner region of the P -well as the $\mathrm{W}_{\mathrm{JFet}}$ more than $1.6 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. This shift leads to a relocation of the internal hotspot, which is the primary reason for the enhanced avalanche capability of the devices.

title: Trust Verification in Connected Vehicles Using Unsupervised Variational Autoencoder
authors: Ramzi Boutahala, Hacène Fouchal, Marwane Ayaida, Shiwen Mao
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Connected and Automated Mobility (CCAM) is undergoing a paradigm shift, with safety and efficiency increasingly dependent on connectivity. Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C-ITS) support this transformation by enabling the exchange of Cooperative Awareness Messages (CAMs) between vehicles and roadside infrastructure. These messages, transmitted periodically at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 - 1 0 ~ H z}$</tex>, must be digitally signed in compliance with ETSI standards using Pseudonym Certificates (PCs). However, this security process introduces a significant overhead, as the size of the security data can be up to three times larger than the CAM payload, thereby consuming a considerable portion of the communication channel bandwidth. In this paper we propose a new authentication scheme based on deep learning. Instead of exchanging signed CAMs every time, the vehicles will authenticate each other once to establish cluster-based trust relationships, and then they will exchange only unsigned CAMs during the cluster lifetime. To ensure security within the cluster, an unsupervised variational autoencoder analyzes vehicle behavior to detect anomalies and confirm that each vehicle remains the same entity originally authenticated. Through simulations using OMNeT++, SUMO, and Artery, our method achieved a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{48.9 \%}$</tex> reduction in the volume of messages exchanged between vehicles, significantly decreasing communication channel overhead.

title: Predetermined-Time Output Projective Synchronization of Coupled Fuzzy Neural Networks via Generalized Exponential Function
authors: Ting Liu, Shiwen Xie, Yongfang Xie, Peng Liu, Tingwen Huang
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: The main motivation of this paper arises from the fact that some complex systems have high demands for time precision, which need to reach the desired state in a pre-specified time interval. This paper addresses the predetermined-time output projective synchronization of coupled fuzzy neural networks. To mimic the uncertainty and relatedness among complex systems, coupled fuzzy neural networks are introduced to characterize complex systems in this paper. First, a novel controller is developed by means of a generalized exponential function and output states information, which can effectively avoid the chattering situations arising from the sign function. Under the controller, the output states of coupled fuzzy neural networks eventually converge to the projective state in the predefined time, which can reduce the requirements for sensor devices and improve the flexibility and efficiency of the control scheme. Second, in light of Lyapunov function and inequality techniques, sufficient criteria for ensuring to achieve the predetermined-time output projective synchronization of coupled fuzzy neural networks are deduced based on the assumption of the digraph containing a spanning tree. Furthermore, the results obtained in this paper not only represent an extension of master-slave systems but also demonstrate that the output synchronization of coupled fuzzy neural networks is a specific case of projective synchronization exemplified by a corollary. Finally, numerical examples are offered to reveal the correctness of theoretical results.

title: Energy-Efficient and Accurate Stochastic Computing-Based Multiply-Accumulate Architecture for Neural Network Accelerator Design
authors: Chia-Heng Liu, Hsuan-Yu Huang, Bo-Chun Chen, Kun-Chih Jimmy Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Due to high computational complexity, the design of Deep Neural Network (DNN) accelerators faces significant challenges, including high power consumption and considerable area overhead. While Stochastic Computing (SC) provides a way to reduce hardware overhead in DNN accelerator design, it has lower computing accuracy compared to traditional methods. The reason is that randomized bit-stream representations introduce statistical errors and sensitivity to correlation between input streams, leading to significant computing errors in the multiplyaccumulate operation. To mitigate the accuracy limitations inherent in stochastic computing (SC), in this work, we introduce the Integrated Multiply-Accumulate (IMAC) architecture, which enhances precision while maintaining SC's hardware efficiency. The IMAC uses an Accumulating Bipolar-to-Unipolar Converter (ABUC) and a Correlating Linear Gain (CorrGain) to correct the scaling errors from SC adders. To further reduce the area and power overhead, we employ a toggle flip-flop (TFF)-based adder tree and hardware sharing in this work. Compared to traditional SC-based MAC design, the proposed IMAC can reduce MSE by 64.3%-90.6% and improves throughput-to-error ratio by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.77 \times-10.68 \times$</tex>. Integrating the proposed IMAC into the LeNet-5 architecture allows LeNet-5 with IMAC to achieve the same inference accuracy as conventional LeNet-5 without IMAC.

title: Medical Image Segmentation Using Transformer Encoders and Prompt-Based Learning: A Systematic Review of Adaptation Strategies, Performance, and Challenges
authors: Mina A. Awad, Mai S. Mabrouk, Ahmed F. Elnokrashy
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Medical image segmentation faces inherent challenges due to data heterogeneity, noise, and complex anatomical structures, demanding robust AI solutions. While the Segment Anything Model (SAM) has shown promise as a foundational vision model for generic segmentation, its generalization to medical imaging-particularly through transformer encoders and prompt-based adaptation-remains an active research frontier. This systematic review evaluates SAM-based approaches for multi-modality medical image segmentation, analyzing adaptation strategies (e.g., fine-tuning, prompt engineering) and benchmarking performance against conventional models like nnUNet. From an initial pool of 100 papers, we rigorously selected 15 peer-reviewed studies (2023-2025) sourced from PubMed, IEEE Xplore, and arXiv, based on inclusion criteria focusing exclusively on medical image segmentation using SAM's generalized architecture. Our findings reveal that fine-tuned SAM variants (e.g., MedSAM) achieve comparable performance to traditional models in 2D segmentation but exhibit limitations in 3D tasks. Prompt-based methods (e.g., TV-SAM) reduce annotation time by 40-60%, while architectural modifications (e.g., SAM-Att) improve accuracy by 8-15%. Beyond performance, we identify critical barriers to clinical adoption, including scalability and domain shift. This review synthesizes empirical evidence to highlight SAM's potential and constraints in medical imaging, offering actionable insights for future research in generalizable AI-driven segmentation.

title: Study on Laser-induced Plasma under Vacuum based on PIC Simulation
authors: Yanqing Lu, Pei Cao, Kai Gao, Jiaqi Liu, Xiaokang Ding, Huan Yuan, Aijun Yang, Xiaohua Wang, Mingzhe Rong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The characteristics of laser-induced plasma exhibit considerable potential for industrial applications in fields such as electrical engineering, environmental monitoring, medical and health sciences, and laser processing, thereby demonstrating significant research value. However, current understanding of the formation and evolution mechanisms of laser-induced plasma remains limited. It is well recognized that both the initial plasma parameters and external environmental conditions play critical roles in determining the behavior of laser-induced plasma. In this study, a numerical model of laser-induced plasma under vacuum conditions was established based on the Particle-in-Cell (PIC) method using the VSim simulation software. The model investigates the dynamic processes of laser-plasma interaction and the associated diffusion characteristics. A two-dimensional spatial domain coupled with three-dimensional momentum space was constructed to simulate the evolution of the pre-formed plasma generated by the interaction between laser pulses and a copper target. To address the challenge of representing an infinite physical space within a finite computational domain, absorbing boundary conditions and the Perfectly Matched Layer (PML) technique were implemented. Convergence verification and validation of the PML absorption coefficients were also conducted to ensure the stability and accuracy of the numerical computations. The simulation results indicate that the proposed model is capable of effectively capturing the early-stage evolution of laser-induced plasma. These findings offer theoretical support for the advancement and application of laser-induced plasma technologies in electrical engineering and related disciplines.

title: FUELSPARK – Embedded Precision System for Proactive Fuel Awareness and Optimization
authors: Saiharshith KS, Sanjayaakash T, Rahul N, Rupesh Kumar M, Jabasheela L, Lincy Jemina
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: FUELSPARK is an intelligent embedded system aiming to enhance vehicle fuel monitoring and control. The conventional fuel gauges lack accuracy and do not always give an accurate reading. To address this, FUELSPARK integrates GPS and a microcontroller-based float sensor to enable real-time fuel tracking. When the fuel level is so low, the system is designed such that it sends out an alarm via a buzzer and finds the nearest gas stations based on geospatial (latitude and longitude) mapping. Drivers are provided with an onboard LCD screen to view critical data such as the volume of fuel, an approximate mileage estimate as well as the route to the nearest fuel station. Unlike conventional systems FUELSPARK shifts fuel monitoring towards intelligent and predictive monitoring. By comparing fuel consumption cycles and range travelled, the system enables more accurate mileage estimation. This helps motorists to plan trips efficiently and avoid unexpected fuel shortages. Efficiently and prevent inauspicious shortage of fuel. Tested in different automobile classes, FUELSPARK has proven to be more responsive, reliable, and easy to integrate, which is why it is classified as a smart vehicle technology and practical step. It promotes sustainable fuel management.

title: Efficient Power Transfer for EV Propulsion System Using Interleaved Sepic Converter
authors: Deenaa S, Manasa A, C. Pavithra, Mohanaram K, Logeshwaran
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Optimizing power electronic converters is crucial for enhancing electric vehicle (EV) propulsion systems. In this context, the interleaved Single-Ended about L, Primary Inductor Converter (SEPIC) offers superior performance by ensuring continuous input current, reducing current ripple, and improving thermal efficiency. The adoption of Model Predictive Control (MPC) further enhances performance by predicting the system's future behavior and making real-time adjustments. This combination of interleaved SEPIC and MPC leads to improved power management, lower power losses, and extended battery life. Simulation and experimental results confirm significant gains in energy efficiency and overall vehicle performance, making this approach a promising solution for next-generation EV propulsion systems and the advancement of sustainable transportation technologies.

title: Risk-Aware Bidding Strategy for Wind-Pumped Storage in Joint Energy and Ancillary Service Markets
authors: Xin Li, Haiqing Li, Xiaoran Shi, Ruimin Zhu, Junnan Liu, Beihong Zhang, Zhongwei Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: To address the challenges of wind power forecast uncertainty faced by pumped storage power stations participating in electricity spot markets, this study proposes a conditional value-at-risk (CVaR)-incorporated coordinated bidding optimization method for energy and frequency regulation ancillary service markets. First, a bi-level decision-making framework is established for wind-pumped storage hybrid systems participating in electricity markets: the upper level maximizes the expected revenue of wind farms and pumped storage stations in joint energy-frequency regulation markets while quantifying wind power uncertainty risks through CVaR; the lower level minimizes electricity procurement costs for market clearing. The bi-level model is transformed into a solvable single-level mixed-integer linear programming problem using Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions and strong duality theory. Numerical simulations are conducted on a modified 30 -bus system. The results demonstrate that the proposed framework maintains the revenue of wind farms and pumped storage stations while effectively mitigating extreme market risks, reducing revenue volatility by 36.3% compared to conventional methods and decreasing maximum potential losses in extreme scenarios by 42.1%. This enhanced revenue stability enables decision-makers to control CVaR within an acceptable range at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5 \%}$</tex> confidence level, significantly improving investment decision predictability and system operational robustness. The findings provide strategic support for joint participation of windpumped storage systems in energy-frequency regulation market bidding and capacity allocation.

title: IoT Based Smart Energy Billing System
authors: Karthikeyan. R, Senthilkumar. R, Tharani. B, Sundar. G, Theepasri. S, Sountharya. D
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This project focuses on measuring voltage and current using voltage and current sensors to determine power consumption. By calculating the power, the total units of electricity consumed can be tracked. Currently, electricity boards (EB) generate bills bi-monthly and deliver them via mail or other methods. However, a system that provides daily or weekly updates on electricity consumption can help users monitor their usage more effectively. Using an Arduino IoT Cloud application, this project enables real-time tracking and analysis of electricity usage in homes. The system is integrated with EB power supply and includes features to detect power availability and identify reasons for power outages, such as scheduled maintenance. The built-in Wi-Fi module and lithium-ion cell pack ensure data logging and storage continue seamlessly during power outages. The system also incorporates an LCD for viewing real-time electricity consumption and bill details. Data is automatically stored in the IoT cloud, allowing users to access it remotely from anywhere. For rental properties, the system facilitates monitoring individual consumption, enabling fair and accurate billing for tenants. An efficient methodology is presented for handling and assessing electricity utilization in a simplified manner.

title: ChemoInsight: Analysis and Visualization of Standardized Chemotherapy Records
authors: Aditya Bangia, Shelly Sachdeva
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Electronic Health Records (EHRs) contain enormous amounts of patient data stored in structured, semi-structured, and unstructured formats, posing significant challenges in decision making. ChemoInsight is a framework designed for the analysis and visualization of standardized chemotherapy EHRs. The framework employs a comprehensive methodology that begins with targeted MongoDB queries to extract chemotherapy-related compositions from standardized EHRs. These clinical records are then converted into structured DataFrames, capturing essential attributes such as procedure details, diagnosis dates, tumor staging, and patient demographics. The framework encompasses various dynamic visualization modules, including density plots, pie charts, histograms, and line charts, that effectively reveal distinct aspects of treatment patterns and patient characteristics over the population. Our results show ChemoInsight can be used in early‑stage tumor detection, revealing gender‑based disparities in tumor staging patterns, capturing seasonal and long‑term fluctuations in advanced‑stage diagnoses, and highlighting age‑related prevalence trends. By transforming complex EHRs into clear visual narratives, ChemoInsight empowers clinicians and researchers to make evidence‑based decisions, optimize screening strategies, and enhance patient outcomes through improved treatment protocols and resource utilization.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Lunar Landing: A Comparative Analysis of Algorithm Performance
authors: Dhinesh Sadhu Subramaniam Ponnarasan, Deepika Gottam, Likith Podalakuru, R. Manimegalai
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of developing autonomous control systems for various vehicles and devicesspecifically spacecraft landing procedures. Precise planetary landing is a classical control problem in aerospace engineering, which requires that the spacecraft decelerates/repels, orients and lands safely under uncertain dynamics with limited fuel. Conventional control techniques like PID and model predictive control need good models and substantial tuning. In this paper we explore the ability of recent reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms to learn such control policies directly from interaction with a physics simulator. We compare our approach against four popular algorithms - Deep Q-Network (DQN), Double DQN, Dueling DQN and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) on OpenAI Gymnasium and LunarLander-v2 benchmark. We present a unified PyTorch implementation, conduct multi-seed experiments and compare in terms of convergence speed, stability of rewards and computation efforts. We observe that PPO achieves competitive rewards in a quarter of training time compared to value-based methods, while the best peak reward is obtained by Dueling DQN. We discuss for real world autonomous landing and other high risk robotic tasks.

title: An FPGA-Based Hardware-Software Co-Design Approach for Embedded Machine Learning Acceleration
authors: Obed K. Allotey Babington, N. Amanquah
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Embedded machine learning on microcontrollers employing hardware acceleration face significant latency constraints due to communication overheads between the generalpurpose microcontrollers and external hardware accelerators. This paper presents an FPGA-based hardware-software co-design approach that integrates a MicroBlaze softcore processor with custom neural network acceleration units on a single chip, eliminating off-chip data transfer bottlenecks. Our approach implements a complete neural network inference pipeline using memory-mapped interfaces for on-chip communication. Experimental validation using a Morse code decoding neural network demonstrates a remarkable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$420 \times$</tex> speedup compared to baseline softcore execution, significantly outperforming traditional external acceleration approaches. The system maintains over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \times$</tex> performance improvements even at reduced clock speeds, highlighting the substantial impact of eliminating communication latency in hardware-accelerated embedded ML applications.

title: Hybrid Frequency-guided Fusion Network for Face Forgery Detection
authors: Mengze Li, Jin Li, Shihao Jia
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Although face forgery detection has achieved considerable progress in recent years, many existing approaches display high accuracy on specific datasets but still struggle to generalize effectively to novel datasets produced by diverse image manipulation techniques. To address this limitation, we present a detection framework that jointly exploits frequency-domain, local spatial, and global spatial features. The design is motivated by the observation that frequency-domain artifacts tend to be more consistent across different forgery methods compared to spatial-domain artifacts. Building on this insight, we construct a frequency-guided multi-feature fusion architecture.In the frequency stream, multi-scale Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) features are combined with 8×8 block-level Discrete Fourier Transform (B-DFT) features, where the latter are efficiently computed using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). This combination enables the extraction of spectral patterns that are widely shared across manipulation techniques. The derived frequency information then guides the feature-level fusion between local spatial features, obtained via an Xception network, and global representations captured by the Swin-Transformer V2, thereby improving the robustness of spatial-domain analysis. At the decision level, the outputs from all three streams are integrated to further enhance detection accuracy.Ablation experiments indicate that the proposed fusion strategy increases the accuracy of the Swin-Transformer V2 and Xception baselines by 3.09% and 3.75%, respectively. Cross-dataset evaluations further demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms multiple state-of-the-art approaches in terms of generalization capability, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

title: IAM-based Zero Trust Architecture for IoT: Securing Non-Human Identities in a Connected World
authors: Sthembile Mthethwa, Edgar Jembere, Moses Dlamini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: The widespread adoption of IoT devices has fundamentally altered digital connectivity, facilitating real-time data exchange and autonomous interactions worldwide. While this transformation offers significant operational advantages, it also introduces critical security challenges, particularly concerning the Identity and Access Management (IAM) of non-human identities such as sensors, devices, machine agents, and service accounts. Traditional perimeter-based security models, which rely on static trust boundaries and implicit trust for internal actors, have been used over the years for human identities. However, they are inadequate for non-human identities. Their limitations have led to a growing interest in Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA), a cutting-edge security concept, built upon the foundational rule of "never trust, always verify". This paper explores the application of ZTA in securing IoT ecosystems, with a specific focus on managing nonhuman identities. It investigates ZTA’s core tenets, like least privilege, micro-segmentation, continuous monitoring, and identity-centric access control—and analyses how these can be effectively implemented in resource-constrained IoT environments. The study identifies key implementation challenges and considerations for the use of ZTA in IoT. The findings of this paper highlight that ZTA, when properly implemented, offers a robust framework for mitigating cyber risks inherent in IoT ecosystems. Finally, the paper outlines future research directions, aimed at integrating ZTA into IoT environments. Ultimately, this work contributes to the growing body of knowledge advocating for Zero Trust as a foundational approach to modern IoT security.

title: A Deep Learning and NLP-Based Platform for Computer Science Development
authors: Mustafa Hussein, Waleed Mohamed, Abdalla Mohsen, Mennatullah Ibrahiem, Kerolos Samaan, Hajer Essam, Radwa Reda Hossieny, Sally Saad
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Recently, students and graduates in computer science have encountered increasing difficulty in navigating academic and career pathways due to the absence of centralized, domain-specific platforms. Existing online forums and social media channels are often fragmented and cluttered with irrelevant discussions, sarcasm, and offensive text, limiting their effectiveness in providing accurate guidance and technical support. These challenges disrupt meaningful engagement, hinder information retrieval, and reduce the overall quality of academic discourse within the computer science community. This study introduces FCIS F1 system, an AI-driven platform designed to facilitate structured, safe, and relevant communication among computer science students and graduates. The system integrates deep learning models for multilingual offensive text detection, topic classification, and content filtering. For English offensive text detection, BERT achieved the highest accuracy (92.90%), followed by CNN (92.45%) and Bi-LSTM (90.51%). In Arabic, Naive Bayes outperformed other models with 96.25% accuracy, while Bi-LSTM reached 95.16%, and up to 94.88% in optimized trials. These models demonstrated strong performance across multiple configurations, enabling the platform to automatically moderate content and categorize discussions effectively. FCIS F1 supports a focused and constructive environment that enhances knowledge exchange, academic decision-making, and career development in the field of computer science.

title: Energy-Aware Computing: Cutting CPU Cycles through Intelligent Thread Management and Code Smell Optimization
authors: Sonali Jolly, Asmita Yadav, Sandeep Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: In the field of high-performance computing, increasing resource efficiency and enhancing code quality is essential for minimizing CPU cycles, reducing execution duration, and reducing energy usage. This study introduces an approach for Thread management and Code smell optimization aimed at boosting software performance and reducing the workload on the CPU. The framework achieves significant reductions in overall computational time by employing intelligent thread allocation techniques with respect to memory thereby reducing CPU cycles and speeding up the processing. This paper also incorporates experiments on code smell detection by using Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) traversal and recommendation along with optimization to boost efficiency and quality code. By identifying and addressing code smell indicators of subpar coding practices that negatively affect readability, maintainability has achieved results in reduced CPU cycles and Execution Time. The resulting code demonstrates enhanced modularity and improved performance, minimizing energy usage without sacrificing results. Findings reveal that the optimization decreases in processing duration by 33.34% over non-optimized programs, CPU utilization, and energy consumption across a set of few programs and highlighting the efficacy of thread management. These Experiments contribute to the advancement of energy-efficient software methodologies suitable for modern resource-intensive applications.

title: Operational Framework for Fault Detection in Power Systems: A Foundation for AI-Driven Analysis
authors: K N Dinesh Babu, Lakshmanan Paulraj
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Modern power systems generate vast volumes of protection data through digital relays, SCADA systems, and disturbance recorders. While these datasets are invaluable for system reliability, their scale and complexity often make fault detection challenging. This paper presents a structured framework for fault analysis that integrates relay event records, oscillograph playback, and malfunction diagnosis into a systematic methodology. The framework has been validated using four real-world case studies, including circuit breaker failures, relay misoperations, and protection logic anomalies, demonstrating its ability to identify root causes and propose corrective measures. Beyond the engineering insights, the methodology establishes a foundation for automation using data-driven approaches. By formalizing data categorization, sequence correlation, and decision pathways, the framework provides a pathway for future AI-based evaluation, enabling predictive diagnostics and real-time fault classification. This work therefore bridges current practical fault analysis with emerging AI applications, offering a replicable and scalable approach for enhancing resilience in modern smart grids.

title: Adaptive Fuzzy Energy-Efficient Clustering and Energy Optimization Protocol for Underwater Wireless Sensors Networks
authors: Hamza Zradgui, Khalil Ibrahimi, Mohamed El Kamili
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Research on underwater wireless sensor networks (UWSNs) has been significant for applications such as forecasting adversity and disaster, hydrological and military surveillance, seepage monitoring, and underwater triangulation. These networks however, face challenges like significant delay spread, soaring interference, noise, jarring environments, poor connectivity, and restricted battery life. They also cause significant problems in terms of energy efficiency and network longevity. Nodes in UWSNs are subject to additional limitations, including fluctuating ambient conditions, large propagation delays, and limited energy supplies. Designing routing protocols for UWSNs is a promising solution to overcome these issues. The Adaptive Fuzzy Energyefficient Clustering and Energy Optimization (AFECEO) protocol, proposed especially for UWSNs, is thoroughly evaluated in this study in comparison to six popular clustering protocols: GEC, LEACH, PEGASIS, DCHS, DEEC, and LGCA. The fuzzy logic-based adaptive clustering process used by AFECEO dynamically chooses cluster heads by taking into account variables including distance to the sink, node residual energy, and underwater communication difficulties such as acoustic signal attenuation. According to simulation data, under various underwater settings, AFECEO performs better than its competitors in a number of critical performance parameters, such as average remaining energy, dead node count, and network longevity. Notably, AFECEO outperforms conventional protocols in terms of residual energy by up to 45% and dead node reduction by 60 %, guaranteeing improved energy optimization and dependable data transfer in UWSNs. This study demonstrates how well AFECEO works as a reliable option for energy-efficient communication in submerged settings, opening the door for more advanced monitoring and exploration uses.

title: Enhancing Security of Semiconductor Supply Chain Using Blockchain and Smart Contracts
authors: Nayantara Thomas, Liya Treesa Philip, Pampana Jahnavi, Sujatha Rajkumar, Vinod Salunkhe
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The increasing complexity and globalization of the semiconductor supply chain, particularly in Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs), has introduced significant vulnerabilities including counterfeiting, unauthorized modifications, and malicious hardware insertions. To address these challenges, this project proposes a novel security framework that integrates Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA), blockchain technology, and Arbiter Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) to enhance the authenticity, traceability, and resilience of the FPGA supply chain. The framework employs PUFs to generate unique hardware identities for FPGA components, which are authenticated through smart contracts and immutably recorded on a permissioned blockchain. By adopting ZTA principles, the system ensures continuous verification of all entities and components across the supply chain. The proposed architecture supports real-time monitoring, automated anomaly detection, and role-based access control, creating a tamper-proof and transparent ledger of FPGA transactions. This approach significantly strengthens supply chain integrity, mitigates risks of counterfeit insertion, and establishes a secure foundation for deploying FPGAs in mission-critical applications such as defense, telecommunications, and AI systems.

title: Technical Insights into Net Metering for Distributed Solar Photovoltaics
authors: Abhay Kumar Pandey, Priyanshu Praliya, Ankit Kumar, Amit Arya
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: India has recently ascended to the third position globally in solar power generation, marking a significant milestone in its renewable energy trajectory. The nation's solar capacity has witnessed exponential growth, surging from 2.6 GW in March 2014 to approximately 123.13 GW as of August 2025[1]. This includes 93.90 GW from groundmounted solar plants, 20.85 GW from grid-connected rooftop installations, and additional contributions from hybrid and off-grid systems. The National Institute of Solar Energy (NISE) has estimated India's solar potential at approximately 748 GW[1], underscoring the vast untapped opportunity for clean energy expansion. As India continues to integrate new solar connections into its electrical infrastructure, particularly at the distribution level, it becomes imperative to evaluate the technical feasibility and grid stability implications of such additions. Uncoordinated integration can lead to voltage fluctuations, reverse power flows, and protection malfunctions, especially in radial distribution networks. This paper presents a structured methodology for assessing the impact of proposed solar connections on the distribution electrical network. The approach includes load flow analysis, voltage profile assessment, fault level evaluation, and hosting capacity estimation to ensure reliable and secure grid operation while facilitating the country's transition to a sustainable energy future. In this paper we would like to share the methodology to analyze the technical feasibility & impact of new solar connection on Distribution electrical network.

title: Large Language Models: Fundamentals, Necessity, Impacts, Challenges, and Opportunities for Future Applications
authors: M. Sivakumar, N. Krishnaraj, Amit Kumar Tyagi
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The creation of LLMs which focus on specific domains will enable new opportunities for analyzing healthcare conditions while also performing legal tasks in the future. The chapter examines the complete characteristics and evolution of Large Language Models (LLMs) in modern artificial intelligence as well as their essential contribution to contemporary systems. The discussion shows how LLMs can resolve complicated language problems while enabling human-computer communication and multimodal information learning. The review demonstrates how Large Language Models reshape different sectors in society including education and healthcare and they influence the finance sector and entertainment industry. The exceptional performance of LLMs comes with substantial difficulties particularly regarding their costly operations and demanding training requirements alongside empathy-intensive interpretation of their judgment methods. Ongoing research must focus on model efficiency as well as explainable approaches and sustainable AI practices because these challenges exist. The adoption of responsible AI development procedures becomes vital because of ethical risks which include privacy violations as well as bias and misinformation challenges. Building fair and transparent AI-driven technologies requires full cooperation between policymakers, researchers and industry stakeholders to create guidelines focused on accountability. The upcoming era of LLM technology development will rely on fresh approaches to explain analysis methods while adopting power-efficient training processes and enhanced interpretability software frameworks. The deployment of LLMs between practical execution objectives and moral principles enables progress in natural language processing and their suitable implementation throughout various disciplines. The future success of AI depends on how human beings utilize LLM technology with both knowledge and responsibility to generate maximum positive impact alongside risk management.

title: Bridging the Semantic Gap: Contrastive Rewards for Multilingual Text-to-SQL
authors: Ashish Kattamuri, Ishita Prasad, Meetu Malhotra, Arpita Vats, Rahul Raja, Albert Lie
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Current Text-to-SQL methods are evaluated and only focused on executable queries overlooking the semantic alignment challenge both in terms of the semantic meaning of the query and the execution results correctness. Even execution accuracy itself shows significant drops when moving from English to other languages, with an average decline of 6 percentage points across non-English languages. We address these challenges by presenting a new framework that combines Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) within a multilingual contrastive reward signal to enhance both task efficiency and semantic accuracy in Text-to-SQL systems in cross-lingual scenarios. Our method teaches models to obtain better correspondence between SQL generation and user intent by combining a reward signal based on semantic similarity. On the seven language MultiSpider dataset, finetuning the Llama-3-3B model with GRPO improved the execution accuracy up to 87.4% (+26 pp over zero-shot) and semantic accuracy up to 52.29% (+32.86 pp). Adding our contrastive reward signal in the GRPO framework further improved the average semantic accuracy to 59.14% (+6.85 pp, up to +10 pp for Vietnamese). Our experiments showcase that a smaller parameter efficient 3B llama model finetuned with our contrastive reward signal outperforms a much larger zero shot 8B llama model with uplift of 7.43pp on execution accuracy from 81.43% on 8B model to 88.86% on 3B model and cutting close on semantic accuracy with 59.14% on 3B vs 68.57% on 8B just with 3,000 reinforcement learning training examples. These results demonstrate how we can improve the performance of Text-to-SQL systems with contrastive rewards for directed semantic alignment without requiring huge amounts of datasets for training.

title: Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encryption Based on Semantic Extension
authors: Xiang Li, Liupiao Zhang, Congge Xie, Xiaofang Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Dynamic Searchable Symmetric Encryption (DSSE) facilitates secure encrypted data retrieval and dynamic updates in the cloud but struggles to balance search flexibility, efficiency, and security, with most schemes lacking semantic-aware query support or efficient forward/backward security. This paper presents SEFB, a novel DSSE scheme integrating BERT-based semantic extension and forward/backward security. SEFB leverages BERT for contextual keyword expansion to enhance search accuracy. It employs a hybrid index (Bloom filters, homomorphic additive encryption bitmap index) in a balanced binary tree for efficient updates. Security analysis shows SEFB meets adaptive semantic security, ensuring forward/backward privacy. Experiments on the Enron dataset demonstrate SEFB’s competitive efficiency and improved semantic precision over existing schemes.

title: Application of Current Limiting Reactors in Transmission System
authors: Naveen Bhardwaj, Peter Dopplmair, Dominik Mitterberger
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Short circuit events in transmission grids pose significant threats to the stability and reliability of power systems. One of the most effective methods for controlling short circuit currents and minimizing their impact is the use of series reactors. This paper explores the different fault level mitigation methods with a clear comparison of the advantages and disadvantages of each. Further, the paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the concept, design and implementation of series reactors in transmission grids as a means of controlling short circuit currents by discussing their important aspects in terms of design & construction, installation, maintenance, operational principles and effectiveness. Paper also highlights key features of current limiting reactors including the benefits and challenges. A case study on use of Current Limiting Reactors and its impact on the system by a Brazilian utility is also referenced in the Paper.

title: Geospatial Potential Assessment of Dynamic Line Rating: A High-Level Methodology for Early-Stage Planning
authors: Robinson T. Maswedza, Chantelle Y. van Staden, Munyaradzi J. Chihota
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: The rapid integration of renewable energy into the energy mix has resulted in transmission line power flows becoming increasingly constrained. Traditionally, transmission system operators have relied on a conservative Static Line Rating (SLR) approach. In contrast, Dynamic Line Rating (DLR) is an innovative approach that potentially increases transmission headroom by accounting for the spatial and temporal variability of parameters that influence line ratings. During early-stage planning, a high-level potential assessment of DLR is crucial to identify lines that benefit the most. In this study, a geospatial assessment methodology is implemented to evaluate the potential benefits of DLR using historical weather data of wind speed, wind direction, solar radiation and ambient temperature. These parameters are spatially mapped to individual transmission lines to identify lines that potentially benefit the most from DLR. This work represents the first regional-scale DLR potential assessment in South Africa. Results demonstrate the ability of DLR to unlock additional headroom on overhead lines with some lines rating above the SLR for over 90% of the year. This shows how DLR can unlock additional transfer capability, highlighting its value as a short- to medium-term measure to relieve transmission constraints and enable higher renewable energy integration while long-term grid reinforcements are developed.

title:
Enhancement-mode Operation in GaN Trigate Transistor with SiN
                    <sub>x</sub>
                    /AIN Dielectric Stack
authors: Yu Li, Guohao Yu, Ang Li, Zhongming Zeng, Baoshun Zhang
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In this work, we propose a Tri-gate AlGaN/GaN high electron mobility transistor (HEMT) that leverages the dielectric stack consisting of low-pressure chemical vapor deposition (LPCVD)- $\mathrm{SiN}_{\mathrm{x}}$ and atomic layer deposited (ALD)AlN. The device architecture incorporates $50-\mathrm{nm}$-wide fins to strengthen electrostatic control, while a tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAH) surface treatment is employed to improve surface quality and suppress interface-related defects. The combination of LPCVD-SiN ${ }_{x}$ and ALD-AlN enables strong polarization-induced modulation and reduced interface trap density, thereby stabilizing the gate potential. As a result, the fabricated enhancement-mode (E-mode) MIS-HEMTs exhibit a positive $V_{\text {TH }}$ of 0.2 V (at $1 \mu \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{mm}$), a low on-resistance of $27 \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~mm}$, and an ON/OFF current ratio exceeding $10^{8}$, together with minimal threshold hysteresis ($\Delta V_{\mathrm{TH}} \sim 10 \mathrm{mV}$). Importantly, the devices maintain excellent off-state robustness with a breakdown voltage of 614 V, underscoring the reliability of the gate stack under high electric fields. These findings demonstrate that integrating a multi-layer dielectric with Trigate architecture provides an effective pathway to simultaneously achieve enhancement-mode operation, low conduction loss, and high-voltage capability, paving the way for next-generation GaN power transistors.

title: Classification of Cardiomyopathy Conditions Using Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Sowmiya M, Malar E, Sudharshana M K
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The heart is most vital organs in the human body, and even a brief interruption in its function can have severe and life-threatening consequences. The leading cause of death globally, cardiovascular illnesses claim almost 17.1 million lives each year. Among these, cardiomyopathy represent a significant group of disorders that affect cardiac function. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging is an essential tool for the diagnosis and management of such conditions. In this context, deep learning has emerged as a powerful technique for predicting and classifying heart diseases, including different types of cardiomyopathy. The preprocessing involved image enhancement using CLAHE and normalization to ensure computational efficiency. These processed images were then classified using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The model is designed to identify and categorize various cardiomyopathy conditions, including dilated cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, myocardial infarction, and abnormal right ventricle. Different activation functions and optimizers were applied to achieve faster convergence. The proposed deep learning framework demonstrated excellent performance, achieving a classification accuracy of 98.9%, effectively distinguishing between multiple categories of cardiomyopathy and related heart diseases.

title: Robust Scheduling Method for Power Systems With Csp Units Considering Solar Thermal Resource Uncertainty
authors: Chong Shao, Yaqun Wang, Wenqin Song, Xi Yang, Zan Ni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: Due to the thermal storage system, the Concentrating solar power (CSP) plant has merged the flexible regulation capabilities of traditional thermal power with the environmental advantages of renewable energy. While the number of CSP units continues to increase, research on the impact of solar thermal resource uncertainty remains insufficient. In this paper, a two-stage robust optimization model considering solar thermal resource uncertainty is proposed. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed model, case studies are carried out on the modified IEEE-RTS79 system. Optimal operation results are obtained under different scenarios, including different levels of solar thermal resource prediction deviations and various thermal storage times.

authors: Mingzhen Pan, Wenke Liang
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: In order to achieve the real-time monitoring of methane (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>) and ethane (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf>), a near-infrared dual-gas sensing system based on the Wavelength Modulation Spectroscopy (WMS) technique is designed in this paper. The Eblana distributed feedback laser with a wavelength of 1680 nm is selected as the light source for the system. A gas absorption cell with an absorption path length of 0.5 meters is built, and absorption peaks of methane at 1676 nm and ethane at 1677 nm are chosen. A seven-segment large-range current-tuning peak-scanning method enables simultaneous gas detection with a current offset range of 81.7 mA. The collected light intensity signals are processed by Python programming, and the first and second harmonic components in the signals are extracted by combining with the orthogonal phase-locked demodulation technique. Among all the concentration measurement points, the maximum relative error of methane during peak fixing is 2.10%, and the minimum relative error is 0.15%. Ethane is greatly affected by noise during the measurement process, with its maximum relative error being 6.35% and the minimum being 1.03%. During peak scanning, the maximum relative error of methane is 6.28%, and the minimum relative error is 0.25%. The maximum relative error of ethane is 5.50%, and the minimum is 0.56%.

title: Towards Streamlined Dg Interconnection Criteria: a Fast Risk-Based Hosting Capacity Estimate Method
authors: Munyaradzi Justice Chihota, Bernard Bekker
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Distribution network operators (DNOs) face growing backlogs of distributed generation (DG) interconnection requests, threatening the energy transition. Effective regulation requires balancing efficiency in application processing with accuracy in assessing hosting capacity (HC). Existing frameworks fall short: fast-track screening is overly conservative, while detailed studies are resource-intensive. Intermediate methods that combine the speed of screening with the accuracy and risk-awareness of detailed analysis are needed. Shorthand HC methods aim to fill this gap but are typically deterministic, neglecting DG spatial diversity and load stochasticity that strongly influence HC. This paper develops a risk-based HC estimation method with two key probabilistic enhancements to short-hand HC calculations: (1) centering the DG's aggregate voltage effect at a risk-based impedance location to PV spatial distribution, and (2) probabilistic computation of available voltage and transformer loading headroom to account for load stochasticity. Tested on practical feeders in South Africa, the method shows reliable estimates with acceptable accuracy relative to detailed stochastic HC results while substantially outperforming deterministic estimates based on standard screening criteria. The method streamlines interconnection processes, facilitating more effective utilization of the grid capacity.

title: SwarmRoute Collaborative Optimization for Efficient Logistics Routing with Road Metric Optimization
authors: Amogh Singh, Christy Jackson Joshua, Abraham Sudharson Ponraj
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Route-finding algorithms are used extensively in multiple domains from networking to logistics and play a crucial role in computing the most efficient path. Applying the existing route-finding algorithms to a large map, however, can be computationally intensive while also being inefficient due to the large number of possible paths. Swarm algorithms have demonstrated their effectiveness in solving problems using the power of collective intelligence and in order to address this issue, we propose SwarmRoute which can compute and evaluate multiple routes concurrently. SwarmRoute uses a weighted function with each of the road parameters assigned weight values that can be modified to prioritize on different parameters, with genetic algorithm optimized weights being used for the comparison study. A network graph of Chennai is extracted from the OSMNX package for comparing the algorithms and SwarmRoute is able to demonstrate an 81% decrease in route length compared to the best-performing existing algorithm, stochastic hill climbing, and a 10% decrease compared to a modified breadth first algorithm that has been described in this paper.

title: Approximate Calculation Method of Clcc Dc Current With Consideration of the Influence of the Control System Under Ac Faults
authors: Zhiqiang Ma, Yupeng He, Xinyuan Zhao, Dong Ding, Shuyu Chen, Chuanjie Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The Controllable Commutation Converter (CLCC) integrates the advantages of traditional converters, including large capacity, low loss, and strong overload capacity, while enabling controllable turn-off of bridge arms to fundamentally address the issue of commutation failure. When a fault occurs on the AC side of a DC system, changes in DC current directly affect AC shortcircuit current. Moreover, since the DC control system of the LCC-CLCC configuration exerts a significant impact on the transient process of DC current after a fault, this paper proposes an approximate analytical method for calculating DC current that accounts for the influence of the DC control system, applicable to fault analysis of the receiving-end AC system in LCC-CLCC systems. Firstly, the basic topology and operating principle of the controllable line-commutated converter are introduced. Secondly, considering the impact of the DC control system, its structure and transient response characteristics are analyzed, and an approximate DC current calculation method is put forward. Finally, the correctness of the proposed calculation method is verified by comparison with actual simulation results. These approximate analytical results can provide a basis for selecting line protection settings and configuring relevant circuit breaker parameters.

title: A High Level Synthesis Tool for Multiple FPGAs
authors: Kazutoshi Wakabayashi, Wataru Takahashi, Hideharu Amano
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: This paper presents a High Level Synthesis tool which partitions a large-scale circuit into multiple FPGAs. The proposed partitioning method in this tool is designed for stream processing, such as CNN, and aims to partition the circuit into a minimum number of FPGAs and to minimize the through-put degradation caused by the partitioning. Unlike traditional approaches that divide circuits at the RTL or netlist level, in the proposed method, circuits described in the C++ language are divided by high-level synthesis. After partitioning, the RTL descriptions for communication interface circuits between the portioned modules. Also, the RTL descriptions for data stream packing and unpacking circuits are also automatically generated. This stream packing trys to minimize the latency for data transfer between the partitioned modules. Thirdly, the RTL description for data stream sharing circuits is generated. This stream sharing also try to minimize the latency for data transfer. This technique takes advantage of the Data Initial Interval (DII) of the packed data. Lastly, the header information of the packet, such as destination address, slot address, is automatically decided, creating an RTL description. This capability is similar to Network-on-chip (NoC), but this tool does this function with small circuits. The proposed tool allows the designer to synthesize circuit on multiple FPGAs completely automatic. In the experiment, MobileNet-v1 written in C++ language was automatically partitioned into multiple FPGAs, and it was confirmed that the partitioning was done correctly and there was no degradation in throughput.

title: An Improved DeepLabV3plus-Based Method for Transmission Line Icing Detection
authors: Jianjun Xiao, Guoliang Liu, Xiangyue Meng, Jie Zhang, Qing Liu, Gaohe Liu, Qian Zhang, Yinming Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: To accurately assess the icing conditions of transmission lines and enable real-time monitoring, this paper proposes an automatic segmentation and detection method based on an improved DeepLabV3+ algorithm. A specialized dataset of 1,500 iced transmission line images was constructed from field data collected in Dingxi, Gansu Province, China, and preprocessed using noise reduction and data augmentation techniques. To optimize the network structure, attention mechanisms were integrated into the DeepLabV3+ architecture, and the loss function was refined to improve the segmentation accuracy of small-area icing. Furthermore, the dilation rates in atrous convolutions were adjusted to increase the receptive field, enabling more precise detection of long-distance icing. The icing thickness was subsequently calculated by comparing images of the transmission lines before and after icing events. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an MIoU of 96.37% on the validation set, outperforming both the original DeepLabV3+ and its variants with additional modules. These findings provide reliable technical support for intelligent power grid inspection and hold significant engineering application value.

title: Security Vulnerabilities in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Systems: A Case Study of Ardupilot
authors: Abdullah Al-Boghdady, Mohammad El-Ramly, Basheer Youssef, Khaled Wassif
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) systems have become increasingly prominent in recent decades in both civilian and military applications, owing to their ability to perform a wide range of complex tasks quickly and accurately. The software architecture of UAVs is inherently complex, requiring coordinated management of hardware, software, communications, and sensors, along with integration of advanced technologies like the Internet of Things. As a result, UAV systems face significant security and privacy challenges. They are frequently viewed as attractive targets for malicious actors and remain vulnerable to diverse attacks that threaten data confidentiality, integrity, and availability. This paper presents a pilot analytical study of security vulnerabilities in UAV systems by examining the growth rate and density of security related-errors measured as the number of errors per 1K physical Source Lines of Code (SLoC) across four releases of the ArduPilot system. To identify these vulnerabilities, a static analysis tool, Cppcheck, was applied to detect weaknesses categorized under the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE). In addition, the study explores the evolutionary properties of UAV systems using the CodeScene tool, aiming to establish how these properties correlate with the presence of security vulnerabilities. The findings show that ArduPilot exhibits a consistently high rate of source code vulnerabilities across the analyzed versions. The most frequently detected vulnerabilities were CWE-398, CWE-563, and CWE-758. Overall, this work advances the comprehension of UAV system security by providing detailed analytical insights into source code vulnerabilities, thereby serving as a guiding resource for future research and secure UAV development.

title: LSTM Based Vector Control Approach for PMSM Drives
authors: Ashly Mary Tom, Febin Daya J.L., Edgar Peralta Sanchez, Benin R
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: A deep learning based control approach is proposed in this paper for permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drive. A popular choice for traction application is the PMSM drive because of its reliability and low maintenance requirements. The PI (Proportional-Integral) controller is used in the standard vector control technique for traction motors used in industrial applications. The technique's fundamental flaw is its susceptibility to changes in parameters. DL-based regression has not yet been examined as a control technique for traction drive control, to our knowledge. A long short-term memory network (LSTM)-based regression is investigated in this paper to find a suitable replacement for the conventional controller. Performance metrics are used to conduct a comparative performance analysis for normal and uncertain settings. The RMSE values of the LSTM controller outputs reduce by an average of 31.81% compared to the PI controller outputs. The simulation results suggest that while LSTM responses are slower than traditional methods, they can be used as as as alternative to traditional controller, with more fine-tuning. This study examines the application of deep learning to electric motor speed control.

title: ML-Based UAV Routing with Dynamic Geofencing Using 5G NEF and CAMARA APIs
authors: Wassim Kribaa, Miloud Bagaa, Ibrahim Afolabi, Adlen Ksentini, Mohammed Elmusrati, Petri Välisuo
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: In dense urban environments, traditional GNSS-based navigation for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) suffers from multipath interference and signal obstructions, compromising positioning accuracy and increasing risks of collisions and airspace violations. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based system architecture for autonomous UAV parcel delivery, leveraging standardized 5G Network Exposure Function (NEF) and CAMARA Device Location API to achieve sub-meter location precision. Our approach integrates dynamic geofencing and predictive rerouting at the network edge, powered by a Random Forest-based collision prediction model that proactively adjusts UAV trajectories to avoid restricted zones in real time. Through simulations of six UAVs navigating dynamically updated no-fly zones, we demonstrate that our system significantly reduces time spent in restricted areas to near zero, compared to GNSS-only and rule-based methods, while limiting path-length inflation to approximately 30% for five of six flights. These results underscore the potential of combining 5G-enabled location services with edge intelligence to enhance safety and compliance in urban UAV operations.

title: Coordinated Planning Method for Distribution-Microgrid Systems Considering Massive Reliability Constraints
authors: Jiawei Qu, Zeyu Liu, Bingchen Zhang, Kai Hou, Lewei Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the increasing integration of renewable energy sources, the number of active microgrids has grown significantly. However, the spatiotemporal mismatch between load demand and generation introduces operational risks to the distribution network. To mitigate these risks, integrating load shedding analysis into the planning stage is essential. Therefore, this paper proposes a coordinated planning model for distribution-microgrid systems considering large-scale reliability constraints. Massive uncertainties are quantified through potential operational scenarios, ensuring that operational uncertainties are thoroughly addressed during the planning stage. To alleviate the computational burden associated with massive reliability scenarios, a Lagrangian-based state-space classification method is developed. By identifying the active constraints, the proposed approach significantly reduces computational complexity while maintaining planning accuracy. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed method not only enhances system reliability but also significantly improves planning efficiency.

title: An Efficient ResNet50 Model Integrated with SE Module for Tea Leaf Disease Image Classification
authors: Lingling She, Jiaxu Dao, Mengting Mei, Zhuoying Li, Jinli Tong, Xiaoli Lan, Xiuzhong Tang, Qingsong Zhou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: To address the challenges of low accuracy and limited feature extraction capabilities inherent in conventional methods for classifying tea leaf diseases, this study introduces an enhanced ResNet50 model incorporating Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) channel attention mechanisms. Focusing on a dataset comprising seven tea leaves (six diseased and one healthy), the proposed approach integrates the SE module into each residual block of ResNet50 to enhance the emphasis on disease manifestations. Additionally, the utilization of Focal Loss with label smoothing aims to mitigate issues related to class imbalance and overfitting. Experimental findings demonstrate that the SE-ResNet50 model achieves an accuracy of 94.27% through 5-fold cross validation, surpassing alternative models such as VGG16, DenseNet169, and EfficientNet-B5 by a margin of 0.59%, 6.25%, and 5.56%, respectively. These results underscore the model's efficacy in proficiently extracting features related to tea diseases, thereby offering a viable solution for intelligent disease recognition.

title: AI-Native 6G: Empowering Intelligent RAN With Accelerated Compute
authors: Xingqin Lin, Lopamudra Kundu, Sebastian Cammerer, Yan Huang, Chris Dick, Charles Santhosam, Rajesh Gadiyar, Reinhard Wiesmayr, Christoph Studer
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: The coming era of 6G will be marked by a paradigm shift in the radio access network (RAN), propelled by pervasive and embedded artificial intelligence (AI). In this article, we examine the essential roles of software-defined, accelerated compute platforms with graphics processing units (GPUs) in building AI-native 6G RAN.

title: 3D High-quality Power Doppler Using Coherence-based Null Subtraction Imaging_supp8-3649288.pdf
authors: Jianwen Luo
publish: N/A
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) power Doppler (PD) imaging enables visualization of volumetric microvasculature networks. However, 3D ultrafast PD imaging with matrix arrays suffers from limited resolution due to the restricted aperture size and the use of unfocused plane waves, while delay-and-sum (DAS) exhibits high sidelobe levels and broad main lobes, hindering high-quality PD imaging. In this study, we aim to improve the 3D null subtraction imaging (NSI) and propose coherence-based NSI beamformers including NSI based on coherence factor (NSI-CF) and NSI based on spatial and angular coherence factor (NSI-SACF). Specifically, NSI-SACF integrates the high-resolution capability of NSI and the high-contrast performance of spatial and angular coherence factor (SACF). The proposed beamformers are validated through simulations, phantom experiments, and in vivo experiments. Qualitative and quantitative evaluations confirm the superiority of NSI-SACF. In the simulations, NSI-SACF achieves a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 0.059 mm compared with 0.391 mm for DAS and 0.225 mm for SACF. NSI-SACF also reduces the sidelobe level by 75.5 dB and 33.6 dB compared with DAS and SACF respectively, while effectively suppressing grating lobes. In the in vivo experiments, NSI-SACF improves the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) of blood flow by 20.03 dB and 8.65 dB over DAS and SACF, respectively. Furthermore, the FWHM of the vessel is reduced to 0.098 mm with NSI-SACF, compared with 0.326 mm for DAS and 0.159 mm for SACF. In summary, the proposed NSI-SACF beamformer effectively enhances the PD imaging by simultaneously improving spatial resolution and contrast, demonstrating the potential for clinical applications.
