title: Functional Brain Connectivity Analysis of the Amygdala Using SPM and ICA on VAM fMRI Data
authors: Rohini A, Packialatha A
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of the functional structure of MRI based on the analysis of antisocial behavior, the special intensity of the amygdala, the important areas of the brain, the essential elements of emotion regulations, the response of the threat and the essential parts of social behavior. Using three data sets, including VAM (Visual, Auditory and Movements), using three data sets, using the spatial and temporary independent activation of the nerve delay, to identify the spatial and temporary independent activation of independent component analysis (ICA) using SPM (Statistical Parametric Mapping) (SPM). We have developed and implemented the integrated conveyor processing. The implementation is clearly included in the analysis conveyor's amygdala and ensures accurate detection and display of the activity model under various irritating conditions. Our system shows the diverse and reliable activation of the amygdala that maintain additional understanding of the main role of emotional control and antisocial characteristics. This work not only checks the technical work process, but also provides practical tools by applying the potential clinical and judicial application of behavioral neurological biology focused on functional disorders related to amygdala.

title: ACO-LSTM Driven Prediction of Lithium-Ion Battery State-of-Charge: a Hybrid Approach
authors: Reshma Gopi Remabhai Amma, Chitra Annamalai, Maher Al-Greer, Razia Sultana W, Indra Gandhi V, Pujari Harish Kumar
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The precise determination of the state of charge (SOC) in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) is important, particularly in view of the increasing prevalence of electric vehicles. However, the precise estimation of SOC is a complex endeavor due to the inherent non-linear characteristics of these batteries. Recent advancements in Artificial Neural Networks and Machine Learning have introduced significant modifications in the estimation of these parameters. Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) exhibit significant promise for state of charge estimation, as they can learn temporal patterns and generate predictions independently of a predetermined battery model. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are particularly proficient, providing precise real-time SOC predictions and the capability to project future SOC over diverse timeframes. This paper presents a novel deep learning architecture developed through the fine-tuning of the traditional LSTM model using Ant Colony Optimization.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Model with Isolated Thresholding for Intrusion Detection in Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Sasson Taffwin Moses S, Abraham David L, Emil Selvan G S R, Ramkumar M P
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: In the evolving landscape of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs), ensuring robust intrusion detection mechanisms is vital for maintaining security and data integrity. Initially, a hybrid deep learning model combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Deep Neural Network (DNN) was developed to classify attacks with high accuracy using the WSN-DS dataset. This model effectively captured spatial and abstract features from network data, achieving strong baseline performance. Building on this foundation, the current work introduces an Isolated Thresholding Method (ITM) based on the Inter Quartile Range (IQR) to further enhance detection reliability. The ITM acts as a post-processing filter that re-evaluates samples initially classified as 'Normal' by the hybrid model. By applying IQRbased anomaly scoring, hidden outliers often corresponding to false negatives are identified and reclassified as intrusions. This statistical refinement significantly reduces undetected attacks, particularly those belonging to minority or stealthy classes. Experimental results demonstrate a marked improvement in sensitivity and an overall boost in the system's robustness. The integration of IQR-based statistical analysis with deep learning provides an intelligent, making the intrusion detection system more precise and dependable for real-world WSN security applications.

title: Leveraging Sentiment Analysis and Particle Swarm Optimization for Accurate Mental Disorders' Detection
authors: Alwan Atta, Dina El Sayad, Doaa Ezzat, Safaa Amin, Mahmoud El Gamal
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Accurate diagnosis of mental disorders is a prerequisite for the use of effective forms of treatment. The proposed solution highlights the potential of sentiment analysis in assessing a person's emotional status by examining the context of their written words, the precision of the diagnostic process is bolstered by Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The use of the PSO algorithm to optimize model parameters ensures best overall performance. Empirical evidence confirms the viability of the proposed approach to identifying the various mental disorders more accurately in contrast to current best practice. This new approach has much promise for the accurate early diagnosis of mental disorders and offers a considerable advantage to clinics through the ability to spot and treat conditions more accurately and reliably. The optimized Support Vector Classification using Particle Swarm Optimization achieved a global F-score of 0.89, showing the advantage of coupling sentiment analysis and swarm intelligence for the diagnosis of mental disorders.

title: End-to-End Intelligent Solution for Smart Gardening Using AWS and Blockchain
authors: Amal CN, Varun Jain, K Anusha, R Prakash
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This study presents an integrated, intelligent solution for smart gardening that synergizes Internet of Things (IoT), cloud computing, and blockchain technologies to automate and optimize plant irrigation. By using a network of embedded sensors to continuously monitor soil moisture and nutrient levels, the suggested system allows for real-time evaluation of environmental conditions and plant health. Through an easy-to-use user interface, the Amazon Web Services (AWS) Cloud processes and analyses the data collected by the sensors to enable remote decision-making and dynamic irrigation control. Every sensor reading and system action is permanently documented on a blockchain ledger to guarantee the accuracy, safety, and openness of environmental data. In addition to facilitating effective water use and enhancing crop management, its dual-layer architecture offers a tamperproof audit trail of resource consumption and environmental conditions. The suggested framework provides a safe and scalable method of smart agriculture that might greatly improve resilience and sustainability in gardening ecosystems in both urban and rural areas.

title: A Quantitative Framework for Layer-Wise Material Selection in MOSFETS Using Priority-Aware Property Mapping
authors: Yiyang Fu, Fage Liu, Zhengyao He, Qianrui Lin, Tee Hui Teo
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: This work introduces a quantitative physics-driven approach to make material choices for each layer of MOSFETs by combining priority-conscious property mapping with singlepass three-dimensional visualization. The proposed scheme can uniformly represent application-oriented scenario constraints and designer priority settings into physical parameters, leading to interpretable and replicable choices among semiconductor, dielectric, and metal materials. The proposed framework is divided into two steps. The first step is Material and Properties Selecting Tool. The scheme uses constraints imposed by application-oriented scenarios to determine design priority values. The second step is AI-assisted 3D Visualization Tool. The tool normalizes the best five candidates of each specific layer into the design property space using a weighted distance-overlap criteria. The proposed framework was evaluated using a scenario of a 28 nm Low Power CMOS (HK/MG-optimized process. The proposed scheme provides interpretable choices of physical materials.

title: Synthesizing Thermal Backgrounds from Visible-SWIR Spectral Imagery for Use in Earth Scene Simulations
authors: Robert Sundberg, Timothy Perkins
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: This paper examines the utility of synthetic spectral imagery derived from visible-SWIR HSI or MSI sensor data. Our method uses an endmember matching approach to extend spectral information to wavelengths beyond the original imagery. The derived images exhibit some loss of spectral and spatial clutter, but the dimensionality may be sufficient for applications such as synthetic scene simulations and development of algorithms for object detection.

title: A Solution to Optimal Power Flow Problems Using Improved Dragonfly Algorithm
authors: Soraphon Kigsirisin, Peerapol Jirapong, Panida Thararak, Hajime Miyauchi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Optimal power flow (OPF) problems are a challenging issue for worth economic and secure power systems under satisfying constraints. An approach to accomplish these issues is optimizing the systems by Dragonfly Algorithm (DA). DA dragonflies behave flying toward the food source (optimal solution) and outward from the enemy source (worst solution) only directionally. This results in limited exploration, premature convergence and poor solutions. To overcome these drawbacks, this study proposes Improved DA with Sinusoidal Movement (IDASM). By modifying the weight factors of those flying movements into a sinusoidal pattern, IDASM dragonflies can fly bidirectionally toward and outward from these sources, locate at various positions, and avoid local optima. Also, exploration and exploitation are improved throughout iterations. The effectiveness of IDASM is tested on the IEEE-30 bus test system via mathematical OPF objective functions. The results show that IDASM outperforms DA and the other referred algorithms achieving superior solutions for OPF problems.

title: Multi-Similarity Molecular Fingerprint Screening Approach Based on Morgan Fingerprints for the Discovery of Novel 5 $\alpha$ Reductase Inhibitors
authors: Ahmed Bahaa Shalaby, Huda A. Maghawry, Nagwa L. Badr
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Computer-based drug discovery has changed how scientists find new medicines by allowing them to search through huge collections of chemical compounds in a systematic way. The main challenge in targeting <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \alpha$</tex>-reductase comes from the need for safer treatments than current drugs that cause serious side effects. This study created a multi-similarity approach to find new 5a-reductase blockers by screening 249,456 compounds from the ZINC 250 database against 458 known active blockers. This research combines nine different similarity measures with molecular property analysis to find high-priority lead compounds with the best drug-like features. The method successfully found nine high-priority lead compounds (Table IV) with greater than 0.6 Tanimoto similarity and 100 % drug-likeness compliance, providing promising candidates for experimental testing while keeping computational efficiency for large-scale screening applications.

title: Impact of Concurrency and Dataset Size on MongoDB Performance Using YCSB and Perf
authors: Rashmi M S, Subramaniam Kalambur
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: MongoDB has become a popular NoSQL database for large-scale, latency-sensitive applications. Although existing benchmarking studies using the Yahoo Cloud Serving Benchmark (YCSB) typically focus on the default single-table configuration with varying thread counts, they often overlook scenarios involving multiple tables, clients, or larger datasets.This study expands the evaluation beyond traditional methods by introducing multi-table, multi-client scenarios, as well as varying data sizes while maintaining identical operational loads. The study shows that dual-table configurations introduce significant performance degradation, with runtime increasing up to 21× times and throughput dropping substantially compared to default single-table setups. Similarly, scaling the dataset size caused runtimes to increase up to 18× times, highlighting the substantial performance penalties introduced by larger working sets. Function-level profiling with Linux perf revealed that approximately 10.4% of the additional runtime overhead in multi-table cases is due to extra computation, with 5.66% due to new functions. Scaling the dataset size resulted in an additional 9.13% runtime overhead, primarily due to increased costs along existing code paths.This dual-layered analysis highlights scalability limitations and internal overheads associated with MongoDB under diverse workloads and deployment conditions, providing valuable insights for system architects optimizing database performance at scale.

title: A Semantic Ontology for Modeling COVID-19 Data in Egyptian Hospitals: Structure, Scope, and Use Cases
authors: Mohamed Ali, Zaki Taha, Mohamed Mabrouk
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic revealed significant gaps in the structure, integration, and interoperability of clinical data in many healthcare systems, especially in developing countries. This paper presents a domain-specific Resource Description Framework (RDF)/Web Ontology Language (OWL) ontology built to model COVID-19 medical data across Egyptian hospitals. The ontology captures key schema-level elements such as symptoms, treatments, laboratory indicators, outcomes, and hospital metadata, providing a semantic framework for organizing and querying medical information. By formalizing these concepts, the ontology enables better data integration, facilitates clinical knowledge sharing, and supports future applications in decision support and epidemiological analysis. This paper further demonstrates how ontology-driven querying and reasoning can address complex clinical questions and outlines multiple use cases in healthcare integration, public health surveillance, and pandemic response.

title: The Evolution of Metaverse for Smart Psychotherapy System
authors: Ahmed Zedaan M. Abed, Tamer Abdelkader, Mohamed Hashem
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Recently, smart devices have become increasingly popular, drawing the attention of researchers for their ability to enhance the quality of life for citizens by providing essential services. The Smart Psychotherapy system makes use of these devices in combination with modern digital technologies, including the Internet of Things (IoT), extended reality (XR) technologies such as Virtual, Augmented, and Mixed Reality, in addition to big data processing, cloud-based infrastructures, and artificial intelligence (AI) techniques. This approach aims to modernize the Psychotherapy framework, resulting in improved efficiency, convenience, and personalized care. This paper emphasizes the primary characteristics of the Smart Psychotherapy System by outlining its essential components. We performed a comparative analysis between the elements of the Metaverse for Smart Psychotherapy System and the Cyber-Physical-Social System (CPSS), illustrating that the Metaverse for Smart Psychotherapy System operates as a Cyber-Physical-Social System (CPSS). Additionally, we explore the evolution of the Metaverse for the Smart Psychotherapy System and examine potential security threats.

title: FPGA-Based Muon Beam Monitoring with Real-Time Fault Recovery
authors: Yoshiki Yamada, Yoshiki Yamaguchi, Kenya Okabe, Yowichi Fujita, Yoshinori Fukao, Eitaro Hamada, Youichi Igarashi, Masayoshi Shoji, Hironori Uchinoyae, Tetsuichi Kishishita, Kazuki Ueno
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: This paper presents a scalable and autonomous FPGA-SoC architecture designed for real-time muon-beam monitoring in the COMET experiment at J-PARC. The proposed system integrates a parallel stream-alignment mechanism and on-chip error-correction logic within a deterministic pipeline, achieving a processing latency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.56 \sim \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> and an alignment accuracy exceeding 99.99 %. In contrast to our previously reported single-channel prototype, this design introduces full multi-channel scalability, autonomous synchronization, and a hardware-level fault-recovery mechanism. Implemented on a Kintex-7 FPGA and validated on the COMET Phase- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex> beamline, the system demonstrated stable operation for more than 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> beam cycles without any packet loss or timing drift. The architecture supports hierarchical scalability up to 256 channels, enabling real-time adaptability under radiation-exposure conditions. These results confirm that deterministic, low-latency data acquisition with a self-healing capability can be achieved entirely in hardware. The proposed approach establishes a foundation for heterogeneous and reconfigurable SoC systems applicable to next-generation accelerator instrumentation as well as intelligent sensing environments.

title: MicroIntent: Intent-Based Placement Strategy for Microservice Application in the Compute Continuum Using LLMs
authors: Koushikur Islam, Guilherme Da Cunha Rodrigues, Bahman Javadi, Rodrigo N. Calheiros
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: The placement of microservices in the compute continuum plays a vital role in delivering services that comply with customers’ needs, such as reduced latency, storage requirements, quality of service and availability. To achieve customers’ needs in the geographically dispersed architecture of the compute continuum, Service Level Objectives (SLOs) have been largely used in decision-making to place microservices. However, because low-level SLOs increase the barrier to entry for continuum users, placement decisions based on high-level business vocabulary are required if the compute continuum is to be adopted at scale. This paper proposes an architecture for microservices placement decisions in the computing continuum utilizing highlevel user intents described in natural language as input. The approach utilizes Generative Artificial Intelligence to translate the intents to low-level SLOs, which are used along with the infrastructure description to decide where different microservices that compose an application must be deployed so that SLOs are met. We implement and evaluate a prototype of the architecture to demonstrate the approach’s feasibility.

title: IoT Based Smart Irrigation System Using Image Processing
authors: Felicia R P, Brisilla R M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Traditional irrigation methods often result in inefficient wa ter di stribution, le ading to pr oblems su ch as over-watering or under-watering for farmers. To address this issue, this paper proposes a smart irrigation system that integrates IoT, machine learning, and environmental data analysis. The system utilizes Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and the YOLO model to capture plant images, identify species, and determine their specific water needs from a database. I <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$t$</tex> a lso monitors soil moisture, temperature, and humidity to calculate precise water needs in real time. In addition, it can detect potential hazards, such as smoke or gas, and adjust the water pressure accordingly. This data-driven irrigation system conserves water, improves crop yield, reduces manual labor, and minimizes risks such as fire.

title: FMCW Radar Respiratory Monitoring via Sequential Motion State Classification and Apnea Segmentation
authors: Ruoyu He, Masaki Kurosawa, Guanghao Sun
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Communication and Information Systems (ICCIS)
abstract: In recent years, research on using frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) radar to make non-contact measurements of human vital signs has attracted widespread attention. This study proposes a two-step signal processing system based on FMCW radar for non-contact respiratory analysis. The system first classifies target motion states and then segments stationary state signals into normal breathing and apnea intervals. During the motion recognition stage, a threshold comparison of the target’s velocity is used to label the target as moving or stationary. In the stationary state phase, this method extracts the target’s chest vibration signal (breathing and heartbeat) and then calculates the sliding standard deviation of the vibration signal. A low standard deviation indicates apnea, while a higher value indicates normal breathing. In this study, threshold processing of the vibration signal was used for demonstration, showing that even this basic method can reliably separate breathing signal based on motion state and sliding standard deviation.

title: Concept Discovery in Power Electronics Training Using Non-Negative Matrix Factorization
authors: Abdurahim Mannonov, Dhanasri S, Rajvir Saini, Israa G. AL-Kafaji, Otamirzaev Muzaffar Bakhodirugli
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Power electronics training involves mastering complex concepts that are crucial for designing and controlling electronic power systems. Traditional teaching methods often struggle to identify and address students' conceptual weaknesses efficiently. This paper proposes a novel approach called Concept Discovery via Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (CD-NMF) to analyze learners' responses and uncover underlying concept patterns. The primary problem is the challenge of extracting interpretable and actionable insights from large-scale training data, which is often sparse and nonnegative by nature. CD-NMF leverages the mathematical properties of NMF to decompose student response matrices into meaningful latent components corresponding to core concepts in power electronics. These components serve to reveal concept mastery levels and identify misconceptions. The interpretability of NMF facilitates educators' understanding of students' learning status without requiring labeled data or complex feature engineering. Experiments on a dataset collected from power electronics training sessions demonstrate that CD-NMF outperforms baseline matrix factorization and clustering methods in terms of concept detection accuracy and educational relevance. The approach successfully identifies distinct concept clusters aligning with curriculum design, providing a practical tool for personalized intervention and curriculum adjustment. In conclusion, CD-NMF is an effective and interpretable datadriven method for concept discovery in power electronics education. It enhances training efficacy by pinpointing knowledge gaps and supporting tailored feedback, potentially improving learning outcomes significantly. Future work will explore integrating CD-NMF with adaptive learning systems to automate personalized curricula dynamically.

title: A Novel 4H-SiC 3D Trench MOSFET with Punch-Through Protection and Gate Trench Bottom Implantation
authors: Xinyue Lu, Jiupeng Wu, Na Ren, Kuang Sheng, Ji Cheng, Liming Wei, Jue Wang, Qing Yu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This paper presents the simulation-based optimization of a novel 3D 4H-SiC trench MOSFET. The device features a P+ electric field shielding region placed perpendicular to the gate trench, enabling a compact cell pitch and achieving a low specific on-resistance ($\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{on}, \mathrm{sp}}$) of $2.24 \mathrm{~m} \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$. However, the thin P -well base layer required for low $\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{on}, \mathrm{sp}}$ introduces punch-through possibility and high trench-corner gate oxide electric fields. To address these issues, two innovations are proposed. Firstly, a P-well additional implantation (PAITMOS) can suppress premature punch-through and thus enhance breakdown voltage from 900 V to<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>|738 V. And secondly, a gate trench bottom implantation (GTBI-TMOS), which deepens the deep P+ electric field shielding region and reduces the peak oxide electric field from $4.6\lt sup\gt1\lt/sup\gt| \mathrm{MV} / \mathrm{cm}$ to 3.30 MV/cm. Furthermore, simultaneous optimization of channel length and P -well doping raises the threshold voltage ($\mathrm{V}_{\text {th }}$) to 3.42 V with minimal Ron,sp penalty. The structure combining all the optimizations, referred to as PGI-TMOS, achieves a great performance with a $\mathrm{R}_{\text {on, sp }}$ of $2.38 \mathrm{~m} \Omega \cdot \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$, a BV of<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>|455 V, an $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{ox}}$ of $3.30 \mathrm{MV} / \mathrm{cm}$, and a $\mathrm{V}_{\text {th }}$ of 3.42 V, while also demonstrating clear design guidelines on the trade-offs among N+ source geometry, shielding region coverage, and blocking capability.

title: Economic Comparison and Scheduling Optimization of Oxygen-Integrated Integrated Energy System
authors: Bowen Wang, Jun Wu, Shitong Luo, Liang Wang, Shuo Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the transformation of the global energy structure and the proposal of low-carbon development goals, the development of a clean, economical and efficient energy supply system has become an important task in the energy field. Integrated Energy Systems (IES), as a system that is synergistically optimized through multiple energy forms, are gaining traction due to their potential to improve energy efficiency and reduce system operating costs. Especially at high altitudes, it is particularly important to promote the application of oxygen integrated energy systems due to the special needs and challenges of oxygen supply. This system can not only effectively meet the demand for oxygen in high-altitude areas, but also cope with the impact of new energy volatility. By promoting local energy sharing transactions between multiple energy entities, it can not only improve the utilization rate of new energy, but also reduce the overall operating cost of the system. In this paper, we propose an oxygen integrated energy system (OIES), in which oxygen is introduced as an important energy carrier to optimize its use, thereby improving energy conversion efficiency and resource utilization. The main contributions of this paper include the proposal and exploration of the Oxygen-Integrated Energy System (OIES), which effectively integrates multiple energy forms while specifically addressing the unique oxygen demands of high-altitude regions. By optimizing the processes of oxygen production, storage, and release, the paper demonstrates the advantages of OIES in improving energy efficiency, reducing operational costs, and mitigating the volatility of renewable energy sources. Through an economic comparison of water electrolysis and compressed air methods for oxygen production, the study reveals the benefits of each approach in different operational contexts, with water electrolysis being particularly well-suited to addressing energy fluctuations. Furthermore, the paper introduces a scheduling model based on the Improved Particle Swarm Optimization (IPSO) algorithm, which optimizes the oxygen production, storage, and release process, thus reducing costs and enhancing system flexibility. This system provides a practical and effective solution for the efficient management of oxygen in multi-energy systems.

title: IoT-Based Predictive Maintenance in Smart Electric Vehicles for Enhanced Reliability and Sustainability
authors: Arivoli Sundaramurthy, Bavithra Karunanithi, Karthikeyan B
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: With the rapid rise of electric vehicle (EV) adoption in 2024-2025, ensuring reliability and serviceability is a major challenge. Traditional reactive or scheduled maintenance cannot adequately prevent sudden subsystem failures in batteries, motors, or power electronics, which cause downtime, safety risks, and higher costs. This study presents an Internet of Things (IoT)-based predictive maintenance framework for smart EVs, emphasizing real-time fault prediction and anomaly detection. The framework integrates sensor networks, cloud analytics, and machine learning models to anticipate failures before escalation. Key components include: (i) monitoring of the Battery Management System (BMS), traction motor, and thermal modules; (ii) a machine learning pipeline using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) for time-series forecasting and Random Forest for fault classification; and (iii) a scalable, cloud-enabled architecture for fleet-wide reliability. A prototype drivetrain instrumented with voltage, current, temperature, and vibration sensors transmitted data via a Raspberry Pi gateway over MQTT. The LSTM achieved above 92% accuracy in thermal forecasting, while the Random Forest reached up to 96% accuracy and balanced precision-recall above 92% with cross-validation. Results demonstrated a 30% reduction in unplanned service events and up to 8% efficiency gain, confirming IoT-driven predictive maintenance as a viable strategy for smart EVs.

title: Design and Implementation of a Digital Titration Analyser Based on ESP32
authors: Zhuohang Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This article shows the design and how to make a digital titration analyzer that's based on the ESP32 microcontroller. It's like a precise dance where the hardware and algorithms work together perfectly, just like how different elements blend in a special reactor. Using the HX711 24-bit ADC to carefully watch the signals from the weight sensor, and with the AT24C02 EEPROM acting like a permanent storage for liquid density records, the system sends data through Bluetooth BLE channels. It also uses polynomial fitting algorithms to make measurements more accurate. This system can figure out liquid density, calculate volume, clean up data, and send it wirelessly. It's known for being super precise, responding really fast, and easy to use. Tests prove that the system is really stable and accurate for titration analysis, meeting the needs of both labs and factories. Using the ideas from ESP32-based edge computing, this design makes data handling better in places with limited resources, making the embedded systems work really quickly, in less than 200 milliseconds.

title: Design and Implementation of an Environmental Monitoring System Based on Multimodal Sensors
authors: Yuqi Hu
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: With the acceleration of industrialization and urbanization, the requirements for real-time and accuracy of environmental monitoring are increasingly high. To meet this demand, this study designs and implements an environmental monitoring system based on multimodal sensors. The system uses an STM32 microcontroller as the core control unit, and integrates the DHT11 digital temperature and humidity sensor, BH1750 light intensity sensor, and MQ-135 air quality sensor modules, and is equipped with a serial communication module to ensure the reliability of data transmission. Experimental tests show that the system can collect multi-dimensional environmental parameters such as gas concentration, light intensity, temperature, and humidity in real-time, providing a new reference method for the field of intelligent environmental monitoring.

title: Sensor-Driven Ensemble Learning for Crop Recommendation and Disease Prediction in Precision Agriculture
authors: Gerasimos Vonitsanos, Emmanouela-Electra Economopoulou, Spyros Sioutas, Andreas Kanavos, Phivos Mylonas
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Agriculture plays a vital role in ensuring global food security, yet it faces growing challenges from climate change, resource limitations, and increasing demand. This paper presents an ensemble learning framework that leverages Internet of Things (IoT) sensor data for crop recommendation and plant disease prediction in precision agriculture. Environmental parameters including temperature, humidity, rainfall, soil pH, and nutrient levels are modeled using Random Forest, Neural Networks, and Logistic Regression classifiers. Experimental evaluation on a publicly available dataset shows that Random Forest achieves superior performance, reaching 89.20% accuracy and the highest F1-score, outperforming baseline models in robustness and interpretability. The integration of Apache Spark enables scalable and near real-time analysis, making the approach suitable for practical deployment. By combining ensemble learning with sensor-driven environmental monitoring, the proposed framework supports sustainable, interpretable, and data-driven agricultural decision-making for farmers, researchers, and policymakers.

title: Design and Development of Extended Phase Shift Controlled Dual Active Bridge Converter for EV Battery Charging
authors: Manav Kumar Agarwal, Arunavo Das, Rajalakshmi M, Razia Sultana W, Chitra A
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper focuses on the design, simulation, and implementation of a Dual Active Bridge (DAB) DC-DC converter for bidirectional power transfer in EV battery charging applications. The performance of the converter is rigorously evaluated under both Single Phase Shift (SPS) and Extended Phase Shift (EPS) modulation techniques in open-loop and closed-loop control systems. The study highlights how the closed-loop system significantly e nhances o utput p ower <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r$</tex> egulation a nd dynamic responsiveness compared to the open-loop setup. A comparative analysis of power losses between Silicon (Si) and Silicon Carbide (SiC) MOSFETs was conducted in simulations, showcasing the superior efficiency of S iC d evices d ue t o r educed switching and conduction losses, making them ideal for high-power, high-frequency applications. Experimental validation, conducted using a closed-loop DAB system hardware prototype, further confirmed the converter's efficacy for lithium-ion b attery charging through stable charging characteristics and dependable performance. EPS modulation proved more suitable for real-world applications due to smoother power transmission and higher efficiency a cross a wider range of operating conditions. This work offers a valuable foundation for the future development of more reliable and effective power electronic interfaces for applications including electric vehicles and renewable energy storage systems.

title: Towards Accurate Water Quality Prediction Using Attention-Guided Deep Imputation Models
authors: Marwah A. Helaly, Sherine Rady, Mohamed Mabrouk, Mostafa M. Aref, Ahmed T. El Awady
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: This research examines how various imputation methods and deep learning models influence water quality forecasting by utilizing time-series sensor data from Galicia, Spain. We evaluated the advanced SAITS imputation model against traditional Median and KNN techniques across various targets - pH, Dissolved Oxygen (DO), Total Ammonium (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{NH}_{4}{ }^{+}$</tex>), and Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD-5) - utilizing multiple neural network structures, including CNN, CNN-LSTM, CNN-LSTM with Attention, and CNN-BiLSTM. Our findings indicate that SAITS significantly enhances predictive performance in almost every task. For example, in DO prediction with LSTM, SAITS lowered RMSE by 98.6 % relative to Median imputation and raised <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> from 0.992 to an ideal 1.0. In the pH prediction task employing CNN-LSTM with Attention, SAITS decreased RMSE by 71.6% compared to the Median and lowered MAE by 73.3%. In predicting Total Ammonium using CNN-LSTM, SAITS attained the lowest MAE (0.037), surpassing KNN by 15.9% and enhancing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> from 0.921 to 0.943. Ultimately, for DOB-5 forecasting, SAITS employing CNN-BiLSTM lowered RMSE by 89% versus KNN and enhanced <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> from 0.988 to 0.996. In summary, the integration of SAITS imputation with recurrent neural structures consistently resulted in the best accuracy, validating the benefits of temporal-aware imputation and appropriate model frameworks in predicting water quality.

title: Automating Timing Enclaves for Reactive Programs in Lingua Franca
authors: Julian Robledo, Jeronimo Castrillon
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Lingua Franca (LF) is a coordination language for cyber-physical systems that ensures deterministic execution through the reactor model. While LF's conservative scheduler guarantees correctness, it can hinder performance due to synchronization barriers that limit parallelism. Timing enclaves, a recent extension to LF, mitigate this by partitioning programs into independently scheduled regions with decoupled logical timelines. However, determining optimal enclave configurations is non-trivial and not intuitive to programmers, as it requires balancing parallelism, synchronization overhead, and system constraints. In this paper, we present a framework for Design Space Exploration (DSE) of timing enclaves in LF programs. Our approach automatically analyzes the program's topology, identifies valid enclave partitions, and uses heuristics to explore trade-offs between determinism and latency. We evaluate the effectiveness of our method on synthetic benchmarks and a realworld 4G baseband processing application. Results show that our DSE framework can significantly improve performance while preserving deterministic semantics, highlighting its practical value for complex real-time systems.

title: MTDC for Connecting Indonesian Islands Enabling Renewable Energy Generation
authors: Hanchi Zhang, Sanjay Chaudhary, Rian Fatah Mochamad, Roni Irnawan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Multi-terminal high voltage DC (MTDC) technology can be a feasible solution for long-distance interconnection of the islands in archipelago power systems, thereby transmitting renewable energy from remote islands to the load centres. This paper proposes the interconnection of Flores, Sumba, Sumbawa and Lombok islands using the MTDC transmission system in Indonesia. The proposed MTDC system has four terminals, one on each island. Each terminal has a modular multilevel converter for the connection of the AC and DC power networks. Thus, the photovoltaic power generated on Sumba and Flores islands can be transmitted to the load centres on Sumbawa and Lombok islands. Droop controllers are implemented on the converter terminals to improve dynamic sharing of disturbances and variations. The performance of such a system is studied using time domain simulations of generation fluctuations and transient short circuit faults in the AC side on Flores as examples. These simulation studies show that the MTDC system can ride through the faults on the three islands and safely recover to normal operation, as long as the Lombok terminal, which is the largest of all, is operational.

title: A RAG-Based Approach for Knowledge Retrieval and Question Answering on Diabetic Foot Ulcers Using LLMs
authors: Bhavika Patel, Sonali Gandhi, Monali Gandhi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Diabetic foot ulcers are a severe and common complication of diabetes, often leading to infection and lower limb amputation. Early and effective treatment is crucial. The internet offers millions of documents to support effective treatment strategies for this condition. However, accurate information extraction from high-dimensional datasets is still quite difficult. Traditional Information Retrieval approaches rely on keyword matching, statical ranking and rule-based approaches to search the relevant documents. These approaches struggle to retrieve relevant knowledge before generating the well-formed answers. To overcome these limitations, this research highlights the potential of AI-driven technologies like Large Language Model, Retrieval Augmented Generation and FAISS vector database. This hybrid approach enables structured document processing, context-aware text chunking, and interactive communication via a web interface by extracting semantics from multiple PDFs. This study aims to bridge the gap between healthcare professionals and the knowledge in documents, promoting LLM-driven solutions to improve decision-making.

title: TransUNet++: A Multiscale CNN-Transformer Hybrid Framework for Multi-Modal Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Chaymae El Mechal, Najiba El Amrani El Idrissi, Loubna Mazgouti, Fatima Zahra Ammor
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Accurate brain tumor segmentation from multi-modal MRI scans remains a difficult task due to the wide variability in tumor morphology and the complexity of brain anatomy. To tackle these challenges, we present TransUNet++, a hybrid CNN-Transformer model that integrates convolutional feature extraction with hierarchically organized multi-scale attention pathways. This design enables the network to capture detailed local structures while simultaneously modeling global contextual dependencies. To address boundary ambiguity and class imbalance, we employ a composite loss function that combines focal loss, multi-scale structural similarity (MS-SSIM), and the Jaccard index. In addition, an attention-guided decoder is incorporated to filter out irrelevant background signals and refine segmentation accuracy. We evaluated TransUNet++ on the BraTS 2021 benchmark and a clinical dataset from CHU Hospital. The model achieved Dice scores of 0.92 for whole tumor, 0.87 for tumor core, and 0.85 for the enhancing region. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of TransUNet++ and its strong potential for supporting clinical neuro-oncology workflows, particularly in diagnosis and surgical planning.

title: AeroMeldNet: Lightweight Multi-Task MambaVision Framework for Real-Time Aerial Scene and Disaster Detection
authors: Anuvab Sen, Angshuman Roy, Subhabrata Roy, Subhrajit Deb
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and other edge devices often require real-time scene classification and disaster detection under tight resource constraints. However, most existing pipelines treat these tasks separately or artificially merge data, overlooking potential synergies while risking data imbalance. We propose AeroMeldNet, a lightweight partial-labeled multi-task pipeline built on MambaVision, featuring two heads (scene vs. disaster) and advanced optimization stages: pruning, dynamic quantization, half-precision training, and knowledge distillation. Our multi-stage approach drastically reduces FLOPs and parameter counts without sacrificing accuracy. We leverage the AID dataset for aerial scene classification and AIDER dataset for disaster detection, preserving each dataset's unique label space. Extensive experiments indicate up to 95-96% accuracy on respective test sets with significant FLOPs reduction, making it feasible for real-time edge deployment. Our method addresses the scarcity of combined aerial datasets by enabling partiallabeled multi-task training, demonstrating that synergy across tasks can yield robust feature extraction without forcing normal re-labeling. This pipeline sets a practical precedent for resourceefficient drone-based aerial detection systems.

title: Work-in-Progress: An Open-Source Evaluation Framework for Time-Sensitive Networking Scheduling Research
authors: Chuanyu Xue, Elaine Hu, Tianyu Zhang, Song Han
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Reproducing and extending research on TimeSensitive Networking (TSN) scheduling has become increasingly challenging, as most published methods lack open-source implementations. The few available implementations are often scattered across different programming languages and formats, forcing researchers to reimplement algorithms from scratch—a time-consuming and error-prone process that hinders fair comparison of methods and slows research progress. In this work, we present TSNKit, an open-source toolkit designed to address these challenges through: (i) standardized implementations of a broad set of representative scheduling algorithms with unified interfaces for integrating new methods; (ii) an end-to-end pipeline covering test case generation, scheduling, and simulation-based validation; and (iii) comprehensive benchmarking modules for reproducible performance evaluation. TSNKit enables researchers to reproduce published results, extend existing methods, and perform fair comparisons across algorithms. Our ongoing work extends TSNKit to support multiple traffic shapers beyond Time-Aware Shaping (TAS), improve benchmark efficiency through enhanced scheduling heuristics, and incorporate hardware-in-the-loop capabilities for seamless real-world deployment.

title: Research on Few-Shot Defect Classification Based on Improved MobileNetV3
authors: Xu Li, Yanan Yu, Zongli Liu, Shuyan Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: To address the limited generalization capability of detection models caused by emerging rare defect types in steel surface inspection, this study proposes a meta-learning framework integrating data augmentation and transfer initialization. The framework first acquires generic feature representations through large-scale pre-training, then enhances sample diversity via self-supervised data augmentation strategies. The MAML (Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning) algorithm enables rapid adaptation to new classification tasks, while the SE (Squeeze-and-Excitation) attention mechanism in Bottleneck modules is replaced with self-attention to optimize feature extraction efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that the improved model achieves significant performance gains on the few-shot image classification benchmark FSC-20, with 34.5% higher accuracy and 29.68% improved F1-score under the 10-shot setting. This method provides an efficient and practical solution for industrial defect classification under few-shot learning conditions.

title: Bridging Vision and Arabic: A Deep Learning Survey of Arabic Image Captioning Techniques
authors: Mohamed Magdi Mohamed, Mohamed Mabrouk Morsey, Mostafa Aref
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The past decade has seen a surge in interest toward intelligent systems that can interpret and describe visual content using natural language. While this progress is notable across many languages, morphologically rich languages such as Arabic present unique difficulties for such systems, including intricate grammar, deep semantic structure, and limited annotated re- sources. These challenges have motivated research in Arabic Image Captioning (AIC), which integrates computer vision with natural language generation. This survey compiles and analyzes over twenty research contributions, covering both model-oriented studies and works introducing key datasets. The approaches discussed in this work, range from early Convolutional Neural Network-Recurrent Neural Network (CNN-RNN) pipelines to transformer-based designs, multimodal encoder-decoder frame- works, and Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) models enhanced with reinforcement learning (RL). Additionally, we summarize widely used datasets, evaluation benchmarks, and scoring strategies in AIC (e.g., BLEU, ROUGE, CIDEr, BERT Score). By consolidating the current state of the field, we highlight persistent issues-such as adapting to dialectal and cultural nuances, maintaining semantic fidelity, and overcoming data scarcity. Finally, we discuss potential research directions for advancing Arabic image captioning

title: Zero-Shot YOLOv8 Descriptors for Low-Latency Object Tracking
authors: Ayoub El-Alami, Younes Nadir, Khalifa Mansouri
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Object tracking in real-time applications often relies on the tracking-by-detection paradigm, where object localization and temporal association are decoupled. While methods such as DeepSORT integrate a detector like YOLO with additional CNN-based ReID module for appearance matching, the ReID network imposes significant computational and memory burdens, especially on edge or CPU-only systems. This work explores the use of zero-training appearance descriptors extracted directly from YOLOv8's internal multi-scale feature maps (P3, P4, P5), used individually as lightweight alternatives to conventional ReID embeddings. Our method selects a feature scale based on object size and retrieves a fixed-length feature vector via a simple center-cell lookup. On the MOT20 train benchmark, our fastest configuration, (i.e. based on the P3 feature map) achieves more than 90% of the HOTA score of the standard DeepSORT with ReID, while reducing tracking time per frame from 0.279 s to 0.035 s on a CPU. These results demonstrate that YOLOv8's native features hold sufficient discriminative power for training-free, real-time object association, eliminating the need for costly ReID networks in resource-constrained deployments.

title: Embedded Proportional Plus Integral Controller Feedback in UNet++ for Dynamic Feature Stabilization and Segmentation of Lung Nodules
authors: Sangeetha V, Kalaivani S
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Segmentation operations are vital for detecting lung nodules in CT images and distinguishing between benign and cancerous types. Early detection is crucial in lung cancer, which has high malignancy rates. Although several deep-learning methods exist for nodule segmentation, challenges such as nodule characteristics, positioning, false positives, and boundary detection still remain. An innovative approach using a Proportional Integral Controller (PIC) within the UNet++ framework effectively manages feature map intensity during training, targeting a normalized mean of 0.5. This method adjusts activations based on the difference between current and desired intensities, with learnable proportional (Kp) and integral (Ki) gains enabling real-time internal feature modulation. Concepts from control theory enhance adaptive control, optimization, and training dynamics. The PIC framework improves convergence, reduces errors, and stabilizes training, resulting in better neural network performance. The design ensures stable feature flow and clearer feature maps, while the PIC Attention Layer enhances supervision for more consistent training outcomes. With a Dice coefficient of 0.96 and an IoU of 0.91, the model shows outstanding performance on the LIDC-IDRI dataset. A p-value of 0.0006 further confirms the model's stability and effectiveness compared to the current state-of-the-art.

title: Operational Pattern Mining in Industrial Maintenance Using the SPADE Algorithm
authors: Muyassar Kholova, Rajameena S, Ravinder Sharma, Saif O. Husain, Mansurov Isroiljon Gofur Ugli
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Operational pattern mining plays a vital role in industrial maintenance by identifying recurring sequences of machine behavior, faults, and maintenance activities to enhance system reliability. The increasing complexity of industrial systems and the large volume of sensor and maintenance log data create challenges for effective pattern discovery. Existing methods often rely on statistical analysis or manual expert rules, which are unable to efficiently capture hidden sequential dependencies and temporal relationships in large datasets, leading to incomplete or inaccurate predictive insights. This study proposes the SPADE-Based Sequential Pattern Mining Framework (SSPMF), a datadriven approach that leverages the SPADE algorithm to automatically extract frequent operational and fault sequences from historical maintenance and sensor data. The framework transforms raw data into structured sequences, applies SPADE for pattern discovery, and enables predictive maintenance decision support. The proposed method helps maintenance teams predict faults and schedule preventive actions in advance. Experimental results demonstrate that SSPMF effectively uncovers significant patterns, improving fault prediction accuracy and reducing unplanned downtime.

title: Radar Multi-Target Tracking Data Association Method Based on Transformer
authors: Jiani Liu, Liqiang Luo, Jian Gao, Sen Yang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Radar multi-target tracking is a core research direction in radar data processing, where data association, as a key step, directly affects tracking accuracy. Traditional data association methods are prone to errors in clutter, noise, and target intersection scenarios. In contrast, deep learning technologies have shown superior performance potential over traditional methods in this field. Therefore, this paper proposes a data association method based on Transformer, addressing the limitations of classical data association algorithms, which require prior information such as the target motion model and clutter density. The proposed method leverages data-driven learning to capture the relationships between target tracks and measurements. It uses position embedding to capture the motion characteristics of targets and Doppler information embedding to maintain velocity similarity, effectively performing the data association task for multi-target tracks and measurements in motion-crossing scenarios.

title: Automated Drainage Monitoring and Gas Hazard Prevention System with Energy Utilization
authors: V. Karunambigai, M. Janani, B. Tharani, G. Sundar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of an Automated Drainage Monitoring and Gas Hazard Prevention System with Energy Utilization, aimed at improving urban infrastructure safety and sustainability. Integrating IoT-based real-time monitoring with automation and energy recovery, the system employs an ESP32 microcontroller, gas and ultrasonic sensors, and a GSM module for effective hazard detection and remote communication. The system detects toxic gas emissions (such as methane and hydrogen sulfide), monitors water levels to predict blockages or overflows, and automatically triggers safety mechanisms, including solenoid valves and SMS alerts. A key innovation is the utilization of hazardous gases through a boiler-turbine-generator system to convert waste gas into usable electrical energy, contributing to environmental sustainability. Notably, release gas is also used for burning stoves, further emphasizing the practical energy reuse aspect of the design. Performance testing confirmed the system's high sensor accuracy, quick hazard response, and effective energy conversion, making it a scalable and eco-smart solution for future urban drainage management.

title: Design of a Graph Retrieval-Augmented Question Answering Model for the ATT&CK Knowledge Graph
authors: Xing Wei, Jun Ma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: With the increasing sophistication of cyber attacks, traditional passive defense systems struggle to cope with stealthy offensive techniques. Although the MITRE ATT&CK framework provides a comprehensive knowledge base of adversarial behaviors, its structured and specialized nature limits its accessibility for average security practitioners. Large language models (LLMs) excel in natural language processing tasks but suffer from hallucinations, outdated knowledge, and data privacy concerns in specialized domains. To address these issues, this paper proposes a Graph Retrieval-Augmented Generation (GraphRAG) based question-answering model that integrates the ATT&CK knowledge graph with LLMs to accurately answer multi-hop reasoning questions in cybersecurity. The method constructs a knowledge graph integrating multiple sources such as ATT&CK, CVE, and CWE, and leverages LLMs for entity recognition, relation pruning, and path reasoning. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly outperforms baseline models in F1-score, validating its effectiveness in cybersecurity knowledge question-answering.

title: Hybrid CNN-Transformer Model for Oral Cancer Detection from Oral Photographs
authors: Siva Chaithanya V, Vijayabhaskaramoorthy V, T S Sainiranjan, R Bharathwaj, Swapna T R
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents a Hybrid CNN-Transformer model for oral cancer detection from photographic images. While CNNs are efficient in capturing spatial features, and Transformers excel at modeling global dependencies, each has limitations in isolation. Our hybrid architecture combines CNN-based local feature extraction with Transformer-based global context modeling to improve classification performance. The model was evaluated on the Mendeley Oral Cancer Dataset and achieved an accuracy of 98.46 %. However, the dataset's limited diversity and the absence of statistical significance testing limit the generalizability of these results. This study contributes to the ongoing exploration of hybrid deep learning models in medical imaging, with emphasis on computational efficiency and real-world applicability. This research highlights the potential of hybrid deep learning architectures in medical imaging, providing a robust, scalable, and AI-driven solution for early oral cancer detection and enhanced clinical decision-making.

title: Effect of Growth Temperature on C-face 4H-SiC Homoepitaxy
authors: Yuyang Wang, Hanyu Zhao, Yicheng Pei, Moyu Wei, Yunkai Li, Jingyi Jiao, Qing Katherine Mu, Guoguo Yan, Yingxi Niu, Xingfang Liu
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: The homoepitaxial growth of silicon carbide was conducted on 4° off-axis n-type 4 H -SiC C -face substrates using low-pressure chemical vapor deposition. This study systematically investigated the influence of growth temperature $\left(1550^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 1600^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right.$ and $\left.1650^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\right)$ on the crystallinity and surface morphology of the epitaxial layers. The results revealed a strong dependence of both surface morphology and crystalline quality on growth temperature. At $1550^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, the epitaxial layer consisted of 3C-SiC polytype with rough surface morphology and non-uniform grain distribution. When the growth temperature was elevated to $1600^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, step-flow growth mode became dominant, producing a smooth and dense $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ epitaxial layer with optimal crystalline quality and a surface roughness of merely 1.27 nm. Further increasing the temperature to $1650^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ maintained the step-flow growth mode but induced step coalescence and local surface roughening, resulting in diminished surface flatness. These findings provide significant guidance for optimizing the homoepitaxial growth process on C-face $4 \mathrm{H}-\mathrm{SiC}$ substrates and contribute valuable insights for enhancing the performance of SiC-based electronic devices.

title: XATNYS: AI-Powered Operating System with Integrated Reinforcement Learning and Context-Aware Productivity Assistant
authors: Ishaan Katara, Shivendra Vikram Singh, Mansi Bhardwaj, Anil Kumar Mahto, Puja Kumari
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: This research presents XATNYS—an AI-powered operating system architected with a secure, Rust-based microkernel and embedded with intelligent modules for autonomous system control and user-centered productivity enhancement. Unlike traditional OS environments, XATNYS integrates reinforcement learning (RL) schedulers, deep learning anomaly detection, adaptive power optimization, and a real-time assistant (R.I.M.A.S.) into its core.XATNYS incorporates a PPO-based RL task scheduler, which achieved 87% task-priority alignment compared to manual schedules, improving average application launch time by 28%. The deep anomaly engine, trained on synthetic and real logs, flags threats with 91% precision, enabling proactive mitigation of system instability. A supervised resource manager dynamically balances CPU and memory usage, while an AI-driven power optimizer yielded an average 23% gain in battery efficiency during trials. The integrated NLP module enables natural system control, while R.I.M.A.S. adds user engagement through computer vision and voice feedback.Empirical evaluations across 35 diverse users demonstrated 86% satisfaction, with reported boosts in focus, lower idle time, and intelligent intervention handling. The YOLOv8-based activity recognition within R.I.M.A.S. recorded 98.1% mAP@0.5, with precision above 93% across all classes including "Focused," "Phone Usage," and "Idle." All AI inference is performed locally, ensuring GDPR-compliant privacy.

title: An Ultra-Low-Power Wearable Wristband with Compressed Sensing and on-Chip AI for Real-Time Cardiovascular Monitoring
authors: A. Dhivya Parameswari, S. Pradeep, Kaaviyakanth K, C Karuppanasamy, Kailasapathi T, C. Muthuselvi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: In today's fast-paced world, timely and accurate cardiovascular monitoring can mean the difference between life and loss. We present an ultra-low-power wearable wristband designed for continuous, real-time cardiovascular monitoring, powered by compressed sensing and on-chip artificial intelligence. With an average power consumption below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex>, the device enables 72+ hours of uninterrupted operation, making it ideal for long-term wear without user burden. A custom compressed sensing algorithm reduces physiological signal bandwidth by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times$</tex> while preserving signal fidelity with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<2 \%$</tex> reconstruction error. Embedded deep learning models perform on-chip inference, achieving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>93 \%$</tex> accuracy in detecting arrhythmic events with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<50 ~\text{ms}$</tex> latency, all without the need for cloud connectivity. This closed-loop, edgebased solution ensures data privacy, ultra-low power consumption, and responsiveness-offering not just innovation in wearable design but a deeply human solution to proactive heart health. It is more than a device; it is a personal guardian, always on, always vigilant.

title: Information Extracting Method for Ship Routing Based on Image Data
authors: Yan Chen, Jian Xu, Shenping Hu, An Yan
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: Selecting a safe and optimized route for ships is a route design requirement in ship transportation, and crew members design and choose ship routes through various methods. Aiming at the color image sensing data obtained from high-density AIS (Automatic Identification System) data, this study proposes a method for extracting route information from ship navigation trajectory sensing images, providing a new technical path for the application of maritime sensors. Firstly, focusing on the color image sensing model driven by ship AIS data, this study classifies the ship trajectory information in the sensing images and proposes a K-means clustering method based on Lab brightness and color features. This method can establish the customary route of a ship and fully leverages the high-precision advantage of color image sensing data in trajectory recognition. Secondly, by using a low-pass filter and sensing image edge extraction technology, the noise interference in color image sensing data is reduced. Closed clustering regions and continuous trajectory information are extracted, enabling the identification of route continuity from color image sensing data. Then, through the feature point matching of color image sensors and image stitching technology, the dense ship routes under large-scale nautical charts are established. Combined with a distributed sensor network, the efficiency of multi-region data fusion can be improved, ultimately realizing the extraction of long-distance customary routes. Finally, taking the AIS color image sensing data from Shanghai Port to the East Sea Estuary as an example, the proposed method is used to derive the characteristics of the habitual ship routes in this water area. The results show that the route information extracted based on the color image sensing model is consistent with the actual trajectories; the clustering algorithm can solve problems such as ambiguous pixel distinction and noise interference, verifying the effectiveness of the sensor application. Compared with traditional K-means, DBSCAN, and hierarchical clustering algorithms, the clustering algorithm based on the color image sensing model is superior in pixel processing, noise reduction, operation efficiency, and result accuracy, providing data support for the maritime promotion of color image sensing technology.

title: A Survey on Multimodal Generation of Dynamic Digital Humans: From Face to Full-Body
authors: Baiyan Wan, Jie Jiang, Ruoli Yang, Yuanyuan Yang, Hanshuo Qiu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This paper surveys recent advances in dynamic digital human generation—a pivotal bridge connecting static modeling with interactive applications, essential for achieving realistic and fluid motion. We examine progress in motion generative models and digital human spatial representations. From an application standpoint, methods are categorized by body region, covering dynamic facial generation, dynamic body generation, and dynamic face-body co-generation. Under this framework, and further classified by driving signals, we summarize key technical challenges and dominant paradigms, review representative works, and discuss promising future research directions.

title: Enhancing Misogyny Detection through Context-Aware Semantic Enrichment
authors: Alaa Mohasseb, Eslam Amer
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Detecting online misogyny remains a critical challenge, particularly when abusive language is implicit or context-dependent. Traditional keyword-based models often fail to capture these subtleties. This research investigates the impact of sentence-level semantic enrichment on misogyny detection performance across various model types. The input text was enriched through three methods—MiniLM, FastText, and ConceptNet—each generating semantically meaningful paraphrases. These enriched inputs are evaluated using traditional classifiers, deep learning, and transformer models. The results show that semantic enrichment, especially with ConceptNet, significantly boosts detection accuracy across all different models. ELECTRA combined with ConceptNet achieved the highest performance, with an F1 score of 92% and an accuracy of 97%, while the BiLSTM models achieved a strong balance of efficiency and precision. Our findings highlight the value of semantically enriched representations in improving the detection of nuanced misogynistic language on online platforms.

title: New Memory Architectures Will Drive Future Computing
authors: Jim Handy, Thomas Coughlin
publish: Computer
abstract: Modern computing is undergoing radical changes, many to enable artificial intelligence applications. But continued computing advances will require even greater changes. Just what are these changes, and how will tomorrow’s memory architectures and new memory technologies move the industry past today’s memory wall?

title: Work-in-Progress: Learning to Refine Priority Assignment in Fixed-Priority Real-Time Scheduling
authors: Binqi Sun, Linghan Fang, Andrea Bastoni, Marco Caccamo
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: We address the problem of priority assignment for global fixed-priority scheduling on multicore real-time systems, where identifying a feasible priority ordering is a combinatorial challenge. We propose a learning-based framework that trains a lightweight policy network via reinforcement learning to refine existing priority assignments toward schedulable solutions. Based on the policy network, we propose an inference-time policy refinement mechanism that improves schedulability without additional training. It combines breadth sampling—generating candidate orderings via stochastic perturbations—with depth refinement, which iteratively enhances promising candidates. A continuous reward function based on a schedulability hazard metric enables effective training. Preliminary experiments show that the proposed method performs better than classical heuristics such as Deadline Monotonic and DkC, demonstrating its potential as an effective learning-assisted approach to real-time scheduling.

title: Nova: Real-Time Agentic Vision-Language Model Serving With Adaptive Cross-Stage Parallelization
authors: Yuhang Xu, Shengzhong Liu, Dong Zhang, Bingheng Yan, Fan Wu, Guihai Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: This paper presents Nova, a real-time scheduling framework for serving agentic vision-language models (VLMs) on a single GPU with balanced per-request latency and overall request process throughput. Our design begins by enabling effective pipelining across vision encode, LLM prefill, and LLM decode stages of VLMs, by exploiting their heterogeneous resource demands during execution and incorporating elastic GPU spatial partitioning among stages to maximally utilize the compute and memory resources. Building on this, we introduce a realtime scheduling algorithm that adaptively calibrates resource allocation among stages based on a Pareto-optimal analysis of the latency-throughput trade-off, allowing the system to sustain responsiveness and resource efficiency under dynamic request loads. To further alleviate GPU memory pressure, we design a lightweight weight offloading strategy for vision encoders that preserves inference efficiency with minimized memory overhead. Extensive evaluations on both synthetic and real-world agent workloads demonstrate that Nova consistently outperforms the state-of-the-art baselines, improving the maximum latency by up to 23.3 %, while keeping competitive throughput.
