title: UAVs Missions for Sea Emergencies
authors: Sajjad Ghobadi, Leonardo Mostarda, Alfredo Navarra, Francesco Piselli
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This paper presents the First Boat Rescue (FBR) problem, a new challenging variant of the well-known Electric Vehicle Routing problem. FBR stems from practical rescue operations where a rescue lifeboat and its medical team provide assistance to a boat close to the coast. Quite often the boat calls for unnecessary assistance which leads to a waste of resources. As an alternative and cheaper approach, this paper proposes the use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) equipped with basic medical tools. More precisely, a lifeboat departure can be avoided when the UAV reaches the boat and remotely connects to the medical team which, by using the UAV’s medical tools, deems the assistance unneeded. UAVs are battery powered which may require recharging activities to accomplish the rescue operations. A buoy recharging station that uses the sea movement and provides a charging pad for a UAV can be used. When buoys are suitably disposed in the rescuing area, a UAV can assist multiple boats in need of emergency without wasting rescue lifeboat fuel and unnecessarily occupying the time of the medical team. This paper studies FBR in two scenarios with partial and full battery recharging policies and presents the Integer Linear Programming (ILP) formulations of the problems. For FBR in the partial recharging scenario, the paper proposes two heuristics. The paper also proves that there is an algorithm that approximates FBR with full recharging policy. The paper concludes by describing various simulations and evaluates the proposed algorithms on random and ad-hoc instances.

title: Online Learning Robust Control Design for a Class of Uncertain Nonlinear Systems
authors: A. Banderchuk, J. P. Jordanou, D. Coutinho, E. Camponogara
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Well-established nonlinear control methods often rely on mathematical models that can be imprecise or uncertain. Classical robust control techniques address this by designing conservative control laws, which inherently limit performance. As modern applications demand higher performance, learningbased controllers have emerged as a promising alternative; however, they frequently lack stability guarantees, rendering them unsuitable for safety-critical systems. To bridge this gap, this paper introduces a novel control strategy that integrates a robust controller with an Echo State Network (ESN)-based adaptive law to stabilize a class of uncertain nonlinear systems under persistent disturbances. The robust controller is first designed to ensure Input-to-State Stability (ISS) of the closed-loop system, irrespective of the ESN’s actions or disturbances. Subsequently, the ESN is trained online to compensate for the disturbances and improve the system’s output performance. A key feature of this architecture is that the closed-loop stability is guaranteed a priori by the robust controller, regardless of the ESN’s learning process, while the online adaptation significantly enhances performance. This framework also maintains relatively low computational complexity. Numerical simulations demonstrate the strategy’s effectiveness: in one example, the average performance improves from 60.6% to 92.7% over time, and in another, from 22.8% to 92.3%. These results confirm the controller’s ability to learn and adapt online, showing a significant attenuation of disturbance effects compared to using the robust controller alone.

title: USBTrack: Efficient Underwater Single-Branch Tracker via Template Prompt Learning
authors: Xue-Han Xu, Tao Jing, Qing-Hao Meng
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Underwater object tracking (UOT) is a core component of underwater vehicle observation systems. Current UOT trackers include two-stream and one-stream trackers represented by Siamese network and OSTrack, respectively. However, these trackers have not achieved a balance between performance and efficiency. In addition, when observing large numbers of visually similar underwater objects (such as schools of fish), the current UOT trackers might result in tracking drift. To address these issues, we propose a novel underwater single-branch tracker, USBTrack, which only performs inference on the branch of search area. The template is preprocessed once through a novel template prompt module (TPM) consisting of a convolutional layer, a linear layer, and a residual connection, and the generated template prompt features are summed to the search area. The USBTrack integrates the advantages of template pre-processing in two-stream trackers and joint feature processing in one-stream trackers, thus achieving a balance between efficiency and performance. Additionally, the summation-based interaction paradigm in USBTrack enables the model to focus more on the feature representation of the central part of the search region while suppressing tracking drift caused by the similar appearances of numerous objects of the same type. Comprehensive experiments show that USBTrack achieves state-of-the-art performance while balancing efficiency. The code is available at https://github.com/xxh1016/USBTrack.

title: Integrated Task Scheduling, Path Planning, and Control for Cooperative UGV–UAV Systems via an Extended MPPI-GA Framework
authors: Da-Hyun Nam, Hyeong-Geun Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study presents a cooperative algorithm for heterogeneous unmanned ground and aerial vehicles (UGVs and UAVs). Such cooperative systems have recently garnered significant attention in domains like disaster response, target tracking, and exploration. However, many existing methods are constrained by hierarchical structures for task assignment, path planning, and control, which limits adaptability in dynamic environments. Furthermore, these approaches often rely on clustering processes, with performance frequently sensitive to the chosen granularity. To address these limitations, thiswork extends the previously proposed model predictive path integral control-genetic algorithm (MPPI-GA) framework, initially developed for UGVs, to quadrotor UAVs, resulting in an output-sampled MPPI-GA (oMPPI-GA), by adapting it to their dynamic characteristics. Building upon this extension, a unified algorithm is proposed that integrates task scheduling, obstacle-avoidance path planning, and control input generation into a single, cohesive framework. The algorithm adopts an output-sampled MPPI structure to alleviate control input sampling sensitivity for UAVs, and a novel triple-layer chromosome enabling UAVs to generate closed tours without explicit task clustering. In this system, UAVs equipped with oMPPI-GA and UGVs using MPPI-GA cooperatively execute missions. A distributed task conflict resolution scheme facilitates seamless task allocation among these heterogeneous agents. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is validated through numerical simulations and real-world hardware experiments.

title: A Multichannel CNN-LSTM-Based Prediction Model for Precipitable Water Vapor in a Region with a Single GNSS Station
authors: Dantong Zhu, Wang Li, Kefei Zhang, Qingfeng Hu, Peipei He, Linjing Zhang, Suqin Wu, Weibo Yin, Minjie Gao, Longjiang Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate prediction of precipitable water vapor (PWV) is of great significance in meteorological applications. Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) is a widely used technique to obtain PWV data. However, many regions still suffer from sparse station coverage, with only a single station available in some cases. This study proposes a multichannel CNN–LSTM model designed for a single-station scenario by integrating key meteorological variables, including surface pressure, weighted mean temperature, and zenith wet delay, using a 5-day historical input sequence. Compared to the widely used Global Forecast System (GFS) and classical LSTM model, the CNN–LSTM model achieved superior performance, with an MAE of 0.694 mm, an RMS of 0.789 mm, and a correlation coefficient of 0.997. This indicates 69.8% reductions in MAE and 68.6% reductions in RMS relative to GFS, and a slight reduction in MAE along with a 20.8% reduction in RMS compared to LSTM. The subsequent seasonal and weather-specific analyses reveal the high accuracy in winter with 0.443-mm MAE and 0.580-mm RMS, and under clear skies with 0.708-mm MAE and 0.769-mm RMS. Performance declined during summer and rainfall periods due to heightened atmospheric instability and rapid PWV variations. Nevertheless, the developed CNN-LSTM model maintains robust prediction capability across all conditions, demonstrating the benefit of integrating meteorological features for PWV prediction in effectively data‑scarce or data-sparse regions.

title: A Tunable Capacitance ReRAM for Improvement of Dynamic Range in CMOS Image Sensors
authors: S. Chourasia, S. Pande, A. Padovani, L. Larcher, G. Thareja, B. Chakrabarti
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: work reports a tunable-capacitance resistive memory (TCReRAM) device. The TCReRAM uses a binary metal-oxide active-layer and exhibits strong voltage-dependent capacitance (VDC) under appropriate operating conditions. The observed VDC dynamics is characterized experimentally, and its physical origin is investigated through comprehensive multiscale simulations. The developed TCReRAM device, integrated at the floating diffusion node of a CMOS image sensor (CIS) pixel, introduces VDC that helps mitigate saturation under high illumination conditions. Pixel-level simulations further demonstrate that incorporating the TCReRAM significantly improves the dynamic range by nearly 25% compared to the existing reported Hybrid CIS, effectively addressing performance limitations across varying illumination levels.

title: Modeling and Experimental Validation of Flow-Thermal-Coupled Lumped-Parameter Network for Axial-Flux Permanent-Magnet Motor with Oil-Immersed Cooling System
authors: Yunshuo Gu, Weiwei Geng, Chaohui Tang, Jing Wang, Wenlong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: With the increase of electrical load, the temperature rise in axial flux permanent magnet (AFPM) motor is gradually prominent. Excessive temperature rise directly affects the stable operation of the motor and limits its performance improvement. This article proposes an efficient immersion cooling system for high-torque AFPM motor. Comprehensively considering the cooling oil flow characteristics, oil baffle plates are installed between the end windings and the shell, which improve the cooling oil coverage and enhance the stator heat dissipation capability. Furthermore, flow channels are integrated in the sealing plate, reinforcing the cooling of winding regions with high eddy current losses. Based on computational fluid dynamics (CFD), the thermal analysis of the AFPM motor is carried out. The results show that compared to the conventional oil-immersed cooling structure, the stator core temperature decreases from 67°C to 52°C, and the winding temperature declines from 85°C to 63°C. Then, the flow network and thermal network are constructed and coupled iteratively to investigate the effect of key parameters on motor thermal performance. Finally, a 850 N·m AFPM motor is manufactured and tested. The experimental data for temperature rise are in good agreement with the proposed calculation method, with a deviation of within 5%.

title: Longitudinal Monitoring of Full-Course Gait Rehabilitation using Musculoskeletal Modeling and Muscle Coordination Analysis
authors: Zijie Liu, Chuxuan Guo, Binjun Chen, Yuchao Liu, Yibin Chen, Yike Li, Dongdong Ren, Jiajie Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Muscle coordination pattern can be disrupted by neural disorders and perceptual disturbance, leading to abnormal gaits. However, it is still unclear how neuro-muscular control regulates walking gaits through training and exercising due to lengthy rehabilitation periods and complicated musculoskeletal redundancies. This paper proposes a gait rehabilitation monitoring method based on muscle deformation to elucidate the evolution of muscle coordination during the full-course vertigo-gait rehabilitation. The proposed method is verified by musculoskeletal dynamics simulation and experimentally validated through immediate applications to five healthy subjects and five vertigo patients. The vertigo gaits were assessed by comparing with the normal gait of healthy subjects. For the first time, this paper reports experimental results and muscle coordination analysis throughout the full course of vertigo-gait rehabilitation. The findings reveal that the vertigo patient adjusts phase difference between the rectus femoris (RF) and medial gastrocnemius (MG) at toe-off, driving the knee and ankle joints to regulate foot-to-ground angle, thereby enhancing gait stability and walking efficiency. These results indicate that muscle deformations serve as an alternative quantity besides traditionally employed kinematic features, and the proposed wearable sensing method is expected to provide an effective tool for clinical gait assessment.

title: Compact Ultra Massive Antenna Arrays under Mutual Coupling: Modeling and Spectral Efficiency Analysis
authors: Jiacheng Lu, Jun Zhang, Yu Han, Jue Wang, Shi Jin, Kai-Kit Wong, Chan-Byoung Chae
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Compact ultra-massive antenna arrays (CUMA) share key characteristics with holographic communication systems, featuring densely spaced and individually controlled antenna elements that enable precise manipulation of electromagnetic waves. In this paper, we investigate the spectral efficiency (SE) of CUMA deployed within some constrained physical space. Departing from prior works that assume ideal isotropic antennas, we derive a closed-form expression for the SE assuming a line-of-sight (LoS) channel at the electromagnetic level, explicitly accounting for mutual coupling and antenna orientation. The analysis reveals that the channel gain is highly sensitive to both the array orientation and individual antenna directions. In the single-user case, our results show that the optimal orientation of the user array is either aligned parallel or perpendicular to the signal direction, depending on the inter-element spacing. Notably, near-optimal channel gain is achieved when individual antennas are oriented perpendicular to the signal direction. In the multi-user case, we further optimize transceiver configurations under mutual coupling constraints. Simulation results confirm that SE is strongly influenced by the directional alignment of user antennas and array placement in the near-field regime. CUMA significantly outperforms traditional half-wavelength spaced arrays in terms of SE when constrained to the same physical aperture.

title: Entrepreneurial Ecosystems in Cities: Stages of Entrepreneurship and City Technology
authors: David B. Audretsch, Maksim Belitski
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Do entrepreneurial ecosystems (EEs) in cities facilitate nascent, emergent, and hypergrowth entrepreneurial activity, and what configurations of city EE quality and technological development correspond to distinct types of entrepreneurial activity? The answer to these questions is not straightforward. Building new space for EE theory, we use rigorous research methodology to provide compelling empirical evidence identifying how EE quality and city-level technological development shape nascent, emergent, and hypergrowth stages of entrepreneurship. Using fixed effects in generalized least squares estimation, we analyze data from 762 cities worldwide in 2019 to explore the direct and indirect effects of city-level technological development in alpha, beta, gamma, delta and insufficient cities, as well as the impact of improvements in EE elements on the three stages of entrepreneurship. Our findings from rigorous research methods clearly demonstrate that nascent, emergent, and hypergrowth entrepreneurship all benefit from an increased quality of EE elements. Nascent and hypergrowth entrepreneurship are facilitated by a combination of high EE quality and high technological development (alpha cities). In contrast, emergent entrepreneurship is facilitated in cities with high EE quality but, on average, lower city-level technological development, where there remains room for technological improvement. We also challenge traditional clustering arguments and suggest that digital technologies allow scale-ups and unicorns to transcend local ecosystem boundaries.

title: Comparison and Evaluation of Typical Marine Gravity Field Models from Satellite Altimetry
authors: Qiankun Liu, Zhaoyu Chen, Ke Xu, Xiyu Xu, Xiaoyang Liu
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Satellite altimeter is an important data source for constructing marine gravity field models because it can obtain high-precision sea surface height data in a large area of the world. Over the past 50 years, the technology and performance of satellite altimetry have been continuously improved, especially the successful launch of the new generation of altimetry satellite SWOT. Based on the abundant altimetry data accumulated over the years, a series of global ocean gravity field models were constructed. In the paper, the typical marine gravity field models DTU17, SIOV32.1, SDUST2022, NSOAS24 and SIO SWOT were selected for comparison, and their accuracy and spatial resolution were evaluated by using the shipborne gravity data of the NCEI. The evaluation showed that the SIO SWOT model built with 7 months of next-generation altimeter data had an accuracy of 1.43 mGal, which was at the same level as the ocean gravity field model constructed by fusing traditional altimeter data for many years. Compared with the spatial resolution of other ocean gravity field models (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13.4 ~\text{km} \sim 14.6 ~\text{km}$</tex>), its spatial resolution is 9.9 km, which is significantly improved.

title: Enhancing Photovoltaic Efficiency: A Modified Convolutional Neural Network for Soiling Classification*
authors: Harish Aggarwal, Pokuri Siva Krishna, Rajasekar Natarajan, Siti Zaliha Mohammad Noor, Azlin Mohd Azmi, Hathaithip Ninsonti Sintuya
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The operational efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) plants is significantly hampered by soiling, the a ccumulation of environmental particulates on panel surfaces. To address this, we introduce a specialized artificial intelligence (AI) framework for the precise identification a nd classification of PV panel soiling. This paper details a modified convolutional neural network (CNN) engineered to perform binary classification distinguishing clean from soiled panels based on panel imagery. Evaluated on a comprehensive dataset of solar panel images, our model demonstrates superior classification speed and a ccuracy, achieving 98.95 % training accuracy and 95.33 % validation accuracy. Our method facilitates the deployment of targeted and resourceefficient c leaning s trategies, thus enhancing overall system performance and energy yield. We present a comparative analysis against established algorithms, highlighting the enhanced diagnostic capabilities of our approach. The findings discussed here have significant implications for the future of a utomated and intelligent solar plant maintenance.

title: Flywheel Energy Storage Systems Utilization for Short Duration Power Systems Frequency Stability Support
authors: Willy Stephane Ngaha, David G. Dorrell, Chandima Gomes
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The transition to decentralized and inverter-based resources (IBR) in the power system has led to a significant reduction in system inertia, which in traditional systems is used for inertia support, making frequency stability a critical operational challenge. Flywheel energy storage systems (FESS) offer a promising solution for short-duration frequency support due to their rapid response time, high power density, and long cycle life compared to similarly sized battery energy storage systems (BESS). This paper investigates the use of FESS to enhance power system frequency stability during transient disturbances and load-generation imbalances. The study emphasizes the dynamic behavior of FESS in delivering synthetic inertia and primary frequency regulation within milliseconds. Various control strategies, including virtual synchronous generator (VSG) control, frequency-droop characteristics, and coordinated control with other storage systems, are reviewed and evaluated. The simulation was conducted on MATLAB/Simulink to demonstrate the effectiveness of FESS-based DC machines in limiting frequency deviations, improving the rate of change of frequency (RoCoF), and supporting system recovery. The findings underscore the suitability of FESS for short-duration, high-power applications in power systems. Future research directions are proposed to address optimization in sizing, integration with hybrid systems, large-scale FESS, and advanced control for improved frequency resilience.

title: Composite Adaptive Critic Design
authors: Yongliang Yang, Hamidreza Modares, Kyriakos G. Vamvoudakis, Frank L. Lewis
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel adaptive critic design with a finite excitation (FE) condition for adaptive optimal control of continuous-time nonlinear systems. The online recorded data is combined with instantaneous data via a hierarchical design scheme to replace the persistence of excitation condition with a FE condition. The online data is recorded in the preprocessing step and verified online, whereas the novel critic is implemented in the assembling step through appropriate algebraic calculations. On this basis, the composite adaptive critic design is developed with satisfactory convergence. The adaptive critic design can be implemented in an online fashion with the hierarchical design scheme, and the FE condition can also be online verifiable. It is shown that the composite adaptive critic design guarantees the closed-loop stability of the equilibrium point and convergence to the optimal solution. Simulations are conducted to show the efficacy of the composite adaptive critic design.

title: Generative AI-Powered Mock Interview System with Real-Time Multimodal Feedback & Skill Matching
authors: Simmran Agarwal, Jatin Gupta, Aman Kulshrestha, Alka Singhal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Preparing for technical interviews is a critical yet challenging task for job aspirants, especially in the software industry. This paper introduces an AI-powered mock interview system that offers an interactive, personalized, and real-time evaluation experience. The system dynamically generates domain-specific questions by analysing a candidate's resume and job description using the Gemini API. It incorporates speech and video emotion recognition models to evaluate a candidate's confidence and communication skills. Speech input is transcribed using Wav2Vec2 and evaluated for emotional tone using a pre-trained emotion classification model. Video responses are analysed using Ollama's Gemma3 for facial emotion detection and expression analysis. Candidate performance is scored based on technical correctness and emotional expressiveness, with comprehensive feedback provided after each session. Empirical studies show an average accuracy of 89% for technical evaluation and 84% for emotion detection, validating the system's reliability. This work demonstrates the potential of integrating multimodal AI technologies to improve technical interview readiness and reduce candidate anxiety.

title: A Novel Real-Time UAV Self-Calibration Model using Lightweight Online Normalization and Dispersion Learning
authors: Mingke Gao, Guyang Yu, Tao Pang, Hong Xu, Fei Xia, Miankuan Zhu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) perception systems frequently encounter sudden changes in lighting, altitude, and viewpoint that were never present in the training data, causing rapid drops in object detection accuracy. We propose SkyMapper-RT, a fully source-free self-calibration framework that updates a convolutional or transformer-based object detector on-board the UAV within a single forward–backward pass for each new frame. The core components are: (1) Adaptive Covariance Normalization (ACN), which standardises each batch of features by dynamically decorrelating their covariance, and (2) Spherical Dispersion Learning (SDL), which enlarges the angular separations among latent features without requiring any memory queue or explicit negative samples. Together, these two modules yield domain-agnostic yet discriminative feature representations, optimized by an entropy-regularised objective that encourages confident predictions. Evaluated on public UAV datasets UAVDT and DomainNet-126, SkyMapper-RT achieves the highest mean average precision (mAP) by 60.3% in overall detection and attains the highest top-1 accuracy of 71.5%, while adding only approximately 8 ms processing latency per 640 × 384 frame on a Jetson AGX Xavier edge GPU. The framework thus offers a practical real-time solution for on-the-fly UAV model maintenance in the face of continuously shifting data distributions.

title: Enhancing Personalized Tourism Experiences: Modelling Cultural Resonance through User Profiling and the ACUX Typology
authors: Fotios Pastrakis, Markos Konstantakis, George Caridakis
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: Tourism recommendation systems have evolved from traditional methods to AI-driven frameworks that personalize cultural experiences. This paper reviews the integration of user profiling, persona-based classification, and cultural heritage modelling to enhance personalized tourism. We synthesize research on the Augmented Cultural User eXperience (ACUX) typology, Object-Oriented User Experience (OOUX) design, and hybrid recommendation systems. Our systematic review identifies key trends, evaluates user profiling techniques, and examines the role of cultural resonance in destination matching. Findings indicate that hybrid systems combining collaborative filtering, content-based methods and machine learning achieves precision improvement over 85%, compared to the popularity-based method. The study contributes insights into how cultural heritage digitization, user modeling, and AI-driven personalization can reduce cognitive load and support sustainable tourism. This paper examines the current state of research in personalized tourism recommendation systems, with particular focus on user profiling techniques, cultural heritage modelling, and the application of ACUX typology for enhanced cultural resonance.

title: Perceiver IO for Weakly Supervised Multimodal Violence Detection in Surveillance Video
authors: Noorhan K. Fawzy, Sally S. Ismail, Moatafa M. Aref
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Automated violence detection in surveillance videos is a critical component of public safety systems. Traditional approaches often depend on handcrafted features or fixed-length input constraints, limiting their ability to capture complex spatiotemporal dynamics. This work introduces a novel weakly supervised multimodal architecture that leverages advanced transformer-based models for fine grained violence detection. Visual features are extracted using TimeSformer, a transformer architecture employing divided space-time attention for video representation learning, while audio cues are encoded with VGGish, a VGG-based convolutional neural network adapted for audio representation learning. These multimodal embeddings are processed by Perceiver Input-Output (IO), a transformer-based model capable of handling arbitrary input modalities and producing structured, task-specific outputs. The framework simultaneously supports binary violence detection, event type recognition, and temporal localization. Evaluation on the Extensive-Description Violence dataset demonstrates state-of-the-art performance, achieving an average precision of 89.4%. Comparative experiments further highlight the effectiveness of this design, confirming that the integration of domain-specific encoders with Perceiver Input-Output (IO) provides a scalable and robust solution for complex video surveillance tasks.

title: SummARai: A Transformer-Based System for Hybrid Summarization of Large-Scale Arabic Documents
authors: Rowan Madeeh Mohamed, Abdelrahman Gomaa Fathy, Abdelrahman Mohamed Ezzat Akeel, Fatma El-zahraa Ashraf Serry, Momen Mostafa Mabrouk elsayed, Mohammad El-Ramly
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: With the increasing volume of digital Arabic literature, the demand for efficient and accessible summarization tools has grown significantly. Summarizing Arabic with AI (SummARai) is a novel web-based system designed to automatically generate hybrid summaries for Arabic documents using advanced transformer-based language models. The system addresses key challenges in Arabic Natural Language Processing (NLP), including complex morphology and rich semantic structure. It combines a graph-based extractive algorithm (TextRank) with a fine-tuned Text-to-Text Transformers for Arabic Language Generation (AraT5) for abstractive generation, followed by a large language model (LLM)-based smoothing step to enhance fluency and coherence. SummARai offers users an interactive experience, allowing documents to be uploaded, summarized, and accessed through the platform at any time. SummARai achieves competitive results in BERTScore. It scored 70.71 % in BERTScore F1, confirming its effectiveness in producing fluent, coherent, and informative summaries for Arabic texts. It bridges the gap between deep learning-based NLP and Arabic literary content, offering a practical tool for students, researchers, and general readers seeking concise yet informative summaries of Arabic documents.

title: An Approach for Extracting Material Design Criteria Based on Neural Networks and SHAP Analysis
authors: Yujia Chen, Zhaoxu Zhou, Qiying Liu, Siyu He, Feixiang Tang, Yueyun Weng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Material selection is a critical factor affecting the core performance and reliability of engineering structures, whereas traditional approaches often struggle to effectively address the relationship of such complex coupling of multiple factors. In order to overcome this challenge, this study proposes a modeling and interpretation framework that integrates Backpropagation Neural Networks (BPNN) with Shapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), aiming to reveal the influence mechanisms of key features of automotive chassis materials on performance indicators. The study first constructs a Backpropagation Neural Network (BPNN) model based on experimental data, and then employs SHAP to analyze the importance of input features, thereby enhancing model interpretability. The model achieved a high prediction accuracy of 0.9444 with a computation time of just 10.001 seconds. Finally, the Kruskal–Wallis H test is applied to statistically validate feature differences. The results demonstrate that the proposed method, while maintaining high predictive accuracy, successfully identifies the elastic modulus (E) and shear modulus (G) as the core discriminative criteria for chassis material selection. This study not only provides a scientific basis for material optimization under complex operating conditions but also highlights the potential of artificial intelligence methods in the field of engineering materials.

title: Work-in-Progress: Toward Real-Time Cross-ISA Execution on the AMD Embedded+ Architecture
authors: Lukas Neef, Daniele Ottaviano, Denis Hoornaert, Alexander Zuepke, Marco Caccamo, Andrea Bastoni
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: Emerging embedded platforms increasingly rely on heterogeneous processing units to address diverse performance and energy requirements. The recently introduced AMD Embedded+ architecture reflects this trend by interconnecting via PCIe on the same motherboard one AMD x86 host processor with one Arm AArch64+FPGA complex. This implementation is another step forward towards a more compact heterogeneousISA platform designed with embedded applications in mind. While cross-ISA execution has been explored in the past with a focus on performance, programmability, and energy efficiency, its potential for embedded and predictable real-time workloads remains largely unexplored. In this paper, we start exploring such potential by investigating the real-time capabilities of the first commercial platform based on the AMD Embedded+ architecture: the Sapphire Edge+. We (1) outline key research challenges and real-time use-cases, (2) discuss suitable software architectures for the use-cases and highlight associated trade-offs, and (3) report an initial assessment of the potential of such architectures and use-cases via an experimental evaluation of latency and bandwidth on the real hardware.

title: Federated Multi-Layered Deep Neural Networks with Adaptive Hyperparameter Optimization for Privacy-Preserving Personalized Healthcare Intelligence
authors: S Sanjay, Jagadeesh Gopal
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The societal movement toward smart, personalized healthcare highlights the need to protect the individual privacy of people in utilizing machine learning. In this paper, we introduce a new system called Federated Multi-Layered Deep Neural Network with Adaptive Hyperparameter Optimization (Fed-MLDNN-AHPO) which combines federated learning, metaheuristic optimization, and Biogeography Based Optimization (BBO) to apply to deep neural networks with sensitive healthcare data. It has the capacity to apply training processes from across multiple locations to comply with privacy-related legislation such as HIPAA and GDPR. Moreover, the adaptive tuning works with data from the customer which is heterogeneous and not consistently independent and identically distributed (IID). Applications are demonstrated and evaluated from datasets from eICU, FeTS, MIMIC-III, and BRATS20. Various approaches were considered from this novel system to be very effective in classification and segmentation performance over baseline approaches. Furthermore, we have implemented modules for explainability and fairness to support trust in AI in healthcare. Thus, Fed-MLDNN-AHPO allows the implementation of safe, understandable, and scalable privacy-preserving intelligence in the healthcare domain.

title: An Intelligent and Automated Medical Dispensing System Utilizing IoT for Enhanced Healthcare Management
authors: Rajeshwari J, Madhura J, Manjula Sanjay Koti, Rashmi S, Bharath Bc
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The "Smart Automatic Medical Dispenser with Personal Health Care Using Iot" aims to revolutionize healthcare technology by developing an innovative, user-friendly, precise, and affordable AMD. It addresses the limitations of existing AMDs by focusing on increased capacity, accuracy, reliability, and affordability. It aims to accommodate a wide range of medication forms, including pills and capsules, empowering individuals to manage their treatment regimens effectively. The proposed Automatic Medical Dispenser can be known for its prominent design, accuracy in dispensing the precise medicine , and low-cost, which tends to improve medication adherence and also enhance the quality of life for patients.

title: Hamming Distance aware Fault Analysis for LTLBC
authors: Yusuke Nozaki, Shu Takemoto, Masaya Yoshikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Low-latency lightweight cryptography is attracting attention as a promising security solution for Internet of Things (IoT) devices. LTLBC is a low-latency lightweight cryptography introduced in 2024, which has a smaller circuit size and lower latency than conventional cryptographic algorithms. These cryptographic algorithms ensure computational security. However, risks such as fault analysis using information from cryptographic hardware implementations have been reported, and it is important to evaluate the tamper resistance (security) against this analysis. Therefore, this study evaluates the security of LTLBC against fault analysis. Experimental results show that all subkeys can be recovered with as few as 20 ciphertext pairs when the fault injection probability is 20%.

title: Tight Cache Contention Analysis for WCET Estimation on Multicore Systems
authors: Shuai Zhao, Jieyu Jiang, Shenlin Cai, Yaowei Liang, Chen Jie, Yinjie Fang, Wei Zhang, Guoquan Zhang, Yaoyao Gu, Xiang Xiao, Wei Qin, Ouyang Ouyang, Wanli Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS)
abstract: WCET (Worst-Case Execution Time) estimation on multicore architecture is particularly challenging mainly due to the complex accesses over cache shared by multiple cores. Existing analysis identifies possible contentions between parallel tasks by leveraging the partial order of the tasks or their program regions. Unfortunately, they overestimate the number of cache misses caused by a remote block access without considering the actual cache state and the number of accesses. This paper reports a new analysis for inter-core cache contention. Based on the order of program regions in a task, we first identify memory references that could be affected if a remote access occurs in a region. Afterwards, a fine-grained contention analysis is constructed that computes the number of cache misses based on the access quantity of local and remote blocks. We demonstrate that the overall inter-core cache interference of a task can be obtained via dynamic programming. Experiments show that compared to existing methods, the proposed analysis reduces inter-core cache interference and WCET estimations by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 2. 3 1 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8. 9 4 \%}$</tex> on average, without significantly increasing computation overhead.

title: Mufakkir: RAG-Based Arabic Educational Chatbot for University Students
authors: Mohamed Khaled Tawfik, Mohamed Osama Ali, Sohier Khaled Mohamed, Farah Safwat Ezz Elregal, Paula Emad Edward, Maryam Elsawaf, Dina Khattab
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: The scarcity of Arabic-language educational tools tailored for university students, particularly in specialized fields like law and humanities, limits academic engagement and learning effectiveness. Mufakkir addresses this gap by providing an Arabic educational RAG-based chatbot designed to assist students with retrieving, summarizing, and interacting with academic content. The system is trained on a curated Arabic dataset of legal books collected from Ain Shams University, with synthetic question-context pairs generated for evaluation using an LLM. Mufakkir achieved 88% accuracy, 88 % recall, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.78 \text{nDCG} {@} 10$</tex> on this benchmark. Its embedding model ranked first on the Arabic RAG Leaderboard with a score of 0.65, reflecting strong retrieval performance. In answer generation, it outperformed major LLMs such as DeepSeek, LLAMA, and Qwen, scoring 0.79 in Answer-Ground Similarity and 0.73 in Question-Answer Similarity. By combining fine-tuned embeddings, hybrid retrieval, and domain-specific evaluation data, Mufakkir delivers accurate, context-aware educational support.

title: AI-Driven Diagnostic Tool for Predicting Brain Stroke with High-Precision Neuroimaging Analysis
authors: K. Saranya, R. Praveena, C. Divyarevathi, S. Shantha Kumar, S. Revathi, V. Ragumuniraja
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Brain stroke continues to be an acute life-threatening condition where immediate diagnosis in necessary for successful intervention and better patient outcomes. Current clinical practice relies mostly on manual interpretation of CT scans by radiologists, an approach that incurs considerable delay and variability since it is dependent on human knowledge. In order to overcome such limitations, the present research proposes Optimized CNN, a novel vision transformer-based automated stroke detection system for high-accuracy analysis of neuroimaging data. The model utilizes powerful self-attention mechanisms to exhaustively assess localized microstructural defects and global contextual patterns in CT scans, which allows for identification of subtle indicators of stroke easily overlooked by standard approaches. In contrast to conventional CNN-based methods that are prone to long-range dependencies in medical imaging, Optimized CNN vision Transformer model is able to attain robust performance in a wide range of clinical situations, such as early ischemic changes and hemorrhage detection. Validation on a multicenter dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{12, 000}$</tex> annotated CT scans depicts the system's high accuracy, with 94.1% sensitivity and 93.2% specificity, superior to both radiologist readings and current deep learning models. The technology scans in less than 60 seconds a stark contrast to the standard <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}$</tex>-minute manual test window yet retains diagnostic accuracy even on low-contrast or artifact images. Clinically, the technology has revolutionary potential by allowing swift triage in emergency departments, curbing treatment delay, and avoiding human errors in diagnosis.

title: IoT-Driven Smart Battery Management System for Performance Optimization of Lithium-Ion and Lead-Acid Batteries in Electric Vehicles
authors: Arun R, P Harini, Krishna Kumba, Patri Upender
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This study explores the performance optimization of IoT-driven smart Battery Management Systems (BMS) for Lithium-Ion and Lead-Acid batteries in electric vehicles (EVs). Various parameters, including voltage, current, temperature, state of charge (SoC), state of health <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{SoH})$</tex>, power, and resistance, were analyzed for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$48 ~\mathrm{V}(50 \text{Ah})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$72 ~\mathrm{V}(35 \text{Ah})$</tex> batteries over a 60 -minute operational cycle. The results indicate that the 48 V battery exhibits lower resistance buildup <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(8.8 \Omega$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10.6 \Omega)$</tex>, lower power fluctuations <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(220 ~\mathrm{W}-260 ~\mathrm{W})$</tex>, and stable SoC retention, suggesting higher energy efficiency and longer lifespan. In contrast, the 72 V battery shows higher power demand <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(340 ~\mathrm{W}-400 ~\mathrm{W})$</tex>, greater resistance variation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(13 \Omega$</tex> to 15.5Ω), and increased heat generation, indicating greater performance stress. The IoT-based monitoring system enables real-time data acquisition, improving battery reliability and predictive maintenance. The findings highlight the significance of efficient thermal and resistance management in enhancing EV battery performance, ensuring safety, longevity, and energy efficiency.

title: BlockSDN: Towards a High-Performance Blockchain via Software-Defined Cross Networking optimization
authors: Wenyang Jia, Jingjing Wang, Ziwei Yan, Peng Xiangli, Guohui Yuan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: The scalability of blockchain systems is constrained by inefficient P2P broadcasting, as most existing optimizations focus only on the logical layer without considering physical network conditions. To address this, we propose BlockSDN, the first SDN-based integrated architecture for blockchain. BlockSDN employs a distributed control plane for a global network view, a graph engine for hierarchical clustering, and a hybrid macro-micro neighbor selection with hierarchical broadcasting. A dedicated simulation platform shows that BlockSDN reduces global block synchronization time by 65% and 55% compared to Gossip and Mercury, respectively. These results highlight the potential of SDN-enabled cross-layer coordination to significantly enhance blockchain scalability and performance.

title: IoT-Based Livestock Animal Tracking and Health Monitoring System
authors: Mahendrakumar S, Sanjeeth S, Sarvesh K, Shalini G R, Thiyaneshwar S R, Vanitha K
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Efficient livestock control is essential to fashionable farming, ensuring both animal welfare and productivity. An IoT-based system that uses DS18B20 and MAX30100 sensors to continuously monitor livestock's vital health parameters, such as body temperature and heart rate, is suggested as a solution to this problem. GPS is also incorporated into the system to track locations in real-time. Data gathered by Arduino Nano-based transmitters is wirelessly sent to an ESP32 receiver via nRF24L01 modules. The receiver shows the data on an OLED screen and then uses the Blynk platform to send it to a mobile dashboard. According to experimental results, the system enables the accurate identification of abnormal health conditions and the effective real-time monitoring of livestock across large farm environments. This method facilitates the early detection of health anomalies and enhances farm management by offering a scalable and affordable precision livestock farming solution.

title: Automotive Interior Lighting: A study of Subjective Perception and Mood Statues for Napping and Waking Scenarios
authors: Nuoyi Li, Wenqing Miao, Jun Song, Yandan Lin
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: As vehicles become extensions of the living environment, automotive interior lighting for non-driving activities like napping is gaining significant interest. This study investigates the effects of illuminance and correlated color temperature (CCT) on subjective perception and mood states in in-vehicle napping and waking scenarios. A within-subjects experiment was conducted in a vehicle mockup where participants were exposed to lighting conditions before napping and after waking. The lighting conditions comprised three eye-level illuminance values (10 $\mathrm{~lx}, 150 \mathrm{~lx}, 300 \mathrm{~lx}$) and two CCTs (warm white light, $\sim 2000 \mathrm{~K}$; natural white light, $\sim 4500 \mathrm{~K}$). Subjective evaluations of happiness, comfort, tension, glare, brightness, satisfaction, as well as positive/negative affect (using the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule, PANAS) were collected. Results revealed that for the napping scenario, lower illuminance significantly increased comfort and reduced tension. For the waking scenario, a low CCT significantly enhanced comfort. The tested lighting parameters did not, however, produce a significant impact on positive or negative affect in either scenario. There was a significant difference in perception of the same light stimulus between pre-nap and post-nap states, particularly for happiness, comfort, tension ratings and positive affect. Furthermore, the study demonstrated a brightness perception saturation effect around<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>|50 lx within the confined vehicle space, indicating a higher sensitivity to light compared to larger, open-plan indoor environments. In conclusion, this research provides evidencebased recommendations: lower illuminance is preferable for inducing sleep, while low-CCT light is better for a comfortable awakening.

title: Towards Transparent IoT Malware Detection: A ML/DL and XAI-Based Multi-Class Classification Approach
authors: Mohamed Elsersy, Ahmed Abdelwahab
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has introduced significant security risks due to limited processing power and weak protection mechanisms. This paper presents a machine learning and deep learning-based framework for multi-class classification of IoT malware traffic. Using the CTUIoT dataset, we evaluate random forest, gradient boost, fully connected neural networks (FCNN), and recurrent neural networks (RNN) for attack detection. XGBoost achieved the highest performance with a weighted F1-score of 94.1% and a macroaveraged ROC-AUC of 96.3%. To enhance model transparency, explainable AI techniques such as SHAP and LIME were applied, providing insights into feature contributions. The proposed framework effectively identifies various types of malicious traffic, demonstrating its potential for real-world cybersecurity applications in IoT environments.

title: Design of a Low-Profile High-Current EMI Filter Based on Nano-crystalline Materials
authors: Qiang Kang, Yugang Yang, Ying Zhang, Huan Gao, Minchao Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The increasing adoption of wide-bandgap semiconductor devices has significantly enhanced the power density and switching frequency of switch-mode power supplies., yet exacerbated electromagnetic interference (EMI), challenging system-level electromagnetic compatibility (EMC). This paper proposes a low-profile, high-current EMI DC filter with a compact height of 12 mm and 20 A current rating, addressing the demands of high-density power electronics. A key innovation is the use of iron-based nano-crystalline materials for the common-mode inductor, enabling high magnetic performance within tight thermal and spatial constraints. Based on conducted noise mode separation theory, the propagation paths of common-mode and differential-mode noise in a full-bridge LLC resonant converter are analyzed. The filter topology and parameters are designed according to the insertion loss criterion. A three-dimensional electromagnetic model of the common-mode inductor is developed in ANSYS Maxwell to optimize magnetic and thermal characteristics. Experimental results show the filter achieves around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$44 \text{dB} \mu \mathrm{V}$</tex> noise attenuation above 300 kHz and meets thermal rise requirements, validating its effectiveness for compact and high-efficiency power electronics.

title: An sEMG-Based Stroke Severity Objective Assessment using Random Forest and SMOTE
authors: Irfan Hakim Bisyir, Riries Rulaningtyas, Khusnul Ain, Kusumo Widi Wardana, Nico Gilang Aprully
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Objective assessment of post-stroke motor impairment is crucial for effective rehabilitation, yet current clinical scales often suffer from subjectivity. This study proposes a machine learning framework to classify stroke severity using surface Electromyography (sEMG) signals from the flexor digitorum muscle. We collected sEMG data from 7 ischemic stroke survivors and 7 healthy subjects during controlled grasping tasks. Ten time-domain features were extracted from the signals and used to train a Random Forest classifier, while the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) was employed to address class imbalance. The proposed model achieved a classification accuracy of 89.29 %, with feature analysis revealing Hjorth Complexity, Waveform Length, and Slope Sign Changes as the most significant predictors. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of using an sEMG-based system for objective and reliable stroke severity assessment, offering a valuable tool to augment traditional clinical evaluations.

title: 1200V/13mΩ 4H-SiC MOSFET with Low Specific On-Resistance and High Avalanche Robustness
authors: Rui Guo, Yue Zhang, Shi Yan Li, Runhua Huang, Yong Yang, Song Bai, Longxin Shi
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: The rapid advancement of power electronics has driven the demand for semiconductor device capable of operating at high voltages, high frequency, and elevated temperature application. Benefitted from the characteristics of high thermal conductivity, fast switching speed, low dissipation and large power density, SiC MOSFET is regarded as the most potential candidate to take place of Si IGBT in 600 V 3300 V power applications. In this paper, the $1200 \mathrm{~V} / 13 \mathrm{~m} \Omega$ SiC planar MOSFET with retrograded P -well doping and JFET doping architectures (RPJ-MOS) are fabricated and comprehensively investigated. Numerical simulations have been completed to study the proposed device. The $R_{\mathrm{on}, \mathrm{sp}}$ of the proposed device is tremendously decreased compared with that of conventional SiC planar MOSFET (CON-MOS) and the avalanche robustness of RPJ-MOS is comparable to that of CON-MOS. Compared with the CON-MOS, the RPJ-MOS demonstrates 15% improvement of room temperature conduction capability, 33% improvement of high temperature conduction capability and 14% improvement of static FOM, which suggests that the proposed device is a promising candidate for high current density applications.

title: Radiation-Hardened Flip-Flop Design Using Dice and Quatro Cell for Enhanced Soft-Error Resilience
authors: B. Sreepriya, Aarthy M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This Study Proposes, in order to improve softerror resistance against Single Event Upsets (SEUs) and Double Node Upsets (DNUs), a radiation-hardened flip-flop design that integrates Dual Interlocked Storage Cell (DICE) and Quatro cell. While the Quatro cell enhances multiple-node upset (MNU) protection, guaranteeing data stability in radiation-prone situations, the DICE structure offers intrinsic fault tolerance. Using Cadence Virtuoso, the design is implemented at the 65 nm technology node and is optimized for reduced power consumption, reduced propagation latency, and enhanced noise immunity. The resilience of the circuit is confirmed by simulation results, which demonstrate decreased error vulnerability while preserving high-speed operation. The transient response shows stable state transitions under radiation-induced perturbations, and the power analysis emphasizes effective energy use. These developments make the suggested architecture ideal for high-reliability applications needing radiation-tolerant digital circuits, such as space missions and aerospace.

title: An Optimized Scheduling Method for Improving the Flexibility and Adjustability of Cement Load
authors: Yao Hongmin, Yao Yao, Wang Tengxin, Gao Le, Zhang Shifeng, Fan Rui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: Currently, cement manufacturers generally use the new dry process pre-decomposition technology to produce cement, with the main process being “two grinding and one burning,” where “one burning” refers to high-temperature calcination in a rotary kiln. In existing methods, rotary kilns are generally considered to be non-adjustable, which limits the flexibility and adjustability of cement production. This paper aims to address the shortcomings of the existing cement industry load, which generally treats rotary kilns as constant loads and ignores their potential for adjustment. It proposes a cement industry load production optimization scheduling method that takes into account the adjustability of rotary kilns, helping cement manufacturers to participate more accurately in production scheduling and thereby improving the flexibility of cement production.

title: Optimized Colon Cancer Nuclei Classification Using Hybrid Swin Transformer and CNN Model: A Comparative Study
authors: K. Venugopal, A. V. Ramana, P. Annan Naidu
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Colon cancer remains a significant global health issue, and early identification plays a crucial role in improving patient outcomes. This study focuses on enhancing the automated classification of colon cancer nuclei through a hybrid model that combines the capabilities of the Swin Transformer and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Rather than relying on a single method, this approach utilizes the Swin Transformer to capture broader contextual information, while the CNN is employed to extract fine-grained image features. To measure the performance of the proposed model, it is compared with two well-known architectures ResNet and EfficientNet using standard evaluation metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The experimental findings demonstrate that the hybrid model achieves superior results in all tested areas. These results highlight its promise in supporting healthcare professionals with faster and more accurate diagnosis of colon cancer.

title: Miniature Ion Propulsion System with Real-Time Feedback Control
authors: Hrishi Venkitesh M, T V Sudharsana Prasath, Shanmugasundaram M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This work analyses a condensed method of using FreeRTOS on an Arduino UNO microcontroller to control an ion thruster system. Two stages of an ion thruster activated through relays depending on distance and an ultrasonic sensor measuring distance form part of the setup. Separating sensor reading from thruster control into independent real-time chores guarantees responsive and effective switching depending on proximity input. Though the thrust produced is small, the prototype functions as a practical example of how real-time operating systems might be applied in space uses including thrust modulation and station-keeping. The objective is to replicate in an affordable and easily available manner basic control ideas applied in spacecraft propulsion.

title: LISA: A Lightweight Authenticated Encryption Scheme for Blockchain-Based IoMT Secure Data Transmission and Identity Verification
authors: Danya S, Bose S, Gokulraj G, Pradeep Kumar M, Illakiya Varshini C, Shruthi T
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: With the rapid growth of the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT), ensuring secure, lightweight, and real-time transmission of health data has become a critical challenge. Traditional encryption schemes like AES and RSA exhibit excessive computational overhead for resource-constrained devices. Moreover, centralized identity management schemes are vulnerable to breaches. This research proposes LISA-a Lightweight IoMT Secure Authenticator-combining efficient authenticated encryption with blockchain-compatible identity verification based on Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs). Using smart contracts on the Solana blockchain and IPFS-based storage, LISA enables secure, low-latency, tamper-proof transmission of health records. Evaluation shows that LISA outperforms AES-GCM and Ed25519 in energy efficiency, latency, and m emory consumption, making it a practical security solution for next-generation healthcare networks.

title: Research on Formation-Based Inspection of Underground Coal Mine Robots Using Variable Universe Fuzzy Control
authors: Qiaoyan Sun, Yu Han
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: To improve control accuracy and response speed in formation-based robot inspection within complex underground coal mine environments, this paper proposes a variable-universe fuzzy obstacle avoidance method. A multi-input system generates steering angle commands via fuzzy inference, while a contraction–expansion factor enables adaptive adjustment of input and output universes. MATLAB simulations show that the method effectively guides robot formations to avoid static and dynamic obstacles and accurately reach targets, enhancing flexibility and environmental adaptability.

title: Hybrid Feature Engineering and Tree-Based Ensembles for Predicting Epidemic Outbreaks
authors: Banala Saritha, G Purnachandrarao, P. Vishwak, M. Narendra, M. Harish, M. Shourya Balaji
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Machine learning is gaining significant prominence as a practical approach for predicting disease outbreaks and trends. Regression-based models have drawn considerable attention in the time-series disease forecasting domain. Earlier, disease prediction relied heavily on handcrafted statistical models like ARIMA and SEIR. However, the evolving nature of COVID-19 data has made machine learning-based forecasting an active area of research. Regression models like e Extreme Gradient Boosting XGBoost and Random Forest have recently shown promising results when trained on temporal clinical and demographic data. These models analyze lagged case data and mobility trends to discover low-level patterns not captured by classical models, enabling the system to anticipate infection surges more efficiently. Efficient feature engineering and model optimization are vital to achieving this. The architecture proposed in this paper integrates time-lag and rolling average features with a tuned regression pipeline for end-to-end COVID-19 prediction. The proposed approach converges quickly and outperforms conventional regressors in both accuracy and error metrics. This research work has been tested on public COVID-19 datasets and improved R-squared score by 15% and reduced RMSE by 28%.

title: Implementable Control Strategy for Residential Energy Management System Incorporating Demand Response Program
authors: Aiman Muqri Bin Mohamad Sukri, Nurulafiqah Nadzirah Binti Mansor, Jia Yun Lian, Rizki Mendung Ariefianto, Hazlie Bin Mokhlis, Mohammad Sameer Ahmad
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimized Energy Management System (EMS) for grid-connected-residential solar photovoltaic (PV) systems, integrating Demand Response (DR) program to maximize user benefits while ensuring system reliability and stability. The proposed EMS comprises of solar PV array and Battery Energy Storage System (BESS), with the residential loads modelled and simulated using MATLAB. The EMS prioritizes renewable energy utilization while minimizes grid power consumption, incorporating automatic load control for enhanced efficiency. Variability of residential loads is addressed through DR program with Interruptible Load (IL) control, optimized using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Crayfish Optimization Algorithm (COA). The optimization targets maximum user comfort as well as peak load and cost reduction. Comparative analysis reveals that COA outperforms PSO, leading to its adoption in the optimized EMS. Real-world evaluation using daily residential data demonstrates that the optimized EMS achieves lower electricity costs, higher user satisfaction, and improved system stability compared to a conventional EMS.

title: Radar Target Range-Azimuth-Elevation Tracking Using Adaptive Kernel Kalman Filtering
authors: Zhanke Li, Junfeng Jin
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Aiming at the challenge of target tracking under nonlinear and non-Gaussian noise conditions in radar measurements, this paper proposes a range–azimuth–elevation tracking algorithm based on Adaptive Kernel Kalman Filtering. The algorithm employs kernel functions to map raw measurement data into a high-dimensional Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space and integrates an adaptive noise covariance estimation mechanism. This approach effectively overcomes the limitations of traditional Kalman filtering in dealing with nonlinear systems by leveraging the nonparametric representation and functional learning capabilities of kernel methods. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms the standard Particle Filter in terms of both tracking accuracy, computational efficiency, and robustness, especially under conditions of high maneuverability and complex noise distributions.

title: AI-Driven Stator Fault Detection Using Time-Domain Features of Current Signal
authors: Geetha G, Geethanjali P
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The difficulty in the identification of permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) faults has attracted significant a cademic a ttention recently. T his w ork a ddresses the identification o ff aults i n P MSM s tators u tilizing statistical features including mean absolute value, zero crossing, simple sign integral, waveform length, slope sign change, and specific machine learning algorithms including k-nearest neighbors and support vector machine. This study examines current signal data of PMSM with two distinct motor power levels over eight varying degrees of stator fault severity. The instances of PMSM, comprising normal operation, inter-coil fault, and inter-turn fault, are exhibited on two motors with power ratings of 1 and 1.5 kW. The PMSMs work under identical torque load conditions and rotational speeds. The KNN is more efficient; it is easy and does not require a lot of computation for stator fault identification.

title: Game-Theoretic AI for Zero Trust Cyber Defense
authors: Al Amin Hossain, Darryl Ahner
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: The increasing reliance on cyber-connected systems to safeguard critical infrastructure—such as industrial control systems, nuclear facilities, and military networks—demands rigorous methods for evaluating and improving resilience. Existing approaches often employ narrow, single-technique models that lack adaptability to complex operational environments. This paper proposes a game-theoretic AI framework that integrates strategic reasoning, probabilistic modeling, and mathematical optimization to assess and enhance cyber defense capabilities. The framework supports Zero Trust enforcement across all OSI layers by continuously evaluating threats and enabling adaptive, real-time decision-making. Grounded in the principle that no entity is inherently trustworthy, the system dynamically adjusts defensive strategies, prioritizes resources, and improves network robustness. This strategy enables cyber defense analysts to anticipate risks, optimize resource allocation, and sustain mission operations. Ultimately, the framework delivers a scalable, intelligent foundation for resilient cybersecurity, strengthening the ability of critical systems to resist and recover from sophisticated, persistent attacks.

title: Modernizing Legacy Healthcare Systems Utilizing Semantic-Based Automated Mapping
authors: Su-Cheng Haw, Tong-Ern Tai, Wan-Er Kong, Kok-Why Ng, Palanichamy Naveen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Automated data mapping of legacy systems is one of the most critical enablers of digital transformation across various sectors, including healthcare, finance, and government. In system modernization when organizations shift from their legacy systems to new platforms, an automated mapping scheme is vital in handling many and often disparate data models, thus allowing seamless data migration without any loss or corruption that manually transformed data might incur. Over the past two decades, the demand for solutions with higher accuracy and reliability has increased. Thus, a semantic-based mapping is thus proposed in this context to enhance accuracy and reliability regarding data transformations while exploiting ontologies and semantic relations within the data. This gives a possibility for precise, relevant mapping of entities enhancing their integrity while minimizing errors. The observed results show that sematic-based mapping reduces data greatly loss, increases interoperability, and ensures consistency across platforms as compared to the rule-based mapping. Therefore, by maintaining quality information during transitions between systems, semantic mapping facilitates more effective digital transformation where organizations can make full use of their legacy information in modernized contexts.

title: AI-Enhanced System for Occupancy-Aware Indoor Air Quality and Safety Monitoring
authors: S. Xavier Arockiaraj, B. Jaishree, K. Kavipriya, J. Mohankumar, F. Vijay Amirtha Raj, M. K. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Indoor air quality (IAQ) meaningly influences human health and safety, particularly in enclosed environments. This work presents a machine learning (ML)-based framework for predicting air quality hazards and occupancy states using sensor-derived features, including gas concentrations (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{C O}_{\mathbf{2}}, \mathbf{C O}$</tex>, LPG), environmental parameters (temperature, humidity), and occupancy indicators (ultrasonic distance). Four supervised learning models-Random Forest, Logistic Regression, Gradient Boosting, and Decision Tree-were evaluated for their predictive performance on a dataset of 500 labeled samples collected from controlled experiments and real indoor environments. Amongst, Random Forest achieved the highest accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(56 \%)$</tex>, highlighting the ability of ensemble tree-based methods to capture intricate, non-linear relations in sensor data. The results also underscore the limitations of linear and singletree models when applied to small datasets with high variability. Overall, this study demonstrates that machine learning can provide predictive intelligence for indoor environments, supporting the development of real-time hazard monitoring and alert systems. Future work will explore temporal modeling, feature expansion, and real-time deployment to improve prediction accuracy and operational reliability.

title: Realistic Assessment of PV and EV Hosting Capacity in Low-Voltage Networks: A Comparative Study of Deterministic and Time-Series Methods
authors: Tapparit Bangtit, Yuttana Kumsuwan, Paramet Wirasanti, Watcharin Srirattanawichaikul
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of Deterministic and Time-Series methods for evaluating the hosting capacity (HC) of distributed energy resources (DERs), including rooftop photovoltaic (PV) systems and residential electric vehicle (EV) chargers. Simulations were conducted on a low-voltage residential feeder with 18 nodes, each representing a household. PV sizes ranged from 3 to 25 kW and EV chargers from 7.4 to 22 kW. The Time-Series method identified constraint violations more accurately across a 24-hour cycle, while the Deterministic method produced variable results depending on static assumptions—ranging from overly conservative to overly optimistic. Time-Series simulations revealed voltage rise at far-end nodes during midday due to PV export and transformer overloading during evening EV charging. These findings highlight the value of temporal analysis in realistic HC assessment. The Time-Series method is recommended for utility planners due to its ability to reveal when and where violations occur, supporting smarter DER integration strategies.
