title: Silicon Diode Temperature Sensors With Improved Performance For Cryogenic Applications
authors: Yuriy M. Shwarts, Marina M. Shwarts, Valeriy N. Sokolov, Aleksandr E. Belyaev
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The performance of commercial silicon diode temperature sensors (DTs) (stability, reproducibility, wide temperature range, high sensitivity, and linear voltage-temperature dependence) has made them most attractive and widely demanded for cryogenic applications. However, in the lowest temperature range, near the helium temperature, DTs are strongly affected by the influence of the self-heating and external magnetic fields, which makes their use as temperature sensors practically impossible. In this work, the new design of DTs, the advanced silicon diode temperature sensors (AdvDTs), created on the basis of a heavily doped silicon diode structure, is proposed and tested, which allows improving their performance for cryogenic applications. For AdvDTs, in the low temperature range, the influence of Joule heating and magnetic fields on their performance is minimized. The physical mechanisms responsible for the formation of the improved performance of AdvDTs are discussed.

title: Design and Implementation of a Real-Time Compensation Algorithm for Age Error in Heterodyne Interference Signal Data
authors: Hao Du, Zhiwei Xia, Wentao Zhang, Xinjian Li, Quan Feng, Huiying Gao, Peiyuan Xiong
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This paper analyzes and compensates for Data Age Error (DAE) in heterodyne interferometers under high-dynamic conditions, systematically elucidating the origins and mechanisms of this error. Building upon the derivation of the DAE model, we introduce parametric quantization modeling to enhance computability. Furthermore, we propose a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) -based Optimized Twin-Complementary Algebraic Derivative Estimation Method (OTC-ADEM) for dynamic DAE compensation that balances accuracy with computational efficiency. Through a quantitative analysis of the impact of derivative order and initialization period on compensation performance, this method constructs parameter-adaptive windows suitable for diverse dynamic operating conditions. Experimental results demonstrate effective suppression of displacement errors: reducing the error from ±4 nm to within ±0.2 nm during initial uniform motion and from ±65 nm to within ±9.73 nm during variable-speed motion. Compared to conventional correction methods, our proposed approach exhibits superior performance in continuous compensation accuracy while enhancing suitability for measurements under high dynamic changes. It simultaneously mitigates the risk of Algebraic Derivative Estimation Method (ADEM) errors during sudden high-speed transitions, achieving a favorable balance between compensation precision and computational efficiency.

title: A Scalable Multilevel Series-Connected Ripple Suppression Unit for High Voltage DC Power Supply
authors: Jing Wang, Yang Liu, Zongjian Li, Renfeng Guan, Peijiu Sun, Chao Zhang, Zhixing He, Hongliang Wang, Wenguang Chen, Qibei Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: High-voltage dc power supply (HVdcPS) is widely used in vacuum tubes such as radar and microwave plasma generators. In these applications, low output charge and low ripple are required. Consequently, the traditional method of reducing ripple by increasing output capacitance is not applicable. In this article, a scalable multilevel series-connected ripple suppression unit (RSU) for reducing voltage ripple in HVdcPS is proposed. The RSU is composed of two switches, two diodes, and one capacitor. It generates a multilevel staircase wave to fit the ripple and suppress it through antiphase superposition by connecting the RSU in series with the HVdcPS and load. Compared with the traditional solutions, this method uses additional RSU to suppress ripple, featuring a scalable structure with negligible additional losses. The operating principle and state analysis of the RSU are presented, along with a comprehensive study of the optimal control method for ripple suppression. Finally, a prototype of the RSU used in two different HVdcPS is built to verify. The experimental results demonstrate that the two-stage RSUs can reduce the voltage ripple to 28% while the power loss is only increased by 0.13%.

title: On the Exclusion of Hyperspectral Sources
authors: Zihan Zhang, Thierry Blu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: This paper introduces a blind source separation approach based on a “source exclusion” principle for hyperspectral image unmixing (HSU). We define the exclusion mathematically as a metric quantifying the global purity of the pixels. We then develop an efficient algorithm to minimize this criterion (Weak Exclusion Principle—WEP), and devise a convex optimization strategy (WEP+) to enforce sum-to-one and non-negativity, which are common constraints for hyperspectral sources. Through comprehensive experimental validations against standard and state-of-the-art unmixing algorithms on synthetic and real-world datasets, we demonstrate the superior accuracy and computational efficiency of our WEP+ solution.

title: Compact Magnetostrictive-Driven Resonant Mechanical Antenna for Efficient Extremely-Low Frequency Electromagnetic Emission
authors: Yifan Diao, Qixin Guo, Liang Yu, Weikang Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A resonant extremely low-frequency (ELF) mechanical antenna prototype with an adjustable resonant frequency is developed for long-range cross-media communication. Magnetostrictive actuation is studied to achieve high energy conversion rate. The resonance mechanism is utilized to significantly enhance radiation efficiency compared to a conventional amplifying lever. This prototype employs a high-performance electret thin film as the source of electromagnetic radiation, offering advantages such as miniaturization and high radiation intensity. Additionally, the radiation mechanism of the electret with a single charge is studied, and a vibration-radiation model of the electromagnetic dipole is established. The vibration and the magnetic field simulations and tests are conducted to evaluate the prototype’s performance. A tenfold vibration amplification is obtained at resonance with the designed lever compared to the off-resonance state. As a result, the designed mechanical antenna can achieve a radiation distance of up to 92.2 km at 1 fT. This study demonstrates a promising path for developing miniaturized and efficient ELF transmitters.

title: GNN-Enabled Coordinated Beamforming Design for High Speed Railway Communication Systems
authors: Changpeng He, Yang Lu, Ruichen Zhang, Yidong Li, Bo Ai, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: This paper proposes a graph neural network (GNN)-enabled coordinated beamforming design, termed HSTGNN, for high speed railway (HSR) communication systems, where a high-speed train (HST) and low-speed users (LUs) coexist in multi-cell scenarios. Two transmission schemes with the goal of maximizing quality-of-service (QoS)-constrained sum rate and rate of the HST are formulated and then reformulated using a hybrid maximum ratio transmission and zero-forcing strategy. The HSR communication system is abstracted into a heterogeneous graph, and HSTGNN consists of complex heterogeneous graph attention layers and fully-connected layers. To meet QoS requirements and power budget constraints, we employ constraint-based penalty terms and a numerical scaling operation. HSTGNN is trained via unsupervised learning to solve the two schemes in a unified framework. Numerical results demonstrate that HSTGNN achieves millisecond-level inference speed with an average optimality gap of only 4% relative to traditional optimization algorithm across various scenarios. Moreover, HSTGNN exhibits strong scalability to unseen configurations of both cells and LUs.

title: Modulation, Control, and Tank Design for ZVS of a Resonant T-Type Bridge in a 20 kW Unfolding-Based Single-Stage AC-DC Converter
authors: Aditya Zade, Shubhangi Gurudiwan, Regan Zane
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: This article proposes a robust closed-loop control architecture with a leading-edge-aligned modulation strategy to ensure zero-voltage switching (ZVS) of the resonant T-type bridge in an unfolding-based ac-dc conversion system. In the proposed approach, ZVS is achieved throughout the grid cycle by precisely aligning the leading edges of the T-type bridge output quasi-square voltages. The closed-loop control is designed for the high-frequency T-type bridge to simultaneously achieve sinusoidal grid current shaping and output power regulation. Accurate small-signal modeling is presented to ensure appropriate closed-loop bandwidths for system stability and robust dynamic performance. Additionally, a detailed ZVS analysis is presented, taking into account the nonlinear behavior of the MOSFET output capacitance to ensure accurate results. Based on this ZVS analysis, combined with conduction loss calculations, optimized tank design guidelines are provided. The effectiveness of the proposed modulation and control architecture, along with the ZVS operation of the T-type bridge throughout the grid cycle, is experimentally validated on a 20 kW, 480 V, 3-ϕ grid-tied ac-dc hardware prototype. Experimental results demonstrate complete ZVS operation throughout the grid cycle, a peak ac-dc efficiency of 96.51%, and a low grid current total harmonic distortion of 2.3% at rated output power. Furthermore, a comparison with a center-aligned modulation strategy implemented on the same hardware prototype shows a 0.76% higher ac-dc efficiency and a 6 dB reduction in radiated electromagnetic interference, corresponding to a twofold decrease, thereby establishing the superior practical performance of the proposed approach.

title: A Fractional-order Wireless Power Transfer System With A Wide Load Range
authors: Xujian Shu, Chen Li, Guoxin Wu, Bo Zhang, Jingjing Yang, Yanwei Jiang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Currently, most magnetic coupling wireless power transfer (MCWPT) systems are designed based on integer-order components (IOCs). However, in practice, inductors and capacitors exhibit fractional-order characteristics due to physical factors, giving rise to fractional-order MCWPT systems. Although these systems can reduce the sensitivity of traditional integer-order MCWPT systems to coupling coefficients, load disturbances, and resonant frequency offsets, they suffer from narrow transfer range and poor load adaptability, which restrict their application prospects. To address this, this paper proposes a fractional-order MCWPT system with extended load adaptability. Firstly, a fractional-order MCWPT topology with a wide load range is proposed based on topology switching. Then, the frequency and output characteristics of the system are analyzed using circuit theory. Subsequently, an optimized control method for fractional-order capacitors applicable to the proposed system is presented, and an output control strategy of constant current (CC) and constant voltage (CV) is designed. Finally, an experimental prototype with a 24V/2A output is built to verify the feasibility. The results show that the proposed system significantly expands the load variation range and ensures that the output voltage and current of the system have strong robustness to the variations of coupling coefficient, resonant frequency deviation, and load fluctuation.

title: Simple Solution to Overcome Fault Recovery Issues of Grid-forming Inverter With Current Limiter
authors: Shimiao Chen, Yao Sun, Xiaochao Hou, Mingxin Hu, Mei Su, Kai Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Grid-forming (GFM) inverters with priority current limiter suffer the fault recovery issue, commonly manifested as the failure to exit from current limitation after fault clearance. To overcome this issue, this paper proposes a virtual power PIVS-feedback method. This method employs the virtual power of the internal voltage source PIVS as power feedback, rather than relying on the actual output power Pe. The inherent fault recovery issue of priority current limiters can be well-solved in this simple yet efficient way. Furthermore, the proposed universal virtual power PIVS-feedback framework can be expanded from a specific case of d-axis priority current limiter to other cases of circular current limiters. Besides, a comparative study of typical virtual power feedback methods shows the feasibility and superior applicability of the proposed method. Compared to existing methods, the proposed method eliminates the necessity for complex control design, additional line or grid information, and control structure reconfiguration. Comprehensive theorical analysis and hardware-in-loop experiments verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Cross-Model Face Recognition Via Guided Alignment Mutual Decoupled Distillation
authors: Jungyun Kim, Tiong-Sik Ng, Taeyong Kim, Andrew Beng Jin Teoh
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Cross-model face recognition poses a major challenge due to inconsistent embeddings produced by diverse face recognition models, limiting system interoperability. Enhancing compatibility among these models is essential for scalable, maintainable face recognition systems. This paper presents the Kolmogorov-Arnold Guided Alignment (KAGA) model, optimized with Mutual Decoupled Distillation (MDD), to effectively bridge embedding discrepancies. KAGA integrates a cross-attention mechanism and a learnable Guided Alignment Embedding to unify feature spaces, while Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks ensure robustness of the transformation. MDD facilitates selective knowledge transfer without compromising class separability, and bidirectional distillation refines feature representations for improved generalization. Extensive experiments across multiple face recognition benchmarks confirm KAGA's effectiveness, demonstrating substantial gains in accuracy and cross-model compatibility compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: 3D High-quality Power Doppler Using Coherence-based Null Subtraction Imaging_supp6-3649288.mp4
authors: Jianwen Luo
publish: N/A
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) power Doppler (PD) imaging enables visualization of volumetric microvasculature networks. However, 3D ultrafast PD imaging with matrix arrays suffers from limited resolution due to the restricted aperture size and the use of unfocused plane waves, while delay-and-sum (DAS) exhibits high sidelobe levels and broad main lobes, hindering high-quality PD imaging. In this study, we aim to improve the 3D null subtraction imaging (NSI) and propose coherence-based NSI beamformers including NSI based on coherence factor (NSI-CF) and NSI based on spatial and angular coherence factor (NSI-SACF). Specifically, NSI-SACF integrates the high-resolution capability of NSI and the high-contrast performance of spatial and angular coherence factor (SACF). The proposed beamformers are validated through simulations, phantom experiments, and in vivo experiments. Qualitative and quantitative evaluations confirm the superiority of NSI-SACF. In the simulations, NSI-SACF achieves a full width at half maximum (FWHM) of 0.059 mm compared with 0.391 mm for DAS and 0.225 mm for SACF. NSI-SACF also reduces the sidelobe level by 75.5 dB and 33.6 dB compared with DAS and SACF respectively, while effectively suppressing grating lobes. In the in vivo experiments, NSI-SACF improves the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) of blood flow by 20.03 dB and 8.65 dB over DAS and SACF, respectively. Furthermore, the FWHM of the vessel is reduced to 0.098 mm with NSI-SACF, compared with 0.326 mm for DAS and 0.159 mm for SACF. In summary, the proposed NSI-SACF beamformer effectively enhances the PD imaging by simultaneously improving spatial resolution and contrast, demonstrating the potential for clinical applications.

title: Design and Implementation of an IoT-Enabled Greenhouse Environmental Control System
authors: L.Jenifer Amla, K.Sheela Sobana Rani, C.V. Pavithra, R. Divya
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Sustainable agriculture requires the adoption of advanced technologies to increase crop yield and optimize resource use. This study details the design and implementation of a smart greenhouse monitoring and control system utilizing the ESP8266 and the Blynk Internet of Things (IoT) platform. The system incorporates multiple sensors to monitor environmental parameters such as temperature, humidity, soil moisture, and light intensity. Real-time data is transmitted wirelessly to the Blynk application, allowing remote access via smartphones or tablets. Automated actuators manage irrigation, ventilation, and shading to maintain optimal greenhouse conditions. Users can monitor environmental data, receive alerts for deviations from set thresholds, and manually override control actions through the Blynk interface. Experimental results indicate that the system enhances crop productivity, resource efficiency, and user accessibility. Integrating IoT-based monitoring with automated control offers a scalable and cost-effective approach to sustainable greenhouse management.

title: Design and Development of Wireless Power Transfer Based Charger for Eskate Scooter
authors: Dhinesh Sadhu Subramaniam Ponnarasan, Jayasurya Chinnappaudayar Murugan, Raguraja Krishnan Natarajan Mangaleshwaran, Venkateshwaran Mohan, Mahalakshmi Senthilkumar, Hemapriya Yuganderan
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The objective of the project is to design a wireless power transfer charging circuit for e skate scooter. Wireless power transfer is the transmission of electrical power without using transmission network. Issues associated with safety, maintenance and simple structure as compared with wired system. There are many ways of transferring power wirelessly, but the more suitable way is inductive power transfer and resonant power transfer. The wireless power transfer consists of transmitter and the receiver network. In transmitter end, a switched-mode power supply (SMPS) and a DC-DC converter are connected to convert the grid supply into required DC voltage for transferring the power to a transmitter coil. In receiver end, a rectifier circuit, filter, battery management system (BMS) is connected to charge the battery as per the standards. The core workflow of the design moves through four major stages. The creation of a Switched-Mode Power Supply (SMPS) as a better power regulation solution is the first stage. Next, a 100 W wireless power transfer system with a Series-Series compensated topology is established to achieve high power transfer efficiency and a successful system implementation. The stage 4 is largely centered on providing full control of the State of Charge (SOC) and battery charge cycle to properly optimize battery life and performance. The confirmation of the prototype and the new design simulation to ascertain the effectiveness and the durability of the design are the last stages of the proposed workflow.

title: Optimal Online EV Charging with Discrete Rates and Phase Unbalance Constraints
authors: Can Berk Saner
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: In this work, we focus on the optimal electric vehicle (EV) charging problem for a station equipped with single-phase chargers, considering the aspects of mitigating phase current unbalance and chargers that operate at discrete, non-continuous rates. We frame the problem as maximization of aggregate user utility subject to per-phase current capacity, phase unbalance constraints, and discrete charging rates. We propose an online algorithm by recasting the problem as a separable and increasing concave maximization over an integer polymatroid. The resulting algorithm is proven to find the globally optimal solution in polynomial time. The algorithm is computationally lightweight, does not require specialized optimization solvers, and is scalable for real-time control of large-scale EV charging, offering a practical and effective solution for charging station operators.

title: Deep Learning for Enhancing Sentinel-1 Imagery
authors: Juan Francisco Amieva, Christian Ayala, Mikel Galar
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) systems, offer remarkable advantages such as continuous monitoring capabilities regardless of weather conditions or time of day. Among SAR constellations, Sentinel-1 (S1) stands out for its provision of openly accessible imagery. However, challenges arise from S1's intrinsic spatial resolution limitations and the high level of speckle noise, which complicates data analysis. An alternative to address these limitations is to utilize commercial satellite missions, which typically provide high-resolution on-demand data, but their widespread adoption is hindered by the significant costs associated with accessing such resources. To tackle these challenges, this research introduces a novel methodology designed to simultaneously alleviate speckle noise and enhance the spatial resolution of S1 data. Accordingly, this methodology consists of two phases. Firstly, the model is pre-trained using either simulated noisy input images or synthetic clean reference images to mainly focus on despeckling. Then, the model is finetuned, leveraging low-resolution S1 Interferometric Wide Swath (IW) mode products as input and high-resolution TerraSAR-X Stripmap mode imagery as ground truth data to further enhance the super-resolution task. As a result, despeckled S1 images at 5 m ground sampling distance (GSD) are generated from noisy S1 IW images at 10 m GSD, narrowing the resolution gap between S1 and commercial SAR satellites while enhancing output quality in terms of speckle noise disturbances.

title: Accelerating Cerebral Diagnostics with BrainFusion: A Comprehensive MRI Tumor Framework
authors: Walid Houmaidi, Youssef Sabiri, Salmane El Mansour Billah, Amine Abouaomar
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The early and accurate classification of brain tumors is crucial for guiding effective treatment strategies and improving patient outcomes. This study presents BrainFusion, a significant advancement in brain tumor analysis using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) by combining fine-tuned convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for tumor classification —including VGG16, ResNet50, and Xception—with YOLOv8 for precise tumor localization with bounding boxes. Leveraging the “Brain Tumor MRI Dataset”, our experiments reveal that the fine-tuned VGG16 model achieves test accuracy of 99.86%, substantially exceeding previous benchmarks. Beyond setting a new accuracy standard, the integration of bounding-box localization and explainable AI techniques further enhances both the clinical interpretability and trustworthiness of the system's outputs. Overall, this approach underscores the transformative potential of deep learning in delivering faster, more reliable diagnoses, ultimately contributing to improved patient care and survival rates.

title: Comparative Radiation Analysis of Vertical and Circular Disk Monopole Antennas for 433 MHz LoRa IoT Applications Using Method of Moments
authors: Jinfeng Li, Haolin Zhou
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The 433 MHz frequency band plays a pivotal role in long-range (LoRa) wireless communication due to its favorable propagation characteristics within the Industrial, Scientific, and Medical (ISM) spectrum. This study investigates and compares the radiation performance of two antenna configurations-circular disk monopoles (CDMs) and vertical monopoles (VMs)-operating at this frequency. Both antenna types are simulated using the Method of Moments (MoM) implemented in MATLAB, with identical ground plane dimensions and material properties to ensure a fair comparison. Key performance metrics, including the two-dimensional (2D) elevation (E-plane) pattern and the three-dimensional (3D) radiation pattern, are analyzed. Current density distribution is smeared in the CDM one, i.e., reduced peaking is evidenced. The findings provide valuable insights into the relative advantages of each monopole structure in LoRa applications requiring directional and omnidirectional radiation characteristics.

title: Design of a Network Public Opinion Analysis System for Short Texts
authors: Tao Liu, Zhize Hao, Fei Cheng, Fan Bai
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Communication and Information Systems (ICCIS)
abstract: With the rapid development of internet, online platforms have increasingly become the primary channels for the public to obtain information and share opinions. Under these circumstances, the timely collection and effective analysis of online discussions are of great practical significance for identifying negative sentiments and misinformation, thereby reducing public deception and fostering a healthier digital environment. Consequently, efficiently gathering and accurately assessing public opinion from massive internet data has emerged as a critical research challenge. This study focuses on information collection and analysis technologies for online public opinion within complex internet ecosystem. We designed and implemented a short-text oriented public opinion analysis system featuring hotspot detection, keyword extraction, sentiment analysis, and trend visualization. The system provides governmental agencies and individuals with intuitive insights into online sentiment dynamics, enabling effective tracking of trending events and supporting data-driven decision-making.

title: Decoding Human Emotions Through EEG: An Intelligent Multi-Model Architecture
authors: Dhivya M R, Brindha V, Gokula Krishanan P, A. Mohanarathinam
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: This proposed study investigated how human emotions, such as positive, neutral, and negative, can be identified using electroencephalograms (EEG). We made use of the Brainwave Emotions EEG Dataset, which was gathered by wearing a Muse headband that captured brain activity while viewers viewed videos that evoked strong emotions. We extracted valuable patterns in the time and frequency domains after cleaning and processing the data using filtering and normalization. Next, we evaluated three distinct models: one that used Autoencoder, CNN, LSTM, and Attention for deep learning, another that used Autoencoder, CNN, and Transformer for simple TQWT + Random Forest with SMOTE. The same dataset was used to train all three models, and metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, ROC curve, and AUC were used to assess each model. The Transformer-based model among them provided thebest accuracy of 98.12%, whereas the Random Forest model fared well with quicker training. Strong performance was also demonstrated by the LSTM-based model, particularly in comprehending timerelated patterns. All things considered, our research demonstrates that EEG signals are capable of accurately identifying emotions, and the best model can be selected depending on the requirements for simplicity, speed, or accuracy.

title: SMMEG-IoT: A Secure Multi-app Multi-protocol Edge Gateway for the IoT
authors: Abdulkadir Dauda, Olivier Flauzac, Florent Nolot
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: The growing heterogeneity and complexity of modern IoT systems necessitate architecture solutions that not only support multiple protocols but also provide strong security guarantees. This paper presents a specification for integrating security into an edge gateway that we previously proposed, which supports dynamic, multi-application, and multi-protocol deployments. The proposed gateway supports both IP and non-IP protocols while enforcing isolation mechanisms across its operational layers. Our architecture features a containerized and extensible design that separates protocol handling and application execution. This is achieved using a Docker container runtime on a Raspberry Pi. The proposed security specifications are based on best-practice guidelines issued by leading cybersecurity agencies, including the U.S. CISA and the French ANSSI. These controls encompass access control, end-to-end encryption, and regular firmware updates. Overall, the proposed design offers a strong foundation for secure, scalable, and flexible edge computing in multi-application, multi-protocol IoT deployments.

title: A Neuro-Symbolic Approach to Translating Natural Language Instructions into Structured, Verifiable Commands
authors: Shang Li, Zhiwei Zong, Yang Chen, Xin Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Communication and Information Systems (ICCIS)
abstract: Automating procedural tasks from natural language instructions is crucial for industrial applications but is hampered by ambiguity and the need for implicit domain knowledge. While Large Language Models (LLMs) offer unprecedented semantic understanding, their propensity for factual hallucination renders them unreliable for safety-critical systems. This paper presents a novel neuro-symbolic framework to address this challenge. Our approach leverages an LLM for initial instruction translation, guided by Chain-of-Thought prompting for logical transparency and Retrieval-Augmented Generation for contextual grounding. Critically, we introduce a post-hoc verification layer where every structured command candidate generated by the LLM is rigorously validated against a domain-specific knowledge graph for entity correctness, operational legality, and parameter safety. Through a series of case studies, we demonstrate that our framework effectively resolves contextual ambiguities, prevents the execution of factually incorrect commands, and enforces implicit safety constraints that a standalone LLM would miss. Our work provides a robust methodology for creating verifiable and trustworthy instruction-following systems, bridging the gap between linguistic flexibility and operational reliability.

title: Explainable AI-Supported Financial Forecasting for EV Charging Infrastructure Investments
authors: R. Radhika, Sakshi Venkatesh, Bhavna Agrawal, Anuj Kumar Shah, Devdas Gupta, E. Muthukumar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The rapid growth of electric vehicles (EVs) has intensified the demand for efficient and strategically planned charging infrastructure, making accurate financial forecasting crucial for sustainable investments. Traditional forecasting approaches often rely on opaque statistical models or historical trends, which limit transparency, hinder investor confidence, and fail to capture complex market dynamics, regulatory changes, and consumer adoption patterns. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an Explainable AI-Supported Financial Forecasting framework for EV Charging Infrastructure Investments (XAI-FFECI), which combines advanced machine learning algorithms with explainable AI techniques to predict revenue streams, operational costs, and investment returns while providing interpretable insights for decision-makers. XAI-FFECI integrates time-series forecasting, feature importance analysis, and scenario-based simulations to capture market volatility, policy interventions, and demand fluctuations. Experimental evaluation conducted using publicly available EV adoption and charging infrastructure datasets demonstrated that XAI-FFECI improved forecasting accuracy by 28%, enhanced interpretability for stakeholders by 34%, and enabled more informed investment decisions compared to conventional black-box financial models. The framework allows investors and policymakers to identify key drivers of profitability, evaluate risk exposure, and optimize resource allocation in EV charging networks. In conclusion, XAI-FFECI provides a scalable, transparent, and adaptive solution for financial planning in EV infrastructure investments, bridging the gap between predictive performance and explainability, and supporting sustainable, datadriven investment strategies in the rapidly evolving electric mobility sector.

title: Smart Sieving System for Jaggery Powder Processing and Grading
authors: M. Lizzy Nesa Bagyam, Saran C S, Sivaraj S, Sowmiya S
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Traditional jaggery powder sieving methods often face challenges such as inconsistent particle size, hygiene issues, and frequent production interruptions due to reliance on manual labor. These limitations reduce product quality and efficiency in small-scale processing units. This paper presents a Smart Automated Sieving System developed to address these concerns. The system employs an automation controller integrated with load cell-based weight sensing to regulate input and monitor waste levels. A motorized sieving mechanism ensures uniform separation of fine powder, while an automatic waste ejection unit is activated once thresholds are reached, minimizing downtime. Real-time monitoring through a user-friendly display improves operational transparency, and the compact modular design enables easy integration into existing setups. Field testing demonstrated enhanced product consistency, hygiene, and throughput compared with conventional methods. The system provides a cost-effective, reliable, and lowmaintenance solution, making it particularly suitable for rural and small-scale food processing environments.

title: In-Network Collective Operations: Game Changer or Challenge for AI Workloads?
authors: Torsten Hoefler, Mikhail Khalilov, Josiah Clark, Surendra Anubolu, Mohan Kalkunte, Karen Schramm, Eric Spada, Duncan Roweth, Keith Underwood, Adrian Caulfield, Abdul Kabbani, Amirreza Rastegari
publish: Computer
abstract: This paper summarizes the opportunities of in-network collective operations for accelerated collective operations in artificial intelligence (AI) workloads. We provide sufficient detail to make this important field accessible to nonexperts in AI or networking, fostering a connection between these communities.

title: Promises and Perils of LLM- and Agent-Generated Code
authors: Premkumar T. Devanbu
publish: Computer
abstract: This article draws attention to the fact that, traditionally, software maintenance costs have strongly dominated initial development costs, and calls for more in-depth, focused, specialized studies of the actual impacts of large language model- and agent-generated code.

title: No-Reference Image Quality Assessment Using FPLBP Features with Laplacian of Gaussian
authors: Yassine Benhlal, Khadija Marzagui, Abdelkaher AIT Abdelouahad, Abellatif Dahmouni
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The image quality assessment (IQA) process seeks to determine how people perceive the quality of an image it remains necessary for many image processing and computer vision applications. In this paper, we propose a novel noreference IQA method based on quality-aware texture descriptors constructed using Four-Patch Local Binary Patterns (FPLBPs). Our First, to improve the description of local textures typically affected by visual distortions, we propose modeling them using a multiscale approach. In which, each image is rendered on several subscales using Laplacian-Gaussian (LoG) filters at varying frequency bandwidths. Second, obtained subband images are then used to calculate the FPLBPs descriptors. Second, we calculate the FPLBP descriptors for each of the subband images. In fact, FPLBP consists of modeling the spatial structure based on local intensity variations across each patch, defining local texture representations as local histograms, and generating the global feature vector by concatenating these local histograms. This reflects the overall perceived image quality. Lastly, we train a Support Vector Regressor (SVR) to estimate the Mean Opinion Score (MOS) directly from the feature vectors. Evaluation using a benchmark for IQA, shows that our method has strong associations with subjective quality scores.

title: Towards Explainable Multi-Modal Fusion Strategies for ASD Detection: A Review
authors: Nada S. El-Askary, Mohamed Gawish, Mohamed Mabrouk Morsey, Abeer M. Mahmoud, Mostafa Aref, Taha Ibrahim El-Arif
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder marked by complexities that has attracted considerable attention recently, leading to extensive research on automated diagnosis through artificial intelligence. As largescale neuroimaging data becomes more accessible datasets, researchers have begun to build systems incorporating multi-model fusion strategies and Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) techniques to enhance classification performance and model interpretability. This review presents a comprehensive overview with extensive analysis of recent advancements in multi-model fusion approaches for ASD detection including early (featurelevel), intermediate (model-level), and late (decision-level) fusion techniques applied to structural MRI, functional MRI, and phenotypic data, focusing on studies utilizing the ABIDE dataset. In parallel, the growing importance of XAI is addressed, highlighting methods such as “GMDH”, “SHAP”, and “LIME” that provide transparency and insight into model decisions, enabling clinicians to understand these decisions. The paper discusses common challenges in multi-site datasets, model generalizability, and interpretability, and offers guidance for selecting appropriate fusion strategies and explanation tools. Finally, future directions are proposed to improve the clinical relevance, robustness, and ethical deployment of AI systems for ASD diagnosis.

title: Enhancing Image-Based Object Detection for Autonomous Driving Using Deep Learning Technique
authors: Yomna Hatem Mohamed, Sherine Rady, Rasha Ismail
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Accurate real-time image-based object detection is key to ensuring safety and efficiency in autonomous driving. One of the most common techniques used in real-time object detection is Deep Learning (DL) because of its ability to process vast amounts of visual data efficiently and accurately. Among the various deep learning-based detection algorithms, You Only Look Once (YOLO) has established itself as a cornerstone of real-time object detection due to its unique ability to combine high accuracy with exceptional processing speed. Its successive versions have introduced significant architectural enhancements, innovative training strategies, and attention mechanisms, making YOLO a preferred choice in mission-critical applications such as autonomous driving, surveillance, and robotics. In this study, YOLOv11 algorithm is applied to the KITTI dataset, a well-known benchmark dataset for computer vision tasks in autonomous driving. This research evaluates the capability and efficiency of enhancing real-time object detection within the autonomous driving domain. A comparison also is made between our work and other studies that applied different algorithms using the same dataset to evaluate the efficiency of YOLOv11. Their strengths and weaknesses are evaluated using parameters such as precision, recall, F-measure and computation time. The results show that YOLOv11 demonstrated robust performance in detecting the majority of road objects. The model achieved an overall precision of 91.7%, recall of 89.5%, and F-measure of 90.62% across all classes.

title: Digital Dice Design Using Pseudo Random Number Generator
authors: Tee Hui Teo, Maoyang Xiang, Qianrui Lin, Michael Kee Hian Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: The primary objective of this innovative project is to develop a digital dice that can display dice numbers in real-time. This digital dice operates by utilizing a pseudo-random number generator (PRNG) that employs the XORshift algorithm. This algorithm is coded explicitly in Verilog Hardware Description Language (HDL) and is integrated into a field-programmable gate array (FPGA). The digital dice itself comprises various components such as a tilt sensor, display screen, power management circuit, and a rechargeable battery, all neatly enclosed within a 3D-printed dice casing. When interacting with this digital dice, users can initiate the generation of a random number by simply shaking the device. This action triggers the tilt sensor within the dice, which in turn generates a seed for the PRNG to produce a random number. The numbers displayed by this digital die range from 1 to 100, effectively simulating the various sides of a traditional dice. This comprehensive kit, aptly named SUTDicey, showcases a perfect blend of cutting-edge technology and practical application in the realm of gaming and probability.

title: Accent Classification in Industrial Voice-Controlled IoT Systems Using i-Vector Framework
authors: Saida Nazarova, Dhanananth R, Arasuraja Ganesan, Garifullina Alsu Robert Kizi, R. Udayakumar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Accent classification in industrial voice-controlled IoT systems is essential for ensuring accurate speech recognition and safe operation in multilingual industrial environments. With the rise of voice-activated machinery, recognizing diverse accents of operators has become critical for improving command interpretation and operational efficiency. Existing accent classification methods often rely solely on conventional i-vector frameworks or basic acoustic features, which struggle to maintain accuracy in noisy industrial settings and under varying phonetic patterns. To address these limitations, this study proposes an Accent-Adaptive Deep i-Vector Fusion with Convolutional Bottleneck Features (CABi-Vector) framework. The method first extracts MFCC or logmel spectrograms from speech signals and passes them through a convolutional neural network to obtain deep bottleneck features capturing fine-grained phonetic-acoustic patterns. These embeddings are fused with traditional i-vectors to form accent-adaptive representations, which are then classified using a lightweight neural network optimized for real-time industrial deployment. The proposed CAB-iVector framework enhances the robustness of accent recognition in challenging industrial environments and allows voice-controlled IoT systems to dynamically adapt to operator accents. Experimental results demonstrate improved classification accuracy, reduced misinterpretation of commands, and increased operational safety and efficiency compared to conventional methods.

title: Low Power Key Insertion Technique Using FinFET for Secure Gate Level Design
authors: B. Menaka, D. Rama Prabha
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Current era aims at low-power, high-speed nano devices with security concerns. The fundamental components of digital circuits are logic gates that convert binary inputs into binary outputs by performing simple logical operations. In digital computing and circuit design, logic gates AND, OR, NOT are significant, to build combinational and sequential circuits that satisfy specific logic principles. This paper concentrates on speed and security concerns in logic gates. When there is a change from micro to nano devices, a trade-off exists between speed and power. Logic locking is emerging as a powerful strategy for safeguarding integrated circuits (ICs) against intellectual property (IP) piracy, overproduction, and hardware Trojan threats. This work emphasizes high speed with satisfactory power dissipation while addressing security issues. Security is implemented using the logic encryption technique, Input-Dependent Key-Based Logic Locking (IDKLL). Unlike traditional methods that rely on a single key sequence, the suggested IDKLL method employs several key sequences to lock and release the functionality across different input combinations, thereby fully mitigating attacks. Based on this concept, Gate Lock, a lightweight gate-level logic locking method, is introduced to replace standard CMOS gates with IDKLL-based FinFET counterparts. Logic structures with keys are implemented using FinFET and simulated using Cadence Virtuoso 6.1 in 20nm and 16nm nodes. The experimental findings indicate that the power and energy consumption of the XNOR gate has decreased by 27.57 % and 32.6 %, respectively, while the delay of the NOR gate has been reduced by 28.9 % at 16 nm. The results confirm the effectiveness of FinFETs in achieving power-delay trade-offs while being secure and reliable for lower nanometres.

title: Attendance Monitoring System Using Image Processing and Deep Learning
authors: Nithin S, Nitish R, Abhijith P, Ganesan M
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The increasing incidence of the use of smartphones in classes has been greatly affecting students' concentration and interfering with learning environments. This paper proposes an intelligent monitoring system capable of computer vision. The solution employs facial recognition for real-time attendance tracking and for detecting inappropriate behaviours such as unauthorized use of mobile devices and indications of student inattention. When these behaviours are detected, the system immediately alerts educators with visual evidence. Securely operating on institutional networks with strong privacy protections, this system integrates behaviour analysis with open reporting. Our solution illustrates how technology can be implemented in a thoughtful way to benefit classroom environments by minimizing digital distraction and promoting effective learning

title: Agentic AI: A New Paradigm for Cyber–Physical Systems Cybersecurity
authors: Georgios Xenos, Dimitrios Serpanos
publish: Computer
abstract: Agentic artificial intelligence and advancements in large language models are transforming cyber–physical systems security into a proactive and adaptive paradigm, where intelligent agents autonomously detect, analyze and respond to cyber threats in real time.

title: Hybrid Clustering Algorithms for Skill Profiling in Microgrid and Distributed Energy Resources Education
authors: Nilufar Tursunova, Rustambek Karimov, Ulugbek Eshkuvvatov, Shuxratjon Ismoiljonov, Akram Sokhibov, Iroda Rasulova
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Hybrid clustering algorithms have emerged as powerful tools for addressing the complexity of skill profiling in technical education, particularly in fields such as microgrids and distributed energy resources (DERs), where interdisciplinary knowledge and hands-on expertise are critical for workforce readiness. Traditional training approaches often fail to capture the multi-dimensional nature of students' competencies, leading to skill gaps in system operation, control, and integration of renewable technologies. The problem lies in accurately mapping students' heterogeneous learning patterns and technical proficiency to craft adaptive learning trajectories that ensure comprehensive understanding of both theoretical and practical aspects. To overcome the issues, the paper propose a Hybrid Clustering for Skill Profiling (HCSP) framework that integrates <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-means for fast partitioning with hierarchical agglomerative clustering (HAC) for structural refinement, leveraging their complementary strengths to achieve both scalability and fine-grained grouping. The HCSP algorithm incorporates domain-specific performance indicators such as control system simulations, energy management case studies, and laboratory-based DER integration tasks. Experimental results on a dataset of microgrid-focused training programs demonstrated that HCSP significantly outperforms singlemodel clustering in terms of cluster cohesion, interpretability, and alignment with expert evaluations, achieving a 15% improvement in normalized mutual information and better mapping of learner trajectories. The findings indicate that adaptive curricula generated through HCSP can more effectively identify high-potential learners, guide intervention for underperformers, and promote collaborative learning in team-based projects. In conclusion, HCSP provides an intelligent and scalable methodology for deriving actionable skill profiles to enhance education in microgrid and DER domains, thereby supporting workforce transformation in the clean energy transition.

title: Use of the cuckoo search algorithm to enhance the detection of kidney tumours
authors: Priyanga Subbiah, Krishnaraj N, Amit Kumar Tyagi
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Detecting kidney tumours as quickly and correctly as viable is important for efficient remedy and a fast diagnosis. This article offers a singular manner to enhancing kidney tumour diagnostics the use of deep studying techniques and the Cuckoo Search Algorithm (CSA). In order to increase the detection accuracy and computational efficiency, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are skilled the use of the CSA to optimise their feature selection and hyperparameters. Some species of cuckoo get their optimisation strategy from their brood parasitism. Beginning with medical image preprocessing to boom fine and decrease noise is the initial phase of the proposed strategy. The next step is to extract features from the information the use of CNNs if it is want to stumble on sizable symptoms of kidney tumours. Improved overall performance is the end result of the CSA's paintings in optimising the CNN's hyperparameters and deciding on the maximum vital features. Experiments conducted on a publicly available dataset of kidney tumours display sizable upgrades in segmentation accuracy, recall, precision, and F1-rating compared to the traditional strategies. An extremely good device for medical experts, the CSA-optimized model can reliably and constantly come across and segment kidney tumours. In order to address complex scientific imaging issues, this take a look at results display that bio-inspired optimisation algorithms mixed with contemporary deep studying techniques are possible. More unique prognosis and better fitness consequences for sufferers might follow.

title: e-Complaint Management System for Women Harassment Using Block Chain Technology
authors: G. Hemanth Kumar, S Teja Surendra, K. Gayathri, D. Umanandhini, G. Janaki
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: The growing concern of harassment of women calls for a safe and transparent complaint management system. This study proposes a blockchain-based electronic complaints management system to ensure anonymous and untraceable reporting. Using blockchain technology, the system provides a decentralised and immutable platform for women to register their complaints, thereby facilitating swift action and justice Designed entirely to combat harassment, the electronic complaint system has a normal interface that allows victims to report incidents anonymously, in accordance with regulations GDPR [General Data Protection Regulation]. By creating a secure backend, the system ensures Using real-time tracking, blockchain and web technologies, the system ensures quick responses, prioritises user privacy and improves efficiency. Compared favourably with existing systems in terms of efficiency, processing time and user satisfaction, the electronic complaints system sets a new standard for managing harassment issues, increasing trust and credibility.

title: Numerical Modeling and Efficiency Enhancement for CdTe/CdS Thin-Film Photovoltaic Cell
authors: Risabh Paul, Sathya Pichandi, Tuhina Bhuniya, Abesh Bhattacharya
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Thin-film photovoltaic cells utilizing Cadmium Telluride (CdTe)/Cadmium sulphide (CdS) are a potential technology for achieving high-efficiency, cost-effective, and sustainable photovoltaic energy solutions. This paper focuses on optimizing CdTe/CdS thin-film photovoltaic cell to maximize power conversion efficiency. The study utilizing the SCAPS-1D (Solar Cell Capacitance Simulator in One Dimension) strategically analyzes the effectiveness of material properties, layer thickness, doping concentrations, and interfacial characteristics on device performance. A careful adjustment of these factors is required to improve the efficiency of CdTe-based photovoltaic cells. The findings show that the integration of transparent conducting oxides (TCOs) like <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SnO}_{2}$</tex> enriches light absorption and charge transport, helping to achieve better cell performance. The optimized device parameters resulted in an open circuit voltage of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2 8 9 7} \mathbf{V}$</tex>, current density of 25.9551 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mA} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>, Fill Factor of 89.3277 %, and power conversion efficiency of 29.9012 %.

title: Load Aggregator Operation Optimization Taking Into Account the Uncertainty of Users' Flexible Resources
authors: Hongjuan Zheng, Yufeng Zhang, Mengyang Yao, Jie Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: With the development of flexible loads, broad energy storage resources such as temperature-controlled loads and electric vehicles have become key to adjustable demand. This paper focuses on its uncertainty and constructs a load aggregation and operation optimization model to maximize the benefits of aggregators. Establish multi-type flexible load aggregation models: Electric vehicles adopt virtual battery aggregation models to solve the problem of decentralized management; The temperature-controlled load is based on the thermodynamic equivalent model and the law of large numbers to construct an approximate aggregation model, reducing the computational load. At the same time, establish incentive and price demand-side resource aggregation models. On this basis, an intraday scheduling optimization model is constructed. With a 24-hour cycle, it integrates the cost of conventional units and the revenue on the demand side, incorporates power balance, unit operation, and flexible resource constraints, etc., to provide theoretical support for the efficient operation of aggregators with uncertain flexible resources.

title: Artificial Intelligence Applications in Battery Management Systems for Electric Vehicles
authors: Hany S. E. Mansour, Leila A. M. Saad, M. Abdel-Aziz, Eyad S. Oda, Salah A. Abdelmaksud
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: This study reviews AI techniques for predictive state assessment of lithium-ion (SoH) batteries, focusing on feedforward neural networks (FFNN), Gaussian process regression (GPR), and recurrent neural networks (GRU). Using the NASA Randomized Battery Usage dataset under varying conditions (temperature fluctuations and driving patterns), a comparative analysis was conducted. Results show that GPR enables very fast inference but struggles with large datasets, while GRU requires longer training yet better scales and captures sequential patterns effectively. With larger datasets and proper hyperparameter tuning, GPR performance can be further enhanced. Overall, GPR outperforms GRU in terms of RMSE, MSE, and MAE, highlighting the strengths and tradeoffs of current AI-based SoH prediction models in accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Identification Method for Multiple Power Quality Disturbances
authors: Wentong Chen, Jia'nan Yu, Hao Wu, Junhan Guo, Yixiang Zhang, Huifang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: As a large number of new energy sources and nonlinear loads are connected to the power grid, the power quality disturbances become more and more complex and frequent. Therefore, this paper proposes a power quality disturbance identification method based on Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN). This method builds a power quality identification model based on TCN, uses the dilated layer to extract the characteristics of disturbance signals, obtains the waveform disturbance probability distribution of sampling points, and completes the category identification of normal disturbance signals through the classification results of sampling points. In addition, the model applied an OOD detection module, distinguishing abnormal disturbances which significantly enhance the practical reliability. The experimental results show that the average classification F1 value of model signal at 30 dB noise level of the proposed method is as high as 97.81%.

title: Multi-Criteria Decision Making for Optimal and Sustainable Silver Nanocatalysts in Environmental Remediation
authors: Badma Priya Dhananjayan, Muthunandhini Rajadurai, Palanivel Kaliyaperumal
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Nanomaterials have significant p roperties s uch as catalyst, photocatalyst which are widely used in numerous environmental applications. Even though, now the synthesis of nanoparticles have been carried out by ecofriendly method, characterization procedure needs substantial costs and predicting their catalytic activities required series of trials and experiments has a major drawback towards sustainable impact to the environment. To address this challenge, Multi-Criteria Decision-Making (MCDM) techniques have been employed in this research to identify the most effective silver nanocatalyst (AgNp) by evaluating a combination of physicochemical characteristics and catalytic performance across twelve distinct AgNps. Specifically, the TOPSIS, MARCOS, and COCOSO methods were applied to establish a comprehensive ranking of the nanoparticles (Nps), minimizing the need for extensive experimental trials related to characterization and catalytic testing on organic contaminants. This strategy promotes environmental sustainability while optimizing the selection process, ultimately conserving time, cost, and energy.

title: Retinal Disease Prediction Model Using Optimized Deep Learning Architecture for Accurate Detection of Retinitis Pigmentosa in Medical Imaging
authors: Divya R, Swathi Mogilisetty, Shamil S U, D Prema
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a hereditary disorder impacting the retina condition that gradually leads to vision deterioration, typically beginning with difficulty seeing at night and potentially resulting in significant vision loss. Early detection of RP is essential, but traditional methods like ERG, OCT, and genetic testing require costly equipment and skilled professionals, limiting accessibility especially in resource-limited settings. This study explores a deep learning based for automated Rp detection using retinal fundus images. The proposed system utilizes MobileNetV2, a lightweight neural network, trained on a dataset of healthy and Retinitis Pigmentosa-affected retinal images. Preprocessing steps are including resizing, normalization, and augmentation that enhances the model robustness. A user- friendly web interface allows clinicians to upload images and receive quick diagnostic results, predicted intensity of the disease. Results showed high 97% of accuracy, 98% of training and 96% of validation, demonstrating strong generalization. The model achieved 96.7% precision and 97.8% recall, minimizing misdiagnoses. Additionally, the system generates PDF reports for clinical documentation.

title: Depression Detection in Speech Using Generative Models
authors: Lojaine Amr Elghandour, Adel Eltoweiry, Mohammed A.-M. Salem, Nada Sharaf
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Depression is a widespread yet often undiagnosed mental health issue due to the limitations of traditional depression detection methods. Speech-based depression detection offers a non-invasive alternative, but its development is affected by data scarcity, class imbalance, and privacy concerns. This paper investigates synthetic data augmentation to improve depression detection from speech. In Experiment 1, real speech is segmented, and traditional features like MFCC, ZCR, and Spectral Centroid are extracted to train classical machine learning models (SVM, RF, LR). In Experiment 2, deep audio embeddings from wav2vec 2.0 are summarized and used with the same classifiers in addition to XGBoost. Synthetic speech is introduced to balance the dataset, and its quality is assessed using Frechet Audio Distance (FAD). <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${}^{\prime}$</tex> Results show that synthetic data can improve model performance when carefully integrated. SVM achieved the best performance in Experiment 1, with 0.661 accuracy and a macro F1-score of 0.617. While synthetic data isn't a replacement for real data, it presents a practical and scalable solution for reducing data scarcity, especially in domains where privacy is a concern, like the medical domain.

title: Experimental Analysis of Waste Cooking Oil in Transformer Insulation
authors: A. Cianna, S. Sumathi, M. Ponmathy, T. Jarin, B. Deepanraj, Gaydaa Al Zohbi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The increasing global emphasis on environmental sustainability has intensified the demand for biodegradable and eco-friendly alternatives to traditional mineral-based transformer insulating oils. Vegetable oils, because of their favourable dielectric characteristics, high thermal stability, and environmental compatibility, have gained considerable attention. This study investigates waste cooking oil (WCO) as a cost-effective, low-viscosity insulating fluid for transformers. The WCO was processed via a potassium hydroxide (KOH)-catalyzed transesterification reaction, and its physical, chemical, and electrical properties that includes breakdown voltage (BDV) and dissipation factor—were evaluated in accordance with standard test procedures. The treated WCO exhibited significantly reduced viscosity and a BDV approximately 50% larger than the IEEE standard for new natural ester fluids. These results demonstrate that waste cooking oil methyl ester (WCOME) is a technically feasible and environmentally sustainable candidate for transformer insulation applications.

title: Pervasive Computing X Software Engineering: Perspectives to ICSE 2024
authors: Ella Peltonen
publish: IEEE Pervasive Computing
abstract: Let us call it refreshing to look behind one’s comfort zone and consider another subfield within computer science. The IEEE/ACM International Conference on Software Engineering is an influential conference. In this column, I report on recent software engineering work related to pervasive computing.

title: Implementation of Recursive and Iterative Moving Average Filter for ECG Data in Fixed and Floating Representation
authors: Susithra N, Nidhiyashree V K, Sivatharini R, Priyanka P, Jasmitaa G
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Moving Average Filters are used for digital signal processing applications, such as smoothing ECG signals by minimizing high-frequency noise. This work investigates the design and implementation of Moving Average Filters (MAFs) based on Verilog HDL in iterative and recursive methods with fixed-point and floating-point arithmetic. The research compares the four different implementations—fixed-point iterative, fixed-point recursive, floating-point iterative, and floating-point recursive—tested in terms of performance such as resource usage, timing latency, power dissipation, and numerical precision. In the study, real-life ECG records obtained from the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia database are used to emulate the filter performance. Results prove that fixed-point recursive filters achieve the optimal trade-off between accuracy, stability, and hardware efficiency and therefore are suitable for real-time and low-power embedded applications. On the other hand, floating-point implementations provide increased dynamic range but in exchange for increased resource usage and sensitivity to rounding errors. This study aids in choosing the filter design for performance-limited signal processing applications.

title: AI-Based Demand Forecasting System for Supply Chain Optimization
authors: GV Radhakrishnan, Pranav Pandurang Gaikwad, Vivek Pimplapure, Irshadullah Asim Mohammed, Ashok Dattatraya Todmal, Sri Harsha Vardhan Sanne
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Successful demand forecasting is a key sector in boosting the efficiency and robustness of contemporary supply chains. This paper introduces an AI-based demand forecasting system that has been implemented to streamline supply chain operations by applying sophisticated machine learning methods and data analytics. The system incorporates sales history, current market sentiment, and external events such as weather and economic conditions to make highly accurate demand forecasts. In contrast to traditional forecasting methods, which often rely on linear models and data, the AI method can accommodate complex, non-linear supply chain patterns. The architecture is a hybrid deep learning model that utilizes Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and ensemble learning methods to address the temporal dependency and heterogeneity of the data. Experimental testing on actual datasets from real business firms in the manufacturing and retail industries demonstrates improved prediction accuracy to a considerable extent, reducing errors by as much as 25% compared to statistical models. Additionally, the system's predictive forecasts enable companies to minimize inventory expenses, enhance order fulfillment rates, and anticipate supply-demand imbalances, allowing them to respond accordingly. The study also highlights the scalability and flexibility of the proposed system across various supply chain functions, noting its ability to facilitate strategic decision-making. By incorporating AIbased forecasting into supply chain operations, organizations can achieve greater operational efficiency, reduce waste, and enhance customer satisfaction. The findings confirm the system's ability to serve as an effective solution for handling uncertainty in the modern business world.

title: Sparse Mixture-of-Experts LLMs for Efficient ICD Code Prediction in Clinical Outcome Modeling
authors: Naad Dantale, Priyansh Goel, Shikha Mundra, Ankit Mundra, Gaurav Aggarwal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The Mixture of Experts (MoE) architectures serve as an efficient computational solution compared to traditional dense large language models (LLMs) for clinical outcome prediction . The research project creates and tests MoE-based LLMs with parameter sizes between 2 and 3 billion to predict patient outcomes from MIMIC-IV multimodal database data . The proposed MoE models use sparse activation to select only a portion of experts for each input while distributing computational power according to input modality and feature relevance. The proposed models will surpass dense LLMs (with 7 billion+ parameters) in forecasting patient deterioration and mortality risk and hospital stay duration by activating only 40-50% of total parameters. Our method uses hierarchical attention mechanisms with cross-modal fusion techniques to merge structured data (ICU vitals, lab results) and unstructured data (radiology reports, clinical notes) for strong temporal and contextual understanding. Model performance is benchmarked against state-of-the-art methods using evaluation metrics such as AUROC, AUPRC, and calibration scores. The study evaluates MoE efficiency for real-time clinical inference through performance metrics that include latency and memory footprint and deployment feasibility in limited resource settings. Our research uses MIMIC-IV heterogeneity to validate MoE architectures as scalable solutions for accurate yet low-compute clinical AI applications.

title: Improved Accuracy CMOS Sigmoidal Function Synthesizers
authors: Cosmin Radu Popa
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: This paper presents original CMOS implementations of two function synthesizers designed to generate unipolar and bipolar sigmoidal mathematical functions, which are widely applicable in analog signal processing. The design methodology is based on the use of two higher-order approximation functions, selected for their accuracy and suitability for CMOS integration. These functions are implemented using newly proposed fundamental computational building blocks: squaring and multiplier/divider circuits. The synthesizers operate in current mode, enabling low-voltage functionality with a minimum supply voltage of 0.7 V. Moreover, the architectures support extremely low bias currents, resulting in ultra-low power consumption- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex> for the unipolar synthesizer and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.26 \mu ~\mathrm{W}$</tex> for the bipolar version. The silicon area requirements are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \mu ~\mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \mu ~\mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>, respectively. SPICE simulations based on the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> TSMC CMOS process confirm the theoretical predictions, validating both the functionality and the energy efficiency of the proposed designs.

title: An Enhanced Explainable Machine Learning Approach for Livestock Diseases Classification Using Neutrosophic Set-Based Feature Selection
authors: Aya Adel, Eman Ahmed, Nour Eldeen Khalifa
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Machine Learning algorithms have demonstrated considerable potential in handling complicated challenges in livestock health, such as disease prediction, data-based treatment, and recognizing host-pathogen interactions. This study proposes an enhanced machine learning approach for classifying livestock diseases using symptom data. The approach combines a Neutrosophic Set-based Feature Selection to recognize the most valuable features, connected with a Random Forest classifier to avoid overfitting and guarantee robust performance. To further improve the explanation of the model, explainable AI algorithms such as SHAP and LIME are utilized to supply insights into model classifications. The proposed model reached 98% accuracy, 98.5% recall, 98% precision, and an F 1 -score of 98.25 % on the test samples of the dataset. Comparative outcomes present the superiority of our model over traditional models, which may reach ideal scores but are prone to overfitting. Our proposed Neutrosophic-Set-Based Feature Selection Random-Forest model provides a credible, explainable, and generalizable tool for livestock disease diagnosis based on symptom data for cattle.

title: Toxicity Analysis of Instagram Reels and Comments using Machine Learning
authors: Sneh Prabha, Aditya Yadav, Aman Yadav, Akash Kumar, Manu Tyagi
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Toxic content on social media is a growing problem. It can harm users' mental health and their overall experience online. In this research, we present a new way to detect those content by looking at both the video transcripts of Instagram Reels and the comments from users. The audio from the reels is first converted into text. Then, we check this text for toxic content. We do the same with user comments and compare the two results. To do this, we used several machine learning algorithms, such as LR, KNN, Random Forest, Bert and Decision Tree. Surprisingly, Logistic Regression outperformed the others in accurately classifying toxic content. This highlights its reliability and effectiveness for these tasks. Our work provides a new way to assess toxicity in content creation and user interaction. The goal is to help make online platforms safer and more respectful for everyone through smarter and more proactive content moderation.
