title: Reliability Test Optimization of Mixed-Signal ICs Using Few-Shot Characterization and CNN-LSSVM Enhanced Performance Drift Estimation
authors: Kewei Deng, Houjun Wang, Zhou Shu, Pu Pu, Enxiao Liu, Zhenyu Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Mixed-signal integrated circuits (ICs) are critical in various electronic systems, requiring precise and cost-effective testing to ensure their functionality under real-world conditions. A significant challenge lies in the post-silicon validation phase, where low-temperature performance screening is a complex, time-consuming, and expensive process. Traditional methods require dedicated, extensive testing at cryogenic temperatures, which substantially increases overall time-to-market and manufacturing costs. This article addresses this critical industry need by proposing an artificial intelligence framework to predict the low-temperature performance of mixed-signal ICs using the efficient low-cost few-shot characterization results from normal- and high-temperature. A convolutional neural network and least squares support vector machine (CNN-LSSVM) model helps to improve the estimation accuracy of full-temperature range performance drift. The CNN is leveraged for automated feature extraction from the high-dimensional test data, while the LSSVM provides a robust regression engine for accurate performance prediction in highly imbalanced dataset. The efficacy of the proposed framework is validated on 2102 and 4634 sets of measured results from two types of mixed-signal chips. The results demonstrate that it achieves an accuracy of 98.86% and 99.48%, allowing for the reliable pruning of redundant low-temperature test steps. This study provides a highly efficient, supervised learning method that significantly reduces test time and cost for the reliability screening of mixed-signal chips.

title: Intelligent Semantic Communication Scheme Integrating ISAC for Low-Altitude Intelligent Networks
authors: Shuai Liu, Helin Yang, Wancheng Xie, Mengting Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Semantic communication technology conserves spectrum resources, while unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-mounted reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS), a key component of the low-altitude intelligent networks, enhance communication flexibility. Combining these technologies improves wireless performance. However, due to the openness of wireless channels, high-quality communication links are vulnerable to eavesdropping, which compromises system security. Additionally, maritime communication faces challenges such as dynamic channel variations, and high-altitude UAVs struggle to locate sea surface users and eavesdroppers. To address these issues, we propose a secure UAV-RIS-assisted communication scheme that integrates semantic communication, and integrated sensing and communications (ISAC). This scheme maximizes the secrecy semantic rate, reduces communication and computation energy consumption, and ensures constraints on sensing spectral efficiency and semantic accuracy. We jointly optimize UAV-RIS trajectories, RIS phase shifts, spectrum allocation, and the average number of semantic symbols to enhance security under eavesdropping attacks. We propose an approach that integrates semantic communication, the multi-agent softmax deep double deterministic policy gradient, and the multi-agent dueling deep Q-network (S-MA-SD5), effectively supports UAV-RIS-assisted communication in maritime environments. Performance evaluations reveal that the proposed method exceeds existing methods, achieving higher security semantic rates and lower energy consumption, thereby significantly enhancing security and efficiency in the low-altitude intelligent maritime networks.

title: Fano-resonant Asymmetric U-type Metasurfaces Integrating Graphene for Trace Biosensing at THz Frequencies
authors: Tongling Wang, Qiyu Ying, Xiangyuan Meng, Yilong Xin, Ziqi Li, Mingyao Wang, Changshun Wu, Li Wang, Maosheng Yang, Xiuwei Yang, Wenjing Zheng, Maojing Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: Terahertz (THz) waves located in an important electromagnetic frequency band have unique characteristics and great application prospects in rapid, non-destructive, and marker-free biomedical detection. Benefiting from Fano resonance has the advantages of high local field enhancement and low loss, we propose a graphene-integrated asymmetric U-type split-ring (Gr-AUSR) Fano resonance metasurfaces THz biosensor. Experimental results show that the Fano resonance intensity of the proposed Gr-AUSR sensor can be altered by the Fermi level shift of chemical vapor deposition (CVD) graphene under slight external stimuli, achieving a minimum midkine (MK) detection limit of 125 pg/ml. Moreover, we extract the maximum wavelet coefficient from the two-dimensional wavelet time-frequency diagram, combining with the Fano resonance amplitude and effective transmission area to construct a multiscale pyramid-shaped model, where its volumes intuitively correspond to different MK concentrations. This work paves the way toward designing and developing of ultra-sensitive biosensors for picogram-levels biological detection at THz frequencies.

title: SCAL-Net: A Scalable and Adaptive Hierarchical Network Framework for Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Swarms
authors: Seunggyu Kim, Hyosong Lee, Sunghyun Park, Junho Kim, Byoungsun Ahn, Taeho Im
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The growing importance of ocean exploration has established Autonomous UnderwaterVehicle (AUV) swarm operations as a key technology. However, underwater operations face significant challenges due to inherent communication constraints and dynamic mission requirements. Current approaches often lack scalable and adaptive network frameworks capable of responding flexibly to complex mission transitions, such as shifting from wide-area surveying to high-precision inspection. To address these limitations, this paper proposes SCAL-Net, a Scalable and Adaptive Layered Network framework for AUVs. SCAL-Net adopts a three-tier clustering architecture with a Gateway (GW), Cluster Heads (CHs), and Cluster Members (CMs). Operating on this architecture, an adaptive Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA) protocol dynamically adjusts to changing mission phases through four distinct operational modes: Initialization, Search, Deep Search, and Error. Notably, the Deep Search Mode incorporates a novel mechanism that maximizes data throughput by adaptively reallocating idle communication resources from inactive clusters to an active one. Comprehensive evaluations using OMNeT++ demonstrate that SCAL-Net achieves predictable linear scalability with an increasing number of clusters. Furthermore, comparative analysis confirms that the proposed dynamic resource reallocation significantly enhances data throughput compared to conventional static TDMA baselines, while intelligent energy distribution extends the swarm’s operational lifetime. This work establishes a robust foundation for the autonomous and efficient execution of AUV swarm missions in complex marine environments.

title: Geolocation of Vacant Radio-Frequency Bands for Dynamic Spectrum Access via Database-Driven Non-Cooperative IoT Spectrum Sensors
authors: Alfredo Jesús Arbolaez Fundora, Luiz Gustavo Barros Guedes, Dayan Adionel Guimarães
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Existing approaches to overlay dynamic spectrum access (DSA) typically enable spectrum sharing only when the primary transmitter is inactive. However, accurately geolocating vacant bands is essential for supporting spectrum reuse even when the primary transmitter remains active. This study proposes and validates a geolocation strategy based on non-cooperative spectrum sensing within a database-driven Internet-of-Things framework. The method employs scattered sensors that perform individual detections, whose binary decisions are mapped into space through Voronoi partitioning and refined using an adaptive spatial interpolation logic. Simulation results demonstrate that the approach achieves a high spectrum-hole geolocation detection rate with low variance. Compared to cooperative spectrum sensing, the proposed strategy offers superior spatial fidelity while significantly reducing communication overhead, establishing itself as a simpler and more scalable solution for cognitive radio networks.

title: Polarization-Insensitive, Achromatic Metasurface Design for Holographic Imaging Via Cascaded Transmission Line Model
authors: Xinbo Chen, Mingyong Zhuang, Weiwen Li, Jianyang Zhou, Jianliang Zhuo, Zixuan Yang, Yanhui Liu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: An efficient approach is proposed for designing achromatic metasurfaces with broadband and polarization-free properties, suitable for application in holographic imaging. By utilizing the cascaded transmission line model, the reflectivity of over 100,000 meta-atoms can be efficiently computed within just 1.32 days. Guided by the computed phase maps, achromatic metasurfaces are designed by selecting meta-atoms with appropriate phase gradients, thereby enabling holographic imaging under both normal and 25<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula> deflected reflection conditions. Finally, the holographic metasurface capable of achieving achromatic reflection with Y-shaped imaging is fabricated. Measurement results indicate that the metasurface achieves achromatic reflection from 8 to 15GHz (relative bandwidth of 60.87%), with the imaging efficiency exceeding 58.3%, demonstrating high performance for achromatic holographic applications. This work not only accelerates the development of multilayer stacked metasurfaces, but also highlights the extensive applications of achromatic metasurfaces in holographic imaging.

title: Cross-Scene Open-Set Hyperspectral Image Classification via Joint Distribution Matching and Unknown Class Uncertainty Suppression
authors: Kai Deng, Mengying Xie, Sentao Chen, Jiayuan Xie, Jiaxin Li, Chao Chen, Xiaowei Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Cross-scene hyperspectral image (HSI) classification plays a vital role in a variety of applications, including agricultural monitoring, military reconnaissance, and urban planning. Due to the nonlinear nature of land-cover characteristics, the diversity of scenes, and the distribution shifts caused by variations in acquisition conditions or sensors, deep HSI open-set domain adaptation (OSDA) has emerged as a key approach to tackling cross-scene HSI classification. Existing methods assume identical joint distributions between training and test data. However, this rigorous assumption renders them ineffective in real-world scenes when encountering varied sensors, changed imaging conditions, different spatial resolution in HSI imaging, e.g., water vapor bands at 1.36-1.39 μm. To address this, we propose a more generalizable deep HSI OSDA method JDMUS based on Joint Distribution Matching and unknown class Uncertainty Suppression, for cross-scene HSI classification. Specifically, we employ χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-divergence to characterize the joint distribution discrepancy and propose a least-squares χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-divergence estimator without explicitly modeling the two joint distributions, yielding a quadratic problem with an analytical solution. Furthermore, we prove the methodology that the upper bound of the target error for neural network classification model is determined by the average source error, χ<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-divergence, and open-set risk difference. Based on this methodology, we design joint distribution matching and unknown class uncertainty suppression mechanisms, and thus construct the JDMUS algorithm with theoretical guarantees, in which weighted generative adversarial network with dynamic thresholding is used for feature extraction. Experiments on cross-scene HSI datasets demonstrate that our JDMUS outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Joint User Grouping and Power Allocation for Uplink NOMA-ISAC Systems
authors: Haofeng Liu, Emad Alsusa, Arafat Al-Dweik
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: This study considers non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) inspired integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems. In particular, it presents a novel approach that jointly optimizes power allocation (PA) and user grouping (UG) in the uplink of NOMA-based ISAC to achieve higher communication rate while meeting the required radar performance. The proposed optimization is a mixed-integer non-linear programming (MINLP) problem, which is a non-convex and non-deterministic polynomial time-hard. To solve the formulated problem, an outer approximation technique is employed to transform the original MINLP problem into a mixed-integer linear programming problem and a non-linear programming one. The performance of the optimized PA and UG approach is evaluated through extensive simulations, which examine the impact of the radar signal and the maximum power limit for each user equipment. Additionally, the performance of the radar system is assessed using the radar channel estimation and probability of detection. Compared to benchmark techniques, it is shown that the proposed scheme produces higher achievable communication sum rates while satisfying the performance requirements of the radar system.

title: EMF Aware Base Station Deployment and Network performance Estimation by Conditional Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Mohammed Mallik, Guillaume Villemaud
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: As 5G networks rapidly expand and 6G technologies emerge, characterized by dense deployments, millimeter-wave communications, and dynamic beamforming, the need for scalable simulation tools becomes increasingly critical. These tools must support efficient evaluation of key performance metrics such as coverage and radio-frequency electromagnetic field (RF-EMF) exposure, inform network design decisions, and ensure compliance with safety regulations. Moreover, base station (BS) placement is a crucial task in the network design, where satisfying coverage requirements is essential. To address these, based on our previous work, we first propose a conditional generative adversarial network (cGAN) that predicts location specific received signal strength (RSS), and EMF exposure simultaneously from the network topology, as images. As a network designing application, we propose a Deep Q Network (DQN) framework, using the trained cGAN, for optimal base station (BS) deployment in the network. Compared to conventional ray tracing simulations, the proposed cGAN reduces inference and deployment time from several hours to seconds (under 10 seconds) while achieving a prediction accuracy of approximately RMSE 7 dB. Unlike a standalone cGAN, which provides static performance maps, the proposed GAN-DQN framework enables sequential decision making under coverage and exposure constraints, learning effective deployment strategies that directly solve the BS placement problem. Thus making it well suited for real time design and adaptation in dynamic scenarios in order to satisfy predefined network specific heterogeneous performance goals.

title: MPROF: Multi-dimensional Preference-driven Resource Optimization Framework for Cloud-Edge-End Collaboration_supp1-3649656.pdf
authors: Qiang He
publish: N/A
abstract: In cloud-edge-end (CEE) collaboration, the resource optimization based on deep reinforcement learning have achieved significant performance improvements in time-slot systems. However, some studies only focus on computing delay and energy consumption in each time slot, ignoring the impact of task backlog queues on system performance. In addition, the delay-oriented optimization tends to offload a large number of tasks to servers, failing to fully utilize the computing resource of mobile devices. To address these issues, we propose the multi-dimensional preference-driven resource optimization framework (MPROF). This study includes several key points: 1) constructing a three-layer heterogeneous architecture that applying the collaboration among edges for CEE; 2) proposing the task backlog estimation mechanism, which mitigates the impact of previous unfinished tasks on the current time slot; 3) proposing the group relative direct-preference policy optimization (GRDPO) that incorporates the preference information for efficient task offloading, and combines it with mathematical programming for the system resource optimization. The simulation experiments are conducted across multiple typical scenarios. The results show that, the proposed framework outperforms existing mainstream methods in task offloading, system delay, task backlog, and energy consumption control, demonstrating certain practical application prospects.
