title: FPGA Implementation of Binary-Weighted Transformer for Prognostics and Health Management of Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors Using Current Sensors
authors: Soongyu Kang, Yongchul Jung, Sewoon Oh, Yunho Jung
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: In this letter, we propose a prognostics and health management (PHM) method for permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) in urban air mobility (UAM). The method uses a Transformer and three-phase current sensors. The short-time Fourier transform (STFT) is employed for current signals to capture fault-related information. The Transformer architecture effectively extracts both local and global features from time–frequency representations, enabling high classification performance. However, its high computational cost and large model size hinder deployment in practical industrial applications. To address this challenge, we designed a lightweight binary-weighted Transformer (BWT) for PMSM PHM, reducing the model size to 5.5% of the baseline. The proposed BWT achieves 99.81% classification accuracy across four classes. We also developed a hardware accelerator for matrix multiplication (MM)—the most time-consuming operation in BWT—and implemented it on a field-programmable gate array (FPGA). The proposed SW/HW co-design achieved an 85.55× speedup over the software-only implementation on the ARM microprocessor unit (MPU).

title: FocusPatch AD: Few-Shot Multi-Class Anomaly Detection with Unified Keywords Patch Prompts_supp1-3646861.pdf
authors: Jingyu Gong
publish: N/A
abstract: Industrial few-shot anomaly detection (FSAD) requires identifying various abnormal states by leveraging as few normal samples as possible (abnormal samples are unavailable during training). However, current methods often require training a separate model for each category, leading to increased computation and storage overhead. Thus, designing a unified anomaly detection model that supports multiple categories remains a challenging task, as such a model must recognize anomalous patterns across diverse objects and domains. To tackle these challenges, this paper introduces FocusPatch AD, a unified anomaly detection framework based on vision-language models, achieving anomaly detection under few-shot multi-class settings. FocusPatch AD links anomaly state keywords to highly relevant discrete local regions within the image, guiding the model to focus on cross-category anomalies while filtering out background interference. This approach mitigates the false detection issues caused by global semantic alignment in vision-language models. We evaluate the proposed method on the MVTec, VisA, and Real-IAD datasets, comparing them against several prevailing anomaly detection methods. In both image-level and pixel-level anomaly detection tasks, FocusPatch AD achieves significant gains in classification and localization performance, demonstrating excellent generalization and adaptability.

title: Cross-modality Feature Aggregation for Cross-domain Point Cloud Representation Learning
authors: Guoqing Wang, Chao Ma, Xiaokang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Existing methods for learning 3D point cloud representation often use a single dataset-specific training and testing approach, leading to performance drops due to significant domain shifts between training and testing data. While recent crossdomain methods have made promising progress, the lack of inherent semantic information in point clouds makes models prone to overfitting specific datasets. As such, we introduce 3D-CFA, a simple yet effective cross-modality feature aggregation method for cross-domain 3D point cloud representation learning. 3D-CFA aggregates the geometry tokens with semantic tokens derived from multi-view images, which are projected from the point cloud, thus generating more transferable features for cross-domain 3D point cloud representation learning. Specifically, 3D-CFA consists of two main components: a cross-modality feature aggregation module and an elastic domain alignment module. The cross-modality feature aggregation module converts unordered points into multi-view images using the modality transformation module. Then, the geometry tokens and semantic tokens extracted from the geometry encoder and semantic encoder are fed into the cross-modal projector to get the transferable 3D tokens. A key insight of this design is that the semantic tokens can serve as a bridge between the 3D point cloud model and the 2D foundation model, greatly promoting the generalization of cross-domain models facing the severe domain shift. Finally, the elastic domain alignment module learns the hierarchical domain-invariant features of different training domains for either domain adaptation or domain generalization protocols. 3D-CFA finds a better way to transfer the knowledge of the 2D foundation model pre-trained at scale, meanwhile only introducing a few extra trainable parameters. Comprehensive experiments on several cross-domain point cloud benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method compared to the state-of-the-art methods.

title: Traffic Manipulation Via Beamforming Feedback Forgery in Practical Wi-Fi Systems
authors: Yinghui He, Mingming Xu, Xin Li, Jingzhi Hu, Zhe Chen, Fu Xiao, Jun Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: New Wi-Fi systems have leveraged beamforming to manage a significant portion of traffic for achieving high throughput and reliability. Unfortunately, this has amplified certain security risks since beamforming critically relies on the clear-text beamforming feedback information (BFI): though similar risks have been exposed using emulation platforms (e.g., USRP), they have never proven realistic till this day. In this paper, we propose BeamCraft, the first attack to manipulate traffic in commodity Wi-Fi systems; it differs significantly from existing attacks either staying only on emulation platforms with limited real-world applicability or jamming communications by brute force. The core idea of BeamCraft involves corrupting beamforming decisions by injecting crafted BFIs that feed an access point (AP) with erroneous information on channel states. To mount a covert yet purposeful attack, we develop i) a joint location and transmit power selection strategy to evade detection by victims and ii) a novel BFI forgery method to effectively manipulate AP's beamforming decisions. We implement BeamCraft using commodity Wi-Fi devices and perform extensive evaluations with it; the results reveal that BeamCraft effectively manipulates Wi- Fi traffic while maintaining a low exposure rate. Furthermore, we also introduce a defense strategy, namely BeamCrypt, that jointly leverages reciprocity and similarity of the channel within the coherence time to authenticate the legitimate user with low overhead. We implement it using WARP and evaluation results verify the effectiveness.

title: HARQ-IR Aided Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access for URLLC: Tradeoff Between Transmission Reliability and Data Freshness
authors: Fuchao He, Jintao Wang, Zheng Shi, Yaru Fu, Guanghua Yang, Shaodan Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Many emerging artificial intelligence-driven applications rely on the availability of large-scale, stable, and fresh sensing data, underscoring the Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communications (URLLC). This paper proposes to amalgamate Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) and Hybrid Automatic Repeat reQuest with Incremental Redundancy (HARQ-IR) to accommodate reliable and real-time wireless services. The outage probability and the Average Age of Information (AAoI) are used to evaluate the transmission reliability and data freshness for HARQ-IR-NOMA schemes. To reveal physical insights as well as ease system designs, the asymptotic outage probability in the high Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) regime is derived by developing a recursive dominant term approximation method. Moreover, the AAoI is deduced in terms of the outage probability by considering an M/G/1/1 queuing model. The asymptotic AAoI at high SNR is shown to be an increasing function of the diversity order-deficiency, which theoretically justifies the tradeoff between the transmission reliability and the data freshness. Furthermore, the AAoI is minimized by optimizing the transmission powers between users as well as HARQ rounds while maintaining the outage and total power constraints. The minimal AAoI is obtained by developing Geometric Programming (GP)-based and Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-based methods. Finally, the numerical results are presented for verification.

title: Evolution-Guided Q-Learning for Optimal Regulation of Unknown Continuous-Time Systems
authors: Ding Wang, Qinna Hu, Zeqiang Yuan, Ao Liu, Junfei Qiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In practical applications, it is challenging to obtain accurate system models, which limits the applicability of model-based control methods. To address this issue, an evolution-guided iterative Q-learning (EIQL) approach is developed in this paper to solve the optimal regulation problem of continuous-time (CT) systems. Incorporating the data-driven mechanism, the offline data-set is utilized for learning, eliminating dependence on the exact system model. Within the Q-learning structure, an actor-critic framework is employed to facilitate policy improvement and Q-function updating. Specifically, an improved particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is developed to mitigate gradient vanishing and overcome the premature convergence issue of standard PSO. Additionally, theoretical analyses are conducted to establish monotonicity and convergence of the designed Q-function. Finally, the constructed EIQL method is validated on real-world physical systems, demonstrating its effectiveness and advantages over conventional approaches.

title:
Review of Mist-CVD Technology for Ga
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Power and Optoelectronic Devices
authors: Yang-Chao Liu, Man Luo, Xin Qi, Yi Shen, Qing-Chun Zhang, Hong-Ping Ma
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: Gallium oxide $\left(\mathrm{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)$, an ultrawide bandgap (UWBG) semiconductor, has been widely recognized as a promising material for next-generation power and optoelectronic devices due to its wide bandgap ($4.6-4.9 \mathrm{eV}$), high breakdown electric field, and availability of large-area substrates. However, the practical commercialization of Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> devices requires epitaxial technologies capable of delivering high-quality layers at low cost and high efficiency. Mist chemical vapor deposition (Mist-CVD) has emerged as a promising alternative to address these limitations. Distinguished by its vacuum-free operation, simple process, low cost, and compatibility with large-area growth, Mist-CVD also provides precise control over doping concentration, film thickness, and crystalline quality. These advantages make it an attractive route for advancing both research and commercialization of Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-based devices. In power electronics, Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> grown by Mist-CVD has been successfully applied to Schottky barrier diodes (SBDs), Metal-Semiconductor Field Effect Transistors (MESFETs) and Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field Effect Transistors (MOSFETs), demonstrating competitive voltages and leakage currents. In optoelectronics, the intrinsic absorption edge of Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> at around 250 nm naturally enables solar-blind ultraviolet detection without the need for bandgap engineering. As a result, Mist-CVD-grown Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> layers are highly suitable for solar-blind photodetectors and deep-UV sensors, exhibiting high responsivity, low dark current, and excellent spectral selectivity. This review summarizes recent advances in the application of Mist-CVD for Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-based power and optoelectronic devices and discusses current challenges and future perspectives toward its industrial deployment.

title: CykVest: An NRF-enabled Vest with Accelerometer and GPS Sensors
authors: Riti Kushwaha, Gaurav Singal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The increasing number of accidents involving cyclists on the road is a major concern in the modern world. Poor lighting conditions during the night are one of the major reasons behind such accidents. This research paper presents a solution to this problem by developing a wearable vest that can be adjusted according to the convenience of the cyclist. The vest will contain indicator that can be turned on while taking turns. In addition to that, an accelerometer will be attached to the bike to detect a strong impulse of an accident. Whenever the magnitude of the impact is higher than a threshold value, it will send the location of the accident using the GPS module embedded in the vest. The proposed solution aims to enhance the safety of cyclist s on the road and reduce the number of accidents caused by poor lighting conditions. By the market there is no device at cheap rate to promote cycle fitness by telling the number of calories burnt by the distance travelled.

title: Optical Study of Dam Absorbing Devices Based on Micro LED
authors: Wei Wei, Chen Lei, Zou Jun, Song Jinde, Le Gang, Chen Zhizhong
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: In order to achieve ultra-thin, fast, and small volume lithography, a new type of multi structure device array based on Micro LED chips has been developed using Monte Carlo method and ray tracing method, which enables arbitrary combination of multi square beams. It can be applied to cash register printing or taxi printing in the future to achieve fast, fast, and small volume goals.

title: Heart Rate Detection System Based on ADS1292 Module
authors: Jingquan Hong, Bowen Hao, Huaicheng He, Chen Tang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: This study addresses the high cost of commercially available heart rate monitoring devices by designing a low-cost detection system capable of real-time electrocardiogram (ECG) visualization. The system utilizes the ADS1292 module with electrode patches to acquire ECG signals from the human body. The raw signals are processed using a combination of IIR and median filtering, and heart rate is calculated based on RR interval analysis. The processed data is transmitted via a serial port and displayed in real time using VOFA software. Test results demonstrate excellent filtering performance and real-time capability, indicating strong potential for industrial application. Future work may involve integrating high-performance microprocessors to further enhance system performance.

title: A fault diagnosis method for pressure sensors based on isolation forest and linear regression
authors: Danfu Cao, Fuxiao Xu, Ce Han
publish: 2025 4th International Symposium on Sensor Technology and Control (ISSTC)
abstract: The first challenge in fault prediction for pressure transmitters lies in the fact that fault samples are extremely scarce in industrial settings, making some commonly used supervised algorithms inapplicable. The second challenge is that, as a measurement component of an overall system, the observed data dimension of pressure transmitters is very limited. In most cases, the only available data point is the pressure value returned by the transmitter itself, which serves as the starting point and data basis for fault prediction. Given these two challenges, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method for pressure transmitters based on Isolation Forest and Linear Regression, capable of detecting specific types of faults. This method utilizes the unsupervised Isolation Forest algorithm as its foundation, enabling fault prediction without the need for training on fault data. With the aid of univariate linear regression as a supplementary approach, interference from special cases can be filtered out, thereby achieving the goal of fault prediction using one-dimensional fault-free samples.

title: Tifinagh Handwritten Word Recognition Using CNN Algorithm
authors: Laghzil Said, Niharmine Lahcen, Azouaoui Ahmed, Hadi Moulay Youssef
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: The recognition of handwritten Tifinagh words represents an unexplored research area, due to the similarities between character shapes and the rich morphology of this alphabet. To the best of our knowledge, no previous work has specifically addressed the automatic recognition of Tifinagh words. In this context, we propose the first approach based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for the identification of handwritten Tifinagh words. The experiments conducted achieved an accuracy rate exceeding 98.46% on a set of 65 distinct words from a database of 32,500 samples, while maintaining optimized execution time. These results highlight the promising performance of our method, which stands out for its accuracy and efficiency.

title: Feeder Power Disaggregation Using PMU and Smart Meter Data in Distribution Systems
authors: Chaowanan Jamroen, Dulpichet Rerkpreedapong, Sanchai Dechanupaprittha
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: Accurately profiling load and generation in distribution networks is critical for state estimation, operational efficiency, and infrastructure planning. This paper proposes a machine learning-based ensemble framework to disaggregate the power measured at a low-voltage radial feeder into residential baseline load, photovoltaic (PV) generation, and electric vehicle (EV) charging components, using limited measurement data. The framework utilizes active power data from a phasor measurement unit (PMU) at the transformer, a smart meter (SM) at a prosumer node, and meteorological data. An ensemble model comprising sub-models for PV, baseline, and EV components is trained using asynchronous and heterogeneous inputs. Simulations on a five-node test feeder over seven days demonstrate that the proposed approach effectively estimates disaggregated component profiles and accurately tracks the aggregate feeder power. This method offers a scalable and practical solution to enhancing observability in partially monitored distribution networks.

title: Data Allocation Rearrangement on CNN Accelerator Based on Reshaping Systolic Tile Array Using Planarized Matrix Reordering Techniques
authors: Hoseong Kim, Daejin Park
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Recently, demands and usages of artificial intelligence are growing more and more. The various of electrical computation devices, such as mobile devices, are being built with AI technology. But the AI operation's load is very heavy. The AI data processing method, usually a convolutional neural network, mainly consists of the matrix convolution and the matrix multiplication-actually, they are the same effective, depending on how the operation sequences are arranged. The matrix multiplication is not suited to sequential data processing. During matrix convolution or matrix multiplication, the memory access pattern is non-linear. This is difficult to use the parallelized data processing and, actually, the original sequential processor has limit hardware unit resources for parallelized data processing. Even in sequential processing, the non-linear access pattern needs a conditional branch test and jump instruction for address calculation. Eventually, these situations induce large power consumption and poor performance during AI operation. Therefore, it is necessary that the appropriate hardware-software system, that system is the matrix structure planarize to linear access and uses the parallel data processing based on MAC tile, is implemented for efficient AI algorithm computation. In this paper, a parallel data processing structure based on systolic tile array is used for fast operation time and efficient ALU resources usage in matrix multiplication. For enhanced data processing throughput, the proposed new accelerator is equipped with a heavier processing element-(PE) tile than the original systolic tile PE, making it possible to calculate the multi state partial sums at once. Reordering multidimensional matrix as a linear planarization matrix array is also proposed at the micro-architecture level for diminishing the nonlinear access address calculation. The accelerator's memory system enables multiple elements to commit and reduces the data access times to DRAM memory during operation. In conclusion, this proposal accelerator ends up performing AI CNN operations much faster, with low power consumption.

title: SpatialLLM: A Spatial Cloud Computing Assisted Large Language Model Analytical System for Spatial Big Data Analytics
authors: Rabindra K. Barik, Ankit Vidyarthi, Bhagyajit Pingua, Manob Jyoti Saikia, Meenakshi Kandpal, Priyanka Verma
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The advent of Large Language Models (LLMs) has revolutionized natural language processing by enabling advanced capabilities in question answering, summarization, and reasoning. Despite their success, the application of LLMs to specialized, data-scarce domains such as geospatial intelligence remains limited. This study presents a novel approach to adapting a state-of-the-art LLM, Qwen2.5-7B, for geospatial question answering using mineral resource data from the Alaska region. By transforming structured spatial datasets into instruction–question–answer format, the model is trained to interpret and respond to natural language queries related to mineral types, locations, and associated geographic metadata. To enable efficient training within limited computational resources, we employ QLoRA—a method combining 4-bit quantization with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)—allowing fine-tuning of the model with reduced memory requirements. The resulting model, SpatialLLM, demonstrates the feasibility of domain-specific adaptation in geospatial contexts, enabling interactive, language-based access to complex spatial data.

title: AgriCure: An AWS S3-Integrated Deep Learning Platform for Automated Crop Disease Detection
authors: V. Ananthakrishnan, Sounak Shome, Mohit Kumar, Suryakiran R, Tharaga Sharmilan, Gnana Swathika O V
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents AgriCure, a novel platform combining Amazon Web Services (AWS) Simple Storage Service (S3) with MobileNet deep learning model for crop disease detection over cloud. The system enables the farmers and agriculture specialists to upload cropped images using a web-based interactive interface and images are saved in AWS S3 for quick access and analysis. Due to the lightweight building blocks of MobileNet Architecture, the system is able to determine whether the crops are infected or not within a very short time. The conducted research ensures that the classification yields 92.5 % accurate results within an average of 150 milliseconds for every images processed which makes it fit for real time applications. Also, S3 Cloud's resources made the system affordable and efficient in managing data. Due to the level of protection offered, it has provided a safe environment for users. It is therefore a very effective and easy to use strategy for current farming practices as it resolves issues such as disease tracking, growth and cost. In the next steps, the focus will be on increasing the range of capabilities of the model developed and tuning the system for greater usage.

title: Fine-Tuning and Optimizing Lightweight LLMs for Domain-Specific Use Cases
authors: Tapan Kumar Das, Ayan Biswas
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This research presents the development and optimization of a lightweight transformer model tailored for deployment on consumer-grade hardware with limited computational resources. The study aims to address the challenges associated with running large-scale language models on home computers by integrating advanced optimization techniques, including quantization, pruning, and knowledge distillation. These methods are used to reduce the size of the model, improve efficiency, a nd maintain performance while minimizing computational overhead. The proposed methodology includes model design, dataset preprocessing, training optimization, and performance evaluation. The model is fine-tuned on a research paper metadata dataset, ensuring its relevance for academic and research-oriented applications. The implementation is validated on an NVIDIA RTX 4050 (6GB VRAM), with performance metrics that evaluate inference speed, memory utilization, and accuracy trade-offs. By demonstrating an effective balance between computational efficiency and model performance, this research contributes to the broader objective of democratizing transformer-based NLP models for low-resource environments. The findings underscore the feasibility of deploying advanced AI models on consumer-grade hardware, facilitating offline processing, and reducing the dependency on cloud-based infrastructures.

title: Fabrication of 1200V800A Power module used of SiC trench MOSFETs
authors: Shiyan Li, Fengbin Hao, Yang Yang, Yue Zhang, Xiaolei Yang, Runhua Huang, Song Bai
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: SiC MOSFETs are emerging as a promising candidate for power switching applications owing to higher operating temperatures, higher switching frequency and lower specific on-resistance. Compared to the Planar MOSFET, the trench MOSFET allows a more compact cell design with a higher channel density. In this paper, a $1200 \mathrm{~V} / 800 \mathrm{~A} \mathrm{SiC}$ power MOSFET module is reported using the 1200 V SiC trench MOSFET chip independently developed by our research group. A same design of planar SiC MOSFET based modules was chosen, and the Static performance and Switching behavior was compared with the trench SiC MOSFET based module. The trench MOSFET power module shows obvious advantages in terms of on-resistance, threshold voltage, low gate voltage output and turn-on current overshoots. This advanced module performance demonstrates the ability of using 1200 V 800 A trench SiC MOSFET power modules in new energy vehicles.

title: Robust Retinal Vessel Segmentation in Noisy Fundus Images Using Deep Learning-Based UNet Variants
authors: Ekram ul Haque, Imtiyaz Ahmad, Vibhav Prakash Singh
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of retinal blood vessels is crucial for automated detection of diabetic retinopathy (DR), a leading cause of vision impairment worldwide. Although UNet and its variants are widely used for medical image segmentation, their comparative robustness under noisy image conditions remains underexplored. This study systematically evaluates five deep learning-based UNet architectures—UNet, Dense UNet, Attention UNet, Inception UNet, and Residual UNet—using three benchmark retinal image datasets. A uniform preprocessing and augmentation pipeline is applied, and all models are optimized using the Dice loss function with the Adam optimizer. Also, to simulate real-world imaging challenges and assess the noise resilience of these models, salt-and-pepper and Gaussian noise are artificially introduced. The architectures are benchmarked across multiple metrics, including accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, Dice coefficient, and Intersection over Union (IoU). Among the variants, Attention UNet consistently achieved superior performance, particularly in highlighting fine vascular structures and managing inter-image variability. These findings demonstrate that UNet-based deep learning models, especially those incorporating attention mechanisms, provide a robust and scalable approach for retinal blood vessel segmentation.

title: Investigating the Effect of Solar Irradiance and Solar PV Output on the Production of Green Hydrogen
authors: Saboor. S, Vigneshwaran P, Joel Ashirvadam. K, Satheesh. A, Natarajan M, Sreekanth. U
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Hydrogen, as a clean and renewable energy source, has potential applications in various sectors, including power generation, transportation, and industry. However, the production of hydrogen is not without its challenges, which include high costs, low efficiency, and environmental impacts. The focus of this project is to examine the effects of variable voltage on a solar-powered electrolyser aimed at photovoltaic hydrogen production. This study intends to clarify how variations in solar intensity impact solar PV output voltage and electrolyser's hydrogen production. The results show that insufficient driving force and activation overpotential limitations slow down hydrogen production at solar PV output voltages under 2.5 V. However, solar PV voltages over this threshold significantly enhance hydrogen evolution, with optimal analysis occurring between 5 V and 6 V. It is also observed that the hydrogen collection was maximum at higher solar PV output voltages in comparison with lower voltages. The results are helpful to understand how green hydrogen production takes place at lower intensity of solar irradiance and solar PV.

title: Robbit: A User-Friendly and Two-Wheeled Self-Balancing Robot Using an FPGA
authors: Daichi Kumagai, Komei Kodera, Yuya Iwata, Kenji Kise
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: A two-wheeled self-balancing robot or TW-SBR is an automatically operated machine that stands on two wheels. The simple structured TW-SBRs are used as educational material in control engineering. In this paper, we propose an affordable and user-friendly TW-SBR using an FPGA named robbit to promote the adoption of robots and contribute to FPGA education and research. By using a low-end FPGA board and inexpensive and commercially available parts, we lower the barrier of hardware costs, and by leveraging a framework for FPGA development named CFU proving ground, we reduce the technical hurdles. We detail the design and implementation of robbit. Furthermore, through a quantitative comparison with a TW-SBR utilizing the ESP32-C3 microcontroller board, we demonstrate the stability and utility of robbit. Additionally, we show the effectiveness of robbit by showing a discussion of hardware costs, assembly time, and applications of robbit.

title: Efficient Task Offloading in LEO Satellite Edge Networks: A Diffusion-Based DRL Approach
authors: Zhenmou Liu, Changhao Li, Chuanfu Zhang, Zongfu Luo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) based on Low Earth Orbit satellites are drawing increasing attention. They can meet diverse future application requirements, such as anytime connection, low latency, and high immersion. By applying satellite edge computing (SEC) technologies, computation tasks can be distributed and offloaded to improve user quality of service (QoS) and also enhance network resource utilization. However, compared with conventional terrestrial networks, NTNs exhibit greater complexity and dynamics, which substantially complicates offloading decision-making in SEC. To achieve more efficient computation offloading in SEC, we first formulate the interactions among satellite nodes as a Stackelberg game, thereby incentivizing nodes to participate in offloading. Considering factors such as energy consumption and offloading process, the utility function is established for the participants. Then, the backward induction method is used to prove the existence of the unique equilibrium for the game. Finally, we propose a deep reinforcement learning algorithm based on generative stable diffusion models to compute the Stackelberg equilibrium. Numerical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: GAETOPTICS: Graph AutoEncoder with Tuned-OPTICS for effective Community Detection
authors: Shivali Tyagi, Sakshi Gupta
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Community detection in social networks is highly influenced by the noise, outliers, and choice of clustering parameter tuning methods. Graph autoencoder (GAE) models and their variants have been developed for community detection in the last few years which resolved the noise and clustering parameter tuning issues. However, the performance of these models is not significant. Hence, in this work, a new approach, GAETOPTICS, is presented. It combines the enhanced GAE model and tuned-OPTICS density-based clustering for detecting more accurate communities in the network. GAETOPTICS approach uses three significant advances to improve clustering accuracy: (1) enhancing the GAE architecture to capture deeper networks in complicated systems and avoid overfitting; (2) including a clustering-specific loss to directly optimize the embeddings for clustering and achieve a balance between community preservation and rebuilding; (3) tuning the OPTICS clustering parameters to maintain significant clusters while further lowering noise while using agglomerative clustering to reconstruct the communities. Performance of the proposed model GAETOPTICS is evaluated using normalized mutual information evaluation metrics with respect to the four other baseline algorithms, i.e., Louvain, Label Propagation, GAE with DBSCAN and GAE with KMean. The experimental results show that the GAETOPTICS community detection approach is scalable and data-driven, which makes it appropriate for intricate and large-scale networks.

title: COPA: Cost and Performance Aware Traffic Engineering Framework in Multicloud SD-WAN
authors: Venkateshwaran Dorai
publish: 2025 IEEE 18th International Symposium on Embedded Multicore/Many-core Systems-on-Chip (MCSoC)
abstract: Businesses are increasingly using hybrid multi-cloud architectures, which divide workloads among public clouds (e.g., AWS, Azure, OCI, GCP) and branch offices. Despite being the industry standard for connectivity management, Software-Defined Wide Area Networking (SD-WAN) primarily optimizes for metrics like jitter and latency through its traffic engineering methods. This method ignores a significant and erratic operational expense: cloud data egress fees, which can account for 10 - 15% of the overall cloud bill and increase nonlinearly as user adoption and new features increase [1]. We introduce COPA (Cost-Optimized Path Aware), a novel SD-WAN framework that integrates both performance metrics and actual cloud egress costs into its routing decisions. COPA uses an adjustable multi-objective utility function to balance path latency and egress cost. COPA's application-aware policy engine is its key component. Through the use of specific Performance-Cost weights (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha, \beta$</tex>) and traffic classification (e.g., latency-sensitive VoIP vs. cost-sensitive bulk data transfer), the architecture ensures that network path selection aligns with both application-level Service-Level Objectives (SLOs) and overall financial constraints. In our simulation, we show that COPA can lower egress costs by over 66 % compared to a performance-only routing scheme while maintaining a high weighted average SLO compliance of 93.7 %. Our findings provide a useful tool for businesses to control multi-cloud networking expenses without sacrificing user experience by quantifying the trade-off area between cost savings and performance.

title: Revisiting Systems Principles for the Era of Generative AI
authors: Antti Oulasvirta, Björn Hartmann
publish: Computer
abstract: Embracing a systems perspective on generative artificial intelligence (AI) would help users make more out of its capabilities. We discuss implications to five systems principles at the intersection of user-centered and AI-focused research.

title: Neural Network-Driven Simulated Annealing for Trust-Persuasion Optimized Influence Maximization
authors: Kirti Aggarwal
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: An innovative methodology for maximizing the influence in trust-persuasion network by integrating simulated annealing algorithm with a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) regressor is introduced in this paper. The proposed algorithm known as Neural Network-Driven Simulated Annealing (NNDSA) makes use of the adaptive capabilities of the simulated annealing algorithm, guided by realization from a trained MLP regressor to find the optimized seed set. By including the trust, persuasion, and opinion factors, NNDSA embodies the diverse aspects of influence propagation. Here trust determines information credibility, persuasion determines message impact and the opinion aspect models the growing beliefs of peoples in the network. Experiments are performed on two datasets: Bitcoin and Advogato, where the NNDSA algorithm with MLP regressor outperforms the one with- out MLP regressor and achieves higher influence propagation, while maintain the attractive execution time. The proposed algorithm with MLP regressor achieves average influence spread of 592.2 on the Bitcoin dataset and 991.2 on the Advogato dataset, outperforming the influence spread achieved without MLP regressor by 36.6 and 6.6 respectively. These finding reflects the potential of NNDSA technique with MLP regressor for the advancement of influence maximization strategies.

title: Big Data-Driven Sentiment and Topic Extraction in Indonesian E-Government Applications
authors: Endah Purwanti, Nabillah Deris Zulaeka, Nabillah Deris Zulaeka, Nabillah Deris Zulaeka
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: This paper presents a big data-driven approach to sentiment classification and topic extraction from user reviews of three major Indonesian e-Government applications: Identitas Kependudukan Digital (IKD), SAMSAT Digital Nasional (SIGNAL), and M-Paspor. The research supports the development of transparent, user-centered, and accountable digital public services, aligning with SDGs 9 (Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure). User-generated review data was collected from the Google Play Store and processed using natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning techniques. The preprocessing steps included text cleaning, case folding, tokenization, normalization, and a comparative evaluation of stemming effectiveness. Sentiment labeling was conducted using the VADER lexicon, while classification was performed with the XGBoost algorithm. Two preprocessing variants-stemming and non-stemmingwere evaluated to determine their impact on model performance. The results show that stemming improved classification accuracy by reducing lexical variation. The bestperforming models achieved accuracies of 80.84 % (IKD), 89.48% (SIGNAL), and 73.70% (M-Paspor), respectively. Subsequently, Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) was employed to extract key discussion topics from the most accurate sentiment classification pipeline. Identified aspects included reliability, interaction capability, functional suitability, and performance efficiency. These findings highlight the effectiveness of big data techniques in extracting actionable insights from large-scale user feedback, supporting data-informed improvements in public digital services.

title: Gesture-Talk: Sign Language to Text and Speech Translator
authors: S. Madhumita, R. Mounika, S. Vijayalakshmi, K.R. Kavitha
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: Sign language serves as a crucial communication medium for individuals with hearing impairment. The learning process and broader implementation of Indian Sign Language (ISL) encounter difficulties because of various regional dialects and limited resources. This paper proposes a cost-effective and real-time Dynamic Sign Language (DSL) recognition system leveraging Google's MediaPipe framework for hand landmark detection, coupled with a TensorFlow-based supervised learning model for classification. The system utilizes readily accessible webcams, thereby eliminating dependency on expensive sensor gloves and depth cameras, enhancing portability and scalability. A custom DSL10 dataset was created, encompassing diverse signers and regional variations, with the model trained and evaluated using four-fold cross-validation on distinct participant groups for robustness. The proposed lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) achieves an accuracy of 92.7%, processing real-time video at 22-27 frames per second without requiring internet connectivity or high-end hardware. The project advances inclusive communication technologies by developing an accessible offline method to connect hearing and non-hearing communities. The system provides real-time operation at an affordable price point which makes it adaptable for various environmental settings and broad user accessibility.

title: Present-Worth Analysis of a Hybrid PV-Diesel, Wsan-Enabled Energy-Efficient Power System for Remote Farms
authors: Abdel-Rahman Al-Qawasmi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES GTD Grand International Conference and Exposition Asia (GTD Asia)
abstract: This paper uses an engineering-economic present-worth (PW) framework to compare two off-grid farm energy options: (A) diesel generation with diesel irrigation pumps and no efficiency control, and (B) a hybrid solar-diesel system with electric pumps and a wireless sensor-actuator network (WSAN)-based energy management. Using a 10 -year project lifespan and a 10 % interest rate, we parameterize loads (HVAC, lighting, irrigation) and equipment (a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-\text{kW}$</tex> generator, approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13.4-\text{kW} \text{PV}$</tex>, and pumps) based on typical operating conditions. PW models include initial and future (salvage) costs, fuel consumption, and annual maintenance. Sensitivity analyses examine interest rates (520 %) and project durations (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5-15$</tex> years). Results show that the hybrid option reduces the present cost by roughly <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$48-52 \%$</tex> compared to the diesel-only baseline and decreases fuel consumption by about 40 %, with these benefits remaining consistent across most tested ranges; break-even points only shift beyond roughly 18 % interest rates. The findings support prioritizing PV-diesel hybrids with demand-side management for remote farms, offering transparent, transferable formulas and default parameters that practitioners can adapt or customize for other climates. Limitations and data needs are also discussed. This paper now explicitly summarizes the modeling workflow and key sensitivity bounds to clarify how the presented results are generated.

title: AoI Violation Constrained Control Cost Optimization for Delay-Sensitive Industrial IoT
authors: Jiawei Su, Zhixin Liu, Yaping Li, Yazhou Yuan, Kai Ma
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Dear Editor, The industrial internet of things (IIoT) integrates communications and controls into a cohesive system within the framework of Industry 5.0, where time delay critically impairs system performance. Especially, the introduction of wireless networks results in more severe induced delays than wired networks, owing to the greater complexity of factors affecting reliable state updates. From the perspective of control requirements, the state update process depends on the successful rate and real-time performance of information transmission. A low successful transmission rate causes data backlog and delays state updates, while a high rate reduces delay but requires more communication resources. Nevertheless, the control center must rely on previously updated state information before the next sampling period. Therefore, simply increasing the transmission rate may not necessarily enhance long-term system performance.

title: Performance Evaluation of MQTT and ZeroMQ Messaging Protocols for UAV Applications
authors: Yufei Liu, Noor Ahmed
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) increasingly rely on machine learning (ML) for tasks such as environmental monitoring and disaster response, requiring efficient communication protocols to support real-time data exchange. This paper evaluates MQTT and ZeroMQ — two widely used messaging protocols — in UAV-based networks running data-intensive ML applications. We develop a UAV communication framework, dubbed MQLink, and analyze key performance metrics including transmission time, error rate, and CPU usage. A prototype of MQLink is developed and deployed on Raspberry Pi devices to demonstrate the system's effectiveness. Experimental results reveal how workloads of different sizes affect protocol performance, highlighting trade-offs in reliability, latency, and resource consumption. These findings provide valuable insights for selecting the most suitable protocol for UAV applications based on computational workload and network conditions.

title: Multi-Game Fusion Lane-Changing Strategy in Mixed Traffic Flow
authors: Limin Guan, Yingguang Lv, Jiangang Gong, Yu Zhu, Jinyu Zhu, Yanan Zhao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: Autonomous lane-changing in mixed traffic flow presents diverse and challenging scenarios. These challenges often result in low lane-changing success rates and compromised safety, drawing significant attention from researchers in the field of autonomous driving. Focusing on mixed traffic flow scenarios where lane-changing is required, this study proposes a multi-game integrated lane-changing strategy based on dynamic-static games and cooperative-non-cooperative games. During the lane-change preparation phase, a utility-based model is used to select a suitable lane-change gap. The Model Predictive Control (MPC) algorithm then guides the vehicle to a pre-lane-change position smoothly and assesses the safety conditions. To handle various unsafe lane-changing scenarios, the proposed strategy fuses multiple game-theoretic models. This fusion enables the vehicle to adaptively select the most suitable game-theoretic method for the current scenario, thereby completing the maneuver. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed Multi-Game Fusion Lane-Changing Strategy significantly improves the lane-changing success rate compared to algorithms such as SL2015 and MOBIL. This improvement holds under various traffic volumes and penetration rates. Furthermore, during the lane-changing process, both the SV and surrounding vehicles exhibit minor fluctuations in velocity and acceleration, indicating good comfort. This process also has a minimal impact on the overall stability of the traffic flow.

title: Hierarchical Federated Learning for Crop Yield Prediction in Smart Agricultural Production Systems
authors: Anas Abouaomar, Mohammed El hanjri, Abdellatif Kobbane, Anis Laouiti, Khalid Nafil
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Wireless Networks and Mobile Communications (WINCOM)
abstract: In this paper, we presents a novel hierarchical federated learning architecture specifically designed for smart agricultural production systems and crop yield prediction. Our approach introduces a seasonal subscription mechanism where farms join crop-specific clusters at the beginning of each agricultural season. The proposed three-layer architecture consists of individual smart farms at the client level, crop-specific aggregators at the middle layer, and a global model aggregator at the top level. Within each crop cluster, clients collaboratively train specialized models tailored to specific crop types, which are then aggregated to produce a higher-level global model that integrates knowledge across multiple crops. This hierarchical design enables both local specialization for individual crop types and global generalization across diverse agricultural contexts while preserving data privacy and reducing communication overhead. Experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system, showing that local and crop-layer models closely follow actual yield patterns with consistent alignment, significantly outperforming standard machine learning models. The results validate the advantages of hierarchical federated learning in the agricultural context, particularly for scenarios involving heterogeneous farming environments and privacy-sensitive agricultural data.

title: LexiRoBERTa: Soft Ensemble Sentiment Classification with Lexicon-Augmented RoBERTa
authors: Pratyush Sharma, Seba Susan
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: Ensemble modeling offers a powerful approach to harness the strengths and diversity of multiple algorithms for a common classification task. Sentiment analysis, a type of text classification, has seen success with both supervised and unsupervised learning techniques. This paper introduces a novel weighted soft ensemble model, named LexiRoBERTa, designed to enhance interpretability and explainability. LexiRoBERTa combines the supervised RoBERTa transformer with the unsupervised lexicon-based models—VADER, Afinn, and TextBlob—for sentiment analysis of customer product reviews. The proposed hybrid framework enhances the quantitative sentiment classification accuracy by integrating predictions from both supervised and unsupervised systems through a soft voting mechanism, and also enhances interpretability by tracing sentiment outputs to human-readable lexical rules. The model is evaluated on the benchmark Amazon product reviews dataset using a comprehensive set of performance metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, specificity, F1-score, Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), Index of Balanced Accuracy (IBA), and G-mean. Results show a significant improvement in sentiment analysis performance when combining lexicon-based approaches with RoBERTa, outperforming individual models and other BERT-based models such as BERT, DistilBERT, and ALBERT.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for UAV Indoor Navigation Through Task Decomposition
authors: Lu Ren, Zelong Fang, Wenzhang Liu, Chaoxu Mu, Changyin Sun
publish: IEEE/CAA Journal of Automatica Sinica
abstract: Dear Editor, This letter addresses the challenges of sparse and delayed rewards in complex indoor navigation tasks. To this end, we propose a task decomposition-based reinforcement learning framework that integrates a reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm with a path planner. Specifically, the rapidly-exploring random tree star (RRT*) algorithm is employed to generate a sequence of sub-goals, which are incorporated into the state space. This decomposition transforms the original long-horizon task into a series of easier sub-tasks with reward monotonicity, providing valuable spatial priors for the unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and guiding it toward more effective exploration. As a result, the proposed method enhances learning stability and mitigates the negative effects of sparse and delayed rewards, facilitating the learning of an optimal navigation policy. Our source code is available at https://github.com/AHU-QXY/indoor_drone_navigation.

title: Distributionally Robust Scheduling Method for Islanded Microgrids Considering Frequency Security
authors: Jiale Gao, Danyang Xu, Zhigang Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The frequency security of islanded microgrids is addressed through a distributionally robust scheduling method that optimizes heterogeneous frequency regulation resources, including generation sources, storage systems, and loads. A linear approximation model for frequency regulation power is developed by considering differences in response rates and dead zones. Frequency constraints under coordinated regulation are established and incorporated into the microgrid scheduling model. Wind power uncertainty is described using a moment-based ellipsoidal uncertainty set, and joint chance constraints are formulated to limit wind power output and frequency regulation reserves. Auxiliary variables are introduced to transform the joint chance constraints into individual chance constraints. Non-convex individual chance constraints are further converted by accounting for distribution unimodality. Bilinear terms are convexified using the McCormick envelope, reformulating the model into a mixedinteger second-order cone programming problem. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed method ensures the frequency of the islanded microgrid remains above 49.2 Hz following active power disturbances. The inclusion of frequency support from demand-side resources improves operational economics.

title: Core Technology Review of Sichuan Huadian Neijiang Baima Heavy-Duty Peaking Gas Turbine Project
authors: Guiquan Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: The Sichuan Huadian Neijiang Baima <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 475-\text{MW}$</tex> Gas Turbine Innovation and Development Demonstration Project (hereinafter referred to as the “Baima Project”), as one of China's first batch of gas turbine innovation demonstration projects, utilizes M701F4 heavy-duty gas turbine technology to focus on high-efficiency clean power generation and grid peaking capability enhancement. This paper examines the project's technical architecture, core equipment innovations, intelligent control systems, environmental protection and energy-saving designs, and localization practices. Engineering data are analyzed to highlight technological breakthroughs in combustion efficiency optimization, waste heat cascade utilization, intelligent inspection systems, and high-temperature component manufacturing. The project's demonstrative value in enhancing regional energy security and advancing heavy-duty gas turbine localization is substantiated. Research indicates that through technology introduction and independent innovation, the project achieved key performance indicators including a combined cycle efficiency of 59.95 % and NOx emissions <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leqslant 20 \text{mg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}$</tex>, providing critical insights for China's heavy-duty gas turbine technological advancement.

title: A Machine Learning Approach for Real-Time Gait Analysis
authors: Ankan Ghosh, Sumaiya Afroz Mila, Zongwei Zhen, Cong Chen, Swarup Bhunia, Sandip Ray
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Clinical gait analysis is a non-invasive method used to identify abnormalities in human walking patterns. Traditional approaches rely on expensive and complex systems such as force plates, EMG, and motion capture, limiting their use to specialized clinical settings. In this paper, we develop a method for gait analysis that continuously monitor gait through wearables using a stick-and-peel form factor called pasteables, and a machine learning framework to support analysis of sensory data from pasteables for detecting abnormalities. We propose a methodology for designing such a pasteable device that makes use of available gait dataset to identify various monitoring parameters while obviating upfront user studies for parameter exploration and tuning. We apply the method in the design of a pasteable for detecting gait abnormalities through plantar pressure monitoring.

title: A Unified Framework for AR Indoor Navigation and Conversational Information Retrieval in Smart Campus Environments
authors: Ahmed Magdy, Ahmed Mohamed, Amr Ali Boghdady, Basily Achraf, Hassan Mohamed, Ziad Abd-El-Hamid, Samar Ali, Islam Hegazy
publish: 2025 Twelfth International Conference on Intelligent Computing and Information Systems (ICICIS)
abstract: Navigating complex indoor environments like university campuses poses a significant challenge, compounded by the difficulty of accessing specific institutional information. While vision-based Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) offers continuous tracking, it suffers from cumulative drift. Sim- ilarly, standard Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems for question-answering are prone to context collision. This paper presents a unified mobile application that integrates a robust AR indoor navigation module with an intelligent conversational assistant to address both challenges simultaneously. The pro- posed navigation system fuses the continuous motion tracking of SLAM with high-precision QR code markers for drift correction, providing accurate, real-time visual guidance. For information retrieval, a novel RAG architecture is proposed featuring an LLM-powered router that intelligently directs user queries to one of several specialized vector stores, effectively eliminating con- text collision and improving contextual accuracy. Experimental results confirm that the navigation module provides robust and accurate visual guidance in real-world scenarios. Furthermore, the chatbot's router-based architecture demonstrates a marked improvement in retrieval accuracy, consistently identifying more relevant information than a standard RAG system. The proposed system demonstrates the feasibility of synergistically combining spatial computing with advanced conversational AI to create a comprehensive smart campus assistant, enhancing the student experience by providing seamless access to both physical and digital resources.

title: Synergy of Silicon Deposition, Sacrificial Oxidation, and Nitrogen Annealing for Interface Quality Optimization in 4H-SiC MOS
authors: Zhenyu Wang, Limin Yan, Hongping Ma
publish: 2025 22nd China International Forum on Solid State Lighting &amp; 2025 11th International Forum on Wide Bandgap Semiconductors (SSLCHINA: IFWS)
abstract: This study examines nitrogen annealing at $800^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 900^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, and $1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ on 4 H -SiC MOS structures prepared by silicon deposition and sacrificial oxidation. Increasing annealing temperature markedly improves interface quality: $1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ samples show steeper CV depletion, reduced frequency dispersion, and near-ideal behavior. The effective negative oxide charge decreases with temperature, consistent with enhanced nitrogen diffusion and passivation in SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. High-temperature annealing lowers interface states near the conduction band, with near-interface trap density at $1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ about $50 \%$ lower than at $800^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, due to nitrogen bonding with sub-oxides that shifts defect levels deeper in the bandgap. AFM reveals smoother, denser, and more uniform SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> at $1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Overall, nitrogen annealing-especially at $1000^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ clarifies the link among interface defects, temperature, and trap behavior, and significantly improves electrical performance and interface quality.

title: From Industrial to Sports Activity Classification via AI of Things Knowledge Adaptation
authors: Nazia Akter, Andreea Molnar, Dimitrios Georgakopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Smart Internet of Things (SmartIoT)
abstract: Knowledge adaptation for human activity recognition (HAR) allows activity recognition models trained with data from one source domain to be adopted so they can be (re)used effectively in other target domains. Such recognition generalization is important because it reduces the cost and effort required to develop and manage multiple activity recognition models, each limited to a specific domain. Related work on knowledge adaptation is in early stages as it is currently limited to the recognition of generic activities like walking, running, or standing, and related data is usually collected in controlled environments lacking complexity and variability found in real-world settings. This paper proposes a novel AI of Things (AIoT) knowledge adaptation solution that combines full-body wearable sensors for collecting HAR data from real-world environments with an AI-based ensemble (referred to as ADAPT-X) that adapts activity recognition models for use across multiple target domains. ADPAT-X combines Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) with Machine Learning (ML) models, and unlike existing approaches, it performs cross-domain HAR of complex activities in real-world settings. The paper presents an evaluation of ADAPT-X with five real-world datasets collected from 11 activities in sports and industrial production settings, where ADAPT-X achieves 76%–84% accuracy in HAR across target domains.

title: Leakage Inductance Calculation for Three-Winding Transformer in Fully Isolated Series Resonant Threeport Converters
authors: Yiwen Duan, Yugang Yang, Wenjie Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Electrical Engineering and Technology (AEET)
abstract: Multi-port DC-DC converters represent a critical technology in DC micro-grids of modern power systems. The leakage inductance on the output side of the high-frequency transformer in multi-port DC converters can cause the resonant slot currents of other ports to couple, affecting the power transfer of the converter. Accurately estimating the leakage inductance of a three-winding transformer is crucial for optimizing the design and performance of the converter. This paper focuses on the fully isolated series resonant three-port converter and provides detailed design steps for the threewinding transformer and two methods for calculating the leakage inductance of the three-port transformer. The design of the three-winding transformer is optimized to reduce the leakage inductance on the output-side branch. Three-dimensional finite element simulations are used to calculate the leakage inductance of each port under different winding arrangements and winding methods. Both simulation and experimental validation are carried out.

title: Conceptual Modelling of the Cultural Heritage Workflows: Digital Representation of Abandoned Buildings in the City of Piraeus
authors: Filio Patoura, Dimitrios Kotsifakos, Christos Douligeris
publish: 2025 20th International Workshop on Semantic and Social Media Adaptation and Personalization (SMAP)
abstract: This research focuses on conceptual modelling of the cultural heritage workflows for documenting abandoned buildings in Piraeus. The basic thesis of the paper is that digital cultural documentation, when structured through formal modelling methods such as Unified Modeling Language, can serve as a sustainable framework for preserving and interpreting urban heritage. The paper begins with introductory elements on the meaning and importance of documenting abandoned buildings as part of a city’s tangible and intangible cultural identity. Through the text, we analyze how cultural heritage data is organized and represented in conceptual and technical models. Then, we focus on the relationships between buildings, users, and digital tools—such as My Google Maps, ArcGIS StoryMaps, and Artsteps—and how these interactions form coherent workflows for cultural preservation. Finally, we demonstrate how the Unified Modeling Language provides a clear and systematic representation of the documentation process, ensuring that digital heritage projects can be replicated, maintained, and expanded, thereby enabling continuity and public accessibility in the digital era.

title: From NFTs to NFDs: A Non-Fungible Data Digital Decentralized Certification method based on Intelligent Eco Networking
authors: Ziwei Yan, Qiankang Xu, Peng Xiangli, Jingjing Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Engineering and Intelligent Control (ICCEIC)
abstract: To effectively support and manage Named Data Networking (NDN), this paper designs and implements an NFD-oriented storage system. Building upon the Intelligent Eco Networking (IEN) framework that unifies blockchain trust anchors with NDN's data plane, proposed by Peking University's research team, which integrates blockchain and distributed AI with NDN, the proposed Non-Fungible Data (NFD) mechanism implements IEN's tri-layer convergence paradigm which effectively operationalizes its vision through fully leveraging the advantages of NDN's named routing and in-network caching mechanisms. By introducing the Raft consensus protocol, it ensures metadata consistency and fault tolerance. Additionally, innovative optimizations are made in resource scheduling, where an improved auction protocol is designed and implemented to enhance resource allocation efficiency in decentralized storage and data distribution processes. This solution not only effectively addresses the centralized risks and efficiency bottlenecks of traditional off-chain storage but also provides Non-Fungible Data (NFD) with a high-performance, highly available distributed storage environment, ensuring rapid data access and scalability to meet data asset management requirements.

title: Hybrid Consensus System for Traffic Signal Management Using Blockchain
authors: T. Vairam, S. Sarathambekai, A. Raamji, L. R. Tharun Srikanth, K. Vishal
publish: 2025 Innovations in Power and Advanced Computing Technologies (i-PACT)
abstract: Conventional traffic light systems typically depend on centralized data management, which comes with several limitations, such as scalability, security vulnerabilities, and the risk of a single point of failure. To overcome these issues, decentralized technologies like blockchain have emerged as a promising solution for enhancing the security, transparency, and scalability of traffic signal data management. This paper presents a blockchain-powered system tailored for traffic management, emphasizing the role of consensus algorithm which combines the functionalities of PoW and PoS to strengthen data integrity and security. The proposed framework adopts a decentralized approach to traffic data management, ensuring that only authorized entities can access and exchange information. The objective of this work is to develop a secure authentication mechanism leveraging blockchain technology to enable real-time, trustworthy traffic data sharing while mitigating potential security threats. This study creates a robust model for smart city traffic management by protecting against threats including Sybil assaults and hash power manipulation.

title: A Review on Torque Ripple Minimization Techniques in a Switched Reluctance Motor (SRM) for EV Applications
authors: Divya R, Sundaram M
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Intelligent Technologies for Sustainable Electric and Communications Systems (iTech SECOM)
abstract: The strategies for reducing torque ripples in switched reluctance motors, or SRMs, are examined in this review paper. Because of their doubly salient structure, nonlinear magnetic properties, and discrete commutation, SRMs display torque ripple. This torque ripple can cause vibrations, acoustic noise, and a decrease in efficiency. They are not as appropriate for some applications because of these effects. They are unable to function well in high-performance industrial systems or in systems like electric cars. Motor design improvements, current profiling techniques, advanced converter topologies, and smart control strategies such as fuzzy logic and sliding mode control are various methods reported in the literature for minimizing torque ripple. Key findings that are from existing research are summarized along with a thorough study that is of these methodologies. Particularly for emerging applications like electric mobility and renewable energy systems, improving the performance of SRM drives is the primary practical reference.

title: Dynamic Resource Allocation and Management in SDN for Multi-Service Network
authors: Fernando U. S. K, Pieris M. H. N, Abhayathunge H. I, Athapattu A. R. B. L, Uditha Dharmakeerthi, Amila Senarathne
publish: 2025 Seventeenth International Conference on Contemporary Computing (IC3)
abstract: The increase in network traffic due to technological advancements has led to considerable network congestion, complicating manual network management. Software Defined Networking (SDN) addresses these limitations by decoupling the control plane from the data plane, thereby facilitating centralized and programmable network management. This study introduces a novel dynamic resource allocation method utilizing the Ryu controller and Mininet to optimize traffic flow by identifying congestion-free channels based on critical network attributes such as link bandwidth utilization, latency, and packet loss. The proposed method comprises four principal components: traffic categorization, a dynamic queuing system, an advanced status collection module, and a path selection module. The Ryu controller's dynamic packet direction based on priority levels ensures efficient resource utilization and improved Quality of Service (QoS). Simulated traffic scenarios demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed algorithm, hence highlighting its ability to enhance network performance beyond traditional static routing methods.

title: The t -designs and the subcode support weight distributions of r -GMDS codes
authors: Xu Pan, Hongwei Liu, Jun Zhang, Xueyan Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: The Assmus-Mattson Theorem is a famous and effective way to construct t-designs from supports of codewords of a linear code. By extending this idea, we study the t-designs constructed from supports of subcodes of linear codes. In this paper, we introduce the notion of r-generalized maximum distance separable codes (r-GMDS codes) and determine the t-designs constructed from supports of subcodes of a r-GMDS code. Also, we show that t-designs can be constructed from supports of subcodes of a linear code if the automorphism group of this linear code is t-transitive. In particular, we prove that t-designs can be constructed from supports of subcodes of Reed-Muller codes. Then we show that the number of blocks in the t-design constructed from supports of subcodes of a linear code is related to the subcode support weight distributions of this linear code. Next, we provide some new formulas for the subcode support weight distributions of r-GMDS codes. After we present a connection between l-MDS codes and r-GMDS codes, some new formulas are obtained for the subcode support weight distributions of l-MDS codes. In particular, we completely determine the subcode support weight distributions of maximum distance separable (MDS) codes and near maximum distance separable (NMDS) codes. As an example, the subcode support weight distributions of the extended ternary Golay code are completely determined.

title: Consensus Capacity of Noisy Broadcast Channels
authors: Neha Sangwan, Varun Narayanan, Vinod M. Prabhakaran
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: We study communication with consensus over a broadcast channel—the receivers reliably decode the sender’s message when the sender is honest, and their decoder outputs agree even if the sender acts maliciously. We characterize the broadcast channels which permit this Byzantine consensus and determine their capacity. We show that communication with consensus is possible only when the broadcast channel has embedded in it a natural “common channel” whose output both receivers can unambiguously determine from their own channel outputs. Interestingly, in general, the consensus capacity may be larger than the point-to-point capacity of the common channel, i.e., while decoding, the receivers may make use of parts of their output signals on which they may not have consensus provided there are some parts (namely, the common channel output) on which they can agree.
